./Comments.xml:1785:  <row Id="1933" PostId="697" Score="2" Text="I think [open-problem] is exactly for *wide open questions* which are known to be so in the literature (or questions which are equivalent to them). MO's FAQ about open-problem is [here](https://mathoverflow.net/faq#openproblems). Note that we already have a page for [unanswered questions](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/unanswered)." CreationDate="2010-11-29T05:32:56.223" UserId="186" />
./Comments.xml:2781:  <row Id="3064" PostId="1003" Score="0" Text="MO uses [computability-theory](https://mathoverflow.net/questions/tagged/computability-theory) tag and most of its questions also have the [lo.logic] tag. This works well on MO because such questions are mainly classical recursion theory questions. On the other hand I don't like following a similar approach on cstheory, since these questions are not logic questions (as long as you are not going to call half of TCS logic), some of them are more [fl.formal-lang] questions, some of them are not. So I like the way things work now and to keep [computability] top level to other proposed options." CreationDate="2011-02-23T06:41:48.323" UserId="186" />

./Comments.xml:5665:  <row Id="8361" PostId="2894" Score="1" Text="In TCS we often take efficient parallel algorithm to mean something like NC while efficient sequential as P (and with that any efficient parallel algorithm is automatically a efficient sequential algorithm and but efficient parallel algorithms can be exponentially faster to the best of our knowledge). For more information see the book &quot;[Limits of Parallel Computation](https://homes.cs.washington.edu/~ruzzo/papers/limits.pdf)&quot;. If you mean something well-defined but different edit your question to explain what you mean clearly with mathematical rigor." CreationDate="2015-02-26T07:17:04.067" UserId="186" />

./PostHistory.xml:1487:  <row Id="1578" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="647" RevisionGUID="f46e632f-3209-4c10-847b-12dfa8928622" CreationDate="2010-11-11T20:22:21.040" UserId="567" Text="(Part of this answer had been previously posted as a comment, but I decided to move it to an answer with additional information about user scripts.)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The same issue has been raised also on meta.math.stackexchange.com: [TeX formatting in other comments in the same post is lost when the comment list is updated](http://meta.math.stackexchange.com/questions/397/tex-formatting-in-other-comments-in-the-same-post-is-lost-when-the-comment-list-i).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;On that page, [KennyTM posted a user script as a workaround](http://meta.math.stackexchange.com/questions/397/tex-formatting-in-other-comments-in-the-same-post-is-lost-when-the-comment-list-i/650#650) (great!).  I posted there a [modified version of it](http://meta.math.stackexchange.com/questions/397/tex-formatting-in-other-comments-in-the-same-post-is-lost-when-the-comment-list-i/1114#1114) which should be safer in principle in case *.stackexchange.com be cracked.  To use a user script with Firefox, you need the add-on [Greasemonkey](https://addons.mozilla.org/firefox/addon/748/)." />
./PostHistory.xml:2365:  <row Id="2528" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="1041" RevisionGUID="890b073b-a56a-434b-9551-df26891b1c20" CreationDate="2011-03-05T01:01:31.933" UserId="2517" Text="This isn't a direct answer to your question but I think this is also useful.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I use an android smartphone and use the app [Droidstack][1]. You can use it for every SE site not only TCS.SE. Currently it doesn't support MathJax. So if you want to read the questions with math support you have to open it in your browser (there is a button in this app to do this).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Additionally it checks your reputation score if you want to and notifies any changes. It isn't a full client. You can't post any questions/answers/comments. But if you only wan't to read the questions/answers/comments this is a great app.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Do anybody use some other apps (iphone/ipad or android)?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://market.android.com/details?id=org.droidstack" />

./PostHistory.xml:3523:  <row Id="3786" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1530" RevisionGUID="1ba1d914-47a5-4260-a3ba-69c7a67fcd6e" CreationDate="2012-06-03T18:45:07.777" UserId="186" Comment="added 737 characters in body" Text="Probably most have heard about this, but just in case someone has missed it, here is [a short post](https://plus.google.com/u/0/103703080789076472131/posts/DDA6tr8SDJ8) and [a longer post](http://poynder.blogspot.co.uk/2012/05/open-access-peoples-petition.html).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The petition itself is [here](https://wwws.whitehouse.gov/petitions#!/petition/require-free-access-over-internet-scientific-journal-articles-arising-taxpayer-funded-research/wDX82FLQ). You may want to check [the Access2Research site](http://access2research.org/) and [the Wikipedia article about it](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Access2Research).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Edit:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Here is a post on [Tim Gowers' blog][1] and an article in [The Guardian][2]. You don't need to be a US citizen to sign the petition and its effects will not be restricted to the US.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;It can be considered politics but it is an issue deeply related to the community. This post was intended to spread the information so others can also have a look at the petition and sign it in case they agree with it. It is not intended for discussion, arguing, nor convincing other about it. Blog posts like Gowers' are more appropriate for discussion.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://gowers.wordpress.com/2012/05/24/have-you-signed-the-open-access-petition/&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: http://www.guardian.co.uk/science/blog/2012/may/22/us-petition-open-access-publishing?fb=optOut" />

./PostHistory.xml:4645:  <row Id="7015" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="2935" RevisionGUID="121d3192-8791-4d73-b148-ca1237ec19f7" CreationDate="2016-02-17T22:43:48.960" UserId="37732" Text="[![Auto-Latex Equations add-on for Google Docs][1]][2]&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://i.imgur.com/H8e7Cyi.png&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/auto-latex-equations/iaainhiejkciadlhlodaajgbffkebdog?utm_source=cstheorySOAd&#xD;&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:4687:  <row Id="7061" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="2950" RevisionGUID="8b3855bd-4c81-4e5c-a3e0-beb9f6de2b42" CreationDate="2016-07-01T18:13:16.643" UserId="4795" Text="When I ask questions of the form &quot;what is the complexity of problem BLAH&quot;, then there is an ambiguity (to me) about whether an accepted answer should simply give the best known bounds according to current literature, or whether I shouldn't accept an answer until the exact complexity has been nailed (which may require an original proof).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;In particular I am not sure what to do about answers that say that the problem is open. In a sense, these answers solve my problem, as they tell me that the question is already known to be tricky and is not so likely to be answered in the near future. On the other hand, they do not give the answer that I am interested in, and could be ultimately replaced by a more definitive answer. **Should such answers be accepted?**&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Here are some examples:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- In [this question](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/35942/complexity-of-testing-if-a-hypergraph-has-generalized-hypertreewidth-2), I asked about the complexity of a problem, and an author of the most relevant  paper on the topic answered that he did not know. This answer is of course very useful, but I do not know whether I should accept it.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- In [that question](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/32505/is-it-still-open-to-determine-the-complexity-of-computing-the-treewidth-of-plana), I accepted an answer saying that the problem was still open. I guess this is reasonable as my question was asking &quot;is the problem still open&quot;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;(Sorry if this isn't the right kind of questions for meta.CS.SE. I'm not familiar with the meta sites.)" />
./PostHistory.xml:4699:  <row Id="7075" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="2956" RevisionGUID="e1280dbe-e150-4f3e-91e7-3d0453ee8a1b" CreationDate="2016-10-17T16:09:33.457" UserId="1037" Text="StackExchange is looking to discontinue _all_ community blogs, including [our own](http://cstheory.blogoverflow.com). They are asking what we want to be done with our old posts (for example, migration to 3rd parties). **Does anybody have opinions on this?** I am interested in the opinion of post authors and the editors, in particular.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Our blog hasn't seen new posts in over 4 years, and is unlikely to see new ones at this rate. However, I know that a [number of us](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/a/22226/1037) run our own active blogs. So we might be interested in migrating our posts. For example, I have migrated/adapted my two posts on [quantum query complexity](https://egtheory.wordpress.com/2013/12/09/quantum-query-complexity/) ([original](http://cstheory.blogoverflow.com/2011/07/quantum-query-complexity/)) and the [negative adversary method](https://egtheory.wordpress.com/2013/12/16/negative-adversary-method/) ([original](http://cstheory.blogoverflow.com/2011/08/lower-bounds-by-negative-adversary-method/)) over to my own blog nearly three years ago. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;As a possible option, the blog I run -- [TheEGG](https://egtheory.wordpress.com) -- is a community project and has over 18 contributors. I would be happy to welcome any of the non-time specific (i.e. not the old conference announcements/dissections) posts over to my blog if their authors don't run their own blogs (or think it fits poorly with their more narrow theme). I would stagger their (re)release over the coming weeks. If they are interested, I might make slight stylistic edit suggestions to the respective authors to make their post(s) fit better with TheEGG's readership. If you are interested in having your post go this route, either respond in the comments here or email me at: lastname (dot) firstname (at) gmail (dot) com." />
./PostHistory.xml:4702:  <row Id="7078" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2956" RevisionGUID="8bce1616-2108-4633-95f6-34f7d757e3fd" CreationDate="2016-10-23T09:08:46.293" UserId="1037" Comment="added a second option" Text="StackExchange is looking to discontinue _all_ community blogs, including [our own](http://cstheory.blogoverflow.com). They are asking what we want to be done with our old posts (for example, migration to 3rd parties). **Does anybody have opinions on this?** I am interested in the opinion of post authors and the editors, in particular.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Our blog hasn't seen new posts in over 4 years, and is unlikely to see new ones at this rate. However, I know that a [number of us](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/a/22226/1037) run our own active blogs. So we might be interested in migrating our posts. For example, I have migrated/adapted my two posts on [quantum query complexity](https://egtheory.wordpress.com/2013/12/09/quantum-query-complexity/) ([original](http://cstheory.blogoverflow.com/2011/07/quantum-query-complexity/)) and the [negative adversary method](https://egtheory.wordpress.com/2013/12/16/negative-adversary-method/) ([original](http://cstheory.blogoverflow.com/2011/08/lower-bounds-by-negative-adversary-method/)) over to my own blog nearly three years ago. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;As a possible option, the blog I run -- [TheEGG](https://egtheory.wordpress.com) -- is a community project and has over 18 contributors. I would be happy to welcome any of the non-time specific (i.e. not the old conference announcements/dissections) posts over to my blog if their authors don't run their own blogs (or think it fits poorly with their more narrow theme). I would stagger their (re)release over the coming weeks. If they are interested, I might make slight stylistic edit suggestions to the respective authors to make their post(s) fit better with TheEGG's readership. If you are interested in having your post go this route, either respond in the comments here or email me at: lastname (dot) firstname (at) gmail (dot) com.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;As a second, low effort, option: We can simply convert the blog to static pages that would remain on servers that SE manages." />
./PostHistory.xml:4709:  <row Id="7090" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2950" RevisionGUID="598ddf3d-6997-4bc8-9131-0a2d7465f55b" CreationDate="2016-11-29T13:30:16.590" UserId="4795" Comment="update about the first question" Text="When I ask questions of the form &quot;what is the complexity of problem BLAH&quot;, then there is an ambiguity (to me) about whether an accepted answer should simply give the best known bounds according to current literature, or whether I shouldn't accept an answer until the exact complexity has been nailed (which may require an original proof).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;In particular I am not sure what to do about answers that say that the problem is open. In a sense, these answers solve my problem, as they tell me that the question is already known to be tricky and is not so likely to be answered in the near future. On the other hand, they do not give the answer that I am interested in, and could be ultimately replaced by a more definitive answer. **Should such answers be accepted?**&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Here are some examples:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- In [this question](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/35942/complexity-of-testing-if-a-hypergraph-has-generalized-hypertreewidth-2), I asked about the complexity of a problem, and an author of the most relevant  paper on the topic answered that he did not know. This answer is of course very useful, but I do not know whether I should accept it.  *(Update: meanwhile, a new answer has been posted, so the description here no longer makes sense)*&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- In [that question](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/32505/is-it-still-open-to-determine-the-complexity-of-computing-the-treewidth-of-plana), I accepted an answer saying that the problem was still open. I guess this is reasonable as my question was asking &quot;is the problem still open&quot;.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;(Sorry if this isn't the right kind of questions for meta.CS.SE. I'm not familiar with the meta sites.)" />

Bottom line:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* it's unlikely this decision will be changed&#xD;&#xA;* Jeff Atwood claims that a site reaching &quot;[ServerFault][3]&quot; levels of traffic (38k views/day at least count) will get their own domain, else not&#xD;&#xA;* He also thinks all names in the SE family are terrible, except the cooking site. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;This is extremely inside baseball stuff, so I don't expect anyone to care greatly about it. But it does mean our wranglings over the domain name are irrelevant. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://webapps.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/624/webapps-stackexchange-com-versus-nothingtoinstall-com&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: http://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/66443/public-service-announcement-ongoing-offsite-discussion-about-area51-graduates&#xD;&#xA;  [3]: http://serverfault.com/" />

./PostHistory.xml:4729:  <row Id="7114" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="75" RevisionGUID="a53971af-6852-431a-b910-b0f90fc02a17" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:44:09.650" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.stats.stackexchange.com/ with https://stats.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="These questions are actually in-scope on the [data analysis site][1]. ./PostHistory.xml:4730:  <row Id="7115" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="131" RevisionGUID="e4957e57-d1bc-4b98-be89-94a20d7841c4" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:44:21.953" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.math.stackexchange.com/ with https://math.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="I believe that These arXiv tags should not be used at all.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;My biggest concern is that these tags are not friendly to people who don't know arXiv (I'm one of these people). I have an interest in many computer science topics, but I rarely read computer science publications, have never browsed arVix, and really don't want to learn how to use such a system that I'll never use off of this site.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;However, I routinely read other publications of papers by the IEEE (in fact, I have the most recent issue of IEEE Transactions on Software Engineering next to me right now). Papers in this publication have &quot;index terms&quot; - keywords that describe what the paper is about. I grabbed a copy of the ACM Transactions on Software Engineering and Methodology out of my shelf, and they have three sections: categories and subject descriptions (which contain a code as well as textual descriptions), general terms, and additional key words/phrases. Whenever I've searched for papers in an online database, my matches have always come from the keywords sections or the body of the paper.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Looking at these tags, they are unwieldy. I have no idea what the tag means, and I wouldn't expect that most undergraduate computer scientists and software engineers would either. Given the responses to [my previous question here on Meta][1], you want to be inclusive of multiple skill levels. If I find it difficult to search and browse through questions based on tags (which are also used in the site search engine), I'll be less likely to use this site.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Instead of following MathOverflow, I believe that this exchange should follow a path closer to that of [Mathematics][2]. There are [three][3] [relevant][4] [discussions][5] on their Meta that I could find. The Mathematics community appears to be doing quite well in terms of having people of various skill levels (appears to range from undergraduate university-level mathematics on up), their tagging appears to be working quite well, and I honestly find it easier to read and search than MathOverflow.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;But really, if this Stack Exchange follows MathOverflow, I actually see someone else coming along and making another Computer Science exchange geared toward a broader audience, in terms of skill levels. I think that this exchange can avoid this splintering of the community (avoiding another Unix/Linux versus Ubuntu Stack Exchange problem) by catering to as many people of various skill levels and educational backgrounds as possible. Yes, you need a specific focus on certain topics and clearly define what is and is not on-topic, but you want to segregate based on those topics, not by knowledge or experience. By dumping the arVix style tags, you make it easy for everyone to find questions/answers, but also make the site friendlier to less knowledgeable and experienced people such as myself.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;However, that's not to say that arVix isn't useful. I believe Stack Exchanges have the &quot;tag wiki&quot; page that Stack Overflow has. It would be benefitial to identify which tags correspond to arVix topic areas and link to those topic areas in the tag wiki for a given tag.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Also, a technical consideration: The [tags are specified using rel=&quot;tag&quot;][8] in the source of a page. If you aren't familiar with microformats, search engines actually do pick up on them and they do help people find pages. People who do searches search for things like &quot;data structure&quot; and &quot;data structures&quot;, not &quot;cs.DS.data-structures&quot;. The tags should reflect what people are searching on Google and Bing so that they are brought to questions on Stack Exchanges that are relevant to their searches.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;----------&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I also want to address a few comments and other postings.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Another point that I've read in [some postings and comments here][6] is that you want to maintain compatibility with MathOverflow. I think this is a mistake. MathOverflow is a Stack Exchange 1.0 site and, last I heard, had no intention of migrating to Stack Exchange 2.0. However, there are a number of Stack Exchange 2.0 sites that might be of interest to this community in some way that are at various levels of existance - Stack Overflow (people might ask algorithm or data structure implementation questions here), Mathematics (which includes discrete mathematics, graph theory, combinatorics...), Statistical Analysis (which includes machine learning), Not Programming Related, Compiler Design, Software Engineering, Artificial Intelligence, Application Security, Machine Learning, Numerical Modeling and Simulation, Signal Processing, Operating systems Development, Natural Language Processing and Computational Linguistics, and Cryptography (and those are just the first 10 pages of proposals, sorted by progress). These are the communities that need to work together to decide what best belongs where, especially since it appears that there will be a feature to move questions between various Stack Exchange 2.0 sites. Unless things change on MathOverflow, you will never be able to migrate a question from here to MO. However, in the future, it will be possible to migrate questions to the exchanges I mentioned, and so far, none of them are using ArVix tagging.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;As [first mentioned in a comment here][7], some of the ArVix tags are long. Potentially too long to fit in the limit of a tag. The purpose of tags is to help people search and sort through questions. If you start abbreviating ArVix tags, you open up a whole new can of worms with the best way to abbreviate the tags.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/115&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: http://math.stackexchange.com/&#xD;&#xA;  [3]: https://math.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/48/should-mathoverflow-tag-prefixes-be-used&#xD;&#xA;  [4]: https://math.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/186/setting-things-straight-what-style-of-tags-are-we-going-to-be-using-when-we-laun&#xD;&#xA;  [5]: https://math.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/59/mathoverflow-tags-others&#xD;&#xA;  [6]: http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/41/arxiv-tags-vs-not/74#74&#xD;&#xA;  [7]: http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/41/arxiv-tags-vs-not/42#42&#xD;&#xA;  [8]: http://microformats.org/wiki/rel-tag" />
./PostHistory.xml:4731:  <row Id="7116" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="496" RevisionGUID="95bba7b8-a408-4182-849f-8a638b0e3fd6" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:44:21.953" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.math.stackexchange.com/ with https://math.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="As far as I know, there are five ways to render dollar signs in questions and answers.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;1. &lt;code&gt;&amp;#x60;$example$&amp;#x60;&lt;/code&gt; → `$example$`.  (use backticks in Markdown)&#xD;&#xA;2. `$\$$example$\$$` → $\$$example$\$$.  (use LaTeX)&#xD;&#xA;3. `\$example\$` → \$example\$.  (if you do not mind additional backslashes rendered)&#xD;&#xA;4. `$example` → $example.  (if you need just one dollar sign)&#xD;&#xA;5. `＄example＄` → ＄example＄.  (abuse [Fullwidth Dollar Sign (U+FF04)](http://www.fileformat.info/info/unicode/char/ff04/index.htm))&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;More details:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;1. As Suresh wrote in a comment, you can use a code span in Markdown (backticks).&#xD;&#xA;2. You can use LaTeX.&#xD;&#xA;3. As you did in the question, if you prepend a backslash to a dollar sign, the dollar sign is not considered as a LaTeX math delimiter, but the backslash is also rendered.&#xD;&#xA;4. If just one dollar sign is needed, you can write it without any trouble.  What counts as one seems complicated (for example, the example above really contains two dollar signs).&#xD;&#xA;5. You can abuse [Fullwidth Dollar Sign (U+FF04)](http://www.fileformat.info/info/unicode/char/ff04/index.htm).  But note that most Latin fonts do not contain this letter and that therefore some people may not have a font containing it.  Also, this is an abuse because the character U+FF04 exists only for compatibility with some legacy character sets/encodings.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;See also a [related question on meta.math.stackexchange.com](https://math.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/403/texification-is-too-aggressive-or-how-to-enter-a-dollar-sign), but note that part of the question is obsolete (as stated in an [answer](https://math.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/403/texification-is-too-aggressive-or-how-to-enter-a-dollar-sign/434#434)).&#xD;&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:4732:  <row Id="7117" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="502" RevisionGUID="4c9d9a07-16bf-494f-806b-17a56586671d" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:44:21.953" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.math.stackexchange.com/ with https://math.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="I am experimenting with some UserScripts to provide additional functionality that the StackExchange sites currently do not support.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;In particular, two have proved highly useful:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* https://math.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/689/latex-rendering-delay shows how to reduce the TeX preview delay from the default 5 seconds (!).  Thanks to @Sadeq for the detective work in http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/485&#xD;&#xA;* http://userscripts.org/scripts/show/71948 threads comments based on time and `@`-tagged names used in the comments&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I would like to hear about UserScripts that others have found useful on CSTheory.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;There are also some generic lists (the functionality of quite a few of these has subsequently been incorporated by the StackExchange sites):&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* http://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/5188/what-third-party-tools-exist-to-use-with-stackoverflow&#xD;&#xA;* http://userscripts.org/scripts/search?q=stack+overflow&amp;x=0&amp;y=0&#xD;&#xA;* http://meta.stackoverflow.com/search?q=userscript&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:4733:  <row Id="7118" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="647" RevisionGUID="38caf50e-72ca-4fd6-9067-249873e455c0" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:44:21.953" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.math.stackexchange.com/ with https://math.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="(Part of this answer had been previously posted as a comment, but I decided to move it to an answer with additional information about user scripts.)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The same issue has been raised also on meta.math.stackexchange.com: [TeX formatting in other comments in the same post is lost when the comment list is updated](https://math.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/397/tex-formatting-in-other-comments-in-the-same-post-is-lost-when-the-comment-list-i).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;On that page, [KennyTM posted a user script as a workaround](https://math.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/397/tex-formatting-in-other-comments-in-the-same-post-is-lost-when-the-comment-list-i/650#650) (great!).  I posted there a [modified version of it](https://math.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/397/tex-formatting-in-other-comments-in-the-same-post-is-lost-when-the-comment-list-i/1114#1114) which should be safer in principle in case *.stackexchange.com be cracked.  To use a user script with Firefox, you need the add-on [Greasemonkey](https://addons.mozilla.org/firefox/addon/748/)." />
./PostHistory.xml:4734:  <row Id="7119" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="896" RevisionGUID="79cab2ff-23db-4654-b703-9a02bb0e18b2" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:44:21.953" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.math.stackexchange.com/ with https://math.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="First of all, if you have not seen the [Moderator Election Page][1], please follow the link to see all the nominations and their intros.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;[In the same spirit as mathSE][2] in the 2010 election, I think it is a good idea to ask questions about our site and community to the moderator candidates, and by their responses the community can make a better choice in the election phase. ./PostHistory.xml:4737:  <row Id="7122" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1381" RevisionGUID="6d107c6b-c91d-4070-a74c-cad7e1e9024e" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:44:39.750" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.tex.stackexchange.com/ with https://tex.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="This post is inspired by answers to [this question](http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/q/1369) and a similar list on [TEX.SE](https://tex.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/430).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The idea is to make a bunch of templates for commonly-used comments, like comments explaining that a question is out of scope and the question will be closed. Collecting such templates in one place makes it easier for those who don't wish to type out a personalized comment every time they vote to close a question.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Please post templates as answers. This question is CW, so feel free to edit other people's answers to improve the templates." />
./PostHistory.xml:4738:  <row Id="7123" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1387" RevisionGUID="655f7c9f-0f09-444f-8fad-651a1b927888" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:44:53.120" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.english.stackexchange.com/ with https://english.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="The mission of Stack Exchange is to make the internet a better place to get expert answers to your questions. The Stack Exchange Fellowship Program aims to support students conducting research in subjects related to our academic Q&amp;A sites in order to (a) increase the quality of information in a particular subject and (b) facilitate the exchange of information between experts in the field. Individual awards range from 250 to 1000 dollars (USD).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Applicants should be advanced undergraduate, graduate students or professionals pursuing research related to one the following Stack Exchange sites:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; - [English][1]&#xD;&#xA; - [Linguistics][2]&#xD;&#xA; - [Physics][3]&#xD;&#xA; - [Statistics][4]  &#xD;&#xA; - Theoretical Computer Science&#xD;&#xA; - [Theoretical Physics][5]&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Applications will be accepted on a rolling basis starting immediately. For more details and to apply, check out the [application][6]!&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;We are also accepting volunteers from the community to help review applications. Volunteers should have some level of expertise in the subject area (professors and those who have or are pursuing advanced degrees are ideal candidates). Reviewers will be given 3 weeks from when they receive materials or may request more time if needed. Following the first wave of submissions, those selected to be Stack Exchange Fellows will be asked to review 3 to 4 new applications. To facilitate the review process, reviewers will rate applications on several scales instead of making judgments on funding. You can find the Reviewer Form [here][7].&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Reviewers and successful candidates are encouraged to customize the &quot;about me&quot; section of the user profile by including information on:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; 1. Area of expertise and current occupation &#xD;&#xA; 2. Key academic goals/milestones&#xD;&#xA; 3. Role in the Fellowship program (applicant, reviewer, fellow, both)&#xD;&#xA; 4. SE grant project, if applicable &#xD;&#xA;   &#xD;&#xA;If you have any questions regarding the Fellowship Program, or would like more information about applying or becoming a reviewer, please email *academics@stackexchange.com*.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Edited: Applications accepted on a rolling basis until December 31, 2011. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://english.meta.stackexchange.com/q/2077/13231&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: http://meta.linguistics.stackexchange.com/q/202/344&#xD;&#xA;  [3]: http://meta.physics.stackexchange.com/q/942/5450&#xD;&#xA;  [4]: http://meta.physics.stackexchange.com/q/942/5450&#xD;&#xA;  [5]: http://meta.theoreticalphysics.stackexchange.com/q/170/533&#xD;&#xA;  [6]: http://dl.dropbox.com/u/37818223/SE%20Fellowship%20Application.docx&#xD;&#xA;  [7]: http://dl.dropbox.com/u/37818223/Reviewer%20Sheet.docx" />

Based on past experience with other SE sites, a domain name that's parked but not taken is admissible. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;**Note that you can vote more than once!**" />
./PostHistory.xml:4741:  <row Id="7127" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="118" RevisionGUID="90c0682d-5be7-45e8-9505-548cbf370bc0" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="I answered the [Arxiv tags or not][1] question so:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; The current `AA.BB.CCCCC` tags are unwieldy &amp;mdash;a defect in a question tagging scheme, not so bad in an article classification scheme&amp;mdash; and `AA` is nearly always `cs`.  The exceptions are, AFAICT, misclassifications.  &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt;If we simply dropped the `AA.` part off the tag, we would have a system that looks like the MO scheme, and is more pleasant.  We'd also remove the tiresome `math.lo.logic` vs. `cs.lo.logic` issue.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt;The full Arxiv code can be given in the tag description.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Since the suggestion was well-received, I am promoting it to a retag request.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Two concrete examples: make [cs.cc.complexity-theory] a synonym of [cc.complexity-theory] and [cs.ds.data-structures] a synonym of [ds.data-structures].  There are currently 11 such &quot;cs.&quot; prefixed tags.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;This is tagged [feature-request], so vote up if you think this retagging should be done, down if you think it shouldn't.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/41/arxiv-tags-vs-not" />
./PostHistory.xml:4742:  <row Id="7128" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="25" RevisionGUID="dda15772-6fdc-4e3b-9eea-53b8c3b66723" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="Since many of the visitors here are new to the Stackexchange environment, it might be useful to collect questions and answers here to add to [the official site FAQ](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science). In addition, it would be useful to add questions and answers that help delineate the scope of this site, since we're already getting questions about it. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I'll make this &quot;question&quot; community wiki. Feel free to post answers, or even edit this post to add to the list. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;**StackExchange Questions**&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; - What is a &quot;community wiki&quot;? &#xD;&#xA; - What purpose does a community wiki designation serve? &#xD;&#xA; - What is the difference between an&#xD;&#xA;   Answer and a Comment, and what&#xD;&#xA;   technical restrictions are there on&#xD;&#xA;   Comments?&#xD;&#xA; - What happens if you delete something&#xD;&#xA;   you've posted?&#xD;&#xA; - How does closing and re-opening work? ([see this link][1] for good practices when voting to close)&#xD;&#xA; - [When should you downvote/upvote][2] ?&#xD;&#xA; - [An updated cross-posting policy][3]&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;**Subject-related Questions**&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; - What kind of questions work best ?&#xD;&#xA;   (i.e what questions won't get closed)&#xD;&#xA; - [What is the policy on cross posting&#xD;&#xA;   to/from Mathoverflow][4]&lt;/a&gt;&#xD;&#xA; - How should we tag questions (see &lt;a&#xD;&#xA;   href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/41/arxiv-tags-vs-not&quot;&gt;this&#xD;&#xA;   meta post&lt;/a&gt;)&#xD;&#xA; - Which sources should I check&#xD;&#xA;   before asking a question.&#xD;&#xA; - [What kinds of tags should I use][5]&#xD;&#xA;   ?&#xD;&#xA; - How do I ask a good question ? ([this post by Jon Skeet][6] of SO could be adapted for our needs)&#xD;&#xA; - [How should I cite a post on the site in my paper?][7]&#xD;&#xA; - [Is my question suitable for cstheory?][8]&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/56/are-list-questions-such-as-about-conferences-on-topic&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/25/material-to-supplement-the-faq/54#54&#xD;&#xA;  [3]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/a/2682/&#xD;&#xA;  [4]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/25/material-to-supplement-the-faq/36#36&#xD;&#xA;  [5]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/41/arxiv-tags-vs-not&#xD;&#xA;  [6]: http://msmvps.com/blogs/jon_skeet/archive/2010/08/29/writing-the-perfect-question.aspx&#xD;&#xA;  [7]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/352/how-will-you-cite-a-discussion-on-this-site-in-your-paper&#xD;&#xA;  [8]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/a/2662/" />
./PostHistory.xml:4743:  <row Id="7129" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="132" RevisionGUID="2fb9b9be-cb2a-42d7-a399-08ff0e1883c4" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="While at it, we could try to come up with better names for the tags. Here is the current list of tags and their new names. Feel free to edit, but please keep in mind that tags can only have at most 24 characters. Old tags can be left as synonyms.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; - **cc.complexity-theory**     &lt;- cs.cc.complexity-theory (*Computational Complexity*, cs.cc.complexity-theory in MO)&#xD;&#xA; - **cr.crypto-security**       &lt;- cs.cr.crypto-security (*Cryptography and Security*)&#xD;&#xA; - **cg.comput-geometry**       &lt;- cs.cg.comp-geom (*Computational Geometry*, cs.cg in MO)&#xD;&#xA; - **dc.distributed-comp**      &lt;- cs.dc.distributed-comp (*Distributed Computing*)&#xD;&#xA; - **dc.parallel-comp**         &lt;- parallelism (*Parallel Computing*)&#xD;&#xA; - **ds.data-structures**       &lt;- cs.ds.data-structures, data-structures (*Data Structures*)&#xD;&#xA; - **ds.algorithms**            &lt;- algorithms (*Algorithms*)&#xD;&#xA; - **fl.formal-languages**      &lt;- cs.fl.formal-languages (*Formal Languages and Automata Theory*)&#xD;&#xA; - **gt.game-theory**           &lt;- cs.gt.game-theory (*Computer Science and Game Theory*)&#xD;&#xA; - **lg.machine-learning**      &lt;- cs.lg.learning (*Machine Learning*, cs.lg.learning in MO)&#xD;&#xA; - **lo.logic**                 &lt;- cs.lo.logic (*Logic in Computer Science*, lo.logic in MO is related)&#xD;&#xA; - **ne.neural-evol**           &lt;- cs.ne.neural-evol (*Neural and Evolutionary Computation*)&#xD;&#xA; - **pl.programming-lang**      &lt;- cs.pl.programming-lang (*Programming Languages*)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Again, [here][1] is the list of ArXiv/CORR subject classes.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;And as it seems that [people would like to keep the tags as simple as possible][2], I'd suggest that we also change:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; - **combinatorics** &lt;- co.combinatorics&#xD;&#xA; - **category-theory** &lt;- math.ct.category-theory&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The idea would be that each post is tagged with at least one &quot;dotted&quot; ArXiv/CORR tag, and those would be our &quot;top level&quot; tags. Everything else is extra and kept as simple as possible.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://arxiv.org/corr/subjectclasses&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/41/arxiv-tags-vs-not" />

./PostHistory.xml:4747:  <row Id="7134" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="62" RevisionGUID="b0573817-f0e4-42af-8109-50c55d9ec06f" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="In the discussion on [this meta question][1], I made a comment in passing that I thought there were too many CW questions on the site at present. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;While this may be a transient phenomenon while the site is being seeded, I thought it brought up important issues about whether certain questions should be CW or just closed. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;So my question is:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; What is a clear policy to determine&#xD;&#xA;&gt; which questions should be deemed CW,&#xD;&#xA;&gt; which answers should be made CW, and&#xD;&#xA;&gt; which questions should just be closed&#xD;&#xA;&gt; ?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;As a reference point for discussion, I'll refer people to [this meta thread on MO][2], where many of the issues we're facing have been discussed. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;In keeping with the spirit of that discussion, since I do think that there is a good answer and that people's direct experiences are helpful, I'm **NOT** making this CW. I also think that the reduction in points for upvotes on questions actually makes me more comfortable about this, since my ability to acquire rep points is limited in comparison to people with good answers. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/56/are-list-questions-such-as-about-conferences-on-topic&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: http://meta.mathoverflow.net/discussion/6/when-should-questions-be-community-wiki" />
./PostHistory.xml:4748:  <row Id="7136" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="67" RevisionGUID="2e16804d-9cd3-412f-9508-a9902d9e3c41" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="**Update**: This post is now closed since the temporary moderators have been selected. Please see [this announcement][1] for details. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;**Important: if you're nominated and accept the nomination, please add the word 'accept' somewhere in the answer, and also mention which timezones you are likely to be able to handle.** &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Based on [the web-apps template][2], we should be choosing candidates to be our site moderators.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* Each nomination should be a separate answer. Link the name to the user's profile so we can see their activity.&#xD;&#xA;* The nominee should indicate their acceptance by editing the answer, adding that they accept the nomination. Optionally they can write something about their self. This can be just practical stuff like which hours and how many hours they expect to spend on the site, but also some motivation.&#xD;&#xA;* From the top voted nominees a number of temporary moderators will be appointed, until the site is out of beta and real elections can be held.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Some guidelines:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;1. Must be a currently registered user in good standing&#xD;&#xA;2. Must have a reasonably high reputation score to indicate active, consistent participation.&#xD;&#xA;3. Should exhibit patience and fairness at all times in their questions, answers, and comments.&#xD;&#xA;4. Should lead by example, showing respect for their fellow community members in everything they write.&#xD;&#xA;5. They should want the responsibility. Nominating users isn’t the same as an obligation. It’s purely voluntary!&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;When nominating, please put the name of the nominee as a heading (with a #) and as a link to their real profile. Also add a link to their meta profile. (See the already provided answers). After that, please keep them empty for the nominees to add information themselves.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Besides voting, everybody could off course also point out in the comments why that nominee is a good candidate to be moderator or not.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Read more about [the moderator nomination process here][3].&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/222/moderator-pro-tem-announcement&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: http://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/57986/how-to-organize-a-formal-moderator-election-on-a-beta-se-site&#xD;&#xA;  [3]: http://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/57986/how-to-organize-a-formal-moderator-election-on-a-beta-se-site" />
./PostHistory.xml:4749:  <row Id="7137" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="228" RevisionGUID="fa8e4111-5698-4d3e-9515-9660cdf6b513" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="What kinds of tags should I use?&#xD;&#xA;--------------------------------&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Each question should have at least one &quot;ArXiv tag&quot;, and any number of additional tags (there is a limitation of at most 5 tags per question and at most 24 characters per tag). Try to re-use [existing tags](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/tags) whenever possible, but you are also welcome to propose new tags. See [this page](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/tags/synonyms) for our current list of tag synonyms.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;---&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### ArXiv tags&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;[FIXME: add answer]&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Related discussion:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;1. [arXiv tags vs not?][1]&#xD;&#xA;2. [Proposal: Remove discipline prefix from the Arxiv-style tags][2]&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; [1]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/41/arxiv-tags-vs-not)&#xD;&#xA; [2]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/118/proposal-remove-discipline-prefix-from-the-arxiv-style-tags&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;---&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### [[soft-question]](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/tags/soft-question/info)&#xD;&#xA; &#xD;&#xA;A soft-question is subjective and argumentative without a precise answer and can be a question **about** theoretical computer science rather than being a question in it. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Examples:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- How would you teach X to undergrads?&#xD;&#xA;- Why computer scientists do X when Y happens?&#xD;&#xA;- Is theoretical computer science part of pure math?&#xD;&#xA;- How long will it take to settle P vs NP in your opinion?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;[More discussion](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/182/big-picture-vs-soft-question).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;---&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### [[big-picture]](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/tags/big-picture/info)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;A big-picture question is higher-level question, and although it can be subjective and argumentative it does not need to be, and is a question **in** theoretical computer science. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Examples:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- What is the main idea behind Razborov-Rudich natural proofs?&#xD;&#xA;- What are the obstacles to prove a super-polynomial lower-bound for SAT?&#xD;&#xA;- Where did the idea of Domain theory came from?&#xD;&#xA;- What are the main objects and constructions used in crypto?&#xD;&#xA;- Is there a program to settle Unique Games Conjecture?&#xD;&#xA;- Is polynomial time Turing computable the right definition for feasible computation?&#xD;&#xA;- What evidence do we have for Church-Turing thesis?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;[More discussion](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/182/big-picture-vs-soft-question)." />

./PostHistory.xml:4751:  <row Id="7139" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="69" RevisionGUID="9a1ba0e0-a0e5-4479-849c-00d726ee0999" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="#[András Salamon][1]&#xD;&#xA;[(meta)][2]&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;**Decline**: I will not be able to contribute significantly for the next month at least.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/users/109/andras-salamon&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/users/109/andras-salamon" />
./PostHistory.xml:4752:  <row Id="7140" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="231" RevisionGUID="55f26fa2-8c8b-4ce4-b2a5-07944d27b836" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="What is the policy on crossposting to/from MathOverflow or other StackExchange sites?&#xD;&#xA;--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Crossposting from [MathOverflow](http://mathoverflow.net/) and other StackExchange sites is perfectly fine, as long as they aren't done in parallel. That is, if you post a question on one site, you should only post to the other site after you have not received a satisfactory answer for some time, and you should provide a link in each post (or in the comments on it) to the other one. As a courtesy, if you post your question here after trying MathOverflow or another StackExchange site, please try to integrate in your question the answers you received on MathOverflow/the other site (even if they did not answer everything).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;---&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Related discussion:&#xD;&#xA;[[1]](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/25/material-to-supplement-the-faq/36#36)&#xD;&#xA;[[2]](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/65/repeat-a-question-from-math-overflow)&#xD;&#xA;[[3]](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/a/2853)" />

./PostHistory.xml:4757:  <row Id="7145" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="235" RevisionGUID="c2741492-0981-4193-bc3b-161f9e9140a0" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="What kind of questions are too basic?&#xD;&#xA;-------------------------------------&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Our aim is to ask and answer **research-level** questions in theoretical computer science.  &quot;Research-level&quot; means, roughly, questions that might be discussed between two professors, or between graduate students working on Ph.D.'s, but not usually between a professor and the typical undergraduate student. *It does not include questions at the level of difficulty of undergraduate homework*. Here are some examples of questions that are off-topic because they are not research-level or because they are too easy:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; - Questions that can be easily answered by reading a Wikipedia article on the topic.&#xD;&#xA; - Questions that can be easily solved by Googling.&#xD;&#xA; - Questions that are solved by browsing [one of these web sites](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/229#229).&#xD;&#xA; - Typical homework problems in textbooks.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;If you do not think that your question is research-level but you cannot find an answer in above options, you may want to try http://math.stackexchange.com/.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;---&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Related discussion:&#xD;&#xA;[[1]](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/17/scope-of-questions)&#xD;&#xA;[[2]](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/115/what-level-and-types-of-questions-are-appropriate-for-theoretical-computer-scienc)&#xD;&#xA;[[3]](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/209/homework-or-things-that-look-like-homework)" />

./PostHistory.xml:4759:  <row Id="7147" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="237" RevisionGUID="dfb9162b-0059-4e4f-a75b-1f229e4c07f5" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="How do I write formulas?&#xD;&#xA;------------------------&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;This site uses [MathJax](http://www.mathjax.org/). You can simply type (almost) any LaTeX equations between a pair of $-signs, and the system will display it properly typeset. This should work in questions, answers, and comments (with some exceptions).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;---&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Why don't I see any formulas? Why do I get a *[Math Processing Error]*?&#xD;&#xA;-----------------------------------------------------------------------&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Try [this page](http://www.mathjax.org/demos/) first and see if MathJax works in your system at all. If the demo page works, but formulas on this site don't work, try to **clear your browser's cache**.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;---&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Related discussion:&#xD;&#xA;[[1]](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/3/latex-math-support)&#xD;&#xA;[[2]](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/195/cant-see-formulas)&#xD;&#xA;[[3]](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/25/material-to-supplement-the-faq/244#244)&#xD;&#xA;[[4]](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/258/math-processing-error)" />
./PostHistory.xml:4760:  <row Id="7148" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="91" RevisionGUID="79c6e73b-d549-4c96-bcdc-5bb1df791285" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="#[David Eppstein][1]&#xD;&#xA;[(meta)][2]&#xD;&#xA;&lt;BR&gt;&lt;BR&gt;&#xD;&#xA;**Accept**&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/users/95&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/users/95/david-eppstein" />
./PostHistory.xml:4761:  <row Id="7149" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="239" RevisionGUID="3ed8ac63-028d-4800-8890-b6e2527c88b3" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="When to use &quot;community wiki&quot;?&#xD;&#xA;-----------------------------&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The &quot;community wiki&quot; (CW) flag should be reserved for questions where either (i) you do not believe that there exists one (or even a few) good answers, and where **any individual response contributes a small enough piece of the overall answer that no reputation increase is warranted**, or (ii) you want to encourage other users to edit your answer or question, perhaps if you realise there are gaps in your answers that you would like other users to fill in.  &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;CW is irreversible. When in doubt, do not mark a question CW – this can always be changed later.  A crucial technical point: any answers made to a CW question will themselves be CW.   &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Often, a question that seems like it should be CW can be modified to be more direct and focused, thus avoiding the need for the tag. For example, the seemingly CW question &quot;What are the key papers in topic X&quot; can often be reworded as the more focused &quot;What I should start reading when studying topic X&quot;. The latter has one or a few definite answers and need not be made CW.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;If a question or answer is CW, there is something of an invitation to edit it: the reasons for editing are broader for CW posts than non-CW posts.  &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;---&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Related discussion:&#xD;&#xA;[[1]](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/201/community-wikis)&#xD;&#xA;[[2]](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/34/community-wiki-etiquette)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;---&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;When to mark an answer as &quot;community wiki&quot;?&#xD;&#xA;-------------------------------------------&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Anyone can edit a CW (community wiki) answer and no one earns reputation for it.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;One good use of the CW flag is to aggregate multiple answers into a single one with uniform formatting. Another possible use of the CW flag is to invite others to fill in an incomplete answer. (Perhaps you only have time to sketch the idea, or perhaps you do not know the complete answer but have a strong hunch that your idea points in the right direction.)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;This answer is flagged CW for good reason: There's room for improvement." />

This is important to make sure tags reflect the true content of the question, which makes searching and filtering easier. Please use [the tagging guide][1] to decide what the right tags should be.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/228#228" />

./PostHistory.xml:4765:  <row Id="7153" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="307" RevisionGUID="7d496cff-3368-4c19-bb7f-11b792d68f3b" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="### Understand what you really want to ask&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;This may sound odd but, even if you know that you want to ask something, it is sometimes difficult to pin down exactly _what you really want to ask_.  It is a good idea to make some effort to identify the exact question you want to ask before actually posting a question.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;For example, many people incorrectly ask “Is there an algorithm which computes X?” when what they really want to know is “Is there a polynomial-time algorithm which computes X?” or even “X can be computed in time O(&lt;i&gt;n&lt;/i&gt;&lt;sup&gt;3&lt;/sup&gt;) in a straightforward way.  Is there a faster algorithm?”&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Knowing the precise question makes it easier to write a clear and easy-to-understand question, which hopefully makes more people interested in your question.  Also, by the time you know the question well enough so that you can state the question clearly, you can sometimes find out the answer by yourself!&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Related guidelines:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- Why should you make any effort to ask a question in the first place?  See [this guideline](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/300/how-to-ask-a-good-question/318#318).&#xD;&#xA;- Asking a precise question also allows one to tell what is an answer and what is not.  See [this guideline](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/300/how-to-ask-a-good-question/323#323) for more on this.&#xD;&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:4766:  <row Id="7154" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="99" RevisionGUID="905afbd8-bd28-4f54-8043-53cd0a8e336a" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="*In accordance with [this][1], I'm asking this question here.*&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;So, I've recently found a social network for scientists, and would like to know, if there are more such networks, where scientists and phd-students discuss their articles and thesises.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/62/developing-a-cw-policy/63#63" />
./PostHistory.xml:4767:  <row Id="7155" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="106" RevisionGUID="d0fbf8f8-0fc2-4d26-859b-fb252cea3f70" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="Related to the question on [$\LaTeX$ math support][1], it would be nice to view the Markdown for questions and answers with nice “typesetting.” Yes, users with sufficiently high rep can click edit and then back, but that isn't quite the same.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;[1]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/3/latex-math-support" />
./PostHistory.xml:4768:  <row Id="7156" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="318" RevisionGUID="40985854-da6e-404f-a5d7-e16f0f0957a8" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="### Only ask what you care about&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;When stated explicitly, this may sound obvious.  Do not ask what _someone_ cares about, but ask what _you_ care about.  If _you_ do not care about a question, either no one really cares or those who care can ask a better question.  Posting a question which you do not care about is a waste of time for everyone who reads the question (and possibly tries to answer it).  Put differently: **Do not ask a question for the sake of asking a question**.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;A corollary of this is: **Try to answer by yourself before posting a question**.  If you really care about a question, the first thing to do should not be posting the question on a website, but trying to solve it by yourself.  This includes looking up literature, formulating it from different angles, considering small cases, special cases and/or variations, and so on; in short, what you normally do to solve a problem.  If you do not want to think about the question by yourself, ask yourself whether you really care about the question.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;This does not mean that you must not ask a question unless you have proved that you cannot answer it by yourself (which is obviously impossible).  However, make some reasonable effort to try to answer your own question before posting it.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Related guidelines:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- Even if you care about the question, the reader may not know it.  Therefore, it is a good idea to include some evidences that you care about it in the question.  Doing so also helps the reader to understand the question better and hopefully results in better answers.  For more on this point, see [this guideline](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/300/how-to-ask-a-good-question/304#304) and [this guideline](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/300/how-to-ask-a-good-question/306#306).&#xD;&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:4769:  <row Id="7157" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="115" RevisionGUID="93beaab1-9ab2-44ae-af44-f910cef05e6f" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="As a starting point, I was interested in [András Salamon's answer][1] to a question about the need for a [TCS Stack Exchange][2].&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Now, as a software engineer, there are a number of topics in theoretical computer science that interest me that fall into the realm of computer science (theoretical or not), but at a much simpler level than it appears many of the questions here discuss:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; - Automata Theory&#xD;&#xA; - Computability Theory&#xD;&#xA; - Computational Complexity / Analysis of Algorithms&#xD;&#xA; - Cryptography&#xD;&#xA; - Algorithms and Data Structures (probably beyond scope here - my interested is in the applied, not theoretical)&#xD;&#xA; - Artificial Intelligence (probably beyond scope here - my interested is in the applied, not theoretical)&#xD;&#xA; - Computer Vision (probably beyond scope here - my interested is in the applied, not theoretical)&#xD;&#xA; - Image Processing (probably beyond scope here - my interested is in the applied, not theoretical)&#xD;&#xA; - Data Communication (potentially beyond scope, but I can see the theoretical underpinnings being within scope)&#xD;&#xA; - Programming Language Theories (potentially beyond scope, but there are mathematical underpinnings to the design/implementation of programming languages and compilers/interpreters that would probably be within scope)&#xD;&#xA; - Models of Concurrency&#xD;&#xA; - Models of Parallel Computing&#xD;&#xA; - Models of Distributed Computing&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;So, my questions:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; - What difficulty of questions are acceptable? My experience in theoretical computer science is limited, but I'm still interested in the theories that underpin what I do.&#xD;&#xA; - What topics are specifically considered a subset of theoretical computer science? I'm looking for someplace where I can ask and get answers to questions in (at least a subset of) the above-listed topics, which are unarguably topics within computer science, but potentially not within theoretical computer science. If this is not the place, can someone point me to a Stack Exchange where these are potentially within scope?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/92/is-there-really-a-need-for-theoretical-computer-science-se-site/93#93&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/92/is-there-really-a-need-for-theoretical-computer-science-se-site/93#93" />
./PostHistory.xml:4770:  <row Id="7158" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="361" RevisionGUID="c2a3735a-538c-45c7-ae6e-17daeb36c9b3" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="##My (wonderful!) question was closed! What do I do now? ##&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;There are many reasons a particular question might be closed. Don't be discouraged if this happens to you!&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Many such questions have a lot of merit but are closed for reasons that may not have occurred to you. You should consider re-asking your question after reading the comments others leave and adjusting your presentation.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;If, after reading through the rest of this FAQ, you have additional concerns about how to effectively formulate your question, post a new question on [meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/) and link that question to the original source. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;----------&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Related discussion: [here][1]&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/374/re-ask-vs-edit-reopen" />
./PostHistory.xml:4771:  <row Id="7159" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="390" RevisionGUID="6b72b4f0-0abe-49e3-816a-a6b80886c4a9" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="I would like to see the following entry in FAQ (in the “Best Practice” section):&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; My answer turned out to be incorrect.  What should I do?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;if there is a consensus about the answer.  Reasonable actions include:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- Correct it.  (But sometimes it is better to delete it and repost a correct answer; see the link to Meta Stack Overflow below.)&#xD;&#xA;- Leave it as it is after adding a clear notice that it is incorrect and why.&#xD;&#xA;- Delete it.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Such an FAQ entry should cover both the case where a flaw is found by the answerer him/herself and the case where a flaw is pointed out by someone else and the answerer is convinced (because I do not think there is much difference between them).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Related discussions:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- [Policy on deleting incorrect answers?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/386/policy-on-deleting-incorrect-answers)&#xD;&#xA;- [Should I remove a wrong answer (Peer Pressure)?](http://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/22630/should-i-remove-a-wrong-answer-peer-pressure) on Meta Stack Overflow (but I do not think that everything written there applies to us in the same way)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;(There is another discussion about [deleting your own _question_](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/50/deleting-your-own-question), but it is not much related.)&#xD;&#xA;" />

./PostHistory.xml:4773:  <row Id="7161" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="424" RevisionGUID="b7036a76-6e4c-4a34-9ec0-88f8f3eaa908" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="Why can't I comment on my own question?&#xD;&#xA;---------------------------------------&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Ideally, you should always be able to comment on your own question.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;If you cannot find a link labeled “add comment” below your own question, you may be using a different account from the one you used to post the question. Note that _using the same user name and the same icon does not mean that you are using the same account_.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;If this happens, ask the moderators to merge the two accounts by flagging the question and state the situation briefly in the flagging comment.  Alternatively, you can open a thread on [meta](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/) to explain the situation.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;To prevent this from happening in the future, we strongly encourage you to register your account.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Related discussion: [[1]](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/422/what-should-we-do-if-we-noticed-someone-having-the-multiple-account-problem)&#xD;&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:4774:  <row Id="7163" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="120" RevisionGUID="047799b6-6c14-491a-b33f-2bcda5c9bb17" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="I wanted to raise this question based on [the discussion here][1].
