./PostHistory.xml:4775:  <row Id="7164" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="439" RevisionGUID="3b4c75f4-75ce-44d1-a66a-c7f20c18b7de" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="I once posted the following FAQ entry and got two downvotes and no upvotes, so I moved it here to discuss what to do with it.  However, it has been made from [my post in another discussion](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/214/should-there-be-a-protocol-to-notify-authors-if-we-find-an-error-in-a-paper/254#254), which has three upvotes and no downvotes at this moment, and I do not know how to interpret this discrepancy. What should I do with this entry?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;---&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I might have found an error in a paper. Can I discuss it?&#xD;&#xA;---------------------------------------------------------&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;In general, it is considered wrong to discuss a possible error in a paper on a public forum before giving the author a chance to think about and correct it first. Before posting a question about a possible error, use your imagination to consider what the author may feel about the post.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Related to this, a question or a discussion may reveal an error of a paper in an unexpected way. In that case, it would be better to contact the author to let him/her know about the finding. (If you contacted the author, please leave a line so that other people do not have to worry about the possibility that the author is not notified.) If you are not involved in the discussion but happen to notice a case like this, you can flag the post for a moderator attention.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Related discussions: [[1]](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/214/should-there-be-a-protocol-to-notify-authors-if-we-find-an-error-in-a-paper) [[2]](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/204/are-specific-questions-about-theorem-x-in-paper-y-fine)&#xD;&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:4776:  <row Id="7165" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="457" RevisionGUID="a9980b49-ffab-41fd-a148-315048e1fb1b" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="Aaron Sterling had the [nice suggestion (in comments here)][1] for site promotion at FOCS: his idea was:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; a poster with a few &quot;best questions&quot;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; in large print on it: representatives&#xD;&#xA;&gt; of &#xD;&#xA;&gt; &#xD;&#xA;&gt;  1. community wiki, &#xD;&#xA;&gt;  2. a reference request where a top expert swooped in and resolved the&#xD;&#xA;&gt; issue, and &#xD;&#xA;&gt;  3. an open problem such as an NP-reduction where answerers solved it&#xD;&#xA;&gt; on the spot&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Any nominations ? One per answer, and specify which category: in each case, also pick an answer if none was accepted. If we can get some nominations within a week I can mock up a poster and stick it at the registration desk. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;**Update:** Great suggestions all. Any thoughts on the best way to lay these out on a poster ? One idea would be to orient the poster in landscape mode and have three columns, with 1/2 questions/answers in each. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;**Update 2:** For logistical reasons, I had to can the poster idea. but I thought I'd use a variant of what Joshua was suggesting, which was to use a single sheet for each question, with the question on the front and the answer on the back. I can generate a number of copies for different questions, and try to slip them into people's registration bags :). &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;[Here's an example][2] of what I'm thinking. Tell me what you think. AND SOON :)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;**Update 3:** New version with only answer hints. Thoughts ? &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;**Update 4:** I'm in Las Vegas now, and successfully got a sheet inserted in each registration packet, as well as scattering copies of the sheets on registration desks. I hope this will encourage more people to visit. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/453/site-outreach-promotion-at-focs&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: http://www.cs.utah.edu/~suresh/example.pdf" />
./PostHistory.xml:4777:  <row Id="7167" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="565" RevisionGUID="d77277fe-0486-4540-88e5-d535fd524322" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="While undergrad homework is allegedly not within the scope of this site, you can have assignments in graduate courses that are definitely not basic. For example, I am giving a talk in the near future to researchers about something I worked with in my Bachelor's thesis. So it might be hard to draw the line.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;My proposal: Let us create a tag 'homework' if it does not exist already. This way, homework questions that are well posed (ref [this discussion][1]) can be allowed while people not interested in them can easily filter them out via the form on the main questions page. Something like http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/-homework should yield a static page (with corresponding RSS feed) but I did not figure it out exactly. Anyway, this could be implemented easily if we went for it.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;**Edit:** In response to the comments, let me elaborate why I want basic TCS questions here, not on MO.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; 1. Students looking for help in TCS naturally go to the TCS site, not MO. &#xD;&#xA; 2. I would expect more TCS expertise here than on MO (if not now because of the recent split, then certainly later on)&#xD;&#xA; 3. By refusing to answer basic questions -- often in a less than nice way -- we leave a bad impression.&#xD;&#xA; 4. No pity for people that prefer rejecting questions over using existing tools for filtering. One should be able to expect regular users to use filters rather than newcomers to know the scopes of at least two different communities.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/559/another-go-at-scope-of-desirable-questions/560#560" />
./PostHistory.xml:4778:  <row Id="7168" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="121" RevisionGUID="9f826a81-4481-4abb-9788-0682e8250579" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="This has been raised several times and we should make a group decision.  Raised before:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; - [Developing a CW policy.][1]&#xD;&#xA; - [Are list questions such as about conferences on-topic?][2]&#xD;&#xA; - [Places to look for articles and discussions][3]&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Are questions about the field of TCS on or off topic?  Examples would be lists of books, journals, or conferences.  &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Assuming that they're off-topic, Robert Cartaino has already stated that these questions should not be posted on meta (even though there was some community support for the idea):&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; Because it is off-topic against the&#xD;&#xA;&gt; purpose of the site. There's already a&#xD;&#xA;&gt; wide-spread belief that if something&#xD;&#xA;&gt; is off topic, you just make it&#xD;&#xA;&gt; community wiki. You don't need to add&#xD;&#xA;&gt; another layer to that.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;So we need to determine:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;1. Are questions about the field really off-topic?&#xD;&#xA;2. If they are off-topic, does that mean that they can't be asked on meta?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;These decisions should go into our FAQ.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/62/developing-a-cw-policy/63#63&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/56/are-list-questions-such-as-about-conferences-on-topic/66#66&#xD;&#xA;  [3]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/99/places-to-look-for-articles-and-discussions" />
./PostHistory.xml:4779:  <row Id="7169" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="596" RevisionGUID="1f785f28-0f01-400a-b42d-6af5a16265da" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="Please do not remove tags mechanically just because questions are closed.  If a question is about graph theory and tagged as [graph-theory], there is no need to remove that tag if it is closed for being subjective or for some other reasons.  As [András wrote](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/587/about-retagging-as-tag-removed/595#595), closed questions should be reasonably exposed as such to users who are trying to ask similar questions.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;If a question is tagged as [graph-theory] but it is not really related to graph theory or any other reasonable topic, I think that it is perfectly fine to remove tags and just tag it as [tag-removed], unless you bump many questions at once for the sake of retagging.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;As Jukka wrote in a comment on the question, if you want to exclude closed questions from search results, add “closed:0” (without the quotation marks) to search terms.  See http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/search for other search options." />
./PostHistory.xml:4780:  <row Id="7170" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="598" RevisionGUID="4ea84009-c613-4126-9fa3-72d13aad68be" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="Stack Exchange has an experimental feature called timeline view ([example](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/posts/597/timeline)).  It is useful when you want to know when a post was made, an answer was accepted, and so on (but be careful because it does not always show the complete history).  See [my answer](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/502/useful-userscripts/508#508) to another question for more details and a link to a user script which makes the timeline view easier to use." />
./PostHistory.xml:4781:  <row Id="7171" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="664" RevisionGUID="1d23de46-b793-4196-a328-7bc86ed3f4b3" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="When a question is closed, no additional answers may be posted to it.  A user who votes to close a question must select one of the following reasons:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- Exact duplicate&#xD;&#xA;- Off topic&#xD;&#xA;- Belongs to meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com&#xD;&#xA;- Subjective and argumentative&#xD;&#xA;- Not a real question&#xD;&#xA;- Too localized&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Since questions on cstheory.stackexchange.com are expected to be research-level questions in theoretical computer science, “off topic” means anything that fails to satisfy this criterion.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Even a question in theoretical computer science will be considered as off topic if, for example, it is too basic to be research-level.  **Forget about the system-generated boilerplate message.**&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;A question being closed as off topic means that the question does not belong to cstheory.stackexchange.com.  It does not necessarily mean that the question is bad.  For example, a question about programming (actually writing code) will be probably closed as off topic on cstheory.stackexchange.com even if it is very interesting.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;For general information about closed questions and the meanings of other close reasons on Stack Exchange websites, please refer to [this post](http://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/10582/what-is-a-closed-question/10583#10583) on Meta Stack Exchange.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Related:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- [My (wonderful!) question was closed! What do I do now?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/361#361)&#xD;&#xA;- [What kind of questions are too basic?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/235#235)&#xD;&#xA;- Other discussions/questions posted on meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com about the [scope of cstheory.stackexchange.com](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/scope)&#xD;&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:4782:  <row Id="7172" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="691" RevisionGUID="cebfc84c-4481-4bcf-b2fb-08c3775e9c12" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="I do not see anything wrong with creating a tag about quantum information processing.  However, as I suggested in an [answer](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/455/using-at-least-one-top-level-arxiv-tag/686#686) to another question, I fail to see why it matters whether some tag has the same name as an arXiv category or not.  For example, the tag [tag:cc.complexity-theory] is useful not because it is the same name as arXiv (it is not even the same name as arXiv, actually), but because it groups questions in complexity theory together.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;In short, I do not think that “it is called quant-ph in arXiv” is a valid reason to have that tag." />
./PostHistory.xml:4783:  <row Id="7173" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="701" RevisionGUID="6402b190-003d-4a70-bb25-9bd88f57d4ff" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="Hi all. I think they represent the concept of TCS very well. ./PostHistory.xml:4785:  <row Id="7175" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="813" RevisionGUID="f147a560-6bdb-4e0b-870d-477a74ff4a8e" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="I cannot understand what is exactly being proposed.  You state:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; **POLICY**: Thesis topic questions are only within site scope if the asker requests feedback about a specific proposed topic.  General, unfocused questions like, &quot;What would be a good topic?&quot; will be closed as off topic.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;but “general, unfocused questions” are closed even without this policy as e.g. “not a real question.”  So, what exactly do you want to achieve by proposing this?  I think that it is better to rephrase the proposed policy to reflect what you really meant.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;---&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;_Update_: Based on your comment to this answer, I propose to rephrase the policy as follows:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; **POLICY**: Thesis topic questions are only within site scope if the asker requests feedback about a specific proposed topic.  Questions like “What would be a good topic?” will be deemed to be general and unfocused and therefore will be closed.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Some people have already interpreted the original proposal like this, but I believe that this wording is clearer in what exactly is being proposed.  At the same time, I removed the close reason “as off topic” because I agreed to [Kaveh](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/802/policy-questions-about-topic-for-research-project/811#811) that “not a real question” may be a better reason to use and that which reason to use is not of primary importance.&#xD;&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:4786:  <row Id="7176" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="824" RevisionGUID="24b0163b-eb35-4910-99e9-c727de9f4d4d" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="While problems without a clear demonstration that the author had put effort in are less-motivated for me to answer, the judgement of &quot;the evidence that they have took some work&quot; varies from people to people. It is especially hard to tell the difference when the question is from a new user of the site. They may have good question in mind, but failed to express the ideas in a suitable way, as defined by the site's policy.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;For sure we do not want a flood of homework problems and requests for checking the correctness of proofs to some famous open questions, but those have been already discussed and banned in [these][1] [discussions][2]. And furthermore, we have an alternative choice for questions which do not show their efforts - just ignore them.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;In summary, as long as the problems are within scope (that is, *research level* questions in *theoretical* CS), I see no immediate need to set a policy for restricting the type of the problems people ask, since that may introduce some side-effects.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/q/601/1800&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/274/is-it-ok-to-ask-about-the-correctness-of-preprints-on-crank-friendly-topics" />
./PostHistory.xml:4787:  <row Id="7177" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="851" RevisionGUID="9c9452d5-f1f0-40f5-873d-fcb3e9c694b9" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="As [Jukka wrote](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/845/reposted-questions/847#847), sometimes reposting is a good thing, so I cannot accept the current wording of the proposal.  I would like the policy of the form “If a question is reposted [under some conditions], it should be closed,” but I do not have a concrete proposal for the conditions now.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;On the other hand, it may be better to include answers as well as questions into the scope of the proposed policy.  There was at least one time where someone posted an answer which was eventually downvoted, he/she deleted the answer, and he/she reposted exactly the same answer.  I flagged the reposted answer as a spam with an explanation of the situation as a comment, and the reposted answer was eventually deleted by many spam flags.  I hope that this was an exceptional case, but it might be worth thinking about.  (But after all, that situation was handled without moderator interventions, which may suggest that a new policy does not have to cover the situations like that.)" />

./PostHistory.xml:4791:  <row Id="7181" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="897" RevisionGUID="d4df7f93-60d3-4e62-8373-a73c8a254470" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="Here's a question for all the candidates:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Promotion is one of the main issue to this site. There has been [a lot of discussion][1] on this topic, and our site is (slowly) growing with more active participates.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Still I think such a great site should be noticed more by the public (I mean, in the math and cs theory communities) by its high quality answers and low quantity of spam/cranky questions. And we're thirsting for experts in different areas in cs theory; more experts devoted to this site means more and more interesting questions and answers, and more usefulness the site is.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; What will you do to help promoting this site if you become a moderator?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/promotion" />
./PostHistory.xml:4792:  <row Id="7182" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="909" RevisionGUID="2993f899-88cc-4faa-9f18-5971d0a6cb52" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="For the benefit of later readers, here is a summary of the facts explained in [the answer by a site admin Rebecca Chernoff](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/907/nomination-statement-is-grayed-out-after-re-nomination/908#908) and the comments on it:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- A grayed out statement means that the nomination was withdrawn.&#xD;&#xA;- The intent of the admins was not to allow renomination after withdrawal.&#xD;&#xA;- The description of the election did not state this restriction explicitly.  In addition, there was a bug which made renomination seemingly possible.&#xD;&#xA;- In the case of Lev, the admins declared that the withdrawal was a mistake, and added him back to the candidate list.&#xD;&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:4793:  <row Id="7183" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="927" RevisionGUID="8e0f74b7-bc51-4aac-9d23-ba2b6f620590" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="To put things forward, I suggest a concrete text.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The current text:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; Theoretical Computer Science - Stack Exchange is for theoretical computer scientists and researchers in related fields.&#xD;&#xA;&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; A rough outline (inclusive, but not exclusive) of topics that are &quot;within scope&quot; for this site is as follows:&#xD;&#xA;&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; &gt; The field of theoretical computer science is interpreted broadly so as to include algorithms, data structures, computational complexity theory, distributed computation, parallel computation, VLSI, machine learning, computational biology, computational geometry, information theory, cryptography, quantum computation, computational number theory and algebra, program semantics and verification, automata theory, and the study of randomness.  **Work in this field is often distinguished by its emphasis on mathematical technique and rigor.**&#xD;&#xA;&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; General FAQs about using the Stack Exchange system are given below.  For specific questions more pertinent to this particular site, please visit the **[Official Theoretical Computer Science FAQ](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science)**.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Although this is not bad as a starting point, there are several shortcomings.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* As is often pointed out, it only mentions what theoretical computer science is and that it does not mention the expected level of questions.&#xD;&#xA;* Related to the first item, a list of alternative sites to ask questions is desirable.  The scope of our website is often better communicated by such a list.&#xD;&#xA;* The quotation is unclear about where it is quoted from.  In fact, it is originally quoted from the self-description of ACM SIGACT but it seems that SIGACT has modified this description after the text was copied, so it is kind of obsolete.  For example, the current list includes computational economics and omits the reference to VLSI, both of which are understandable.&#xD;&#xA;* I cannot see the point of emphasizing only the last sentence in the quotation from SIGACT.&#xD;&#xA;* The distinction between “general FAQs” and “official theoretical computer science FAQ” is confusing at best and makes no sense at worst.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I suggest to revise the above text to the following.  [http://math.stackexchange.com/faq/](http://math.stackexchange.com/faq/) is written very well, and I stole part of the general structure from it.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; **Theoretical Computer Science - Stack Exchange** is for theoretical computer scientists and researchers in related fields.  We welcome _research-level_ questions in _theoretical computer science_ (TCS).&#xD;&#xA;&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; Although there is no black-and-white distinction between research-level questions and non-research-level questions, questions are considered to be “research-level” roughly when they can be discussed between two professors or between two graduate students working on Ph.D.’s, but not usually between a professor and a typical undergraduate student.&#xD;&#xA;&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; For questions other than research-level questions in TCS, you may want to consider the following places to ask:&#xD;&#xA;&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; * Research-level mathematics — [Math Overflow](http://mathoverflow.net/)&#xD;&#xA;&gt; * Programming — [Stack Overflow](http://stackoverflow.com/)&#xD;&#xA;&gt; * General mathematics — [Mathematics - Stack Exchange](http://math.stackexchange.com/); they seem to accept also questions in TCS.&#xD;&#xA;&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; For an explanation of what TCS is, we refer you to the description of ACM Special Interest Group on Algorithms and Computation Theory (SIGACT):&#xD;&#xA;&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; &gt; TCS covers a wide variety of topics including algorithms, data structures, computational complexity, parallel and distributed computation, probabilistic computation, quantum computation, automata theory, information theory, cryptography, program semantics and verification, machine learning, computational biology, computational economics, computational geometry, and computational number theory and algebra.  Work in this field is often distinguished by its emphasis on mathematical technique and rigor. &#xD;&#xA;&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; Currently we have two separate lists of FAQs.  See also **[Official Theoretical Computer Science FAQ](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science)**.  Some of the most important entries in the other FAQ are:&#xD;&#xA;&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; * [What kind of questions are too basic?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/235#235)&#xD;&#xA;&gt; * [How to ask a good question?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/300/how-to-ask-a-good-question)&#xD;&#xA;&gt; * [How do I write formulas?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/237#237)&#xD;&#xA;&gt; * [My (wonderful!) question was closed!  What do I do now?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/361#361)&#xD;&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:4794:  <row Id="7184" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1009" RevisionGUID="52befc46-e102-4e51-a83b-ab535a9b47b2" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="Should we have a list of suggested top-level tags somewhere in the FAQ (the [tagging guide](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/228#228) seems like the obvious place), and encourage people to one of them?" />
./PostHistory.xml:4795:  <row Id="7185" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1043" RevisionGUID="96fe1438-a35e-405d-abbc-4c617462653e" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="My guess is that a lot of it has to do with that computer scientists also form a real-life community.  We read each other's papers, see each other at conferences, try to collaborate.  I think seeing people you know (or at least know of) in real life participate in the site helps new members want to join.  I don't know if the same thing is possible for quants as, from the little of what I know, strategies, etc., are closely guarded company secrets.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;But I'm sure there are other reasons why TCS-SE was successful, including our efforts in promotion, us using real names, and being a genuinely useful tool for researchers.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;EDIT below: &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;To explain some of our publicity efforts. We 1) have promoted TCS-SE at [conferences][1], 2) [blogged][2] and tweeted about the site, 3) wrote [articles][3] in professional magazines announcing the site, 4) tried to formally connect with [SIGACT][4] (a TCS professional group), 5) told our many peers about it.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Perhaps you can do the equivalent of some of these steps?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/1045/promoting-tcs-se-at-fcrc&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: http://blog.computationalcomplexity.org/2010/09/theory-social-network.html&#xD;&#xA;  [3]: http://portal.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=1907532&#xD;&#xA;  [4]: http://www.sigact.org/" />
./PostHistory.xml:4796:  <row Id="7186" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1058" RevisionGUID="c8a4ff74-00c3-44ea-8513-4d2ec044ace6" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="Updated version (March 20, 2011):&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; Use this tag if:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt;- **well-known open problems**: the problem is equivalent to a well-known [open problem](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open_problem) in the literature&#xD;&#xA;- **community open problems**: the question is not answered after considerable time and the community decides that the question is an open problem ([meta][1] can be used for discussions)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt;---&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt;[cstheory][2] is **not** the right place to ask **well-known open problems**. You should post questions you're actually seriously thinking about. If you're thinking about a well-known open problem, provide some background and ask about something specific related to the problem, like &quot;Such and such is a well-known open problem. So-and-so proposed this and that approach. Does anybody know if this aspect of their proposal can be made to work under these circumstances?&quot; If you want to contribute to (or view) a list of open problems, visit the [Open Problem Garden][3].&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt;If it turns out that a problem is equivalent to a well-known open problem, then the [tag:open-problem] tag is added. After that, the question essentially becomes, &quot;What is known about this problem? What are some possible ways to approach this problem? What are some ways that people have tried to attack it before, and with what results?&quot; That way, the cstheory thread for the problem becomes a repository of resources related to the problem. Perhaps the answers could be organized by approach, with an outline of the basic approach, followed by a horizontal rule and a summary of what is promising about the approach and why it doesn't give a complete solution.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt;To join the discussion about how cstheory should deal with open problems, go to [this][4] meta cstheory thread.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;---&#xD;&#xA;The [tag:open-problem]'s [tag wiki][5] is based on [MO][6]'s FAQ on open-problems.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/&#xD;&#xA;  [3]: http://garden.irmacs.sfu.ca/&#xD;&#xA;  [4]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/1058/tag-wiki-open-problem&#xD;&#xA;  [5]: http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/open-problem  &#xD;&#xA;  [6]: http://mathoverflow.net/faq#openproblems&#xD;&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:4797:  <row Id="7187" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1065" RevisionGUID="dce8bcbb-f240-4313-b597-aa66f9d8630b" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="Echoing Suresh, CSTheory is still some way from being successful, as it only attracts a small fraction of the TCS community.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;However, it is important that early users set a high standard, and it might be worth highlighting the especially thoughtful questions and perceptive answers at quant.SE to date.  Perhaps blog posts, an overview article on the Meta site, or an article in a quant publication such as Wilmott magazine could all assist.  Such initiatives have all worked for CSTheory as mentioned by other answers.  The list at http://quant.stackexchange.com/questions?sort=votes seems to be a great starting point, and I have found voting feedback at CSTheory useful in choosing which questions to highlight, for instance when adding entries to Radu Grigore's list at https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/446/broadening-the-scope-of-questions/985#985 and for https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/457/nominations-for-publicity-poster-at-focs&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Listing some of the &quot;greatest hits&quot; allows potential contributors to quickly find content that they are likely to find compelling, and also more firmly establishes the standard that contributors are going to aspire to.&#xD;&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:4798:  <row Id="7188" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="131" RevisionGUID="60953a12-4844-4141-b1d6-f31ef0c22094" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="I believe that These arXiv tags should not be used at all.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;My biggest concern is that these tags are not friendly to people who don't know arXiv (I'm one of these people). I have an interest in many computer science topics, but I rarely read computer science publications, have never browsed arVix, and really don't want to learn how to use such a system that I'll never use off of this site.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;However, I routinely read other publications of papers by the IEEE (in fact, I have the most recent issue of IEEE Transactions on Software Engineering next to me right now). Papers in this publication have &quot;index terms&quot; - keywords that describe what the paper is about. I grabbed a copy of the ACM Transactions on Software Engineering and Methodology out of my shelf, and they have three sections: categories and subject descriptions (which contain a code as well as textual descriptions), general terms, and additional key words/phrases. Whenever I've searched for papers in an online database, my matches have always come from the keywords sections or the body of the paper.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Looking at these tags, they are unwieldy. I have no idea what the tag means, and I wouldn't expect that most undergraduate computer scientists and software engineers would either. Given the responses to [my previous question here on Meta][1], you want to be inclusive of multiple skill levels. If I find it difficult to search and browse through questions based on tags (which are also used in the site search engine), I'll be less likely to use this site.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Instead of following MathOverflow, I believe that this exchange should follow a path closer to that of [Mathematics][2]. There are [three][3] [relevant][4] [discussions][5] on their Meta that I could find. The Mathematics community appears to be doing quite well in terms of having people of various skill levels (appears to range from undergraduate university-level mathematics on up), their tagging appears to be working quite well, and I honestly find it easier to read and search than MathOverflow.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;But really, if this Stack Exchange follows MathOverflow, I actually see someone else coming along and making another Computer Science exchange geared toward a broader audience, in terms of skill levels. I think that this exchange can avoid this splintering of the community (avoiding another Unix/Linux versus Ubuntu Stack Exchange problem) by catering to as many people of various skill levels and educational backgrounds as possible. Yes, you need a specific focus on certain topics and clearly define what is and is not on-topic, but you want to segregate based on those topics, not by knowledge or experience. By dumping the arVix style tags, you make it easy for everyone to find questions/answers, but also make the site friendlier to less knowledgeable and experienced people such as myself.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;However, that's not to say that arVix isn't useful. I believe Stack Exchanges have the &quot;tag wiki&quot; page that Stack Overflow has. It would be benefitial to identify which tags correspond to arVix topic areas and link to those topic areas in the tag wiki for a given tag.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Also, a technical consideration: The [tags are specified using rel=&quot;tag&quot;][8] in the source of a page. If you aren't familiar with microformats, search engines actually do pick up on them and they do help people find pages. People who do searches search for things like &quot;data structure&quot; and &quot;data structures&quot;, not &quot;cs.DS.data-structures&quot;. The tags should reflect what people are searching on Google and Bing so that they are brought to questions on Stack Exchanges that are relevant to their searches.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;----------&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I also want to address a few comments and other postings.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Another point that I've read in [some postings and comments here][6] is that you want to maintain compatibility with MathOverflow. I think this is a mistake. MathOverflow is a Stack Exchange 1.0 site and, last I heard, had no intention of migrating to Stack Exchange 2.0. However, there are a number of Stack Exchange 2.0 sites that might be of interest to this community in some way that are at various levels of existance - Stack Overflow (people might ask algorithm or data structure implementation questions here), Mathematics (which includes discrete mathematics, graph theory, combinatorics...), Statistical Analysis (which includes machine learning), Not Programming Related, Compiler Design, Software Engineering, Artificial Intelligence, Application Security, Machine Learning, Numerical Modeling and Simulation, Signal Processing, Operating systems Development, Natural Language Processing and Computational Linguistics, and Cryptography (and those are just the first 10 pages of proposals, sorted by progress). These are the communities that need to work together to decide what best belongs where, especially since it appears that there will be a feature to move questions between various Stack Exchange 2.0 sites. Unless things change on MathOverflow, you will never be able to migrate a question from here to MO. However, in the future, it will be possible to migrate questions to the exchanges I mentioned, and so far, none of them are using ArVix tagging.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;As [first mentioned in a comment here][7], some of the ArVix tags are long. Potentially too long to fit in the limit of a tag. The purpose of tags is to help people search and sort through questions. If you start abbreviating ArVix tags, you open up a whole new can of worms with the best way to abbreviate the tags.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/115&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: http://math.stackexchange.com/&#xD;&#xA;  [3]: https://math.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/48/should-mathoverflow-tag-prefixes-be-used&#xD;&#xA;  [4]: https://math.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/186/setting-things-straight-what-style-of-tags-are-we-going-to-be-using-when-we-laun&#xD;&#xA;  [5]: https://math.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/59/mathoverflow-tags-others&#xD;&#xA;  [6]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/41/arxiv-tags-vs-not/74#74&#xD;&#xA;  [7]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/41/arxiv-tags-vs-not/42#42&#xD;&#xA;  [8]: http://microformats.org/wiki/rel-tag" />
./PostHistory.xml:4799:  <row Id="7189" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1104" RevisionGUID="328e23bb-30d8-49f4-bbb2-5d4d29b8cc88" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="As Kaveh points out, the most bang for the buck is at the FCRC, which combines a large number of ACM conferences, and can also serve as advertisement for creating SE sites in other research domains. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;There are many people here who are probably already going to FCRC and might have papers at STOC/CCC/EC (I'm not one of them unfortunately - I'm going to a different conference at the same time). &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;However, all these conferences are well past their deadlines for paper submission and the program is probably mostly set. Also, these conferences don't usually have slots for promotional discussions. Possibly one good place to advertise this site would be at the STOC business meeting, where a discussion item could be placed on the agenda (and I can help with contacting the relevant people). &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;There's even been talk of [printing cstheory T-shirts][1], although that effort is languishing a little. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I've been busy with work and haven't had time to think about promotional efforts lately, but I'd be willing to help out in any way I can. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The next big conference after FCRC, whose program has NOT been set yet, is [FOCS 2011][2]&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;p.s Jeff, one of the MOST effective ways we could have done promotion would have been with a formal SIGACT tie-in (SIGACT runs the major theory conference happening at FCRC), but ever since Joel's post on a federated CS stackexchange, that has bee dormant (inspite my repeated queries). &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/1052/promotion-t-shirt-design&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: http://www.cs.ucla.edu/~rafail/FOCS11/" />
./PostHistory.xml:4800:  <row Id="7191" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1272" RevisionGUID="1283a471-3e3a-47a0-b794-c7a17f29692a" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="Here is my two cents:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;1. Down voting a post (answer/question) without commenting is NOT OK, it is against the norm, this is discussed in the last town hall meeting and there seemed to be a consensus among the people attending the meeting. Without a comment the purpose of the down-vote is not clear, it is not a constructive down-vote, and a user answering the question can get confused because he or she might not understand what is wrong with the answer or what behavior is being criticized.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;2. I don't find down-voting answers just because of answering a question reasonable. If the user answering the question has not done anything unreasonable and the answer is OK it does not deserve a down-vote IMO. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;3. On the other hand, it might be reasonable to down vote an answer when its poster has done something unreasonable or against the norms, e.g. [answering a question which is clearly homework](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/q/601/1037) (not just off-topic), it can be reasonable in such situation because the user is violating an agreed norm about not answering homework questions (and note that even in these cases the down-vote should be explained in a comment).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;4. If an answer is not: a. correct, b. well-written, c. an answer to the question; i.e. it is not a good answer to the question then it is reasonable (and even sometimes encouraged) to down-vote it, (but again, even in these cases the down-vote should be explained in a comment)." />
./PostHistory.xml:4801:  <row Id="7192" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1384" RevisionGUID="d13125e8-155a-429d-9ca8-a40365679036" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="**User crossposts a question on multiple sites.** &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;`It appears that you have crossposted this question *simultaneously*. While we don't mind a question being reposted, our [site policy](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/a/231/) only permits a repost after sufficient time has passed and you have not obtained the desired answer elsewhere. I am closing the question since simultaneous crossposting duplicates effort and fractures discussion. Please wait a few days and then if your question is still not answered request a reopening by flagging the question for moderator attention (after summarizing relevant discussions from other sites). `&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Which will appear as:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt;It appears that you have crossposted this question *simultaneously*. While we don't mind a question being reposted, our [site policy](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/a/231/) only permits a repost after sufficient time has passed and you have not obtained the desired answer elsewhere. I am closing the question since simultaneous crossposting duplicates effort and fractures discussion. Please wait a few days and then if your question is still not answered request a reopening by flagging the question for moderator attention (after summarizing relevant discussions from other sites).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;----&#xD;&#xA;Version 2:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;`It appears that you have crossposted this question *simultaneously*. While we don't mind a question being reposted, our [site policy](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/a/231/) prohibits simultaneous crossposting as it duplicates effort and fractures discussion. Crossposting is only permitted after sufficient time has passed and you have not obtained your desired answer elsewhere. When crossposting please summarize the relevant discussions from other sites in your question and link to the copies in both directions. `&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Renders as:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt;It appears that you have crossposted this question *simultaneously*. While we don't mind a question being reposted, our [site policy](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/a/231/) prohibits simultaneous crossposting as it duplicates effort and fractures discussion. Crossposting is only permitted after sufficient time has passed and you have not obtained your desired answer elsewhere. When crossposting please summarize the relevant discussions from other sites in your question and link to the copies in both directions." />
./PostHistory.xml:4802:  <row Id="7194" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1436" RevisionGUID="5eed53ab-9427-4bda-9684-221d9c4869e4" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="I am in full agreement with you. Please see [this](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/628/a-page-for-most-recent-significatly-modified-questions-not-tag-edits-and-who-h) and [this](http://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/69659/a-page-for-questions-sorted-based-on-last-significant-modification-not-tag-edit). We have already asked for this feature, SE didn't agree. (Maybe they will change their opinion if more people complain about it. I think at least we should get something like [this](http://stackoverflow.com/?tab=interesting)).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I edit questions which don't use one of the top level tags (for classification reason). I would prefer if people use one of them when asking a question and I wouldn't need to do this retagging. I try to restrict my tag edits to the questions on the front page so it has a less annoying effect. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;ps: I don't use RSS/email to get the updates so maybe this is a bigger problem for people using them.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;pps: I think a reasonable solution is to have something similar to [the minor edit checkbox on Wikipedia][1]. It works on Wikipedia well even with completely anonymous users, surely would not create a problem if the edits are made by high rep users.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Help:Minor_edit" />

./PostHistory.xml:4806:  <row Id="7198" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="146" RevisionGUID="575738b3-9cc9-476d-bab4-716fd6e7e69b" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="I asked this question as a vehicle for answering questions about [my statement that &quot;I'm not convinced the site has a future&quot;][1].  I don't think we are yet on course to be a successful Q&amp;A site for a few reasons:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;1. We have no users who I would call names to conjure with.  This matters for any site: e.g., SO has many active users who are highly recognised experts for a large number of topics, and the SX folk think that this is essential to SOs success and will be essential to the sites coming through the SX beta phase. For academic Q&amp;A sites, as opposed to problem-solving sites I think this is even more important.  How important has Terence Tao's endorsement of MO been to that site's success?  The other two beta sites I've participated in, math.SX and tex.SX, had done far better by their 10th day.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;2. We have a lack of high reputation users.  We don't have any 1k+ reputation users at all, so apart from the SX moderators, we have no-one who can edit weak questions, let alone access the moderation tools. It takes five 500+ users to close a question without moderator actions; we have 8.  We have only 23x 250+ users who can retag.  To some extent, this is a fact of life about the early public beta stage, but other sites have done better.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;3. Very little interest has been shown, or effort put into in the things that need to be done on meta to make the site a success.  Shane is our distinguished exception, Suresh has put in some effort, as well.  Besides these two, we have a list of fairly undifferentiated potential moderators: I haven't seen a whole lot of indication as to why one 500+ user would make a better moderator than another.  Work on the FAQ is nonexistent.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;That said, interesting questions have been asked and answered, we've got a pretty clear idea of our scope, and it's early days.  Call me moderately pessimistic, and since I have discovered that I am suddenly what counts for a high-reputation user around here, I'm going to start making an effort.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;**Postscript**&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I don't think we have exactly what I would call &quot;names to conjure with&quot;, but maybe that's too much to expect in TCS, which is much more balkanized that maths, and where the famous names are that much older, and that much less involved in web-based social networking (but, you know, Alan Kay has [an account on SO][2]).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;That said, the comments to this post have shown what a breadth there are of scientists who have made indubitably major contributions to the field, and there has been the beginnings of what I hope will be an influx of users have been excellent contributors to MO.  Lance Fornow, in particular, is a young scientist with a high profile.  I am now officially relaxed about point #1.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/67/who-should-the-moderators-be/122#122&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: http://stackoverflow.com/users/48710/alan-kay" />
./PostHistory.xml:4807:  <row Id="7200" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="148" RevisionGUID="2f2d7908-861a-4179-b19e-67c9d327dc06" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="&gt; Do you have general thoughts about the future of the site?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I see a lot of potential here. I'm a software engineer, but I'm dealing with a lot of topics at work that touch on topics here - algorithms and data structures (especially performance), cryptography, stenography, security, as well as concurrent and distributed systems (but these are more from an applied standing rather than the theoretical that is more appropriate here). Even taking a look back at previous jobs, having a Stack Exchange to ask questions and provide answers about computer science topics I've encountered would have been helpful a long time ago.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;If anything is going to be a problem, it's going to be scaring away people who aren't experts in the field. Honestly, I'm not that thrilled with the current state of TCS. It's following MathOverflow too closely and is catering to the experts. What makes Stack Overflow (and even Mathematics and Statistical Analysis) so great is that people of various levels of knowledge and experience are using the exact same site. The problem with MathOverflow (and TCS is going down this road) is that it focuses on the experts and the researchers. TCS does have some college students using it, but many are in a program or that deals exclusively with theoretical CS, and these people appear to be doing OK. However, people like me who have a more practical background, but are interested in the theoretical side of things without a formal education, aren't made to feel as welcome (or at least, that's the impression I get).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I think part of the problem is that there is no hands on leadership. This Stack Exchange was proposed by Anand Kulkarni ([meta profile][1], [site profile][2]). Yet this user has less than 200 reputation, has only posted 3 things (1 question, 2 answers) on the main site, and has only posted 2 answers on the meta. So right from Day 1, the person who came up with this idea hasn't been involved in the site. Stack Exchange doesn't give you the tools you need to lay the framework for a site until it goes into Private Beta, and by then, it's too late for the person who came up with this idea to propose a framework of how the system works in his/her mind, since other people have already started to use the site.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Given the focus on experts/experienced people and lack of hands on leadership (although some people are emerging as leaders, so this might turn around with the addition of moderators), I wouldn't be surprised if this Stack Exchange doesn't make it. And I think that it would be a shame if it didn't.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; Are you pleased with the quality and interest of the questions and answers you've seen on the main site?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I've asked [one question][3], and I'm quite pleased with the answer I got. The way I worded my question, I didn't expect someone to take the time to write up such a detailed answer. But they did, and I'm better off because of it.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; How well do you think we are doing at resolving issues and conflicts that arise?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I think this is a problem with the Stack Exchange system. The fact that there is no place for meta discussions until the site goes into private beta is a bad thing. So right now, we (and I think several Stack Exchanges have had this problem) have lots of people who read the description of the site, but then got there and were disappointed because the description didn't capture what was really happening. Because of this, everyone comes to Meta after there are already questions and answers posted on the site, time is passing, more questions/answers are being posted, and there's no agreed upon method to do things.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I think it will get better once there are more high reputation users and moderators on the main site, but I do think that this is something that the Stack Exchange team needs to address.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/users/71/anand-kulkarni&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/users/71&#xD;&#xA;  [3]: http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/585/what-is-the-difference-between-a-second-preimage-attack-and-a-collision-attack" />
./PostHistory.xml:4808:  <row Id="7201" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1485" RevisionGUID="20ff12c0-f552-4996-848c-18d308ed1b04" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="@Janoma,&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;1. The issue of down voting without commenting has been discussed extensively and the current view is that commenting is not required but encouraged.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;2. Closing is not a big deal as is explained in the comment template says. A question can be reopened if it is deemed suitable for the site by 5 high rep members of the community. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;3. It is not easy to see whether a question is research-level or not unless the author of the question explains the motivation and background. It is normal to close a question which looks like non-research-level when there is not any motivation or when it seems that the author does not understand the elementary stuff.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;4. The question you have linked to is by student working on a problem set. IIRC, the question already had a -1 vote when I posted the comment. And again as the *full* comment says:&#xD;&#xA;&gt; Welcome to cstheory, a Q&amp;A site for *research-level* questions in *theoretical computer science* (TCS). Your question does not appear to be a research-level question in TCS. **Please see the [FAQ] for more information on what is meant by this and suggestions for sites that might welcome your question. Finally, if your question is closed for being out of scope, and you believe you can edit the question to make it a research-level question, please feel free to do so. Closing is not permanent and questions can be reopened, check the [FAQ] for more information.**&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; The FAQ also contains an item [My (wonderful!) question got closed! What do I do now?][1]. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; I think we have emphasized it enough that closing is not a big deal. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;5. Further more, neither of the questions that you have linked to have got closed in the first place, so I am not sure if they are examples of what you are claiming. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;6. If you think there is nice question hidden inside a question, then you can make suggestions to the OP to improve the question, or ask a new question yourself.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;7. The opinion at the time was that we are not closing the question too quickly, there is no problem with closing clearly off-topic questions as soon as possible. If later the question is improved to an on-topic question it can be reopened. As you could see from the state of this discussion before your new answer, it was accepted that quickly closing these questions is fine so I am not sure why you expected a change regrading in closing them.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;ps: next time, please start a new discussion by posting a question in place of posting an answer to an old discussion.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/361#361" />
./PostHistory.xml:4809:  <row Id="7202" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="152" RevisionGUID="2b3ec835-15ec-48dc-9302-3bc8f8d8071d" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="For what it's worth: I think that the site is coming along very well, especially at this early stage.  I'm not a part of the community by any stretch of the imagination, but view this as an exciting opportunity to learn about a field for which I have a great interest.  And I think that the site has struck a good balance between being expert friendly, while also allowing some questions that can open up the field to non-experts.  &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;As others have mentioned, the core members of the field would have to comprise of a fairly small number.  Many of the top ranked contributors to the site are clearly experts.  This is a real difference to the other stackexchange sites (putting MO aside for a minute).  While there may be a valid concern about the possibility of too many CW questions (and I am probably one of the top perpetrators), this hasn't been an overwhelming problem: the vast majority of questions have been properly on-topic, and this should only continue to improve as the site develops more of a clear heuristic.  &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;We also have a real opportunity to use this site in a meaningful way.  One trivial example is [my idea for promoting the site][1].  I would love to see more &quot;meta&quot; thought being given to *how we can use the site beyond known Q&amp;A to tackle real open problems*.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;If anything, it would seem that the primary challenge is getting experts from the different branches of TCS.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/58/how-to-promote-the-site/137#137" />

./PostHistory.xml:4814:  <row Id="7207" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="172" RevisionGUID="62185504-0937-492e-8289-c1b04f6dd385" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="Given the large overlap between math and TCS, my recommendation for questions that might seem out of scope for this site is to do nothing. Either they won't get much attention, or someone will post something, indicating that the question is within scope. Since we don't have a problem with [cross posting to MO within limits][1], that seems the most effective 'let the community decide' strategy. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/25/material-to-supplement-the-faq/36#36" />
./PostHistory.xml:4815:  <row Id="7208" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="179" RevisionGUID="05550af1-47bc-46d1-892b-bd08e9c217e2" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="# [Jeff Erickson](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/users/111/jeffe)&#xD;&#xA;[(meta)](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/users/111/jeffe)" />
./PostHistory.xml:4816:  <row Id="7209" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="188" RevisionGUID="fdb452bb-950b-4c02-9378-6ba645726543" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="This question builds on a comment of Shane's in a [previous meta post][1] on what can be achieved using a theory Q&amp;A site.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I've spent a good deal of time on Jeff Erickson's lovely problem about [unshuffling a string][2], and during the proposal phase, on his question about the complexity of minimum sequences in generalized Rubik's cube.  However, I haven't posted any responses to those questions because I didn't end up with an answer.  &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Most of what I've done is discover dead ends and approaches that don't work.  These might be useful for someone to know so that they don't spend time on the same issue or if they'd like to pick up where I left off.  Unfortunately, the Q&amp;A format doesn't seem naturally suited to this style of inquiry.   A wrong answer isn't an &quot;answer&quot; per se, and a detailed discussion won't fit in a non-nested comment thread.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; The question: how can the CSTheory Q&amp;A&#xD;&#xA;&gt; format better be used to support these&#xD;&#xA;&gt; kinds of parallel group investigations&#xD;&#xA;&gt; into problems?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;One idea is to adopt the convention that &quot;answers&quot; to open questions are to be regarded as a discussion of possible approaches, rather than literal answers or partial answers to the question, then to encourage development of these approaches in the comments.  The downside is that these comments are not nested.  &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; Another possibility is to fork new questions concerning particular avenues of inquiry with links back to the parent question, perhaps with a dedicated &quot;subproblem&quot; tag; this might lead to a messy proliferation of subquestions.  &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Has any better format been discovered for collaborative investigation of open problems on other StackExchange sites, in particular, MO?  Are there other features in StackExchange we can activate to support this process?  Or is it better to instead restrict these kinds of investigations to blogs and wikis, as was done in Polymath? &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]:  https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/144/how-are-we-doing/152#152&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/34/how-hard-is-unshuffling-a-string" />
./PostHistory.xml:4817:  <row Id="7210" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1610" RevisionGUID="a183b24b-7e92-4b56-8715-c0beac46fde8" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="will take a stab at answering this based on comments &amp; culture here &amp; sketch something out that can be used as a point for further discussion because its a direction/approach Ive been thinking about &amp; looking into &amp; even veering towards myself &amp; its key to this group. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;this question is probably a little too hypothetical. in principle you could build a paper by stringing together some stackexchange answers but it would be unusual. as mod kaveh writes, each question must stand on its own separate merit and also note, few people regularly post questions here or with high frequency esp those with high rep, and there is some possibility that frequent questions are actually informally frowned on via the voting mechanisms &amp; current collective voting tendencies. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;the pattern is more in general that high rep users answer random newcomer questions. also, it is unlikely that you would get solid answers to all the separate (presumably nontrivial) questions.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;basically yes, that is part of the _raison d'etre_ of the group, to occasionally collaboratively generate scientific research to theoretical computer science in general &amp; complexity theory in particular (complexity theory entries even were once highlighted here in css formatting). however the conventions around this are new &amp; still being established as we speak.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;1st, use the stackexchange search engine highly extensively and also the tag system, both can be very effective. find every relevant post to your paper or subject. figure out the best knowledge that is posted on the group. figure out the border between the known and unknown and what is posted vs not posted. this also requires close familiarity with nearby papers. it helps to bookmark or &quot;favorite&quot; all related posts on here &amp; elsewhere. use the related posts column on the right also. mix this with heavy cross use of google. in some cases you may find an expert on here posting on the subj. you can look at their own answers &amp; look at their papers.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;next, try posting a single carefully crafted question totally centered on your subject and your paper and what you're thinking of establishing. its a delicate mix between the general (background) and the specific (the new result/concept you're aiming for). as if you have a single chance to ask the experts what you'd most want to know but what you also most think they'd be able to answer. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;responses will help you figure out what is known by the crowd but also how relevant it is to this group based on reaction in form of comments, enthusiasm, voting, etc. it has to be at a &quot;just right difficulty&quot; between too easy [not research] and too hard [you wont get replies/answers]. it takes some time to find that balance &amp; its an ongoing challenge. dont assume that if there is a good answer, someone will post it. dont assume that if people post answers, those are the best possible. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;you will prob find if you are very focused that there are two gaps. one is the gap between what you want to establish in your paper and what is established in related literature. the other gap is what you can actually find out by using this group (both by searching it and posting questions). these two gaps are interrelated. you can judge whether you can build on all this with meaningful new results. but those key results will basically have to be generated by you, nobody else, unless you have found _offline_ collaborators in your own professional circles. you can use other results as a &quot;jumping off&quot; point.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;so finally, leverage everything youve found and write a paper. if the answers on stackexchange are very notable and innovative, you can cite them in your paper using the stackexchange urls/&quot;cite&quot; feature. this is really not much different than citing blogs, which is occasionally done in real scientific papers. however note that this is somewhat problematic because content on here can disappear very easily due to voting, moderators, users [who can delete stuff] etc...&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;probably the best and most successful model of all this invented so far is polymath[3] with a difficult problem and published arxiv paper to its credit but keep in mind this is a project started by a field medalist Gowers and promoted by his friends eg Tao and Kalai who are also very elite/accomplished theorists.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;[1] https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/352/how-will-you-cite-a-discussion-on-this-site-in-your-paper&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;[2] https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/188/how-can-we-collaboratively-investigate-open-problems?rq=1&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;[3] [Massively collaborative mathematics/Polymath](http://www.siam.org/news/news.php?id=1731)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;[4] https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/383/highlights-of-cstheory-stackexchange-com&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;[5] https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/697/what-interesting-open-problems-have-been-asked-on-this-stackexchange&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;[6] https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/1316/attacking-open-questions&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;[7] https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/1257/references-to-cstheory-in-the-literature&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;[8] https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/784/original-proofs-generated-on-the-parent-site&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;[9] [Questions answered. in theory.](http://www.cs.utah.edu/~suresh/cstheory.pdf)&#xD;&#xA;(early tcs.se ad &amp; highlights reel for the beta period by mod Suresh)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;[10] https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/300/how-to-ask-a-good-question&#xD;&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:4818:  <row Id="7211" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="192" RevisionGUID="5fbd20d5-36b3-4739-895c-9fab642b6aef" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="&gt; **Possible Duplicate:**  &#xD;&#xA;&gt; [Who should the moderators be?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/67/who-should-the-moderators-be)  &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&lt;!-- End of automatically inserted text --&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The nine users who have 6+ votes on [Who should the moderators be?][1] are:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* Suresh -accepted&#xD;&#xA;* Shane - accepted&#xD;&#xA;* Joshua - declined&#xD;&#xA;* András - declined&#xD;&#xA;* Noam&#xD;&#xA;* David - accepted&#xD;&#xA;* Ryan - accepted&#xD;&#xA;* Anand - accepted&#xD;&#xA;* Jukka&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;It would be great if the others accepted or declined, but we can make a slate from that list:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;1. Suresh&#xD;&#xA;2. Shane&#xD;&#xA;3. Ryan&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/67/who-should-the-moderators-be" />
./PostHistory.xml:4819:  <row Id="7212" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2682" RevisionGUID="edcd5bd1-5a93-49fe-b066-6bf0fba76b89" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="##An updated cross-posting FAQ item?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The [old one](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/231#231) is restricted to MO. &#xD;&#xA;Here is a possible update:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; While we don't mind an on-topic question being reposted, &#xD;&#xA;our [site policy][1] prohibits simultaneous crossposting as &#xD;&#xA;it duplicates effort and fractures discussion. &#xD;&#xA;Cross-posting is only permitted if:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; * it is not simultaneous, and &#xD;&#xA;&gt; * the OP has waited a reasonable time (a few days) without receiving a satisfying answer before posting it on another site, and&#xD;&#xA;&gt; * the OP has provided links in both directions between the copies.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; The OP is expected to keep all copies up-to-date, &#xD;&#xA;e.g. if one copy is clarified based on the comments, &#xD;&#xA;the OP should clarify the other one also. &#xD;&#xA;Similarly, &#xD;&#xA;if she receives a satisfying answer on the other site, &#xD;&#xA;she should post an answer on cstheory linking to the full answer&#xD;&#xA;(or do better by posting a complete answer &#xD;&#xA;tailored to cstheory based on what she has leaned). &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; In the case that the cross-posting does not satisfy these conditions &#xD;&#xA;moderators close the question as not-constructive and &#xD;&#xA;will explain the policy in a comment: &#xD;&#xA;the OP should wait a week and &#xD;&#xA;if she does not receive a satisfying answer by then &#xD;&#xA;she can flag the question for moderator attention and &#xD;&#xA;ask for the question to be reopened.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/a/231/" />
./PostHistory.xml:4820:  <row Id="7213" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="221" RevisionGUID="f015db86-b7db-4b52-a4e4-3951593de631" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="This is relevant to the [other thread][1] too, but I thought I'll just post my comment here. It is a combined answer to the questions asked in both threads.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The other question, which reads &quot;Are specific questions about Theorem X in paper Y fine?&quot; actually covers two types of questions from posters.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Type 1: Questions like &quot;How does one reach eq 3.14 from eq 3.15 in paper X, page Y? I tried the following ... but it didn't work.&quot;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I think most people would agree that these questions are appropriate for this site. The other type of question is the following:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Type 2: &quot;How does the proof of Theorem 3 in [citation] handle the case of disconnected graphs? I don't see how it works for that case.&quot;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;This question might be pointing out a genuine error in a paper. But then again it might just be something the poster did not understand. What I want to say is that it is often hard to tell whether there is a mistake/confusion/non-understanding on your part, or an error in the paper. These correspond to type 1 and 2 questions respectively. If the poster is not able to distinguish between the two types of questions, and if we make it a policy to only allow Type 1 questions and not Type 2, this will be hard for posters.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Would a solution like the following work?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;We allow both type of questions. Questions of type 1 are handled as they usually are by the community. If we realize that it is a question of type 2 (i.e., there are answers which indicate that there is a genuine mistake in the paper), then a moderator emails the author of the paper and informs him of the thread, and offers to have the thread deleted.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Now the author may choose to have the thread deleted, or reply on the thread explaining how the poster has misunderstood and it is not an error, or reply thanking the poster for finding the error, or do nothing, etc. (I am assuming that moderators can delete threads.)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/204/are-specific-questions-about-theorem-x-in-paper-y-fine" />
./PostHistory.xml:4821:  <row Id="7214" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2688" RevisionGUID="18871795-a2fb-4dd4-b843-1ae856dd37c7" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="### Not a preprints discussion forum:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt;Questions about the general correctness of unpublished preprints and solutions of major open problems are off-topic.&#xD;&#xA;For more information, see [our policy for questions about preprints](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/274/is-it-ok-to-ask-about-the-correctness-of-preprints-on-crank-friendly-topics/281#281)." />

Crossposting is permitted after a week has passed without a satisfying answer elsewhere. When crossposting please summarize the relevant discussions from other sites in your question and link between the copies in both directions.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;$ $&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt;`Our [site policy](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/a/231/) prohibits ***simultaneous***  **crossposting**: it duplicates effort and fractures discussion. ./PostHistory.xml:4823:  <row Id="7216" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="225" RevisionGUID="c5018fb3-c1bc-4a6c-9bae-f948bd884530" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="This is the official site FAQ for Theoretical Computer Science. This question will contain a list of questions, with each question linking to a **single** answer. If there is prior discussion on an answer, or you wish to discuss a particular answer, please create a separate meta question and link to it (so that this FAQ remains uncluttered). &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The scope of this site:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; - [Are questions about *[this area of computer science]* on-topic here?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/234#234)&#xD;&#xA; - [What kind of questions are too basic?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/235#235)&#xD;&#xA; - [Specific questions about Theorem X in paper Y?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/238#238)&#xD;&#xA; - [I'm looking for ideas for a project. Can I ask here ?][1] &#xD;&#xA; - [My question is not a research-level question in TCS, where can I ask it?][2]&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;How to use this site:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; - [Can I discuss questions and answers on cstheory.sx?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/232#232)&#xD;&#xA; - [I can't see any formulas!](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/237#237)&#xD;&#xA; - [What is a *[Math Processing Error]*?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/237#237)&#xD;&#xA; - [How do I write formulas?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/237#237)&#xD;&#xA; - [How do I copy-and-paste a formula?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/233#233)&#xD;&#xA; - [There are too many questions on boring topic X that I don't care about][3]. &#xD;&#xA; - [What is meta ?
