What do I do now?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/361#361)&#xD;&#xA; - [How do I delete my own question/answer?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/376#376)&#xD;&#xA; - [Why can't I comment on my own question?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/424#424)&#xD;&#xA; - [What does “closed as off topic” mean?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/663/what-does-closed-as-off-topic-mean)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;How to help the site:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;This site is run by YOU, and your help is needed to maintain it as a valuable resource for the community. Here are some ways in which you can help (once you acquire enough reputation points):&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; - [What if I see a question that I think is inappropriate/off topic/offensive ?][5] &#xD;&#xA; - [I did a search for a tag, and a mislabelled question came up. what do I do ?][6] &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Best practices:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; - [How to ask a good question?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/300/how-to-ask-a-good-question)&#xD;&#xA; - [Should I use my real name?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/236#236)&#xD;&#xA; - [When should I downvote/upvote?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/230#230)&#xD;&#xA; - [What kinds of tags should I use?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/228#228)&#xD;&#xA; - [When should I use the &quot;community wiki&quot; flag?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/239#239)&#xD;&#xA; - [What is the policy on crossposting to/from MathOverflow or other StackExchange sites?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/231#231)&#xD;&#xA; - [Useful resources to check before asking questions](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/229#229)&#xD;&#xA; - [My answer turned out to be incorrect. ./PostHistory.xml:4824:  <row Id="7217" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2712" RevisionGUID="e8262087-2e9e-4d50-ad8b-25da4966bd51" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="I have a request.  It would be nice if the moderators here would avoid migrating low-quality questions to CS.SE.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I noticed recently a few low-quality questions that were migrated to the Computer Science Stack Exchange (CS.SE) site.  I would suggest that we avoid doing that.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* If it's a good question, and on-topic for CS.SE, I definitely encourage you to migrate to CS.SE.  For instance, if it is not research-level but would be a reasonable question, migrating to CS.SE is a great idea.  Go for it!&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* But if it's a bad question -- one that would be a bad question for CS.SE -- please don't migrate it to CS.SE.  If it's a bad question, just close it, don't migrate it.  Please don't make CS.SE a dumping ground for bad questions.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* If it's a good question -- well-researched, on-topic, focused, narrow -- but has some English/grammar problems, don't let that stop you from migrating.  If it's just the English, we can edit it over at CS.SE.  But if it is a fundamentally bad question -- e.g., not well-researched, or a duplicate, or unclear -- I personally don't think it should be migrated over to CS.SE&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;One recent example: http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/q/18536/5038.  In my opinion, that question shouldn't have been migrated to CS.SE.  It is not a good fit for the Computer Science Stack Exchange.  The question does not show evidence of effort.  It asks a question about a topic that is already covered by reference questions at CS.SE, with no evidence that the question-asker was aware of that.  These issues are not something that those of us at CS.SE can fix through simple edits to the question.  Of course, that's just one example.  I don't mean to pick on that one or focus on that one too much.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Kaveh explains that the CS.SE admins specifically requested that &quot;badly written&quot; questions are still OK to migrate to CS.SE.  I didn't realize that!  That explains a lot.  Perhaps that's something we should discuss.  I'm not sure whether &quot;badly written&quot; refers to the English/grammar, or to more fundamental issues (like whether it's a good question, whether it is well-researched, whether it is on-topic and focused and detailed and not a duplicate).  If the former, I agree, English/grammar problems should not be a barrier to migration.  If the latter, well, I guess I might have a slight difference of opinion with the CS.SE admins -- maybe that's something we need to discuss on CS.meta, instead of here.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I certainly don't mean to imply that this is a huge, systemic problem that requires major changes to migration, and I don't mean to imply the moderators here are doing anything wrong (I think the moderators are doing a great job!).  Overall I think the process is generally working well.  I just wanted to suggest a minor refinement that I think might make things work better on CS.SE.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Related:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/q/1086/5038&#xD;&#xA;* https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/q/1285/5038&#xD;&#xA;* https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/q/1507/5038&#xD;&#xA;* [Do we want CSTheory.SE to migrate bad questions over here?](http://meta.cs.stackexchange.com/q/691/755)" />
./PostHistory.xml:4825:  <row Id="7218" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="229" RevisionGUID="3f947333-58fb-401b-b109-eb1381199c8e" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="Useful resources&#xD;&#xA;----------------&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Complexity classes:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- [Complexity Zoo](http://qwiki.stanford.edu/wiki/Complexity_Zoo). In questions that are related to complexity classes, it's a good idea to first check the Zoo and see if your question is already answered there – or if it's a well-known open problem. The Zoo also defines the standard naming convention for complexity classes on this site.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Hardness and approximability:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- [A compendium of NP optimization problems](http://www.nada.kth.se/~viggo/wwwcompendium/).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Problems related to graph families:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- [Information System on Graph Classes and their Inclusions (ISGCI)](http://www.graphclasses.org/).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;---&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Related discussion: [[1]](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/25/material-to-supplement-the-faq/44#44)" />
./PostHistory.xml:4826:  <row Id="7219" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2730" RevisionGUID="48137994-e054-4184-a275-eb63335337da" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="**A small note and update about migration**&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;As you know only moderators can migrate questions to CS.SE right now and this is unlikely to change until CS.SE graduates. I think Suresh generally does not migrate questions, Dave does sometimes, but most of the migrations to CS.SE was performed by me. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Since the discussions here and on meta.CS.SE I have stopped migrating questions except in very special cases because people do not seem to be happy with them and migration has become too complicated (check if there is a duplicate or reference questions, etc.). In practice questions are either [**OK here**](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/2706/) or [**not OK there**](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/posts/2714/).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;So **in practice we don't migrate questions to CS.SE anymore**. Please keep this in mind when commenting or flagging for migration." />
./PostHistory.xml:4827:  <row Id="7220" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="230" RevisionGUID="1d30c3a8-c759-4af9-bf95-d18d7e0f5795" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="When should I downvote/upvote?&#xD;&#xA;------------------------------&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;First of all, try to vote **often**. You have a budget of 30 votes per day, and it is perfectly fine to use up your daily quota.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Here are some guidelines that you can use to decide whether you should upvote, downvote, or not vote at all:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- **Upvote** only questions and answers you understand but do so whenever they are of high quality. To evaluate quality for a question think of whether it is interesting, whether it is at the appropriate level, whether it is well formulated. To evaluate quality for an answer think whether it addresses the question and whether you learned something from it. Above all, use your judgement.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- **Downvote** a question only if it is clearly not at the appropriate level or it is clearly not well formulated. Downvote an answer only if it is technically wrong, or does not address the question, or is so badly formulated that it is impossible to understand. You should leave a comment explaining why you downvoted whenever you do so, unless that would duplicate an already existing comment.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- You should **ignore a question/answer's current score** when you decide on *your* vote.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;You can't upvote or downvote your own question/answer.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;---&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Related discussion:&#xD;&#xA;[[1]](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/6/vote-early-and-often)&#xD;&#xA;[[2]](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/25/material-to-supplement-the-faq/54#54)&#xD;&#xA;[[3]](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/108/ethics-of-upvoting-own-answer)" />
./PostHistory.xml:4828:  <row Id="7221" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2758" RevisionGUID="e17cba6f-d40f-4e52-9cd1-f0943bcd92e5" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="There has been questions about similar resources like videos: [What videos should everybody watch?](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1198/what-videos-should-everybody-watch) but they are very very infrequent.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Soft questions are considered a gray area in the scope and need way more care in asking.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;See [tag:soft-question] tag, [good subjective, bad subjective](http://blog.stackoverflow.com/2010/09/good-subjective-bad-subjective/), and [Is my question suitable for cstheory?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/a/2662/)" />
./PostHistory.xml:4829:  <row Id="7222" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="234" RevisionGUID="3dea4a3e-370c-4cb0-b137-385f8c860ab3" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="Are questions about *[this area of computer science]* on-topic here?&#xD;&#xA;----------------------&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;As [our FAQ](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/faq) explains, we interpret &quot;Theoretical Computer Science&quot; broadly. Roughly speaking, the subareas of computer science that put **emphasis on mathematical technique and rigor** are on-topic.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Here are some further clarifications regarding possible borderline cases:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; - **Pure math**: if the problem has some applications in theoretical computer science, it is welcome here – [more discussion](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/169/when-are-areas-of-pure-math-that-are-used-in-cs-considered-on-topic).&#xD;&#xA; - **Artificial intelligence**: theoretical aspects of artificial intelligence are on-topic; philosophical questions are probably off-topic – [more discussion](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/114/cstheory-vs-ai-stackexchange-site).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;---&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Further discussion:&#xD;&#xA;[[1]](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/115/what-level-and-types-of-questions-are-appropriate-for-theoretical-computer-scienc)&#xD;&#xA;[[2]](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/119/our-domain-scope-specifically-defined)" />
./PostHistory.xml:4830:  <row Id="7223" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2761" RevisionGUID="29631959-56b1-4b6c-babc-c8975fb2f741" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="Some sites have a custom close reason to handle this kind of cases. For example, on [Unix &amp; Linux](http://unix.stackexchange.com/):&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; Questions describing a problem that can't be reproduced and seemingly went away on its own (or went away when a typo was fixed) are off-topic as they are unlikely to help future readers.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I doubt that CSTheory gets enough questions of this type to warrant a custom close reason. If a question is about understanding a point in a research paper, then&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; * either the point is a subtle one that others may miss as well (or the paper omitted a step of the proof), in which case the question is potentially useful to anyone reading the paper and should be answered and remain open;&#xD;&#xA; * or the point is a basic one that the asker happened to miss but where other readers aren't likely to stumble, in which case closing as off-topic with a custom comment plus a comment to explain is fine.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Basically, I agree with what you did, except for one thing: don't use the words “too localized”, which is historical Stack Exchange jargon that most people won't understand. Write something like&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; This question concerns a basic point and is unlikely to be useful to future visitors, [therefore](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/2748/what-to-do-with-too-localized-questions) I am voting to close it.&#xD;&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:4831:  <row Id="7224" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2765" RevisionGUID="e051458f-46de-4de7-b34f-831945962c9c" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="What is your personal view of the role of CSTheory: in particular, please post an answer to [Gil Kalai's question here][1]. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/2752/what-tcs-stackexchange-is-for-and-what-is-your-aim-in-participation" />
./PostHistory.xml:4832:  <row Id="7225" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="236" RevisionGUID="11214a67-7509-4704-b202-048a562db049" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="Do I need to use my real name?&#xD;&#xA;------------------------------&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;You do not have to, but you are strongly encouraged to use your real name. We hope that this site will become a valuable resource for the research community, and that reputation earned here will translate into reputation outside as well. Using your real name will help make that connection. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;We also hope that research discussions on this site will occasionally lead to actual citations in papers, or even new research ! From that perspective, using your real name will help immensely. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;---&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Related discussion:&#xD;&#xA;[[1]](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/4/on-using-actual-names)&#xD;&#xA;[[2]](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/187/policy-on-suspending-users)&#xD;&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:4833:  <row Id="7226" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2824" RevisionGUID="a643c9a8-bbfb-41e3-b88d-ed6fb3934c06" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="As [Artem Kaznatcheev notes](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/a/2823), comments on Stack Exchange sites are really designed to be an ephemeral &quot;scratchpad&quot; for improving questions and answers.  They provide very limited markup options, they're not searchable (using the internal SE search; Google and other external search engines do index *some* of them), and they're subject to deletion at any time for any or no reason.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The idea is that, once the question has been solved through discussion in the comments, the solution should be written up as an answer (or incorporated into an existing answer), crediting the contributors to the discussion as needed. At that point, the &quot;scratchpad&quot; comments are no longer needed, and may be deleted.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;No, it doesn't always work that way in practice, but that's the way it's designed to work.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;One thing you can do, to try and get a little closer to the ideal, is to occasionally go over your old answers and see if any of them have comments (written by you or someone else) that add value to the answer. If you spot any, edit the answer to incorporate the information directly into it (with appropriate credit, as needed). This ensures that, even if the comments are later deleted, the useful information in them will not be lost. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;You can also go over your old comments (available in your user profile, under &quot;activity&quot; &amp;rarr; &quot;comments&quot;) and see if any of them might be usefully turned into edits or stand-alone answers.  Also, if any questions you've asked have been effectively answered via comments, you can either summarize the conclusions into a self-answer (again, with appropriate credit, of course) or just ask the user who posted the most useful comment(s) to turn them into an answer.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;In some cases, once the comments have been turned or edited into answers, you may also want to delete them (if they're yours) or flag them as obsolete (if not) immediately.  However, that's completely optional." />
./PostHistory.xml:4834:  <row Id="7227" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="238" RevisionGUID="3597d20f-cca9-4e39-ab9e-039081371bc8" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="Questions about Theorem X in paper Y?&#xD;&#xA;-------------------------------------&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;It is perfectly fine to ask very specific questions like this:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt;How does one reach eq 3.14 from eq 3.13 in paper X, page Y? I tried the following ... but it didn't work.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;However, if you suspect that there is a *mistake* in a paper, it might be polite to first contact the authors by email before posting a question here.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;---&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Related discussion:&#xD;&#xA;[[1]](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/204/are-specific-questions-about-theorem-x-in-paper-y-fine)&#xD;&#xA;[[2]](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/214/should-there-be-a-protocol-to-notify-authors-if-we-find-an-error-in-a-paper)" />
./PostHistory.xml:4835:  <row Id="7228" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2831" RevisionGUID="2840f107-921b-41c7-b3fa-feb9dc802661" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="##cstheory polices&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Policies are cstheory's laws &#xD;&#xA;(in addition to general Stack Exchange policies &#xD;&#xA;required to be followed by all sites on the Stack Exchange network).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Policies are passed by voting on meta.&#xD;&#xA;Right now a policy requires 2/3 majority in favor with at least 5 up votes to pass.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Typically we start with a [meta-tag:discussion] question on meta.&#xD;&#xA;When the discussion has received enough feedback &#xD;&#xA;we move to the voting phase &#xD;&#xA;by posting a [meta-tag:policy] question.&#xD;&#xA;The policy question must start with&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt;This is a policy question. The proposed policy in the question (or answers) will be adopted in the case that after 7 days it receives at least 5 up votes with a 2/3 majority in favor. Please upvote or downvote this question based on your opinion of the policy statement as presented (not based on whether the premise of the question is reasonable).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;A policy post should contain a short summery of the discussion and a link to it. &#xD;&#xA;It should be followed by the statement of the proposed policy:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; Policy Proposal ([DATE]): [STATEMENT OF THE POLICY]&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The title of the policy question should start with &quot;Policy:&quot;.&#xD;&#xA;Typically the [meta-tag:featured] tag is added to the question by a moderator.&#xD;&#xA;During the 7 days following the proposal users can vote for or against the policy.&#xD;&#xA;After 7 days voting ends and the policy either is passed or is rejected.&#xD;&#xA;A moderator tags the post accordingly with either [meta-tag:status-completed] or [meta-tag:status-declined], and locks the question and its answers to preserve the votes, and removes the [meta-tag:featured] tag.&#xD;&#xA;Users who want to propose a change to a policy should start a new discussion.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;During the voting period there can be suggestions for amendments or modifications.&#xD;&#xA;If an amendment is passed a moderator will modify the policy question to add the passed amendments.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;For an example, please see [this policy](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/q/802/).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:4836:  <row Id="7229" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="251" RevisionGUID="26ad8d25-e2e8-4600-8645-1c868bf10c96" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="Svrist,&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;It looks like your question *may* fit here, but you want to take some time to formulate it appropriately before posting it. In particular, questions strictly on the theory of PL are fine, but any of the practical design questions will fit in much better at StackOverflow.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;For a brief history of PL theory on this site, see [this thread](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/21/compiler-design-and-pl-theory-questions).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Good luck!&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;P.S. Also see [this piece](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/234#234) of our Work-In-Progress-FAQ on which types of questions are appropriate." />
./PostHistory.xml:4837:  <row Id="7230" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2871" RevisionGUID="600021f4-b2d6-463e-a995-cd704b928053" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="1. There is nothing wrong per se with questions which don't have a single answer. Where have you got that idea? If you mean [tag:big-list] questions then yes, we allow them, for more information have a look at https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/2865/on-the-efficacy-of-big-list-questions&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;2. Yes, as a research oriented site we have allowed things that might be problematic on other sites like SO. If you want a simple guide, we follow MO model than SO model. The reason is simple: we started the site with the goal of making something similar to MO for TCS, the communities are similar, etc. So if it is OK on MO it is probably OK here. Other SE sites don't matter that much for our policy decisions.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;3. See also [Good subjective, bad subjective](http://blog.stackoverflow.com/2010/09/good-subjective-bad-subjective/). There is nothing wrong with asking _good_ subjective questions." />
./PostHistory.xml:4838:  <row Id="7231" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="281" RevisionGUID="3aa3b58b-45df-4607-a9ec-86d9209b3be0" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="### A proposed policy for questions on preprints.###&#xD;&#xA;(in the form of an FAQ.)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;There are good ways to ask about new seemingly exciting results in TCS, and there are bad ways. Below, we give a few examples of each: &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- **BAD**: Have you read this new paper on the arXiv on (seminal problem in complexity)?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- *Answer*: Yes, we have. Please do not post this question on this site.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- **BAD**: Is the new claimed proof of (seminal problem in complexity) correct?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- *Answer*: If it's at all credible, be assured that people are reading it and trying to determine that. In fact, why not read it yourself ! But don't post this question on this site. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- **GOOD**: In this new preprint on the arXiv that claims to solve (seminal problem in TCS), the author refers to quantum range searching on squashed hypercubes. What is that?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- *Answer*: We can answer your question here.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- **GOOD**: This new paper claiming a big result is beyond my ken to read. Before I invest the time to learn all this stuff and try to read it, I am curious: have there been any technical rebuttals or discussions of it?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- *Answer*: We can answer your question here. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- **note**: Such cases are acceptable only if they are really *reference-requests* (see [Josh's answer][1]). This item cannot be used if the real motivation of the OP is not reading the paper. Using this item to circumvent the general policy will not be permitted.   &#xD;&#xA;Also this item doesn't apply if it is unlikely that there are such references, e.g.  &#xD;&#xA;1. the time is too short for existence of such references,  &#xD;&#xA;2. reasonable time has passed but the author's claims is not considered credible, &#xD;&#xA;e.g. the author is not considered an expert in the area and &#xD;&#xA;the author's claims has not been taken seriously by experts in the area.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  Note that if a claim about progress on a famous long standing open problem (like &quot;P vs. NP&quot;) is credible at all, there will be discussions about it online in a short time after its announcement (e.g. on theory blogs like [Computational Complexity](http://blog.computationalcomplexity.org/), [Gödel's Lost Letter and P=NP](http://rjlipton.wordpress.com/), etc.) and if there is not then it is a sign that the claim is not taken seriously by experts.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;---&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* **BAD**: This new unpublished papers on arXiv proposes a new algorithm and claims it can solve problem X way faster than the best known algorithms. I don't understand the paper and don't want to spend time reading it, can someone verify that the author's claim is correct?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* *Answer*: If it's at all credible, be assured that people are reading it and trying to determine that. If you can't check the correctness of the algorithm yourself, you should wait until it is [peer-reviewed][2] and [published][3]. The peer-review process does not take a very long time, if the paper hasn't been published after several years it is a strong sign that the paper has failed to pass the peer-review process and the author's claim is at least doubtful. Discussing the general correctness of papers which have not passed the peer-review process are off-topic for this site.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* **Good**: What is the fastest known algorithm for problem X?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* *Answer*: We can answer your question here.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;---&#xD;&#xA;**In summary, focus your question on specific technical aspects of the work that you'd like clarification on. You can also try to rephrase your question in a way that avoids mentioning a specific unpublished work but will ask essentially what you want to know.**&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Remember: if your question is closed as off-topic, you can still edit your question to address the issues stated for closing it, in which case it can be reopened.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/a/707&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peer_review&#xD;&#xA;  [3]: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Published_research" />
./PostHistory.xml:4839:  <row Id="7232" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2875" RevisionGUID="063164d5-92e7-4928-abb2-640debcb1f95" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="The dawn of a new year, 2015, now approaches, or has already approached, either way it means that it is now time to reset our Community Promotion Ads!&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### What are Community Promotion Ads?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Community Promotion Ads are community-vetted advertisements that will show up on the main site, in the right sidebar. The purpose of this question is the vetting process. Images of the advertisements are provided, and community voting will enable the advertisements to be shown.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### Why do we have Community Promotion Ads?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;This is a method for the community to control what gets promoted to visitors on the site. For example, you might promote the following things:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; - cool site-related open source apps&#xD;&#xA; - the site's twitter account&#xD;&#xA; - cool events or conferences&#xD;&#xA; - anything else your community would genuinely be interested in&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The goal is for future visitors to find out about *the stuff your community deems important*. This also serves as a way to promote information and resources that are *relevant to your own community's interests*, both for those already in the community and those yet to join. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### Why do we reset the ads every year?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Some services will maintain usefulness over the years, while other things will wane to allow for new faces to show up. Resetting the ads every year helps accommodate this, and allows old ads that have served their purpose to be cycled out for fresher ads for newer things. This helps keep the material in the ads relevant to not just the subject matter of the community, but to the current status of the community. We reset the ads once a year, every December.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The community promotion ads have no restrictions against reposting an ad from a previous cycle. If a particular service or ad is very valuable to the community and will continue to be so, it is a good idea to repost it. It may be helpful to give it a new face in the process, so as to prevent the imagery of the ad from getting stale after a year of exposure.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### How does it work?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The answers you post to this question _must_ conform to the following rules, or they will be ignored. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;1. All answers should be in the exact form of:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;        [![Tagline to show on mouseover][1]][2]&#xD;&#xA;        &#xD;&#xA;           [1]: http://image-url&#xD;&#xA;           [2]: http://clickthrough-url &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;    Please **do not add anything else to the body of the post**. If you want to discuss something, do it in the comments.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;2. The question must always be tagged with the magic [meta-tag:community-ads] tag. In addition to enabling the functionality of the advertisements, this tag also pre-fills the answer form with the above required form.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### Image requirements&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; - The image that you create must be **220 x 250 pixels**&#xD;&#xA; - Must be hosted through our standard image uploader (imgur)&#xD;&#xA; - Must be GIF or PNG&#xD;&#xA; - No animated GIFs&#xD;&#xA; - Absolute limit on file size of 150 KB&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### Score Threshold&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;There is a **minimum score threshold** an answer must meet (currently **6**) before it will be shown on the main site.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;You can check out the ads that have met the threshold with basic click stats [here][1].&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/ads/display/2875" />
./PostHistory.xml:4840:  <row Id="7233" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2897" RevisionGUID="ad1d8143-5d60-4d83-b63d-43cc850c3025" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="LaTex code doesn't work for me for these pages:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- [Something you should know about: Quantifier Elimination (Part I)][1]&#xD;&#xA;- [Something you should know about: Quantifier Elimination (Part II)][2]&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;tested with Chrome and Firefox.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Based on the comments in the 1st page and [another meta post][3] it seems the problem was before, however stopped working again I guess.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The 2nd page has some missing images, however they can be still retrieved from Archive.org, for example:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;http://web.archive.org/http://web.mit.edu/abhatt/www/fig3.png&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;(copy the link manually, as it could not work when clicking on it)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;So it's worth to re-upload them.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://cstheory.blogoverflow.com/2011/11/something-you-should-know-about-quantifier-elimination-part-i/&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: http://cstheory.blogoverflow.com/2012/02/something-you-should-know-about-quantifier-elimination-part-ii&#xD;&#xA;  [3]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/q/1203/19473" />
./PostHistory.xml:4841:  <row Id="7235" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2925" RevisionGUID="55ac50e1-40a0-4daf-abed-0ceb57ab9922" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="It's 2016 now, and we've [made some changes to the sidebar size](http://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/272563/were-standardizing-the-sidebar-width-at-300px-on-all-sites). As such, we can now restart the Community Promotion Ads for 2016!&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Keep in mind, we have updated some of the guidelines compared to previously - the changes are marked in bold in the Image Requirements section.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### What are Community Promotion Ads?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Community Promotion Ads are community-vetted advertisements that will show up on the main site, in the right sidebar. The purpose of this question is the vetting process. Images of the advertisements are provided, and community voting will enable the advertisements to be shown.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### Why do we have Community Promotion Ads?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;This is a method for the community to control what gets promoted to visitors on the site. For example, you might promote the following things:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; - cool site-related open source apps&#xD;&#xA; - the site's twitter account&#xD;&#xA; - cool events or conferences&#xD;&#xA; - anything else your community would genuinely be interested in&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The goal is for future visitors to find out about *the stuff your community deems important*. This also serves as a way to promote information and resources that are *relevant to your own community's interests*, both for those already in the community and those yet to join. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### Why do we reset the ads every year?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Some services will maintain usefulness over the years, while other things will wane to allow for new faces to show up. Resetting the ads every year helps accommodate this, and allows old ads that have served their purpose to be cycled out for fresher ads for newer things. This helps keep the material in the ads relevant to not just the subject matter of the community, but to the current status of the community. We reset the ads once a year, every December.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The community promotion ads have no restrictions against reposting an ad from a previous cycle. If a particular service or ad is very valuable to the community and will continue to be so, it is a good idea to repost it. It may be helpful to give it a new face in the process, so as to prevent the imagery of the ad from getting stale after a year of exposure.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### How does it work?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The answers you post to this question _must_ conform to the following rules, or they will be ignored. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;1. All answers should be in the exact form of:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;        [![Tagline to show on mouseover][1]][2]&#xD;&#xA;        &#xD;&#xA;           [1]: http://image-url&#xD;&#xA;           [2]: http://clickthrough-url &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;    Please **do not add anything else to the body of the post**. If you want to discuss something, do it in the comments.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;2. The question must always be tagged with the magic [meta-tag:community-ads] tag. In addition to enabling the functionality of the advertisements, this tag also pre-fills the answer form with the above required form.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### Image requirements&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; - The image that you create must be **300 x 250 pixels**, or double that if high DPI.&#xD;&#xA; - Must be hosted through our standard image uploader (imgur)&#xD;&#xA; - Must be GIF or PNG&#xD;&#xA; - No animated GIFs&#xD;&#xA; - Absolute limit on file size of **150 KB**&#xD;&#xA; - **If the background of the image is white or partially white, there must be a 1px border (2px if high DPI) surrounding it.**&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### Score Threshold&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;There is a **minimum score threshold** an answer must meet (currently **6**) before it will be shown on the main site.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;You can check out the ads that have met the threshold with basic click stats [here][1].&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/ads/display/2925" />
./PostHistory.xml:4842:  <row Id="7236" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="300" RevisionGUID="141f42c7-7715-4e08-b995-f690cf4ee6ff" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="The moderators spend considerable time on editing badly written questions. A possible way for reducing the number of badly written questions is writing down some guidelines (similar to the MO [guidelines](http://mathoverflow.net/howtoask)) on how to ask/write a good question, and possibly add a link to it on the top of the &quot;ask question&quot; page.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;This thread is for discussing related issues, specially what should be included in our guidelines?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;---&#xD;&#xA;Related: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/q/295/186" />
./PostHistory.xml:4843:  <row Id="7237" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2945" RevisionGUID="daf0b0ac-ee8b-41d0-ad38-6c1c20b5bfe1" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="As I mentioned in https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/a/2944/5038, flag it for moderator attention, and downvote.  Use a custom flag, and explain what's going on; the moderators have tools to deal with this.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Plagiarism violates SE rules.  The moderators can take action. ./PostHistory.xml:4844:  <row Id="7238" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="317" RevisionGUID="f002d933-11c9-4c91-9b28-42e0003c3072" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="I'm not sure how a post-grad is different from an MS or Ph.D student, but I'd say that the questions being discussed here have a lower bound at advanced undergraduate/beginning grad student, and extend all the way up into active researchers at all levels. Many of the &quot;big-list&quot; questions are at the lower end of this range. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;While MO is definitely a strong influence on how we use the site, I think that we are likely to entertain certain kinds of broader questions, especially in the realm of applications. However, from a level point of view, we're probably similar. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I would hope that you wouldn't get scared away ! While the questions might seem out of reach, they do span a wide breadth of topics, on which few of us are experts, and so it's not surprising that many of the topics might appear inaccessible. There might be some crustiness towards ill-posed, unmotivated questions, but clear questions that aren't answerable by Google ([see this thread][1] on how to ask questions) will (hopefully) get a fair shake, even if they might seem basic.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/300/how-to-ask-a-good-question" />
./PostHistory.xml:4845:  <row Id="7239" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2963" RevisionGUID="37db5f9f-5145-49b2-9049-7987976037cd" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="It is a bit late into this new year, being that we're already in the second month, but we are now cycling the Community Promotion Ads for 2017!&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### What are Community Promotion Ads?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Community Promotion Ads are community-vetted advertisements that will show up on the main site, in the right sidebar. The purpose of this question is the vetting process. Images of the advertisements are provided, and community voting will enable the advertisements to be shown.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### Why do we have Community Promotion Ads?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;This is a method for the community to control what gets promoted to visitors on the site. For example, you might promote the following things:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; - the site's twitter account&#xD;&#xA; - cool events or conferences&#xD;&#xA; - anything else your community would genuinely be interested in&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The goal is for future visitors to find out about *the stuff your community deems important*. This also serves as a way to promote information and resources that are *relevant to your own community's interests*, both for those already in the community and those yet to join. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### Why do we reset the ads every year?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Some services will maintain usefulness over the years, while other things will wane to allow for new faces to show up. Resetting the ads every year helps accommodate this, and allows old ads that have served their purpose to be cycled out for fresher ads for newer things. This helps keep the material in the ads relevant to not just the subject matter of the community, but to the current status of the community. We reset the ads once a year, every December.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The community promotion ads have no restrictions against reposting an ad from a previous cycle. If a particular service or ad is very valuable to the community and will continue to be so, it is a good idea to repost it. It may be helpful to give it a new face in the process, so as to prevent the imagery of the ad from getting stale after a year of exposure.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### How does it work?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The answers you post to this question _must_ conform to the following rules, or they will be ignored. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;1. All answers should be in the exact form of:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;        [![Tagline to show on mouseover][1]][2]&#xD;&#xA;        &#xD;&#xA;           [1]: http://image-url&#xD;&#xA;           [2]: http://clickthrough-url &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;    Please **do not add anything else to the body of the post**. If you want to discuss something, do it in the comments.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;2. The question must always be tagged with the magic [meta-tag:community-ads] tag. In addition to enabling the functionality of the advertisements, this tag also pre-fills the answer form with the above required form.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### Image requirements&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; - The image that you create must be 300 x 250 pixels, or double that if high DPI.&#xD;&#xA; - Must be hosted through our standard image uploader (imgur)&#xD;&#xA; - Must be GIF or PNG&#xD;&#xA; - No animated GIFs&#xD;&#xA; - Absolute limit on file size of 150 KB&#xD;&#xA; - If the background of the image is white or partially white, there must be a 1px border (2px if high DPI) surrounding it.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### Score Threshold&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;There is a **minimum score threshold** an answer must meet (currently **6**) before it will be shown on the main site.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;You can check out the ads that have met the threshold with basic click stats [here][1].&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/ads/display/2963" />

./PostHistory.xml:4850:  <row Id="7244" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="351" RevisionGUID="9f7121aa-8c25-4162-a354-8d7e32963c26" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="As explained in [Suresh’s post](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/340/retag-all-cs-xyz-abc-to-xyz-abc/345#345) to another discussion, some tag synonyms are created without their master tags being created.  However, I think that some reconsideration is desirable because creating a tag synonym whose master tag does not exist in the system seems to have caused two problems.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;1. Some tag-related pages are Not Found.  See comments to [Suresh’s post](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/340/retag-all-cs-xyz-abc-to-xyz-abc/345#345).&#xD;&#xA;2. Users with rep less than 200 cannot tag his/her own question with either the older tag or the newer tag until some user with rep ≥200 uses the newer tag, even if the older tag is in use.  See a note and comments in a [question](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1527/confidentiality-of-partial-private-keys-in-certificateless-public-key-crypto) by Zack (but let’s avoid discussing about the issue on the question page).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Judging from [how the feature of tag synonyms was requested](http://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/2779/could-the-tagging-system-be-enhanced-to-support-tag-synonyms) on meta.stackoverflow.com, it seems to me that a tag synonym is supposed to be created when the master tag is already in use.  Therefore, it is understandable that the system behaves oddly if the master of a tag synonym has not been created.&#xD;&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:4851:  <row Id="7245" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="356" RevisionGUID="f28e7622-9da0-4b51-9681-ed4f05ce543b" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="**Update**: I gave up trying to convince other people to use “too localized” instead of “off topic” when closing too elementary questions.  It seems that most people disagree, and I started to feel that it is a waste of time to try to convince people otherwise.  For now, I still hesitate to vote for off topic (or to be listed as one of the people who closed the question as off topic) when I see too elementary a question, so probably I will not vote to close it.  Hopefully there are enough people to close it anyway.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;---&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;When we vote to close a question, we choose the reason from several choices.  It seems that if a question is too elementary, it is often closed for the reason “off topic.”&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I understand that this choice of reason is based on the consensus about the expected level of questions on cstheory.stackexchange.com.  However, if a question is closed for the reason “off topic,” the following explanation is added to the question:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; closed as off topic by [Someone], [Someone], [Someone], [Someone], [Someone] [Date]&#xD;&#xA;&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; Questions on Theoretical Computer Science are expected to generally relate to Theoretical Computer Science, within the scope defined in the [faq](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/faq).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I have trouble even parsing this sentence because of the tentative name of the website, but more importantly this does not mention the expected level of questions on cstheory.stackexchange.com.  It plainly states that the question is not related to the theoretical computer science, which is often false.  This gives the false impression that we take the theoretical computer science very narrowly.  I think that this is problematic.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;(_Added in revision 5_: The link in the explanation quoted above links to the [built-in FAQ](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/faq), not to the [FAQ on Meta](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science).  The built-in FAQ is not clear about the expected level of questions, either, except that the sentence “Theoretical Computer Science - Stack Exchange is for theoretical computer scientists and researchers in related fields” may suggest that research-level questions are expected.  A clearer statement can be reached by the following chain of links: the explanation of “off topic” → [built-in FAQ](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/faq) → [FAQ on Meta](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science) → [What kind of questions are too basic?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/235#235)  But I doubt that users can find this path unless they are already familiar with the website.)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;What should we do?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Here are a few suggestions:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;1. If the consensus is really that cstheory.stackexchange.com is for questions of at least certain level, the explanation of the reason “off topic” should be rewritten to reflect it.  Is this possible?&#xD;&#xA;2. &lt;del&gt;On [MathOverflow](http://mathoverflow.net/), too elementary questions are often closed for the reason “too localized.”  Obviously this is an abuse and [it certainly confuses some users](http://meta.mathoverflow.net/discussion/274/what-does-too-localized-mean-exactly/), but it is possible to interpret it as “This question is so elementary that it is useful only for the asker,” and it is understandable (or at least less prone to misunderstanding).  How about adopting this convention, at least until the explanation of “off topic” is modified to a better description?&lt;/del&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Related:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- See a [related FAQ entry](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/235#235) and the links given there for discussions about what we mean by “too elementary.”&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;_Added in revision 4:_ Whereas the description of the close reason is not shown on the question page on MathOverflow, it is shown on cstheory.stackexchange.com, which may make abusing harder.  Here is the description of the close reason “too localized”:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; This question would only be relevant to a small geographic area, a specific moment in time, or an extraordinarily narrow situation that is not generally applicable to the worldwide audience of the internet.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The point of the suggestion 2 above is that it is at least possible to argue that too elementary questions fall into the third group (and possibly also the second group) of this description.&#xD;&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:4852:  <row Id="7246" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="358" RevisionGUID="255c6571-0a31-469f-933a-ec15b5dfbc2c" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="Currently the question “[Do you use any article organizers?](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1574/do-you-use-any-article-organizers)” has three votes to close as off topic.  However, in my opinion, this question can be interesting to people working on theoretical computer science and is not off topic, although it is not a question _in_ TCS.  At least I am interested in what other people in TCS use.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;(As I wrote in a [post to another discussion](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/333/protocol-for-accepting-answers-in-cw-and-list-type-questions/337#337), I am a little bit tired of big-list questions, and this question may be one of them, but that is a separate story.)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Also, if you are a theoretical computer scientist looking for good citation organization software, I can imagine a reason for you to want to ask for recommendations of other theoretical computer scientists rather than researchers in other fields; it can be expected that they have similar requirements to you.  In this sense, I can argue that the question is _about_ TCS, although admittedly the relation is not strong.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Is this question on topic or off topic?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;---&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;_Added:_ The question has been closed as off topic.  If that is the consensus of people here, I am fine with that, even though it was a little surprising to me because I had an impression that most people were [happier with non-technical or broad questions than with technical, focused questions](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions?sort=votes).  Honestly speaking, I personally prefer technical, focused questions than highly-voted soft or broad questions, so I guess that I should feel happy to see that this question has been closed as off topic rather than feeling sad.&#xD;&#xA;" />

./PostHistory.xml:4854:  <row Id="7248" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="368" RevisionGUID="30c78c46-b350-41f0-8c92-c0994607de3d" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="Lance Fortnow asked a question, [What is the Volume of Information?](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1593/what-is-the-volume-of-information), which Ross Snider criticised on two grounds:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;1. It really doesn't meet the qualifications in the FAQ so far as I can tell*, and&#xD;&#xA;2. Not advanced as a TCS question: *the question (while legitimate and interesting) isn't really a TCS question (and so is not appropriate), and also doesn't meet the qualification here ([meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/225/…](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/235#235))*&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I'm generally of the opinion that the physical basis of computation is fundamental to computer science &amp;mdash;slogan: computer science is ultimately a physical science, one that involves a lot of formal science&amp;mdash; and is perfectly amenable to formal treatment.  Indeed, quantum computation could hardly be treated rigorously if that were not so.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I'm guessing that Ross' objection is not on those grounds, but rather he finds Lance's question to be the kind of question that has too much physics in it to be good for this site.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Are we worried about this?  Should we resist questions whose TCS to physics quotient gets too low?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;*Related: [Scope of questions?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/17/scope-of-questions)*&#xD;&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:4855:  <row Id="7249" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="377" RevisionGUID="60df71ad-e586-4109-9fd1-6f9ccebd79ee" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="This is a follow up to [Shane's early question][1] on site promotion. In one respect, things are going fairly well. Our traffic is steadily increasing: from an early number of around 2500 visits/day, we are now at 3200 visits/day. We also have nearly 1500 registered users (part of this is no doubt some reddit love we got for [a post on functional data structures][2]).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;And yet, I think our numbers overestimate the true penetration of the site within the theoryCS community at large. Here's an experiment I did:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; Estimate the fraction of users with a&#xD;&#xA;&gt; reputation in the range $(1, 101) \cup&#xD;&#xA;&gt; [102, \infty)$, and compare this to the fraction of MO users in the range $(1, \infty)$&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The rationale for this is that merely signing up gets you a reputation score of 1, or 101 if you come in via the SE system. So that score doesn't reflect any actual involvement. MO on the other hand is an SE 1.0 site, and so they don't have the 101 bonus. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;While in one respect this is an unfair comparison, because MO has been around a lot longer, it's not entirely unfair because we're only comparing ratios here. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The results: &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; TCS: roughly 20%  &#xD;&#xA;&gt; MO: roughly 40%  &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; (I did a crude approximation by looking&#xD;&#xA;&gt; at number of *pages* of users, because&#xD;&#xA;&gt; I have a life :))&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;It seems to me that this might suggest that our relatively large user numbers (relative to this stage in the beta) is an illusion, and so we need to work more at getting people in the community to participate. I know for a fact that many of my colleagues even in the narrow realm of computational geometry aren't here. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I don't have too many concrete ideas apart from some of the suggestions from the last post. But maybe it's a matter of doing more in-community - mentioning the site in talks, citing the site generously when appropriate, and encouraging co-workers and students to post questions (note that I'm not mentioning things like twitter which only touch a small fraction of the *theory* community)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/58/how-to-promote-the-site&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1539/whats-new-in-purely-functional-data-structures-since-okasaki" />
./PostHistory.xml:4856:  <row Id="7250" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="380" RevisionGUID="874f8246-fd72-4e6a-bd65-8cd916791093" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="Please merge the tags [game-theory] and [cs.gt.game-theory] into a tag [gt.game-theory], which does not currently exist.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Related: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/340/retag-all-cs-xyz-abc-to-xyz-abc&#xD;&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:4857:  <row Id="7251" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="389" RevisionGUID="3fba42fe-a96e-47eb-a66d-749d0fd08dbe" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="This question came up while discussing [this question][1]. Since we've chosen our domain name to be **cstheory.org**, does this mean that our site's name will have to be **cstheory**? All the other SE sites I've seen follow this: SuperUser, StackExchange, ServerFault, etc. (Even MathOverflow)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I couldn't find the answer on any of the SE sites, does anyone know what will happen?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/352/how-will-you-cite-a-discussion-on-this-site-in-your-paper" />
./PostHistory.xml:4858:  <row Id="7252" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="393" RevisionGUID="8b79aab2-25ea-4c31-8965-994aa121d998" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="_Edit: I rewrote this answer significantly in revision 3 to simplify the reasoning, although the conclusion is the same._&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I do not know whether the website name and the domain name of a Stack Exchange website _have to_ be the same or not.  I agree to Suresh that you should ask on Meta Stack Overflow if you want to know that.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;However, in our case, the website name should be “cstheory.org,” that is, exactly the same as the domain name.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The [poll](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/1/what-should-our-site-domain-name-be) to decide the site name and the domain name was already closed, and the decision was cstheory.org.  Although most proposals, including the chosen one, only stated a domain name and did not state a website name explicitly, it should be understood that the website name was going to be the same as the domain name up to minor modifications (such as removing the top-level domain or breaking into more than one word).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I prefer “cstheory.org” to “cstheory” or “CS Theory” as the website name for a reason which [Jukka already stated](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/389/does-our-name-and-domain-name-have-to-be-the-same/391#391): when pronounced, “C-S-theory” does not identify us.  (In fact, [I stated this during the poll as a comment](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/1/what-should-our-site-domain-name-be/100#100), too.)&#xD;&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:4859:  <row Id="7253" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="403" RevisionGUID="5d3e8644-a03f-42f6-98e4-1a788c94eb17" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="My answer turned out to be incorrect.  What should I do?&#xD;&#xA;--------------------------------------------------------&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;There is no perfect rule telling you what to do in such cases.  Here are some of the options:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- Edit it to a correct answer.  In this case, leaving a comment to the answer explaining the edit might be also a good idea.&#xD;&#xA;- Leave it as it is after adding a clear notice that it is incorrect and an explanation of why at the beginning of the answer.&#xD;&#xA;- Delete it.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The consensus seems to be that leaving only a comment about incorrectness is not sufficient because readers will not notice it until they read the comments.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;An incorrect answer clearly marked as such is often informative because it shows an incorrect approach which other people may think is correct.  Therefore, some people consider that we should not delete an answer just because it is incorrect.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Related discussions: [[1]](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/386/policy-on-deleting-incorrect-answers) [[2]](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/25/material-to-supplement-the-faq/390#390)&#xD;&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:4860:  <row Id="7254" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="404" RevisionGUID="abcf6045-c085-486d-bc50-291f5708d2cc" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="The (domain) name is very important to the success of this site and a strong, witty one can sometimes be that extra hook to grab a new user, while a weak, boring one can put people off, alienate them, or, worse, make others disdainful of the community. That is why we need to put our brains together and take the time to come up with something really striking!&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;However, for reasons that I do not understand, the &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/1/what-should-our-site-domain-name-be&quot;&gt;official race for the site name&lt;/a&gt; was given only four weeks. (If someone can point out where I can find the decision to make September 10th the deadline, please comment.) Then, although there were some small mutterings about a runoff poll (partly due to a number of negative comments against the declared winner), Suresh recently closed the debate by locking the poll. Robin Kothari (and JeffE with a &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/389/does-our-name-and-domain-name-have-to-be-the-same/392#392&quot;&gt;clever new proposal&lt;/a&gt;) reopened the discussion a tiny bit &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/389/does-our-name-and-domain-name-have-to-be-the-same&quot;&gt;here&lt;/a&gt;. Let me formally (propose to) open this again fully.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Full disclosure: I find the current choice extremely unappealing.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;For the &quot;yes&quot; and &quot;no&quot; answers, please **do not downvote**! (Comments on the question and comments giving reasons for your vote are encouraged though.)&#xD;&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:4861:  <row Id="7255" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="405" RevisionGUID="a0c7d1c3-cbe6-4762-9978-e34b0770807c" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="&lt;h1&gt;Yes, definitely.&lt;/h1&gt;&#xD;&#xA;Edit: I gave my own justification in the question, and I also discussed it &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/389/does-our-name-and-domain-name-have-to-be-the-same/401#401&quot;&gt;elsewhere&lt;/a&gt;, but since Tsuyoshi commented in his answer, I should give a synopsis here too:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; 1. There didn't seem to be an outright&#xD;&#xA;    winner in the original poll.&#xD;&#xA; 2. More time should have been given to&#xD;&#xA;    the name selection process.&#xD;&#xA; 3. The naming process should have been&#xD;&#xA;    discussed more openly.&#xD;&#xA; 4. The site is still new, growing and&#xD;&#xA;    we have no imperative to lock in our&#xD;&#xA;    choice right away.&#xD;&#xA; 5. Least important of all, but still worth mentioning, in my opinion there are *several reasons* why the current choice is *horrible* and some of these are mentioned in the &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/1/what-should-our-site-domain-name-be/100#100&quot;&gt;respective comments thread&lt;/a&gt;." />
./PostHistory.xml:4862:  <row Id="7256" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="406" RevisionGUID="8abbe2ba-292f-47a9-af14-219b41edd982" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="It is painful to say this to you because I think that [your proposal](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/1/what-should-our-site-domain-name-be/259#259) was the best, but my answer is: no, we shouldn’t.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;First, I do not know if changing the decision is realistic.  I guess that Suresh already told the decision to Stack Overflow, and I do not know if it is possible or desirable to take it back.  (_Added_: The domain name CSTheory.org was registered by Stack Overflow on August 26.  &lt;del&gt;While I am sure that they can afford some number of unused domain names, I do not know if it is the right thing to ask them to buy another; it sounds irresponsible to me.&lt;/del&gt;)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Second, I am afraid that canceling the concluded poll sets a bad example.  This poll was done according to a procedure.  If this poll was canceled, polls in the future will not look serious any more.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Third, while a name is important and a good name adds value to the website, I do not think that it is critical for the success of the website.  What is critical is, needless to say, good content and good community.  We should be done with the debate on website name and domain name.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;(More on the third point: Honestly speaking, I think that the name MathOverflow is far from a good name.  It only makes sense to those who know Stack Overflow, and the relation to TeX no longer makes sense because questions about TeX are no longer allowed there (in other words, they chose a name based on an element which was only tangentially related to the topic of the website).  However, as long as the content is good, these negative facts do not matter, at least to me.)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;It must have been surprising to some people that the name “CSTheory.org” was supported by most people.  It was surprising to me at least.  Please accept this surprising fact.&#xD;&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:4863:  <row Id="7257" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="422" RevisionGUID="d67d8ae5-bd76-45a7-a5fb-985463d60b19" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="This is another take to [the problem that a new user asks a question without registering and loses the cookie](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/268/should-we-encourage-a-new-user-to-register-before-he-she-asks-a-question).  In the discussion I linked to, I wanted to prevent this situation from happening, but I became unsure that it was at all possible to prevent it.  Therefore, I would like to know what should be done when this happens.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;To take a concrete example, I realized that in [this question](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1785/definition-of-a-monotone-machine), the asker replied to a comment by posting an _answer_, which is a typical symptom of multiple accounts.  I quickly verified that although the asker and the user who replied had the same user name and the same icon, they were different accounts.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;What should I do in a case like this?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- Flag it for a moderator attention by myself explaining the situation.&#xD;&#xA;- Ask the user to do this.&#xD;&#xA;- Ask the user to open a thread on meta.&#xD;&#xA;- Something else.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Also, should I ask the user to register?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Note:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- I cannot verify that the two accounts really belong to the same person.&#xD;&#xA;- It seems that only moderators can merge two accounts.&#xD;&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:4864:  <row Id="7258" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="427" RevisionGUID="4ff31dbf-0cbe-40d1-824e-7f5521fda49c" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="In his [answer](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/425/questions-about-compilation-errors-in-coq/426#426), supercooldave mentions “the exact nature of the question,” which I think is the very issue.  The problem is: Is the exact nature of these questions “the theory of proof assistants and/or programming languages” or just “programming”?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- If they are about the theory of proof assistants and/or programming languages and using Coq merely for concreteness, they are fine.&#xD;&#xA;- If they are about programming in Coq, they are off topic.  The askers may want to ask them on Stack Overflow, considering there are several [questions on Coq on Stack Overflow](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/coq) and they get some answers, although I do not know whether the answers are correct or not.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Honestly speaking, the more I think about it, the more the questions seem like programming questions.&#xD;&#xA;" />

./PostHistory.xml:4866:  <row Id="7260" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="436" RevisionGUID="08bb6a20-5832-4985-ada1-1711d7481044" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="Thank you for sharing this information.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I feel disappointed to hear this.  I had no opinion whether we should use a separate domain name or a subdomain of stackexchange.com.  I simply followed [their own policy](http://blog.stackoverflow.com/2010/07/domain-names/) of using a separate domain name, which was a reasonable opinion although I did not buy everything written in the blog post.  After all, they are experts of running websites whereas I am not, and they had a clear policy which was at least reasonable; following their policy seemed just right.  Now they have overturned what they had said apparently without any good explanation why things should be changed.  This is disappointing.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;---&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;_Edit_: As [RJK already mentions](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/435/a-psa-not-a-question-regarding-our-domain-name/438#438), [Robert Cartaino of Stack Overflow explained the change of the policy](http://blog.stackoverflow.com/2010/10/domain-names-the-wrong-question/). ./PostHistory.xml:4868:  <row Id="7262" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="440" RevisionGUID="cf01ffc6-bc1c-4953-ade1-f4437bdece60" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="I realise that there have been a number of questions on this topic already (specifically [this one][1]), but I hope that this one will be indulged. Currently there are 35 users with the power to vote to close out of a total of 1640 registered users. I am becoming a little worried that there is a tendency to close questions very quickly if they appear in any way poorly formed. To those of us who have been using the site heavily, asking a question which will be accepted as legitimate (and hence not closed) is relatively easy, but for new users it is not clear that this is the case. I can imagine that it is an extremely discouraging experience to see you question almost immediately closed as off topic. Perhaps with questions from new users we should be more tolerant and use comments to try to shape the question into an acceptable form?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;So, are we being too quick to close?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/378/how-much-time-before-closing-a-question" />

./PostHistory.xml:4872:  <row Id="7266" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="463" RevisionGUID="7ca7a13f-d566-44fd-8458-d3dbb659f660" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="*We closed the [domain naming thread (click for details)](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/1/what-should-our-domain-name-be).* &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Instead, **let's start with a killer &quot;elevator pitch!&quot;** Joel will be blogging about the elevator pitch approach to naming, but to get you started: &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;##The Elevator Pitch &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;This isn't as easy as it sounds. Imagine the user who will never read your FAQ and you have two seconds to grab their attention. It should be catchy but descriptive. It should be thoroughly clear but painfully concise. **Make every... word... count.** &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Here are some creative examples: &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- [Gawker](http://gawker.com/): Daily Manhattan media news and gossip. Reporting live from the center of the universe. &#xD;&#xA;- [Gizmodo](http://gizmodo.com/): The gadget guide. So much in love with shiny new toys, it’s unnatural. &#xD;&#xA;- [Autoblog](http://www.autoblog.com/): We obsessively cover the auto industry. &#xD;&#xA;- [DumbLittleMan](http://www.dumblittleman.com/): So what do we do here? Well, it’s simple. 15 to 20 times per week we provide tips that will save you money, increase your productivity, or simply keep you sane. &#xD;&#xA;- [Needcoffee.com](http://www.needcoffee.com/): We are the Internet equivalent of a triple espresso with whipped cream. Mmmm…whipped cream. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;##Use it as a Tagline &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;A shorter elevator pitch *can* be used as a tagline&amp;thinsp;&amp;mdash;&amp;thinsp;something you can display in the header at the top of the page. If it doesn't fit, consider shortening it or creating a separate tagline. Here are some great examples: &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- [Slashdot](http://slashdot.org/): News for nerds. Stuff that matters. &#xD;&#xA;- [Lifehacker](http://www.lifehacker.com/): Don’t live to geek, geek to live! &#xD;&#xA;- [The Simple Dollar](http://www.thesimpledollar.com/): Financial talk for the rest of us. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;##The Motto (don't forget your logo) &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;A logo begs for it own little, short tagline&amp;thinsp;&amp;mdash;&amp;thinsp;like a motto. Maybe the tagline inspires the logo; Maybe it's the other way around. Mottos make good t-shirt, bumper stickers, and other marketing material. Either way, you'll recognize a good motto when you see it: &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- Just do it. &#xD;&#xA;- Think Different. &#xD;&#xA;- The Uncola. &#xD;&#xA;- Intel inside. &#xD;&#xA;- Like a rock. &#xD;&#xA;- The king of beers. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&amp;hellip;and perhaps all this leads to a proper name and domain for your site&amp;hellip; *eventually*. So let's start from the basics. **Come up with a killer elevator pitch, tagline, and/or motto!** " />
./PostHistory.xml:4873:  <row Id="7267" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="471" RevisionGUID="08478c33-bf66-46a7-9c91-22a49b382694" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="Inspired by Kaveh's post.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;A tagline for cstheory:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt;Questions answered. In theory.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;As Tsuyoshi pointed out, this goes great with [the logo that has the highest number of votes at present][1].&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/33/what-should-our-logo-be/314#314" />
./PostHistory.xml:4874:  <row Id="7268" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="473" RevisionGUID="c40fce78-a0e2-4182-8ff9-1e2c3c58b0a4" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="Here are a few elevator pitches which I came up with.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; Drop-in seminar to share problems and answers in theoretical computer science, 24/7.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;(The idea to compare the site to a seminar is borrowed from [MathOverflow](http://mathoverflow.net/faq#pants).  Could use more polishing, as András commented.)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; Virtual coffee break for theoretical computer scientists to ask and answer questions.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;(The coffee-break idea is borrowed from the answers to the question “[How will you cite a discussion on this site in your paper?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/352/how-will-you-cite-a-discussion-on-this-site-in-your-paper)” on Meta.
