./PostHistory.xml:4875:  <row Id="7269" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="485" RevisionGUID="9a95c746-939c-41bc-bb29-2cd03f0b1c73" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="As far as I learned from [this topic](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/q/3/873), both CSTheory &amp; MathOverflow use MathJax. In addition, when I checked the version, I noticed that both use v1.0.1.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;However, the math rendering experience is quite different on TCS &amp; MO: while the former takes a (considerable) time to render a formula, the latter works on the fly (especially while entering a question or answer).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Is there a reason behind this?" />
./PostHistory.xml:4876:  <row Id="7270" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="502" RevisionGUID="b4267db6-4c1f-4e13-a39d-5d0ca84813ac" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="I am experimenting with some UserScripts to provide additional functionality that the StackExchange sites currently do not support.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;In particular, two have proved highly useful:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* https://math.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/689/latex-rendering-delay shows how to reduce the TeX preview delay from the default 5 seconds (!).  Thanks to @Sadeq for the detective work in https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/485&#xD;&#xA;* http://userscripts.org/scripts/show/71948 threads comments based on time and `@`-tagged names used in the comments&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I would like to hear about UserScripts that others have found useful on CSTheory.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;There are also some generic lists (the functionality of quite a few of these has subsequently been incorporated by the StackExchange sites):&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* http://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/5188/what-third-party-tools-exist-to-use-with-stackoverflow&#xD;&#xA;* http://userscripts.org/scripts/search?q=stack+overflow&amp;x=0&amp;y=0&#xD;&#xA;* http://meta.stackoverflow.com/search?q=userscript&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:4877:  <row Id="7271" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="503" RevisionGUID="60b3eb41-5565-417c-ba3c-a2fca30425da" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="I have found these tricks useful:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- Forcing that MathJax re-renders Latex math after clicking on &quot;show N more comments&quot;: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/293/latex-math-and-show-n-more-comments/294#294&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- Show only questions with &quot;interesting&quot; tags: http://meta.mathoverflow.net/discussion/509/see-only-questions-with-interesting-tags/&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Not sure if you can call these things UserScripts, though. They are just bookmarks that include a fragment of JavaScript code.&#xD;&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:4878:  <row Id="7272" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="511" RevisionGUID="6e3fe8bc-84a0-49b4-ad2d-324f350d1350" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="Regarding the layout of such a poster: I actually prefer ad campaigns consisting of several small posters, each in the same style but with different contents. Each time you see a new poster you think how clever it is, rather than just thinking &quot;Oh, there's that same poster again that I've seen 5 times already.&quot;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I don't know if this is feasible or not given the physical layout of FOCS, since there's probably only one registration table and not really other opportunities to put up flyers.  But even if you just have one pile of flyers spread out a little so people can see that there are in fact several distinct ones, that could work.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;If so, then I'd suggest one question per page.  The question big and bold, near the top (maybe use landscape layout), and the answer(s) in smaller text--probably necessary because the answer's tend to be longer--maybe with the most exciting/relevant part of the answer also in bold.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Oh, and of course, &quot;cstheory.stackexchange.com&quot; (perhaps plus a &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/463/write-an-elevator-pitch-tagline&quot;&gt;tag line&lt;/a&gt;, which doesn't have to be the same on each page) at the bottom.  Doesn't have to be too large: once you hook 'em with the interesting Q&amp;A, hopefully they'll be interested enough to find out what the flyer is about, regardless of how large or spiffy the URL is." />
./PostHistory.xml:4879:  <row Id="7274" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="524" RevisionGUID="75a9e5ea-ebf4-4e8c-a7e9-0952d92b7abe" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="On the positive side, I think the quality of questions and answers are really high. We have some involvement from some famous names in theory (for example&#xD;&#xA;[Scott Aaronson](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/users/1575/scott-aaronson), &#xD;&#xA;[Eric Allender](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/users/1533/eric-allender), &#xD;&#xA;[Boaz Barak](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/users/1202/boaz-barak), &#xD;&#xA;[Andrej Bauer](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/users/705/andrej-bauer), &#xD;&#xA;[Paul Beame](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/users/1190/paul-beame), &#xD;&#xA;[David Eppstein](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/users/95/david-eppstein), &#xD;&#xA;[Jeff Erickson](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/users/111/jeffe), &#xD;&#xA;[Joe Fitzsimons](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/users/204/joe-fitzsimons), &#xD;&#xA;[Lance Fortnow](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/users/550/lance-fortnow), &#xD;&#xA;[Sariel Har-Peled](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/users/424/sariel-har-peled), &#xD;&#xA;[Russell Impagliazzo](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/users/332/russell-impagliazzo), [Gil Kalai](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/users/712/gil-kalai), &#xD;&#xA;[Shiva Kintali](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/users/344/shiva-kintali), &#xD;&#xA;[Pascal Koiran](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/users/1748/pascal-koiran), &#xD;&#xA;[Dana Moshkovitz](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/users/1621/dana-moshkovitz), &#xD;&#xA;[Noam Nisan](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/users/42/noam), &#xD;&#xA;[Mihai Pătraşcu](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/users/106/mihai), &#xD;&#xA;[Luca Trevisan](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/users/1069/luca-trevisan), &#xD;&#xA;[Emanuele Viola](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/users/259/emanuele-viola), &#xD;&#xA;[Noam Zeilberger](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/users/674/noam-zeilberger), ...).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;On the negative side, there are many others that are not using the site. (I find it a little bit ironic that mathematicians are faster than cs theorist in adopting new technologies.) Ideally we should have every active theory prof and every tcs graduate student in good universities actively use the site, post questions and answers. We should look more carefully on why this is not the case and address the issues that make people uninterested in using the site. We are also not getting reasonable involvement from researchers in areas outside algorithms, complexity, and computational geometry. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Theory B is very weak on the site, not enough crpto/privacy, combinatorics, and algorithmic game theory and many other very active research areas in [our scope](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/119/our-domain-scope-specifically-defined).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; - more involvement from community (profs, grad students)&#xD;&#xA; &#xD;&#xA; - more questions and answers&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; - more active areas&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I think we need a number of active core users who are experts in each area to keep those area active on the site. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Here are some suggestions:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; 1. There are number of reasons that I have heard from people who I have talked with and tried to get interested in using the site. It might help if we collect those reasons and try to address them if possible. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; 2. Moderators can contact some of the top experts that have used the site, and ask their opinion and for suggestions on making the site more interesting and useful. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; 3. List a number of reasons why every theory prof/grad student should use the site: &quot;Why I should check cstheory? Because ...&quot;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; 4. Contact a number of researchers in areas that are not active on the site, and tell them that their area is not active on the site and ask them to help us in getting more questions and answers in those areas. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; 5. We can also hold special weeks where every user is encouraged to ask a question (even very basic ones from people unfamiliar with those areas, you have attended a talk in some area and you have a very basic question you haven't asked) in a specific area, if we get enough question in those areas, they may generate enough interest to make those areas active. We can also directly invite some of the experts in those areas for the week assigned to each area.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;(Most of these are already suggested by others in other questions.)" />
./PostHistory.xml:4880:  <row Id="7275" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="549" RevisionGUID="ab952287-0628-435e-9ef1-8b5b09f5ff5e" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="Martin Pál's question on the [Warren Buffett problem][1] is currently tagged with gt.game-theory, machine-learning and online-learning. Should the gt.game-theory tag instead be lg.learning-theory ? See also [this related discussion][2] on machine-learning vs learning-theory.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2391/the-warren-buffett-problem&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/343/machine-learning-vs-learning-theory-vs-both" />
./PostHistory.xml:4881:  <row Id="7276" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="570" RevisionGUID="b4b99f89-da0e-4140-9e4e-3c44e22b3103" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="Many users on this site use their real identity.  So, via google or a linked website, it is usually easy to find the contact details of a fellow user.  However, in cases when users wish -- for whatever reason -- to keep their identity secret, what is the protocol for private contact?  (This is not a cryptography question, btw.)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;This is somewhat related to &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/4/on-using-actual-names&quot;&gt;the question on using actual names&lt;/a&gt;.  Adding a private email function has its issues and one of these might be that it removes one less incentive for giving your true identity.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;This question occurred to me while answering &lt;a href=&quot;http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2328/when-should-you-say-what-you-know/2361#2361&quot;&gt;When should you say what you know?&lt;/a&gt;." />
./PostHistory.xml:4882:  <row Id="7277" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="583" RevisionGUID="a95c7480-d031-4caf-8cf2-7e4ee0f3ac41" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="Hi all,&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  I chatted with Lance Fortnow at FOCS about the various ideas I brought up in [my answer][1] to &quot;[Beta period progress][2]&quot;. This &quot;question&quot; is about the first, namely: &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; Write a note in SIGACT News&#xD;&#xA;&gt; advertising the site.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I was thinking (and maybe this is too pie-in-the-sky) that this post could be written jointly by the community, by editing this very post (I'll put a crude skeleton in place). The article, when published, could be attributed to the website &quot;with contributions from&quot; anyone who helped edit the post (but only real names, please). &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I'd like to make a few requests though:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; 1. Use an answer to discuss a particular aspect of the article. I understand that issues will overlap, but it's easier to track answers than have one giant comment thread below this question&#xD;&#xA; 2. Make sure you use your real name when editing. We can use revision history to determine who changed what. &#xD;&#xA; 3. I think it's also fair to assume that simple edits (syntax, spelling) are not at the contribution level that might merit &quot;with contributions from&quot;, so try to focus on content edits, and we can all chip in to fix minor issues. &#xD;&#xA; 4. If you want to discuss whether we should be doing this at all, a different question might be a better place for that. Frankly, I don't see a downside. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;**Current contributors (please update)**: Dave Clarke, David Eppstein, Kaveh Ghasemloo, Lev Reyzin, András Salamon, Peter Shor, Aaron Sterling, Suresh Venkatasubramanian.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;**Further Update:** I think we should finalize all edits by Friday noon (Mountain time). At that point I'll take the text and links, convert to latex-ized PDF, and send it off to the SIGACT News Editor. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;**More updates**. I'm now locking this post, since it's Friday @ Noon here in Utah. I'll start doing the latexing, and will link to a PDF shortly. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;**PDF Update**: [Here's a link to the PDF][3], with the citation format taken from [this meta discussion][4]. I have emailed this version to [Brendan Mumey][5] (SIGACT News editor)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;---&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Questions Answered. In theory.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    cstheory.stackexchange.com&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;------------------------------&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;###Questions Answered.  In Theory.###&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Perhaps you're a computer scientist wondering [how much the Axiom of Choice matters to the theorems you study and prove](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1923/which-interesting-theorems-in-tcs-rely-on-the-axiom-of-choice-or-alternatively).  Perhaps you're a mathematician who needs [a top expert to explain what &quot;randomness&quot; really means in computability and complexity](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1263/truly-random-number-generator-turing-computable).  Perhaps you need [a list of problems that can be used to show polynomial-time hardness results, to strengthen your toolkit of reductions](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1284/problems-that-can-be-used-to-show-polynomial-time-hardness-results/).  Or perhaps you think a problem might be open -- but might just as easily be solved -- so [you'd like to ask](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2708/complexity-of-greatest-common-divisor-gcd/2713) a group of professionals [what they think](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2461/interactive-proofs-for-levels-of-the-polynomial-hierarchy).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;###Visit cstheory.stackexchange.com###&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;[cstheory.stackexchange.com](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/) provides this interaction &quot;at the speed of the internet,&quot; by bringing together researchers from around the world, and across the broad spectrum of theoretical computer science.  Active participants range from advanced undergraduates to well-established scientists. Currently the majority of participants are graduate students and postdoctoral fellows, but the number of senior researchers active within the site is growing quickly.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Even though [cs.theory.stackexchange.com](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/) is only two months old, it can already boast of 2,000 registered users, 700 answered questions, and -- perhaps most exciting -- [new research collaborations among computer scientists](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2328/when-should-you-say-what-you-know/2362#2362) who otherwise might never have realized that they were working on related problems.  The atmosphere of the site is a bit like a corridor discussion at a conference: researchers discuss and explain both folklore and the newest results, in a format that can be read at leisure.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Some questions and their answers are highly technical, but the answers from experts are often more than just answers; they contain insights that are not available in papers or textbooks.  For example, a student who requested a &quot;common sense&quot; explanation for how padding arguments related to complexity class separations received [an intuitive answer from Russell Impagliazzo](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2434/why-do-complexity-classes-translate-upwards-and-not-downwards/2453#2453); Scott Aaronson summarized the [state-of-the-art in non-relativizing techniques][6]; Jeff Erickson explained why [the real RAM model is preferred in computational geometry][7]; and a student who asked whether the Nisan-Wigderson pseudorandom number generator relativizes received [an answer from Noam Nisan](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2236/does-nisans-pseudo-random-generator-relativize/2239#2239).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Questions have also generated new proofs: Peter Shor gave a [reduction from Max-Cut with positive weights to a constant-factor approximation for the version of the problem with negative weights][8]; Jukka Suomela demonstrated that [DOMINATING SET remains NP-complete for planar bipartite graphs of maximum degree 3][9]; Sariel Har-Peled showed that [Hamiltonicity is NP-complete for k-regular graphs for any fixed k][10]; and Per Vognsen outlined a [proof for the Schwartz-Zippel Lemma using projective geometry][11].&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;In addition to specific technical questions, participants have asked for more general advice from the community, such as [how to referee papers][12], possible [Master's thesis topics in automata theory](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/979/automata-theory-formal-language-thesis-topic), pointers to [recent purely functional data structures][13], suggestions for an [inspirational talk about theoretical computer science][14], and [how to find a job](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2215/how-to-get-a-job).  The site is a place for the larger theory community to come together.  The overall scope of the site is **research-level theoretical computer science, broadly defined**.  _Note that homework questions are not allowed on the site_.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Everyone with a research interest in theoretical computer science is welcome to create an account.  We encourage participation using real names -- and almost everybody does this -- but it's not required.  Participation costs nothing, and takes as little or as much time as you choose. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;###Site Origin and Structure###&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Some of the founding members of [cstheory.stackexchange.com](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/) participated in discussion of a proposed solution to the P/NP problem that spanned multiple blogs, led to the creation of wiki pages, and brought together researchers in disparate fields from around the world.  This effort made it clear that the worldwide theoretical computer science community was ready for -- and needed -- a structured way to ask research-level questions and to consider answers to such questions.  The success of MathOverflow.net (a site devoted to research-level mathematics) encouraged us to adopt the StackExchange software developed by Jeff Atwood and Joel Spolsky. This software provides a user reputation system built on up- and down-voting of contributions to highlight and encourage high quality, and to control spam.  There is also a [&quot;Meta&quot; area][15], for discussions about site scope and direction. Thus far, the system has worked extremely well and we are very pleased with it. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;###Who runs the site?###&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;You do ! The site is moderated by the community, with users gaining access to more management tools as they gain more reputation within the site. We have an active core of users who diligently monitor the site, help improve the quality of questions and answers, and filter out spam. In fact, this very article is a product of community participation on the site. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;But you don't have to worry about any of that to contribute to the numerous research discussions taking place right now. Please visit -- and participate in! -- [cstheory.stackexchange.com](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/), the 24/7/365 gathering-place for theoretical computer scientists from around the world to share information and insights.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/522/beta-period-progress/526#526&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/522/beta-period-progress&#xD;&#xA;  [3]: http://www.cs.utah.edu/~suresh/cstheory.pdf&#xD;&#xA;  [4]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/352/how-will-you-cite-a-discussion-on-this-site-in-your-paper&#xD;&#xA;  [5]: http://www.cs.montana.edu/mumey/www/Home.html&#xD;&#xA;  [6]: http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2045/are-there-canonical-non-relativizing-techniques/2048#2048&#xD;&#xA;  [7]: http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2119/the-reasons-for-bss-real-ram-model-being-prefered-in-computational-geometry/2124#2124&#xD;&#xA;  [8]: http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2312/max-cut-with-negative-weight-edges/2318#2318&#xD;&#xA;  [9]: http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2505/is-the-dominating-set-problem-restricted-to-planar-bipartite-graphs-of-maximum-de/2508#2508&#xD;&#xA;  [10]: http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1651/hamiltonicity-of-k-regular-graphs/1656#1656&#xD;&#xA;  [11]: http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1772/alternative-proofs-of-schwartzzippel-lemma/1883#1883&#xD;&#xA;  [12]: http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1893/how-do-i-referee-a-paper&#xD;&#xA;  [13]: http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1539/whats-new-in-purely-functional-data-structures-since-okasaki&#xD;&#xA;  [14]: http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2386/inspirational-talk-for-final-year-high-school-pupils/2411#2411&#xD;&#xA;  [15]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" />
./PostHistory.xml:4883:  <row Id="7278" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="597" RevisionGUID="b00b3050-61cb-4e27-b345-4f635b804759" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="Jukka has [mentioned](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/587/about-retagging-as-tag-removed) a [feature](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/search) (a page for more advanced searching) that I was not aware of. Are there other less-known features that you have found useful?" />
./PostHistory.xml:4884:  <row Id="7279" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="618" RevisionGUID="a6686450-33a9-425a-a1f8-9f2275bdbb5d" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="I think that one week is a good time to consider crossposting.  If you do so, please add links _in both directions_ so that people who read your question at either place will have a chance to know everything posted at the other place.  You can add a comment to the older post if you do not want to bump the question on the top page.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Since the [FAQ entry about crossposting](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/231#231) links here, I would like to express my opinion about something other than what is asked in this question, namely about crossposting in a short period of time (such as one day).  I feel that it is unfair that some people crosspost a question in more than one place, usually MathOverflow and cstheory.stackexchange.com.  Of course everyone wants to get his/her question answered as quickly as possible, and exposing the question in many places increases the chance.  But they should refrain from doing that, like the rest of us.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Some new users seem to crosspost questions because they do not know where the best place to ask is.  I do not think that it is the right reason for crossposting, either.  For them, I would recommend the following:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;1. Read each of the candidate websites a little so that you can make an educated guess about where the best place for your question is.&#xD;&#xA;2. Post your question at only one website.&#xD;&#xA;3. If you do not get a satisfactory answer in one week or so, crosspost the question on another website if you want to.  Do not forget to link in both directions!&#xD;&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:4885:  <row Id="7280" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="623" RevisionGUID="953d5937-f71d-492c-9447-2b07b4f70c7e" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="The comments and links to used when closing an elementary/homework question. I am making it CW, feel free to edit and/or add links to related discussions.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;---&#xD;&#xA;Related discussions:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/356/the-reason-to-close-too-elementary-questions&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/209/homework-or-things-that-look-like-homework&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/601/flood-of-homework-questions&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:4886:  <row Id="7281" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="625" RevisionGUID="6e6dca1a-2797-4c22-abf1-4ae3235694f3" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="As we're now one week away from the end of the 90-day beta period, I thought I'd re-raise the issue of our &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/522/beta-period-progress&quot;&gt;beta period progress&lt;/a&gt;.  So, what news?  &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;(This question really is about news, rather than about how we can bolster our progress, which I think was pretty well covered in the previous question.)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;At least on the &lt;a href=&quot;http://area51.stackexchange.com/proposals/8766/theoretical-computer-science&quot;&gt;proposal site&lt;/a&gt; we are no longer listed as &quot;worrying&quot; in any category, but still only &quot;okay&quot; in terms of questions and visits per day. ./PostHistory.xml:4887:  <row Id="7282" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="636" RevisionGUID="80c8e7e3-a2b5-4d4a-998d-ba99d3386a11" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="Current policy is to close all questions that &quot;feel like homework&quot; to at least five (high-reputated) people. Those more militant even downvote answers given by others even if those were hints rather than complete solutions. I want to argue for stopping this crusade and allowing all kind of questions that are posed well ([to be defined][1]) and concern TCS. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;First, rational reasons:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; 1. We cannot for sure distinguish homework from other questions¹&#xD;&#xA; 2. Getting help/inspiration is not always forbidden, sometimes even encouraged&#xD;&#xA; 3. We are not responsible for other people cheating&#xD;&#xA; 4. Some people are willing to help with low-level question&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Second, opinions:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; 1. By providing help for homework questions we can reach new users&#xD;&#xA; 2. We should let people help that want to&#xD;&#xA; 3. A well-posed question deserves at least some hints&#xD;&#xA; 4. Such questions will continue to pop up, always, thanks to Google. We may as well answer them.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The only two reasons I ever read against homework/low-level questions are cheating and scope. Cheating I consider not an issue (see above) and scope should, imho, be defined by active users. If such answer low-level questions, so be it. Those who have some pure utopia in their minds should evaluate wether or not they really speak for most people and/or the greater good. Using RSS it is easy enough to preselect questions based on their titles.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Your thoughts, please.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Ad (1): Let me link to some accepted questions one might consider as homework level:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; - [Proving skip-lists strongly weight-balanced in expectation][2] (skip lists and more complex analyses were covered in a Master course I took)&#xD;&#xA; - [Writing universal recursive function][3] (content in the very first Bachelor TCS course)&#xD;&#xA; - [Is the following problem NP-Hard?][4] (although allegedly no homework, simple NP-hardness proofs are Bachelor level)&#xD;&#xA; - [Is there a non Turing-complete model of computation whose halting problem is undecidable?][5] (could very well be asked in basic TCS courses for intuition building)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/559/another-go-at-scope-of-desirable-questions/&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2430/proving-skip-lists-strongly-weight-balanced-in-expectation&#xD;&#xA;  [3]: http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2398/writing-universal-recursive-function&#xD;&#xA;  [4]: http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2781/is-the-following-problem-np-hard&#xD;&#xA;  [5]: http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2537/is-there-a-non-turing-complete-model-of-computation-whose-halting-problem-is-unde" />

./PostHistory.xml:4889:  <row Id="7284" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="649" RevisionGUID="00b9d89f-47a6-4193-bbe3-1ec9b708dcc5" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="I have seen (and I have also used myself) the phrase “research-level questions in theoretical computer science” to describe the scope of cstheory.stackexchange.com.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;However, thinking about it, I believe that the word “research-level” in this context means something like “which arise or can arise in research _in TCS_”.  In other words, if a TCS question arises in research in an applied field and it is too easy for TCS research, I do _not_ think that it is usually called a “research-level question in TCS”.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;This seems too restrictive given that the consensus, though still being developed, seems to be to allow easy questions in TCS as long as they are not something like homework or typical exercises in textbooks and the asker has done reasonable due diligence (see the discussion “[On the feasibility of homework questions](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/636/on-the-feasibility-of-homework-questions)” started by Raphael and the comments on the question “[Is the following problem NP-Hard?](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2781/is-the-following-problem-np-hard)”).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Therefore, I want a better description of the scope.  What is your take?" />

./PostHistory.xml:4894:  <row Id="7289" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="673" RevisionGUID="1cba2b03-f4d5-485b-8112-887935acd26d" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="In the light of [this discussion on crossposted questions][1], I'm wondering if we should revisit our crossposting policy. [The current policy i][2]s:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; Crossposting from MathOverflow is&#xD;&#xA;&gt; perfectly fine, as long as they aren't&#xD;&#xA;&gt; done in parallel. That is, if you post&#xD;&#xA;&gt; a question on one site, you should&#xD;&#xA;&gt; only post to the other site after you&#xD;&#xA;&gt; have not received a satisfactory&#xD;&#xA;&gt; answer for some time. As a courtesy,&#xD;&#xA;&gt; if you post your question here after&#xD;&#xA;&gt; trying MathOverflow, please try to&#xD;&#xA;&gt; integrate in your question the answers&#xD;&#xA;&gt; you received on MathOverflow (even if&#xD;&#xA;&gt; they did not answer everything).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I'm proposing that we delete the statements &#xD;&#xA;&gt; as long as they aren't&#xD;&#xA;&gt; done in parallel. That is, if you post&#xD;&#xA;&gt; a question on one site, you should&#xD;&#xA;&gt; only post to the other site after you&#xD;&#xA;&gt; have not received a satisfactory&#xD;&#xA;&gt; answer for some time.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The rationale is that &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; - people are crossposting simultaneously anyway, and it seems tiresome to police users who for the most part have good intentions&#xD;&#xA; - Based on the above discussion, it seems that users don't have problems posting related answers on either site, so the duplication problem isn't that severe&#xD;&#xA; - It might even be viewed as a success of our site, as well as a natural reflection of the close ties to math, that this happens. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Thoughts ? &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Update: Current view (as Peter Shor recommends, in the light of discussion on MO) is: keep the policy as is, but don't come down too hard on cross posting (but definitely encourage people to wait)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/665/what-to-do-with-cross-posted-questions-answered-on-another-site&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/231#231" />
./PostHistory.xml:4895:  <row Id="7290" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="685" RevisionGUID="4615775f-8aaf-4f1a-a0df-13c665d01c70" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="We have an informal policy that all questions should have [at least one top level arxiv tag][1]. ./PostHistory.xml:4897:  <row Id="7292" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="706" RevisionGUID="0214a97c-d03a-400b-8b36-079d68fc41a9" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="_Update_: I like the design revision 2 very much.  Thank you, Jin!&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;---&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;_Edit: Below is my comments on revision 1._&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Thank you for the interesting design.  I like this modern look.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Here are a few comments:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### Logo&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;To be honest, I do not think the uppercase sigma is ideal as a logo.  The uppercase sigma is strongly related to discrete mathematics (because the symbol is used for summation), and it is true that theoretical computer science uses discrete mathematics a lot, but theoretical computer science is not the same as discrete mathematics.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;However, without a better alternative, the uppercase sigma is an acceptable compromise.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I like the [DFA idea](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/33/what-should-our-logo-be/314#314) as is used in Suresh’s publicity materials, but it will not be recognizable in a 16×16-pixel favicon.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### Typewriter font&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I like the use of typewriter font in the website title written on a tape of a Turing machine.  On the other hand, as Suresh said, I am worried about the use of typewriter font in question titles, too, but for a different reason.  Some of the question titles are long, and typewriter font takes too much width.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I do not think that a mix of two fonts is bad by itself.  I am not sure if we want to use the same roman font in both question titles and question bodies just because they can contain MathJax math.  &lt;del&gt;In my (uneducated) opinion, question bodies are probably better in a roman font but question titles can be sans-serif.&lt;/del&gt;  _Edit: I removed the last sentence; see my reply to Jin in a comment._&#xD;&#xA;" />

A note for IE6/IE7, while we try to make sure the site is functional for people using older browsers, we don't support them to the point of pixel perfectness.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I typically fix CSS/usability issues asap. As for more subjective styling requests, I tend to let the new design simmer a bit. After having used the Beta Sketchy theme for a few months, it will take a bit of time to get used to the new design.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The favicons may be cached by your browsers, to see the new ones, load the following URL in your browser's address bar and hard refresh.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;http://sstatic.net/cstheory/img/favicon.ico&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;http://sstatic.net/cstheorymeta/img/favicon.ico&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;P.S. ./PostHistory.xml:4900:  <row Id="7295" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="745" RevisionGUID="15b2a089-4efa-404b-988f-42d60d79a1be" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/358/on-topic-or-off-topic-do-you-use-any-article-organizers/359#359&quot;&gt;This answer&lt;/a&gt; is like saying in a CS class, a prof isn't allowed to talk (even briefly) about study habits.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;In my opinion closing this type of question out doesn't really benefit the site.  People on the __CLOSE OR DIE__ side want people to talk strictly about CS, but not about how to study CS.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I hadn't heard of Mendelay before, though I'm glad I have now, thanks to one of the answers to that question.  Interestingly, a &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.google.ca/#q=research+paper+organizer&quot;&gt;Google search for research paper organizer&lt;/a&gt; doesn't reveal Mendelay on the first page of results just yet.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;So, my point is, although this question doesn't fit in `/Academia/CS`, it still fits in `/Academia`.  Its not out of scope.&#xD;&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:4901:  <row Id="7296" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="759" RevisionGUID="5de77fae-c7d1-4937-b2c8-6a290a998197" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="I have been thinking about this for sometime. As you know, SE has changed the Community Wiki policy and now only moderators can make a question a CW. Community Wiki has 2 main effects:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;1. The question becomes owned by community, the original OP does not gain reputation,&#xD;&#xA;2. The required reputation to edit drops to 100,&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;and a side effect:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;3. The answers posted after a questions becomes a Community Wiki become Community Wiki automatically, i.e. the answers are owned by community, (but answers posted before the question becoming CW don't).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;These three effects are not always correlated and there are cases that one wants to have one of these three but not the other two, e.g. the owner does not want to earn reputation but wants the users answering the question to earn reputation for their answers. So it seems to me that SE is mixing too many things in one concept and that is the main reason for many issues we had and have with CW policy.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Robin brought up the idea that we should make the non-CW answers to a CW question CW also. I have a problem with answers becoming CW when the question becomes CW because sometimes the answers deserve to earn reputation, but in the current situation it makes sense, if the answers need to be CW then the previous ones also need to be CW, on the other hand a user might not have answered a question if it was a CW question so I don't know what is the right thing to do here.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I see three clear reasons for making a question a CW (and it would be nice to add other reasons to this list):&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;1. OP doesn't want to earn reputation (for some reason),&#xD;&#xA;2. OP wants to allow others to edit,&#xD;&#xA;3. the question is a ranking list.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;For example I think a question like [this][1] and [this][2] should be CW but the answers should not be and the users answering them should earn reputation for their answers. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Another issue is that the new policy is not clear on what we should do when we think a question or answer needs to be CW, I used to flag some posts for moderator attention but don't do it any more because I now think it is not very nice to suggest someone else question or answer should be CW to the moderators, so I have decided to go with a softer way of adding comments like &quot;I would upvote it if it becomes CW&quot;.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I have an proposal that I think might solve some issues and would like to hear what others think about it:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; In general the question or answer should be made CW only on the request of the owner (with some exceptions, see below), other users that think the post should be CW can leave a non-abusive comment like: &quot;nice answer, I would upvote it if it becomes CW&quot; and up-vote only if/when it becomes CW.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Exceptions:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;1. the OP is a drive-by user and does not reply to the answers or comments after considerable time,&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;2. some clear cases like: a ranking list. These should be explicitly included in the policy,&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;3. other special situations where the moderators have strong reasons for making a question CW.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;What do you think about this proposal (agree, disagree, opinions, improvements and suggestions, ...) and CW in general? &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;**ps:**&#xD;&#xA;Another minor issue about CW is its (lack of) effect on badges, it seems strange that a user does not earn reputation but does earn badges for CW posts, e.g. I should not have earned a badges for [these answers](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/174/major-unsolved-problems-in-theoretical-computer-science/218#218). Right now many of higher level badges are awarded for CW questions/answers, which does not seem a good thing to me.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;---&#xD;&#xA;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/239#239&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/25/material-to-supplement-the-faq&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;---&#xD;&#xA;### MO policy&#xD;&#xA; - http://meta.mathoverflow.net/discussion/6/when-should-questions-be-community-wiki&#xD;&#xA; - http://mathoverflow.net/faq#communitywiki&#xD;&#xA; &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### SE policy&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; - http://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/392/should-the-community-wiki-police-be-shut-down&#xD;&#xA; - http://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/67581/community-wiki-checkbox-missing-in-action&#xD;&#xA; - http://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/67039/what-can-we-do-to-make-community-wiki-better&#xD;&#xA; - http://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/11740/what-are-community-wiki-posts&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### Old discussions on cstheory meta:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; - https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/34/community-wiki-etiquette&#xD;&#xA; - https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/62/developing-a-cw-policy&#xD;&#xA; - https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/201/community-wikis&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]:  http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/45/what-are-good-references-to-understanding-the-proof-of-the-pcp-theorem&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2953/advice-on-good-research-practices" />
./PostHistory.xml:4902:  <row Id="7297" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="792" RevisionGUID="a4639f1d-df21-4b86-ab6d-03f221cb4f92" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="The Stack Exchange software has many small oddities.  Serious misfeatures should be fixed, but often small oddities are just slightly frustrating and not properly called bugs.  Although all of the oddities should be fixed in the ideal world, it cannot be expected that every small glitch will be fixed.  Sharing them and their workarounds may mitigate the harm caused by those oddities.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; **Question**.  What is the small oddity you are aware of, and what is a workaround for it?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The question may not be as clear as I hoped it to be.  See [my answer](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/792/small-oddities-in-the-se-software-and-their-workarounds/793#793), which may clarify the question." />
./PostHistory.xml:4903:  <row Id="7298" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="803" RevisionGUID="0d38c29e-14f8-43ab-b22f-7b00dac4a4f0" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="_Edit: I take back this proposal. Also, they can be renamed to a new tag [tag:pseudorandom-generators] for clarity.  Therefore, I propose the following:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- Rename [tag:prg] and [tag:pseudorandomness] to [tag:pseudorandom-generators].&#xD;&#xA;- Make [tag:prg] and [tag:pseudorandomness] synonyms for [tag:pseudorandom-generators].&#xD;&#xA;- Cancel my older [proposal](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/tags/pseudorandomness/synonyms) to make [tag:prg] a tag synonym for [tag:pseudorandomness], which I started without considering alternatives.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;__Note__. ./PostHistory.xml:4904:  <row Id="7299" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="810" RevisionGUID="60fdd123-c5ea-43c1-a7da-ef0665cafb27" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="Here is what Suresh added to the meta discussion “[Policy: Questions about topic for research project](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/802/policy-questions-about-topic-for-research-project)” started by Aaron Sterling:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; This is a policy question.  The proposed policy in the question (or answers) will be adopted in the case that after 3 days it received at least 5 votes with a majority in favor.  Please upvote or downvote this question based on your opinion of the policy statement as presented (not based on whether the premise of the question is reasonable)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;While I agree on the general principle, I do not agree on the implementation because “at least 5 votes with a majority in favor” is too weak.  In my opinion, most policy changes will not be urgent, and therefore we should adopt a new policy only when it is highly supported.  A proposal with 3 upvotes and 2 downvotes would not be highly supported.  Therefore, I think that we should require at least 5 upvotes in net, that is, (# of upvotes) − (# of downvotes) ≥ 5.  If 5 sounds too large, it is negotiable.&#xD;&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:4905:  <row Id="7300" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="816" RevisionGUID="35b960db-611b-4230-80b8-7a9f8325151c" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="We have just had our [1000th question][1]; and this is the 12th day we launched; not long, but enough to see how we're doing. Lots of discussions have been done in the [review post of beta][2], while the number of questions is a [weak link][3] of us, we do not have [enough upvotes][4], and also there are a number of [homework problems][5], we tried our best to [increase the quality][6] of the posts and answers.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Although numbers are not important, sometimes they serve as indicators. I have just observed [a drop in the answer ratio][7]; at the time [we graduated from beta][8] it was about 2.8, and now it is about 2.5. It is also interesting that in the mean time, our traffic rate is constantly increasing, and the number of [active users][9] (users with a positive reputation change) in the late month is passed a hundred, a little increase compares to it was in beta.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Maybe the cause of the drop in the answer ratio is the homework problems, but I am not sure. Is this a healthy decrease (since we do not want to push the site too hard), or is it a signal of lacking enough thrust to keep flying our rocket? What do you think?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Another issue is the bounty system. It seems to me that recently, none of the questions with bounties have been answered in the bounty time period. The same problem [occurs in MO][10], which may due to both sites are theoretical oriented, and since it is related to the system of SE, we do not have too much we can do. Is there any solution to the bounty problem, despite the fact that it serves as a [mechanism to attract more attention][11]?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Final thoughts, it seems that most of the traffics comes from a particular region of the world (maybe US), since there is a low traffic gap (for about 8 hours) in the posts. Not a problem but an observation, but I do expect more experts and grad students all over the world to join our community.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Keep going, see how far we can reach :)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/3756/why-is-it-tn-4-work-for-each-block-of-the-matrix-in-this-divide-and-conquer-tra&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/522/beta-period-progress&#xD;&#xA;  [3]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/522/beta-period-progress/544#544&#xD;&#xA;  [4]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/6/vote-early-and-often&#xD;&#xA;  [5]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/601/flood-of-homework-questions&#xD;&#xA;  [6]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/522/beta-period-progress/524#524&#xD;&#xA;  [7]: http://stackexchange.com/sites&#xD;&#xA;  [8]: http://area51.stackexchange.com/proposals/8766/theoretical-computer-science&#xD;&#xA;  [9]: http://stackexchange.com/leagues/44/month/cstheory/2010-12-01?sort=reputationchange&amp;page=3&#xD;&#xA;  [10]: http://meta.mathoverflow.net/discussion/710/the-bounty-time-is-just-too-short/#Item_0&#xD;&#xA;  [11]: http://meta.mathoverflow.net/discussion/246/if-nobody-responds-to-a-bounty-why-do-you-still-lose-the-rep/#Item_0" />
./PostHistory.xml:4906:  <row Id="7301" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="822" RevisionGUID="f543853d-eed3-40f2-8c33-01f32593284e" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="_Update_: I withdrew this policy proposal.  It received 5 downvotes and no upvotes.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;---&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;This is a **policy proposal**.  The proposed policy in the question or its answers will be adopted in the case that after 3 days it received at least 5 upvotes with a 2/3 majority in favor (*).  Please upvote or downvote this question or its answers based on your opinion of the policy statement as presented, not just based on whether the premise of the question or its answers is reasonable.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;(*) That is, &lt;i&gt;x&lt;/i&gt;≥5 and &lt;i&gt;x&lt;/i&gt;≥2&lt;i&gt;y&lt;/i&gt;, where &lt;i&gt;x&lt;/i&gt; is the number of upvotes and &lt;i&gt;y&lt;/i&gt; is the number of downvotes.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;---&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I propose the following as a policy:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; **POLICY**.  Questions that describe a proof of some statement or an algorithm for some problem and ask others to do all the work to check its correctness are deemed to be off topic and closed.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The intent is to give a clear ground to close questions like “[Algorithm for Longest Path in Undirected Weighted Graph](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/3706/algorithm-for-longest-path-in-undirected-weighted-graph-closed)” in the future.  While the question had a specific goal (present a counterexample to the stated algorithm), I find it wrong to ask other people simply to do all the work to check the correctness of proofs or algorithms.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The proposal has something in common with some of the answers to “[How to ask a good question?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/300/how-to-ask-a-good-question),” namely [this one](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/300/how-to-ask-a-good-question/304#304), [this one](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/300/how-to-ask-a-good-question/306#306) and [this one](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/300/how-to-ask-a-good-question/318#318), even if they did not already cover the case with which this proposal is concerned.&#xD;&#xA;" />

./PostHistory.xml:4910:  <row Id="7305" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="838" RevisionGUID="1a85b901-d09b-4d3f-b371-106137ce846b" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="As I wrote in a comment on [V Vinay’s answer](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/826/dealing-with-user-issue/827#827), I hope that the standard methods can handle these issues.  Indeed, the Stack Exchange server has a few ways to “hide” posts with low score, which I think can be used to mitigate the ill effects of poorly written posts, not limited to the ones posted by a particular user.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- Questions with score −4 or below are not shown on the top page.&#xD;&#xA;- Answers with score −3 or below are shown in gray ([they were not for a while, but it has been fixed](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/837/answers-with-low-score-are-no-longer-shown-in-gray-text)).&#xD;&#xA;" />

./PostHistory.xml:4915:  <row Id="7310" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="886" RevisionGUID="394b4cf1-8953-4309-be54-4ca3eb16b523" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="&gt;This is a policy question. The proposed policy in the question (or answers) will be adopted in the case that after 7 days it receives at least 5 up votes with a 2/3 majority in favor. Please upvote or downvote this question based on your opinion of the policy statement as presented (not based on whether the premise of the question is reasonable).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;1. Please first read: [Should we permit linking to illegal stuff?][1]&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;2. If you have a proposal please post it as an answer.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;3. I will start with a draft just for online copies of copyrighted books which are both unauthorized and illegal (under laws of USA and the state that its laws apply to SE). If you want to include any other thing please post it as a modification to the policy in an answer.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;4. This is a policy for the site that *we adopt* (in the case it is accepted) and does not imply legal obligations of any kind for moderators/community.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; **Policy Proposal** (Jan. 19, 2011): Links to unauthorized illegal online copies of copyrighted books are not welcome on this site. Posting such links is considered *unethical* and *not respectful* to our colleagues; it is not a nice practice. Users are **discouraged** from posting such links.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; Questions asking for such links should be closed.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/879/should-we-permit-linking-to-illegal-stuff" />

On the [election page](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/election/1?tab=nomination), [his statement](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/election/1?tab=nomination#post-4578) is grayed out, and there is no “add comment” link.
