./PostHistory.xml:4917:  <row Id="7312" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="911" RevisionGUID="77fd5dbc-a4a3-43fe-9000-b871f2f0d4c2" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="It took me some time to figure out how the user interface at http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/election works, so here is what I learned:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- It is not a typical SE user interface where you can change your mind by clicking the vote button again.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- If you are quick, you *can* change your votes, and you can remove *some* of your votes. For example, if you have chosen A = 1st and B = 2nd, then you can select C = 2nd and your vote on B is removed. And then you can then select C = 1st, and your vote on A is removed, too. This way you can remove all of your votes, *except one*! A strange limitation, but that seems to be how it works.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- At some point your votes get frozen. If you try to change your votes, you only get a popup note that says &quot;Your votes are too old to be changed&quot;.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;**Edit:** See https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/913/your-votes-are-too-old-to-be-changed for yet another feature of the system." />
./PostHistory.xml:4918:  <row Id="7313" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="920" RevisionGUID="9571961e-089c-4d27-b63f-fd0fc31bd541" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="Each StackExchange site should have a Migration FAQ. For us, this would be a summary of selected answers in our [FAQ][1], namely those dealing with what is on- and what is off-topic. It should not be longer than half a dozen one-liners.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Before a migration vote can be made, the target site's Migration FAQ pops up with a button to actually vote below it (similar to license crap). This directly educates the migrator under the assumption that he cares (hopefully valid) and prevents a nasty bounce to happen.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science" />
./PostHistory.xml:4919:  <row Id="7315" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="944" RevisionGUID="ac1e3d5f-8eac-4be4-b51b-7493aef5d840" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="Now that [one problem](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/823/should-we-put-the-phrase-research-level-in-our-general-faq) of the page [cstheory.stackexchange.com/faq](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/faq) has been resolved, we would like to discuss another: namely, the existence of two lists of FAQs is confusing.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- [cstheory.stackexchange.com/faq](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/faq) (which I call “FAQ on main” here)&#xD;&#xA;- [Official FAQ for Theoretical Computer Science](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science) on the meta site (which I call “FAQ on meta” here)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;(I am not talking about the [FAQ _about_ meta](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/faq), which serves a different purpose.)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I hope that the new text on the FAQ on main reduces the problem of having two lists by listing some of the most important entries in the FAQ on meta.  Still, I cannot help imagining that both pages are claiming _I am the official one!  I am more important than the other list!  Read me first!_, which I do not like.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Note that the moderators cannot edit everything on the FAQ on main, although they can edit certain parts of it.  In a discussion which happened in comments on [this post](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/823/should-we-put-the-phrase-research-level-in-our-general-faq/927#927), Suresh (Feb 4 at 16:22) has suggested merging the FAQ on meta to the FAQ on main by putting everything before the section “What kind of questions should I _not_ ask here?” (if I understand it correctly).  I am not sure if that is the best way.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;_Update: It turned out that Suresh’s suggestion was something different.  See the comment._&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Other solutions may be:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;1. Include the links of all _questions_ in the FAQ on meta in the FAQ on main as an itemized list.&#xD;&#xA;2. Leave the FAQ page on main as is now, and rename the FAQ on meta to something along “Supplemental FAQ for Theoretical Computer Science.”&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;What do you think?" />
./PostHistory.xml:4920:  <row Id="7316" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="946" RevisionGUID="14535d41-3097-493d-9811-cdcddbb99e99" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="*It seems that overzealous folks at Area 51 closed the proposal without giving it a fair chance.* (Dave Clarke)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;--&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;`mathoverflow.net` is for mathematicians. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;`math.stackexchange.com` is for *wannabe* and *newbie* mathematicians. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;-&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;`cstheory.stackexchange.com` is for computer scientists. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;`but-there-is-nothing-AFAIK` for *wannabe* and *newbie* computer scientists. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Some might say that you can ask your stupid non-research-level questions at math.SE. &#xD;&#xA;Well, most probably that won't work. For these [reasons][1].&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Such website can help beginners to get to &quot;research level&quot; quickly and then contribute to cstheroy.SE. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; - **UPDATE:** Now there is one for [Beginner Theoretical Computer Scientists!](http://area51.stackexchange.com/proposals/29144/beginner-theoretical-computer-science)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;NOTES:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; - By newbie and wannabe I mean me :D &#xD;&#xA; - &lt;strike&gt;I have searched area51.SE but there is no such proposal currently.&lt;/strike&gt;&#xD;&#xA; - Being a beginner I strongly feel need for beginner cstheory website.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;So, should there be cstheory website for beginners? &#xD;&#xA;If yes, please suggest a good name for the same. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/q/92/612" />
./PostHistory.xml:4921:  <row Id="7317" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="962" RevisionGUID="ea9f6f99-51be-41c6-aa47-08edf3b37191" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="This is in part a response to Robert Cartaino's comment on Suresh's comment response [here](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/947/is-theoretical-computer-science-too-narrow/961#961).  I wanted to separate it out from the other discussion, though.  I'd like to start by contrasting two questions, one on StackOverflow, and one here.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;First, consider [How do I move the turtle in LOGO](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/1003841/how-do-i-move-the-turtle-in-logo), especially the history of edits and closes.  A simple question with a simple answer, and, instead, it was repeatedly edited and closed by users who decided the question was fake, had nothing to do with programming, etc.  In this case, the asker was someone who wasn't leaving, so he clarified his position and eventually got an answer.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Now consider the question about [disproving the Church-Turing thesis](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/88/what-would-it-mean-to-disprove-church-turing-thesis).  In this case, I answered the question, it received a lot of upvotes, and was accepted by the asker.  However, in the months since that occurred, some of the finest minds in TCS have commented or answered that question, both explaining how wrong I was, and also sharing deep insights about the issue.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;A question I'd like people to consider is: Would you rather have a culture of arrogance, in which anyone with enough rep can decide, &quot;Get real, you couldn't possibly be Donald Knuth, I'm closing your question,&quot; or would you rather have a culture in which leading researchers feel comfortable adding to a question where a fairly high rep user already posted an accepted answer?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The question behind this question is, &quot;Why is there such a difference in the two sites?&quot;  I believe the answer lies in StackOverflow's fallacious belief that crowdsourcing is the best way to arrive at truth.  This may be the case for questions at the level of an Ask-the-Audience game show -- or even most in-the-trenches programming questions -- but when literally only a handful of people know the answer, and there are plenty of ways to deceive yourself that you solved the problem (when you didn't), the method breaks down.  Crowdsourcing does not produce truth; it only produces *an answer that nobody feels like debating any more*.  This lack of debate might arise because everyone is convinced, or because the few people who know the real answer don't see the point of participating.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Suresh has made the point well that a one-size-fits-all perspective about StackExchange sites does not work.  However, I believe this argument does not go far enough.  The quality of questions and answers on StackOverflow would *significantly increase* if that site were broken into smaller pieces.  If quality in answers is the priority, it should be harder than it currently is for C# experts to answer functional programming questions, as one example.  Rather than the academic caution that we have inherited -- not wanting to brashly say things about a field we know little about -- the StackOverflow model encourages people who get lots and lots of upvotes to answer questions in areas where there is little participation, because they'll get even more upvotes, and the people who know better aren't around, or don't want to start confrontation by calling them out.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Right now, on cstheory, if someone created a profile named &quot;Donald Knuth&quot; or &quot;Avi Wigderson&quot; or whoever, and asked a question, I bet everyone would be careful to treat that user like any other, and to treat the question professionally.  The content of the question is what is important, not &quot;making sure we're not being trolled&quot; or whatever.  I believe this attitude comes from our common belief in the importance of truth, as something beyond, &quot;Good enough,&quot; or, &quot;This is what works.&quot;  Moving forward, I think the most important thing to bear in mind is that we want to attract members who share that understanding of the primacy of mathematical truth.  That's what we share with others interested in theory.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;StackExchange, of course, gets revenue as a function of number-of-hits, so I am sure they see the high traffic of StackOverflow as a great thing that should not be messed with by separating out pieces of it.  Ok, fine.  But if they are interested in more crossover among disciplines, they could, for example, institute a tag system that crosses sites.  So, for example, a chemist posting on biostar about the degree sequence of a molecular graph could see questions about degree sequences on cstheory -- and the graph theorist here could see a potential application for the theoretical work!  Personally, I would *love* such a feature.  I'd like to ask Joel Spolsky and Robert Cartaino to work on *that*, instead of asking us to adapt to the StackOverflow site model, which would not serve us well." />
./PostHistory.xml:4922:  <row Id="7318" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="975" RevisionGUID="e531c651-b2d5-4884-8261-1ed1280c1e4d" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="In our discussion of whether the _Theoretical_ Computer Science is too narrow for this site, I [suggested][1] a compromise idea that would have different forums like this site, all linked together more so than the average SE sites.  It has been observed that this idea can even tackle the [beginners forum][2] issue (though I am not sure that would be a good idea).  One major impediment is that the current software does not support such an idea, so the SE people would have to put in considerable effort to make it happen.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The idea went as follows:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; I think it would be great to have a&#xD;&#xA;&gt; CS stackexchange site that had&#xD;&#xA;&gt; multiple &quot;forums&quot; (for the different&#xD;&#xA;&gt; fields of CS) like cstheory. The&#xD;&#xA;&gt; membership could be shared. The&#xD;&#xA;&gt; reputation points could transfer&#xD;&#xA;&gt; across the forums. But each site&#xD;&#xA;&gt; should have its own homepage which&#xD;&#xA;&gt; featured only its own questions - tags&#xD;&#xA;&gt; and filters are not nearly enough.&#xD;&#xA;&gt; Perhaps the featured bounty questions&#xD;&#xA;&gt; could be shared across forums, as&#xD;&#xA;&gt; could questions with very high scores.&#xD;&#xA;&gt; That way, we could see what exciting&#xD;&#xA;&gt; things are happening in the other&#xD;&#xA;&gt; fields and would be tempted to&#xD;&#xA;&gt; occasionally browse the other forums&#xD;&#xA;&gt; without their questions clogging the&#xD;&#xA;&gt; theory ones. This would increase the&#xD;&#xA;&gt; user base as users from all the forums&#xD;&#xA;&gt; would occasionally do some browsing&#xD;&#xA;&gt; and answering each others' questions.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The response seems to have been positive.  I am curious:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; 1. **Is there support within the community for such a proposal (if done right)?**&#xD;&#xA; 2. **_Assuming there is community support_, is this something the people running StackExchange are willing to consider implementing.**&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Does anyone see a downside? Is there opposition to this idea?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I guess cstheory users can only answer question 1 and the people running SE can only answer question 2.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/947/is-theoretical-computer-science-too-narrow/964#964&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/946/a-cstheory-website-for-beginners/974#974" />
./PostHistory.xml:4923:  <row Id="7319" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1002" RevisionGUID="b67743b2-6307-40a6-b3d2-57d9997f5f07" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="This is related to [the question about top-level tags](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/q/455/1800).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;It seem to me that the tag [tag:computability] acts differently than other tags. While it belongs to the top-level tag [tag:lo.logic] (is it?), a large number of question with [tag:computability] just don't have any top-level tags. I guess some of the poster raises their questions in the field out of [tag:lo.logic], and it is just hard to think of this top-level tag while posting. And maybe some of them just think that [tag:computability] *is* the top-level tag.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;It seems that there are no related categories in Arxiv, so what should we do? Should we leave them there? Should we tag them with [tag:lo.logic]? Or should we make a fake Arxiv tag, like [tag:cp.computability]?" />
./PostHistory.xml:4924:  <row Id="7320" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1003" RevisionGUID="c783ce74-7708-4f74-a273-dc67338a1b08" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="Yes, we have treated the [computability] tag as a top level tag, it is like the [quantum-computing] and [physics] tags, and I personally don't see any problem with them. I also don't think they need to have the [lo.logic] tag.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;It might be better to have one corresponding to the AA.BBBB syntax like other top level tags, in which case I should say I don't think [cp.computability] is a good one, [ct.computability] (for computability theory) would be much better, but I think [computability] is also good enough.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/271/official-interim-procedure-for-doing-retagging" />
./PostHistory.xml:4925:  <row Id="7321" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1012" RevisionGUID="1360dbc2-4144-4a27-b624-1f1239b39611" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="It is [recommended](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/455/using-at-least-one-top-level-arxiv-tag) to tag every question with at least one in the (vaguely recognized) set of tags that represent the subject areas of questions.  These tags are sometimes referred to as “top-level tags,” but I would like to change this name if there is a better name.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The word “top-level” implies existence of a hierarchical structure.  Since most tags are not part of any hierarchical structure, the word “top-level” does not make much sense.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Does anyone have an idea what they should be called?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;---&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;_Update_: Let’s call them “area tags.”  (Thanks to Kaveh for proposing this name.)  It is a concise name which describes their nature pretty accurately." />
./PostHistory.xml:4926:  <row Id="7322" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1019" RevisionGUID="2fd79459-a06b-4f54-9fdb-b05e77dd8d58" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="This is a continuation of a discussion which took place in comments on [this post](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/1002/computability-behaves-like-a-top-level-tag/1006#1006).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;It is [recommended](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/455/using-at-least-one-top-level-arxiv-tag) to tag every question with at least one **area tag** ([formerly called “top-level tag”](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/1012/better-name-for-the-so-called-top-level-tags)).  Currently area tags are named in the following way:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- The area tags which originate from [CoRR subject areas](http://arxiv.org/corr/subjectclasses) are named as `xx.description` where `xx` is the coresponding CoRR subject area codes and `description` is the descriptive name of the area.  Examples are [tag:cr.crypto-security], [tag:cg.comp-geom], [tag:ds.algorithms] and [tag:ds.data-structures].  Note that some area tags deviate from the categorization in CoRR.&#xD;&#xA;- The other area tags are labeled like usual tags.  Examples are [tag:computability] and [tag:quantum-computing].&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;There are two problems with the current area tags.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- Names depend on whether they originate from CoRR subject areas or not, which is not an important distinction.  Therefore tags look simply inconsistent.&#xD;&#xA;- There is no advantage of having the corresponding CoRR subject area codes in the tags.  As I understand it, the only purpose of these codes is to indicate that they are area tags.  However, this is incomplete because not every area tag has a two-letter code.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I think that a more consistent naming is better.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;If the Stack Exchange server had a functionality of showing area tags in a different color, we would not have to distinguish them by names.  Because it does not have such a functionality, it is better to distinguish area tags by names.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Therefore, I propose the following:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;**Proposal**.  Remove the `xx.` part from the area tags of the form `xx.description` and instead add a fixed prefix to all the area tags.  As the fixed prefix, I suggest to use either `a.` (for “area”) or just `.`.  [_Edit_: I removed the earlier suggestions `a:` and `:` because it turned out that a colon cannot be used in tags.]&#xD;&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:4927:  <row Id="7323" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1045" RevisionGUID="ea0f26cf-ac30-4369-9d98-d63f8505adfb" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="The last time we did an IRL (in real life) promotional event for TCS.SE was at [FOCS 2010][1]. I don't unfortunately have any data on whether that event worked to draw more people in. We also had the SIGACT News article in the latest issue. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;[FCRC](http://www.acm.org/fcrc/) is coming up, and STOC/CCC/EC/PLDI/PODC/SPAA will be there. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;What kinds of promotional events might we carry out at FCRC ? In your answer, please clarify also if you plan to attend, and in what capacity you'd be willing to help with execution of your suggestion. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Also, to help with brainstorming, it might be useful to separate out &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; - activities that help with spreading word about the site&#xD;&#xA; - activities that help increase participation from established researchers as well&#xD;&#xA; - new activities that could become regular occurrences at major conference events.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/457/nominations-for-publicity-poster-at-focs" />
./PostHistory.xml:4928:  <row Id="7324" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1086" RevisionGUID="c524fba7-ca8d-40d7-a489-7e49ef4bb396" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="I ask moderators to be very careful when migrating questions to Stack Exchange websites.  When in doubt, please close questions as off topic, possibly with a comment suggesting one or a few candidates of websites, and let the asker decide where to ask.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Note that [we have been frustrated](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/919/migration-problems-both-sides-should-be-involved-in-making-migration-decisions) by the fact that some questions are migrated _to_ cstheory when they should not be.  We should not do the same thing to other websites.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Here is a recent example: [Is there a program / app / algorithm that can sort items using manual choices and deductive logic?](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/5615/is-there-a-program-app-algorithm-that-can-sort-items-using-manual-choices-and?noredirect=1)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;This question was recently migrated to Stack Overflow, but I cannot see any programming aspect in the question, and I think that it was wrong to migrate it to Stack Overflow.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;In fact, this is a question on query complexity.  Since it is too basic (the Ω(&lt;i&gt;n&lt;/i&gt; log &lt;i&gt;n&lt;/i&gt;) lower bound is well-known and sometimes even covered in undergraduate courses) and the asker had posted the same question on [math](http://math.stackexchange.com/questions/28752/is-there-a-program-or-app-that-will-let-you-sort-items-using-manual-choices-and-d) (thanks to Yuval Filmus for the link), I think that it should have been closed as off topic." />
./PostHistory.xml:4929:  <row Id="7325" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1089" RevisionGUID="efb66b1f-8d03-47d1-9f8e-e0db6eebc662" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="Is there any chance that some ideas from &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/1052/promotion-t-shirt-design&quot;&gt;this discussion&lt;/a&gt; might be implemented some day?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;If yes, probably, we can start discussion here?" />
./PostHistory.xml:4930:  <row Id="7326" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1093" RevisionGUID="8f3eb7de-9f74-4b51-8185-e6c58e68b21a" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="While a person can become a pro in one topic, it is not possible to master all the fields; even if we narrow it to computer science. Interdisciplinary fields make the problem worse. For instance, someone who works in (theoretical, not applied) cryptography must have a good knowledge of the computational complexity.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;What happens when you need to ask a question which, while related to your research topic, happens to be lie within another field? Well, a complicated problem for you might be too basic for researches in the target field.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I like the model of Math.SE / MathOverflow a lot: If I think my question is too basic (which usually is!), I'll ask it on Math.SE. Research-level questions can be asked on the latter.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;This discussion has recently gained momentum on Area51; here are some links:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* [Two level model (MO/Math.SE) vs one level model (SO)](http://discuss.area51.stackexchange.com/questions/612/two-level-model-mo-math-se-vs-one-level-model-so)&#xD;&#xA;* [What problems does the two-level split solve](http://discuss.area51.stackexchange.com/questions/630/what-problems-does-the-two-level-split-solve)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;And even proposals like **Beginner Theoretical Computer Science** or **Computer Science** were  considered; but they were soon deleted/closed due to lack of support / misunderstanding that they are exact duplicates of other SE sites.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;**Lack of Support:** I believe that such proposals did not advertise themselves well. For instance, if I ever knew that they exist, I'd join them at once. This is the main reason I'm raising the issue here.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;**Exact Duplicates:** Some of the voters (to close) claimed that such proposals are exact duplicates of StackOverflow, while others claim that they are exact duplicates of TCS.SE. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* The former group believed that anything in computer science which is not theoretical is programming related. In my opinion, that is plain wrong. A basic question about Turing machines is a simple counterexample.&#xD;&#xA;* The latter group were unable to distinguish between research-level questions and basic ones.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Some discussions can be found here: [Is Computer Science a duplicate of Theoretical Computer Science](http://discuss.area51.stackexchange.com/q/682/22946).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;In an extreme case, Jonik suggested: &quot;Instead of another site, how about modifying the description of the existing site to allow a little less advanced CS theory questions too.&quot; His suggestion was unwelcome, and received some down-votes. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;In another thread, &#xD;&#xA;Joel Spolsky [requested](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/q/947/873) that we (TCS.SE) broaden our view. His suggestion didn't go anywhere either.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; **The bottom line:** I believe that CSTheory must have a non-research-level counterpart. I ask people here to help (re)create one on Area51, and support it adequately.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;PS: There's always an issue of homeworks: Professors don't like their students to *cheat* by asking homework problems in online forums. This can be handled as in Math.SE, or by developing adequate policies at the new site." />
./PostHistory.xml:4931:  <row Id="7327" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1099" RevisionGUID="2c6d03ad-6f12-47d7-90ee-1bdb13450baf" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="This question http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/5927/how-fundamental-is-undecidability-closed was closed within 25 minutes of being asked.  The OP was rude to a moderator in the comments, and it isn't a great question, so I do think closing it was a fair call.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;However, for me this has highlighted that we seem to be closing questions rather quickly, and certainly before the OP has a chance to change the question in light of comments, for instance to add pointers to literature, or to explain their motivation.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;This may be a reasonable rule, but I don't see it in the FAQ.  Some poor questions in the earlier days of the site went on to be revised (by the OP and by others) to become interesting and useful, generating significant numbers of page views and votes.  There were even instances where for initially uninteresting questions some great answers were provided (e.g. http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/4372/highest-lower-bound-on-np-problems-tsp/4373#4373, http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2349/true-bit-complexity-of-matrix-multiplication-is-on4/2350#2350, and http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2274/permanents-approximation-and-connection-to-integer-factorization/2276#2276 come to mind).  I don't have easy access to the vote histories for pages, but I seem to recall that some fairly anodyne questions even ended up being heavily upvoted after a stellar answer was provided, sort of basking in the reflected glow.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Previous discussions mentioned wanting to keep a clean front page _during the beta_, see https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/299/on-closing-and-the-awesome-power-of-moderation, https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/378/how-much-time-before-closing-a-question, and https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/695/why-the-extreme-strictness-on-topic-closing/699#699.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I would even hesitate asking a question like http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2136/rigour-leading-to-insight today.  This question started out quite vague but through feedback turned into a reasonable question, and more importantly led to insightful responses by several people.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Is there an unwritten rule that no-one (not even Ryan) shall ever receive the [reversal][1] badge?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/badges/50/reversal" />
./PostHistory.xml:4932:  <row Id="7328" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1110" RevisionGUID="eec6329b-df44-4517-8a7d-33adb80da2b8" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="The consensus seems to be that [if people find errors in papers, they should contact the author directly, not post a question here](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/214/should-there-be-a-protocol-to-notify-authors-if-we-find-an-error-in-a-paper).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Unfortunately, it seems that we haven't enforced this policy [in this thread](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1064/polynomial-time-algorithm-for-graph-isomorphism-testing). There is an [answer](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1064/polynomial-time-algorithm-for-graph-isomorphism-testing/5874#5874) whose sole purpose seems to be exactly this – to point out a possible mistake in a specific paper. This has already led to [follow-up discussion](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1064/polynomial-time-algorithm-for-graph-isomorphism-testing/6135#6135) that isn't really appropriate on this site.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I would suggest that the moderators delete both of these answers, and encourage the participants to discuss the possible errors offline.&#xD;&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:4933:  <row Id="7329" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1157" RevisionGUID="03aadd09-0cf8-4208-a82f-171bf8cd4696" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="&gt; **Possible Duplicate:**  &#xA;&gt; [Community Promotion Ads - 1H 2012](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/1448/community-promotion-ads-1h-2012)  &#xA;&#xA;&lt;!-- End of automatically inserted text --&gt;&#xA;&#xA;### What in the Wide, Wide World of Sports is Going On Here?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;TL;DR -- put images and links in the answers. If they get voted up enough, they will appear on the main site as community promotion ads.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### But whyyyyyyy?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;This is a method for the community to control what gets promoted to visitors on the site. For example, you might promote the following things:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- cool site-related open source apps&#xD;&#xA;- the site's twitter account&#xD;&#xA;- scripts packs or power tools&#xD;&#xA;- cool events or conferences&#xD;&#xA;- anything else your community would genuinely be interested in&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The goal is for future visitors to find out about *the stuff your community deems important*. And to click on it for great justice!&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### How does it work?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The answers you post to this question _must_ conform to the following rules, or they will be ignored. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;1. All answers should be in the exact form of:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;        [![Tagline to show on mouseover][1]][2]&#xD;&#xA;        &#xD;&#xA;           [1]: http://image-url&#xD;&#xA;           [2]: http://clickthrough-url &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;    Please **do not add anything else to the body of the post**. If you want to discuss something, do it in the comments.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;2. The question must always be tagged with the magic [meta-tag:community-ads] tag.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### Image requirements&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; - The image that you create must be **220 x 250 pixels**&#xD;&#xA; - Must be hosted through our standard image uploader (imgur)&#xD;&#xA; - Must be GIF or PNG&#xD;&#xA; - No animated GIFs&#xD;&#xA; - Absolute limit on file size of 150 KB&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### Score Threshold&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;There is a **minimum score threshold** an answer must meet (currently 6) before it will be shown on the main site.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;You can check out the ads that have met the threshold with basic click stats [here][1].&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/ads/display/1157" />

./PostHistory.xml:4936:  <row Id="7332" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1205" RevisionGUID="10f65062-b80b-439c-83c6-04e61af415f3" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="We have already [discussed](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/q/1155/1037) the general scope of the blog, and there seems to be some ideas as to what it is. Now that we are starting to write posts, I thought it would be nice to figure out the more technical details. Of particular interest: what  &lt;b&gt;length&lt;/b&gt; and &lt;b&gt;level of formality&lt;/b&gt; should we aim for?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Right now I am writing in a style that is pretty close to how I would write an academic paper. For specific claims I reference the literature with proper citations, and for more general further-interest topics I link to Wikipedia or relevant cstheory questions. Is this too formal? Should we cite specific claims in-text or just have a short bibliography section at the end of the post (or neither?). &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;This question is for posts in the 'Expository material on particular sub-areas' genre." />
./PostHistory.xml:4937:  <row Id="7333" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1228" RevisionGUID="05c12381-cf38-407f-bdcb-e996194065fb" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="### change log&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;----&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Jul. 27, 2012:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- Added [academia.se] to the list of suggested sites&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;----&#xD;&#xA;Mar. 20, 2012:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- Added [cs.se] to the list of suggested sites&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;----&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Feb. 23, 2012:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Another small update to the FAQ. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Change log:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; * Added [crypto.se] and [scicomp.se] to the list of suggested sites,&#xD;&#xA; * Made the tips for writing a better question a section.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;----&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Nov. 17, 2011:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I have edited the official FAQ a little bit (mainly adding links to some entries of the official FAQ that we refer to in comments). Please comemnt if you don't like the edits or have other suggestions on how to improve the general FAQ:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;----&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;[FAQ](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/faq)&#xD;&#xA;----&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;**Theoretical Computer Science - Stack Exchange** is for theoretical computer scientists and researchers in related fields.  We welcome _research-level_ questions in _theoretical computer science_ (TCS).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Although there is no black-and-white distinction between research-level questions and non-research-level questions, questions are considered to be &quot;research-level&quot; roughly when they can be discussed between two professors or between two graduate students working on Ph.D.'s, but not usually between a professor and a typical undergraduate student. It does not include questions at the level of difficulty of typical undergraduate course/textbook homework/exercise.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;For an explanation of what TCS is, we refer you to the description of ACM Special Interest Group on Algorithms and Computation Theory (SIGACT):&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; &gt; TCS covers a wide variety of topics including algorithms, data structures, computational complexity, parallel and distributed computation, probabilistic computation, quantum computation, automata theory, information theory, cryptography, program semantics and verification, machine learning, computational biology, computational economics, computational geometry, and computational number theory and algebra.  **Work in this field is often distinguished by its emphasis on mathematical technique and rigor.** &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;##My question is not a research-level question in TCS, where can I ask it?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;For questions other than research-level questions in TCS, you may want to consider the following places to ask:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; * General Computer Science — [Computer Science - Stack Exchange](http://cs.stackexchange.com/)&#xD;&#xA; * General Mathematics (including *theoretical* CS) — [Mathematics - Stack Exchange](http://math.stackexchange.com/)&#xD;&#xA; * Research-level Mathematics — [Math Overflow](http://mathoverflow.net/)&#xD;&#xA; * Social and Professional Academic Issues — [Academia - Stack Exchange](http://academia.stackexchange.com/)&#xD;&#xA; * Programming — [Stack Overflow](http://stackoverflow.com/)&#xD;&#xA; * General Artificial Intelligence — [Meta Optimize](http://metaoptimize.com/qa/)&#xD;&#xA; * Statistics and Data Mining — [Cross Validated](http://stats.stackexchange.com/)&#xD;&#xA; * Applied Cryptography and Security — [Crypto - Stack Exchange](http://crypto.stackexchange.com/)&#xD;&#xA; * Computation used in Science and Engineering — [Computational Science - Stack Exchange](http://scicomp.stackexchange.com/)&#xD;&#xA; * Questions about this site — [Theoretical Computer Science - Stack Exchange - Meta][1]&#xD;&#xA; * Other — check the list of sites on [Stack Exchange Network](http://stackexchange.com/sites)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;##Questions should be based on knowledge sharing, not on shirking&#xD;&#xA;You should only post questions you're actually seriously thinking about. Users are expected to do their part and try to answer their question by themselves before posting them on cstheory and asking for help from others. Search to see if your question is already answered somewhere else (e.g. Wikipedia) before asking a question. **Try to make your question interesting for others by providing some background knowledge**. Remember, *questions should be based on knowledge sharing, not on shirking. Shirking goes against the spirit of the site.* &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;##Tips about writing better questions&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* [How to Ask?](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/how-to-ask)&#xD;&#xA;* [How to ask a good question?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/300/how-to-ask-a-good-question)&#xD;&#xA;* [How to write a good MathOverflow question?](http://mathoverflow.net/howtoask)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Please also check our list of [**useful resources**](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/229#229) *before* asking a question.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;##FAQ&#xD;&#xA;Currently we have two separate lists of FAQs.  See also the longer **[Official Theoretical Computer Science FAQ](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science)**.  Some of the most important entries in the other FAQ are:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; * [How do I write **formulas**?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/237#237)&#xD;&#xA; * [What kind of questions are **too basic**?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/235#235)&#xD;&#xA; * [My (wonderful!) **question got closed**!  What do I do now?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/361#361)&#xD;&#xA; * [What is the **policy on crossposting** to/from MathOverflow?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/231#231)&#xD;&#xA; * [Can I ask about this **cool paper** that I just saw **on the arxiv**?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/274/is-it-ok-to-ask-about-the-correctness-of-preprints-on-crank-friendly-topics/281#281)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" />

./PostHistory.xml:4939:  <row Id="7335" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1253" RevisionGUID="3ae78614-90bb-4dd6-93a5-fa897b2a6aa5" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="“How can I do X?” and “Is X studied?” are very different.  The latter (as it is) is silly as Suresh writes.  However, the former can be interesting.  I think that it is incorrect to close a question just because it is application-oriented.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I think that the discussion about [How-to-model-this questions](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/514/how-to-model-this-questions) applies.  In particular, as [Scott Aaronson writes](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/514/how-to-model-this-questions/519#519), there are better and worse ways to ask a “How can I do X?” question:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; Having said that, there are better and worse ways to pose a modeling question. I think the best ways would make it clear (a) why TCS (as opposed to a different field, like systems or AI) might be well-equipped to answer the question, and (b) what a helpful answer would look like. (In other words: if the only answer to your question you could reasonably expect from a TCS expert is &quot;I dunno,&quot; why are you asking it here? :) )" />

./PostHistory.xml:4941:  <row Id="7337" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1286" RevisionGUID="1feb3b90-e3f5-4569-9423-f8e09cbc9bb8" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="For question which are completely and clearly off-topic and are very unlikely to get reopens or edited in a reasonable way that would make them on-topic on cstheory, (e.g. undergrad homework questions) it is reasonable to migrate. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;A main reason that OP asks such a question on cstheory is that he/she does not know where to ask it and asks the question on the wrong one.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Pro:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;1. It will keep the question open, (one question is saved)&#xD;&#xA;2. May cause less bitterness than just closing the question (since it is probable that it will get answered on the other site)&#xD;&#xA;3. Usually such questions get negative total vote here, and might eventually get deleted.&#xD;&#xA;4. ?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Con:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;1. We might make a mistake as in [this case][1] (but by being more careful we can reduce the possibility of something similar happening).&#xD;&#xA;2. ?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/1274/why-was-all-pairs-shortest-path-in-undirected-and-unweighted-graphs-closed-and" />
./PostHistory.xml:4942:  <row Id="7338" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1287" RevisionGUID="6afe25cc-4a1f-4efc-8596-e21ed0baef15" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="Question: [All pairs shortest path in undirected and unweighted graphs](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/7809/all-pairs-shortest-path-in-undirected-and-unweighted-graphs)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;As discussed in [another thread](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/1274/why-was-all-pairs-shortest-path-in-undirected-and-unweighted-graphs-closed-and), the question linked above had been migrated to math.stackexchange.com and the decision of migration was decided to be incorrect. ./PostHistory.xml:4943:  <row Id="7339" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1295" RevisionGUID="b20fe58f-ab21-4434-ab6d-755cf62db222" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="It would be nice to have a set of general recommendations and requirements for users asking &quot;[How to model X][1]&quot;, &quot;[Applications of theory][2]&quot;, and &quot;How to do X&quot; questions where X is an informal task (i.e. not stated in a clear mathematically rigorous way). Having such a list of recommendations and requirements would help the OPs of those post in improving the quality of their question and make it easier for others to answer them.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;MathOverflow has a set of general suggestions on its &quot;[How to ask][3]&quot; page, and we also have some other [general suggestions][4] in our [FAQ][5]. If you have any suggestion please post it below as an answer.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;---&#xD;&#xA;Related meta-discussions:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/514/how-to-model-this-questions&#xD;&#xA;* https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/1251/how-to-deal-with-how-to-do-x-questions-where-x-is-a-very-high-level-software&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I have created a [wiki][6] for formal-modeling tag. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/formal-modeling&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/application-of-theory&#xD;&#xA;  [3]: http://mathoverflow.net/howtoask&#xD;&#xA;  [4]: http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/faq#questions-should-be-based-on-knowledge-sharing-not-on-shirking&#xD;&#xA;  [5]: http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/faq&#xD;&#xA;  [6]: http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/tags/formal-modeling/info" />
./PostHistory.xml:4944:  <row Id="7340" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1312" RevisionGUID="d9870310-d18b-4267-915b-da9d162b18c8" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="The number of users on the site is approaching 5000. Note that [as per this question][1], extremely inactive user accounts are being removed, so while I make no claim that there are even 1000 ACTIVE users, the number is less meaningless than it used to be :). &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Note that there are about 340 users with score above 200 (which is the benchmark SE used to determine transition from beta). &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;**Update**: we just crossed the 5000 mark. so I'm closing this question now :)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/1283/number-of-users-or-am-i-going-crazy" />
./PostHistory.xml:4945:  <row Id="7341" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1322" RevisionGUID="b2e1299f-f204-4c01-91c6-d6aac26e4546" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="[Jeff Atwood encourages us][1] to explore support from SE for our conferences. ./PostHistory.xml:4947:  <row Id="7343" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1372" RevisionGUID="daba93ac-3860-44ea-a95e-2820409ecdee" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="This question is on rewriting of the [automata theory question.][1]&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I am at a loss to understand this extensive rewriting of the question to make it look &quot;research&quot; level. In the process a certain innocence and resonance the question had is gone! Can the site allow some latitude in these matters?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;PS: I appreciate the effort and time that goes into rewriting driven the desire to make this a better site.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Update (from suresh): Here's the original question:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; In class we are currently learning about state machines and so-called&#xD;&#xA;&gt; &quot;regular expressions&quot; and languages that are &quot;accepted&quot;.&#xD;&#xA;&gt; &#xD;&#xA;&gt; This is all interesting stuff we are learning, but I was hoping there&#xD;&#xA;&gt; was a really good reason for learning such a concept...&#xD;&#xA;&gt; &#xD;&#xA;&gt; I know that there is always a way for application in topics related to&#xD;&#xA;&gt; CS theory, but with this whole automata concept I can't really&#xD;&#xA;&gt; extrapolate the cruciality of it... any experts here would like to&#xD;&#xA;&gt; offer their perspective?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;and the final edit (for comparison):&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; There is always a way for application in topics related to theoretical&#xD;&#xA;&gt; computer science. But textbooks and undergraduate courses usually&#xD;&#xA;&gt; don't explain the reason that automata theory is an important topic&#xD;&#xA;&gt; and whether it still has applications in practice. Therefore&#xD;&#xA;&gt; undergraduate students might have trouble in understanding the&#xD;&#xA;&gt; importance of automata theory and might think it is not of any&#xD;&#xA;&gt; practical use anymore.&#xD;&#xA;&gt; &#xD;&#xA;&gt; Is automata theory still useful in practice?&#xD;&#xA;&gt; &#xD;&#xA;&gt; Should it be part of undergraduate CS curriculum?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/q/8539/1449&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/q/1369/1449" />
./PostHistory.xml:4948:  <row Id="7344" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1381" RevisionGUID="1c98d82a-2241-4542-b564-09c14ee56bad" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="This post is inspired by answers to [this question](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/q/1369) and a similar list on [TEX.SE](https://tex.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/430).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The idea is to make a bunch of templates for commonly-used comments, like comments explaining that a question is out of scope and the question will be closed. Collecting such templates in one place makes it easier for those who don't wish to type out a personalized comment every time they vote to close a question.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Please post templates as answers. This question is CW, so feel free to edit other people's answers to improve the templates." />
./PostHistory.xml:4949:  <row Id="7345" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1383" RevisionGUID="f1c02f88-7f42-49cc-9947-246586b7c080" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="I would like to share my vague feeling: reducing the personal tone from a post can be sometimes good, but it must be difficult to do it right.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;As a general principle, I think that reducing the personal tone from the question is sometimes good.  Too much personal tone can be distracting, and reducing the personal tone can improve the readability of a question (or perhaps also an answer).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;In this particular example, the question before the edit sounds a little like a diary rather than a question written as a question from the beginning.  It is fine in a blog, but it is probably suboptimal on a Q&amp;A website.  I guess that this is why Kaveh felt the need for an edit.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;However, in this particular example, I do not think that it was done well.  I do not like the opening after the edit:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; There is always a way for application in topics related to theoretical computer science.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Despite the intent of the edit which Kaveh explained, this does not sound like a professional to me.  Instead, it sounds like some newbie who tries to pretend to be a professional.  Frankly speaking, the question sounded at least honest before the edit, but it sounds pretentious after the edit.  I am sorry, but I do not like how the question is stated after the edit at all.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Also, it should be pointed out that [we encourage to include a personal motivation in a question](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/300/how-to-ask-a-good-question/306#306): we want a question which the asker cares out of his/her own interest rather than a question which the asker thinks that someone cares.  In this sense, good questions necessarily contain some personal part.  I do not think that it is right to remove everything personal from a question.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Thinking this way, it seems very difficult to edit a question to reduce the personal tone while maintaining some degree of personality.  If you do it, you should do it right.  I guess that it is a perfectly reasonable choice to give up such a difficult task and just either leave the question open or close it.&#xD;&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:4950:  <row Id="7346" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1394" RevisionGUID="edf9efcf-7bb3-4c77-a7be-87502ed39943" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="Lots of people come on this site asking (often) similar questions about PhD.&#xD;&#xA;Shouldn't we create some sort of &quot;Master&quot; However for readability reasons, if at least the main ideas were in the same place it might be easier for the people asking the questions?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Then of course we can create a template that refers to this CW when people ask about PhD." />
./PostHistory.xml:4951:  <row Id="7347" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1395" RevisionGUID="353773a9-c0da-4bbf-9b5e-42ac378e3a15" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="I am worried about the attitude of some people who claim that down-voters must always explain the reason for down-voting or who criticize the users who vote down posts without explanations.  ([Here is an example of such a criticism](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/1264/conventions-on-downvoting/1272#1272).)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;On the Stack Exchange system, voting is anonymous: users have the right to vote without revealing their identities for whatever reasons they have.  Down-voters who do not wish to reveal their identities cannot explain the reason because there is no way to post a comment anonymously.  This is a legitimate use of the system, and I do not think that users should be criticized just because they down-voted a post without giving an explanation.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Of course, no one should expect that votes without explanation are as convincing as votes with good justification.  Because of this, I think that it is wiser to explain the reason when you vote down a post.  But that is a separate issue.  My point is that as long as we use a system which allows anonymous voting, it is users’ right to vote up or down without giving any justification.&#xD;&#xA;" />

./PostHistory.xml:4953:  <row Id="7349" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1448" RevisionGUID="eb53000e-0139-4e67-8005-1f603a061edc" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="&gt; **Possible Duplicate:**  &#xA;&gt; [Community Promotion Ads - 2013](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/1619/community-promotion-ads-2013)  &#xA;&#xA;&lt;!-- End of automatically inserted text --&gt;&#xA;&#xA;We're hitting the start of the new year, and that means a new iteration of the Community Promotion Ads!&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### What in the Wide, Wide World of Sports is Going On Here?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;TL;DR -- put images and links in the answers. If they get voted up enough, they will appear on the main site as community promotion ads.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### But whyyyyyyy?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;This is a method for the community to control what gets promoted to visitors on the site. For example, you might promote the following things:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- cool site-related open source apps&#xD;&#xA;- the site's twitter account&#xD;&#xA;- scripts packs or power tools&#xD;&#xA;- cool events or conferences&#xD;&#xA;- anything else your community would genuinely be interested in&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The goal is for future visitors to find out about *the stuff your community deems important*. And to click on it for great justice!&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### How does it work?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The answers you post to this question _must_ conform to the following rules, or they will be ignored. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;1. All answers should be in the exact form of:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;        [![Tagline to show on mouseover][1]][2]&#xD;&#xA;        &#xD;&#xA;           [1]: http://image-url&#xD;&#xA;           [2]: http://clickthrough-url &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;    Please **do not add anything else to the body of the post**. If you want to discuss something, do it in the comments.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;2. The question must always be tagged with the magic [meta-tag:community-ads] tag.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### Image requirements&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; - The image that you create must be **220 x 250 pixels**&#xD;&#xA; - Must be hosted through our standard image uploader (imgur)&#xD;&#xA; - Must be GIF or PNG&#xD;&#xA; - No animated GIFs&#xD;&#xA; - Absolute limit on file size of 150 KB&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### Score Threshold&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;There is a **minimum score threshold** an answer must meet (currently 6) before it will be shown on the main site.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;You can check out the ads that have met the threshold with basic click stats [here][1].&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/ads/display/1448" />
./PostHistory.xml:4954:  <row Id="7350" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1462" RevisionGUID="5d809189-fb29-45ae-b067-93a4b961157a" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="A main source of reasonable closed questions that we have are questions that are just below research-level: maybe they're really advanced undergraduate questions, or intro grad-level questions that are straightforward. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Our policy has been to close these questions (maybe with hints in the comments) and recommend that the user ask them on math.SE if appropriate.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I'm not proposing a change in scope to allow such questions. What I'm proposing is that we suggest that these questions be posted on our chat system. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;This idea is actually due to [Artem Kaznatcheev in an answer][1] [to this question][2]. I think it's an interesting suggestion for three reasons:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;1. It allows us to keep such questions 'in-house' without watering down the quality of questions on the main site. This would encourage people who might not otherwise be able to be on the site to participate, and over time they might be able to &quot;graduate&quot; to questions on the main site. &#xD;&#xA;2. It allows us to use the chat feature, which has been left unused thus far. Since many of the questions of this nature that people post have quick answers, the chat system enables that quick back-and-forth&#xD;&#xA;3. Participation is 'opt-in': since the chat system isn't front and center, there's no danger that people uninterested in answering such questions might be forced to wade through pages and pages to get to the 'research-level' questions.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;One fear that we've had in the past with allowing lower-level questions is that we'd get swamped with such questions and that things like reputation counts and question scores would get biased towards answering such questions. Keeping them in the chat system ensures that questions get answered, but this doesn't happen.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Thoughts ? &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/a/1460/80&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/1459/simple-questions-during-reading-papers" />

./PostHistory.xml:4957:  <row Id="7356" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1499" RevisionGUID="0bda0418-bf97-45b8-b10e-aa77b2af2d25" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="[Related question.][1]&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;When you flag a question as &quot;it does not belong to this site&quot;, you end-up in the following menu.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;![enter image description here][2]&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The question is, could it be useful to include some more choices in this menu such us Maths.SE or Physics.SE?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;**Update**. ./PostHistory.xml:4958:  <row Id="7357" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1502" RevisionGUID="dd8d8151-c5b2-4837-a9c4-6926621e82fb" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="&#xD;&#xA;Sorry if this has already been asked, I could not find an appropriate answer and  I want to make sure that I understand these features.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;**Question**: what's the most correct way to use flags and down-votes? &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Or, what makes less harm: an incorrect flag or an incorrect vote down + comment? Should I do nothing if I doubt or should I try to participate?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;**Explanation**.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; I am one of those users without enough reputation to vote for closing but I can try to help the site by voting up good questions (which I try to use *much* more often) and flagging or voting down those which I believe not to be suitable. My question is about what to do in theSo, the question is, if you doubt between what to do latter case.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;First, this what the FAQ says about flagging vs answering low-quality posts:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; Most importantly, don't feed the trolls! Replying to abusive, off-topic, or inappropriate content only encourages it – whereas flagging allows removal without providing undue attention. &#xD;&#xA;Post related to: [conventions on downvoting][1].&#xD;&#xA;Which suggest that flagging is the best thing to do when you thing a post does not match the standards we expect. However, declined flags get a preventive remark:&#xD;&#xA;&gt; Flag declined - flags should only be used to make moderators aware of content that requires their intervention.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Which suggests that flagging may flood moderators. Then I thought, maybe it is better that users control content by voting up/down. But whenever you vote down you see a pop-up:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; Please consider adding a comment if you think this post can be improved.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Or in other words, try to make constructive suggestions. But then you can be &quot;feeding trolls&quot;...&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;**Related posts:** [conventions on downvoting][1].&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/1264/conventions-on-downvoting" />
./PostHistory.xml:4959:  <row Id="7358" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1507" RevisionGUID="b94a0e28-6ade-4831-b8af-aa3aa7d638d5" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="We have a few questions where it seemed like cs.SE might be their natural home. For example, &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* [Learning Automated Theorem Proving][1] (just migrated)&#xD;&#xA;* [Is there some other way to describe a formal language other than grammars?][2] (migrated)&#xD;&#xA;* [Reducing directed hamiltonian cycle to graph coloring][3]&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;and I imagine we'll have more as time goes on.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;We have a [migration policy][4] that is very conservative: for the most part we merely close and suggest another venue. The question here is:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; Should we have a different policy for cs.SE, because we can fairly&#xD;&#xA;&gt; claim to understand the forum a lot better, and a number of us are&#xD;&#xA;&gt; active there (including all three cstheory mods). Specifically, should&#xD;&#xA;&gt; mods be free to migrate to cs.SE and not merely close and suggest&#xD;&#xA;&gt; reposting ?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/10861/learning-automated-theorem-proving&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/10852/is-there-some-other-way-to-describe-a-formal-language-other-than-grammars&#xD;&#xA;  [3]: http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/10854/reducing-directed-hamiltonian-cycle-to-graph-coloring&#xD;&#xA;  [4]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/1086/moderators-please-be-very-careful-when-migrating-questions-to-other-stack-excha" />
./PostHistory.xml:4960:  <row Id="7359" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1515" RevisionGUID="e98f8852-729d-4e33-adc6-7f9516e571be" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="&gt; **Possible Duplicate:**  &#xA;&gt; [How should the tag \[graph-algorithms\] be used?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/680/how-should-the-tag-graph-algorithms-be-used)  &#xA;&#xA;&lt;!-- End of automatically inserted text --&gt;&#xA;&#xA;Do we really need the [tag:graph-algorithms] tag? Isn't [tag:ds.algortihms] and [tag:graph-theory] sufficient?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Note: &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Currently there are 147 questions tagged with it, two third of them also have the tags reffed above.&#xD;&#xA;From the remaining 43 questions, 14 are tagged with [tag:cc.complexity-theory] and are not about algorithms but complexity of graph problems (e.g. $\mathsf{NP\text{-}hardness}$). &#xD;&#xA;The remaining 29 questions also seem to mostly fall in [tag:ds.algorithms]+[tag:graph-theory] and few are again not algorithmic questions and should be tagged as [tag:cc.complexity-theory]+[tag:graph-theory]." />
./PostHistory.xml:4961:  <row Id="7360" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1533" RevisionGUID="6337f6cd-817b-4fbf-995d-98e6f0256dfd" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="I propose to rename the tag [tag:dynamic] (currently 8 questions) to [tag:dynamic-algorithms] (currently nonexistent), because the questions with the tag are really about dynamic algorithms, that is, algorithms about certain objects with online updates.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;(There was [one closed question](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1588/variable-profit-knapsack) where the tag [tag:dynamic] was used to mean dynamic programming.  I modified this tag manually.)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I cannot use the existing system for creating a tag synonym (which would automatically merge the created tag synonym to the real tag) because the tag [tag:dynamic-algorithms] does not exist at this moment.  Therefore, I would like to invoke the [official interim procedure for doing retagging](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/271/official-interim-procedure-for-doing-retagging) for this purpose.  This means:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; Score +4 or more of this meta post is interpreted as a consensus that the tag [tag:dynamic] should be renamed to [tag:dynamic-algorithms].&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I do **not** think that the old tag [tag:dynamic] should be a tag synonym after renaming, but I do not have a strong opinion about this.&#xD;&#xA;" />

This means that closed questions in the data dump do not probably reflect typical closed questions, unless you take the union of multiple data dumps." />
./PostHistory.xml:4963:  <row Id="7362" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1554" RevisionGUID="cfb799c1-f1d3-4942-a7a9-065b0890c54b" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="I wonder who on earth would be happy to read a series of long, boilerplate comments such as:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; Welcome to cstheory, a Q&amp;A site for _research-level_ questions in _theoretical computer science_ (TCS). Your question does not appear to be a research-level question in TCS. Please see the [FAQ](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/faq) for more information on what is meant by this and suggestions for sites that might welcome your question. Finally, if your question is closed for being out of scope, and you believe you can edit the question to make it a research-level question, please feel free to do so. Closing is not permanent and questions can be reopened, check the [FAQ](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/faq) for more information.&#xD;&#xA;&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; Please add some context/background/motivation for the question if you think the question is a research-level question and in [Theoretical Computer Science](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/)'s scope. You can find tips about writing a better question in our FAQ. For general level questions please consider posting on [Computer Science](http://cs.stackexchange.com/).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I know, these comments partly came from [another thread on meta](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/1381/comment-templates), but this does not change the fact that they are stupidly long.  Please do not use them.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;_Added_: It is fine to argue that in theory, it should be possible to improve the templates to make it concise and to the point.  I have seen this argument many times.  In practice, no one has ever been able to make such an edit, and I think that there is a good reason why it is impossible.  If you have time to argue the theoretical possibility, just edit the templates instead and have it done.&#xD;&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:4964:  <row Id="7363" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1570" RevisionGUID="3b47f2ba-26cd-42e9-a334-0230cf6e5f42" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="One issue that we should be careful and is included in the FAQ is that people should ask questions that they really care about. If you intend or are thinking about working on a related problem then the question can be fine and explaining this motivation and the kind of problems that you want to work on would make the question focused. On the other hand, an out of curiosity question is not a real question, neither questions that are intended to be discussions about a topic or solicit opinions about it.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;We have many tips in [the meta post about writing and asking better questions][1] and there are a [few more links][2] to similar advice in the FAQ that you should check if you haven't. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The problem is that some users insist on ignoring these even if they are reminded several times by various people.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/300/how-to-ask-a-good-question&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/faq#tips-about-writing-better-questions" />

Is there a mechanism in place to do so? I imagine accidental votes like mine don't happen often (since it requires 3 button clicks; and only the completely absent minded people like me would get confused by that), but questions do get edited for the better, potentially nullifying an early close-vote.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;__How can I withdraw my close vote?__" />
./PostHistory.xml:4966:  <row Id="7365" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1588" RevisionGUID="2b46ebc8-a307-4f39-a7cb-f0bf64861bd8" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="If you come across a question which has been answered correctly, but in a fashion that would require effectively a total rewrite to make it (in your opinion) understandable for the question-asker and who ever comes across the answer later, is it better to edit the answer (even though it's essentially a rewrite), or to post a new answer, with a clear statement of credit?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;As this is meant to be a research level Q &amp; A, I assume that we can expect the reader to do a bit of work, but there's also a point where an answer is opaque thanks to the style of the writer (as opposed to because the question is difficult). The situation may also be complicated by the answer being original research (though only a small chunk of course).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I guess an alternative formulation is whether it's more valued (in the context of the site) to recognise primacy or clarity (on the assumption that reputation will be siphoned one way or the other)? &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;This is kind of similar to [this question](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/338/policy-on-editing-answers), but beyond the point where a few suggestions would improve the answer, it really needs a total rewrite." />
./PostHistory.xml:4967:  <row Id="7366" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1604" RevisionGUID="0aeb442c-2b76-4998-888e-4ec9688f08c9" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="Although I am guilty of using the phrase “research-level questions” again and again, it is not at all clear whether “research-level” really describes the current scope or the desirable scope correctly.  [I once suggested “research-oriented”](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/1066/we-should-stop-claiming-that-this-website-is-research-level#comment3475_1115) as a more honest description of the current criteria, but this term has not been used often.  There are too many discussions about the appropriate level of questions; see [this](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/1572/on-modifying-our-scope-a-proposal) for example.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I think that it would be ideal to settle the issue on the scope first and then state this scope clearly in the website.  However, in reality, I do not think that this will happen any time soon.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Just in case we decide to put some words about the scope, another place to consider is the placeholder text of the Title textbox on the “Ask Question” page.
