./PostHistory.xml:4968:  <row Id="7368" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1619" RevisionGUID="587631fb-ef7d-4ccd-a535-40c2ebe130ae" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="As it is December 2012, we are now going to reset our Community Promotion Ads for the new year.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### What are Community Promotion Ads?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Community Promotion Ads are community-vetted advertisements that will show up on the main site, in the right sidebar. The purpose of this question is the vetting process. Images of the advertisements are provided, and community voting will enable the advertisements to be shown.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### Why do we have Community Promotion Ads?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;This is a method for the community to control what gets promoted to visitors on the site. For example, you might promote the following things:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; - cool site-related open source apps&#xD;&#xA; - the site's twitter account&#xD;&#xA; - script packs or power tools&#xD;&#xA; - cool events or conferences&#xD;&#xA; - anything else your community would genuinely be interested in&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The goal is for future visitors to find out about *the stuff your community deems important*. This also serves as a way to promote information and resources that are *relevant to your own community's interests*, both for those already in the community and those yet to join. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### Why do we reset the ads every year?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Some services will maintain usefulness over the years, while other things will wane to allow for new faces to show up. Resetting the ads every year helps accommodate this, and allows old ads that have served their purpose to be cycled out for fresher ads for newer things. This helps keep the material in the ads relevant to not just the subject matter of the community, but to the current status of the community. We reset the ads once a year, every December.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The community promotion ads have no restrictions against reposting an ad from a previous cycle. If a particular service or ad is very valuable to the community and will continue to be so, it is a good idea to repost it. It may be helpful to give it a new face in the process, so as to prevent the imagery of the ad from getting stale after a year of exposure.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### How does it work?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The answers you post to this question _must_ conform to the following rules, or they will be ignored. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;1. All answers should be in the exact form of:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;        [![Tagline to show on mouseover][1]][2]&#xD;&#xA;        &#xD;&#xA;           [1]: http://image-url&#xD;&#xA;           [2]: http://clickthrough-url &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;    Please **do not add anything else to the body of the post**. If you want to discuss something, do it in the comments.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;2. The question must always be tagged with the magic [meta-tag:community-ads] tag. In addition to enabling the functionality of the advertisements, this tag also pre-fills the answer form with the above required form.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### Image requirements&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; - The image that you create must be **220 x 250 pixels**&#xD;&#xA; - Must be hosted through our standard image uploader (imgur)&#xD;&#xA; - Must be GIF or PNG&#xD;&#xA; - No animated GIFs&#xD;&#xA; - Absolute limit on file size of 150 KB&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### Score Threshold&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;There is a **minimum score threshold** an answer must meet (currently **6**) before it will be shown on the main site.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;You can check out the ads that have met the threshold with basic click stats [here][1].&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/ads/display/1619" />
./PostHistory.xml:4969:  <row Id="7369" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2661" RevisionGUID="f8d9d1ca-89f4-4598-8bbb-13946e2e19e3" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="##My question is not a research-level question in TCS, where can I ask it?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;For questions other than research-level questions in TCS, you may want to consider the following places to ask:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; * General Computer Science — [Computer Science - Stack Exchange][1]&#xD;&#xA; * General Mathematics (including *theoretical* CS) — [Mathematics - Stack Exchange][2]&#xD;&#xA; * Research-level Mathematics — [Math Overflow][3]&#xD;&#xA; * Social and Professional Academic Issues — [Academia - Stack Exchange][4]&#xD;&#xA; * Programming — [Stack Overflow][5]&#xD;&#xA; * General Artificial Intelligence — [Meta Optimize][6]&#xD;&#xA; * Statistics and Data Mining — [Cross Validated][7]&#xD;&#xA; * Applied Cryptography and Security — [Crypto - Stack Exchange][8]&#xD;&#xA; * Computation used in Science and Engineering — [Computational Science - Stack Exchange][9]&#xD;&#xA; * Questions about this site — [Theoretical Computer Science - Stack Exchange - Meta][10]&#xD;&#xA; * Other — check the list of sites on [Stack Exchange Network][11]&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://cs.stackexchange.com/&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: http://math.stackexchange.com/&#xD;&#xA;  [3]: http://mathoverflow.net/&#xD;&#xA;  [4]: http://academia.stackexchange.com/&#xD;&#xA;  [5]: http://stackoverflow.com/&#xD;&#xA;  [6]: http://metaoptimize.com/qa/&#xD;&#xA;  [7]: http://stats.stackexchange.com/&#xD;&#xA;  [8]: http://crypto.stackexchange.com/&#xD;&#xA;  [9]: http://scicomp.stackexchange.com/&#xD;&#xA;  [10]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/&#xD;&#xA;  [11]: http://stackexchange.com/sites" />

./PostHistory.xml:4973:  <row Id="7373" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2697" RevisionGUID="e75f273f-af2d-4424-8d9f-761eeb4f4572" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="I noticed that we get a fair number of non-research-level questions.  This is not too surprising, since if someone comes here and just looks at the title of the site, they might get the wrong impression.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Suggestion: Add some text to the &quot;Ask a Question&quot; page to clarify this.  For instance, on the sidebar it currently says &quot;Is your question about theoretical computer science?  We prefer questions that can be answered, not just discussed.&quot;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Perhaps this could be revised to &quot;Is your question about theoretical computer science?  We prefer questions that can be answered, not just discussed.  We prefer questions at a research level.&quot; Would this help avoid confusion, or do you think people would just overlook that?  &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;See also: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/q/1603/5038 (which seems like an even better suggestion, but apparently has not been implemented)." />
./PostHistory.xml:4974:  <row Id="7374" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2724" RevisionGUID="9f789bbd-018c-4122-8c02-6c7700e659e3" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="There are several reasons to down-vote a post. We have discussed previously (see [this](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/1264/) and [this](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/1395/)) that we are not going to require or even demand people to explain their votes. When I see a down-vote that I don't understand I politely comment that I don't understand it, but I think demanding an explanation or stating that there is no reason for the down-vote goes too far. It is not an abuse if people are using their votes in a way different from us.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I have argued a number of times that I am against counter-voting, that is voting to null the effect of another user's vote. Everyone has their own opinion. The total reflects the opinion of the community, it is not the job of any particular user to decide what the total should be. Counter-voting encourages other users to do the same and use their votes to null votes in place of express their opinion about the question. Each vote is a manifestation of some user's opinion and if we respect their opinions then we should respect their votes even when we disagree with them.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I think it is more productive if we comment and explain why we think it is a suitable and interesting question in place of just asking others why they have down-voted the post.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;In this particular case, I see several possible reasons for a down-vote. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;1. Formating: It is using an image in place of writing the expression which I think has been one of the reasons people down-vote. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;2. Content: The questions seems to simply ask how to calculate some expression for some particular values. It seems to ask how to apply a method explained in a paper in a particular case in practice. It is too localized and it doesn't seem to be a _research-level_ question in _theoretical_ computer science. It is also unclear what is the trouble the OP is facing in calculating the expression.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;If you ask me I think we are being too open right now (I guess it is partly because people get bored that there are not as many questions as they would like) to questions which should not be here and are more suitable for CS.SE. E.g. [1](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/18703/are-randomized-algorithms-considered-as-complete), [2](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/18628/confused-about-disparity-and-depth-map), [3](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/18886/proof-that-turing-machine-and-lambda-calculus-are-equivalent), [4](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/18575/pigeon-holing-or-bucketing-a-number-based-on-a-set-of-ranges) have been in [the closing review queue][1] for sometime but have not been put _on-hold_. Similarly, it is not clear what [this question](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/18871/bounded-computation-and-incompleteness/18883) is asking and should be put _on-hold_ until clarified but it does not have a single close vote. And [this](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/18903/how-would-the-use-of-ternary-computers-change-complexity-of-algorithms) is clearly not-research level in my opinion.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/tools?tab=close&amp;daterange=last30days" />
./PostHistory.xml:4975:  <row Id="7375" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2728" RevisionGUID="da5b6c41-452a-4513-bce6-db951e283df0" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="In addition to what Suresh wrote, keep in mind that the audiences are also different. The cstheory community is mainly composed of professional researchers in theoretical computer science. We have more specialists here who might not visit CS.SE. However the expectations from questions are also higher. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;See also&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;1. [How to write a good question](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/300/how-to-ask-a-good-question)&#xD;&#xA;2. [Is my question suitable for cstheory?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/25/material-to-supplement-the-faq/2662#2662)" />
./PostHistory.xml:4976:  <row Id="7376" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2735" RevisionGUID="e04993f6-5df3-4443-bb50-1b2a6c0915de" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="I flagged this [question][1] as *needs moderator attention* and in my reason I wrote, is not a research level, but moderator rejected the flag. ./PostHistory.xml:4977:  <row Id="7377" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2740" RevisionGUID="cd4f56db-2887-47ac-bf7b-4c962cc747f4" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="I agree completely. ./PostHistory.xml:4978:  <row Id="7378" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2744" RevisionGUID="7bb816e3-8b48-49c7-bc44-4a0f3d3a02b6" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="At the time I write this, the leading option in the poll is [SHRUG](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/2738/should-we-participate-in-the-stack-exchange-winter-bash#comment6819_2738).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;If SHRUG wins, then instead of hats, CSTheory should get epaulettes.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;![Suresh with badly cut epaulettes][1]&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://i.stack.imgur.com/KC4c0.jpg" />
./PostHistory.xml:4979:  <row Id="7379" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2745" RevisionGUID="b079b9e9-5f8a-4bfc-836a-0f916fd5ad1f" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="It's the time of the year again, namely it is December 2013, and so we shall now refresh our Community Promotion Ads for the new year.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### What are Community Promotion Ads?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Community Promotion Ads are community-vetted advertisements that will show up on the main site, in the right sidebar. The purpose of this question is the vetting process. Images of the advertisements are provided, and community voting will enable the advertisements to be shown.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### Why do we have Community Promotion Ads?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;This is a method for the community to control what gets promoted to visitors on the site. For example, you might promote the following things:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; - cool site-related open source apps&#xD;&#xA; - the site's twitter account&#xD;&#xA; - script packs or power tools&#xD;&#xA; - cool events or conferences&#xD;&#xA; - anything else your community would genuinely be interested in&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The goal is for future visitors to find out about *the stuff your community deems important*. This also serves as a way to promote information and resources that are *relevant to your own community's interests*, both for those already in the community and those yet to join. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### Why do we reset the ads every year?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Some services will maintain usefulness over the years, while other things will wane to allow for new faces to show up. Resetting the ads every year helps accommodate this, and allows old ads that have served their purpose to be cycled out for fresher ads for newer things. This helps keep the material in the ads relevant to not just the subject matter of the community, but to the current status of the community. We reset the ads once a year, every December.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The community promotion ads have no restrictions against reposting an ad from a previous cycle. If a particular service or ad is very valuable to the community and will continue to be so, it is a good idea to repost it. It may be helpful to give it a new face in the process, so as to prevent the imagery of the ad from getting stale after a year of exposure.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### How does it work?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The answers you post to this question _must_ conform to the following rules, or they will be ignored. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;1. All answers should be in the exact form of:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;        [![Tagline to show on mouseover][1]][2]&#xD;&#xA;        &#xD;&#xA;           [1]: http://image-url&#xD;&#xA;           [2]: http://clickthrough-url &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;    Please **do not add anything else to the body of the post**. If you want to discuss something, do it in the comments.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;2. The question must always be tagged with the magic [meta-tag:community-ads] tag. In addition to enabling the functionality of the advertisements, this tag also pre-fills the answer form with the above required form.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### Image requirements&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; - The image that you create must be **220 x 250 pixels**&#xD;&#xA; - Must be hosted through our standard image uploader (imgur)&#xD;&#xA; - Must be GIF or PNG&#xD;&#xA; - No animated GIFs&#xD;&#xA; - Absolute limit on file size of 150 KB&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### Score Threshold&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;There is a **minimum score threshold** an answer must meet (currently **6**) before it will be shown on the main site.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;You can check out the ads that have met the threshold with basic click stats [here][1].&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/ads/display/2745" />
./PostHistory.xml:4980:  <row Id="7380" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2760" RevisionGUID="22a6cff8-952e-4652-8348-ec69ab7836de" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="In your previous interactions on cstheory&#xD;&#xA;we have seen that you lack the mathematical maturity to understand &#xD;&#xA;what is a valid mathematical argument as I have written several times &#xD;&#xA;(and that is the main reason that &#xD;&#xA;you don't understand the problem with your &quot;arguments&quot; and &#xD;&#xA;keep insisting on them and engaging in extended discussions). &#xD;&#xA;Therefore your questions are off-topic here because you don't have the minimal understanding of the problem being solved, i.e. understand the answers given to you.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;In addition, on cstheory we have [an explicit policy against crank-friendly topics][1]. &#xD;&#xA;The goal of the policy is to be unwelcoming to cranks on this site. &#xD;&#xA;cstheory does not welcome cranks. &#xD;&#xA;It is not a personal issue and &#xD;&#xA;it doesn't mean anything about interactions &#xD;&#xA;we might have outside this site. &#xD;&#xA;But **_on cstheory_ we will not welcome cranks**.  &#xD;&#xA;As a non-expert who has been [insisting to have proven P is not equal to NP][2] for a considerable time despite the fact that no expert has accepted your claim you are considered a crank.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Also you tend to post question to later post (incorrect) answers ( e.g. [1](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/a/9281/), [2](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/a/18007/)),&#xD;&#xA;that is also unwelcome on cstheory.&#xD;&#xA;cstheory should not be used for self-promotion of one's ideas,&#xD;&#xA;if the intention is not to genuinely ask a question then &#xD;&#xA;the question is &quot;not a real question&quot; and&#xD;&#xA;should be closed.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Aside these, questions of the form &#xD;&#xA;&quot;I have this idea, what is wrong with it?&quot; &#xD;&#xA;can be on-topic stated suitably.&#xD;&#xA;However such questions need considerable extra care since &#xD;&#xA;they often result in open-ended extended discussions and &#xD;&#xA;generally open-ended extended discussions are not suitable for &#xD;&#xA;the sites on the Stack Exchange network, these are Q&amp;A sites, not discussion sites.&#xD;&#xA;I and other users have expressed the opinion that &#xD;&#xA;we need a place for discussions, &#xD;&#xA;but cstheory as a Q&amp;A site is not that place.&#xD;&#xA;In fact &#xD;&#xA;_the software for these sites is &#xD;&#xA;intentionally designed to make extended discussions difficult_.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;These are the reasons your question was closed. &#xD;&#xA;Whether some respected expert on the topic has replied to your email does not change them, &#xD;&#xA;so I think your question should remain closed.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;ps: &#xD;&#xA;I don't use &quot;[crank][3]&quot; as a derogatory or disrespectful term, &#xD;&#xA;I use crank to refer to non-experts who &#xD;&#xA;insist on attacking famous open problems and/or their ideas/&quot;solutions&quot; to them, &#xD;&#xA;without any indication that they have the required knowledge and &#xD;&#xA;capability to solve the problem &#xD;&#xA;(or even worse showing signs that &#xD;&#xA;they have problems understanding even basic concepts of the topic).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/q/274/&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: http://arxiv.org/find/cs/1/au:+Feinstein_C/0/1/0/all/0/1&#xD;&#xA;  [3]: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crank_%28person%29" />
./PostHistory.xml:4981:  <row Id="7381" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2763" RevisionGUID="6777b9ee-55e4-40df-acf4-a5df4e22b847" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="In connection with the moderator elections, we will be holding a Q&amp;A with the candidates.  This will be an opportunity for members of the community to pose questions to the candidates on the topic of moderation.  Participation is completely voluntary.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; **The purpose of this thread was to collect questions for the questionnaire. The questionnaire is now live, and you may find it [here](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/2778/2014-moderator-election-qa-questionnaire).**&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Here's how it'll work:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; - During the nomination phase, (so, until January 20th at 20:00:00Z UTC, or 3:00 pm EST on the same day, give or take time to arrive for closure), this question will be open to collect potential questions from the users of the site. Post answers to this question containing any questions you would like to ask the candidates. Please only post *one question per answer*.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; - We, the Community Team, will be providing a small selection of generic questions. The first two will be guaranteed to be included, the latter ones are if the community doesn't supply enough questions. This will be done in a single post, unlike the prior instruction.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; - This is a perfect opportunity to voice questions that are specific to your community and issues that you are running into at current.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; - At the end of the phase, the Community Team will select **up to 8 of the top voted questions submitted by the community** provided in this thread, to use in addition to the aforementioned 2 guaranteed questions. We reserve some editorial control in the selection of the questions and may opt not to select a question that is tangential or irrelevant to moderation or the election. That said, if I have concerns about any questions in this fashion, I will be sure to point this out in comments before the decision making time.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; - Once questions have been selected, a new question will be opened to host the actual questionnaire for the candidates, containing 10 questions in total.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; - This is not the only option that users have for gathering information on candidates. As a community, you are still free to, for example, hold a live chat session with your candidates to ask further questions, or perhaps clarifications from what is provided in the Q&amp;A.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;If you have any questions or feedback about this new process, feel free to post as a comment here." />
./PostHistory.xml:4982:  <row Id="7382" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2778" RevisionGUID="0ba92e1c-5a6e-4982-b42e-ce1bfe4a0de7" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="In connection with the moderator elections, we are holding a Q&amp;A thread for the candidates. Questions collected [from an earlier thread](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/2763/2014-moderator-election-qa-question-collection/) have been compiled into this one, which shall now serve as the space for the candidates to provide their answers. Due to the lack of submission count, we have selected all provided questions as well as our back up questions for a total of 10 questions.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;As a candidate, your job is simple - post an answer to this question, citing each of the questions and then post your answer to each question given in that same answer. For your convenience, I will include all of the questions in quote format with a break in between each, suitable for you to insert your answers. Just [copy the whole thing after the first set of three dashes](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/revisions/3cd73cb5-df21-4957-90f7-e57c60fdea44/view-source).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Once all the answers have been compiled, this will serve as a transcript for voters to view the thoughts of their candidates, and will be appropriately linked in the Election page. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Good luck to all of the candidates!&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;---&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; What is your personal view of the role of CSTheory: in particular, please post an answer to [Gil Kalai's question here](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/2752/what-tcs-stackexchange-is-for-and-what-is-your-aim-in-participation).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; How would you deal with a user who produced a steady stream of valuable answers, but tends to generate a large number of arguments/flags from comments?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; How would you handle a situation where another mod closed/deleted/etc a question that you feel shouldn't have been?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; What is your personal view of the role that CSTheory should/will/does play in the greater TCS community?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; Practically, one of the most important roles of a moderator, is to decide which questions to close, if at all. There are several attitudes toward this problem. Do you think that referring specifically to the user who asks the question and his or her perceived capabilities (e.g., &quot;lack of mathematical maturity&quot;, as expressed by some moderators) is a legitimate reason (or part of a reason) for closing a question? Or should you judge a question only by its own merits?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; In your opinion, what do moderators do?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; A diamond will be attached to everything you say and have said in the past, including questions, answers and comments. Everything you will do will be seen under a different light. How do you feel about that?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; In what way do you feel that being a moderator will make you more effective as opposed to simply reaching 10k or 20k rep?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; We often get low quality or obsolete or chatty flags. Based on early discussions the moderators normally don't take any action and dismiss them as not requiring moderator intervention. Do you think we should continue this way or change the policy?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; This is one of my concerns about long term health of the site. Do you consider the primary goal of this Q&amp;A site to be helping researchers in theoretical computer science and related fields to get help with their research?&lt;br/&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; If you do how should we deal with persistent trouble making users who try to abuse the site for their own wishes? E.g. users who are not researchers in theoretical computer science or any related field and insist on posting questions/answers/comments that are off-topic by the site's policies, e.g. cranks that want to use the site to verify or draw attention to their attempts on famous open problems?&lt;br/&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; How can we make sure the site will not be overridden by users who are not researchers so cstheory does not suffer the faith of other online open resources for researchers like Usenet groups? (Keep in mind that with the current amount of community participation in closing we are going to have very serious trouble if the number of such users with 3k+ reputation reaches 5)." />
./PostHistory.xml:4983:  <row Id="7383" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2788" RevisionGUID="fef36db8-8081-4d33-8b9a-4e95b8449f5d" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="&gt; What is your personal view of the role of CSTheory: in particular, please post an answer to [Gil Kalai's question here](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/2752/what-tcs-stackexchange-is-for-and-what-is-your-aim-in-participation).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;As a graduate student, I find that in my studies and research I am only exposed to a certain small part of theoretical computer science. This website allows me to keep my finger on the pulse of other subfields and see what sort of questions are interesting others and how they think about certain problems. As such, I think cstheory is primarily a great way to bring the community together.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;In the longer term, my hope is to use the [algorithmic lens](http://egtheory.wordpress.com/2013/09/15/algorithmic-lens/) as a viewpoint on other sciences and I hope others do so as well. If non-computer scientists start using tools from cstheory then this website (and its placement among other science and math websites in the SE network) could provide a great way for us to engage with them, and share our knowledge while figuring out what problems they want to use our tools to address.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; How would you deal with a user who produced a steady stream of valuable answers, but tends to generate a large number of arguments/flags from comments?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I would address the specific flags through comments, discuss with the other moderators, and if the behavior persists contact the user over chat. If direct communication with the user does not resolve the issue then I would consider a suspension for some amount of time and contact over email (if such means are available).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; How would you handle a situation where another mod closed/deleted/etc a question that you feel shouldn't have been?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I would contact the mod in private. If after a discussion we are still unsure of the decision then I would raise the question in meta for input from the community. However, I doubt this would come up since in my experience so far I have not seen closed questions for which I disagreed with closing.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; What is your personal view of the role that CSTheory should/will/does play in the greater TCS community?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;In my answer to the first question, I described my views for this site in cstheory and the larger scientific community. I think we are already moving toward this organically, but it might help to show more clearly why cstheory is a worthwhile part of a researcher's workflow by generating more answers to lists like:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* [Original proofs generated on the parent site](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/q/784/1037)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;*[References to cstheory in the literature](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/q/1257/1037)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; Practically, one of the most important roles of a moderator, is to decide which questions to close, if at all. There are several attitudes toward this problem. Do you think that referring specifically to the user who asks the question and his or her perceived capabilities (e.g., &quot;lack of mathematical maturity&quot;, as expressed by some moderators) is a legitimate reason (or part of a reason) for closing a question? Or should you judge a question only by its own merits?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I think it is important to judge questions by their own merit. The only time I would let my knowledge of the users previous activity affect my decision is if I am unsure about the questions. However, in these cases of being unsure, I will never act before the community voices their opinion.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;There is a special case of questions that accidentally capture a deeper issue, and are simple when read at a surface level but significant at a deeper level. In this case, I think it is important to engage with the user through comments to see if this deeper exploration will serve the user, or if they were just looking for the easy answer. This is often a judgement of the users &quot;mathematical maturity&quot;. If they were not looking for a deeper discussion, and the question is fine otherwise, I would consider migration to CS.SE.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; In your opinion, what do moderators do?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Moderators should interfere as little as possible with community self-governance, and act decisively only in clear cut cases where the community guidelines are already set. Moderators should also act as unbiased intermediaries in case of heated discussions and encourage good behavior by example.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; A diamond will be attached to everything you say and have said in the past, including questions, answers and comments. Everything you will do will be seen under a different light. How do you feel about that?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;It will not change how I ask or answer questions. However, I will actively take note to make sure my comments are always unbiased, constructive, and within community norms.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; In what way do you feel that being a moderator will make you more effective as opposed to simply reaching 10k or 20k rep?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The only differences I know is the binding vote and diamond (I guess there are also some drastic actions like suspension, but I will hopefully never have to use those). As someone that spends an unreasonable amount of time on the internet, the binding vote will allow me to act decisively and quickly in clear cut cases. Since &quot;close&quot; now means &quot;on hold&quot;, this will hopefully improve questions. The diamond will allow me to set a good example in my actions on the site.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; We often get low quality or obsolete or chatty flags. Based on early discussions the moderators normally don't take any action and dismiss them as not requiring moderator intervention. Do you think we should continue this way or change the policy?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I would encourage use of our third space (i.e. the chat room) to avoid some of the chatty discussions. However, otherwise I would leave the decision on this policy to more experienced moderators or the community (maybe we should raise a meta discussion on this?).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; This is one of my concerns about long term health of the site. Do you consider the primary goal of this Q&amp;A site to be helping researchers in theoretical computer science and related fields to get help with their research?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;As I mentioned in my first answer, I see helping researchers with their research as only part of the goals of this site. I think it is also a way to communicate with other disciplines, and a way to build community. Further, it is a way for future researchers to keep an idea of what the community is interested in, and learn from reading others questions and answers.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; If you do how should we deal with persistent trouble making users who try to abuse the site for their own wishes? E.g. users who are not researchers in theoretical computer science or any related field and insist on posting questions/answers/comments that are off-topic by the site's policies, e.g. cranks that want to use the site to verify or draw attention to their attempts on famous open problems?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;We already have a [policy on crank-friendly preprints and topics](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/q/274/1037), I will enforce this policy. I don't think we have gotten too many problems with cranky users, especially compared to other SE sites. We have a great community that already deals with this well.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; How can we make sure the site will not be overridden by users who are not researchers so cstheory does not suffer the faith of other online open resources for researchers like Usenet groups? (Keep in mind that with the current amount of community participation in closing we are going to have very serious trouble if the number of such users with 3k+ reputation reaches 5).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;We can make sure of this by continuing to ask great research-level questions and providing amazing answers. However, I do agree that the reputation mechanism on the site is broken and it is easy for a persistent user to accumulate reputation. These sort of users are unavoidable, and in most cases they don't cause much trouble. However, if a specific user continually upsets the community then I will proceed as in the &quot;large number of arguments/flags&quot; question: discuss with the user and community and suspend if necessary." />
./PostHistory.xml:4984:  <row Id="7384" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2791" RevisionGUID="ca9d7a1b-8bdf-4460-8e44-ad8a2ad06b69" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="dont post a lot here, because sometimes my questions here which I put significant time into writing get deleted (seemingly unilaterally), from almost &quot;day1&quot;.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;the nomination window ended with 3 candidates volunteering within the last minute, within the last three hours, so it wasnt clear who would be in the election, and there is no primary phase as on other sites where there are more volunteers/competitors for nomination to narrow the choices. therefore was hoping somehow to &quot;think outside the box&quot; &amp; broaden them.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;hence I decided to add to [k's post](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/2767/who-would-you-like-to-become-the-new-moderators) which is now completely hidden from the main meta list some of whom are elite members of this site in the TCS field &amp; eg spend quite a bit of time writing blogs, books etcetera ... luminaries of the field! it was intended for the record &amp; future reference &amp; maybe to spark some discussion on the subject. kaveh quickly deleted it within minutes of posting it and then locked down that post, which is within his right as moderator to do. ./PostHistory.xml:4985:  <row Id="7385" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2821" RevisionGUID="664b9893-c0bc-45d8-bc80-55078a48bd67" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="### Asking questions like &quot;is my/this solution to P vs. NP correct&quot; is off-topic &#xD;&#xA;###(also applies to other famous open problems similar to P vs. NP)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;cstheory is not a peer-review site. We don't check, verify, or discuss such solutions. If you think you have a solution send it to a journal or conference that peer-reviews such articles. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Keep in mind that most reputable ones have a policy similar to [JACM's policy][1]:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; No author may submit more than one paper to J. ACM, ACM Trans. on Algorithms, or ACM Trans. on Computation Theory  in any 24 month period,  purporting to resolve the P versus NP question or related long-standing questions in complexity theory, except by invitation of the Editor-in-Chief. This applies to resubmissions of previously rejected manuscripts.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;----&#xD;&#xA;Related discussions&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* [Policy on unverified solutions of famous open problems][2]&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Related discussions on CS.SE:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* [How to deal with questions about crank-heavy topics?](http://meta.cs.stackexchange.com/q/109/)&#xD;&#xA;* [What constitutes an appropriate check-my-proof question?][3]&#xD;&#xA;* [How to ask P vs NP questions without getting closed?][4]&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Related discussions on MathOverflow:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* [Can I ask whether or not a paper that proves P=NP is correct?][5]&#xD;&#xA;* [What should be the policy on “open problems” on MO?][6]&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://jacm.acm.org/instructions/pnp&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/q/274/&#xD;&#xA;  [3]: http://meta.cs.stackexchange.com/q/647/&#xD;&#xA;  [4]: http://meta.cs.stackexchange.com/q/786/&#xD;&#xA;  [5]: http://meta.mathoverflow.net/q/1263&#xD;&#xA;  [6]: http://meta.mathoverflow.net/q/360" />

./PostHistory.xml:4987:  <row Id="7387" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2836" RevisionGUID="163c7751-62b6-4a15-ba4a-ab3f8daa7dd1" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="I think there are a few separate issues here, that perhaps should be handled differently depending on the behavior of the individual(s). I'll just focus on one that I've noticed (at least one other that I won't touch on is students, like Ryan's, asking homework problems under pseudonyms).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The surge I've noticed recently is primarily PilarLoof, HeloLobo, and Grid_y_Bill, who I suspect are all the same person (and others have expressed the same opinion), and have been posting questions more suitable for mathoverflow, often without any indication as to why they are relevant to CS, although a few of them seem to be. When asked why they chose cstheory.SE over MO, they gave essentially nonsensical responses. (BTW, I think we definitely &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/q/2691/129&quot;&gt;should open the migration path to mathoverflow&lt;/a&gt;, because of these questions. It would make them much easier to identify and deal with...)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;In this case, I think it would be appropriate for the moderators to 1) determine if these pseudonyms are all in fact the same individual, and if so 2) ask for a good reason they keep using pseudonyms to post off-topic questions, and if there is not a good reason then, 3) take some sort of action.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;What sort of action? I could imagine several possibilities, though I don't know which of them are technically feasible with the current SE software:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;a) Ban the user (by which I mean the actual person, not just the username - perhaps by IP address as suggested by Saeed in the comments, or some other mechanism?)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;b) Ban the user (same as above) for a fixed period of time - e.g. 30 or 60 days&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;c) Put the user on &quot;probation&quot; (possibly for a fixed period of time). I imagine this would be something like: any of their questions must be approved by, say, 3 or 4 users with sufficient rep before the question appears on the site. This would be a pre-filtering approach to questions rather than the current post-filtering approach. If the user continued to abuse the site causing high rep users to spend lots of time rejecting off-topic questions, then more drastic action could be taken.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;d) Other suggestions...?" />
./PostHistory.xml:4988:  <row Id="7388" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2850" RevisionGUID="46ecfb70-6fd2-418a-8258-d20d77980bf1" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="If I post a question on CS.SE and don't get an answer, is it OK to post the same question on TCS.SE after waiting a week or so?  In other words, is cross-posting on CS.SE and TCS.SE OK (rather than migrating) if there is a delay of a week between them?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I'm asking to see if I can clarify the policy, because I am confused.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;To be clear: I am not asking about simultaneous cross-posting.  I'm asking about cross-posting after a delay of a week, when the question didn't get an answer on the original site. I'm not talking about migrating a question or deleting the original one and posting it on a new site; I'm talking about cross-posting, where the question is open on both CS.SE and TCS.SE.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Here is what I have been able to find:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- The standard StackExchange policy is: it is not OK to cross-post the same question on multiple sites.  If you post it on one site and after a week or two don't get an answer, you can flag it to ask the moderators to migrate it, but you should not cross-post (not even after a week or two).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  Source: http://meta.stackexchange.com/q/64068/160917&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- Currently, the TCS policy says that it is OK to cross-post on TCS.SE and MathOverflow, if you post on one and don't get an answer even after waiting a week or so (and if you must cross-link the two).  However this doesn't say anything about other SE sites other than MathOverflow, so it's not clear if this applies more broadly.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  Source: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/a/231/5038&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- There was a proposal to change that policy to allow simultaneous cross-posting on TCS.SE and MO, but that proposal was marked status-declined (it was rejected).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  Source: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/q/673/5038&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- Peter Shor points out that one of the close reasons says&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  &gt; Our [site policy](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/a/231/5038) prohibits ***simultaneous* crossposting**: it duplicates effort and fractures discussion. Crossposting is permitted after a week has passed without a satisfying answer elsewhere. When crossposting please summarize the relevant discussions from other sites in your question and link between the copies in both directions. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  This sure sounds like cross-posting after a delay is allowed.  On the other hand, when you click on the link to the &quot;site policy&quot;, the policy described at the link target actually only mentions MathOverflow, not other SE sites.  (I hadn't noticed this previously, because I don't have enough reputation to vote to close.)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- CS.SE does not seem to have any special policy about this, and I can't find any discussion of this on Meta.CS.SE.  Therefore, I would assume that CS.SE abides by the standard StackExchange policy, by default.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  Also, given the standard StackExchange policy and the impact on both sites, I would guess that probably cross-posting on two SE sites should only be allowed if both sites opt into a policy of allowing cross-posting.  CS.SE does not seem to have opted to allow cross-posting on CS.SE+TCS.SE, and since I can't find any clear evidence that TCS.SE has, either.  (It appears that before adopting the current policy regarding cross-posting on TCS.SE+MO, both TCS.SE and MO were consulted; however, I can't find any evidence of any consultation with CS.SE about cross-posting on CS.SE+TCS.SE.)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;My conclusion: It's not clear to me what is allowed.  The information on the policy does not seem entirely self-consistent, to my eyes.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;So, what *is* the current policy?  Is cross-posting on CS.SE and TCS.SE allowed, if you wait a week?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;And if this has not been previously addressed, what *should* the policy be?" />
./PostHistory.xml:4989:  <row Id="7390" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2867" RevisionGUID="43cacb2b-6ee8-4a68-b227-441871dafa6f" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="Like most of our other policies initially we copied the policy from MathOverflow. They were using it successfully for sometime. ([meta.MO] might be a better place to ask about it as MO is older and considerably larger than cstheory.)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;We do get spam and low quality answers from time to time but they are generally removed or heavily down-voted. There is also the fact that like other popular CW questions (it is [our policy](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/759/the-new-community-wiki-policy) that big-list questions must be turned into CW) we protect popular big-list questions. This adds a barrier for adding new answers. I think it is a reasonable barrier, in a sense we are saying that these questions are special and potentially problematic so they are required to pass higher standards. To post an answer you have to first show that you are contributing positively in a sense before being able to post your answer to a big-list question. The same applies informally to big-list questions, i.e. they are expected to pass a higher standard of quality otherwise they get several down-votes and/or closed as too broad. (So far those standards are left subjectively to users, I don't think we have discussed or spelled out a guideline on what we expect from big-list questions/answers.)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I should also add that some of these big-list questions are extremely useful. For example, I don't know any online/offline resource that is a better reference than [this big-list question](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/79/problems-between-p-and-npc) for NPI problems." />
./PostHistory.xml:4990:  <row Id="7391" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2869" RevisionGUID="e23f6240-e8b6-4db8-bc18-d3fbe95c25dd" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="The link colors look different enough, I think.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;However, the [core premise here](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/856/contrast-visited-unvisited-hyperlinks#comment2417_856) (that we use visited/unvisited styles to indicate new answers on a post) is flawed. We don't.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;With that in mind, I suggest keeping an eye on the questions list (sorted by active, so posts with new edits/answers/etc float to the top) instead of relying on the link color." />
./PostHistory.xml:4991:  <row Id="7392" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2872" RevisionGUID="75f09a15-ef9a-4fd8-9933-896cac32f267" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="To those who vote to close non-theoretical-computer-science questions: Thank you for tidying up the website, but when you do so, could you please choose the precise reason?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Sometimes new users post questions not in theoretical computer science but in other fields of study such as physics and more applied side of computer science.  Often many close-voters choose the following reason to close such questions:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; Your question does not appear to be a **research-level** question in theoretical computer science. For more information about the scope, please see [help center](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/help/on-topic).  Your question might be suitable for [Computer Science](http://cs.stackexchange.com/) which has a broader scope.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;While it might be technically correct, this reason is very misleading, particularly for those not familiar with theoretical computer science _such as the posters of those questions_, because the bold part strongly suggests that the problem with the question is that it is not at the research level, whereas the real problem is that it is not a question in or about theoretical computer science.  (Moreover, the question might even be a research question in the field which it belongs to.)  If you are curious, [the message quoted above was proposed to be used when a question was not research-level](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/a/2700), so it is an abuse of this reason by all means in my opinion.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;When you choose “off-topic” as the reason, you have an option to enter your custom reason instead of choosing one of the canned responses.  Please use it instead.  Unfortunately, a custom reason works differently from canned responses in that the custom reason is posted as a comment at the time you cast a vote, and I can imagine some circumstances in which you do not want to do this.  But usually this should be fine.&#xD;&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:4992:  <row Id="7393" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2908" RevisionGUID="b81dd82f-3b0e-4d33-b963-2f1742f02fd6" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="Consider the following question: http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/32245/example-of-r-and-g-when-r-subseteq-lg-is-undecidable&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Is this question on-topic for cstheory? ./PostHistory.xml:4993:  <row Id="7394" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2959" RevisionGUID="5d6555a5-7d04-45cf-9946-84c188c03302" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="Based on [earlier feedback](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/q/2949/5038), I'm creating this thread to advertise questions on CS.SE that would be interesting to this community and haven't received an answer.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Guidelines:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;1. Each answer should link directly to a **single question** on CS.SE that has not been adequately answered and that **would be of interest** to this community.  In particular, the question should be research-level and related to theoretical computer science.  Also, make sure the question has remained open on CS.SE for a significant period of time with no answer (say, at least two weeks).  Don't re-post a question that's an already well-known open problem or has already been re-posted on CSTheory.SE.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;2. Each answer should include a **short summary** of the question asked. There's no need to repost the CS.SE question verbatim, but it should be fairly clear what the question is about without following the link.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;3. Feel free to **downvote and vote-to-delete suggestions that aren't &quot;up to snuff&quot;**.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;4. **Don't abuse this thread**.  Abusing this thread is an easy way to ensure it is closed/deleted. This thread will stay open only as long as the CSTheory community feels it serves a useful purpose.  For instance, don't post links to CS.SE questions that are essentially homework exercises, not research level, or not within our scope." />
./PostHistory.xml:4994:  <row Id="7395" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1387" RevisionGUID="6474139c-1afc-49aa-b67d-96abdab832ef" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:54.607" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.physics.stackexchange.com/ with https://physics.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="The mission of Stack Exchange is to make the internet a better place to get expert answers to your questions. The Stack Exchange Fellowship Program aims to support students conducting research in subjects related to our academic Q&amp;A sites in order to (a) increase the quality of information in a particular subject and (b) facilitate the exchange of information between experts in the field. Individual awards range from 250 to 1000 dollars (USD).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Applicants should be advanced undergraduate, graduate students or professionals pursuing research related to one the following Stack Exchange sites:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; - [English][1]&#xD;&#xA; - [Linguistics][2]&#xD;&#xA; - [Physics][3]&#xD;&#xA; - [Statistics][4]  &#xD;&#xA; - Theoretical Computer Science&#xD;&#xA; - [Theoretical Physics][5]&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Applications will be accepted on a rolling basis starting immediately. For more details and to apply, check out the [application][6]!&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;We are also accepting volunteers from the community to help review applications. Volunteers should have some level of expertise in the subject area (professors and those who have or are pursuing advanced degrees are ideal candidates). Reviewers will be given 3 weeks from when they receive materials or may request more time if needed. Following the first wave of submissions, those selected to be Stack Exchange Fellows will be asked to review 3 to 4 new applications. To facilitate the review process, reviewers will rate applications on several scales instead of making judgments on funding. You can find the Reviewer Form [here][7].&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Reviewers and successful candidates are encouraged to customize the &quot;about me&quot; section of the user profile by including information on:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; 1. Area of expertise and current occupation &#xD;&#xA; 2. Key academic goals/milestones&#xD;&#xA; 3. Role in the Fellowship program (applicant, reviewer, fellow, both)&#xD;&#xA; 4. SE grant project, if applicable &#xD;&#xA;   &#xD;&#xA;If you have any questions regarding the Fellowship Program, or would like more information about applying or becoming a reviewer, please email *academics@stackexchange.com*.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Edited: Applications accepted on a rolling basis until December 31, 2011. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://english.meta.stackexchange.com/q/2077/13231&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: http://meta.linguistics.stackexchange.com/q/202/344&#xD;&#xA;  [3]: https://physics.meta.stackexchange.com/q/942/5450&#xD;&#xA;  [4]: https://physics.meta.stackexchange.com/q/942/5450&#xD;&#xA;  [5]: http://meta.theoreticalphysics.stackexchange.com/q/170/533&#xD;&#xA;  [6]: http://dl.dropbox.com/u/37818223/SE%20Fellowship%20Application.docx&#xD;&#xA;  [7]: http://dl.dropbox.com/u/37818223/Reviewer%20Sheet.docx" />
./PostHistory.xml:4995:  <row Id="7396" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1516" RevisionGUID="c94f48fd-035e-4dc7-9f58-2ecc3d2a2831" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:45:54.607" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.physics.stackexchange.com/ with https://physics.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="[TP.SE is closing](http://meta.theoreticalphysics.stackexchange.com/q/245/57) and it seems that the questions/answers will be [migrated in-bulk to physics.SE](https://physics.meta.stackexchange.com/q/1193). Please have a look [at the list][1] and let him know if you have any suggestions about the list.&#xD;&#xA; &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://physics.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/1258/quantum-computing-questions-from-tp" />
./PostHistory.xml:4996:  <row Id="7397" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1387" RevisionGUID="aea597de-55c6-4f27-98a1-3efb89caf811" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:49:12.240" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.linguistics.stackexchange.com/ with https://linguistics.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="The mission of Stack Exchange is to make the internet a better place to get expert answers to your questions. The Stack Exchange Fellowship Program aims to support students conducting research in subjects related to our academic Q&amp;A sites in order to (a) increase the quality of information in a particular subject and (b) facilitate the exchange of information between experts in the field. Individual awards range from 250 to 1000 dollars (USD).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Applicants should be advanced undergraduate, graduate students or professionals pursuing research related to one the following Stack Exchange sites:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; - [English][1]&#xD;&#xA; - [Linguistics][2]&#xD;&#xA; - [Physics][3]&#xD;&#xA; - [Statistics][4]  &#xD;&#xA; - Theoretical Computer Science&#xD;&#xA; - [Theoretical Physics][5]&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Applications will be accepted on a rolling basis starting immediately. For more details and to apply, check out the [application][6]!&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;We are also accepting volunteers from the community to help review applications. Volunteers should have some level of expertise in the subject area (professors and those who have or are pursuing advanced degrees are ideal candidates). Reviewers will be given 3 weeks from when they receive materials or may request more time if needed. Following the first wave of submissions, those selected to be Stack Exchange Fellows will be asked to review 3 to 4 new applications. To facilitate the review process, reviewers will rate applications on several scales instead of making judgments on funding. You can find the Reviewer Form [here][7].&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Reviewers and successful candidates are encouraged to customize the &quot;about me&quot; section of the user profile by including information on:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; 1. Area of expertise and current occupation &#xD;&#xA; 2. Key academic goals/milestones&#xD;&#xA; 3. Role in the Fellowship program (applicant, reviewer, fellow, both)&#xD;&#xA; 4. SE grant project, if applicable &#xD;&#xA;   &#xD;&#xA;If you have any questions regarding the Fellowship Program, or would like more information about applying or becoming a reviewer, please email *academics@stackexchange.com*.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Edited: Applications accepted on a rolling basis until December 31, 2011. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://english.meta.stackexchange.com/q/2077/13231&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: https://linguistics.meta.stackexchange.com/q/202/344&#xD;&#xA;  [3]: https://physics.meta.stackexchange.com/q/942/5450&#xD;&#xA;  [4]: https://physics.meta.stackexchange.com/q/942/5450&#xD;&#xA;  [5]: http://meta.theoreticalphysics.stackexchange.com/q/170/533&#xD;&#xA;  [6]: http://dl.dropbox.com/u/37818223/SE%20Fellowship%20Application.docx&#xD;&#xA;  [7]: http://dl.dropbox.com/u/37818223/Reviewer%20Sheet.docx" />

Is there a significant overlap? &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; What should we do if there is a significant overlap between the two sites?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;----&#xD;&#xA;As a side issue, I feel that we might have an even larger problem when the CS proposal launches if its scope is modified later in such a way that it contains cstheory, and I should say that [the current attitude of the SE team about the proposal description][4] is not comforting for me. ./PostHistory.xml:4999:  <row Id="7400" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2712" RevisionGUID="45590acd-e222-45e1-b222-b0bdeda39273" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:50:22.977" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cs.stackexchange.com/ with https://cs.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="I have a request.  It would be nice if the moderators here would avoid migrating low-quality questions to CS.SE.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I noticed recently a few low-quality questions that were migrated to the Computer Science Stack Exchange (CS.SE) site.  I would suggest that we avoid doing that.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* If it's a good question, and on-topic for CS.SE, I definitely encourage you to migrate to CS.SE.  For instance, if it is not research-level but would be a reasonable question, migrating to CS.SE is a great idea.  Go for it!&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* But if it's a bad question -- one that would be a bad question for CS.SE -- please don't migrate it to CS.SE.  If it's a bad question, just close it, don't migrate it.  Please don't make CS.SE a dumping ground for bad questions.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* If it's a good question -- well-researched, on-topic, focused, narrow -- but has some English/grammar problems, don't let that stop you from migrating.  If it's just the English, we can edit it over at CS.SE.  But if it is a fundamentally bad question -- e.g., not well-researched, or a duplicate, or unclear -- I personally don't think it should be migrated over to CS.SE&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;One recent example: http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/q/18536/5038.  In my opinion, that question shouldn't have been migrated to CS.SE.  It is not a good fit for the Computer Science Stack Exchange.  The question does not show evidence of effort.  It asks a question about a topic that is already covered by reference questions at CS.SE, with no evidence that the question-asker was aware of that.  These issues are not something that those of us at CS.SE can fix through simple edits to the question.  Of course, that's just one example.  I don't mean to pick on that one or focus on that one too much.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Kaveh explains that the CS.SE admins specifically requested that &quot;badly written&quot; questions are still OK to migrate to CS.SE.  I didn't realize that!  That explains a lot.  Perhaps that's something we should discuss.  I'm not sure whether &quot;badly written&quot; refers to the English/grammar, or to more fundamental issues (like whether it's a good question, whether it is well-researched, whether it is on-topic and focused and detailed and not a duplicate).  If the former, I agree, English/grammar problems should not be a barrier to migration.  If the latter, well, I guess I might have a slight difference of opinion with the CS.SE admins -- maybe that's something we need to discuss on CS.meta, instead of here.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I certainly don't mean to imply that this is a huge, systemic problem that requires major changes to migration, and I don't mean to imply the moderators here are doing anything wrong (I think the moderators are doing a great job!).  Overall I think the process is generally working well.  I just wanted to suggest a minor refinement that I think might make things work better on CS.SE.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Related:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/q/1086/5038&#xD;&#xA;* https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/q/1285/5038&#xD;&#xA;* https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/q/1507/5038&#xD;&#xA;* [Do we want CSTheory.SE to migrate bad questions over here?](https://cs.meta.stackexchange.com/q/691/755)" />
./PostHistory.xml:5000:  <row Id="7401" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2821" RevisionGUID="40eaf0eb-e58b-4cb3-94a6-2b5a4c8d6934" CreationDate="2017-03-16T15:50:22.977" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.cs.stackexchange.com/ with https://cs.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="### Asking questions like &quot;is my/this solution to P vs. NP correct&quot; is off-topic &#xD;&#xA;###(also applies to other famous open problems similar to P vs. NP)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;cstheory is not a peer-review site. We don't check, verify, or discuss such solutions. If you think you have a solution send it to a journal or conference that peer-reviews such articles. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Keep in mind that most reputable ones have a policy similar to [JACM's policy][1]:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; No author may submit more than one paper to J. ACM, ACM Trans. on Algorithms, or ACM Trans. on Computation Theory  in any 24 month period,  purporting to resolve the P versus NP question or related long-standing questions in complexity theory, except by invitation of the Editor-in-Chief. This applies to resubmissions of previously rejected manuscripts.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;----&#xD;&#xA;Related discussions&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* [Policy on unverified solutions of famous open problems][2]&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Related discussions on CS.SE:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* [How to deal with questions about crank-heavy topics?](https://cs.meta.stackexchange.com/q/109/)&#xD;&#xA;* [What constitutes an appropriate check-my-proof question?][3]&#xD;&#xA;* [How to ask P vs NP questions without getting closed?][4]&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Related discussions on MathOverflow:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* [Can I ask whether or not a paper that proves P=NP is correct?][5]&#xD;&#xA;* [What should be the policy on “open problems” on MO?][6]&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://jacm.acm.org/instructions/pnp&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/q/274/&#xD;&#xA;  [3]: https://cs.meta.stackexchange.com/q/647/&#xD;&#xA;  [4]: https://cs.meta.stackexchange.com/q/786/&#xD;&#xA;  [5]: http://meta.mathoverflow.net/q/1263&#xD;&#xA;  [6]: http://meta.mathoverflow.net/q/360" />

./PostHistory.xml:5002:  <row Id="7404" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2" RevisionGUID="9fa6e868-b41b-4737-b442-6f64b3df872b" CreationDate="2017-03-16T16:02:33.520" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.tex.stackexchange.com/ with https://tex.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="Over at the TeX SE site, there's been a fair amount of [meta discussion][1] about whether the site should be closer to the StackOverflow or MathOverflow model for discussions. The linked post has a good summary of the differences, and I'll also link to Andrew Stacey's [link off his home page][2]. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I suspect that we will need to grapple with this question as well: do we want the 'advanced grad student' lower bound that MO effectively maintains, or something lower ? StackOverflow does handle what I'll consider undergraduate-level theoryCS questions. I'll post my own thoughts in an answer below. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://tex.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/197/so-versus-mo-model-possible-faq-entry&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: http://www.math.ntnu.no/~stacey/CountingOnMyFingers/MOversusSO.html" />
./PostHistory.xml:5003:  <row Id="7405" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="6" RevisionGUID="89cb4495-14a3-46f5-93f0-adde3058cc6e" CreationDate="2017-03-16T16:02:33.520" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.tex.stackexchange.com/ with https://tex.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="*[Below is Scott Morrison's [post from tex.se](https://tex.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/12/vote-early-and-often), reproduced here because it's good advice we need to see early.]*&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;---&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I'm a moderator from MathOverflow, and this &quot;question&quot; is actually unsolicited advice, based on our experience from the initial launch of MathOverflow.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; We should encourage everyone to vote positively as often as possible!&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Every Stack Exchange site will eventually end up with a different &quot;base level&quot; of voting --- that is, the expected number of upvotes for a question of a given level of excellence. (This effect occurs because people see a good question, but already with a certain number of votes, and think &quot;oh, I would have upvoted this, but it already has enough&quot;.)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;It's easy for us to affect this &quot;base level&quot; by encouraging high levels of upvoting now. We're setting the standards, and this really will have an effect.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;(On MathOverflow, we were very active about this early on, specifically encouraging all the initial round of users to vote early and often. You can compare statistics, and see that the average vote total for a MathOverflow question is much higher than on any of the other SE 1.0 sites.)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;In case it's not obvious: the rationale for wanting this base level to be high is that it provides better positive feedback to good contributors.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;---&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;*— By Scott Morrison*" />
