./PostHistory.xml:5007:  <row Id="7409" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="626" RevisionGUID="c3230dc1-836d-416d-ba97-33537ad58344" CreationDate="2017-03-16T16:37:16.437" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.math.stackexchange.com/ with https://math.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="Judging from the blog posts “[When will my site graduate?](http://blog.stackoverflow.com/2010/10/when-will-my-site-graduate/)” by Robert Cartaino and “[Pruning season](http://blog.stackoverflow.com/2010/09/pruning-season/)” by Joel Spolsky, it is highly unlikely that the website is shut down in a week.  See also other websites on Area 51 which have been in public beta for more than 90 days.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;At the same time, it is unlikely that we graduate the beta in a week because the strategy seems that the websites in all-green graduate first.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;My guess is that the number “90 days” has little real effect.  We should continue to be a good community, and I guess that we will graduate the beta eventually.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;_Added_: By the way, “graduating beta” does not only mean that we have our own site design and that we have probably less chance to get shut down.  Actually, from the system point of view, the most relevant effect of graduating beta is that the [thresholds for some privileged actions are raised](https://math.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/984/promotion-implies-higher-rep-needed-for-privileges-and-nobody-has-such) from the beta level to the [normal level](http://math.stackexchange.com/privileges).  This means that it is probably not good to go out of beta if we do not have many users with high reputation points.&#xD;&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:5008:  <row Id="7411" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1108" RevisionGUID="1508c295-3418-4f84-9e3b-666fd4ab64b0" CreationDate="2017-03-16T16:37:16.437" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.math.stackexchange.com/ with https://math.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="Here is what happened in this case:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The questions is clearly off-topic for the site and was closed by Dave. But two answers were posted before the closing.&#xD;&#xA;The first one was a one line answer by a new unregistered anonymous user (i.e. didn't have the reputation to comment):&#xD;&#xA;&gt;To be NP-complete, it must be in NP.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;So I converted it to a comment. But the second answer was similar in essence (by a regular relatively high rep user) and I felt it would be unfair to just convert one of them, so I converted the second one. Then I felt that it would better if I just delete them since they were not adding any information not on the Wikipedia page. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I personally didn't feel good about it after deleting  because we don't have a clear policy on this (and the second answerer knew that the questions is clearly off-topic and that we don't answer them on cstheory), my justification for deletion was previous meta discussions we had where IIRC the conclusion was that we should not answer these questions even in the comments and should just forward the OP to the place where he/she could find the answer (Wikipedia, textbook, ...).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I also felt that deleting them would be in line with closing clearly off-topic questions by moderators (i.e. inside minimal mod intervention). I would have suggested adopting a policy like: &#xD;&#xA;&gt; answers *not containing new information* (in addition to what is on Wikipedia, ...) to *clearly* off-topic questions should be deleted, preferably by OP.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;But I think we probably **don't** need to do this for the following reason:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;---&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The [feedback](https://math.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/1966/migration-from-cstheory-to-math-se) from Math.SE guys on adding Math.SE to the off-topic flagging wizard has been quite positive, so I think it we can simply migrate these questions *with their answers* to Math.SE and there is no need to delete the answers by us if the question is migrated to Math.SE.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;ps: I also made a small edit to the general FAQ (Math.SE entry) based on the feedback from Math.SE folks." />
./PostHistory.xml:5009:  <row Id="7412" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1427" RevisionGUID="05045a48-cbf4-49a2-ae9d-84e962a9df1c" CreationDate="2017-03-16T16:37:16.437" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.math.stackexchange.com/ with https://math.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="There are two things which feel wrong to me in this game.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;One is the wrong metric.  Because of the metric used in the game, the game seems to encourage quantity over quality.  That is not what we want in this community, as Gilles stated.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;More importantly, the other is the very intent of this game, namely, trying to make the users as productive as possible.  Let me quote Asaf Karagila’s comment on [meta.math.stackexchange.com](https://math.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/3212/battle-of-the-sites) (emphasis in original):&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; To add on the above, this is exactly why I left DeviantART.  I **hate** (with true passion) communities that try to prod me into being &quot;more&quot; productive as a member of the community.  Especially communities which I actually feel a part (which as a person I can honestly say that it is a very rare and very transient feeling).  I truly hope that the SE sites do not plan on having these &quot;happy happy joy joy&quot; activities often, I'd imagine I am not the only one feeling negatively about this sort of initiative.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I share this feeling.  I do not want cstheory.stackexchange.com to tell me to be more productive on the website.  I participate in the website to the extent that it is fun to me, not more, and it is annoying to be asked to change it in any way.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Usually I try to ignore such an annoying request.  But when it becomes a burden to ignore the requests like this, that will be the time for me to leave this website.&#xD;&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:5010:  <row Id="7413" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="62" RevisionGUID="3fb27a8d-7b45-4a8a-a964-1e930bc8985b" CreationDate="2017-03-17T10:13:04.397" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.mathoverflow.net/ with https://meta.mathoverflow.net/" Text="In the discussion on [this meta question][1], I made a comment in passing that I thought there were too many CW questions on the site at present. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;While this may be a transient phenomenon while the site is being seeded, I thought it brought up important issues about whether certain questions should be CW or just closed. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;So my question is:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; What is a clear policy to determine&#xD;&#xA;&gt; which questions should be deemed CW,&#xD;&#xA;&gt; which answers should be made CW, and&#xD;&#xA;&gt; which questions should just be closed&#xD;&#xA;&gt; ?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;As a reference point for discussion, I'll refer people to [this meta thread on MO][2], where many of the issues we're facing have been discussed. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;In keeping with the spirit of that discussion, since I do think that there is a good answer and that people's direct experiences are helpful, I'm **NOT** making this CW. I also think that the reduction in points for upvotes on questions actually makes me more comfortable about this, since my ability to acquire rep points is limited in comparison to people with good answers. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/56/are-list-questions-such-as-about-conferences-on-topic&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: https://meta.mathoverflow.net/discussion/6/when-should-questions-be-community-wiki" />
./PostHistory.xml:5011:  <row Id="7414" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="187" RevisionGUID="f579c704-92d9-42cf-b529-c0e75f9865a9" CreationDate="2017-03-17T10:13:04.397" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.mathoverflow.net/ with https://meta.mathoverflow.net/" Text="We will soon have temporary moderators from within the community, and so I wanted to initiate a discussion on policies for suspension/blocks/bans. Right now I'm thinking mostly of cases where users are posting questions that repeatedly get closed, without appearing to learn from the reasons given for closing. [This discussion on MO][1] is one example of how to conduct such a policy, and [here's the SE blog post][2] on the same issue. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;My question, specifically: can we list the conditions and procedures that lead up a user suspension ? ideally not just the behavior, but the sequence of warnings etc. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://meta.mathoverflow.net/discussion/417/suspension/&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: http://blog.stackoverflow.com/2009/04/a-day-in-the-penalty-box/" />
./PostHistory.xml:5012:  <row Id="7415" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="356" RevisionGUID="dce7e773-1c8c-4813-83b7-b79b628f58d6" CreationDate="2017-03-17T10:13:04.397" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.mathoverflow.net/ with https://meta.mathoverflow.net/" Text="**Update**: I gave up trying to convince other people to use “too localized” instead of “off topic” when closing too elementary questions.  It seems that most people disagree, and I started to feel that it is a waste of time to try to convince people otherwise.  For now, I still hesitate to vote for off topic (or to be listed as one of the people who closed the question as off topic) when I see too elementary a question, so probably I will not vote to close it.  Hopefully there are enough people to close it anyway.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;---&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;When we vote to close a question, we choose the reason from several choices.  It seems that if a question is too elementary, it is often closed for the reason “off topic.”&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I understand that this choice of reason is based on the consensus about the expected level of questions on cstheory.stackexchange.com.  However, if a question is closed for the reason “off topic,” the following explanation is added to the question:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; closed as off topic by [Someone], [Someone], [Someone], [Someone], [Someone] [Date]&#xD;&#xA;&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; Questions on Theoretical Computer Science are expected to generally relate to Theoretical Computer Science, within the scope defined in the [faq](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/faq).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I have trouble even parsing this sentence because of the tentative name of the website, but more importantly this does not mention the expected level of questions on cstheory.stackexchange.com.  It plainly states that the question is not related to the theoretical computer science, which is often false.  This gives the false impression that we take the theoretical computer science very narrowly.  I think that this is problematic.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;(_Added in revision 5_: The link in the explanation quoted above links to the [built-in FAQ](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/faq), not to the [FAQ on Meta](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science).  The built-in FAQ is not clear about the expected level of questions, either, except that the sentence “Theoretical Computer Science - Stack Exchange is for theoretical computer scientists and researchers in related fields” may suggest that research-level questions are expected.  A clearer statement can be reached by the following chain of links: the explanation of “off topic” → [built-in FAQ](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/faq) → [FAQ on Meta](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science) → [What kind of questions are too basic?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/235#235)  But I doubt that users can find this path unless they are already familiar with the website.)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;What should we do?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Here are a few suggestions:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;1. If the consensus is really that cstheory.stackexchange.com is for questions of at least certain level, the explanation of the reason “off topic” should be rewritten to reflect it.  Is this possible?&#xD;&#xA;2. &lt;del&gt;On [MathOverflow](http://mathoverflow.net/), too elementary questions are often closed for the reason “too localized.”  Obviously this is an abuse and [it certainly confuses some users](https://meta.mathoverflow.net/discussion/274/what-does-too-localized-mean-exactly/), but it is possible to interpret it as “This question is so elementary that it is useful only for the asker,” and it is understandable (or at least less prone to misunderstanding).  How about adopting this convention, at least until the explanation of “off topic” is modified to a better description?&lt;/del&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Related:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- See a [related FAQ entry](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/235#235) and the links given there for discussions about what we mean by “too elementary.”&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;_Added in revision 4:_ Whereas the description of the close reason is not shown on the question page on MathOverflow, it is shown on cstheory.stackexchange.com, which may make abusing harder.  Here is the description of the close reason “too localized”:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; This question would only be relevant to a small geographic area, a specific moment in time, or an extraordinarily narrow situation that is not generally applicable to the worldwide audience of the internet.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The point of the suggestion 2 above is that it is at least possible to argue that too elementary questions fall into the third group (and possibly also the second group) of this description.&#xD;&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:5013:  <row Id="7416" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="503" RevisionGUID="c6f6f1f8-10b1-4812-8842-0877a96a40cc" CreationDate="2017-03-17T10:13:04.397" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.mathoverflow.net/ with https://meta.mathoverflow.net/" Text="I have found these tricks useful:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- Forcing that MathJax re-renders Latex math after clicking on &quot;show N more comments&quot;: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/293/latex-math-and-show-n-more-comments/294#294&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- Show only questions with &quot;interesting&quot; tags: https://meta.mathoverflow.net/discussion/509/see-only-questions-with-interesting-tags/&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Not sure if you can call these things UserScripts, though. They are just bookmarks that include a fragment of JavaScript code.&#xD;&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:5014:  <row Id="7417" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="759" RevisionGUID="41b3a95e-06e1-45b1-a469-4f6c6e8582bb" CreationDate="2017-03-17T10:13:04.397" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.mathoverflow.net/ with https://meta.mathoverflow.net/" Text="I have been thinking about this for sometime. As you know, SE has changed the Community Wiki policy and now only moderators can make a question a CW. Community Wiki has 2 main effects:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;1. The question becomes owned by community, the original OP does not gain reputation,&#xD;&#xA;2. The required reputation to edit drops to 100,&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;and a side effect:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;3. The answers posted after a questions becomes a Community Wiki become Community Wiki automatically, i.e. the answers are owned by community, (but answers posted before the question becoming CW don't).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;These three effects are not always correlated and there are cases that one wants to have one of these three but not the other two, e.g. the owner does not want to earn reputation but wants the users answering the question to earn reputation for their answers. So it seems to me that SE is mixing too many things in one concept and that is the main reason for many issues we had and have with CW policy.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Robin brought up the idea that we should make the non-CW answers to a CW question CW also. I have a problem with answers becoming CW when the question becomes CW because sometimes the answers deserve to earn reputation, but in the current situation it makes sense, if the answers need to be CW then the previous ones also need to be CW, on the other hand a user might not have answered a question if it was a CW question so I don't know what is the right thing to do here.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I see three clear reasons for making a question a CW (and it would be nice to add other reasons to this list):&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;1. OP doesn't want to earn reputation (for some reason),&#xD;&#xA;2. OP wants to allow others to edit,&#xD;&#xA;3. the question is a ranking list.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;For example I think a question like [this][1] and [this][2] should be CW but the answers should not be and the users answering them should earn reputation for their answers. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Another issue is that the new policy is not clear on what we should do when we think a question or answer needs to be CW, I used to flag some posts for moderator attention but don't do it any more because I now think it is not very nice to suggest someone else question or answer should be CW to the moderators, so I have decided to go with a softer way of adding comments like &quot;I would upvote it if it becomes CW&quot;.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I have an proposal that I think might solve some issues and would like to hear what others think about it:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; In general the question or answer should be made CW only on the request of the owner (with some exceptions, see below), other users that think the post should be CW can leave a non-abusive comment like: &quot;nice answer, I would upvote it if it becomes CW&quot; and up-vote only if/when it becomes CW.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Exceptions:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;1. the OP is a drive-by user and does not reply to the answers or comments after considerable time,&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;2. some clear cases like: a ranking list. These should be explicitly included in the policy,&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;3. other special situations where the moderators have strong reasons for making a question CW.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;What do you think about this proposal (agree, disagree, opinions, improvements and suggestions, ...) and CW in general? &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;**ps:**&#xD;&#xA;Another minor issue about CW is its (lack of) effect on badges, it seems strange that a user does not earn reputation but does earn badges for CW posts, e.g. I should not have earned a badges for [these answers](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/174/major-unsolved-problems-in-theoretical-computer-science/218#218). Right now many of higher level badges are awarded for CW questions/answers, which does not seem a good thing to me.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;---&#xD;&#xA;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/239#239&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/25/material-to-supplement-the-faq&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;---&#xD;&#xA;### MO policy&#xD;&#xA; - https://meta.mathoverflow.net/discussion/6/when-should-questions-be-community-wiki&#xD;&#xA; - http://mathoverflow.net/faq#communitywiki&#xD;&#xA; &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### SE policy&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; - http://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/392/should-the-community-wiki-police-be-shut-down&#xD;&#xA; - http://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/67581/community-wiki-checkbox-missing-in-action&#xD;&#xA; - http://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/67039/what-can-we-do-to-make-community-wiki-better&#xD;&#xA; - http://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/11740/what-are-community-wiki-posts&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### Old discussions on cstheory meta:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; - https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/34/community-wiki-etiquette&#xD;&#xA; - https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/62/developing-a-cw-policy&#xD;&#xA; - https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/201/community-wikis&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]:  http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/45/what-are-good-references-to-understanding-the-proof-of-the-pcp-theorem&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2953/advice-on-good-research-practices" />
./PostHistory.xml:5015:  <row Id="7418" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="772" RevisionGUID="f55d587e-e228-40e1-ba98-0ba1586566cb" CreationDate="2017-03-17T10:13:04.397" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.mathoverflow.net/ with https://meta.mathoverflow.net/" Text="There's a [long and contentious discussion][1] over at MO on this topic, and I take the position shared by some of the commenters there that we should not create a policy of any kind until there's an actual need for it. The main fear in allowing non-English posts is balkanization, and so far that hasn't been an issue. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I see no reason to **encourage** posts in another language though, and I'd strongly encourage people to help with translation into English if a post in a different language does show up. We can separate the translation from the original by a rule. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://meta.mathoverflow.net/discussion/142/nonenglish-posts/#Item_0" />
./PostHistory.xml:5016:  <row Id="7419" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="816" RevisionGUID="4cfa4da2-674d-4a90-9121-f710aed03409" CreationDate="2017-03-17T10:13:04.397" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.mathoverflow.net/ with https://meta.mathoverflow.net/" Text="We have just had our [1000th question][1]; and this is the 12th day we launched; not long, but enough to see how we're doing. Lots of discussions have been done in the [review post of beta][2], while the number of questions is a [weak link][3] of us, we do not have [enough upvotes][4], and also there are a number of [homework problems][5], we tried our best to [increase the quality][6] of the posts and answers.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Although numbers are not important, sometimes they serve as indicators. I have just observed [a drop in the answer ratio][7]; at the time [we graduated from beta][8] it was about 2.8, and now it is about 2.5. It is also interesting that in the mean time, our traffic rate is constantly increasing, and the number of [active users][9] (users with a positive reputation change) in the late month is passed a hundred, a little increase compares to it was in beta.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Maybe the cause of the drop in the answer ratio is the homework problems, but I am not sure. Is this a healthy decrease (since we do not want to push the site too hard), or is it a signal of lacking enough thrust to keep flying our rocket? What do you think?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Another issue is the bounty system. It seems to me that recently, none of the questions with bounties have been answered in the bounty time period. The same problem [occurs in MO][10], which may due to both sites are theoretical oriented, and since it is related to the system of SE, we do not have too much we can do. Is there any solution to the bounty problem, despite the fact that it serves as a [mechanism to attract more attention][11]?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Final thoughts, it seems that most of the traffics comes from a particular region of the world (maybe US), since there is a low traffic gap (for about 8 hours) in the posts. Not a problem but an observation, but I do expect more experts and grad students all over the world to join our community.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Keep going, see how far we can reach :)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/3756/why-is-it-tn-4-work-for-each-block-of-the-matrix-in-this-divide-and-conquer-tra&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/522/beta-period-progress&#xD;&#xA;  [3]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/522/beta-period-progress/544#544&#xD;&#xA;  [4]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/6/vote-early-and-often&#xD;&#xA;  [5]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/601/flood-of-homework-questions&#xD;&#xA;  [6]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/522/beta-period-progress/524#524&#xD;&#xA;  [7]: http://stackexchange.com/sites&#xD;&#xA;  [8]: http://area51.stackexchange.com/proposals/8766/theoretical-computer-science&#xD;&#xA;  [9]: http://stackexchange.com/leagues/44/month/cstheory/2010-12-01?sort=reputationchange&amp;page=3&#xD;&#xA;  [10]: https://meta.mathoverflow.net/discussion/710/the-bounty-time-is-just-too-short/#Item_0&#xD;&#xA;  [11]: https://meta.mathoverflow.net/discussion/246/if-nobody-responds-to-a-bounty-why-do-you-still-lose-the-rep/#Item_0" />

./PostHistory.xml:5019:  <row Id="7422" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1580" RevisionGUID="8e416a78-cafc-43f1-bcc9-411211fee1b8" CreationDate="2017-03-17T10:13:04.397" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.mathoverflow.net/ with https://meta.mathoverflow.net/" Text="Is there a need for a _How-To Use_ or _Tips &amp; Tricks_ page? If so, what would be on it?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;(Tips and tricks include searching, urlencoding, markdown, how to see mathjax input, special question urls, site bugs and features.)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;**Motivation:** As you may be aware [MathOverflow](http://mathoverflow.net/) will soon be [part of the stackexchange network](https://meta.mathoverflow.net/discussion/1416/mathoverflow-20/)! One of the things we are thinking about right now is how to transfer all of MathOverflow's add-ons and tweaks to the new platform. We are quite fortunate that many of our little tweaks have already been implemented because sites like this one needed them. Of the leftover features, we have a [Tips and Tricks](http://mathoverflow.net/tips) page and the discreet tips box linking to it from our front page. There doesn't seem to be an equivalent here. (Let me know if I somehow missed it!) I'm wondering if that's because there is no need at all, if it's functionality is already available in another way (there are plenty of tip boxes here and there), or if it would actually be a helpful addition?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;**Just to be clear:** I am asking about the need for such a page here on CSTheory, not about the need on MathOverflow. Please stay on topic! (There is [another place](https://meta.mathoverflow.net/) to discuss MathOverflow issues.)" />

./PostHistory.xml:5022:  <row Id="7425" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2821" RevisionGUID="6a996f99-fd00-4379-a453-aed3374cb41b" CreationDate="2017-03-17T10:13:04.397" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.mathoverflow.net/ with https://meta.mathoverflow.net/" Text="### Asking questions like &quot;is my/this solution to P vs. NP correct&quot; is off-topic &#xD;&#xA;###(also applies to other famous open problems similar to P vs. NP)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;cstheory is not a peer-review site. We don't check, verify, or discuss such solutions. If you think you have a solution send it to a journal or conference that peer-reviews such articles. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Keep in mind that most reputable ones have a policy similar to [JACM's policy][1]:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; No author may submit more than one paper to J. ACM, ACM Trans. on Algorithms, or ACM Trans. on Computation Theory  in any 24 month period,  purporting to resolve the P versus NP question or related long-standing questions in complexity theory, except by invitation of the Editor-in-Chief. This applies to resubmissions of previously rejected manuscripts.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;----&#xD;&#xA;Related discussions&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* [Policy on unverified solutions of famous open problems][2]&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Related discussions on CS.SE:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* [How to deal with questions about crank-heavy topics?](https://cs.meta.stackexchange.com/q/109/)&#xD;&#xA;* [What constitutes an appropriate check-my-proof question?][3]&#xD;&#xA;* [How to ask P vs NP questions without getting closed?][4]&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Related discussions on MathOverflow:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* [Can I ask whether or not a paper that proves P=NP is correct?][5]&#xD;&#xA;* [What should be the policy on “open problems” on MO?][6]&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://jacm.acm.org/instructions/pnp&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/q/274/&#xD;&#xA;  [3]: https://cs.meta.stackexchange.com/q/647/&#xD;&#xA;  [4]: https://cs.meta.stackexchange.com/q/786/&#xD;&#xA;  [5]: https://meta.mathoverflow.net/q/1263&#xD;&#xA;  [6]: https://meta.mathoverflow.net/q/360" />
./PostHistory.xml:5023:  <row Id="7426" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2949" RevisionGUID="98e34021-1fb3-44cc-83c9-18ed7880b9cb" CreationDate="2017-03-17T10:13:04.397" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.mathoverflow.net/ with https://meta.mathoverflow.net/" Text="MO has [a meta thread][1] for listing questions on Math.SE which are interesting but have not been sufficiently answered on Math.SE. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Should we have something similar for interesting not-sufficiently answered questions on CS.SE?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://meta.mathoverflow.net/questions/1967/interesting-and-not-sufficiently-answered-questions-on-math-se" />
./PostHistory.xml:5024:  <row Id="7427" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="502" RevisionGUID="91ee54e9-6f6d-4c17-9daf-e407882e40a6" CreationDate="2017-03-17T10:37:54.420" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.stackoverflow.com/ with https://meta.stackoverflow.com/" Text="I am experimenting with some UserScripts to provide additional functionality that the StackExchange sites currently do not support.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;In particular, two have proved highly useful:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* https://math.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/689/latex-rendering-delay shows how to reduce the TeX preview delay from the default 5 seconds (!). ./PostHistory.xml:5027:  <row Id="7430" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="67" RevisionGUID="319a8433-ffa6-454e-9e03-31ad225cdf74" CreationDate="2017-03-20T10:29:37.593" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.stackexchange.com/ with https://meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="**Update**: This post is now closed since the temporary moderators have been selected. Please see [this announcement][1] for details. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;**Important: if you're nominated and accept the nomination, please add the word 'accept' somewhere in the answer, and also mention which timezones you are likely to be able to handle.** &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Based on [the web-apps template][2], we should be choosing candidates to be our site moderators.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* Each nomination should be a separate answer. Link the name to the user's profile so we can see their activity.&#xD;&#xA;* The nominee should indicate their acceptance by editing the answer, adding that they accept the nomination. Optionally they can write something about their self. This can be just practical stuff like which hours and how many hours they expect to spend on the site, but also some motivation.&#xD;&#xA;* From the top voted nominees a number of temporary moderators will be appointed, until the site is out of beta and real elections can be held.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Some guidelines:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;1. Must be a currently registered user in good standing&#xD;&#xA;2. Must have a reasonably high reputation score to indicate active, consistent participation.&#xD;&#xA;3. Should exhibit patience and fairness at all times in their questions, answers, and comments.&#xD;&#xA;4. Should lead by example, showing respect for their fellow community members in everything they write.&#xD;&#xA;5. They should want the responsibility. Nominating users isn’t the same as an obligation. It’s purely voluntary!&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;When nominating, please put the name of the nominee as a heading (with a #) and as a link to their real profile. Also add a link to their meta profile. (See the already provided answers). After that, please keep them empty for the nominees to add information themselves.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Besides voting, everybody could off course also point out in the comments why that nominee is a good candidate to be moderator or not.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Read more about [the moderator nomination process here][3].&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/222/moderator-pro-tem-announcement&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/57986/how-to-organize-a-formal-moderator-election-on-a-beta-se-site&#xD;&#xA;  [3]: https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/57986/how-to-organize-a-formal-moderator-election-on-a-beta-se-site" />

./PostHistory.xml:5031:  <row Id="7434" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="232" RevisionGUID="5b5792de-ef8d-42da-b11b-5bfc6d284cce" CreationDate="2017-03-20T10:29:37.593" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.stackexchange.com/ with https://meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="Can I discuss questions and answers on the site?&#xD;&#xA;------------------------------------------------&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;In addition to questions and answers, cstheory.sx supports, like other Stack Exchange sites, comments on questions and answers.  This supports discussions, and is important to improving posts, challenging possible mistakes, and bringing attention to relevant resources.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Of course, discussions only work if the participants know of the comments.  Besides comments appearing after the question or answer they comment on, the author of the question or answer will see that you have commented, as will anyone who you have notified by @name, where the site tries to figure out who @name might be by looking at the user names of other users who have participated in the thread.  You need at least the first three characters of the user name for the site to figure out that the @nam might be about them.  For more details on comment replies, see “[How do comment replies work?](https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/43019/how-do-comment-replies-work)” on meta.stackoverflow.com." />

./PostHistory.xml:5033:  <row Id="7436" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="351" RevisionGUID="85f2c4e2-7ff9-4310-978d-a77deab46810" CreationDate="2017-03-20T10:29:37.593" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.stackexchange.com/ with https://meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="As explained in [Suresh’s post](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/340/retag-all-cs-xyz-abc-to-xyz-abc/345#345) to another discussion, some tag synonyms are created without their master tags being created.  However, I think that some reconsideration is desirable because creating a tag synonym whose master tag does not exist in the system seems to have caused two problems.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;1. Some tag-related pages are Not Found.  See comments to [Suresh’s post](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/340/retag-all-cs-xyz-abc-to-xyz-abc/345#345).&#xD;&#xA;2. Users with rep less than 200 cannot tag his/her own question with either the older tag or the newer tag until some user with rep ≥200 uses the newer tag, even if the older tag is in use.  See a note and comments in a [question](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1527/confidentiality-of-partial-private-keys-in-certificateless-public-key-crypto) by Zack (but let’s avoid discussing about the issue on the question page).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Judging from [how the feature of tag synonyms was requested](https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/2779/could-the-tagging-system-be-enhanced-to-support-tag-synonyms) on meta.stackoverflow.com, it seems to me that a tag synonym is supposed to be created when the master tag is already in use.  Therefore, it is understandable that the system behaves oddly if the master of a tag synonym has not been created.&#xD;&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:5034:  <row Id="7437" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="376" RevisionGUID="9ba9282b-1d2a-4200-a28f-164162683e69" CreationDate="2017-03-20T10:29:37.593" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.stackexchange.com/ with https://meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="How do I delete my own question/answer?&#xD;&#xA;---------------------------------------&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The conditions to delete a post is explained in detail on [meta.stackoverflow.com](https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/5221/what-can-cause-a-post-to-be-deleted-and-what-does-that-actually-mean/5222#5222).  If you can delete your post, there is a link labeled “delete” below your post (on the same line as “link” and “flag.”)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;If you have not registered, you cannot delete a post.  To delete your post in this case, [register first](https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/42267/how-to-register-my-unregistered-account) and then try to delete it.  If you still cannot, you may have an unregistered account which is not merged to your registered account.  In this case, ask moderators to merge your unregistered accounts into the registered one.&#xD;&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:5035:  <row Id="7438" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="390" RevisionGUID="c5688e3b-b45b-433c-a413-e7049fc42a07" CreationDate="2017-03-20T10:29:37.593" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.stackexchange.com/ with https://meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="I would like to see the following entry in FAQ (in the “Best Practice” section):&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; My answer turned out to be incorrect.  What should I do?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;if there is a consensus about the answer.  Reasonable actions include:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- Correct it.  (But sometimes it is better to delete it and repost a correct answer; see the link to Meta Stack Overflow below.)&#xD;&#xA;- Leave it as it is after adding a clear notice that it is incorrect and why.&#xD;&#xA;- Delete it.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Such an FAQ entry should cover both the case where a flaw is found by the answerer him/herself and the case where a flaw is pointed out by someone else and the answerer is convinced (because I do not think there is much difference between them).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Related discussions:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- [Policy on deleting incorrect answers?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/386/policy-on-deleting-incorrect-answers)&#xD;&#xA;- [Should I remove a wrong answer (Peer Pressure)?](https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/22630/should-i-remove-a-wrong-answer-peer-pressure) on Meta Stack Overflow (but I do not think that everything written there applies to us in the same way)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;(There is another discussion about [deleting your own _question_](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/50/deleting-your-own-question), but it is not much related.)&#xD;&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:5036:  <row Id="7439" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="413" RevisionGUID="3a74e28a-d47d-4a86-a54e-095bcb9de59f" CreationDate="2017-03-20T10:29:37.593" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.stackexchange.com/ with https://meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="I oppose to your proposal. It is not, nor was it ever intended as, a measurement of how good a theoretical computer scientist you are.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;If you are expected to be already familiar with the system, you get automatic 100 reputation points.  If not, you do not.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;_Added_: Honestly speaking, if some people were frustrated enough by inability to comment or other small things for the first week to quit the website, I guess that they would be frustrated for many other things and would not stay at the website anyway, and giving them 100,000 reputation points would solve little.&#xD;&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:5037:  <row Id="7440" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="435" RevisionGUID="07a5bb3e-a735-4d33-8845-1f499fbac7cc" CreationDate="2017-03-20T10:29:37.593" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.stackexchange.com/ with https://meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="It appears that all our handwringing over domain names might be moot. webapps.stackexchange.com was the first SE site to exit beta, and had chosen the domain nothingtoinstall.com (which I thought was clever). 3 days into graduation, and the SE overlords suddenly decided that this was such a horrible name that they are retracting their promise to give out separate domain names, and the new URL forwards back to webapps.stackexchange.com&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;There's a fairly bitter discussion going on in the [NTI meta section][1], along with a [parallel discussion on meta.SO][2]. Bottom line:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* it's unlikely this decision will be changed&#xD;&#xA;* Jeff Atwood claims that a site reaching &quot;[ServerFault][3]&quot; levels of traffic (38k views/day at least count) will get their own domain, else not&#xD;&#xA;* He also thinks all names in the SE family are terrible, except the cooking site. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;This is extremely inside baseball stuff, so I don't expect anyone to care greatly about it. But it does mean our wranglings over the domain name are irrelevant. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://webapps.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/624/webapps-stackexchange-com-versus-nothingtoinstall-com&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/66443/public-service-announcement-ongoing-offsite-discussion-about-area51-graduates&#xD;&#xA;  [3]: http://serverfault.com/" />

(He [explained](http://blog.stackoverflow.com/2010/10/an-area-51-apology-and-clarification/) that it was a mistake that they did not close it earlier.)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Before it was closed, it had been “on hold,” and it had started [a discussion whether the proposal was a duplicate of Stack Overflow and/or CSTheory](https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/65967/why-is-the-compiler-design-proposal-on-hold).  The consensus in the discussion seems to be that questions about compiler design will be closed on our website. ./PostHistory.xml:5042:  <row Id="7445" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="508" RevisionGUID="e8fe899b-2656-43bc-8169-149e122bd6b5" CreationDate="2017-03-20T10:29:37.593" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.stackexchange.com/ with https://meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="Stack Exchange has an experimental feature called [timeline view](https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/54366/feedback-request-newer-timeline-question-view).  Currently the timeline page of a question can be reached only by tweaking the URL, but there is a [user script by quack quixote](https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/40617/a-greasemonkey-script-that-adds-timeline-links-to-all-the-questions/40623#40623) which adds a proper link.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;By default, the user script does not work on any *.stackexchange.com sites.  You have to add the following line to the declaration part:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    // @include http://*.stackexchange.com/*&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I have been using it for a month and it has never caused a problem as far as I know, which is great.&#xD;&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:5043:  <row Id="7446" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="558" RevisionGUID="a6ff6ae9-d73d-445b-8d22-3fda640870da" CreationDate="2017-03-20T10:29:37.593" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.stackexchange.com/ with https://meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="I wouldn't post this if I didn't think that this is going to create a bad example for future decisions. We are drawing lines about what is appropriate too strictly. We are being too conservative, the default position should be trusting decisions made by other users. If there is a disagreement, if the OP comes back and says I want this removed for some reasons, then we can discuss it, but as long as there is not a conflict, we should be very liberal about what users can do. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;What are we going to do if a user copies a deleted answer and posts it? Are we going to down vote it? Are we going to delete it? What if a number of users undelete a post. The system permits other users to undelete posts, even if it is deleted by the OP. Are we going to punish the users for undeleting it? Are we going to delete it again?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I also don't see any reason legally or ethically for not copying an answer. What is the ethical principle that is being violated? &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;IMHO, copying answers is completely compatible with the philosophy of the site. Let me quote a part of FAQ:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt;Other people can edit my stuff?!&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; Like Wikipedia, this site is collaboratively edited, and all edits are tracked. **If you are not comfortable with the idea of your questions and answers being edited by other trusted users, this may not be the site for you.**&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I think this is clear about the philosophy of SE. If you are not happy about copying answers, I respect your view. But if you are saying that it is inappropriate or unethical and/or if you are trying to draw lines too strictly about how other users or moderators should act, and about what is appropriate and what is not, sorry, but I don't agree.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;---&#xD;&#xA;###Edit 10/26/2010&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I agree with Tsuyoshi that there is not a need to agree on everything, i.e. I agree with Tsuyoshi to disagree.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;**My main point here is on how conservative we should be on what trusted users/moderators can do.** My view, as I wrote above, is that we should trust decisions made by others and be very liberal, we don't need to discuss every decision made by others, unless there is a conflict/disagreement.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Let me also make it clear that there is a difference between being nice to others and what is ethical. An action can be considered &quot;not being nice to others&quot;, but still don't violate any ethical principles. Being nice is boarder than being ethical (in this context).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Now, let me return to the particular case of this question.&#xD;&#xA;My sentence about the ethical principle being violated is in the context of our discussion, i.e. the appropriate use of *this site*. The argument, if I understood it correctly, is that we should respect the decision made by OP about deleting their post, and I guess this is based on the view that *OP own what they have posted*. I am not sure I agree with this. Again if I understood the philosophy of the site correctly, it is very similar to Wikipedia, and it is a collaborative effort. If you have posted something, others can modify, edit, or even copy-and-post it.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Some discussion on why it is not clear to me if a post is owned by OP, specially a CW post:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I. When someone posts an answer/questions, it means that other users are probably going to avoid posting similar content,&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;II. People vote for the answer,&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;III. Other answers may refer to it.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Removing a post can also be considered as not respecting the questioner, other user answering the question, and the votes given to the answer.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Now, if it is CW, i.e. *community wiki*, it is more involved. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;IV. CW answers are owned by community, they are edited by other users, and removing a post can cause even more problems in this case. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Assume that we have a CW question about what is the most famous problem in TCS, and someone posts &quot;$P$ vs $NP$&quot;, and of course receive lots of votes, after a few months the OP goes back and removes the answer. Assume that no one notices this. Think how it would look like if someone from outside or a new user reads the question and does not see an &quot;$P$ vs $NP$&quot; answer?! And even if another users posts it again, how many times do other uses have to vote for the same answer? Should we expect them to vote once every time someone removes it and someone else reposts an answer which is essentially the same?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I suggest you read this post: [What can cause a post to be deleted, and what does that actually mean?](https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/5221/what-can-cause-a-post-to-be-deleted-and-what-does-that-actually-mean/5222#5222)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;In particular, this part:&#xD;&#xA;&gt; When can't I delete my own post?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; You can't delete your answer if it has been accepted.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; You can't delete your question if it has more than two answers, if an answer has a score &gt;= 2, or it has been closed less than 48 hours ago.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;There are restrictions on when an answer can be removed by OP.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;In summery, &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I. it is not clear to me that OP owns what they post, specially CW posts,&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;II. deleting a good highly-voted post by OP (without stating any reasons) can also be considered disrespect towards other users, and may cause problems.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Just to make it clear, I agree that we should be nice to others, and if the OP complains about undeleting their post (and states some reasons for it) I would support the OP, but IMO, the default position should be that &quot;posts can be undeleted by others, even if OP have removed it&quot;, specially if they are good and highly-voted." />
./PostHistory.xml:5044:  <row Id="7447" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="609" RevisionGUID="3eb67078-d71a-4380-977a-7969a30ceb3e" CreationDate="2017-03-20T10:29:37.593" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.stackexchange.com/ with https://meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="This is not a less-known feature but a less-known practice. Note that not everything on the list applies to cstheory.stackexchange.com or meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com.  A Stack Exchange addict (**unlike me**) who is using a feed reader might want to subscribe to the feed for that thread to become a better Stack Exchange addict (**unlike me**)." />
./PostHistory.xml:5045:  <row Id="7448" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="613" RevisionGUID="a681de02-217c-4fd3-85b8-54604936ca70" CreationDate="2017-03-20T10:29:37.593" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.stackexchange.com/ with https://meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="(I do not use a feed reader much, and I may be missing the point.)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I am not sure if the feed for unanswered questions is meaningful.  Since every question is obviously unanswered when it is posted, you will receive every question if your feed reader checks for the update to the feed frequently enough.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;If the feed includes only unanswered questions which are at least a few days old, it might be useful, but that is at least something different from the [page of unanswered questions](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/unanswered).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;That said, there are several (almost duplicate) discussions on Meta Stack Overflow for feeds for unanswered questions:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/13849/rss-for-unansweredtagged-questions&#xD;&#xA;- https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/57300/rss-for-stackoverflows-unanswered-questions-that-matches-my-only-favorite-tags&#xD;&#xA;- https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/41696/why-is-there-no-rss-feed-for-unanswered-tagged-tagname&#xD;&#xA;- https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/42525/anyway-to-get-a-rss-feed-for-unanswered-questions&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;In the first link, someone points out a service to convert a usual page to a feed.&#xD;&#xA;" />

./PostHistory.xml:5047:  <row Id="7450" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="628" RevisionGUID="6090f2bd-2f52-47de-8f9f-00475d9238ed" CreationDate="2017-03-20T10:29:37.593" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.stackexchange.com/ with https://meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="Editing tags is not adding any information to a question/answers, it is a mainly organizational task. It is not an interesting activity for most users. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;It should be possible to see questions sorted based on the time that last significant activity is performed on them. And in place of stating who has performed last activity on the question, it should say who has performed the last significant activity on them.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The main example of **insignificant/uninteresting activity** is *tag edits*, but small edits to questions/answers (like spelling corrections) might also be considered insignificant and uninteresting.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;---&#xD;&#xA;I have posted it on SO meta:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/69659/a-page-for-questions-sorted-based-on-last-significant-modification-not-tag-edits" />
./PostHistory.xml:5048:  <row Id="7451" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="654" RevisionGUID="4e7a0c3a-52bb-45e3-8d91-ac6eb0c11a4f" CreationDate="2017-03-20T10:29:37.593" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.stackexchange.com/ with https://meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="Reading [this answer](https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/57462/is-reputation-100-for-having-at-least-200-on-another-site-retroactive/57463#57463) by Jaydles on Meta Stack Overflow suggests that you may be able to recover the lost +100 bonus by **deassociating and reassociating** your accounts.  Note that [another answer](https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/5909/how-do-reputation-bonuses-for-associations-between-accounts-work/5930#5930) by Daniel Moura to another question states that you have to start the reassociation on the site where you have ≥200 rep points to get +100 bonus.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The situation in the questions on Meta is certainly different from yours, so be warned that there might be an unexpected consequence.  You may want to bring the issue to Meta Stack Overflow so that more people familiar with the SE systems can give you an advice." />
./PostHistory.xml:5049:  <row Id="7452" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="664" RevisionGUID="4e33828a-9596-4c14-ba86-f0615d899010" CreationDate="2017-03-20T10:29:37.593" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.stackexchange.com/ with https://meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="When a question is closed, no additional answers may be posted to it.  A user who votes to close a question must select one of the following reasons:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- Exact duplicate&#xD;&#xA;- Off topic&#xD;&#xA;- Belongs to meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com&#xD;&#xA;- Subjective and argumentative&#xD;&#xA;- Not a real question&#xD;&#xA;- Too localized&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Since questions on cstheory.stackexchange.com are expected to be research-level questions in theoretical computer science, “off topic” means anything that fails to satisfy this criterion.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Even a question in theoretical computer science will be considered as off topic if, for example, it is too basic to be research-level.  **Forget about the system-generated boilerplate message.**&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;A question being closed as off topic means that the question does not belong to cstheory.stackexchange.com.  It does not necessarily mean that the question is bad.  For example, a question about programming (actually writing code) will be probably closed as off topic on cstheory.stackexchange.com even if it is very interesting.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;For general information about closed questions and the meanings of other close reasons on Stack Exchange websites, please refer to [this post](https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/10582/what-is-a-closed-question/10583#10583) on Meta Stack Exchange.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Related:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- [My (wonderful!) question was closed! What do I do now?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/361#361)&#xD;&#xA;- [What kind of questions are too basic?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/235#235)&#xD;&#xA;- Other discussions/questions posted on meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com about the [scope of cstheory.stackexchange.com](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/scope)&#xD;&#xA;" />

They automatically link to the list of tagged questions.  This is sometimes useful on Meta and in tag wikis.  Examples:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- `[tag:graph-theory]` → [tag:graph-theory] (points to a tag on parent)&#xD;&#xA;- `[meta-tag:scope]` → [meta-tag:scope] (points to a tag on Meta; only available on Meta)&#xD;&#xA;- `[tag:this-tag-does-not-exist]` → [tag:this-tag-does-not-exist] (also works for a nonexistent tag)&#xD;&#xA;" />

./PostHistory.xml:5052:  <row Id="7455" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="757" RevisionGUID="c16fea90-0198-4d3e-a2a7-942bcf38704f" CreationDate="2017-03-20T10:29:37.593" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.stackexchange.com/ with https://meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="In brief, the behavior is correct, and the the description of the privilege itself is not well worded. [This discussion on meta.SO][1] details the issue.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/68512/is-the-explanation-of-view-close-votes-misleading" />
./PostHistory.xml:5053:  <row Id="7456" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="759" RevisionGUID="acb283de-c295-4543-baa1-3bf3fef288b0" CreationDate="2017-03-20T10:29:37.593" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.stackexchange.com/ with https://meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="I have been thinking about this for sometime. As you know, SE has changed the Community Wiki policy and now only moderators can make a question a CW. Community Wiki has 2 main effects:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;1. The question becomes owned by community, the original OP does not gain reputation,&#xD;&#xA;2. The required reputation to edit drops to 100,&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;and a side effect:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;3. The answers posted after a questions becomes a Community Wiki become Community Wiki automatically, i.e. the answers are owned by community, (but answers posted before the question becoming CW don't).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;These three effects are not always correlated and there are cases that one wants to have one of these three but not the other two, e.g. the owner does not want to earn reputation but wants the users answering the question to earn reputation for their answers. So it seems to me that SE is mixing too many things in one concept and that is the main reason for many issues we had and have with CW policy.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Robin brought up the idea that we should make the non-CW answers to a CW question CW also. I have a problem with answers becoming CW when the question becomes CW because sometimes the answers deserve to earn reputation, but in the current situation it makes sense, if the answers need to be CW then the previous ones also need to be CW, on the other hand a user might not have answered a question if it was a CW question so I don't know what is the right thing to do here.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I see three clear reasons for making a question a CW (and it would be nice to add other reasons to this list):&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;1. OP doesn't want to earn reputation (for some reason),&#xD;&#xA;2. OP wants to allow others to edit,&#xD;&#xA;3. the question is a ranking list.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;For example I think a question like [this][1] and [this][2] should be CW but the answers should not be and the users answering them should earn reputation for their answers. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Another issue is that the new policy is not clear on what we should do when we think a question or answer needs to be CW, I used to flag some posts for moderator attention but don't do it any more because I now think it is not very nice to suggest someone else question or answer should be CW to the moderators, so I have decided to go with a softer way of adding comments like &quot;I would upvote it if it becomes CW&quot;.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I have an proposal that I think might solve some issues and would like to hear what others think about it:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; In general the question or answer should be made CW only on the request of the owner (with some exceptions, see below), other users that think the post should be CW can leave a non-abusive comment like: &quot;nice answer, I would upvote it if it becomes CW&quot; and up-vote only if/when it becomes CW.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Exceptions:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;1. the OP is a drive-by user and does not reply to the answers or comments after considerable time,&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;2. some clear cases like: a ranking list. These should be explicitly included in the policy,&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;3. other special situations where the moderators have strong reasons for making a question CW.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;What do you think about this proposal (agree, disagree, opinions, improvements and suggestions, ...) and CW in general? &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;**ps:**&#xD;&#xA;Another minor issue about CW is its (lack of) effect on badges, it seems strange that a user does not earn reputation but does earn badges for CW posts, e.g. I should not have earned a badges for [these answers](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/174/major-unsolved-problems-in-theoretical-computer-science/218#218). Right now many of higher level badges are awarded for CW questions/answers, which does not seem a good thing to me.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;---&#xD;&#xA;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/239#239&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/25/material-to-supplement-the-faq&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;---&#xD;&#xA;### MO policy&#xD;&#xA; - https://meta.mathoverflow.net/discussion/6/when-should-questions-be-community-wiki&#xD;&#xA; - http://mathoverflow.net/faq#communitywiki&#xD;&#xA; &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### SE policy&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; - https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/392/should-the-community-wiki-police-be-shut-down&#xD;&#xA; - https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/67581/community-wiki-checkbox-missing-in-action&#xD;&#xA; - https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/67039/what-can-we-do-to-make-community-wiki-better&#xD;&#xA; - https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/11740/what-are-community-wiki-posts&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### Old discussions on cstheory meta:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; - https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/34/community-wiki-etiquette&#xD;&#xA; - https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/62/developing-a-cw-policy&#xD;&#xA; - https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/201/community-wikis&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]:  http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/45/what-are-good-references-to-understanding-the-proof-of-the-pcp-theorem&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2953/advice-on-good-research-practices" />
./PostHistory.xml:5054:  <row Id="7457" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="769" RevisionGUID="8e44cc60-7c3b-46ac-9d6d-da40417d9838" CreationDate="2017-03-20T10:29:37.593" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.stackexchange.com/ with https://meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="This has been bothered my for a while. And a [related discussion][1] is in metaSE, while the post is tagged with [status-declined] and the community seems to disagree with it.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Sometimes by accident I up-voted a wrong comment. Sometimes I misread the comment, and I want to undo my decision. (My fault, of course!) Sometimes I just want to flag the comment instead of upvoting, but after the upvote we *can't even* flag the comment!&#xD;&#xA;That really makes me hesitate to use the functionality of upvoting and flagging. If we can cancel an upvote in a reasonable amount of time (just like the upvotes for questions and answers), it would represents the community's opinion much better.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; Should we have the ability to cancel a comment upvote?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/1170/should-i-be-able-to-cancel-my-up-vote-on-a-comment" />
./PostHistory.xml:5055:  <row Id="7458" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="771" RevisionGUID="0267b7fe-251c-4151-a21f-c7f184c4cf14" CreationDate="2017-03-20T10:29:37.593" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.stackexchange.com/ with https://meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="_Update_: Since April 2012, we can cancel a comment upvote by clicking the upward arrow again.  We can cancel a comment upvote only for 60 seconds and only if we have not navigated to another page.  [Read this for more detail](https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/1170/should-i-be-able-to-cancel-my-up-vote-on-a-comment/129032#129032).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;---&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Yes, we should.  As you wrote very appropriately, there are several reasons why canceling comment upvotes for a limited time window will be useful.  However, note that they declined the request (in August 2009) on Meta Stack Exchange and have not reversed the decision even with more than 70 upvotes.  I would not hold my breath." />
./PostHistory.xml:5056:  <row Id="7459" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="790" RevisionGUID="4a3c4f92-725a-4ffa-b9f7-423f20004cfe" CreationDate="2017-03-20T10:29:37.593" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.stackexchange.com/ with https://meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="The function of the envelope icon changed a while ago (seemingly at the beginning of November).  Now the envelope icon turns yellow only if the system has something to notify you that the global SE inbox does not notify, such as favorite changes.  See [this post on Meta Stack Overflow](https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/68387/the-envelope-icon-driving-me-mad-with-false-positives/69680#69680).&#xD;&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:5057:  <row Id="7460" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="804" RevisionGUID="d58061e7-1c93-48fc-9186-e6117b424f25" CreationDate="2017-03-20T10:29:37.593" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.stackexchange.com/ with https://meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="## A link with an anchor text in a comment&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### Update&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;**This issue has been fixed.**  Read more on [Meta Stack Overflow](https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/52312/comment-links-fail-when-next-to-non-whitespace/77093#77093).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;It seems that this change also affects the comments posted before.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;---&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;_Edit: Below is an older description of the issue, which no longer applies._&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;You can put a link in a comment by either writing a complete URL or using the `[…](http:…)` syntax, just as in Markdown used for questions and answers.  For example, `[TCS Stack Exchange](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/)` results in a link.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;However, be careful when you use the latter syntax in a comment, because not all texts that would produce a link in Markdown also produce a link in comments.  For example, if you enclose the text by a parenthesis like `([TCS Stack Exchange](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/))` in a comment, the server does not recognize the syntax and turn only the URL part into a link.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### Workarounds&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The link syntax `[…](http:…)` in comments is unreliable when a non-space character precedes or follows it.  It is better not to use this syntax.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;If you insist on using this syntax, an easy way to ensure that the server considers it as a hyperlink is to surround it by spaces.  Some symbols such as a period and a comma seem to be allowed after the text.&#xD;&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:5058:  <row Id="7461" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="809" RevisionGUID="33d5c13d-bd5c-489a-97d6-622b3dd5c3a2" CreationDate="2017-03-20T10:29:37.593" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.stackexchange.com/ with https://meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="I do not mind the existence of the tag although I do not see a compelling reason why we _need_ that tag.  It is not always clear whether a question belongs to “application” or not, and I will not try hard to decide one way or the other.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;As for the name, [tag:application-of-theory] (or “application&lt;strong&gt;s&lt;/strong&gt;-of-theory”) seems the best.  [tag:application] could be misinterpreted as questions about application software.  I do not think that [tag:theory-in-practice] is easily discoverable.  To address Suresh’s concern that no one will search for [tag:application-of-theory], the input fields which expect tags have autocompletion which completes “appl” to [tag:application-of-theory].  Well, [except the general search box](https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/29277/autocomplete-tags-in-search-box). :(" />

./PostHistory.xml:5061:  <row Id="7465" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="898" RevisionGUID="fc6f64fe-6c8c-4939-8c0d-f557195e08f2" CreationDate="2017-03-20T10:29:37.593" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.stackexchange.com/ with https://meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="[Yi Jiang](https://meta.stackoverflow.com/users/150097/yi-jiang) has put together a nice site that use the Stack Overflow API to display information on the moderator candidates.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;[Click here to see all the information](http://se.awio.com/election.html).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The information presented is:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;What the candidate wrote when nominating themselves.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* Answers/Questions on the main site and it's meta&#xD;&#xA;* Up-vote/down-vote ratio&#xD;&#xA;* Average reputation earned per post&#xD;&#xA;* Average reputation earned per day.&#xD;&#xA;* Participation in other Stack Exchange sites.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;It displays what Yi Jiang considers to be noteworthy badges and whether the nominee has the badge and a summary of their recent activity.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The information is presented as is with no commentary.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;It came about from this question on MSO [Moderator nomination possibly useful statistics](https://meta.stackexchange.com/q/75454/59303)" />

./PostHistory.xml:5063:  <row Id="7467" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="914" RevisionGUID="9b648fa4-1c69-4d30-85bc-a0d1f5b63229" CreationDate="2017-03-20T10:29:37.593" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.stackexchange.com/ with https://meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="I am not sure if moderators can change the system message calling for voting, but if possible, please consider changing the current message:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; Cast your final vote in the Theoretical Computer Science 2011 community moderator election!&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;to something along&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; Cast your vote in the Theoretical Computer Science 2011 community moderator election if you have at least 150 reputation points!&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The proposed changes are:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- Primary proposal: Add “if you have at least 150 reputation points” because otherwise you are asking people with &amp;lt;150 rep points to do something you disallow, which is not nice.&#xD;&#xA;- Secondary proposal: Change “final vote” to simply “vote” because we did not have the primary phase.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Related to the first item, a user of Meta Stack Overflow had proposed something similar in [Don't have Stack Overflow propose that I vote in the moderator election when I don't have the reputation to do so](https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/76506/dont-have-stack-overflow-propose-that-i-vote-in-the-moderator-election-when-i-do). ./PostHistory.xml:5064:  <row Id="7468" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="922" RevisionGUID="f62b4913-4416-4a27-9429-5b2ba69bbcb3" CreationDate="2017-03-20T10:29:37.593" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.stackexchange.com/ with https://meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="I completely agree that there are legitimate reasons to want to undo votes on posts, such as clicking by mistake or changing your mind after some time.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;As I wrote in a comment, [a vote on a post cannot be canceled except for certain circumstances](https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/5212/are-there-any-voting-limits/5213#5213).  The official explanation for this restriction, which I cannot find where I saw for now, is “Allowing unlimited undoing would open up the possibility of gaming the system.”  Namely, if you want your answer to be voted up, you could vote down the other answers so that your answer will be shown on the top of the page (because the other answers have now negative score) and lazy users will read only your answer and upvote it.  The downside of this strategy is that you lose 1 rep point every time you cast a downvote, but if you can undo the votes, you can cancel your downvotes after a week or so when no one cares what happens in a question which does not appear on the top page.  Moreover, canceling the downvotes hides the evidence that you have cast many downvotes (the number of upvotes and downvotes you have cast is available on your profile page).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Many (seemingly silly) restrictions on Stack Exchange websites like this originate from the same logic of preventing gaming the system.  I guess that these restrictions came from the real experience by the admins at Stack Overflow Internet Services, Inc., on Stack Overflow and other sites which have longer history than ours.  I appreciate the fact that the admins put their experiences to form the whole Stack Exchange network.  However, I am worried by their general tendency of overreacting to the fear that someone may game the system.  I believe that different communities have different priorities and that earning the rep points is not considered to be as important in cstheory.stackexchange.com as in more popular sites such as Stack Overflow.  I understand that it is sometimes difficult to prevent abusing without ruining the usability for legitimate users, but I hope that they will take the difference like this into account to design the system.&#xD;&#xA;" />

./PostHistory.xml:5074:  <row Id="7478" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1358" RevisionGUID="1060eaf3-a5f7-4ac3-84fa-6376c0f2bd0e" CreationDate="2017-03-20T10:29:37.593" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.stackexchange.com/ with https://meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="After reading a [post](http://chat.stackexchange.com/transcript/message/2051962#2051962) by user [Gopi](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/users/4873/gopi) in the chat room, I wrote a [query on Data Explorer which lists the number of questions posted in each month and the number of closed questions among them](http://data.stackexchange.com/theoreticalcomputerscience/s/1921/closed-questions-per-month) (although it is not exactly what Gopi asked).  I will not try to interpret the data here, but if you find it interesting or if you have something to say about it, let me know.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;For the last month in the table, the actual number of questions and closed questions should be larger than the numbers shown in the table because the table is as of the time of the last update of the database.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;[Questions with no answers, low score, and low activity for a while are deleted automatically](https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/81887/what-happens-to-unanswered-questions-from-deleted-accounts/82408#82408).  This means that in most cases, closed questions with negative score which are more than 30 days old and closed questions with score 0 which are more than 365 days old will be deleted and not included in the table.  Therefore, the actual number and the actual rate of closed questions for more than one month old will be higher than shown in the table.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;**Warning**.  I am not familiar with SQL, the language in which this query is written.  Therefore, the query may well contain a bug.  In case you find a bug, I am happy to learn about it.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;**Aside**.  The table shows that there is one question posted in 2008.  Unfortunately this is not an evidence for a time machine.  This question was migrated from another site, and it was posted in 2008 in the original site.  Ideally the query should use the month when the question started to appear on cstheory.stackexchange.com, but I currently ignore this issue because this should affect only the migrated questions and there are not many of them." />
./PostHistory.xml:5075:  <row Id="7479" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1364" RevisionGUID="46aa14c5-2096-4d11-9097-04963da722ff" CreationDate="2017-03-20T10:29:37.593" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.stackexchange.com/ with https://meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="As a long-term [supporter of a computer science site](https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/80023/where-on-se-to-discuss-computer-science), I welcome your proposal and thank you for spending the time to make it and defend it. ./PostHistory.xml:5076:  <row Id="7480" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1367" RevisionGUID="b8fe0695-7de1-4de0-a686-f180e7094ea3" CreationDate="2017-03-20T10:29:37.593" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.stackexchange.com/ with https://meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="(This is a more detailed version of my comment on the question.)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Closing and deletion are different notions.  (But some closed and even non-closed questions are deleted automatically.  See below.)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* Closed but not deleted questions are listed in your profile.&#xD;&#xA;* Unless you have [reputation points ≥ 10,000](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/privileges/moderator-tools) or you are a moderator, you cannot view deleted questions (including your own questions which have been deleted).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;There is a [feature request on Meta Stack Overflow](https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/2645/show-all-of-my-question-answers-to-me-even-if-they-are-deleted) to allow a user to see his/her own questions which have been deleted, but this request was declined in June 2010.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### Why are some closed (and even non-closed) questions deleted automatically?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;If a question has no answers, low score, and no activity for a long time, it is deleted automatically.  Closed questions tend to have low score and low activity, and therefore I imagine that they are often subject to this automatic deletion mechanism.  See [this post](https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/81887/what-happens-to-unanswered-questions-from-deleted-accounts/82408#82408) for the gory details.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;See [this](https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/65768/do-closed-questions-get-deleted-automatically-after-some-time) for another reason why closed questions may be deleted earlier than the automatic deletion kicks in." />
./PostHistory.xml:5077:  <row Id="7481" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1436" RevisionGUID="0081f1de-41f1-4baf-abe1-b0001b07c2dd" CreationDate="2017-03-20T10:29:37.593" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.stackexchange.com/ with https://meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="I am in full agreement with you. Please see [this](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/628/a-page-for-most-recent-significatly-modified-questions-not-tag-edits-and-who-h) and [this](https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/69659/a-page-for-questions-sorted-based-on-last-significant-modification-not-tag-edit). We have already asked for this feature, SE didn't agree. (Maybe they will change their opinion if more people complain about it. I think at least we should get something like [this](http://stackoverflow.com/?tab=interesting)).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I edit questions which don't use one of the top level tags (for classification reason). I would prefer if people use one of them when asking a question and I wouldn't need to do this retagging. I try to restrict my tag edits to the questions on the front page so it has a less annoying effect. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;ps: I don't use RSS/email to get the updates so maybe this is a bigger problem for people using them.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;pps: I think a reasonable solution is to have something similar to [the minor edit checkbox on Wikipedia][1]. ./PostHistory.xml:5078:  <row Id="7483" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1486" RevisionGUID="a48989f4-12c8-4823-9ae3-40b33ea1bc08" CreationDate="2017-03-20T10:29:37.593" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.stackexchange.com/ with https://meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="Here is another user style sheet. This makes the three icons less pronounced.
