./PostHistory.xml:5079:  <row Id="7484" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1535" RevisionGUID="038c3db6-f673-43c6-9cde-072acaf7920b" CreationDate="2017-03-20T10:29:37.593" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.stackexchange.com/ with https://meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="I do not think that the website provides the functionality of hiding questions or answers posted by certain users.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;To hide questions with certain tags, specify those tags as “ignored tags” and check the “hide ignored tags” option in the “prefs” page of your profile. ./PostHistory.xml:5080:  <row Id="7485" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1547" RevisionGUID="e53ce97f-d623-4df0-861c-074d87fba4d1" CreationDate="2017-03-20T10:29:37.593" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.stackexchange.com/ with https://meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="First, make sure that the question is really not suitable.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;If you are sure that it is not suitable, then it is better to do something about it than just leave it as it is.  There are five options: edit, delete, vote to close, flag, and leave a comment.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### Edit a question&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;If you can change the question so that it is suitable, please edit it.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;But please do not edit one question to a completely unrelated question!  It is better to keep different questions separate.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### Delete a question&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;You can delete your own question if you are a registered user of the website and the question has not received an answer.  (For the precise conditions when you can and cannot delete your own post, see “When _can’t_ I delete my own post?” in [this post on Meta Stack Overflow](https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/5221/what-can-cause-a-post-to-be-deleted-and-what-does-that-actually-mean/5222#5222)).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Deleted questions do not appear in lists of questions (including your own profile page), and most non-moderator users cannot read deleted questions.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;For some reason, when you click “delete” link of your question, the system asks “Vote to delete this post?” suggesting that you are merely _voting_ to delete instead of deleting, but this is probably just a glitch in the system; if you click “Yes,” the post is deleted immediately.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### Vote to close a question&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;You can cast a close vote to your own question if your reputation points is 250 or higher.  See [this page](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/privileges/view-close-votes) for an explanation of closure (not in the mathematical sense).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### Flag a question for moderator attention&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;If none of the above helps and you need a help about usage of the website from moderators, please flag your own question for moderator attention.  Please explain what help you need in the flag dialog box.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;[This page](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/privileges/flag-posts) states that you need at least 15 reputation points to flag a post.  I do not know if this applies also to flagging your own post.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### Leave a comment&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;You can always post a comment on your question.  Even when you cannot delete, vote to close, or flag, and you cannot think of a way to edit the question so that it becomes suitable, it is probably better to leave a comment that you are aware that you posted an inappropriate question.  In addition, if you need some help about usage of the website and you cannot flag the post, posting a comment might get some user’s attention.&#xD;&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:5081:  <row Id="7486" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1550" RevisionGUID="3b502f29-7b62-47d3-9985-8482844b73bb" CreationDate="2017-03-20T10:29:37.593" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.stackexchange.com/ with https://meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="We are regularly migrating non-research-level questions from here to CS.SE. I think it would be good to open the migration path to CS.SE so high reputation users can choose to migrate to CS.SE when closing a question (without moderator intervention).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;What do you think? ./PostHistory.xml:5083:  <row Id="7488" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1587" RevisionGUID="15eabbe9-94c7-4a0d-8735-faf96092328a" CreationDate="2017-03-20T10:29:37.593" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.stackexchange.com/ with https://meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="(You already know the answer, but let me post it as an answer.)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Unfortunately, we cannot cancel close votes at our own will. ./PostHistory.xml:5084:  <row Id="7489" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1608" RevisionGUID="925d01a4-5947-42a0-886b-36d4dc9e9de8" CreationDate="2017-03-20T10:29:37.593" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.stackexchange.com/ with https://meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="As Suresh explained, it means that a user who had voted up your posts had his/her account deleted, and therefore his/her votes were automatically cancelled. ./PostHistory.xml:5087:  <row Id="7492" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2702" RevisionGUID="87f248dc-4140-4e5f-8f7b-ec1e7d92722f" CreationDate="2017-03-20T10:29:37.593" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.stackexchange.com/ with https://meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="### Not enough effort &#xD;&#xA;Doesn't know the basics definitions/results, hasn't tried to answer the oneself, the answer can be found on Wikipedia/Complexity Zoo/... or by a simple Google search.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; Questions must demonstrate a minimal understanding of the problem being solved. ./PostHistory.xml:5088:  <row Id="7493" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2733" RevisionGUID="98660af0-fd70-4b87-bdcc-2693c5d4318c" CreationDate="2017-03-20T10:29:37.593" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.stackexchange.com/ with https://meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="TL;DR: This is an excellent suggestion -- one that I think there is sadly no chance of being implemented, alas.  The only way to fix this is to rely upon our moderators to un-CW such questions (you'll have to flag it for their attention).  I'd certainly hope our moderators would be glad to do that.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;----&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;In more detail: I agree with you.  I too would like to see automatic conversion to community wiki disabled.  I think it's a lousy feature; it disincentives improvements to questions and answers.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Unfortunately it has been suggested previously on Meta.Stackoverflow many times over the past 4 years, and it looks very unlikely that it will be changed:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- https://meta.stackexchange.com/q/8654/160917&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- https://meta.stackexchange.com/q/192434/160917&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- https://meta.stackexchange.com/q/179746/160917&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- https://meta.stackexchange.com/q/183918/160917&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- https://meta.stackexchange.com/q/179901/160917&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- https://meta.stackexchange.com/q/333/160917&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- https://meta.stackexchange.com/q/155621/160917&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- https://meta.stackexchange.com/q/181436/160917&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- https://meta.stackexchange.com/q/79250/160917&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- https://meta.stackexchange.com/q/157928/160917&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Apparently, the rationale given for the existing auto-CW-conversion behavior is that the site designers were worried that people would continually edit their question to bump it to the front page of the site.  I personally don't think the current behavior is the best solution to that problem, but whatever: it's clear that the site developers have a different view, that they have thought about this, they do have reasons for the current behavior, and ultimately, this is unlikely to change (at least, not in the foreseeable future).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;For now, no changes seem likely to come our way.&#xD;&#xA;Instead, the standard workaround seems to be: if you notice that a question/answer was auto-converted to CW inappropriately, flag it for a moderator (flag as &quot;needs moderator attention&quot;), and ask the moderator to please reverse the community wiki status.  Moderators have that ability.  Apparently, many moderators have stated that they do routinely grant these requests (absent concrete reasons not to), and it is considered legitimate to ask the moderators to do so.  See, e.g.,&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- https://meta.stackexchange.com/a/179756/160917&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- https://meta.stackexchange.com/q/192784/160917&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- https://meta.stackexchange.com/a/192438/160917&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- https://meta.stackexchange.com/a/83373/160917&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- https://meta.stackexchange.com/a/179825/160917&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Unfortunately, you'll still lose any rep that was accumulated between when the answer was auto-converted to CW and when the moderator reverts the CW status.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;----&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;**My proposal:** Our moderators should routinely and gladly grant such flag requests, as long as there has not been any signs of abuse.  We should be grateful to anyone who takes the time to improve their questions or answers, as long as they're not abusing the feature to try to bump their question/answer to the front page.  I don't think our moderators should refuse to grant such flags (e.g., on the basis that they're going to wait for this behavior to be changed -- as it's pretty clear this behavior is not going to be changed any time soon).  That just penalizes people who put extra time and energy into improving their questions/answers." />
./PostHistory.xml:5089:  <row Id="7494" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2833" RevisionGUID="8e9b5989-c410-4a8d-bee1-63bff0a89054" CreationDate="2017-03-20T10:29:37.593" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.stackexchange.com/ with https://meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="My understanding is that giving flags should not affect reputation.  You can look at the reputation rules here: https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/7237/how-does-reputation-work" />
./PostHistory.xml:5090:  <row Id="7495" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2848" RevisionGUID="6c6bd715-1831-41a6-898a-0f2b423e477c" CreationDate="2017-03-20T10:29:37.593" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.stackexchange.com/ with https://meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="Yes.  This is a known consequence of the design of this feature, and the StackExchange team has indicated that they do not plan to fix it.  The issue is that they cache this number, and the cache gets out of date.  Also, they compute the total number of reviews, rather than the number that you personally can perform, because they don't want to compute it separately for each user, which can also cause the number to be inflated.  Computing the correct number for each user would be too computationally expensive, apparently.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;So, in summary: known defect, no plan to fix it.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;See https://meta.stackexchange.com/q/230742/160917 and https://meta.stackexchange.com/q/230833/160917." />
./PostHistory.xml:5091:  <row Id="7496" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2850" RevisionGUID="261a307e-ed3b-426a-be9b-5ecc3e82eaf5" CreationDate="2017-03-20T10:29:37.593" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.stackexchange.com/ with https://meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="If I post a question on CS.SE and don't get an answer, is it OK to post the same question on TCS.SE after waiting a week or so?  In other words, is cross-posting on CS.SE and TCS.SE OK (rather than migrating) if there is a delay of a week between them?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I'm asking to see if I can clarify the policy, because I am confused.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;To be clear: I am not asking about simultaneous cross-posting.  I'm asking about cross-posting after a delay of a week, when the question didn't get an answer on the original site. I'm not talking about migrating a question or deleting the original one and posting it on a new site; I'm talking about cross-posting, where the question is open on both CS.SE and TCS.SE.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Here is what I have been able to find:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- The standard StackExchange policy is: it is not OK to cross-post the same question on multiple sites.  If you post it on one site and after a week or two don't get an answer, you can flag it to ask the moderators to migrate it, but you should not cross-post (not even after a week or two).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  Source: https://meta.stackexchange.com/q/64068/160917&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- Currently, the TCS policy says that it is OK to cross-post on TCS.SE and MathOverflow, if you post on one and don't get an answer even after waiting a week or so (and if you must cross-link the two).  However this doesn't say anything about other SE sites other than MathOverflow, so it's not clear if this applies more broadly.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  Source: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/a/231/5038&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- There was a proposal to change that policy to allow simultaneous cross-posting on TCS.SE and MO, but that proposal was marked status-declined (it was rejected).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  Source: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/q/673/5038&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- Peter Shor points out that one of the close reasons says&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  &gt; Our [site policy](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/a/231/5038) prohibits ***simultaneous* crossposting**: it duplicates effort and fractures discussion. Crossposting is permitted after a week has passed without a satisfying answer elsewhere. When crossposting please summarize the relevant discussions from other sites in your question and link between the copies in both directions. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  This sure sounds like cross-posting after a delay is allowed.  On the other hand, when you click on the link to the &quot;site policy&quot;, the policy described at the link target actually only mentions MathOverflow, not other SE sites.  (I hadn't noticed this previously, because I don't have enough reputation to vote to close.)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- CS.SE does not seem to have any special policy about this, and I can't find any discussion of this on Meta.CS.SE.  Therefore, I would assume that CS.SE abides by the standard StackExchange policy, by default.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  Also, given the standard StackExchange policy and the impact on both sites, I would guess that probably cross-posting on two SE sites should only be allowed if both sites opt into a policy of allowing cross-posting.  CS.SE does not seem to have opted to allow cross-posting on CS.SE+TCS.SE, and since I can't find any clear evidence that TCS.SE has, either.  (It appears that before adopting the current policy regarding cross-posting on TCS.SE+MO, both TCS.SE and MO were consulted; however, I can't find any evidence of any consultation with CS.SE about cross-posting on CS.SE+TCS.SE.)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;My conclusion: It's not clear to me what is allowed.  The information on the policy does not seem entirely self-consistent, to my eyes.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;So, what *is* the current policy?  Is cross-posting on CS.SE and TCS.SE allowed, if you wait a week?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;And if this has not been previously addressed, what *should* the policy be?" />
./PostHistory.xml:5092:  <row Id="7497" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2851" RevisionGUID="aea3c3c4-3a19-48a9-a63c-3ca89b4c18d1" CreationDate="2017-03-20T10:29:37.593" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.stackexchange.com/ with https://meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="If this has not been addressed before, here is my proposed policy (to allow others to vote on it): We should not allow cross-posting on CS.SE and TCS.SE.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Of course many people might like to get more attention by posting their question on as many places as possible, but that doesn't mean it's good for the community for that to happen.  It has some costs:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;1. It fragments discussion and answers.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;2. Inevitably the two will diverge.  For instance, there might be a good answer on one but not the other.  Even if they are cross-linked, this makes it harder than necessary for others to discover the answer to the question.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;3. It makes it harder for others who have the same question to find the question and benefit from the answers we've built up.  Splitting answers across two pages dilutes the &quot;Google juice&quot; of both.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;These problems are explained well at [the StackExchange page on this issue](https://meta.stackexchange.com/q/64068/160917).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Migration solves the above problems.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;However, migration has its own costs:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;1. If you migrate, the question disappears from the old site.  The old URL doesn't stop working -- it redirects to the location on the new site, so Google searches that turn up the old URL will still get you to the right place -- but search on the new site will no longer turn up the old question.  This makes it impossible for people who have the same question to find the old question by searching on the old site.  To find it, they'd have to either search on Google or search on the new site.  So, if the question was squarely within scope on the old site, this makes it harder to find the information.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;This means there are some pros and cons either way.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Weighing the pros and cons, I'd suggest we stick with the default StackExchange policy and prohibit cross-posting on CS.SE and TCS.SE (cross-posting shouldn't be allowed, not even if you wait a week or two for an answer and get nothing)." />
./PostHistory.xml:5093:  <row Id="7499" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2924" RevisionGUID="aec61a4a-6d80-4ee9-8fdd-39e22e042ddc" CreationDate="2017-03-20T10:29:37.593" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.stackexchange.com/ with https://meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="Now that both sites have graduated, let's revisit this request. I proposed [some criteria](https://meta.stackexchange.com/q/261196/1438) last summer (which we've been using internally for a while). My evaluation:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;1. Sanity check: Yes, there are plenty of reasons a question might be asked here that really belongs on the more general CS site.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;2. Gather statistics: In the past 90 days, there have been [6 migrations to and from CS Theory](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/tools/posts/migrated/stats):&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;        cs.stackexchange.com          =&gt; cstheory.stackexchange.com × 4 (25% rejected)&#xD;&#xA;        datascience.stackexchange.com =&gt; cstheory.stackexchange.com × 1&#xD;&#xA;        cstheory.stackexchange.com    =&gt; cs.stackexchange.com × 1&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;   This is underwhelming. It seems that in practice, people are pretty good about posting to CS when they have a non-research-level question. Just one question has been migrated away. It does not seem as if the moderators are being overwhelmed with migration flags. It's also instructive that there are few migrations the other direction. (A 25% rejection rate would be a red flag if it were not just one question.) &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;So I don't see a lot of evidence that this path is needed. Looking at the [close statistics](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/tools/question-close-stats?daterange=last90days) it seems that the custom close reason that directs people to post to CS on their own is the prefered solution. 115 questions have been closed that way over the same time period. Now if the proportion _does_ shift toward migration and if those migrations are successful as a rule, we might have a reason to add this default path." />
./PostHistory.xml:5094:  <row Id="7500" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2925" RevisionGUID="691502c2-de87-44e5-8002-1fa666978f4e" CreationDate="2017-03-20T10:29:37.593" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.stackexchange.com/ with https://meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="It's 2016 now, and we've [made some changes to the sidebar size](https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/272563/were-standardizing-the-sidebar-width-at-300px-on-all-sites). As such, we can now restart the Community Promotion Ads for 2016!&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Keep in mind, we have updated some of the guidelines compared to previously - the changes are marked in bold in the Image Requirements section.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### What are Community Promotion Ads?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Community Promotion Ads are community-vetted advertisements that will show up on the main site, in the right sidebar. The purpose of this question is the vetting process. Images of the advertisements are provided, and community voting will enable the advertisements to be shown.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### Why do we have Community Promotion Ads?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;This is a method for the community to control what gets promoted to visitors on the site. For example, you might promote the following things:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; - cool site-related open source apps&#xD;&#xA; - the site's twitter account&#xD;&#xA; - cool events or conferences&#xD;&#xA; - anything else your community would genuinely be interested in&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The goal is for future visitors to find out about *the stuff your community deems important*. This also serves as a way to promote information and resources that are *relevant to your own community's interests*, both for those already in the community and those yet to join. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### Why do we reset the ads every year?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Some services will maintain usefulness over the years, while other things will wane to allow for new faces to show up. Resetting the ads every year helps accommodate this, and allows old ads that have served their purpose to be cycled out for fresher ads for newer things. This helps keep the material in the ads relevant to not just the subject matter of the community, but to the current status of the community. We reset the ads once a year, every December.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The community promotion ads have no restrictions against reposting an ad from a previous cycle. If a particular service or ad is very valuable to the community and will continue to be so, it is a good idea to repost it. It may be helpful to give it a new face in the process, so as to prevent the imagery of the ad from getting stale after a year of exposure.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### How does it work?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The answers you post to this question _must_ conform to the following rules, or they will be ignored. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;1. All answers should be in the exact form of:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;        [![Tagline to show on mouseover][1]][2]&#xD;&#xA;        &#xD;&#xA;           [1]: http://image-url&#xD;&#xA;           [2]: http://clickthrough-url &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;    Please **do not add anything else to the body of the post**. If you want to discuss something, do it in the comments.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;2. The question must always be tagged with the magic [meta-tag:community-ads] tag. In addition to enabling the functionality of the advertisements, this tag also pre-fills the answer form with the above required form.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### Image requirements&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; - The image that you create must be **300 x 250 pixels**, or double that if high DPI.&#xD;&#xA; - Must be hosted through our standard image uploader (imgur)&#xD;&#xA; - Must be GIF or PNG&#xD;&#xA; - No animated GIFs&#xD;&#xA; - Absolute limit on file size of **150 KB**&#xD;&#xA; - **If the background of the image is white or partially white, there must be a 1px border (2px if high DPI) surrounding it.**&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### Score Threshold&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;There is a **minimum score threshold** an answer must meet (currently **6**) before it will be shown on the main site.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;You can check out the ads that have met the threshold with basic click stats [here][1].&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/ads/display/2925" />
./PostHistory.xml:5095:  <row Id="7501" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2942" RevisionGUID="d86bd435-7a94-4c86-8b61-087c36a0318b" CreationDate="2017-03-20T10:29:37.593" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://meta.stackexchange.com/ with https://meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="&gt; What is the policy of StackExchange on spam posts?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;They should be flagged as spam, as described in https://meta.stackexchange.com/q/58032 A post that gets 6 spam flags from ordinary users, or 1 spam flag from a moderator, is deleted, locked, &quot;censored&quot; (hidden even from 10K users, unless they look at revision history), and most importantly, the author is blocked from posting again. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;It's important to keep in mind the Stack Exchange definition of spam: an advertisement/promotion of some sort, as elaborated in the linked post. A &quot;low quality non-research question&quot; is not spam.  &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; How should we deal with users that intentionally post many off-topic posts? &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Close _and_ downvote their posts. They will be either blocked or at least slowed down by the system: https://meta.stackexchange.com/q/243460&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:5102:  <row Id="7508" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="653" RevisionGUID="4f1348f0-6614-4481-8eea-b1c48590f999" CreationDate="2017-04-12T07:31:26.050" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://programmers.stackexchange.com/ with https://softwareengineering.stackexchange.com/" Text="I recently opened an account over at https://softwareengineering.stackexchange.com/. I associated my account there with my account here. I then opened CStheory again, and I got a red banner saying &quot;You've associated your Theoretical Computer Science and Theoretical Computer Science accounts: +100 reputation&quot;. I made a printscreen in case it turns out to be useful.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;This is obviously a bug. I'm almost sure this 100 rep was intended to be awarded to the account I just created. My account on this site gained 100 rep (I went from 358 to 458).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;**Edit**: I tried reassociating all my accounts as per Tsuyoshi Ito's answer, which gave the missing 100 rep to my Programming account. ./PostHistory.xml:5103:  <row Id="7509" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1581" RevisionGUID="fc6b9303-2767-4080-bf3c-9f9f6b92b8f7" CreationDate="2017-04-12T07:31:26.050" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://programmers.stackexchange.com/ with https://softwareengineering.stackexchange.com/" Text="*Disclaimer: I am a moderator on [Computer Science Stack Exchange](http://cs.stackexchange.com/). While I try to judge this proposal on its own merit, it is likely that the time and energy I have invested in CS.SE influences me.*&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I'm afraid that broadening the scope in this way would destroy the existing community. A Stack Exchange site is defined by two things: the kind of questions it accepts, and the audience it attracts. Even though each question is in principle judged on its intrinsic merits, the long-term effect is to create a community.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;On this site, the community is centered around researchers in theoretical computer science. Participants tend to be researchers in TCS, researchers in other fields, or graduate students aspiring to become researchers. The participants who are welcomed are generally those who came with the expectation of participating in a community dominated by TCS researchers.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I do not see a problem with allowing more applied questions. As long as academics and people who want to fit in with academics dominate the site, that isn't a problem. It may be difficult to bootstrap an applied CS community (it would have been a lot easier to do when the site was young), but if it works, it won't change the tone of the site, and if it fails, the site won't have changed.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;On the other hand, opening the door to more basic questions means opening the door to a broader audience. This should be a carefully controlled process. In particular, I advise you not to try to draw on Stack Overflow as an audience base. A majority of Stack Overflow does not know or care what it means to be a scientist. The kind of people you would attract are those who now post on [Programmers](https://softwareengineering.stackexchange.com/). If you attract those people, be prepared to moderate their content. And to moderate them.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Reacting to specific points in your proposal:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; We now have a natural forum (cs.stackexchange.com) for the more &quot;basic&quot; algorithms questions, and the cstheory &quot;brand&quot; is well established as a 'research-only' venue. So we have an easy process to shunt questions that are obviously undergrad level.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Keep in mind that CS.SE is not exclusively for basic questions. It is for questions at all level, ranging all the way from CS 101 homework to applied research (and even research in theory, but we suggest CSTheory.SE to the rare asker who comes with a theory question that seems to go unanswered because it is too hard).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; excluding questions from people who might be 'research-level' in a sub area but aren't experts in some other domain&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;From what I see (I admit to not following CSTheory.SE very closely), this already happens: as long as there's a feeling that peers are talking with peers, questions tend to be appreciated, left open and answered.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; creating the impression of an unfriendly site (which is a bigger problem in terms of maintaining the audience)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I think the community is doing an adequate job of retaining the audience it likes in and keeping the undesirables in.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;All in all, while the current guidelines may be stricter than this, I think an intelligent application of the existing policies already gives you what you want.&#xD;&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:5104:  <row Id="7510" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1592" RevisionGUID="34308859-c5d3-4ee6-82ce-3aa7a357ed39" CreationDate="2017-04-12T07:31:26.050" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://programmers.stackexchange.com/ with https://softwareengineering.stackexchange.com/" Text="I've posted my first question:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/12585/to-what-extent-can-an-algorithm-predict-the-time-complexity-an-arbitrary-input-p#12585&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Which admittedly is not a graduate-level question, and thus not covered under the scope of this site. ./PostHistory.xml:5107:  <row Id="7513" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="435" RevisionGUID="c07a663a-1ceb-43b1-92aa-17e60c057a19" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:14:53.897" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://serverfault.com/ with https://serverfault.com/" Text="It appears that all our handwringing over domain names might be moot. webapps.stackexchange.com was the first SE site to exit beta, and had chosen the domain nothingtoinstall.com (which I thought was clever). 3 days into graduation, and the SE overlords suddenly decided that this was such a horrible name that they are retracting their promise to give out separate domain names, and the new URL forwards back to webapps.stackexchange.com&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;There's a fairly bitter discussion going on in the [NTI meta section][1], along with a [parallel discussion on meta.SO][2]. ./PostHistory.xml:5108:  <row Id="7514" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="131" RevisionGUID="08cc48e4-2d75-494d-9ab9-1633b6382155" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:19:18.947" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://math.stackexchange.com/ with https://math.stackexchange.com/" Text="I believe that These arXiv tags should not be used at all.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;My biggest concern is that these tags are not friendly to people who don't know arXiv (I'm one of these people). I have an interest in many computer science topics, but I rarely read computer science publications, have never browsed arVix, and really don't want to learn how to use such a system that I'll never use off of this site.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;However, I routinely read other publications of papers by the IEEE (in fact, I have the most recent issue of IEEE Transactions on Software Engineering next to me right now). Papers in this publication have &quot;index terms&quot; - keywords that describe what the paper is about. I grabbed a copy of the ACM Transactions on Software Engineering and Methodology out of my shelf, and they have three sections: categories and subject descriptions (which contain a code as well as textual descriptions), general terms, and additional key words/phrases. Whenever I've searched for papers in an online database, my matches have always come from the keywords sections or the body of the paper.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Looking at these tags, they are unwieldy. I have no idea what the tag means, and I wouldn't expect that most undergraduate computer scientists and software engineers would either. Given the responses to [my previous question here on Meta][1], you want to be inclusive of multiple skill levels. If I find it difficult to search and browse through questions based on tags (which are also used in the site search engine), I'll be less likely to use this site.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Instead of following MathOverflow, I believe that this exchange should follow a path closer to that of [Mathematics][2]. There are [three][3] [relevant][4] [discussions][5] on their Meta that I could find. The Mathematics community appears to be doing quite well in terms of having people of various skill levels (appears to range from undergraduate university-level mathematics on up), their tagging appears to be working quite well, and I honestly find it easier to read and search than MathOverflow.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;But really, if this Stack Exchange follows MathOverflow, I actually see someone else coming along and making another Computer Science exchange geared toward a broader audience, in terms of skill levels. I think that this exchange can avoid this splintering of the community (avoiding another Unix/Linux versus Ubuntu Stack Exchange problem) by catering to as many people of various skill levels and educational backgrounds as possible. Yes, you need a specific focus on certain topics and clearly define what is and is not on-topic, but you want to segregate based on those topics, not by knowledge or experience. By dumping the arVix style tags, you make it easy for everyone to find questions/answers, but also make the site friendlier to less knowledgeable and experienced people such as myself.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;However, that's not to say that arVix isn't useful. I believe Stack Exchanges have the &quot;tag wiki&quot; page that Stack Overflow has. It would be benefitial to identify which tags correspond to arVix topic areas and link to those topic areas in the tag wiki for a given tag.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Also, a technical consideration: The [tags are specified using rel=&quot;tag&quot;][8] in the source of a page. If you aren't familiar with microformats, search engines actually do pick up on them and they do help people find pages. People who do searches search for things like &quot;data structure&quot; and &quot;data structures&quot;, not &quot;cs.DS.data-structures&quot;. The tags should reflect what people are searching on Google and Bing so that they are brought to questions on Stack Exchanges that are relevant to their searches.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;----------&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I also want to address a few comments and other postings.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Another point that I've read in [some postings and comments here][6] is that you want to maintain compatibility with MathOverflow. I think this is a mistake. MathOverflow is a Stack Exchange 1.0 site and, last I heard, had no intention of migrating to Stack Exchange 2.0. However, there are a number of Stack Exchange 2.0 sites that might be of interest to this community in some way that are at various levels of existance - Stack Overflow (people might ask algorithm or data structure implementation questions here), Mathematics (which includes discrete mathematics, graph theory, combinatorics...), Statistical Analysis (which includes machine learning), Not Programming Related, Compiler Design, Software Engineering, Artificial Intelligence, Application Security, Machine Learning, Numerical Modeling and Simulation, Signal Processing, Operating systems Development, Natural Language Processing and Computational Linguistics, and Cryptography (and those are just the first 10 pages of proposals, sorted by progress). These are the communities that need to work together to decide what best belongs where, especially since it appears that there will be a feature to move questions between various Stack Exchange 2.0 sites. Unless things change on MathOverflow, you will never be able to migrate a question from here to MO. However, in the future, it will be possible to migrate questions to the exchanges I mentioned, and so far, none of them are using ArVix tagging.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;As [first mentioned in a comment here][7], some of the ArVix tags are long. Potentially too long to fit in the limit of a tag. The purpose of tags is to help people search and sort through questions. If you start abbreviating ArVix tags, you open up a whole new can of worms with the best way to abbreviate the tags.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/115&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: https://math.stackexchange.com/&#xD;&#xA;  [3]: https://math.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/48/should-mathoverflow-tag-prefixes-be-used&#xD;&#xA;  [4]: https://math.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/186/setting-things-straight-what-style-of-tags-are-we-going-to-be-using-when-we-laun&#xD;&#xA;  [5]: https://math.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/59/mathoverflow-tags-others&#xD;&#xA;  [6]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/41/arxiv-tags-vs-not/74#74&#xD;&#xA;  [7]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/41/arxiv-tags-vs-not/42#42&#xD;&#xA;  [8]: http://microformats.org/wiki/rel-tag" />
./PostHistory.xml:5109:  <row Id="7515" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="235" RevisionGUID="49d82a7e-5545-4069-81a4-8087c5ab2fc5" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:19:18.947" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://math.stackexchange.com/ with https://math.stackexchange.com/" Text="What kind of questions are too basic?&#xD;&#xA;-------------------------------------&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Our aim is to ask and answer **research-level** questions in theoretical computer science.  &quot;Research-level&quot; means, roughly, questions that might be discussed between two professors, or between graduate students working on Ph.D.'s, but not usually between a professor and the typical undergraduate student. *It does not include questions at the level of difficulty of undergraduate homework*. Here are some examples of questions that are off-topic because they are not research-level or because they are too easy:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; - Questions that can be easily answered by reading a Wikipedia article on the topic.&#xD;&#xA; - Questions that can be easily solved by Googling.&#xD;&#xA; - Questions that are solved by browsing [one of these web sites](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/229#229).&#xD;&#xA; - Typical homework problems in textbooks.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;If you do not think that your question is research-level but you cannot find an answer in above options, you may want to try https://math.stackexchange.com/.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;---&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Related discussion:&#xD;&#xA;[[1]](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/17/scope-of-questions)&#xD;&#xA;[[2]](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/115/what-level-and-types-of-questions-are-appropriate-for-theoretical-computer-scienc)&#xD;&#xA;[[3]](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/209/homework-or-things-that-look-like-homework)" />
./PostHistory.xml:5110:  <row Id="7516" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="626" RevisionGUID="892a1c6d-01b5-4759-adde-0f36bd842c95" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:19:18.947" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://math.stackexchange.com/ with https://math.stackexchange.com/" Text="Judging from the blog posts “[When will my site graduate?](http://blog.stackoverflow.com/2010/10/when-will-my-site-graduate/)” by Robert Cartaino and “[Pruning season](http://blog.stackoverflow.com/2010/09/pruning-season/)” by Joel Spolsky, it is highly unlikely that the website is shut down in a week.  See also other websites on Area 51 which have been in public beta for more than 90 days.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;At the same time, it is unlikely that we graduate the beta in a week because the strategy seems that the websites in all-green graduate first.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;My guess is that the number “90 days” has little real effect.  We should continue to be a good community, and I guess that we will graduate the beta eventually.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;_Added_: By the way, “graduating beta” does not only mean that we have our own site design and that we have probably less chance to get shut down.  Actually, from the system point of view, the most relevant effect of graduating beta is that the [thresholds for some privileged actions are raised](https://math.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/984/promotion-implies-higher-rep-needed-for-privileges-and-nobody-has-such) from the beta level to the [normal level](https://math.stackexchange.com/privileges).  This means that it is probably not good to go out of beta if we do not have many users with high reputation points.&#xD;&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:5111:  <row Id="7517" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="632" RevisionGUID="ebe96792-4548-4730-a23f-13284d2efb3a" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:19:18.947" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://math.stackexchange.com/ with https://math.stackexchange.com/" Text="##[Math.SE](https://math.stackexchange.com/)&#xD;&#xA;Non-research level theoretical computer science/math questions, check their [FAQ](https://math.stackexchange.com/faq).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:5112:  <row Id="7518" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="814" RevisionGUID="e1576a47-bce5-4eab-8703-3a57cebec25d" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:19:18.947" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://math.stackexchange.com/ with https://math.stackexchange.com/" Text="I realized that [math.stackexchange.com](https://math.stackexchange.com/captcha) uses a [cartoon from xkcd](http://xkcd.com/329/). ./PostHistory.xml:5113:  <row Id="7519" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="927" RevisionGUID="f96ffc1c-5061-417f-ac2b-06e3304d6d62" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:19:18.947" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://math.stackexchange.com/ with https://math.stackexchange.com/" Text="To put things forward, I suggest a concrete text.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The current text:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; Theoretical Computer Science - Stack Exchange is for theoretical computer scientists and researchers in related fields.&#xD;&#xA;&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; A rough outline (inclusive, but not exclusive) of topics that are &quot;within scope&quot; for this site is as follows:&#xD;&#xA;&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; &gt; The field of theoretical computer science is interpreted broadly so as to include algorithms, data structures, computational complexity theory, distributed computation, parallel computation, VLSI, machine learning, computational biology, computational geometry, information theory, cryptography, quantum computation, computational number theory and algebra, program semantics and verification, automata theory, and the study of randomness.  **Work in this field is often distinguished by its emphasis on mathematical technique and rigor.**&#xD;&#xA;&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; General FAQs about using the Stack Exchange system are given below.  For specific questions more pertinent to this particular site, please visit the **[Official Theoretical Computer Science FAQ](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science)**.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Although this is not bad as a starting point, there are several shortcomings.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* As is often pointed out, it only mentions what theoretical computer science is and that it does not mention the expected level of questions.&#xD;&#xA;* Related to the first item, a list of alternative sites to ask questions is desirable.  The scope of our website is often better communicated by such a list.&#xD;&#xA;* The quotation is unclear about where it is quoted from.  In fact, it is originally quoted from the self-description of ACM SIGACT but it seems that SIGACT has modified this description after the text was copied, so it is kind of obsolete.  For example, the current list includes computational economics and omits the reference to VLSI, both of which are understandable.&#xD;&#xA;* I cannot see the point of emphasizing only the last sentence in the quotation from SIGACT.&#xD;&#xA;* The distinction between “general FAQs” and “official theoretical computer science FAQ” is confusing at best and makes no sense at worst.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I suggest to revise the above text to the following.  [https://math.stackexchange.com/faq/](https://math.stackexchange.com/faq/) is written very well, and I stole part of the general structure from it.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; **Theoretical Computer Science - Stack Exchange** is for theoretical computer scientists and researchers in related fields.  We welcome _research-level_ questions in _theoretical computer science_ (TCS).&#xD;&#xA;&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; Although there is no black-and-white distinction between research-level questions and non-research-level questions, questions are considered to be “research-level” roughly when they can be discussed between two professors or between two graduate students working on Ph.D.’s, but not usually between a professor and a typical undergraduate student.&#xD;&#xA;&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; For questions other than research-level questions in TCS, you may want to consider the following places to ask:&#xD;&#xA;&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; * Research-level mathematics — [Math Overflow](http://mathoverflow.net/)&#xD;&#xA;&gt; * Programming — [Stack Overflow](http://stackoverflow.com/)&#xD;&#xA;&gt; * General mathematics — [Mathematics - Stack Exchange](https://math.stackexchange.com/); they seem to accept also questions in TCS.&#xD;&#xA;&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; For an explanation of what TCS is, we refer you to the description of ACM Special Interest Group on Algorithms and Computation Theory (SIGACT):&#xD;&#xA;&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; &gt; TCS covers a wide variety of topics including algorithms, data structures, computational complexity, parallel and distributed computation, probabilistic computation, quantum computation, automata theory, information theory, cryptography, program semantics and verification, machine learning, computational biology, computational economics, computational geometry, and computational number theory and algebra.  Work in this field is often distinguished by its emphasis on mathematical technique and rigor. &#xD;&#xA;&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; Currently we have two separate lists of FAQs.  See also **[Official Theoretical Computer Science FAQ](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science)**.  Some of the most important entries in the other FAQ are:&#xD;&#xA;&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; * [What kind of questions are too basic?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/235#235)&#xD;&#xA;&gt; * [How to ask a good question?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/300/how-to-ask-a-good-question)&#xD;&#xA;&gt; * [How do I write formulas?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/237#237)&#xD;&#xA;&gt; * [My (wonderful!) question was closed!  What do I do now?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/361#361)&#xD;&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:5114:  <row Id="7520" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1027" RevisionGUID="1c7632ba-a456-4a94-bd4d-2f68d5614b45" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:19:18.947" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://math.stackexchange.com/ with https://math.stackexchange.com/" Text="I think this question should be closed for two different reasons:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I. This is against the policy about not allowing questions about unpublished not-peer-reviewed approaches to open problems and crank-friendly topics. The OP states that this is equivalent to &quot;$\mathbf{P}$ vs. $\mathbf{NP}$&quot;, and therefore it falls under that policy and should be closed as **off-topic**. The cosmetics like the way of phrasing the question are irrelevant. In fact some users on Math.SE have advised the OP to phrase the question in that way to get around our policy, see [here][1]:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; If you cross-post this question to CSTheory, it may not be well-received. If you re-phrase your question to something like &quot;Are there known barriers to this approach to P \neq NP?&quot;, this might be better.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;II. The post is also not a real question, refer to the comments by OP under the Math.SE post:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; &quot;I am no researcher and therefore I am only privately interested in this question&quot;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt;&quot;With my above question, I wanted only to share my main idea for attacking this problem. Perhaps some experienced mathematician like you is able to use my idea in some way.&quot;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The OP who states that she/he is not a expert wants to *share* his idea about how to solve the open problem with experts, this is clearly **not-a-real-question**.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://math.stackexchange.com/questions/23850/are-there-any-known-barriers-to-some-approach-for-solving-p-vs-np" />
./PostHistory.xml:5115:  <row Id="7521" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1086" RevisionGUID="0bb0c7f6-0e6c-4f7b-aa0e-35fa628f7a05" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:19:18.947" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://math.stackexchange.com/ with https://math.stackexchange.com/" Text="I ask moderators to be very careful when migrating questions to Stack Exchange websites.  When in doubt, please close questions as off topic, possibly with a comment suggesting one or a few candidates of websites, and let the asker decide where to ask.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Note that [we have been frustrated](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/919/migration-problems-both-sides-should-be-involved-in-making-migration-decisions) by the fact that some questions are migrated _to_ cstheory when they should not be.  We should not do the same thing to other websites.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Here is a recent example: [Is there a program / app / algorithm that can sort items using manual choices and deductive logic?](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/5615/is-there-a-program-app-algorithm-that-can-sort-items-using-manual-choices-and?noredirect=1)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;This question was recently migrated to Stack Overflow, but I cannot see any programming aspect in the question, and I think that it was wrong to migrate it to Stack Overflow.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;In fact, this is a question on query complexity.  Since it is too basic (the Ω(&lt;i&gt;n&lt;/i&gt; log &lt;i&gt;n&lt;/i&gt;) lower bound is well-known and sometimes even covered in undergraduate courses) and the asker had posted the same question on [math](https://math.stackexchange.com/questions/28752/is-there-a-program-or-app-that-will-let-you-sort-items-using-manual-choices-and-d) (thanks to Yuval Filmus for the link), I think that it should have been closed as off topic." />
./PostHistory.xml:5116:  <row Id="7522" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1088" RevisionGUID="4a68c295-131a-48b0-aabc-362049fafae6" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:19:18.947" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://math.stackexchange.com/ with https://math.stackexchange.com/" Text="I personally think it is reasonable to include [Math.SE](https://math.stackexchange.com/) in the list. We direct users to Math.SE more often than we direct them to SO, therefore it seems as a more natural option (assuming that people on Math.SE don't have objections and we should check that).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I also think it will decrease the amount of moderator intervention in these cases and will help us keep the site research level." />
./PostHistory.xml:5117:  <row Id="7523" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1228" RevisionGUID="9630b662-10b9-497e-b309-fee3f83ffd00" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:19:18.947" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://math.stackexchange.com/ with https://math.stackexchange.com/" Text="### change log&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;----&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Jul. 27, 2012:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- Added [academia.se] to the list of suggested sites&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;----&#xD;&#xA;Mar. 20, 2012:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- Added [cs.se] to the list of suggested sites&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;----&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Feb. 23, 2012:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Another small update to the FAQ. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Change log:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; * Added [crypto.se] and [scicomp.se] to the list of suggested sites,&#xD;&#xA; * Made the tips for writing a better question a section.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;----&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Nov. 17, 2011:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I have edited the official FAQ a little bit (mainly adding links to some entries of the official FAQ that we refer to in comments). Please comemnt if you don't like the edits or have other suggestions on how to improve the general FAQ:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;----&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;[FAQ](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/faq)&#xD;&#xA;----&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;**Theoretical Computer Science - Stack Exchange** is for theoretical computer scientists and researchers in related fields.  We welcome _research-level_ questions in _theoretical computer science_ (TCS).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Although there is no black-and-white distinction between research-level questions and non-research-level questions, questions are considered to be &quot;research-level&quot; roughly when they can be discussed between two professors or between two graduate students working on Ph.D.'s, but not usually between a professor and a typical undergraduate student. It does not include questions at the level of difficulty of typical undergraduate course/textbook homework/exercise.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;For an explanation of what TCS is, we refer you to the description of ACM Special Interest Group on Algorithms and Computation Theory (SIGACT):&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; &gt; TCS covers a wide variety of topics including algorithms, data structures, computational complexity, parallel and distributed computation, probabilistic computation, quantum computation, automata theory, information theory, cryptography, program semantics and verification, machine learning, computational biology, computational economics, computational geometry, and computational number theory and algebra.  **Work in this field is often distinguished by its emphasis on mathematical technique and rigor.** &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;##My question is not a research-level question in TCS, where can I ask it?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;For questions other than research-level questions in TCS, you may want to consider the following places to ask:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; * General Computer Science — [Computer Science - Stack Exchange](http://cs.stackexchange.com/)&#xD;&#xA; * General Mathematics (including *theoretical* CS) — [Mathematics - Stack Exchange](https://math.stackexchange.com/)&#xD;&#xA; * Research-level Mathematics — [Math Overflow](http://mathoverflow.net/)&#xD;&#xA; * Social and Professional Academic Issues — [Academia - Stack Exchange](http://academia.stackexchange.com/)&#xD;&#xA; * Programming — [Stack Overflow](http://stackoverflow.com/)&#xD;&#xA; * General Artificial Intelligence — [Meta Optimize](http://metaoptimize.com/qa/)&#xD;&#xA; * Statistics and Data Mining — [Cross Validated](http://stats.stackexchange.com/)&#xD;&#xA; * Applied Cryptography and Security — [Crypto - Stack Exchange](http://crypto.stackexchange.com/)&#xD;&#xA; * Computation used in Science and Engineering — [Computational Science - Stack Exchange](http://scicomp.stackexchange.com/)&#xD;&#xA; * Questions about this site — [Theoretical Computer Science - Stack Exchange - Meta][1]&#xD;&#xA; * Other — check the list of sites on [Stack Exchange Network](http://stackexchange.com/sites)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;##Questions should be based on knowledge sharing, not on shirking&#xD;&#xA;You should only post questions you're actually seriously thinking about. Users are expected to do their part and try to answer their question by themselves before posting them on cstheory and asking for help from others. Search to see if your question is already answered somewhere else (e.g. Wikipedia) before asking a question. **Try to make your question interesting for others by providing some background knowledge**. Remember, *questions should be based on knowledge sharing, not on shirking. Shirking goes against the spirit of the site.* &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;##Tips about writing better questions&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* [How to Ask?](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/how-to-ask)&#xD;&#xA;* [How to ask a good question?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/300/how-to-ask-a-good-question)&#xD;&#xA;* [How to write a good MathOverflow question?](http://mathoverflow.net/howtoask)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Please also check our list of [**useful resources**](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/229#229) *before* asking a question.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;##FAQ&#xD;&#xA;Currently we have two separate lists of FAQs.  See also the longer **[Official Theoretical Computer Science FAQ](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science)**.  Some of the most important entries in the other FAQ are:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; * [How do I write **formulas**?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/237#237)&#xD;&#xA; * [What kind of questions are **too basic**?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/235#235)&#xD;&#xA; * [My (wonderful!) **question got closed**!  What do I do now?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/361#361)&#xD;&#xA; * [What is the **policy on crossposting** to/from MathOverflow?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/231#231)&#xD;&#xA; * [Can I ask about this **cool paper** that I just saw **on the arxiv**?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/274/is-it-ok-to-ask-about-the-correctness-of-preprints-on-crank-friendly-topics/281#281)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" />
./PostHistory.xml:5118:  <row Id="7524" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1266" RevisionGUID="2705368e-fc2e-427b-abf4-f862a3711205" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:19:18.947" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://math.stackexchange.com/ with https://math.stackexchange.com/" Text="&lt;a href=&quot;https://math.stackexchange.com/questions/57957/designer-looking-for-help-with-an-algorithm-to-calculate-layout-of-rectangles-bas&quot;&gt;This question&lt;/a&gt; was posted on math.stackexchange.com and I've become curious.  I unfortunately posted an answer that I'm disappointed with. I'd like to research the information using this site and the web and eventually post an answer that's not so research level on the other site, math.stackexchange.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I'm wondering what I should do here - I really feel I've made a mistake already." />
./PostHistory.xml:5119:  <row Id="7525" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1323" RevisionGUID="f8f678c5-a341-4be7-8217-3a80495971eb" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:19:18.947" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://math.stackexchange.com/ with https://math.stackexchange.com/" Text="&#xD;&#xA;Several months back, I asked in math.SE [the following question][1]&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; I wonder if any dynamic programming problem can always be converted to&#xD;&#xA;&gt; a source-sink shortest path problem in a network with source and sink&#xD;&#xA;&gt; nodes given? &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The reason I asked is because I always pictured the type of problems that could be solved by DP as source-sink shortest path problems. In other words, the type of problems seemed to always have the interpretation as source-sink shortest path problems, but I was not sure if it was correct.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The only answer I have got so far is&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; The answer is no. The simplest example off the top of my head is the&#xD;&#xA;&gt; longest substring of ones in a 0,1 string. The typical DP solution&#xD;&#xA;&gt; would be to use a 1D array and store the length of the longest&#xD;&#xA;&gt; substring up that includes the i-th character in the i-th coordinate. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;When I further asked:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; why is the example not able to be formulated into a source-sink&#xD;&#xA;&gt; shortest path problem in a network?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The reply is:&#xD;&#xA;&gt; I don't really see an easy way of doing it as a source-sink SPP. For&#xD;&#xA;&gt; the DP solution, the answer is obtained by scanning the array for the&#xD;&#xA;&gt; largest number.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I am now still not sure how DP solves the longest substring of ones in a 0,1 string, and whether this problem can be interpreted as a source-sink shortest path problem. Also I feel the answerer may run out of idea from his reply. Since my question may also be relevant to algorithm theory, I am not sure if I can post my question on this site?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Thanks and regards!&#xD;&#xA; &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://math.stackexchange.com/questions/36747/dynamic-programming-problem-and-shortest-path-problem" />
./PostHistory.xml:5120:  <row Id="7526" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1404" RevisionGUID="a8f3021b-1ae5-4d71-8934-3cdb9ed2c1e5" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:19:18.947" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://math.stackexchange.com/ with https://math.stackexchange.com/" Text="Zirui, cstheory is a Q&amp;A site with a scope defined in its FAQ. The scope of cstheory is research-level. Questions that are at the level of difficulty of typical undergraduate students are not part of the scope. There are other Q&amp;A sites which have a more general scope like [Math.SE][1] that would welcome questions from students.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Votes (down and up) are one of the main ways users express their opinion about the quality of a question and how interesting it is. A user may down vote a question if she/he thinks the question is off-topic or has other problems (e.g. unclear, not answerable in its current form, argumentative, not a real question, post to solicit opinion, ...).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;----&#xD;&#xA;If you want to know why [your question](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/8826/is-halting-that-hard-yes) is down voted you can ask for that in place of attacking other users. I will explain my down vote in more detail below:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;It seems to me that you are trying to find a way to get around the undecidability of halting problem. The halting problem (as it is defined in the literature) is undecidable and that is a mathematical theorem. Now one might be interested in decidable variations of halting problem. That is a well studied topic, and one can ask a research level question about that. There are also researchers working on these kind of problems who try to find ways to deal with undecidability in practice (mainly in formal methods community, but also in theoretical computer science). &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;On the other hand your question has no sign that you are familiar with the literature. I can tell that this is something a typical undergraduate student taking their first course in computability would ask. It is nice that a student would think about this kind of problems. But everything has a place and the place of this question is not cstheory. If you ask it on Math.SE you probably will not get any down votes. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;As an analogy, it is completely fine and even encouraged that students ask questions like this in an undergraduate computability class from the instructor. Asking it in a research-level computability workshop will probably be unwelcome.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;If you ask a question about halting problem and show that you are familiar with the literature and understand the basics in the area, and the question is a real question (posting a question to see how others think about your idea about how to solve halting problem is not a real question) and is clearly stated (can be answered without much back-and-forth comments where others try to guess what you want to ask, which can be a sign that the question is not well-thought), then that can be on-topic and I would guess would not receive any down votes.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;ps:&#xD;&#xA;I would suggest that you take a look at the [this section of the FAQ](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/faq#questions-should-be-based-on-knowledge-sharing-not-on-shirking) and also the pages linked there. Following those suggestions would increase the chance that your questions are well perceived by the community.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://math.stackexchange.com/&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/faq" />
./PostHistory.xml:5121:  <row Id="7527" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1478" RevisionGUID="c2d25436-e01d-4d12-b851-d745e0e43b30" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:19:18.947" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://math.stackexchange.com/ with https://math.stackexchange.com/" Text="Chat can be a place to provide hints, but not answers. Just because a question is not research-level doesn't mean that it doesn't deserve a proper answer. It's just that this particular site is not the proper site for it.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Questions that are too elementary for this site, and mathematical in nature, can be migrated to [Mathematics Stack Exchange](https://math.stackexchange.com/). Questions that are too elementary or too applied for this site, and that are sufficiently close to development, can be migrated to [Stack Overflow](http://stackoverflow.com/), but that's hit-and-miss, as part of the SO the community is keen to close questions that don't contain actual code, even though “software algorithm” questions are explicitly allowed by its [FAQ](http://stackoverflow.com/faq).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;There is, at long last, a [computer science site proposal](http://area51.stackexchange.com/proposals/35636/computer-science-non-programming?referrer=4M74nqLafvszXN85c5ibxQ2) on [Area 51](http://area51.stackexchange.com/), the staging zone for new Stack Exchange sites. Please point out that proposal to askers who might be interested in it.&#xD;&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:5122:  <row Id="7528" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1527" RevisionGUID="ac08d4a1-6f3f-40fc-bc7c-67fa660654ac" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:19:18.947" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://math.stackexchange.com/ with https://math.stackexchange.com/" Text="I'm asking &lt;a href=&quot;https://math.stackexchange.com/questions/150446/&quot;&gt;this question&lt;/a&gt; about the history of computation. ./PostHistory.xml:5123:  <row Id="7529" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1629" RevisionGUID="ad8a7f3e-7ad1-42fe-88db-e8d83fd19914" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:19:18.947" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://math.stackexchange.com/ with https://math.stackexchange.com/" Text="I did notice it. The question has given a huge spike in the number of visits to csthoery for one day.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I believe the explanation is simple: someone shared [a link to the question](http://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=4961357) on a popular site ([Hacker News](http://news.ycombinator.com/) in this case) which caused a huge temporary spike in the number of visitors. It seems that the question is interesting for general CS audience who may not be researchers in TCS. We have had a number of [famous questions](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/badges/37/famous-question) with relatively huge number of viewers, this one is not that different.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I don't think it is that useful regarding marketing the site to our target community though. However it is a nice example of a question that can be used for outreach to people outside theory. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Note that regular users from other SE sites get enough reputation to vote on the question, so the total number of votes does not necessarily reflect the quality of the question relative to other questions according to regular cstheory users. (This is one of the issues that I think MO negotiated with SE when they decided to migrate to SE2.0 to make sure it won't happen on MO after it migrates to SE2.0).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;This happens also on other SE sites like Math.SE, e.g. [the batman equation question][1]. It will happen from time to time, I don't think it is not a big deal as long as it is not causing a problem. If we see that the question starts to cause problem we can make it protected or even lock it (as is common practice on other SE sites).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://math.stackexchange.com/questions/54506/is-this-batman-equation-for-real" />
./PostHistory.xml:5124:  <row Id="7530" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2661" RevisionGUID="5f113f5d-5d6d-4cbf-bbdb-c6d3d352b055" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:19:18.947" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://math.stackexchange.com/ with https://math.stackexchange.com/" Text="##My question is not a research-level question in TCS, where can I ask it?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;For questions other than research-level questions in TCS, you may want to consider the following places to ask:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; * General Computer Science — [Computer Science - Stack Exchange][1]&#xD;&#xA; * General Mathematics (including *theoretical* CS) — [Mathematics - Stack Exchange][2]&#xD;&#xA; * Research-level Mathematics — [Math Overflow][3]&#xD;&#xA; * Social and Professional Academic Issues — [Academia - Stack Exchange][4]&#xD;&#xA; * Programming — [Stack Overflow][5]&#xD;&#xA; * General Artificial Intelligence — [Meta Optimize][6]&#xD;&#xA; * Statistics and Data Mining — [Cross Validated][7]&#xD;&#xA; * Applied Cryptography and Security — [Crypto - Stack Exchange][8]&#xD;&#xA; * Computation used in Science and Engineering — [Computational Science - Stack Exchange][9]&#xD;&#xA; * Questions about this site — [Theoretical Computer Science - Stack Exchange - Meta][10]&#xD;&#xA; * Other — check the list of sites on [Stack Exchange Network][11]&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://cs.stackexchange.com/&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: https://math.stackexchange.com/&#xD;&#xA;  [3]: http://mathoverflow.net/&#xD;&#xA;  [4]: http://academia.stackexchange.com/&#xD;&#xA;  [5]: http://stackoverflow.com/&#xD;&#xA;  [6]: http://metaoptimize.com/qa/&#xD;&#xA;  [7]: http://stats.stackexchange.com/&#xD;&#xA;  [8]: http://crypto.stackexchange.com/&#xD;&#xA;  [9]: http://scicomp.stackexchange.com/&#xD;&#xA;  [10]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/&#xD;&#xA;  [11]: http://stackexchange.com/sites" />
./PostHistory.xml:5125:  <row Id="7531" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2908" RevisionGUID="46a2b3be-89db-43e3-a133-78f7aac0f7a8" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:19:18.947" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://math.stackexchange.com/ with https://math.stackexchange.com/" Text="Consider the following question: http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/32245/example-of-r-and-g-when-r-subseteq-lg-is-undecidable&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Is this question on-topic for cstheory? On one hand, it has been already [answered on MSE][1] and I was able to find an answer by googling &quot;deciding if a regular language is a subset of a context-free language&quot;, while having a typical CS familiarity with the area (i.e. I am not an expert). On the other hand, asking for a specific example as well as a question that I think is not 100% straightforward to answer, so it could be useful as a reference-request question.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I noticed there are some similar questions in the meta, but nothing that IMHO is a suitable fit, especially this [one](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/65/repeat-a-question-from-math-overflow). Any thoughts?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://math.stackexchange.com/q/70349" />

As the name says, this user script prevents pressing the Enter key from submitting a comment.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Because I use an [input method editor](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Input_method) to enter symbols such as quotation marks and mathematical symbols, I find it very difficult to write comments without this user script.  I do not think that this applies to many people, but if you are experiencing the same problem, the user script will save you a lot of time." />

./PostHistory.xml:5130:  <row Id="7536" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1201" RevisionGUID="38d041a1-bd9b-4acf-9d76-db0f82bb42b1" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:25:39.260" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://stackapps.com/ with https://stackapps.com/" Text="I just noticed some nice user options on MO and I think it would be nice to have them on cstheory also:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;1. Hide questions with ignored tags, (Update: already supported, check the checkbox on perfs page of your profile)&#xD;&#xA;2. Show symbols !, ⋅, ∘, ⊡, ⊟, ⊞ for reputations above 0, 15, 100, 2000, 3000, 10000, respectively, (Update: see below)&#xD;&#xA;3. Do not show user reputations, (Update: see below)&#xD;&#xA;4. Hide vote counts, (Update: see below)&#xD;&#xA;5. Apply ignored-tag styles to closed questions.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I particularly like the idea of using symbols in place of numbers for user reputation.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;A similar idea is to use colors in place of numbers for total vote counts and only show exact vote counts if the user clicks on the color. This can reduce the idea that users are sorting the answers but rather are voting based on the sole quality of them and increase voting on answers/questions.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;###Update:&#xD;&#xA;I modified [this user script](https://stackapps.com/questions/2342/hexadecimal-user-rep) to get 2, 3, and 4. You can find the scripts on the same page." />

./PostHistory.xml:5132:  <row Id="7538" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1521" RevisionGUID="a52daa88-d031-4045-9059-90a20cc079ef" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:25:39.260" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://stackapps.com/ with https://stackapps.com/" Text="I've written a script that lets you insert dollar symbols automatically(via a keyboard shortcut or button) in the editor window on Stack Exchange sites that support MathJax. You guys also get a special `NP` button(&lt;kbd&gt;Alt&lt;/kbd&gt;-&lt;kbd&gt;S&lt;/kbd&gt;, S for sansserif) that encloses the selection in `$\mathsf{...}$`.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Also, note that &lt;kbd&gt;Alt&lt;/kbd&gt;-&lt;kbd&gt;Z&lt;/kbd&gt; lets you exit math mode--this lets you type math smoothly. For example, you can use &lt;kbd&gt;Alt&lt;/kbd&gt;-&lt;kbd&gt;S&lt;/kbd&gt;, type PSPACE, and  then use &lt;kbd&gt;Alt&lt;/kbd&gt;-&lt;kbd&gt;Z&lt;/kbd&gt; to bring the cursor out of math mode, where you can continue typing. (It's been a big help to me on chem.SE, with the `\ce{...}` button--I can type chemical formulae within the flow of the code).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Also, you have &lt;kbd&gt;Alt&lt;/kbd&gt;-&lt;kbd&gt;O&lt;/kbd&gt; for Big O notation, but I doubt you'll use it.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Feel free to check it out!&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;[Installation instructions and details here][1]&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://stackapps.com/questions/3373/mathjax-buttons" />
