./PostHistory.xml:5141:  <row Id="7549" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="356" RevisionGUID="5d4a84a0-6fa9-4298-a676-709835a72c7d" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.537" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="**Update**: I gave up trying to convince other people to use “too localized” instead of “off topic” when closing too elementary questions.  It seems that most people disagree, and I started to feel that it is a waste of time to try to convince people otherwise.  For now, I still hesitate to vote for off topic (or to be listed as one of the people who closed the question as off topic) when I see too elementary a question, so probably I will not vote to close it.  Hopefully there are enough people to close it anyway.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;---&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;When we vote to close a question, we choose the reason from several choices.  It seems that if a question is too elementary, it is often closed for the reason “off topic.”&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I understand that this choice of reason is based on the consensus about the expected level of questions on cstheory.stackexchange.com.  However, if a question is closed for the reason “off topic,” the following explanation is added to the question:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; closed as off topic by [Someone], [Someone], [Someone], [Someone], [Someone] [Date]&#xD;&#xA;&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; Questions on Theoretical Computer Science are expected to generally relate to Theoretical Computer Science, within the scope defined in the [faq](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/faq).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I have trouble even parsing this sentence because of the tentative name of the website, but more importantly this does not mention the expected level of questions on cstheory.stackexchange.com.  It plainly states that the question is not related to the theoretical computer science, which is often false.  This gives the false impression that we take the theoretical computer science very narrowly.  I think that this is problematic.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;(_Added in revision 5_: The link in the explanation quoted above links to the [built-in FAQ](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/faq), not to the [FAQ on Meta](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science).  The built-in FAQ is not clear about the expected level of questions, either, except that the sentence “Theoretical Computer Science - Stack Exchange is for theoretical computer scientists and researchers in related fields” may suggest that research-level questions are expected.  A clearer statement can be reached by the following chain of links: the explanation of “off topic” → [built-in FAQ](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/faq) → [FAQ on Meta](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science) → [What kind of questions are too basic?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/235#235)  But I doubt that users can find this path unless they are already familiar with the website.)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;What should we do?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Here are a few suggestions:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;1. If the consensus is really that cstheory.stackexchange.com is for questions of at least certain level, the explanation of the reason “off topic” should be rewritten to reflect it.  Is this possible?&#xD;&#xA;2. &lt;del&gt;On [MathOverflow](http://mathoverflow.net/), too elementary questions are often closed for the reason “too localized.”  Obviously this is an abuse and [it certainly confuses some users](https://meta.mathoverflow.net/discussion/274/what-does-too-localized-mean-exactly/), but it is possible to interpret it as “This question is so elementary that it is useful only for the asker,” and it is understandable (or at least less prone to misunderstanding).  How about adopting this convention, at least until the explanation of “off topic” is modified to a better description?&lt;/del&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Related:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- See a [related FAQ entry](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/235#235) and the links given there for discussions about what we mean by “too elementary.”&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;_Added in revision 4:_ Whereas the description of the close reason is not shown on the question page on MathOverflow, it is shown on cstheory.stackexchange.com, which may make abusing harder.  Here is the description of the close reason “too localized”:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; This question would only be relevant to a small geographic area, a specific moment in time, or an extraordinarily narrow situation that is not generally applicable to the worldwide audience of the internet.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The point of the suggestion 2 above is that it is at least possible to argue that too elementary questions fall into the third group (and possibly also the second group) of this description.&#xD;&#xA;" />

./PostHistory.xml:5147:  <row Id="7555" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="17" RevisionGUID="9d916dbf-850e-45f8-94e3-7ec83bbbacfe" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="I was waiting to get some examples of questions that might illustrate a lower bound on the kinds of questions we want to field. Here are some examples: &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; - [What does the theorem of Rice help to prove?][1]&#xD;&#xA; - [Minimum spanning tree algorithm.][2]&#xD;&#xA; - [What are the advantages of a red/black tree?][3]&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;In each case, the question has an answer that can be found almost immediately on Wikipedia, or enough of an answer can be found that the question should be made much more specific. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Should we vote to close such questions, after supplying a comment stating where to look ? ./PostHistory.xml:5153:  <row Id="7562" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="148" RevisionGUID="6fd616b5-5f30-4b90-b785-92a4aae9173e" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="&gt; Do you have general thoughts about the future of the site?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I see a lot of potential here. I'm a software engineer, but I'm dealing with a lot of topics at work that touch on topics here - algorithms and data structures (especially performance), cryptography, stenography, security, as well as concurrent and distributed systems (but these are more from an applied standing rather than the theoretical that is more appropriate here). Even taking a look back at previous jobs, having a Stack Exchange to ask questions and provide answers about computer science topics I've encountered would have been helpful a long time ago.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;If anything is going to be a problem, it's going to be scaring away people who aren't experts in the field. Honestly, I'm not that thrilled with the current state of TCS. It's following MathOverflow too closely and is catering to the experts. What makes Stack Overflow (and even Mathematics and Statistical Analysis) so great is that people of various levels of knowledge and experience are using the exact same site. The problem with MathOverflow (and TCS is going down this road) is that it focuses on the experts and the researchers. TCS does have some college students using it, but many are in a program or that deals exclusively with theoretical CS, and these people appear to be doing OK. However, people like me who have a more practical background, but are interested in the theoretical side of things without a formal education, aren't made to feel as welcome (or at least, that's the impression I get).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I think part of the problem is that there is no hands on leadership. This Stack Exchange was proposed by Anand Kulkarni ([meta profile][1], [site profile][2]). Yet this user has less than 200 reputation, has only posted 3 things (1 question, 2 answers) on the main site, and has only posted 2 answers on the meta. So right from Day 1, the person who came up with this idea hasn't been involved in the site. Stack Exchange doesn't give you the tools you need to lay the framework for a site until it goes into Private Beta, and by then, it's too late for the person who came up with this idea to propose a framework of how the system works in his/her mind, since other people have already started to use the site.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Given the focus on experts/experienced people and lack of hands on leadership (although some people are emerging as leaders, so this might turn around with the addition of moderators), I wouldn't be surprised if this Stack Exchange doesn't make it. And I think that it would be a shame if it didn't.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; Are you pleased with the quality and interest of the questions and answers you've seen on the main site?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I've asked [one question][3], and I'm quite pleased with the answer I got. The way I worded my question, I didn't expect someone to take the time to write up such a detailed answer. But they did, and I'm better off because of it.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; How well do you think we are doing at resolving issues and conflicts that arise?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I think this is a problem with the Stack Exchange system. The fact that there is no place for meta discussions until the site goes into private beta is a bad thing. So right now, we (and I think several Stack Exchanges have had this problem) have lots of people who read the description of the site, but then got there and were disappointed because the description didn't capture what was really happening. Because of this, everyone comes to Meta after there are already questions and answers posted on the site, time is passing, more questions/answers are being posted, and there's no agreed upon method to do things.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I think it will get better once there are more high reputation users and moderators on the main site, but I do think that this is something that the Stack Exchange team needs to address.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/users/71/anand-kulkarni&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/users/71&#xD;&#xA;  [3]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/585/what-is-the-difference-between-a-second-preimage-attack-and-a-collision-attack" />

./PostHistory.xml:5170:  <row Id="7581" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="138" RevisionGUID="2c99be29-a139-4c54-aab4-b485eb5ed48f" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="[Which algorithms have the greatest impact on our civilization?][1]; the answers might be interesting, but this is highly argumentative.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;**Resolved**: closed.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/596/which-algorithms-have-the-greatest-impact-on-our-civilization" />
./PostHistory.xml:5171:  <row Id="7582" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="188" RevisionGUID="99f228cb-5d61-422b-bd72-0ba6a6eb9bfd" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="This question builds on a comment of Shane's in a [previous meta post][1] on what can be achieved using a theory Q&amp;A site.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I've spent a good deal of time on Jeff Erickson's lovely problem about [unshuffling a string][2], and during the proposal phase, on his question about the complexity of minimum sequences in generalized Rubik's cube.  However, I haven't posted any responses to those questions because I didn't end up with an answer.  &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Most of what I've done is discover dead ends and approaches that don't work.  These might be useful for someone to know so that they don't spend time on the same issue or if they'd like to pick up where I left off.  Unfortunately, the Q&amp;A format doesn't seem naturally suited to this style of inquiry.   A wrong answer isn't an &quot;answer&quot; per se, and a detailed discussion won't fit in a non-nested comment thread.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; The question: how can the CSTheory Q&amp;A&#xD;&#xA;&gt; format better be used to support these&#xD;&#xA;&gt; kinds of parallel group investigations&#xD;&#xA;&gt; into problems?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;One idea is to adopt the convention that &quot;answers&quot; to open questions are to be regarded as a discussion of possible approaches, rather than literal answers or partial answers to the question, then to encourage development of these approaches in the comments.  The downside is that these comments are not nested.  &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; Another possibility is to fork new questions concerning particular avenues of inquiry with links back to the parent question, perhaps with a dedicated &quot;subproblem&quot; tag; this might lead to a messy proliferation of subquestions.  &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Has any better format been discovered for collaborative investigation of open problems on other StackExchange sites, in particular, MO?  Are there other features in StackExchange we can activate to support this process?  Or is it better to instead restrict these kinds of investigations to blogs and wikis, as was done in Polymath? &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]:  https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/144/how-are-we-doing/152#152&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/34/how-hard-is-unshuffling-a-string" />
./PostHistory.xml:5172:  <row Id="7583" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="613" RevisionGUID="a5b93594-cc6d-4ac8-b86d-bc1f20be8608" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.537" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="(I do not use a feed reader much, and I may be missing the point.)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I am not sure if the feed for unanswered questions is meaningful.  Since every question is obviously unanswered when it is posted, you will receive every question if your feed reader checks for the update to the feed frequently enough.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;If the feed includes only unanswered questions which are at least a few days old, it might be useful, but that is at least something different from the [page of unanswered questions](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/unanswered).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;That said, there are several (almost duplicate) discussions on Meta Stack Overflow for feeds for unanswered questions:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/13849/rss-for-unansweredtagged-questions&#xD;&#xA;- https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/57300/rss-for-stackoverflows-unanswered-questions-that-matches-my-only-favorite-tags&#xD;&#xA;- https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/41696/why-is-there-no-rss-feed-for-unanswered-tagged-tagname&#xD;&#xA;- https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/42525/anyway-to-get-a-rss-feed-for-unanswered-questions&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;In the first link, someone points out a service to convert a usual page to a feed.&#xD;&#xA;" />

./PostHistory.xml:5174:  <row Id="7585" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="770" RevisionGUID="be01c068-e04c-481b-8e92-cfe25a748581" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.537" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="The community of TCS SE comes from many nations all over the world, and this increase the diversity of us, which is a pretty good thing.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Some of the members write their names in their own native languages, (e.g. [Bjørn][1], [Michaël][2] and [András][3]), and I applaud them for writing names as it should be. In [this recent post][4], @johne linked to a pdf file which is named by Mandarin Chinese, since the file may not belongs to him, so this make sense.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;But should we encourage the use of non-English characters in TCS SE? Since this is a place for sharing ideas and communication, a non-unify language can cause some problems. And while I'm using browsers which can read Unicode, not all the characters can be seem in all the systems. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Furthermore, if someone is writing a post almost entirely in non-English? Say a request for translating the following paragraph for a research purpose:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; 令 $U$ 為一大小為 $n$ 的集合, 而 $\mathcal{F}$ 為一非空集合, $\mathcal{F}$ 中每一元素為 $U$ 的子集. 均勻獨立的在 $U$ 上隨機給定 $[2n]$ 內的重量. 則至少有 $1/2$ 的機率會使得 $\mathcal{F}$ 中正好只有一個最小重量的 $U$ 子集.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Is this kind of post allowed in this site?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; Do we encourage the use of non-English characters? If so, what kind of degree do we allowed?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/users/1993/bjorn-kjos-hanssen&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/users/88/michael-cadilhac&#xD;&#xA;  [3]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/users/109/andras-salamon&#xD;&#xA;  [4]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/3604/parity-and-circuit-complexity" />
./PostHistory.xml:5175:  <row Id="7586" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="209" RevisionGUID="5f4100d9-5cdd-4b16-b263-9e54ad615df4" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="c.f [this question on O() notation][1]. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Stackoverflow actually has the 'homework' tag, and is willing to entertain questions of that kind. MO has strong prohibitions in place against it. The first problem here is that it's not entirely obvious that this is a homework question, and that changes my response. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- If it's not a homework question, then I'm willing to nudge the OP along in comments to find the answer themselves&#xD;&#xA;- if it is, I'd rather not help. &#xD;&#xA;- either way, I'm loathe to actually POST an answer, because it's a gratuitous rep honeypot, and it might only encourage more questions along these lines, and I'm not sure I want to encourage questions that are so low-level.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;But I recognize that there are differences of opinion on how welcoming we should be. So what say all ? &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/843/problem-from-growth-of-function" />
./PostHistory.xml:5176:  <row Id="7587" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="822" RevisionGUID="f27fd168-f6f5-4aea-a7b0-234218912761" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.537" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="_Update_: I withdrew this policy proposal.  It received 5 downvotes and no upvotes.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;---&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;This is a **policy proposal**.  The proposed policy in the question or its answers will be adopted in the case that after 3 days it received at least 5 upvotes with a 2/3 majority in favor (*).  Please upvote or downvote this question or its answers based on your opinion of the policy statement as presented, not just based on whether the premise of the question or its answers is reasonable.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;(*) That is, &lt;i&gt;x&lt;/i&gt;≥5 and &lt;i&gt;x&lt;/i&gt;≥2&lt;i&gt;y&lt;/i&gt;, where &lt;i&gt;x&lt;/i&gt; is the number of upvotes and &lt;i&gt;y&lt;/i&gt; is the number of downvotes.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;---&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I propose the following as a policy:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; **POLICY**.  Questions that describe a proof of some statement or an algorithm for some problem and ask others to do all the work to check its correctness are deemed to be off topic and closed.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The intent is to give a clear ground to close questions like “[Algorithm for Longest Path in Undirected Weighted Graph](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/3706/algorithm-for-longest-path-in-undirected-weighted-graph-closed)” in the future.  While the question had a specific goal (present a counterexample to the stated algorithm), I find it wrong to ask other people simply to do all the work to check the correctness of proofs or algorithms.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The proposal has something in common with some of the answers to “[How to ask a good question?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/300/how-to-ask-a-good-question),” namely [this one](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/300/how-to-ask-a-good-question/304#304), [this one](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/300/how-to-ask-a-good-question/306#306) and [this one](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/300/how-to-ask-a-good-question/318#318), even if they did not already cover the case with which this proposal is concerned.&#xD;&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:5177:  <row Id="7588" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="214" RevisionGUID="052f6239-ecf7-4f6b-b026-a804ecbd1576" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="[This question](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/813/is-the-lower-bound-proof-in-this-paper-correct) seems to have found an error in a computational geometry paper on CoRR, and David Eppstein in an answer confirmed the error.  I haven't checked it myself, but I wanted to ask if we should set up some policy to contact an author with a pointer to questions of this sort.  This seems to have a lot of potential as an additional service to the community this site could provide (part of &quot;Peer Review 2.0&quot;).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;A concrete suggestion: if a Q&amp;A locates/seems to locate an error in a paper, a moderator should email the corresponding author of the paper with a pointer to the question, and comment in the question that this happened." />

./PostHistory.xml:5179:  <row Id="7590" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="218" RevisionGUID="cfebcbc6-b414-4466-be05-ca3428a7d738" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="I'm not against homework questions where the qner is upfront about the fact, shares what they understand and don't understand about the solution (both SO guidelines), and where the question is at an appropriate level.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;In general, the magic shield against the bad kind of homework question is for answerers to ask themselves &quot;Do I know why the questioner wants to know the answer?&quot;  If not, don't rush to answer, ask why.  For real questions, that typically casts light on how to go about providing an answer.  For abusive questions, it is hard to give good reasons.  I want something along these lines to be in the FAQ, along with what Shane said about the spirit of the site.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;In this respect, we could do with being better about questions.  I note that [one of my own questions][1] is not well-motivated: I should go off and fix it.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/246/extensions-of-beta-theory-of-lambda-calculus" />

./PostHistory.xml:5182:  <row Id="7593" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="234" RevisionGUID="6a2a55dc-2e6f-4817-bfe8-c3f27cc1da0f" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="Are questions about *[this area of computer science]* on-topic here?&#xD;&#xA;----------------------&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;As [our FAQ](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/faq) explains, we interpret &quot;Theoretical Computer Science&quot; broadly. Roughly speaking, the subareas of computer science that put **emphasis on mathematical technique and rigor** are on-topic.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Here are some further clarifications regarding possible borderline cases:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; - **Pure math**: if the problem has some applications in theoretical computer science, it is welcome here – [more discussion](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/169/when-are-areas-of-pure-math-that-are-used-in-cs-considered-on-topic).&#xD;&#xA; - **Artificial intelligence**: theoretical aspects of artificial intelligence are on-topic; philosophical questions are probably off-topic – [more discussion](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/114/cstheory-vs-ai-stackexchange-site).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;---&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Further discussion:&#xD;&#xA;[[1]](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/115/what-level-and-types-of-questions-are-appropriate-for-theoretical-computer-scienc)&#xD;&#xA;[[2]](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/119/our-domain-scope-specifically-defined)" />

./PostHistory.xml:5185:  <row Id="7596" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="156" RevisionGUID="c2a222c8-4d7e-4dbc-bd47-8a1d2aa59521" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="I would agree that the three questions above are examples of the type of question that should be closed due to being too elementary.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Having said that, I would like to argue that the scope of allowable questions should be kept fairly broad.  As someone who hasn't done graduate coursework in TCS, I find the CW/big-list questions very helpful. (My [own question][1] had 4 votes to close before anyone had a chance to reply, but I think it turned out to be useful to others.)  I know that you don't want the mix of questions to become too elementary and put off the serious researchers.  It would be nice to be able to segregate the more basic questions from the advanced, but given that the theory community is small, there probably aren't enough people to support two separate StackExchange sites.  And hopefully some of the people asking basic questions will eventually be asking (and answering) more advanced stuff.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Here's one little idea that might be workable: ask that anyone posting a question that could be considered undergrad-level material to tag it with something like &quot;intro&quot;.  Then anyone who doesn't want that stuff cluttering up their view could add the intro tag to their ignore filter.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I think over time the mix of questions is going to include more like [Jeff Erickson's][2], and this will become a less sensitive issue.  (By the way, has Bill Gasarch visited here yet?  He's posted some questions in the past on the CC blog that would be great for this site.)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/238/references-for-tcs-proof-techniques&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/34/how-hard-is-unshuffling-a-string" />

./PostHistory.xml:5190:  <row Id="7601" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="287" RevisionGUID="3165c5db-3553-4f06-8e34-b2254c7c38ca" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="While writing this [question about range counting][1] I was warned by the site that it is likely subjective and will be closed.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;1. ./PostHistory.xml:5191:  <row Id="7602" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="169" RevisionGUID="4c4691d6-3212-44fd-a304-a0e59991fbce" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="My motivation for this question is the response to my question [here][1], which garnered a vote to close for being too mathy.  Supportive comments and upvoting seemed to have saved that particular question from death, but for future reference, are questions about other fields with applications in CS theory considered OK?  For instance, would CS-oriented questions on these topics be considered on-topic?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; - discrete fourier analysis&#xD;&#xA; - metric geometry&#xD;&#xA; - geometry of polytopes&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;All of these are definitely pure math, but flip through a recent STOC/FOCS proceedings, and you're likely to see a lot of proofs that use theorems and tools from these fields.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;My personal opinion is that if we want TheoryOverflow to be useful to working researchers, then we have to allow questions about the tools and techniques used in TCS and that means allowing appropriate questions from areas of math with applications in TCS.  Such questions could be asked on MathOverflow, but I do not see a bit of overlap as a problem, and people here are likely to have both interest in such questions as well as the expertise needed to answer them.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/682/bounds-on-efx-in-terms-of-fex-other-than-jensens-inequality" />
./PostHistory.xml:5192:  <row Id="7603" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="985" RevisionGUID="f300d262-f34c-4824-8458-b4659282b243" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.537" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="This is a list of questions at [CSTheory][1] focused on Theory B (Logic, Semantics, Automata  and Theory of Programming).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; * [Techniques for Reversing the Order of Quantiﬁers][2]&#xD;&#xA; * [Why do we need formal semantics for predicate logic?][3]&#xD;&#xA; * [What is the theoretical basis of imperative programming?][4]&#xD;&#xA; * [Shallow versus Deep Embeddings][5]&#xD;&#xA; * [Books on programming language semantics][6]&#xD;&#xA; * [Are there “small” machines which can efficiently match regular expressions?][7]&#xD;&#xA; * [What do we know about provably correct programs?][8]&#xD;&#xA; * [Axioms necessary for theoretical computer science][9]&#xD;&#xA; * [Which interesting theorems in TCS rely on the Axiom of Choice?][10]&#xD;&#xA; * [Solid applications of category theory in TCS?][11]&#xD;&#xA; * [Correspondence between complexity classes and logic][12]&#xD;&#xA; * [What's new in purely functional data structures since Okasaki?][13]&#xD;&#xA; * [Higher-order algorithms][14]&#xD;&#xA; * [Where and how did computers help prove a theorem?][15]&#xD;&#xA; * [What would it mean to disprove Church-Turing thesis?][16]&#xD;&#xA; * [What is the difference between proofs and programs (or between propositions and types)?][17]&#xD;&#xA; * [Relationship between contracts and dependent typing][18]&#xD;&#xA; * [Curry-Howard and programs from non-constructive proofs][19]&#xD;&#xA; * [What are practically computable properties of Labelled Transition Systems?][20]&#xD;&#xA; * [What are the differences between logical relations and simulations?][21]&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;This list is posted on the principle that one way to attract people is to highlight questions and answers related to their interests. This is a community wiki; please edit the list if notable new questions are posted.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/q/4473/236&#xD;&#xA;  [3]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/q/1468/236&#xD;&#xA;  [4]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/q/11/236&#xD;&#xA;  [5]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/q/1370/236&#xD;&#xA;  [6]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/q/3533/236&#xD;&#xA;  [7]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/q/1132/236&#xD;&#xA;  [8]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/q/4052/236&#xD;&#xA;  [9]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/q/4816/236&#xD;&#xA;  [10]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/q/1923/236&#xD;&#xA;  [11]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/q/944/236&#xD;&#xA;  [12]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/q/12/236&#xD;&#xA;  [13]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/q/1539/236&#xD;&#xA;  [14]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/q/384/236&#xD;&#xA;  [15]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/q/82/236&#xD;&#xA;  [16]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/q/88/236&#xD;&#xA;  [17]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/5235/what-is-the-difference-between-proofs-and-programs-or-between-propositions-and-t&#xD;&#xA;  [18]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/5228/relationship-between-contracts-and-dependent-typing&#xD;&#xA;  [19]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/5245/curry-howard-and-programs-from-non-constructive-proofs&#xD;&#xA;  [20]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/4952/what-are-practically-computable-properties-of-labelled-transition-systems&#xD;&#xA;  [21]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/5427/what-are-the-differences-between-logical-relations-and-simulations/" />
./PostHistory.xml:5193:  <row Id="7604" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="179" RevisionGUID="157239be-9b24-45d5-a39e-57503ff61c6d" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="# [Jeff Erickson](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/users/111/jeffe)&#xD;&#xA;[(meta)](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/users/111/jeffe)" />
./PostHistory.xml:5194:  <row Id="7606" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1058" RevisionGUID="23b2b640-2c3f-4de1-b361-c800bd517666" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.537" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="Updated version (March 20, 2011):&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; Use this tag if:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt;- **well-known open problems**: the problem is equivalent to a well-known [open problem](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open_problem) in the literature&#xD;&#xA;- **community open problems**: the question is not answered after considerable time and the community decides that the question is an open problem ([meta][1] can be used for discussions)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt;---&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt;[cstheory][2] is **not** the right place to ask **well-known open problems**. You should post questions you're actually seriously thinking about. If you're thinking about a well-known open problem, provide some background and ask about something specific related to the problem, like &quot;Such and such is a well-known open problem. So-and-so proposed this and that approach. Does anybody know if this aspect of their proposal can be made to work under these circumstances?&quot; If you want to contribute to (or view) a list of open problems, visit the [Open Problem Garden][3].&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt;If it turns out that a problem is equivalent to a well-known open problem, then the [tag:open-problem] tag is added. After that, the question essentially becomes, &quot;What is known about this problem? What are some possible ways to approach this problem? What are some ways that people have tried to attack it before, and with what results?&quot; That way, the cstheory thread for the problem becomes a repository of resources related to the problem. Perhaps the answers could be organized by approach, with an outline of the basic approach, followed by a horizontal rule and a summary of what is promising about the approach and why it doesn't give a complete solution.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt;To join the discussion about how cstheory should deal with open problems, go to [this][4] meta cstheory thread.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;---&#xD;&#xA;The [tag:open-problem]'s [tag wiki][5] is based on [MO][6]'s FAQ on open-problems.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/&#xD;&#xA;  [3]: http://garden.irmacs.sfu.ca/&#xD;&#xA;  [4]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/1058/tag-wiki-open-problem&#xD;&#xA;  [5]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/open-problem  &#xD;&#xA;  [6]: http://mathoverflow.net/faq#openproblems&#xD;&#xA;" />

./PostHistory.xml:5197:  <row Id="7609" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="204" RevisionGUID="87416825-ca04-4882-bbd1-fad45a44158f" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="See [this question about an origami paper][1] for example. They provide a nice break from all these CW questions we've been seeing. These questions actually have a correct answer, and are usually technical, and indeed it would be hard for the poster to find the solution anywhere else (other than emailing the authors of said paper).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I just wanted to know if the community finds such questions acceptable. If so, we can include it in the FAQ (if we're going to have a list of example questions in the FAQ).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/813/is-the-lower-bound-proof-in-this-paper-correct" />
./PostHistory.xml:5198:  <row Id="7610" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="346" RevisionGUID="7778de36-0e91-4c2f-a01a-6ebb302b96ad" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="Now it should be ok to merge [distributed-systems](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/distributed-systems) -&gt; [dc.distributed-comp](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/dc.distributed-comp).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;---&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;**Edit:** This has got so far only 1 supporting vote, and according to [our policy](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/271/official-interim-procedure-for-doing-retagging), the threshold is 4 votes before the moderators can act. Why the lack of support? To me this looks like a no-brainer; the tags are now synonymous (recall that we have now a separate tag for dc.parallel-comp), and currently the more popular tag is the &quot;wrong&quot; one (non-arxiv), so merging would help to clean up the situation.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;If you have some specific doubts regarding this proposal, please leave a comment. If you think this is a bad idea, feel free to downvote.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;---&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;**Edit:** It seems that we are getting more and more questions with the [distributed-systems] tag and *no* top-level arxiv tag. Although this should be immediate from the list of questions, I have seen at least &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1574/do-you-use-any-article-organizers&quot;&gt;one question&lt;/a&gt; which was originally tagged as [lg.learning] for no apparent reason and I suspect that the reason is that the asker was confused about what the tag means.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Of course, whether new users (especially those who do not check the list of questions) read the tag wiki or not is another matter, but writing one line will not hurt.&#xD;&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:5203:  <row Id="7616" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="228" RevisionGUID="e5a71459-a472-4945-85d2-ec2cb4370314" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="What kinds of tags should I use?&#xD;&#xA;--------------------------------&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Each question should have at least one &quot;ArXiv tag&quot;, and any number of additional tags (there is a limitation of at most 5 tags per question and at most 24 characters per tag). Try to re-use [existing tags](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/tags) whenever possible, but you are also welcome to propose new tags. See [this page](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/tags/synonyms) for our current list of tag synonyms.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;---&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### ArXiv tags&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;[FIXME: add answer]&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Related discussion:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;1. [arXiv tags vs not?][1]&#xD;&#xA;2. [Proposal: Remove discipline prefix from the Arxiv-style tags][2]&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; [1]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/41/arxiv-tags-vs-not)&#xD;&#xA; [2]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/118/proposal-remove-discipline-prefix-from-the-arxiv-style-tags&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;---&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### [[soft-question]](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/tags/soft-question/info)&#xD;&#xA; &#xD;&#xA;A soft-question is subjective and argumentative without a precise answer and can be a question **about** theoretical computer science rather than being a question in it. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Examples:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- How would you teach X to undergrads?&#xD;&#xA;- Why computer scientists do X when Y happens?&#xD;&#xA;- Is theoretical computer science part of pure math?&#xD;&#xA;- How long will it take to settle P vs NP in your opinion?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;[More discussion](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/182/big-picture-vs-soft-question).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;---&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### [[big-picture]](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/tags/big-picture/info)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;A big-picture question is higher-level question, and although it can be subjective and argumentative it does not need to be, and is a question **in** theoretical computer science. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Examples:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- What is the main idea behind Razborov-Rudich natural proofs?&#xD;&#xA;- What are the obstacles to prove a super-polynomial lower-bound for SAT?&#xD;&#xA;- Where did the idea of Domain theory came from?&#xD;&#xA;- What are the main objects and constructions used in crypto?&#xD;&#xA;- Is there a program to settle Unique Games Conjecture?&#xD;&#xA;- Is polynomial time Turing computable the right definition for feasible computation?&#xD;&#xA;- What evidence do we have for Church-Turing thesis?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;[More discussion](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/182/big-picture-vs-soft-question)." />
./PostHistory.xml:5204:  <row Id="7617" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1287" RevisionGUID="6d144294-0e20-45d7-bc8c-b8c19cdd9626" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.537" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="Question: [All pairs shortest path in undirected and unweighted graphs](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/7809/all-pairs-shortest-path-in-undirected-and-unweighted-graphs)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;As discussed in [another thread](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/1274/why-was-all-pairs-shortest-path-in-undirected-and-unweighted-graphs-closed-and), the question linked above had been migrated to math.stackexchange.com and the decision of migration was decided to be incorrect. ./PostHistory.xml:5205:  <row Id="7618" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="368" RevisionGUID="5447922d-0188-4a70-90f8-38a6f452396b" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="Lance Fortnow asked a question, [What is the Volume of Information?](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1593/what-is-the-volume-of-information), which Ross Snider criticised on two grounds:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;1. Off topic: *I downvoted because I don't find this question relevant to the site (despite how infinitely interesting it is). It really doesn't meet the qualifications in the FAQ so far as I can tell*, and&#xD;&#xA;2. Not advanced as a TCS question: *the question (while legitimate and interesting) isn't really a TCS question (and so is not appropriate), and also doesn't meet the qualification here ([meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/225/…](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/235#235))*&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I'm generally of the opinion that the physical basis of computation is fundamental to computer science &amp;mdash;slogan: computer science is ultimately a physical science, one that involves a lot of formal science&amp;mdash; and is perfectly amenable to formal treatment.  Indeed, quantum computation could hardly be treated rigorously if that were not so.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I'm guessing that Ross' objection is not on those grounds, but rather he finds Lance's question to be the kind of question that has too much physics in it to be good for this site.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Are we worried about this?  Should we resist questions whose TCS to physics quotient gets too low?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;*Related: [Scope of questions?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/17/scope-of-questions)*&#xD;&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:5206:  <row Id="7619" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1371" RevisionGUID="a77fbd5b-58c9-4b27-89fe-bd7cc087a8e9" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.537" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="I think [this question](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/q/8543/30) on the future of computer science could have been worked with instead of closed.  A version of the question like, &quot;What are the main position papers about the future of computer science?&quot; might be very informative.  There are certainly citations available from CACM and other places, about the mismatch between the current hardware curriculum and the emerging needs of the hardware industry, or the current software engineering curriculum and the emerging needs of the software industry.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Without too much work, that question could have been made useful for the site -- i.e., requesting links and hard content, not just the posting of opinions.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Now, perhaps Noam totally disagrees with me about this particular question, and I am hijacking his thread, but as long as we are here, I thought I would let people know my position." />
./PostHistory.xml:5207:  <row Id="7620" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="253" RevisionGUID="7544e5c0-aca4-41e6-a20c-59093127a3f8" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="The question https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/942/in-strongly-connected-tournament-t-is-it-np-hard-to-find-a-minimum-number-of-vert was retagged twice, from the original &quot;np&quot; to add tags &quot;graph-theory&quot; (which makes sense) and &quot;ds.data-structures&quot; (which doesn't, at least to me).  After checking the FAQ for MO about Community Wiki mode it seems retagging does not count to make a post into a community wiki, so I retagged it yet again.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;My retag removes one of the tags that was added in a previous retag.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt;What should the etiquette be for retagging?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I would normally explain my decision to roll back or modify a previous edit.  However, retagging doesn't request an edit comment, so even access to version control tools would not help much here.  It would be nice not to have retag wars, but a meta question for every retag conflict seems too much overhead.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Moreover, if I remember correctly, some MO members were upset when Suresh retagged some old posts, causing them to be bumped onto the front page.  Is this reasonable?&#xD;&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:5208:  <row Id="7621" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="373" RevisionGUID="f0da5e95-da74-4f7f-a74c-b7702a329d6a" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="Because I (inadvertently) initiated this meta discussion I feel I ought to contribute an answer. I also feel the need to defend my position, and what I believe to be true about the relevance of Lance's question in context of this StackExchange.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I agree with Robin under the comments that the question is a good physics question. In fact, Lance's question starts with &quot;From a physics perspective...&quot;. The question is also phrased to include &quot;What is information?&quot; and &quot;What is volume?&quot; (this second question  standing on its own does not qualify in any way as being on-topic).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I am of course aware of the tenable connection between information theory and physics (in fact I mentioned this connection as one of my reasons for pursuing higher studies in TCS in my answer to [this question][1] posted before Lance's question). I hope this dispels to some degree the cargo-cult physics googling caricature of my comment that Charles Stewart presented here; Namely, I am familiar with the topic, but not so familiar that I would hazard to claim any sort of expertise - notice I have never tried to post an authoritative sounding answer to any related question. I hope my comment under Lance's question sounded exactly as handwave-y as it was: it was a motion that was supposed to communicate &quot;you should really talk to physicist because we are by no means the right community to define 'volume' or 'the amount of information in a physical system.'&quot;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;My main thesis would have two parts:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; - Lance's question, while having connections to TCS, doesn't not constitute a good TCS question. It is not refined enough, it has not been distilled enough, to qualify a good TCS answer. For example, it would be better if the question identified some problem with using bits of precision as a basis of information in a physical system, and asked how this might be resolved. Also that, if we were to admit the question as being relevant to TCS, we should reject it on the grounds that quick reference searches are enough to provide background material and links to better coverage.&#xD;&#xA; - That the question got more upvotes than it deserved because of the name of the author of the question. This question rapidly gathered upvotes, and in fact is currently ranked higher than some very strong TCS questions (for example this one [here][2]).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I would like to point out that the answers to the question, from authors I respect and am sure have a great deal of domain knowledge, did *not* amount to more than what can be found with a quick Google search.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;[1]:https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1562/why-go-to-theoretical-computer-science-research&#xD;&#xA;[2]:https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1257/properties-of-random-directed-graphs-with-fixed-out-degree" />
./PostHistory.xml:5209:  <row Id="7622" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1382" RevisionGUID="34422b4b-e237-430b-beef-73d26458c4b2" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.537" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="**New user posts a question which doesn't appear to be in the scope (research-level TCS)**&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;`Welcome to CSTheory, a Q&amp;A site for *research-level* questions in *theoretical computer science* (TCS). I am not sure if your question is a research-level question in TCS. Please see the [FAQ] for more information on what is meant by this. Your question might be more suitable for [cs.se] which has a broader scope than cstheory.`&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;----&#xD;&#xA;Version 6:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;`Welcome to CSTheory, a Q&amp;A site for *research-level* questions in *theoretical computer science* (TCS). Your question does not appear to be a research-level question in TCS. Please check the [help/on-topic] for more information on what is meant by this. ./PostHistory.xml:5210:  <row Id="7623" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="268" RevisionGUID="4bf1146b-75c9-477d-8d91-332d4e823f6d" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="I have encountered the following situation several times on cstheory.StackExchange.com, math.StackExchange.com or MathOverflow.net.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;1. A new user asks a question.&#xD;&#xA;2. Someone answers, or someone points out that something is unclear in the question.&#xD;&#xA;3. The questioner says “Thanks a lot” in a separate answer without accepting the answer, or makes a follow-up post as a new answer to the question without updating the question.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Why didn’t the questioner accept the answer or update the question?  The reason turned out to be that after the questioner posted the question using a cookie-based unregistered account, he/she lost the cookie for some reason.  I guess that he/she can use the &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/users/account-recovery&quot;&gt;recover the access to the account&lt;/a&gt; if he/she had provided an email address, but&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- he/she might not have provided an email address, or&#xD;&#xA;- he/she may not know that it is possible to recover the lost access to the account.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;(Admittedly I do not know how unregistered accounts and the account recovery functionality work, so I might be completely wrong about its functionality.)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;This made me think that it might be better to encourage people to register especially when _asking a question_.  A line in FAQ or the Ask Question page will be fine.  To be perfectly clear, this question is _not_ about encouraging people to register when _posting an answer_, with which the problem is less serious in my opinion.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;On the other hand, it must be a deliberate design that StackExchange allows posting questions and answers without registration.  Therefore, I am not completely sure if it is good to discourage people from asking a question without registering.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;This discussion only tries to address the problem for new users who are unfamiliar with the site but _careful enough to read instructions_.  Trying to solve the problem for those who do not read instructions is out of scope of this discussion.&#xD;&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:5211:  <row Id="7624" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="279" RevisionGUID="3ceb1beb-2c2d-4b27-98df-78458236a8f1" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="I think the same thing happened here: [Is the recent proof that P != NP correct?](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/10/is-the-recent-proof-that-p-np-correct).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;When a new result appears, many people try to email &quot;giants&quot; in the community, asking them what is their idea on the paper. Many of the researchers are tired of such situations.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I recently witnessed such event due to Deolalikar's paper (See Scott Aaronson's, Dick Lipton's, and others' blogs).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;In a [blog post](http://scottaaronson.com/blog/?p=465), Aaronson considers this forum as &quot;the best thing ever to happen to his inbox,&quot; and offers the motto &quot;Exponentially better than emailing Scott Aaronson&quot; for TCS Stack Exchange.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Among other things, I think TCS SE must become the &quot;de facto&quot; place for discussing new results on theoretical computer science. Conferences and journals have their own review process, but why should this prevent us from discussing them here?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I believe Suresh's point is right: We must not embrace authors here, and we should give them enough right to defend their work. Yet, is it right to do so by not discussing any new result here??" />

./PostHistory.xml:5213:  <row Id="7626" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="377" RevisionGUID="e854cb72-bc58-45bd-910e-82bd2369d261" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="This is a follow up to [Shane's early question][1] on site promotion. In one respect, things are going fairly well. Our traffic is steadily increasing: from an early number of around 2500 visits/day, we are now at 3200 visits/day. We also have nearly 1500 registered users (part of this is no doubt some reddit love we got for [a post on functional data structures][2]).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;And yet, I think our numbers overestimate the true penetration of the site within the theoryCS community at large. Here's an experiment I did:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; Estimate the fraction of users with a&#xD;&#xA;&gt; reputation in the range $(1, 101) \cup&#xD;&#xA;&gt; [102, \infty)$, and compare this to the fraction of MO users in the range $(1, \infty)$&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The rationale for this is that merely signing up gets you a reputation score of 1, or 101 if you come in via the SE system. So that score doesn't reflect any actual involvement. MO on the other hand is an SE 1.0 site, and so they don't have the 101 bonus. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;While in one respect this is an unfair comparison, because MO has been around a lot longer, it's not entirely unfair because we're only comparing ratios here. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The results: &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; TCS: roughly 20%  &#xD;&#xA;&gt; MO: roughly 40%  &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; (I did a crude approximation by looking&#xD;&#xA;&gt; at number of *pages* of users, because&#xD;&#xA;&gt; I have a life :))&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;It seems to me that this might suggest that our relatively large user numbers (relative to this stage in the beta) is an illusion, and so we need to work more at getting people in the community to participate. I know for a fact that many of my colleagues even in the narrow realm of computational geometry aren't here. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I don't have too many concrete ideas apart from some of the suggestions from the last post. But maybe it's a matter of doing more in-community - mentioning the site in talks, citing the site generously when appropriate, and encouraging co-workers and students to post questions (note that I'm not mentioning things like twitter which only touch a small fraction of the *theory* community)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/58/how-to-promote-the-site&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1539/whats-new-in-purely-functional-data-structures-since-okasaki" />

./PostHistory.xml:5219:  <row Id="7632" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1447" RevisionGUID="b23f4ec7-738a-48cd-a5c3-2e0edc84b408" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.537" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="**Introducing CSTheory to students via Algorithmic Contest** &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;In order to make the event more interesting for students, we are&#xD;&#xA;organizing an Online Algorithmic Contest as part of FSTTCS.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The format of the contest is as follows:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;1.Three problems will be posed on the first day of the conference on [Algo Muse website][1].&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;2. The students can answer them at their leisure and submit in two&#xD;&#xA;days. The contest is open to anyone, so we are expecting around 100-150 participants. Top performers will get some prizes. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;3. After the contest, we will publish an editorial which will contain&#xD;&#xA;solutions to the problems along with some additional references. (Brief&#xD;&#xA;history: We have been conducting some internal contests in IIT Bombay for a while now).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;**How CSTheory can be promoted**&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;One problem will be designed such that the editorial will contain links&#xD;&#xA;to the following CSTheory posts as a natural extension to the solution:&#xD;&#xA; &#xD;&#xA;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/8569/problems-to-reduce-from-to-prove-an-omegan-log-n-lower-bound&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1284/problems-that-can-be-used-to-show-polynomial-time-hardness-results/&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;This would be a gentle way of getting students interested about CSTheory&#xD;&#xA;site.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://www.algomuse.appspot.com/" />
./PostHistory.xml:5220:  <row Id="7633" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="297" RevisionGUID="6be77061-4396-4af8-a30f-02b17b32194a" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="A problem in answering questions arises when several people try to independently answer a question, and in the middle (or the end) one understands the situation.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The case happened to me, and several other people (See Ryan Williams' comment to Robin Kothari in [this post](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1233/semantic-vs-syntactic-complexity-classes)).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I suggest adding a &quot;Claim&quot; mechanism, which works as follows:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Upon deciding to answer a question, on clicks some &quot;Claim&quot; button.&lt;/li&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;The word &quot;Cliam&quot;, the name of the user who claimed the answer, and several other useful information appears beside the question for some predetermined time (say 20 mins), or until the claimer presses the &quot;Post the answer&quot; button (whichever happens first).&lt;/li&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Everyone else who sees the &quot;claim&quot; notice can decide to wait, or ignorantly answer (based on personal tastes, claimer info, remaining time of the claim, etc.)&#xD;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;" />
./PostHistory.xml:5221:  <row Id="7634" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="410" RevisionGUID="2572ea6f-3136-4891-ac57-9acc81486ff0" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="I recall reading answers from [Alan Turing][1]. I'm sure he has published in neither STOC nor FOCS, but should nonetheless be given a boost in reputation. But what if it is not the real Alan Turing? Any why should someone's publication record determine their reputation, anyway? And &#xD;&#xA;why stop at STOC and FOCS? What about POPL? Or TCS? And who decides anyway? &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The reputation systems avoids having to centralise reputation assignment, which avoids the need for subjective judgement. The reputation system is fair, based purely on participation. Finally, the reputation system avoids problems with someone posing as a famous researcher. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/users/1483/alan-turing" />
./PostHistory.xml:5222:  <row Id="7635" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1454" RevisionGUID="6a10d288-4837-4961-92bc-7f9de789667f" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.537" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="I fail to see where the linked question is provocative. It is maybe not rhetorically brilliant, but who of us non-natives can claim otherwise?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;We have entertained broad questions regarding research practice before, for instance&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; - [Advice on good research practices][1] (65 up, 0 down votes. 60 favorites. Very related to the question at hand.)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I think we can conclude that the *question* posed is very relevant. If people think it is stated in too frank a way, too bad. I think it is just that: frank. Personally, I have no need for graciousness and/or political correctness in an impersonal discussion.&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/q/2953/1546&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/q/1893/1546&#xD;&#xA;  [3]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/892/what-constitutes-enough-work-to-be-cited-or-acknowledged" />
./PostHistory.xml:5223:  <row Id="7636" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="321" RevisionGUID="333c6d93-8597-4fc6-ad8b-0c4d7d820534" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="In [this question](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1335/a-new-p-vs-np-poll-closed) I wrote the following comment.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt;I voted to close as I don't consider the question objectively answerable. I could imagine a version that would fit with the site, though. A community wiki like: &quot;Please post links to opinions of TCS experts about the P/NP problem.&quot; Maybe. for example, I've heard that Terence Tao considers P/NP to be a 500-year problem, but I've never seen a concrete reference. It would be interesting to collect such things.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Now I'm wondering if I was off-base.  It seems sorta-kinda in the big-list category to me, and if someone tries to hijack by posting multiple links to a crank, the community will vote those answers down.  But it's not as clear-cut as links to refereed papers or videos of invited talks.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Thoughts?" />
./PostHistory.xml:5224:  <row Id="7637" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="441" RevisionGUID="08b66adf-d24e-4fa0-a7b2-e9939562a821" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="I think timing is key. I've seen drive-by questions, where the user posts and disappears. I've also seen users interact with the comments and make changes. I'm all for giving some breathing room, especially since this is not like SO with nearly 2K questions/day. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;My personal suggestion (which I use also because my moderator votes are binding) is to use the 'downvote and comment' mechanism more than the close mechanism, if there's any sense of controversy. There are questions that deserve to be shut down via closing (like [this one][1]), and then there are questions that **might** be retrievable with more OP work (like [this one][2]). It costs you almost nothing to downvote, especially if you're a user with enough rep to close. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;But the OP needs to put in some effort as well. If even 24 hours after posting a question and seeing downvotes/comments galore, the OP doesn't either fix the question or repost a new one, then I'm all in favor of moving to close. Or if there's an edit cycle going on and on and on, with no sense of convergence, then again a close might be the best option. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1911/is-fn-log-n-in-theta-log-n-closed&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1881/is-wittens-new-method-of-quantization-useful-for-geometric-complexity-theory-c" />
./PostHistory.xml:5225:  <row Id="7638" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="447" RevisionGUID="e0326903-5e13-4bfd-8b86-ccfee699aa61" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="This is not an answer but an obvious observation, but I post it anyway in the hope that stating the obvious may shed some light on the situation.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Honestly, I think that the situation is pretty much chicken or the egg.  To begin with, people (not necessarily in Theory B) visit the website because people are already here.  If the pioneering people had failed, we could have ended up with an [empty restaurant](http://blog.stackoverflow.com/2010/07/area-51-asking-the-first-questions/) — no one is there, therefore nothing interesting is there, therefore no one wants to visit there.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Thanks to the first participants (especially [those who participated while the site was in private beta](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/badges/16/beta)), the website as a whole seems to have survived the risk of the empty restaurant syndrome.  However, that does not mean that the risk has gone in each subfield of the theoretical computer science.  I see many strong questions in complexity theory and algorithms, so I guess that the website has survived the risk of the empty restaurant syndrome in these areas.  However, in other areas, I think that the website is still in the middle of the risk.&#xD;&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:5226:  <row Id="7640" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="341" RevisionGUID="76715807-6b5a-4f2e-a5cf-fa7a24296612" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="I just edited some tag wikis to explain what the tag was for. I did it for tags like pcp and qma where it may not be clear what the acronyms stand for. So for example, for QMA, I explained what it stands for and linked to the Wikipedia page. ([See the tag wiki for QMA.][1])&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I think it would be nice if tag wikis contained enough information to decide what the tag is about. For some tags this is obvious, for other like qma and approximation-hardness, one could just explain that they stand for Quantum Merlin Arthur and Hardness of Approximation respectively, and link to their Wikipedia page, or their page on the complexity zoo, etc.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Is there anything else people feel that tag wikis should contain? For example, StackOverflow's tag wikis are huge. [See the tag wiki for PHP for example][2]. At this stage of the site it seems unnecessary to have such long tag wikis.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;So this is my suggestion:&#xD;&#xA;&gt; A tag wiki should explain what the tag is for (when the tag name doesn't explain it well enough) and perhaps contain a reference (to a website or book) to explain what the concept is. Usually Wikipedia links should suffice for this purpose.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Suggestions? Comments? Also, if your reputation is not high enough, you can request tag wiki edits in this thread, and someone who has enough rep can make the changes.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/tags/qma/info&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: http://stackoverflow.com/tags/php/info" />
./PostHistory.xml:5227:  <row Id="7641" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="449" RevisionGUID="daac16c1-a250-4c03-ae18-526b67df34ca" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="We have one post tagged with [games](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/games), and 4 tagged with [puzzles](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/puzzles). ./PostHistory.xml:5228:  <row Id="7642" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1481" RevisionGUID="c2bef9ef-6b51-4f32-92ba-5a891750bdf8" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.537" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="As a relatively new user, I am surprised by how quickly some questions seem to be closed. Because of that, sometimes I've been afraid of asking a question because it might not be &quot;research-ish enough&quot;.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;In some cases it is absolutely clear that a question is just homework, but I find it annoying that just because the question *looks like* homework it is almost immediately downvoted and/or closed, without much insight as to *why* it is being downvoted/closed.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;This is particularly true for an area I'm interested in --Automata Theory and Formal Languages--, because many homework questions seem to come from undergrad students taking this course (*&quot;Is $L$ context free?&quot;*), and also because it doesn't seem to be a mainstream research area (it was 50 years ago, but not now). However, some questions are interesting enough, but are welcomed at once with the following message:&#xD;&#xA;&gt; Welcome to cstheory, a Q&amp;A site for research-level questions in theoretical computer science (TCS). Your question does not appear to be a research-level question in TCS. (...)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;See, for example, [this one][1]. Another example is the question about $a^ib^jc^k$ with $i\neq j\neq k\neq i$, which ended up with a [blog post][2] a year after it was asked.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I'm sure that much (if not all) of what I'm saying now has been said before, but I felt the need to express my opinion, because it looks like not much has changed, unless these practices were really worse ten months ago.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/9969/finite-automata-that-accept-binary-strings-divisible-by-n&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: http://cstheory.blogoverflow.com/2011/09/it-only-looks-like-a-homework-problem/" />

I modified this tag manually.)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I cannot use the existing system for creating a tag synonym (which would automatically merge the created tag synonym to the real tag) because the tag [tag:dynamic-algorithms] does not exist at this moment.  Therefore, I would like to invoke the [official interim procedure for doing retagging](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/271/official-interim-procedure-for-doing-retagging) for this purpose.  This means:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; Score +4 or more of this meta post is interpreted as a consensus that the tag [tag:dynamic] should be renamed to [tag:dynamic-algorithms].&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I do **not** think that the old tag [tag:dynamic] should be a tag synonym after renaming, but I do not have a strong opinion about this.&#xD;&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:5232:  <row Id="7647" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="351" RevisionGUID="da3c9257-677f-480a-af36-48fbf8af9572" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="As explained in [Suresh’s post](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/340/retag-all-cs-xyz-abc-to-xyz-abc/345#345) to another discussion, some tag synonyms are created without their master tags being created.  However, I think that some reconsideration is desirable because creating a tag synonym whose master tag does not exist in the system seems to have caused two problems.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;1. Some tag-related pages are Not Found.  See comments to [Suresh’s post](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/340/retag-all-cs-xyz-abc-to-xyz-abc/345#345).&#xD;&#xA;2. Users with rep less than 200 cannot tag his/her own question with either the older tag or the newer tag until some user with rep ≥200 uses the newer tag, even if the older tag is in use.  See a note and comments in a [question](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1527/confidentiality-of-partial-private-keys-in-certificateless-public-key-crypto) by Zack (but let’s avoid discussing about the issue on the question page).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Judging from [how the feature of tag synonyms was requested](https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/2779/could-the-tagging-system-be-enhanced-to-support-tag-synonyms) on meta.stackoverflow.com, it seems to me that a tag synonym is supposed to be created when the master tag is already in use.  Therefore, it is understandable that the system behaves oddly if the master of a tag synonym has not been created.&#xD;&#xA;" />

./PostHistory.xml:5240:  <row Id="7655" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1603" RevisionGUID="ce7e0355-8978-4424-8ede-e332d98afec4" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.537" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="In order to limit the number of &quot;non research level&quot; questions asked on cstheory (that cause annoying downvotes/see-the-FAQ comments/migration/closing), I think that a good idea would be to add a short but visible subtitle under the &quot;Theoretical Computer Science&quot; to underline the scope of the site, something like:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&quot;CSTheory site is for **[research level questions][1]** in theoretical computer science, see [FAQ][2] for more details. ./PostHistory.xml:5241:  <row Id="7656" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="372" RevisionGUID="7b1674a4-353c-41b1-9433-008ca0ea1476" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="Honestly, I'm amazed that this question can be viewed as off-topic. It seems to me that cstheory is the perfect place to ask about whether some concept has an existing crisp formulation.  Previous questions in this vein have included asking about &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/668/is-there-a-complexity-theory-analogue-of-rices-theorem-in-computability-theory&quot;&gt;something in the spirit of Rice's theorem in complexity theory&lt;/a&gt; and &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/399/analogs-of-compressed-sensing&quot;&gt;my own question on analogs for compressed sensing&lt;/a&gt;.  Information theory is most definitely a part of theoretical computer science, and asking about whether the concept of volume, borrowed from physics, can be suitably formalized or not in an information theoretic sense is undeniably a valid one.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Moreover, while I'm all for being more strict about soft questions, I feel that being pedantic about the scope of technical questions is going to be a big turn-off to some people.  cstheory is not supposed to be an elite club or something.  It's the virtual equivalent to a coffee break in a conference.  And Fortnow's question would certainly make for interesting conversation there.  Also, the more types of questions we allow, the more people we bring in from different backgrounds, which only helps the cause of growing this site." />
./PostHistory.xml:5242:  <row Id="7657" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="500" RevisionGUID="ac2a15c8-48c7-4707-8fbd-60195594d586" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="Collecting together some of the comments suggesting open questions (including those by Tsuyoshi and Joshua):&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/34/how-hard-is-unshuffling-a-string&#xD;&#xA;* https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1699/is-gap-3sat-np-complete-even-for-3cnf-formulas-where-no-pair-of-variables-appears&#xD;&#xA;* https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2025/can-we-decide-whether-a-permanent-has-a-unique-term&#xD;&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:5243:  <row Id="7659" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="374" RevisionGUID="11f454ee-5b05-4132-8585-d65b6d61298d" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="A fairly typical case:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- A question is not clear enough in the first attempt.&#xD;&#xA;- There is a lot of discussion in the comments. People ask for clarifications, the user answers questions, people suggest modifications to the question, people make guesses regarding what the question is really about, there are answers that are non-answers or answer the wrong question, the question is edited several times...&#xD;&#xA;- The question gets downvoted and finally closed.&#xD;&#xA;- However, it seems that there is a genuine question that would be on-topic, if it was properly formulated.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Now what should the user do in these cases?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;1. Post a new question (and add a link to the original, closed question).&#xD;&#xA;2. Edit the question and ask the moderators to reopen the question (or let people to vote to reopen).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;[It seems](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1588/variable-profit-knapsack-closed) that our moderators prefer the approach 2. But to me it isn't obvious that this is the best approach. Once the question gets reopened, it looks messy and off-putting; there may be dozens of confused comments, the edit history is long, and finding out what is still relevant isn't going to be easy.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I would think that the approach 1 would be better. We would get a &quot;clean start&quot;. An empty thread, with no comments and answers. In particular, those who didn't follow the previous discussion in the old thread would be much more likely to try to answer it.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Any other opinions? In particular, what are the benefits of the approach 2?" />
