./PostHistory.xml:5245:  <row Id="7661" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="524" RevisionGUID="ae51b6b2-9acb-4386-9cfb-85b3246768e2" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="On the positive side, I think the quality of questions and answers are really high. (I find it a little bit ironic that mathematicians are faster than cs theorist in adopting new technologies.) Ideally we should have every active theory prof and every tcs graduate student in good universities actively use the site, post questions and answers. We should look more carefully on why this is not the case and address the issues that make people uninterested in using the site. We are also not getting reasonable involvement from researchers in areas outside algorithms, complexity, and computational geometry. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Theory B is very weak on the site, not enough crpto/privacy, combinatorics, and algorithmic game theory and many other very active research areas in [our scope](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/119/our-domain-scope-specifically-defined).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; - more involvement from community (profs, grad students)&#xD;&#xA; &#xD;&#xA; - more questions and answers&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; - more active areas&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I think we need a number of active core users who are experts in each area to keep those area active on the site. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Here are some suggestions:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; 1. There are number of reasons that I have heard from people who I have talked with and tried to get interested in using the site. It might help if we collect those reasons and try to address them if possible. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; 2. Moderators can contact some of the top experts that have used the site, and ask their opinion and for suggestions on making the site more interesting and useful. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; 3. List a number of reasons why every theory prof/grad student should use the site: &quot;Why I should check cstheory? Because ...&quot;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; 4. Contact a number of researchers in areas that are not active on the site, and tell them that their area is not active on the site and ask them to help us in getting more questions and answers in those areas. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; 5. We can also hold special weeks where every user is encouraged to ask a question (even very basic ones from people unfamiliar with those areas, you have attended a talk in some area and you have a very basic question you haven't asked) in a specific area, if we get enough question in those areas, they may generate enough interest to make those areas active. We can also directly invite some of the experts in those areas for the week assigned to each area.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;(Most of these are already suggested by others in other questions.)" />

./PostHistory.xml:5247:  <row Id="7663" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1629" RevisionGUID="fed7abc3-5cea-4f18-896e-f3816cc3ca9d" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.537" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="I did notice it. It seems that the question is interesting for general CS audience who may not be researchers in TCS. However it is a nice example of a question that can be used for outreach to people outside theory. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Note that regular users from other SE sites get enough reputation to vote on the question, so the total number of votes does not necessarily reflect the quality of the question relative to other questions according to regular cstheory users. (This is one of the issues that I think MO negotiated with SE when they decided to migrate to SE2.0 to make sure it won't happen on MO after it migrates to SE2.0).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;This happens also on other SE sites like Math.SE, e.g. [the batman equation question][1]. It will happen from time to time, I don't think it is not a big deal as long as it is not causing a problem. If we see that the question starts to cause problem we can make it protected or even lock it (as is common practice on other SE sites).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://math.stackexchange.com/questions/54506/is-this-batman-equation-for-real" />
./PostHistory.xml:5248:  <row Id="7664" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="396" RevisionGUID="6f93e091-a99c-4f7b-8236-a2e1fd5ec46c" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="Someone recently asked a question about [references for work in pattern recognition with fuzzy logic][1]. Leaving aside the issue of topical scope, here's the (harsh) comment I wrote:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; I apologize if this sounds rude, but&#xD;&#xA;&gt; it's not really our job to help you do&#xD;&#xA;&gt; a literature search, especially since&#xD;&#xA;&gt; you haven't provided any evidence of&#xD;&#xA;&gt; prior efforts in this regard. What&#xD;&#xA;&gt; you're asking us to help with is the&#xD;&#xA;&gt; kind of thing you should learn to be&#xD;&#xA;&gt; doing: navigating an area, finding out&#xD;&#xA;&gt; what's important (not what's hot!),&#xD;&#xA;&gt; and so on. If, after doing so, you&#xD;&#xA;&gt; have a specific question, then that&#xD;&#xA;&gt; might be more appropriate.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;This might be my own impatience, but I'm beginning to see more questions of the form of &quot;tell me what what's known about area X, or what's the latest in area Y, and so on&quot;, without any evidence that the OP has done some research, and has genuinely hit a brick wall of the form &quot;This specific question appears to be very natural, but I can't find anything on it&quot;.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I want to encourage people to ask SPECIFIC questions and not go on fishing trips and expect the community to help out - I'm not a Google replacement. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Am I being too harsh ? &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1700/what-are-the-essential-papers-that-i-should-read-to-get-started-with-pattern-rec" />
./PostHistory.xml:5249:  <row Id="7665" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="540" RevisionGUID="90ac5071-d159-49ec-a642-b05ff5428765" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="There seems to be quite a bit of interest in answering some applied questions. (I've answered some myself.) After I commented that https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2050/approximation-algorithms-for-maxsat was off topic, Peter Shor replied:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; In the '80s and '90s, at many universities, theoretical computer science was very unpopular and looked down upon by the rest of computer science because it was viewed as unconnected to practice. Eventually, Google and other successes convinced them that we were worth talking to. Let's please not close off the lines of communication from the other side now, after having worked so long to open them. That would be very bad for the field, not to mention the TCS job market.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Is there a consensus that heuristic algorithms for rigorously defined problems are on-topic, even if we can't prove anything about them? Should we distinguish methods with theoretical partial results (such as branch and bound, which is easily proven correct albeit potentially exponential) from methods with very little theory (such as genetic algorithms)?" />
./PostHistory.xml:5250:  <row Id="7666" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2662" RevisionGUID="01e487db-2301-46ba-b928-40ece91a396d" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.537" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="##Is my question suitable for cstheory?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;**Theoretical Computer Science - Stack Exchange** is a Q&amp;A for &#xD;&#xA;*professional researchers* in *theoretical computer science* and related fields. &#xD;&#xA;We welcome *research-level* questions in *theoretical computer science* (TCS).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;###Reseach-level&#xD;&#xA;Although there is no black-and-white distinction between &#xD;&#xA;research-level questions and non-research-level questions, &#xD;&#xA;questions are considered to be &quot;research-level&quot; roughly when &#xD;&#xA;they can be discussed between two professors or &#xD;&#xA;between two graduate students working on Ph.D.'s, &#xD;&#xA;but not usually between a professor and a typical undergraduate student. &#xD;&#xA;It does not include questions at the level of difficulty of typical undergraduate course/textbook homework/exercise.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;###TCS&#xD;&#xA;For an explanation of what TCS is, &#xD;&#xA;we refer you to the description of ACM Special Interest Group on Algorithms and Computation Theory (SIGACT):&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; TCS covers a wide variety of topics including algorithms, data structures, computational complexity, parallel and distributed computation, probabilistic computation, quantum computation, automata theory, information theory, cryptography, program semantics and verification, machine learning, computational biology, computational economics, computational geometry, and computational number theory and algebra. Work in this field is often distinguished by its emphasis on mathematical technique and rigor.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;###Questions should be based on knowledge sharing, not on shirking&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;You should only post questions you're actually seriously thinking about. Users are expected to do their part and try to answer their question by themselves before posting them on cstheory and asking for help from others. Search to see if your question is already answered somewhere else (e.g. Wikipedia) before asking a question. **Try to make your question interesting for others by providing some background knowledge**. Remember, *questions should be based on knowledge sharing, not on shirking. Shirking goes against the spirit of the site.* &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;----&#xD;&#xA;###Checking if your question is on-topic&#xD;&#xA;You can check if if your question is on-topic cstheory by answering the following questions:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* Do you have a good reason to think that &#xD;&#xA;**your question is likely to receive a *satisfying answer* &#xD;&#xA;from theoretical computer scientists**?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* Do you have a good reason to think that &#xD;&#xA;**answering your question *requires* &#xD;&#xA;the expertise of *professional researchers* in *theoretical* computer science**?  &#xD;&#xA;$ $  &#xD;&#xA;If your question can be answered &#xD;&#xA;by the knowledge of undergraduate/introductory textbook/course on the topic &#xD;&#xA;then it is off-topic for cstheory. &#xD;&#xA;Your question might be suitable for &#xD;&#xA;our sister site [Computer Science - StackExchange](http://cs.stackexchange.com) &#xD;&#xA;which has a broader scope.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* **Do you know the basics of the topic that your question is about** &#xD;&#xA;(at least at the level of an undergraduate/introductory textbook/course on the topic)?  &#xD;&#xA;$ $  &#xD;&#xA;If not, please consider learning the basics before posting your question on cstheory. &#xD;&#xA;Note that if you post a question without knowing the basics &#xD;&#xA;it is likely that you will make a *basic* mistake. &#xD;&#xA;Therefore you should expect your question to get down-voted and closed, &#xD;&#xA;possibly without any further explanation.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;If **yes** then cstheory can be a good place to **ask it**.&#xD;&#xA; &#xD;&#xA;If **no** &#xD;&#xA;(e.g. an expert in some other topic is more likely to &#xD;&#xA;answer the question in a satisfying manner for you, or &#xD;&#xA;there is no reason to believe answering the question requires the expertise of &#xD;&#xA;professional researchers in theoretical computer science) &#xD;&#xA;then **probably not**.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;It can be good to think about these and include your answers to them in your question. &#xD;&#xA;It will show us that you have thought about the suitability of your question for cstheory.&#xD;&#xA;It can also act as motivation for your question, &#xD;&#xA;which can make it more interesting for us.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;----&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Spend time to formulate and write your question clearly. &#xD;&#xA;When you ask a question you are seeking help from us, &#xD;&#xA;you are asking us to spend time to read and think about the question. &#xD;&#xA;We expect you to ask *only* questions that you *really* care about, &#xD;&#xA;not out of idle curiosity. &#xD;&#xA;If you care about your question &#xD;&#xA;you should spend time and effort on it, &#xD;&#xA;the effort correlates with the quality of the question. &#xD;&#xA;If you want us to spend our time on your question, &#xD;&#xA;you should have spent enough time on it.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;In summery, we expect you to spend time doing your part &#xD;&#xA;before asking others for help, e.g. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* **Try to answer your question yourself first &#xD;&#xA;(Google, Wikipedia, Complexity Zoo, etc.) &#xD;&#xA;before asking us,**&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* **Spend enough time thinking about your question to be able to &#xD;&#xA;formulate it clearly and in a way that can be answered, &#xD;&#xA;i.e. you should know what you are looking for,**&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* **Spend time on formulating your question &#xD;&#xA;using the language and terminology of theoretical computer scientists correctly and&#xD;&#xA;following the norms of their community,**&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* **Spend time to write your question &#xD;&#xA;in a clear and easy to understand format for theoretical computer scientists.**&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;FAQ contains more [tips about writing better questions](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/faq#tips-about-writing-better-questions)." />
./PostHistory.xml:5251:  <row Id="7667" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="398" RevisionGUID="f5cdaa0c-7d33-43b2-be13-d1c59e2cc6df" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="I think that this is an important discussion to decide in which direction our website should go, so thank you for raising this issue.  I do not have an answer, but here is what I thought about this specific question.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;On one hand, I agree with you that the asker was just asking for a broad literature search to get accustomed to a field, and the asker has not shown the evidence that he/she has tried.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;On the other hand, I see some inconsistency when I compare this question to [the question asking for ideas of graduation projects about quantum computing](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/710/quantum-computing-project-ideas), which has been perceived positively.  One is about the literature search and the other is about project proposals, but this difference does not seem important (if anything, asking for the literature is _more specific_).  Note that the question about quantum computing projects does not show any evidence of prior efforts, either.  Moreover, I feel that the topic “applications of the fuzzy logic to pattern recognition” is more specific than “quantum computing” (I may be biased here; quantum computing is my field of research, and I am not familiar with either the fuzzy logic or pattern recognition).  I have a difficulty justifying the difference of people’s responses.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;_Added_:  Just to make sure, the question on quantum computing projects I am talking about is _not_ the same as a [more recent question about how to write a research proposal on applications of evolutionary algorithms to quantum computing](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1715/long-term-project-on-quantum-computing).  The latter seems to be of a different nature (therefore I will not talk here about whether it is appropriate or not).&#xD;&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:5252:  <row Id="7668" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="542" RevisionGUID="2cad76d0-c0ae-401e-b2a4-f6e59d376e0f" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="I also like the question on [Max cut with negative edge weights][1], which is a very accessible question with a quite subtle reduction given by Peter Shor.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2312/max-cut-with-negative-weight-edges" />
./PostHistory.xml:5253:  <row Id="7669" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="411" RevisionGUID="80202ff1-3acd-4b9f-88ac-e1cfc0b8be47" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="This question is partly for fun, but partly serious.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;As a fictional example, suppose that someone asks a question like the following (the motivation part omitted for simplicity):&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; I would like to make pumpkin fries which are crispy on the outside and soft on the inside.  What is an algorithm for that?&#xD;&#xA;&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; Tag: [ds.algorithms]&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;(This question is based on a [real question on Food and Cooking Stack Exchange](http://cooking.stackexchange.com/questions/5036/how-to-make-pumpkin-fries).  By the way, from my personal experience, I strongly discourage you to visit _that_ website when you are hungry.)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;It is outright off-topic on our website, right?  After all, it is a question about cooking, not in the theoretical computer science.  But this question is clearly asking for an algorithm.  Although its goal is not to compute any mathematical objects and it is usually called a recipe, these do not mean that it is not an algorithm.  “It cannot be implemented on computers or Turing machines” does not sound like a good reason that it is not an algorithm, either.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;“Well,” you might say, “even if the question is about algorithms, it is too vague for a question in the theoretical computer science.  How do you define ‘pumpkin fries,’ ‘crispy’ and ‘soft’?  Oh, and you speak of the outside and inside.  Do you mean that pumpkin fries lie in a topological space?”&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;However, if we think this way, it starts to sound as if we should close it as “not a real question” or “subjective and argumentative,” not as off topic.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I am still pretty sure that the question _is_ off topic, but I find it more difficult than I thought to define when a question is about algorithms, especially because I believe that it is correct to say that a cooking recipe is an algorithm.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; **Question**.  What are the criteria to call some question “a question about algorithms,” and are questions asking for cooking recipes “about algorithms” according to your criteria?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;What made me think about this is [the recent question asking how to verify someone’s claim that analog sound is better than digital sound](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1697/does-analog-sound-have-something-that-digital-does-not-closed).  I removed the [ds.algorithms] tag from it and voted to close it as off topic, and it soon got closed.  But I have just realized that the question _was_ asking for an algorithm.  Now I wonder how to justify the claim that this question is off topic.&#xD;&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:5254:  <row Id="7670" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2686" RevisionGUID="86ff8927-0b46-4dbb-8613-496781da0f3f" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.537" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="It seems that SE has replaced FAQ with [help][1]. So we need to find a replacement to referring new users to FAQ or directing them to the front page of the help page can be confusing since the scope is not defined on the first page of the help page. It needs one more click to get to [our part][2] of it.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/182812/introducing-a-brand-new-consolidated-help-center&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/helpcenter&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/helpcenter/on-topic" />
./PostHistory.xml:5255:  <row Id="7671" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="422" RevisionGUID="eddb447b-2787-4ce7-a022-35e33a411d16" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="This is another take to [the problem that a new user asks a question without registering and loses the cookie](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/268/should-we-encourage-a-new-user-to-register-before-he-she-asks-a-question).  In the discussion I linked to, I wanted to prevent this situation from happening, but I became unsure that it was at all possible to prevent it.  Therefore, I would like to know what should be done when this happens.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;To take a concrete example, I realized that in [this question](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1785/definition-of-a-monotone-machine), the asker replied to a comment by posting an _answer_, which is a typical symptom of multiple accounts.  I quickly verified that although the asker and the user who replied had the same user name and the same icon, they were different accounts.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;What should I do in a case like this?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- Flag it for a moderator attention by myself explaining the situation.&#xD;&#xA;- Ask the user to do this.&#xD;&#xA;- Ask the user to open a thread on meta.&#xD;&#xA;- Something else.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Also, should I ask the user to register?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Note:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- I cannot verify that the two accounts really belong to the same person.&#xD;&#xA;- It seems that only moderators can merge two accounts.&#xD;&#xA;" />

./PostHistory.xml:5257:  <row Id="7673" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2701" RevisionGUID="62be3e5e-1415-4cc1-b0fa-b7e5de34812a" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.537" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="###Not _theoretical_ computer science:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; Questions does not appear to be a research-level question in **theoretical** computer science.  For more information, please see [scope](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/help/on-topic)." />
./PostHistory.xml:5258:  <row Id="7674" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="559" RevisionGUID="1d251930-d285-41d9-b43d-6e395b5aa5e5" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="There are active discussions around both meta and several TCS questions about what questions should be rejected. The two reasons most often stated are (afaik)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; - *too basic* (aka *too localized*, whatever that means)&#xD;&#xA; - *homework problem*&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;There is a multitude of opionions about wether or not these reasons are legitimate or not; I do not want to discuss this here. Let us assume they are (seems reasonable since there is a large faction in favor of them). But then, should we not also close questions like these:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; - [Counting the number of Hamiltonian cycles in cubic Hamiltonian graphs?][1]&#xD;&#xA; - [Complexity of simplex algorithm][2]&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;My rationale: These and other questions that are phrased like &quot;What is best ... known?&quot; or &quot;Is there ...?&quot; are &quot;only&quot; a replacement for literature research. They do not pose a motivated, original problem or reflect that work has gone into finding an answer. One could say the one asking has not done his homework.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Of course they are research level questions and therefore inherently more interesting -- and they offer a possibility for experts to show off (in a good way), other than undergrad homework problems.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Nevertheless, I feel that a general rule of thumb for question scope should be found and that the negative approach (finding criteria for closing/rejecting) cannot go anywhere.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;So, let us try to answer the following questions: What makes a question good? What questions should *not* be closed?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2396/counting-the-number-of-hamiltonian-cycles-in-cubic-hamiltonian-graphs&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2373/complexity-of-simplex-algorithm" />
./PostHistory.xml:5259:  <row Id="7675" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="425" RevisionGUID="507d6361-9380-41b2-8613-3161b4363a3c" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="I would have voted to close the following question as out of scope if it didn't have 3 votes already.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1807/how-to-define-a-function-inductively-on-two-arguments-in-coq&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;It is similar to asking how to write a function in a programming language like C++, or getting help about a compilation error. I think it is clearly out of scope for cstheory, as it is not a research level question in theoretical computer science, also it is too narrow.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;ps:&#xD;&#xA;Almost the same considerations apply to the following question:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/846/eliminating-cofix-in-coq-proof/872" />
./PostHistory.xml:5260:  <row Id="7676" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2709" RevisionGUID="7626bead-b8b6-4632-8a10-d2efbd0478d7" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.537" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="##Default off-topic closing reason&#xD;&#xA;This is used as default, when other reasons are not used.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Right now it reads:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt;This question does not appear to be a **research-level** question in **theoretical** computer science.  For more information, please see [scope](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/help/on-topic).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Since it is the default, I think we should edit it to be broader. Something like:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; As posted this question is not suitable for cstheory.  For more information about why it is closed please refer to [help center](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/help/on-topic)." />

./PostHistory.xml:5265:  <row Id="7682" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2712" RevisionGUID="3259462d-89e7-4ffb-834f-44a1d769be61" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.537" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="I have a request.  It would be nice if the moderators here would avoid migrating low-quality questions to CS.SE.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I noticed recently a few low-quality questions that were migrated to the Computer Science Stack Exchange (CS.SE) site.  I would suggest that we avoid doing that.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* If it's a good question, and on-topic for CS.SE, I definitely encourage you to migrate to CS.SE.  For instance, if it is not research-level but would be a reasonable question, migrating to CS.SE is a great idea.  Go for it!&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* But if it's a bad question -- one that would be a bad question for CS.SE -- please don't migrate it to CS.SE.  If it's a bad question, just close it, don't migrate it.  Please don't make CS.SE a dumping ground for bad questions.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* If it's a good question -- well-researched, on-topic, focused, narrow -- but has some English/grammar problems, don't let that stop you from migrating.  If it's just the English, we can edit it over at CS.SE.  But if it is a fundamentally bad question -- e.g., not well-researched, or a duplicate, or unclear -- I personally don't think it should be migrated over to CS.SE&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;One recent example: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/q/18536/5038.  In my opinion, that question shouldn't have been migrated to CS.SE.  It is not a good fit for the Computer Science Stack Exchange.  The question does not show evidence of effort.  It asks a question about a topic that is already covered by reference questions at CS.SE, with no evidence that the question-asker was aware of that.  These issues are not something that those of us at CS.SE can fix through simple edits to the question.  Of course, that's just one example.  I don't mean to pick on that one or focus on that one too much.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Kaveh explains that the CS.SE admins specifically requested that &quot;badly written&quot; questions are still OK to migrate to CS.SE.  I didn't realize that!  That explains a lot.  Perhaps that's something we should discuss.  I'm not sure whether &quot;badly written&quot; refers to the English/grammar, or to more fundamental issues (like whether it's a good question, whether it is well-researched, whether it is on-topic and focused and detailed and not a duplicate).  If the former, I agree, English/grammar problems should not be a barrier to migration.  If the latter, well, I guess I might have a slight difference of opinion with the CS.SE admins -- maybe that's something we need to discuss on CS.meta, instead of here.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I certainly don't mean to imply that this is a huge, systemic problem that requires major changes to migration, and I don't mean to imply the moderators here are doing anything wrong (I think the moderators are doing a great job!).  Overall I think the process is generally working well.  I just wanted to suggest a minor refinement that I think might make things work better on CS.SE.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Related:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/q/1086/5038&#xD;&#xA;* https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/q/1285/5038&#xD;&#xA;* https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/q/1507/5038&#xD;&#xA;* [Do we want CSTheory.SE to migrate bad questions over here?](https://cs.meta.stackexchange.com/q/691/755)" />
./PostHistory.xml:5266:  <row Id="7683" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="444" RevisionGUID="dba92abc-132b-4d70-936f-af74f864bd15" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="###[A Boolean function that is not constant on affine subspaces of large enough dimension][1]###&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;A very technical question, with a specific answer. ./PostHistory.xml:5267:  <row Id="7684" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="607" RevisionGUID="2d9a2022-34f5-4e3e-8870-28dffea12bd3" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="In a recent question “[Randomized algorithm that “looks” deterministic?](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2606/randomized-algorithm-that-looks-deterministic)” by arnab, he posted an [answer](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2606/randomized-algorithm-that-looks-deterministic/2629#2629) directly communicated by Shafi Goldwasser with the following note:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; Please do not upvote this answer, as it's not mine.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;(This is not the first time I have seen this kind of note on cstheory.stackexchange.com, although I do not remember when and where I saw a similar note before.  I use arnab’s post as an example.)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;It is perfectly fine (and necessary for honesty) to state that the answer is provided by someone else.  But the “please do not upvote this answer” part makes me _hmmm_.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I guess that he put this note because he considered that he should not earn reputation points by posting an answer provided by someone else.  Although I understand his humbleness, I do not think that it is a good idea to say “do not upvote” for several reasons:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;1. In my opinion, this answer is good and it should be listed in a higher place on the page than score 0.  In general, a good answer should be listed in an earlier place.  That is how Stack Exchange sites work.&#xD;&#xA;2. Avoiding upvoting a good answer just because of reputation points seems missing the point, because reputation points are not of primary importance anyway.&#xD;&#xA;3. If we have this note as a norm, I am afraid that in the future, _not_ stating “do not upvote” in an answer provided by someone else may be viewed as inconsiderate.  This seems like a wrong standard to me.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I hope that people will not mind if an asker or someone else earns some rep points by posting a good answer communicated by someone else.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;What is your opinion?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;(As an aside, an answer can be marked as community wiki to avoid reputation gain (or loss).  But note that the primary purpose of marking a post as community wiki is to let other users edit the post, so that is a slight abuse of the system.)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;---&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;**Added note about community wiki**.  As I wrote above, I am aware that a poster can avoid gaining (or losing) reputation points by marking a post as community wiki (CW).  However, this has its own drawback if the poster does not intend to make editing easier.  Moreover, this does not solve the item 3 above; I do not think that we should give a poster a pressure to mark an answer provided by someone else as CW.&#xD;&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:5268:  <row Id="7685" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2756" RevisionGUID="3795fe74-30cd-4dcf-a3fa-770ca6e523c8" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.537" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="I have [seen][1] that questions asking for book recommendation are considered to be okay/on-topic on this site.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Is the same stance adopted for other sorts of resource recommendations?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;If so, why are such questions considered on-topic on this site?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/q/20086/20866" />

./PostHistory.xml:5270:  <row Id="7687" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="446" RevisionGUID="5def4f41-12f7-4947-84d0-ad3d47ae8ac3" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="As a [Theory B][1] person, I feel the site really lacks Theory B questions. More generally, the questions here seem to be mostly in fairly small areas and not sufficiently covering TCS as we all see it.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;What can we do to expand the scope of cstheory and attract theoretical computer scientists whose focus goes beyond the questions that we see these days? ./PostHistory.xml:5271:  <row Id="7688" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2758" RevisionGUID="62f0e677-a2d8-4e6d-b380-628f46581554" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.537" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="There has been questions about similar resources like videos: [What videos should everybody watch?](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1198/what-videos-should-everybody-watch) but they are very very infrequent.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Soft questions are considered a gray area in the scope and need way more care in asking.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;See [tag:soft-question] tag, [good subjective, bad subjective](http://blog.stackoverflow.com/2010/09/good-subjective-bad-subjective/), and [Is my question suitable for cstheory?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/a/2662/)" />
./PostHistory.xml:5272:  <row Id="7689" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="636" RevisionGUID="6be6920e-9562-4a4b-a2e5-05589973223a" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="Current policy is to close all questions that &quot;feel like homework&quot; to at least five (high-reputated) people. Those more militant even downvote answers given by others even if those were hints rather than complete solutions. I want to argue for stopping this crusade and allowing all kind of questions that are posed well ([to be defined][1]) and concern TCS. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;First, rational reasons:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; 1. We cannot for sure distinguish homework from other questions¹&#xD;&#xA; 2. Getting help/inspiration is not always forbidden, sometimes even encouraged&#xD;&#xA; 3. We are not responsible for other people cheating&#xD;&#xA; 4. Some people are willing to help with low-level question&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Second, opinions:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; 1. By providing help for homework questions we can reach new users&#xD;&#xA; 2. We should let people help that want to&#xD;&#xA; 3. A well-posed question deserves at least some hints&#xD;&#xA; 4. Such questions will continue to pop up, always, thanks to Google. We may as well answer them.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The only two reasons I ever read against homework/low-level questions are cheating and scope. Cheating I consider not an issue (see above) and scope should, imho, be defined by active users. If such answer low-level questions, so be it. Those who have some pure utopia in their minds should evaluate wether or not they really speak for most people and/or the greater good. Using RSS it is easy enough to preselect questions based on their titles.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Your thoughts, please.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Ad (1): Let me link to some accepted questions one might consider as homework level:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; - [Proving skip-lists strongly weight-balanced in expectation][2] (skip lists and more complex analyses were covered in a Master course I took)&#xD;&#xA; - [Writing universal recursive function][3] (content in the very first Bachelor TCS course)&#xD;&#xA; - [Is the following problem NP-Hard?][4] (although allegedly no homework, simple NP-hardness proofs are Bachelor level)&#xD;&#xA; - [Is there a non Turing-complete model of computation whose halting problem is undecidable?][5] (could very well be asked in basic TCS courses for intuition building)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/559/another-go-at-scope-of-desirable-questions/&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2430/proving-skip-lists-strongly-weight-balanced-in-expectation&#xD;&#xA;  [3]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2398/writing-universal-recursive-function&#xD;&#xA;  [4]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2781/is-the-following-problem-np-hard&#xD;&#xA;  [5]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2537/is-there-a-non-turing-complete-model-of-computation-whose-halting-problem-is-unde" />
./PostHistory.xml:5273:  <row Id="7690" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="509" RevisionGUID="efa34601-da31-4f3c-9188-86fb42ceabfa" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="When I saw the question “[What is the most efficient algorithm to sample graphs with trivial automorphism groups ?](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/646/what-is-the-most-efficient-algorithm-to-sample-graphs-with-trivial-automorphism-g)” by turkistany, it reminded me that I saw a similar question recently, but it was difficult to find which question it was.  It turned out that the “similar” question was “[Generating Graphs with Trivial Automorphisms](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2031/generating-graphs-with-trivial-automorphisms)” by Sadeq (which was indeed related, but was not similar after all).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Part of the difficulty of finding this question was due to the fact that the former had a tag [[automorphism](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/automorphism)] while the latter had [[graph-isomorphism](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/graph-isomorphism)], which rendered tag search useless.  (Of course part of the difficulty is due to my poor searching skill.)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;At this moment, there are five questions with the tag [automorphism], and all of them seem to be about the automorphisms of a graph.  Considering that graph isomorphisms and graph automorphisms are obviously very closely related, it makes some sense to merge these tags, which would have avoided the difficulty I encountered.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;However, converting [automorphism] into a tag synonym of [graph-isomorphism] does not sound right for the future use.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Converting both tags into a tag synonym of a new tag [isomorphism] is another option.  However, [isomorphism] is a little vague, and it can refer to the isomorphisms between languages as in the [Berman-Hartmanis isomorphism conjecture](http://blog.computationalcomplexity.org/2003/03/berman-hartmanis-isomorphism.html) for example.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Leaving these tags as they are is also a valid option.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;What should we do about these tags?" />
./PostHistory.xml:5274:  <row Id="7691" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="641" RevisionGUID="20d0317d-e203-497a-8a69-26898209a8f6" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="Currently 50 questions are tagged as [[np-completeness](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/np-completeness)] and 20 questions as [[np-hardness](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/np-hardness)].  Among them, [7 questions are tagged as both](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/np-hardness+np-completeness).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I think that the difference of these two tags is too subtle for the distinction to be useful.  Therefore, I propose to merge [np-completeness] to [np-hardness].  Note the direction; I am proposing to make the _more popular tag_ a synonym for the _less popular tag_, which is different from the usual proposal.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I know that NP-completeness and NP-hardness are two different notions.  However, in most cases, questions tagged as [np-completeness] ask whether a certain problem which is trivially in NP is NP-complete or not.  Therefore, the main point is whether the problem is NP-hard or not.  On the other hand, some of the questions tagged as [np-hardness] are about search or optimization problems, which are themselves not in NP (according to the standard definition of NP as a class of decision problems).  But the difference between search/optimization problems and decision problems is a technicality in most cases and should not be important in the classification of questions.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Some questions tagged as [np-hardness] ask about problems which are not known to be in NP.  Therefore, merging in the other direction would make the tag awkward for some questions.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;What do you think?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;---&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;_Update_: It has reached +4 with 4 upvotes and 0 downvotes, but there are two negative comments.  What should I do?  Let me clarify my points:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;1. We should merge [np-completeness] and [np-hardness] into one tag because for most questions, their distinction depends not on the essence of a question but on a particular way a question is stated.&#xD;&#xA;2. We should not merge them into [np-completeness] because there are rare cases where the [np-completeness] tag would be awkward.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;If merging the two into the [np-hardness] tag is not desired, an alternative suggestion is to merge them into a new tag, for example [np-complete-np-hard].  But this is certainly clumsy.&#xD;&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:5275:  <row Id="7693" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="649" RevisionGUID="0d5aa540-a9af-4e77-a9c9-75d23a466475" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="I have seen (and I have also used myself) the phrase “research-level questions in theoretical computer science” to describe the scope of cstheory.stackexchange.com.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;However, thinking about it, I believe that the word “research-level” in this context means something like “which arise or can arise in research _in TCS_”.  In other words, if a TCS question arises in research in an applied field and it is too easy for TCS research, I do _not_ think that it is usually called a “research-level question in TCS”.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;This seems too restrictive given that the consensus, though still being developed, seems to be to allow easy questions in TCS as long as they are not something like homework or typical exercises in textbooks and the asker has done reasonable due diligence (see the discussion “[On the feasibility of homework questions](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/636/on-the-feasibility-of-homework-questions)” started by Raphael and the comments on the question “[Is the following problem NP-Hard?](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2781/is-the-following-problem-np-hard)”).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Therefore, I want a better description of the scope.  What is your take?" />
./PostHistory.xml:5276:  <row Id="7694" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2789" RevisionGUID="3ecb2a78-2211-417f-a3ca-c774eb890dbb" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.537" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="##***personal*** view on TCS _(.se)_&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;(T)CS is a wondrous, fascinating, beautiful, deep, vibrant field. came to it in preteens, heard about public key cryptography from a relative who clipped out an article from a newspaper on it. dad, a jr high school algebra teacher, brought home one of the 1st PCs, programmed bubble sort for [***fun***,](http://vzn1.wordpress.com/2013/12/02/joy-of-code-2013-natl-cs-edu-week-dec9-16/) explained it to me and said &quot;its slow, it takes $n^2$ time to finish&quot;, and I pondered that concept like a deep zen mystery with beginners mind (before knowing what zen was). &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;in teens, wondered about shannons theorem about hard functions based on counting circuits. _and none of them can be_ ***constructed***. we know they're there, but where are they? what an astonishing deep mystery, almost like a TCS analog of [dark matter](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dark_matter)! and not the only apparent deep parallel between [TCS &amp; physics](http://physics.stackexchange.com/a/89802/33566). and still basically open after more than ½-century. truly this field is full of the Everest of problems. *many or even most in pristine pre-summited state!*&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;in college, learned/experimented/sought [FSM-enlightenment](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/14811/what-is-the-enlightenment-im-supposed-to-attain-after-studying-finite-automata) in an intriguing [research-oriented attack](http://vzn1.wordpress.com/code/collatz-conjecture-experiments/) on one mountain. climbed to a local minimum! also started experimenting with [SAT &amp; factoring](http://cs.stackexchange.com/questions/6588/reducing-the-integer-factorization-problem-to-an-np-complete-problem/6605#6605).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;there are many signs computer science is entering or in the middle of a (very long-range?) [golden age](http://cacm.acm.org/magazines/2013/2/160156-the-explosive-growth-of-postdocs-in-computer-science/fulltext), and thats motivating, energizing, even at times [exciting](http://vzn1.wordpress.com/2014/01/17/dwave-and-the-inception-of-the-qm-computing-dream/). its a field-in-motion. cutting edge and an awesome, buzzing-crackling fusion of abstract theory and real-life application. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;so, a dream job for me would be high-paying TCS research/applications and have come close to that fantasy in real life over the years. but, later, after working 4 yrs in scientific laboratory alongside graduate students and Phds, realized that combination of terms might be verging mostly on an oxymoron; ie it seemed that scientific researchers (not just those in TCS) didnt seem to be (how to put this delicately) reknowned for their salaries.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;am proud to be a contributing part of a rare, unique group that captures some of this energy/momentum/dynamism esp in the way that it [connects with applications](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/19759/core-algorithms-deployed). &#xD;&#xA;([tag:application-of-theory] is my favorite conceptual fusion/paradigm/site tag.) by some very hard work by many dedicated, farsighted, brilliant individuals, cstheory stackexchange is a really superb forum and by far the best venue on the entire cyberspace for that right now, and probably will be for years into the future. it mixes top achievers from academia with the wild open internet (another great/shearing _fusion_).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;TCS is also in the midst and at the forefront of massive/pivotal decade-long shifts and transformations. eg quantum computing, [electronic publishing/open science](http://www.amazon.com/Reinventing-Discovery-The-Networked-Science/dp/0691148902/), [collaborative filtering, collective wisdom, collective intelligence](http://cs.stackexchange.com/questions/4768/references-on-collective-intelligence-with-respect-to-cs-applications) and amazingly the stackexchange site captures various key elements of all that.&#xD;&#xA;am especially interested in &#xD;&#xA;[cyber collaboration](http://vzn1.wordpress.com/volunteer/) possibilities seen in the groundbreaking [polymath](http://polymathprojects.org/) model, which is at heart in its radical/dramatic successes not that different than the [stackexchange system](http://www.simonsfoundation.org/mathematics-and-physical-science/the-global-math-commons/).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;what is [great] TCS? how about simply listing my idiosyncratic personal TCS inspirations/influences/luminary/hero pantheon off the top of my head: [Lipton](http://www.scs.gatech.edu/features/career-solution), [Fortnow](http://www.cc.gatech.edu/features/fortnow), [Jukna](http://www.amazon.com/Boolean-Function-Complexity-Algorithms-Combinatorics/dp/3642245072), [Razborov](http://www.mathunion.org/general/prizes/nevanlinna/prize-winners/o/General/Prizes/Nevanlinna/1990/Razborov/page1.html), [Aaronson](http://www.scottaaronson.com/blog/), [Feynman](http://link.springer.com/article/10.1007%2FBF02650179), [Shor](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shor's_algorithm), Sedgewick, Knuth, [Cook](http://www.claymath.org/sites/default/files/pvsnp.pdf), [Turing](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/11797/alan-turings-contributions-to-computer-science), [Mandelbrot](http://nautil.us/issue/0/the-story-of-nautilus/in-the-mind-of-the-fractal-king), [Hofstadter](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/18968/what-are-the-popular-science-books-that-inspire-tcs), [Wolfram](http://www.wolframscience.com/). etc! (of course not coincidentally several are members of cstheory!)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;oh, and yeah, (sssh, dont tell anyone), then theres my [favorite open problem](http://vzn1.wordpress.com/2012/10/18/math-monster/) of [so many great ones too choose from](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/174/major-unsolved-problems-in-theoretical-computer-science) Ive been interested for ~2½ decades even long before there was a [huge incentive](http://www.claymath.org/millennium-problems/millennium-prize-problems)... _heaven forbid_ not claiming a _proof_ but have a [few new ideas](http://vzn1.wordpress.com/2012/12/08/outline-for-a-np-vsppoly-proof-based-on-monotone-circuits-hypergraphs-and-factoring/)!&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;speaking of zen, at rare times one might even think TCS can even reach [cosmic/transcendant/spiritual](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/189/algorithms-from-the-book) levels! (just had to somehow shamelessly work in the highest-voted question in this essay somehow!)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;hey, if theres still any question about my interest/engagement/affinity for this site, just browse/look at my huge [favorites list](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/users/7884/vzn?tab=favorites) sometime! due to the awesome stackexchange software [built by brilliant software engineers] it can even be searched by keyword eg [cc.complexity theory](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/search?tab=votes&amp;q=infavorites%3a7884%20%5bcc.complexity-theory%5d)" />
./PostHistory.xml:5277:  <row Id="7695" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="514" RevisionGUID="471a2642-1b48-464c-ae5b-7e44b53a77e4" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="There are several questions asking for a good way to model something.  Are they in scope, or should they be closed?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Because a recent example is “[Semantic distance between excerpts of text.](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2200/semantic-distance-between-excerpts-of-text)” by John Berryman, I will take this as an example, but I would like to discuss a general issue.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Some people argue that this question is really about natural language processing and that without a rigorously defined model, the question is not about theoretical computer science and therefore is off-topic.  I almost agree, but not completely, because it seems like a plausible possibility that questions like this can lead to interesting answers in the theoretical computer science.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I am not sure if I want to see more questions of this kind or not.  On the one hand, it is interesting to see connections of theoretical computer science to various fields of computer science, and encouraging this kind of questions increases the chance of seeing such connections.  On the other hand, if 20% of the questions on the top page are like this and few of them get answers interesting to me (and worse yet, they are bumped by [community ♦](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/users/-1/community) from time to time), I am sure that I will get sick of those questions.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;_Added_: Another example of the how-to-model-this questions is “[Finding islands of vertices in a network of roads containing one-way streets](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2227/finding-islands-of-vertices-in-a-network-of-roads-containing-one-way-streets-clo)” by shindigo.  This question was closed, and I was one of those who voted to close it.  Honestly speaking, I did not realize that this question was in the same “how-to-model-this” category until Suresh pointed out in a comment to the question (silly me).  I hope that comparing these two questions (and possibly other questions in the same category) may shed some light on _what we want to aim at_ about how-to-model-this questions.&#xD;&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:5278:  <row Id="7696" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="656" RevisionGUID="b6b44707-f7f5-4cda-a0de-1e3c5886e5cb" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="There are restrictions on editing tag-wikis. For example, I want to add the following to [`[tag-removed]`](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/tag-removed) but I can't, and I don't think anyone other than moderators can edit it since there are not really answered:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; This tag should only be used when there are no other appropriate tags. If you remove tags from a question and can't find any suitable tag to add, use [tag-removed]. The tag should not be combined with other tags. This tag is not intended to be used for closed question, please don't replace the tags on a closed question if the current tags assigned to the question are appropriate. (Please try to replace tags with [tag-removed] only when the question is already on the front page.) &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;We may also want to add something like this: &#xD;&#xA;(this is a trick used by moderators on MO to avoid bumping up questions when moderators get rid of tags which shouldn't be tags in the first place, for example meta-tags like: [math], [cs], [general], [advanced], ...)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; [tag-removed] is also used by moderators to silently get rid of a tag which should not exists by merging the tag with [tag-removed]. Please remove [tag-removed] when it is combined with other tags (try to be gentle and avoid removing [tag-removed] aggressively from questions which are not on the front page.)&#xD;&#xA;" />

./PostHistory.xml:5285:  <row Id="7703" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="541" RevisionGUID="21339210-9630-4c37-a813-907e336920eb" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="I really like the [Multiplicative Version of 3SUM][1] question: given a set of numbers, are there numbers $a$, $b$, $c$ in the set such that $ab=c$? ./PostHistory.xml:5287:  <row Id="7705" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2956" RevisionGUID="4ad11ac4-2ebc-4581-a80c-5de52330a9b0" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.537" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="StackExchange is looking to discontinue _all_ community blogs, including [our own](http://cstheory.blogoverflow.com). They are asking what we want to be done with our old posts (for example, migration to 3rd parties). **Does anybody have opinions on this?** I am interested in the opinion of post authors and the editors, in particular.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Our blog hasn't seen new posts in over 4 years, and is unlikely to see new ones at this rate. However, I know that a [number of us](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/a/22226/1037) run our own active blogs. So we might be interested in migrating our posts. For example, I have migrated/adapted my two posts on [quantum query complexity](https://egtheory.wordpress.com/2013/12/09/quantum-query-complexity/) ([original](http://cstheory.blogoverflow.com/2011/07/quantum-query-complexity/)) and the [negative adversary method](https://egtheory.wordpress.com/2013/12/16/negative-adversary-method/) ([original](http://cstheory.blogoverflow.com/2011/08/lower-bounds-by-negative-adversary-method/)) over to my own blog nearly three years ago. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;As a possible option, the blog I run -- [TheEGG](https://egtheory.wordpress.com) -- is a community project and has over 18 contributors. I would be happy to welcome any of the non-time specific (i.e. not the old conference announcements/dissections) posts over to my blog if their authors don't run their own blogs (or think it fits poorly with their more narrow theme). I would stagger their (re)release over the coming weeks. If they are interested, I might make slight stylistic edit suggestions to the respective authors to make their post(s) fit better with TheEGG's readership. If you are interested in having your post go this route, either respond in the comments here or email me at: lastname (dot) firstname (at) gmail (dot) com.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;As a second, low effort, option: We can simply convert the blog to static pages that would remain on servers that SE manages." />
./PostHistory.xml:5288:  <row Id="7706" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="545" RevisionGUID="fce0fcb4-3874-4d09-a702-587729d6368f" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="I am surprised to see that at least two people commented that the question “[When should you say what you know?](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2328/when-should-you-say-what-you-know)” by asterix is on-topic, because it looked clear to me that it should be migrated to Meta.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The question explicitly asks what we should do on cstheory.stackexchange.com, and if this question does not belong to Meta, I do not know which question does.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;If it were a general question about when to reveal your ongoing work, not limited to the behavior on cstheory.stackexchange.com, then it would be on-topic.  It seems to me that people _want_ to interpret the question as the general question, contrary to what is written in the question.  In my opinion, it is not a good reason to keep it on the parent site.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;_Update_: After this discussion was started, Charles Stewart changed the question from the one about cstheory.stackexchange.com to a more general one.  I am not sure if it is the intent of the asker or not, but at least the question after the edit is on-topic on the parent site in my opinion." />
./PostHistory.xml:5289:  <row Id="7707" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2965" RevisionGUID="6ae01096-4524-41fc-b307-8f7b6353b866" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.537" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="[![See all questions with active bounties][1]][2]&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://stack-exchange-dynamic-ads.herokuapp.com/cstheory.stackexchange.com/bounty.png&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/?tab=featured" />

./PostHistory.xml:5292:  <row Id="7710" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="550" RevisionGUID="48a4cc2c-92a1-4c97-afd5-ff773d6d9700" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="Here are two related questions:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;1. When should moderators _delete_ (not close) questions not posted by themselves?&#xD;&#xA;2. When should users with rep points ≥2000 vote to _delete_ questions not posted by themselves?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I am asking these questions because the moderation tools (available to users with rep points ≥2000) showed that Suresh deleted the [question 2246 on parent](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2246) recently.  I would understand it if it were _closed_, but I do not think that it should have been deleted.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;My opinion is that questions should be deleted if they contain offensive/inappropriate/illegal material and so on, but questions should not be deleted just because they are poorly asked or off-topic.  Closing is enough for poorly-asked or off-topic questions and, moreover, closed questions _serve as bad examples_.  A secondary usage is that if many questions asked by one user are closed, that might tell something about that user to other users.&#xD;&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:5293:  <row Id="7711" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="696" RevisionGUID="c2250427-ebd8-45fb-b95d-5fb9afb9bcc0" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="I just see only one of your questions has been closed and that was for being exact duplicate:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2038/what-techniques-are-used-for-proving-algorithms-optimal-closed&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;There are different reasons for closing questions and it would be more useful if you gave examples of questions you think should not have been closed. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The interpretation of comments depends on the person, I don't think anyone wants to be rude here, they simply state the reason that they are voting to close the question and this is actually being nice (one can vote to close without stating any reason.) I have not seen any comment even close to **&quot;This is the worst question I've ever seen, I think it should be closed immediately,&quot;** so I think this is more about how you read them than how they are written.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I think the appropriate time before voting to close a question depends on the reason for closing, e.g. if a question is being closed for being &quot;exact duplicate&quot; I don't see any point in waiting before voting.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I think the discussion would be more constructive if you restrict the discussion to one specific reason for closing.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;And as stated in the FAQ, when a question is closed it does not mean that much. It can be edited and reopened. (I guess the trouble is that most new users don't read the FAQ but the point of FAQ is exactly answering those *Frequently Asked Questions* so the answers for those questions are not repeated.)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I haven't checked the numbers but I don't think we are closing question with higher frequency than MO (even though I would have expected otherwise, one reason is: the site is still in beta and most of our users are new to the site and are not familiar with the policies)." />

./PostHistory.xml:5296:  <row Id="7714" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="565" RevisionGUID="cf5db330-5d77-4868-bd87-b89068fa4cfd" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="While undergrad homework is allegedly not within the scope of this site, you can have assignments in graduate courses that are definitely not basic. For example, I am giving a talk in the near future to researchers about something I worked with in my Bachelor's thesis. So it might be hard to draw the line.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;My proposal: Let us create a tag 'homework' if it does not exist already. This way, homework questions that are well posed (ref [this discussion][1]) can be allowed while people not interested in them can easily filter them out via the form on the main questions page. Something like https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/-homework should yield a static page (with corresponding RSS feed) but I did not figure it out exactly. Anyway, this could be implemented easily if we went for it.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;**Edit:** In response to the comments, let me elaborate why I want basic TCS questions here, not on MO.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; 1. Students looking for help in TCS naturally go to the TCS site, not MO. &#xD;&#xA; 2. I would expect more TCS expertise here than on MO (if not now because of the recent split, then certainly later on)&#xD;&#xA; 3. By refusing to answer basic questions -- often in a less than nice way -- we leave a bad impression.&#xD;&#xA; 4. No pity for people that prefer rejecting questions over using existing tools for filtering. One should be able to expect regular users to use filters rather than newcomers to know the scopes of at least two different communities.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/559/another-go-at-scope-of-desirable-questions/560#560" />

./PostHistory.xml:5301:  <row Id="7719" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="773" RevisionGUID="fee6deb9-69db-436b-bca1-f132d88e4926" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="I've seen a number of posts where people capture snapshots of parts of a PDF.
