./PostHistory.xml:5302:  <row Id="7720" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="786" RevisionGUID="d85840bf-c854-45be-87e4-e73cd84cc403" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="[Bob Hearn solves an NP-hardness question][1] posed by Jeff Erickson. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1999" />
./PostHistory.xml:5303:  <row Id="7721" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="788" RevisionGUID="51771b36-8dbb-4e5c-9160-db728d72dbed" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="Jukka Suomela [shows the dominating set problem remains NP-complete](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2505/is-the-dominating-set-problem-restricted-to-planar-bipartite-graphs-of-maximum-de/2508#2508) on planar bipartite graphs of maximum degree 3, a question asked by Florent Foucaud." />
./PostHistory.xml:5304:  <row Id="7722" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="583" RevisionGUID="fa3275db-6216-48b8-b65b-049107260b03" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="Hi all,&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  I chatted with Lance Fortnow at FOCS about the various ideas I brought up in [my answer][1] to &quot;[Beta period progress][2]&quot;. This &quot;question&quot; is about the first, namely: &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; Write a note in SIGACT News&#xD;&#xA;&gt; advertising the site.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I was thinking (and maybe this is too pie-in-the-sky) that this post could be written jointly by the community, by editing this very post (I'll put a crude skeleton in place). The article, when published, could be attributed to the website &quot;with contributions from&quot; anyone who helped edit the post (but only real names, please). &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I'd like to make a few requests though:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; 1. Use an answer to discuss a particular aspect of the article. I understand that issues will overlap, but it's easier to track answers than have one giant comment thread below this question&#xD;&#xA; 2. Make sure you use your real name when editing. We can use revision history to determine who changed what. &#xD;&#xA; 3. I think it's also fair to assume that simple edits (syntax, spelling) are not at the contribution level that might merit &quot;with contributions from&quot;, so try to focus on content edits, and we can all chip in to fix minor issues. &#xD;&#xA; 4. If you want to discuss whether we should be doing this at all, a different question might be a better place for that. Frankly, I don't see a downside. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;**Current contributors (please update)**: Dave Clarke, David Eppstein, Kaveh Ghasemloo, Lev Reyzin, András Salamon, Peter Shor, Aaron Sterling, Suresh Venkatasubramanian.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;**Further Update:** I think we should finalize all edits by Friday noon (Mountain time). At that point I'll take the text and links, convert to latex-ized PDF, and send it off to the SIGACT News Editor. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;**More updates**. I'm now locking this post, since it's Friday @ Noon here in Utah. I'll start doing the latexing, and will link to a PDF shortly. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;**PDF Update**: [Here's a link to the PDF][3], with the citation format taken from [this meta discussion][4]. I have emailed this version to [Brendan Mumey][5] (SIGACT News editor)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;---&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Questions Answered. In theory.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    cstheory.stackexchange.com&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;------------------------------&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;###Questions Answered.  In Theory.###&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Perhaps you're a computer scientist wondering [how much the Axiom of Choice matters to the theorems you study and prove](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1923/which-interesting-theorems-in-tcs-rely-on-the-axiom-of-choice-or-alternatively).  Perhaps you're a mathematician who needs [a top expert to explain what &quot;randomness&quot; really means in computability and complexity](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1263/truly-random-number-generator-turing-computable).  Perhaps you need [a list of problems that can be used to show polynomial-time hardness results, to strengthen your toolkit of reductions](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1284/problems-that-can-be-used-to-show-polynomial-time-hardness-results/).  Or perhaps you think a problem might be open -- but might just as easily be solved -- so [you'd like to ask](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2708/complexity-of-greatest-common-divisor-gcd/2713) a group of professionals [what they think](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2461/interactive-proofs-for-levels-of-the-polynomial-hierarchy).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;###Visit cstheory.stackexchange.com###&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;[cstheory.stackexchange.com](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/) provides this interaction &quot;at the speed of the internet,&quot; by bringing together researchers from around the world, and across the broad spectrum of theoretical computer science.  Active participants range from advanced undergraduates to well-established scientists. Currently the majority of participants are graduate students and postdoctoral fellows, but the number of senior researchers active within the site is growing quickly.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Even though [cs.theory.stackexchange.com](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/) is only two months old, it can already boast of 2,000 registered users, 700 answered questions, and -- perhaps most exciting -- [new research collaborations among computer scientists](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2328/when-should-you-say-what-you-know/2362#2362) who otherwise might never have realized that they were working on related problems.  The atmosphere of the site is a bit like a corridor discussion at a conference: researchers discuss and explain both folklore and the newest results, in a format that can be read at leisure.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Some questions and their answers are highly technical, but the answers from experts are often more than just answers; they contain insights that are not available in papers or textbooks.  For example, a student who requested a &quot;common sense&quot; explanation for how padding arguments related to complexity class separations received [an intuitive answer from Russell Impagliazzo](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2434/why-do-complexity-classes-translate-upwards-and-not-downwards/2453#2453); Scott Aaronson summarized the [state-of-the-art in non-relativizing techniques][6]; Jeff Erickson explained why [the real RAM model is preferred in computational geometry][7]; and a student who asked whether the Nisan-Wigderson pseudorandom number generator relativizes received [an answer from Noam Nisan](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2236/does-nisans-pseudo-random-generator-relativize/2239#2239).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Questions have also generated new proofs: Peter Shor gave a [reduction from Max-Cut with positive weights to a constant-factor approximation for the version of the problem with negative weights][8]; Jukka Suomela demonstrated that [DOMINATING SET remains NP-complete for planar bipartite graphs of maximum degree 3][9]; Sariel Har-Peled showed that [Hamiltonicity is NP-complete for k-regular graphs for any fixed k][10]; and Per Vognsen outlined a [proof for the Schwartz-Zippel Lemma using projective geometry][11].&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;In addition to specific technical questions, participants have asked for more general advice from the community, such as [how to referee papers][12], possible [Master's thesis topics in automata theory](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/979/automata-theory-formal-language-thesis-topic), pointers to [recent purely functional data structures][13], suggestions for an [inspirational talk about theoretical computer science][14], and [how to find a job](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2215/how-to-get-a-job).  The site is a place for the larger theory community to come together.  The overall scope of the site is **research-level theoretical computer science, broadly defined**.  _Note that homework questions are not allowed on the site_.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Everyone with a research interest in theoretical computer science is welcome to create an account.  We encourage participation using real names -- and almost everybody does this -- but it's not required.  Participation costs nothing, and takes as little or as much time as you choose. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;###Site Origin and Structure###&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Some of the founding members of [cstheory.stackexchange.com](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/) participated in discussion of a proposed solution to the P/NP problem that spanned multiple blogs, led to the creation of wiki pages, and brought together researchers in disparate fields from around the world.  This effort made it clear that the worldwide theoretical computer science community was ready for -- and needed -- a structured way to ask research-level questions and to consider answers to such questions.  The success of MathOverflow.net (a site devoted to research-level mathematics) encouraged us to adopt the StackExchange software developed by Jeff Atwood and Joel Spolsky. This software provides a user reputation system built on up- and down-voting of contributions to highlight and encourage high quality, and to control spam.  There is also a [&quot;Meta&quot; area][15], for discussions about site scope and direction. Thus far, the system has worked extremely well and we are very pleased with it. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;###Who runs the site?###&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;You do ! The site is moderated by the community, with users gaining access to more management tools as they gain more reputation within the site. We have an active core of users who diligently monitor the site, help improve the quality of questions and answers, and filter out spam. In fact, this very article is a product of community participation on the site. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;But you don't have to worry about any of that to contribute to the numerous research discussions taking place right now. Please visit -- and participate in! -- [cstheory.stackexchange.com](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/), the 24/7/365 gathering-place for theoretical computer scientists from around the world to share information and insights.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/522/beta-period-progress/526#526&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/522/beta-period-progress&#xD;&#xA;  [3]: http://www.cs.utah.edu/~suresh/cstheory.pdf&#xD;&#xA;  [4]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/352/how-will-you-cite-a-discussion-on-this-site-in-your-paper&#xD;&#xA;  [5]: http://www.cs.montana.edu/mumey/www/Home.html&#xD;&#xA;  [6]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2045/are-there-canonical-non-relativizing-techniques/2048#2048&#xD;&#xA;  [7]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2119/the-reasons-for-bss-real-ram-model-being-prefered-in-computational-geometry/2124#2124&#xD;&#xA;  [8]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2312/max-cut-with-negative-weight-edges/2318#2318&#xD;&#xA;  [9]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2505/is-the-dominating-set-problem-restricted-to-planar-bipartite-graphs-of-maximum-de/2508#2508&#xD;&#xA;  [10]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1651/hamiltonicity-of-k-regular-graphs/1656#1656&#xD;&#xA;  [11]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1772/alternative-proofs-of-schwartzzippel-lemma/1883#1883&#xD;&#xA;  [12]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1893/how-do-i-referee-a-paper&#xD;&#xA;  [13]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1539/whats-new-in-purely-functional-data-structures-since-okasaki&#xD;&#xA;  [14]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2386/inspirational-talk-for-final-year-high-school-pupils/2411#2411&#xD;&#xA;  [15]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" />
./PostHistory.xml:5305:  <row Id="7724" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="801" RevisionGUID="aeed0243-c3f3-4ff1-8f54-bb80fdb91ca7" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="Bumping this thread --&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I'm sure part of what is going on is the crunch at the end of the semester.  Also, there's less pressure to &quot;prove we're experts&quot; because we made it out of beta.  But... aren't the way-below-research-level questions dominating all new questions?  Also, several new questions look like homework problems, or requests for advice on class projects or what could be class projects.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I [answered](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/3697/resources-to-learn-about-the-p-vs-np-problem/3700#3700) one &quot;too-basic&quot; question, because I thought it was politely and enthusiastically asked, and I thought I could provide nonstandard information.  But maybe that was an error, especially given the direction things are heading.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;What do you think?  No big deal, ride it out until the new year?  Or, downvote and close questions?" />

./PostHistory.xml:5307:  <row Id="7726" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="803" RevisionGUID="3bf7d0b6-4fb4-47c5-a0ac-20a57f2f2605" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="_Edit: I take back this proposal.  See [Suresh’s answer](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/803/rename-and-synonymize-the-tags-prg-pseudorandomness-pseudorandom-generato/805#805)._&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;---&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I think that the tags [tag:prg] and [tag:pseudorandomness] have no distinction and should be merged.  Also, they can be renamed to a new tag [tag:pseudorandom-generators] for clarity.  Therefore, I propose the following:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- Rename [tag:prg] and [tag:pseudorandomness] to [tag:pseudorandom-generators].&#xD;&#xA;- Make [tag:prg] and [tag:pseudorandomness] synonyms for [tag:pseudorandom-generators].&#xD;&#xA;- Cancel my older [proposal](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/tags/pseudorandomness/synonyms) to make [tag:prg] a tag synonym for [tag:pseudorandomness], which I started without considering alternatives.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;__Note__.  This is a [retag request](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/271/official-interim-procedure-for-doing-retagging), and it will be considered to be approved when it reaches the score of +4." />
./PostHistory.xml:5308:  <row Id="7727" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="594" RevisionGUID="61e0c528-66a2-4865-af6a-9fdf38f7c570" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="I really like both the rhythm and the examples of the first paragraph, but think it should be changed a little, I'm just not entirely sure how.  I've tried to be as constructive as I can, given that I don't have a concrete idea on how to change it.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;It currently (Rev 10) reads: &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; Perhaps you're a computer scientist wondering [how much the Axiom of Choice matters to the theorems you study and prove](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1923/which-interesting-theorems-in-tcs-rely-on-the-axiom-of-choice-or-alternatively).  Perhaps you're a mathematician who needs [a top expert to explain what &quot;randomness&quot; really means in computability and complexity](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1263/truly-random-number-generator-turing-computable).  Perhaps you need [a list of problems that can be used to show polynomial-time hardness results, to strengthen your toolkit of reductions](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1284/problems-that-can-be-used-to-show-polynomial-time-hardness-results/).  Or perhaps you think a problem might be open -- but might just as easily be solved -- so [you'd like to ask a group of professionals what they think](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2379/refereed-games-with-uncorrelated-semi-private-coins).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I have comments on each of the four examples in this opening paragraph:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;(1) I'd guess that most computer scientists have *not* wondered how the Axiom of Choice matters to CS; most probably just think that it doesn't. The fact that we got a really interesting answer to the contrary is a success story for the site.  One of the things I enjoy most about the site is that I have learned interesting answers to questions I never would have thought to ask, not because they are not in my area, but because I always assumed the answer was trivial or never had occasion to think about them.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;(2) Are there any non-CS-mathematicians who read SIGACT News?  (Indeed, even the OP for that question is chair of his CS department, in addition to a joint appointment in the Math Dept.) Laurent Beinvenu's answer to that question was *great*, but I think we need to rephrase how we're selling it in this opening paragraph. I'm not sure the following is a good way, but I'll just note that his answer is like a short tutorial/primer on ML-randomness (basically all it lacks is the most recent results), something which might appear in a publication like SIGACT News. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Note that the amount of effort to write such a thing for such a publication is much greater than on this site, and would take several months to go through the publication pipeline, if it happened at all.  Here we got a direct line to the source, and we got just the part of the tutorial we wanted, right away.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;(3) A list of problems that can be used to show polynomial-time hardness results seems like a great resource for graduate students and people entering that area of research fresh, but I imagine experts in that area are familiar enough with the literature to have produced much of the entire list on their own. I think it's important that the paragraph clearly recognizes the correct audience for such a question, as is already done in the first two examples.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Again, maybe (but I'm not sure) a good way to think about it is that such a list is like part of a short tutorial that might appear in a publication like SIGACT News, but with a much lower barrier to creation (but still high quality).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;(4) The last example is great.  It's universal: it applies to graduate students *and experts*, everyone has had an experience where they wished they could do exactly this.  And on this site, you can. It's a great pre-punch-line for this paragraph (the punchline, of course, being &quot;Visit tcs.se&quot; on the next line)." />
./PostHistory.xml:5309:  <row Id="7728" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="807" RevisionGUID="f7b16545-a663-4226-aefc-c212ee5f2045" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="We had some discussions previously that questions from outside theory are be welcome on this site (to a reasonable extent). We have a tag for modeling: [formal-modeling][1]. I think it would be nice to have one for applications also, but don't know what to name it. I first created [application] but then changed it to [application-of-theory][2]. Another possibility is [theory-in-practice]. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; Should we have a tag for questions about applications of theory? &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; If positive, what should be its name? And which questions should be tagged using it?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/formal-modeling&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/application-of-theory" />
./PostHistory.xml:5310:  <row Id="7729" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="596" RevisionGUID="a0cccb9b-b63d-4a08-9a9a-40c13a36b0a8" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="Please do not remove tags mechanically just because questions are closed.  If a question is about graph theory and tagged as [graph-theory], there is no need to remove that tag if it is closed for being subjective or for some other reasons.  As [András wrote](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/587/about-retagging-as-tag-removed/595#595), closed questions should be reasonably exposed as such to users who are trying to ask similar questions.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;If a question is tagged as [graph-theory] but it is not really related to graph theory or any other reasonable topic, I think that it is perfectly fine to remove tags and just tag it as [tag-removed], unless you bump many questions at once for the sake of retagging.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;As Jukka wrote in a comment on the question, if you want to exclude closed questions from search results, add “closed:0” (without the quotation marks) to search terms.  See https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/search for other search options." />
./PostHistory.xml:5311:  <row Id="7730" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="812" RevisionGUID="67aae7ab-6b16-499f-9b89-72619a8ae2ed" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="I think we should distinguish between asking for a research topic and asking for a topic for an undergrad programming project (like in this question: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/3736/ideas-for-a-project-in-mathematica-related-to-theoretical-computer-science ). Of course this site is not the right place for asking for a topic of a PhD dissertation, but I think we should accept questions like &quot;How can I put 10 thousand lines of Java code to a good TCS-related cause?&quot; (or maybe better we could create a big list of ideas for such projects). Moreover, questions like these seem welcome on mathoverflow: http://mathoverflow.net/questions/18440/what-algorithm-in-algebraic-geometry-should-i-work-on-implementing/&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;When I was an undergrad I had to write thousands of lines of code in various languages, quite often with a free topic (and the topic didn't really count towards the grade, the only criterion was a solid amount of working code). It is usually the case that such projects are used just once for 10 minutes by the grader, and then thrown away - so it's like a week of effort wasted (and there are also courses where for example four people write a project together for a year, so the outcome could potentially be really something very useful).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I think it would be a win-win situation if researchers would be able to put on this site (for example in a big-list topic) announcements like: &quot;I need a program searching for a small counterexample for some conjecture&quot; or &quot;I have an idea for an interesting game/simulation spreading the ideas of TCS, but I don't have the time to write it&quot; and so on; the students could then use these ideas for writing their projects, and if successful they would afterwards share the result with the scientific community." />
./PostHistory.xml:5312:  <row Id="7731" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="604" RevisionGUID="16f0d96b-8d64-4eb0-9fae-d6e9969a409d" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="I don't know what the motivations of homework-answerers are, but from my perspective the question closing process must seem bewildering and downright mean to the homework-question-asker (I know, obviously, that this is not how it's intended.) It makes one want to be more helpful than the official closing process.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The message people get when a question gets closed is: &quot;Questions on Theoretical Computer Science are expected to generally relate to Theoretical Computer Science, within the scope defined in the faq.&quot; Not only does that not really explain that the question was closed as homework level, but the FAQ link &lt;b&gt;doesn't go to the right place&lt;/b&gt; - it goes to the Stack Exchangey FAQ &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/faq&quot;&gt;here&lt;/a&gt;, which then has a link to the &quot;Offical FAQ&quot; which then has only an indirect reference to &quot;Typical homework problems in textbooks&quot; being too basic. So that's two or three links to get the first oblique reference to the real reason why a question question was closed. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Is there a way to make Tsuyoshi Ito's comment linked to above or Kaveh's paraphrase actually appear on closed homework questions?" />
./PostHistory.xml:5313:  <row Id="7732" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="642" RevisionGUID="459d80fc-3906-4722-bc28-5180a8805b0f" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="If I posted a question, and I got an answer that was very good, then I got another answer that is actually more to the point, shorter, easier, and more intuitive. ./PostHistory.xml:5314:  <row Id="7733" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="816" RevisionGUID="0f22cb28-f99c-46a4-af6c-62c8ef73026d" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="We have just had our [1000th question][1]; and this is the 12th day we launched; not long, but enough to see how we're doing. Lots of discussions have been done in the [review post of beta][2], while the number of questions is a [weak link][3] of us, we do not have [enough upvotes][4], and also there are a number of [homework problems][5], we tried our best to [increase the quality][6] of the posts and answers.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Although numbers are not important, sometimes they serve as indicators. I have just observed [a drop in the answer ratio][7]; at the time [we graduated from beta][8] it was about 2.8, and now it is about 2.5. It is also interesting that in the mean time, our traffic rate is constantly increasing, and the number of [active users][9] (users with a positive reputation change) in the late month is passed a hundred, a little increase compares to it was in beta.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Maybe the cause of the drop in the answer ratio is the homework problems, but I am not sure. Is this a healthy decrease (since we do not want to push the site too hard), or is it a signal of lacking enough thrust to keep flying our rocket? What do you think?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Another issue is the bounty system. It seems to me that recently, none of the questions with bounties have been answered in the bounty time period. The same problem [occurs in MO][10], which may due to both sites are theoretical oriented, and since it is related to the system of SE, we do not have too much we can do. Is there any solution to the bounty problem, despite the fact that it serves as a [mechanism to attract more attention][11]?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Final thoughts, it seems that most of the traffics comes from a particular region of the world (maybe US), since there is a low traffic gap (for about 8 hours) in the posts. Not a problem but an observation, but I do expect more experts and grad students all over the world to join our community.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Keep going, see how far we can reach :)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/3756/why-is-it-tn-4-work-for-each-block-of-the-matrix-in-this-divide-and-conquer-tra&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/522/beta-period-progress&#xD;&#xA;  [3]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/522/beta-period-progress/544#544&#xD;&#xA;  [4]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/6/vote-early-and-often&#xD;&#xA;  [5]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/601/flood-of-homework-questions&#xD;&#xA;  [6]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/522/beta-period-progress/524#524&#xD;&#xA;  [7]: http://stackexchange.com/sites&#xD;&#xA;  [8]: http://area51.stackexchange.com/proposals/8766/theoretical-computer-science&#xD;&#xA;  [9]: http://stackexchange.com/leagues/44/month/cstheory/2010-12-01?sort=reputationchange&amp;page=3&#xD;&#xA;  [10]: https://meta.mathoverflow.net/discussion/710/the-bounty-time-is-just-too-short/#Item_0&#xD;&#xA;  [11]: https://meta.mathoverflow.net/discussion/246/if-nobody-responds-to-a-bounty-why-do-you-still-lose-the-rep/#Item_0" />

./PostHistory.xml:5325:  <row Id="7744" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="697" RevisionGUID="6af59108-781b-40d7-8967-c3ab85142cdc" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="One of the things that regularly prompts me to refresh this stackexchange is the promise of interesting open problems (and not &quot;wide&quot; open problems like major complexity class separations or the complexity of factoring/matrix multiplication/etc).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Encoded in this are three qualities I am looking for. Each are mildly subjective but I hope the general idea is communicated:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* Open/important (to somebody).&#xD;&#xA;* Natural/interesting.&#xD;&#xA;* Not &quot;wide&quot; open. By &quot;wide&quot; I mean the problem is probably not solvable with current techniques.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;There have been some [seriously](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/681/multiplying-n-polynomials-of-degree-1) [cool](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/34/how-hard-is-unshuffling-a-string) open problems posted. There is in fact even a [tag](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/open-problem) 'open-problem' used to demarcate questions involving open problems. (The two &quot;seriously cool&quot; examples I linked to are both on this list.)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;However, I am worried that the list of questions tagged with 'open-problem' is not complete. For example, [here](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2461/interactive-proofs-for-levels-of-the-polynomial-hierarchy) is a question that is open, not demarcated with the 'open-problem' tag but that meets the criteria I listed above. This seems to happen with regular frequency: a question is posted, it is resolved soon thereafter that the question has been open in the literature for some time, yet the question is not then given the 'open-problem' tag.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I was wondering if we could compile and keep updated (an ultimately subjective) list of open problems meeting the above criteria which are not given the 'open-problem' tag. A list like this is interesting to me, and I am sure will be interesting to other members. It will be easier to justify the site to newcomers and can help compile some of the most intriguing question for pursuits like the poster for STOC." />
./PostHistory.xml:5326:  <row Id="7745" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="892" RevisionGUID="313925c4-03fa-49cf-9a8d-9977bf580a02" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="In [this question](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/4412/partitioning-a-connected-shape-into-rectangles), I received a spot-on one line answer in a comment that referred me to a more extensive answer by someone else to a different question on MathOverflow.  I plan to acknowledge David Eppstein for his answer on MathOverflow, and to cite one or more of the papers he referred to in his answer.  I'm interested, though, in what people think about acknowledging brief comments, especially since the commenter reposted his comment as an answer in an almost under-protest way.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;In this specific situation, if the commenter (Peter Shor) were to say, &quot;Yes please acknowledge me,&quot; or, &quot;No, don't,&quot; I would move with that, either way, so I'm not that concerned with the specific.  Rather, I'd like to hear more generally about people's thoughts on guidelines for citations and acknowledgements, and how you'd like them to relate to use of this site." />

Before I invest the time to learn all this stuff and try to read it, I am curious: have there been any technical rebuttals or discussions of it?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Note that this avoids issues of credibility, author responses, etc.  It is simply a reference request.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;(This seems to me essentially what has happened with the matrix multiplication question, and seems like it would satisfy the OP for that question, even though his question wasn't originally phrased this way.)" />

./PostHistory.xml:5331:  <row Id="7750" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="743" RevisionGUID="977429e5-7110-4eb0-b0a8-f1453efeaa94" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="The most recent example of the problem stated in the title is [this question][1]:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; what is more difficult to calculate from the viewpoint of a computer : the &quot;sum&quot; or the &quot;maximum&quot; of a finite set of numbers ?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Here's a reformulation in comments: &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; Can we come up with a model that&#xD;&#xA;&gt; separates sum and max? For example,&#xD;&#xA;&gt; could we show that in certain models,&#xD;&#xA;&gt; computing the sum of  b-bit numbers&#xD;&#xA;&gt; requires strictly more extra space (in&#xD;&#xA;&gt; addition to the read-only input tape&#xD;&#xA;&gt; and write-only output tape) than max?&#xD;&#xA;&gt; Or is the answer always trivial?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;While not claiming to know the intent of the OP, it seems to me that the original question was fairly basic, but the reformulated question is far more interesting (to me) and is actually a reasonable research level question. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;In fact, the reformulated question also [has a nice answer][2]. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;So my question is:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt;  - Would it be appropriate to edit the question to reflect what appears to be&#xD;&#xA;&gt; the more interesting question&#xD;&#xA;&gt;  - Would it instead be better to encourage the commenter to post a new&#xD;&#xA;&gt; question ?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/3492/sum-versus-maximum-in-computer-science&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/3492/sum-versus-maximum-in-computer-science/3497#3497" />
./PostHistory.xml:5332:  <row Id="7751" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="911" RevisionGUID="4818b8e9-6943-4c92-9ed3-aa0e36c09ab0" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="It took me some time to figure out how the user interface at https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/election works, so here is what I learned:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- It is not a typical SE user interface where you can change your mind by clicking the vote button again.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- If you are quick, you *can* change your votes, and you can remove *some* of your votes. For example, if you have chosen A = 1st and B = 2nd, then you can select C = 2nd and your vote on B is removed. And then you can then select C = 1st, and your vote on A is removed, too. This way you can remove all of your votes, *except one*! A strange limitation, but that seems to be how it works.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- At some point your votes get frozen. If you try to change your votes, you only get a popup note that says &quot;Your votes are too old to be changed&quot;.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;**Edit:** See https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/913/your-votes-are-too-old-to-be-changed for yet another feature of the system." />
./PostHistory.xml:5333:  <row Id="7752" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="750" RevisionGUID="d682a3fe-7055-4ca0-9f5e-1cab6b69088a" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="When you open the privileges page and select a privilege with a long name, the percentage of the _next_ privilege is aligned incorrectly.  This happens for example when you [choose “cast close and reopen votes” privilege](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/privileges/close-questions).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Always reproducible with Firefox 3.6.12, Internet Explorer 8.0.7600.16385 and Chrome 8.0.552.215 on Windows 7.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;My guess is that the problem itself had been always there, but the font used during the beta was not wide enough to trigger this glitch whereas the font used in the new design is wide enough to trigger it.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;[_Added_: Another cause seems to be that the font used to show the percentage is (probably) higher than the vertical space between rows.  Actually, this table is constructed by using floats instead of using a simple &amp;lt;table&amp;gt; element and, if I understand the intent correctly, the very reason for this is to handle the horizontal overflow nicely.  The font being higher than the vertical space destroys this gimmick and produces a worse result when the horizontal overflow occurs.]&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Screenshot of [the page about the “cast close and reopen votes” privilege](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/privileges/close-questions) with Firefox 3.6.12:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;![screenshot](http://i.stack.imgur.com/AqkVz.png)&#xD;&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:5334:  <row Id="7753" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="756" RevisionGUID="11328634-953c-4192-bb0e-3111f7bd698e" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="[This question][1] had this comment:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; Voted to close as off topic (too basic). – Tsuyoshi Ito 43 mins ago&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I therefore assume at least one close vote was cast for this question. ./PostHistory.xml:5335:  <row Id="7754" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="919" RevisionGUID="f37d42b2-da3d-4943-bf2d-d1a3eeb1a438" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="Migration is a nice feature but I am starting to get annoyed by the bad migrated questions we are receiving. I haven't counted but my feeling is that the majority of migrated questions to cstheory are problematic. Here is a recent case:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/q/4700/186 &#xD;&#xA;is migrated while OP had already posted the same question [here ](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/4644/faster-pseudo-polynomial-time-algorithms-for-partition).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Moderators on other SE sites don't necessarily understand what is an appropriate question on cstheory and this makes their decisions problematic. An ideal person for making the decision to migrate a question is someone who is an active high reputation user on both sites not just the sending site, but right now this is not the case. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I think that the decision about migrating a question should be made by both sides not just the sending site. We should be able to vet questions before they are migrated to cstheory, for example when a moderator on a sending site migrates a questions it should not become migrated at once but should become a possible migratable question on the receiving site visible only to moderators and high reputation users (say +2K) for a limited time (say one week) and if it receives enough migration votes on the receiving site or if a moderator on the receiving site decides that it is on-topic and suitable for the site then the migration is completed.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Another possibility is to allow high reputation users vote to unmigrate a migrated question back to the original site (with a note to the migrating moderator about it so they will be more careful in their feature migration decisions)." />
./PostHistory.xml:5336:  <row Id="7755" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="931" RevisionGUID="dcf75163-7569-4584-aa41-bdafb81d2538" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="The result is available on the [election](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/election/1) page.  Congratulations, Suresh, Kaveh and Dave!&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;_Update_: The three elected candidates have become moderators.  Congratulations again.  Hope you will enjoy the duty. :)  Also, let me thank to Ryan Williams for serving us as one of the first two moderators, and Sadeq Dousti, Hsien-Chih Chang (張顯之), Neel Krishnaswami, Aaron Sterling and Lev Reyzin for volunteering themselves as moderator candidates." />
./PostHistory.xml:5337:  <row Id="7756" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="940" RevisionGUID="13712f69-d868-4829-9261-9748e2ae27c4" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="If you have sufficient rep (10k or diamond mod), visiting&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/tools/&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Will show you the list of questions with &quot;interesting&quot; statistics within a specific date range. Including highest and lowest scores..." />
./PostHistory.xml:5338:  <row Id="7757" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="759" RevisionGUID="c144cbee-5175-43c0-82fe-adb5506b2536" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="I have been thinking about this for sometime. As you know, SE has changed the Community Wiki policy and now only moderators can make a question a CW. Community Wiki has 2 main effects:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;1. The question becomes owned by community, the original OP does not gain reputation,&#xD;&#xA;2. The required reputation to edit drops to 100,&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;and a side effect:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;3. The answers posted after a questions becomes a Community Wiki become Community Wiki automatically, i.e. the answers are owned by community, (but answers posted before the question becoming CW don't).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;These three effects are not always correlated and there are cases that one wants to have one of these three but not the other two, e.g. the owner does not want to earn reputation but wants the users answering the question to earn reputation for their answers. So it seems to me that SE is mixing too many things in one concept and that is the main reason for many issues we had and have with CW policy.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Robin brought up the idea that we should make the non-CW answers to a CW question CW also. I have a problem with answers becoming CW when the question becomes CW because sometimes the answers deserve to earn reputation, but in the current situation it makes sense, if the answers need to be CW then the previous ones also need to be CW, on the other hand a user might not have answered a question if it was a CW question so I don't know what is the right thing to do here.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I see three clear reasons for making a question a CW (and it would be nice to add other reasons to this list):&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;1. OP doesn't want to earn reputation (for some reason),&#xD;&#xA;2. OP wants to allow others to edit,&#xD;&#xA;3. the question is a ranking list.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;For example I think a question like [this][1] and [this][2] should be CW but the answers should not be and the users answering them should earn reputation for their answers. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Another issue is that the new policy is not clear on what we should do when we think a question or answer needs to be CW, I used to flag some posts for moderator attention but don't do it any more because I now think it is not very nice to suggest someone else question or answer should be CW to the moderators, so I have decided to go with a softer way of adding comments like &quot;I would upvote it if it becomes CW&quot;.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I have an proposal that I think might solve some issues and would like to hear what others think about it:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; In general the question or answer should be made CW only on the request of the owner (with some exceptions, see below), other users that think the post should be CW can leave a non-abusive comment like: &quot;nice answer, I would upvote it if it becomes CW&quot; and up-vote only if/when it becomes CW.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Exceptions:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;1. the OP is a drive-by user and does not reply to the answers or comments after considerable time,&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;2. some clear cases like: a ranking list. These should be explicitly included in the policy,&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;3. other special situations where the moderators have strong reasons for making a question CW.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;What do you think about this proposal (agree, disagree, opinions, improvements and suggestions, ...) and CW in general? &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;**ps:**&#xD;&#xA;Another minor issue about CW is its (lack of) effect on badges, it seems strange that a user does not earn reputation but does earn badges for CW posts, e.g. I should not have earned a badges for [these answers](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/174/major-unsolved-problems-in-theoretical-computer-science/218#218). Right now many of higher level badges are awarded for CW questions/answers, which does not seem a good thing to me.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;---&#xD;&#xA;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/239#239&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/25/material-to-supplement-the-faq&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;---&#xD;&#xA;### MO policy&#xD;&#xA; - https://meta.mathoverflow.net/discussion/6/when-should-questions-be-community-wiki&#xD;&#xA; - http://mathoverflow.net/faq#communitywiki&#xD;&#xA; &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### SE policy&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; - https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/392/should-the-community-wiki-police-be-shut-down&#xD;&#xA; - https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/67581/community-wiki-checkbox-missing-in-action&#xD;&#xA; - https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/67039/what-can-we-do-to-make-community-wiki-better&#xD;&#xA; - https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/11740/what-are-community-wiki-posts&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### Old discussions on cstheory meta:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; - https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/34/community-wiki-etiquette&#xD;&#xA; - https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/62/developing-a-cw-policy&#xD;&#xA; - https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/201/community-wikis&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]:  https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/45/what-are-good-references-to-understanding-the-proof-of-the-pcp-theorem&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2953/advice-on-good-research-practices" />
./PostHistory.xml:5339:  <row Id="7758" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="944" RevisionGUID="bcec7699-9646-4c14-abc5-bdc6ce6973b6" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="Now that [one problem](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/823/should-we-put-the-phrase-research-level-in-our-general-faq) of the page [cstheory.stackexchange.com/faq](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/faq) has been resolved, we would like to discuss another: namely, the existence of two lists of FAQs is confusing.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- [cstheory.stackexchange.com/faq](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/faq) (which I call “FAQ on main” here)&#xD;&#xA;- [Official FAQ for Theoretical Computer Science](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science) on the meta site (which I call “FAQ on meta” here)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;(I am not talking about the [FAQ _about_ meta](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/faq), which serves a different purpose.)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I hope that the new text on the FAQ on main reduces the problem of having two lists by listing some of the most important entries in the FAQ on meta.  Still, I cannot help imagining that both pages are claiming _I am the official one!  I am more important than the other list!  Read me first!_, which I do not like.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Note that the moderators cannot edit everything on the FAQ on main, although they can edit certain parts of it.  In a discussion which happened in comments on [this post](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/823/should-we-put-the-phrase-research-level-in-our-general-faq/927#927), Suresh (Feb 4 at 16:22) has suggested merging the FAQ on meta to the FAQ on main by putting everything before the section “What kind of questions should I _not_ ask here?” (if I understand it correctly).  I am not sure if that is the best way.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;_Update: It turned out that Suresh’s suggestion was something different.  See the comment._&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Other solutions may be:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;1. Include the links of all _questions_ in the FAQ on meta in the FAQ on main as an itemized list.&#xD;&#xA;2. Leave the FAQ page on main as is now, and rename the FAQ on meta to something along “Supplemental FAQ for Theoretical Computer Science.”&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;What do you think?" />
./PostHistory.xml:5340:  <row Id="7759" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="760" RevisionGUID="7505054c-0d11-49e3-9bbe-1c1daa9d4f52" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="This may sound radical, but do we ever need CW, especially for questions?  Things will become much easier if we just pretend that questions cannot be made CW, and I suspect that we will not lose much by doing so.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Actually I have never understood when to use community wiki (CW).  As you wrote, making a question CW has several effects, and I cannot see when we want to (1) give up reputation points, (2) make it easy to edit and (3) propagate the same effect to answers at the same time.  For example, I have never understood why big-list questions should be CW.  (I admit that I had flagged several big-list questions for moderator attention to make them CW, following the existing protocol without thinking why.)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;---&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;_Added_: As you pointed out in a comment, it is sometimes explained that big-list questions should be CW because votes on answers reflect how good the items mentioned in the answers are rather than how good the answers themselves are.  However, honestly speaking, I doubt that this explanation ultimately makes sense.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Many useful answers (no matter whether the question is a big-list question or not) are simply links to some external items, and in my opinion the answers pointing to good items in a useful way are good.  (One of the examples which I always think of is [Serge Gaspers’s answer](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/716/computational-complexity-of-the-3-partition-problem-with-distinct-numbers/758#758) to my first question on CS Theory Stack Exchange.  The essential part of the answer is a single reference, and it was extremely useful for me.)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I do not like to talk about reputation points as if they are anything important, but if reputation points are worth talking about, then someone who pointed out a good item in a useful way should gain reputation points in my opinion.&#xD;&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:5341:  <row Id="7760" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="962" RevisionGUID="f258ad86-d631-4775-abaf-dab54013bfea" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="This is in part a response to Robert Cartaino's comment on Suresh's comment response [here](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/947/is-theoretical-computer-science-too-narrow/961#961).  I wanted to separate it out from the other discussion, though.  I'd like to start by contrasting two questions, one on StackOverflow, and one here.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;First, consider [How do I move the turtle in LOGO](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/1003841/how-do-i-move-the-turtle-in-logo), especially the history of edits and closes.  A simple question with a simple answer, and, instead, it was repeatedly edited and closed by users who decided the question was fake, had nothing to do with programming, etc.  In this case, the asker was someone who wasn't leaving, so he clarified his position and eventually got an answer.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Now consider the question about [disproving the Church-Turing thesis](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/88/what-would-it-mean-to-disprove-church-turing-thesis).  In this case, I answered the question, it received a lot of upvotes, and was accepted by the asker.  However, in the months since that occurred, some of the finest minds in TCS have commented or answered that question, both explaining how wrong I was, and also sharing deep insights about the issue.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;A question I'd like people to consider is: Would you rather have a culture of arrogance, in which anyone with enough rep can decide, &quot;Get real, you couldn't possibly be Donald Knuth, I'm closing your question,&quot; or would you rather have a culture in which leading researchers feel comfortable adding to a question where a fairly high rep user already posted an accepted answer?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The question behind this question is, &quot;Why is there such a difference in the two sites?&quot;  I believe the answer lies in StackOverflow's fallacious belief that crowdsourcing is the best way to arrive at truth.  This may be the case for questions at the level of an Ask-the-Audience game show -- or even most in-the-trenches programming questions -- but when literally only a handful of people know the answer, and there are plenty of ways to deceive yourself that you solved the problem (when you didn't), the method breaks down.  Crowdsourcing does not produce truth; it only produces *an answer that nobody feels like debating any more*.  This lack of debate might arise because everyone is convinced, or because the few people who know the real answer don't see the point of participating.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Suresh has made the point well that a one-size-fits-all perspective about StackExchange sites does not work.  However, I believe this argument does not go far enough.  The quality of questions and answers on StackOverflow would *significantly increase* if that site were broken into smaller pieces.  If quality in answers is the priority, it should be harder than it currently is for C# experts to answer functional programming questions, as one example.  Rather than the academic caution that we have inherited -- not wanting to brashly say things about a field we know little about -- the StackOverflow model encourages people who get lots and lots of upvotes to answer questions in areas where there is little participation, because they'll get even more upvotes, and the people who know better aren't around, or don't want to start confrontation by calling them out.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Right now, on cstheory, if someone created a profile named &quot;Donald Knuth&quot; or &quot;Avi Wigderson&quot; or whoever, and asked a question, I bet everyone would be careful to treat that user like any other, and to treat the question professionally.  The content of the question is what is important, not &quot;making sure we're not being trolled&quot; or whatever.  I believe this attitude comes from our common belief in the importance of truth, as something beyond, &quot;Good enough,&quot; or, &quot;This is what works.&quot;  Moving forward, I think the most important thing to bear in mind is that we want to attract members who share that understanding of the primacy of mathematical truth.  That's what we share with others interested in theory.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;StackExchange, of course, gets revenue as a function of number-of-hits, so I am sure they see the high traffic of StackOverflow as a great thing that should not be messed with by separating out pieces of it.  Ok, fine.  But if they are interested in more crossover among disciplines, they could, for example, institute a tag system that crosses sites.  So, for example, a chemist posting on biostar about the degree sequence of a molecular graph could see questions about degree sequences on cstheory -- and the graph theorist here could see a potential application for the theoretical work!  Personally, I would *love* such a feature.  I'd like to ask Joel Spolsky and Robert Cartaino to work on *that*, instead of asking us to adapt to the StackOverflow site model, which would not serve us well." />

./PostHistory.xml:5343:  <row Id="7762" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="966" RevisionGUID="6e4de98c-7957-4b76-be14-6360a3f6b9f7" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="We have a number of questions that float up to the top of the queue every month or so. This is the latest one: [Help needed on method to use for anomaly detection][1].&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;But some are zombie questions (like the one linked): which means that&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; - the question had some issues, and comments were given on how to refine it&#xD;&#xA; - the question was left open so as to allow time for the OP to fix the question. &#xD;&#xA; - the original questioner disappeared or neglected to bother engaging with the commenters&#xD;&#xA; - the question floated down due to inactivity, and then popped back up thanks to Community. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I'd like to propose that we close these questions. I'm NOT proposing that we kill all community-reset questions, but only ones that have the above characteristics. Since closing is reversible, I'm proposing that we treat such questions as if they were just posted and the OP ignored the suggestions, which would normally lead to close votes. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/4236/help-needed-on-method-to-use-for-anomaly-detection" />

./PostHistory.xml:5351:  <row Id="7771" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1028" RevisionGUID="260f490b-417e-4049-9050-0c950d196386" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="There's a rollback extravaganza happening on [this question][1]. There are a number of problems in the question, and foolishly I contributed to this by even answering. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; 1. There are multiple questions within the question, and they are quite different from each other and should have been separated out&#xD;&#xA; 2. On the question of universities with a &quot;focus&quot; on theory, there's a clear ambiguity. If the question was asking for places where one could apply directly into a TCS program, then it makes sense (because not many places have this option). That was my intent in answering. However, if the question was asking for places that have a strong theory group (whatever that means) then it's completely out of bounds for our site. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;My feeling is that given the massive editing and re-editing happening on the answer (by our mods, no less!), we need to shift all discussion here. My personal preference is that this question be closed, and if the OP wishes to ask a set of very specific questions they may do so. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/5180/what-universities-in-the-united-states-or-in-europe-have-a-phd-focus-in-theoretic" />
./PostHistory.xml:5352:  <row Id="7772" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="826" RevisionGUID="21abd56f-0910-4f95-8c54-3489d2b81cb7" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="This is the first time we've had to deal with this, so I'd like to lay it out there (as well giving the user a chance to respond. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;User `johne` has posted three questions on the site, all of which have generated significant controversy and lots of mod requests. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;[The first one][1] was about the parity lower bound, and became an unusually long question about the difference between EE and CS regarding the importance of circuits. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;[The second][2] appeared to be a complaint about the use of contradiction/diagonalization in the proof of the halting theorem, and was closed for lack of clarity and concern about whether the concept of a contradiction was itself being called into question. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;[The third][3] question to my mind seemed more genuine, asking if there were any constructive (my rephrasing) proofs of the Halting theoreom, but has since devolved (in comments) into a bit of a mud-slinging war. The one legitimate answer provided appears to have generated very little response from the user. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;In addition, the user [also answered a question][4] about DLOGTIME and NLOGTIME with what appeared to be another discussion about differences between the VLSI community vs the TCS community, which I feel is not relevant or helpful.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;This is the first time we've had such an issue come up, and I'd like to discuss how we should proceed. I was loathe to make this about the user (and not just about the questions), but I believe there is a sufficient pattern to warrant a discussion here. In each case, the specific issue can be resolved at the source itself using standard methods (downvoting/closing) so maybe there's nothing to discuss. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/3604/parity-and-circuit-complexity&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/3810/is-there-an-alternative-proof-of-the-tm-halting-problem-other-than-the-standard&#xD;&#xA;  [3]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/3837/alternative-turing-machine-proofs&#xD;&#xA;  [4]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/3836/circuit-complexity-charaterization-for-dlogtime-and-nlogtime/3838#3838" />
./PostHistory.xml:5353:  <row Id="7773" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1031" RevisionGUID="b31a7cb0-c058-47a1-8fd1-99284344f32e" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="Please keep in mind the following aspects:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- One of the tags appears in the page title (and hence also in Google search results). The logic seems to be the following: take the most common (least specific...) tag and replace each dash with a space. The end result is something like this with the current tags:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    &gt; cc.complexity theory - Problems Between P and NPC - Theoretical Computer Science - Stack Exchange&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- The maximum length of a tag is 25 characters. For example, these should be fine (just some hypothetical examples to illustrate the limitations):&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    [tag:subject.quantum-computing]&#xD;&#xA;    [tag:subject.history-overview]&#xD;&#xA;    [tag:subject.programming-lang]&#xD;&#xA;    [tag:pl.programming-languages]&#xD;&#xA;    [tag:dc.distributed-computing]&#xD;&#xA;    [tag:a.programming-languages]&#xD;&#xA;    [tag:a.distributed-computing]&#xD;&#xA;    [tag:a.artificial-intelligence]&#xD;&#xA;    [tag:.approximation-algorithms]&#xD;&#xA;    [tag:.communication-complexity]&#xD;&#xA;    [tag:automated-theorem-proving]&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    These would be a bit too long:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    [tag:area.distributed-computing]&#xD;&#xA;    [tag:area.programming-languages]&#xD;&#xA;    [tag:ai.artificial-intelligence]&#xD;&#xA;    [tag:a.approximation-algorithms]&#xD;&#xA;    [tag:a.communication-complexity]&#xD;&#xA;    [tag:.automated-theorem-proving]&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;**Edit:**&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- Yet another place where it matters what our area tags look like: the new https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/users page.&#xD;&#xA;" />

./PostHistory.xml:5355:  <row Id="7775" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1066" RevisionGUID="638d704b-0879-431d-a1b9-9fa7a549d34b" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="Question: [Algorithm to sort pairs of numbers](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/5524/algorithm-to-sort-pairs-of-numbers).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I believe that this question is at the level of midterm/final exams in an algorithm course and not at the level of research.  Given the positive comment from one of the moderators and the high score (both of which are unbelievable to me), I do not mind if people keep it open, but I will not claim that this website is for research-level questions anymore, and I recommend others to stop doing so, too.  The “research-level questions” restriction has not been enforced consistently anyway, so we should be just honest." />
./PostHistory.xml:5356:  <row Id="7776" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="873" RevisionGUID="816aa795-ba2c-4c8c-bef1-e90407ca0aa9" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="I have flagged a few posts for removal using [the review page](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/review) because IMHO it is better to delete them. They were answers which were not answers (I think from new users). We left comments for the OP that answers are not for asking questions but the OP didn't reply.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;In summery, I think there are differences between bad answers and answers which are not answers at all.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;ps: I thought that a deleted post can be undeleted and therefore deletion *is* reversible.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;pps: Another misuse of answers is for commenting on other answers by low reputation users, which makes the restriction that new users cannot comment void. There have been many cases that an expert who just started using the system has written very good comments using answers (which I think qualify as good answers), but I think in general we should not allow this to become common for typical new users. So if a new user is using an answer to comment on the question or another answer and the quality of answer is not very good we should notify the user and if the user does not remove the answer by themselves we should remove them." />
./PostHistory.xml:5357:  <row Id="7777" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="875" RevisionGUID="a5294643-ffc1-4d07-ac71-01a902e619b5" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="I'm proposing a retag as: `[queuing-theory]` --&gt; `[queueing-theory]`. ./PostHistory.xml:5358:  <row Id="7778" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="877" RevisionGUID="012b978d-893a-4bef-a9c9-ce063edf4c3e" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="By improving a known construction, Hsien-Chih Chang [gives a family][1] of $n$-state NFAs $A_n$ for which the shortest word witnessing non-universality has length $2^{(1/5-o(1))n}$, and even to $2^{(1/3-o(1))n}$. This improves upon the previously known bound of $2^{(1/75-o(1))n}$ given in by Ellul et al. (2005).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;References:&#xD;&#xA;K. Ellul, B. Krawetz, J. Shallit, M. Wang: Regular Expressions: New Results and Open Problems. Journal of Automata, Languages and Combinatorics 10(4): 407-437 (2005)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/3496/conditions-for-nfa-universality" />

./PostHistory.xml:5360:  <row Id="7780" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1099" RevisionGUID="2f902081-105c-417e-9f29-c2d5a2ef5984" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="This question https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/5927/how-fundamental-is-undecidability-closed was closed within 25 minutes of being asked.  The OP was rude to a moderator in the comments, and it isn't a great question, so I do think closing it was a fair call.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;However, for me this has highlighted that we seem to be closing questions rather quickly, and certainly before the OP has a chance to change the question in light of comments, for instance to add pointers to literature, or to explain their motivation.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;This may be a reasonable rule, but I don't see it in the FAQ.  Some poor questions in the earlier days of the site went on to be revised (by the OP and by others) to become interesting and useful, generating significant numbers of page views and votes.  There were even instances where for initially uninteresting questions some great answers were provided (e.g. https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/4372/highest-lower-bound-on-np-problems-tsp/4373#4373, https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2349/true-bit-complexity-of-matrix-multiplication-is-on4/2350#2350, and https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2274/permanents-approximation-and-connection-to-integer-factorization/2276#2276 come to mind).  I don't have easy access to the vote histories for pages, but I seem to recall that some fairly anodyne questions even ended up being heavily upvoted after a stellar answer was provided, sort of basking in the reflected glow.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Previous discussions mentioned wanting to keep a clean front page _during the beta_, see https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/299/on-closing-and-the-awesome-power-of-moderation, https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/378/how-much-time-before-closing-a-question, and https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/695/why-the-extreme-strictness-on-topic-closing/699#699.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I would even hesitate asking a question like https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2136/rigour-leading-to-insight today.  This question started out quite vague but through feedback turned into a reasonable question, and more importantly led to insightful responses by several people.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Is there an unwritten rule that no-one (not even Ryan) shall ever receive the [reversal][1] badge?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/badges/50/reversal" />

./PostHistory.xml:5368:  <row Id="7788" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1127" RevisionGUID="5cab44c8-4ce1-48ef-9970-dcae8b721317" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="&gt;Update (May 6, 2011): This policy received 8 upvotes and 4 down votes and is now in effect.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt;This is a policy question. The proposed policy in the question (or answers) will be adopted in the case that after 7 days it receives at least 5 up votes with a 2/3 majority in favor. Please upvote or downvote this question based on your opinion of the policy statement as presented (not based on whether the premise of the question is reasonable). &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Some clearly off-topic questions are getting answer before we can close them. When I comment and request the users to remove the answers some of them do not remove their answers and don't reply to my comments (e.g. see [this one](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/6164/binary-how-does-it-work/6165#6165)). (Also SE has not replied to my email yet regarding adding migration to Math.SE to list of off-topic migration). So I propose the following policy (at least until we find a better solutions):&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt;**Policy Proposal** (April 28, 2011): Questions which are clearly off-topic should not be answered. When such a question is answered before being closed, the answers will be removed (we will post a comment linking to this policy to the question to explain the removal of the answers)." />

./PostHistory.xml:5372:  <row Id="7792" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1163" RevisionGUID="fdd36982-337a-4012-9682-dbecebc30982" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="What is the policy on multiple accounts, especially maintenance accounts?. ./PostHistory.xml:5374:  <row Id="7795" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1196" RevisionGUID="093336e8-fa57-40b4-9f09-5c291dce2731" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="&gt; July 21st: The first technical post is now up, [Quantum query complexity](http://cstheory.blogoverflow.com/2011/07/quantum-query-complexity/), by Artem Kaznatcheev.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; July 16th: The first blog post is now up, [here](http://cstheory.blogoverflow.com/2011/07/welcome-to-the-theoretical-computer-science-community-blog/).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;This is not so much a question as an announcement and a request for participation. We now have a cstheory blog at cstheory.blogoverflow.com ! &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;We'll have to feel out the best way to use it to augment the discussions on the site. To start with, we are happy to announce two editors-in-chief of the blog. [Joe Fitzsimons][1] and [Aaron Sterling][2] have agreed to manage content on the blog, and among their roles will be soliciting posts from YOU to place there.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Which brings me to the second point. As currently envisaged (Joe and Aaron will have more to say on this I'm sure), anyone who's interested can contribute to the blog, and this is how it would work:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; 1. you write a draft on the site&#xD;&#xA; 2. An editor reviews it&#xD;&#xA; 3. It gets posted. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Presumably as time goes on, some contributors might get direct posting rights - we can see how that goes. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;So what should you do now ? Sign up if you're interested in contributing. To do so, post your name and/or a link to your profile, which hopefully has an email address, in an answer below, and one of the admins (Kaveh or myself) will create an account for you. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Once that's done, you can start writing drafts. And I'm sure the editors will nudge people as well. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;If you have questions about the format, content styles etc, please create a new meta question and link it here. Let's keep this post primarily for signups. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/users/204/joe-fitzsimons&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/users/30/aaron-sterling" />

./PostHistory.xml:5376:  <row Id="7797" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1222" RevisionGUID="88084a0c-b7a7-4ac5-9553-54ea2841168e" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="In Scott Aaronson's answer to my [question](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/7528/extended-church-turing-thesis) about the Extended Church-Turing Thesis, he says&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; I don't see how talking about &quot;proofs&quot; of the CT or ECT adds much light to this discussion. Such &quot;proofs&quot; tend to be exactly as good as the assumptions they rest on---in other words, as what they take words like &quot;computation&quot; or &quot;efficient computation&quot; to mean. So then why not proceed right away to a discussion of the assumptions, and dispense with the word &quot;proof&quot;?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I would like to start a &quot;discussion of the assumptions,&quot; or a question like, &quot;What are the right axioms for the notion of computation and algorithm.&quot;  I would probably seed it with the list of axioms Dershowitz and co-authors use to prove Church-Turing Thesis, or Extended Church-Turing Thesis.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;So my meta-question is this: where would the best venue be for this?  It seems as though it would be a natural candidate for a blog entry, but perhaps it would be better as a community wiki on the main site, so people could vote up and down axioms/intuitions that resonated, or didn't.  Any preferences/suggestions?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;EDIT: thanks everyone for your input. I will ask a question, but probably next week. I don't have time to shepherd a question for the next several days." />

[Here][1] is a recent example asking for how to &quot;distributively maintain a database of all baseball games&quot; which will also deal with &quot;spam&quot; and &quot;fake&quot; data from its users. Has this been studied?&quot;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;How should we deal with them?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I am partly asking this meta question so we can refer to it when we get such questions.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/7694/distributed-peer-to-peer-collaboration-to-create-a-database-possible" />
