./PostHistory.xml:5388:  <row Id="7810" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1264" RevisionGUID="97140b38-585d-4d31-b29c-48f64770a7e9" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="I have recently been reflecting on my voting patterns. The discussion on [this answer](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/7728/multiplication-of-normal-distributions/7729#7729) suggests that different people have different views on downvoting. I thought it would be good to figure out what the community thinks should be rule-of-thumb guidelines on downvoting.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I usually downvoted questions if they are poorly written and show little effort on the part of the asker (and if there was edits made to improve the question, I would cancel my downvote) or if I think they are out-of-scope for cstheory.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;For answers I usually downvote if they don't answer the question or if they are incorrect. However, I sometimes downvote answers to a homework question, especially if its a homework-level answers.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;For answers on community-wiki questions I vote much more aggressively, sometimes downvoting something if I don't agree with or the answer is not insightful (especially for big list questions).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I thought this voting strategy is reasonable, but looking at the stats suggests that I downvoted a lot more than everybody else. In particular I think I have the highest total downvotes (~99) and one of the highest downvote percentages (~10%). How should I adjust my downvoting?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Also, there is some general downvoting differences between our top 20 rep users, and the MO top 20 rep users. In particular, it seems MO is more willing to downvote:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; % down | MO | TCS&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; 0.x% | 4  | 7&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; 1.x% | 1 | 2&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; 2.x% | 2 | 3&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; 3.x% | 2 | 2&#xD;&#xA; &#xD;&#xA;&gt; 4.x% | 4 | 2&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; \&gt; 5% | 7 | 4&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;That might mean a difference in convention or cstheory just has higher quality questions and answers.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;**What are the conventions and norms for down-voting on cstheory?**" />
./PostHistory.xml:5389:  <row Id="7811" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1119" RevisionGUID="82e0ed97-1dab-41c5-bebf-0b2cb45eacba" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="There are two tags [tag:network-modeling] and [tag:formal-modeling] that broadly speaking address questions where the main goal is to find the right mathematical model for a scenario. ./PostHistory.xml:5390:  <row Id="7812" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1275" RevisionGUID="56e4bf18-6b2d-40ff-b0af-c0a55069823a" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="I think you are referring to  [this](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/7809/all-pairs-shortest-path-in-undirected-and-unweighted-graphs) question.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;What you are saying about the problem is interesting, but I am not sure that was the what the OP was asking, i.e. although there is a research-level answer to the question as you have explained above, the way the question was phrased by the OP didn't seem to be asking for a research level question, it seemed that the user was not aware of standard material on finding all sources shortest path (and honestly it still seems so to me, e.g. &quot;I'm aware that the single source shortest path in a undirected and unweighted graph can be easily solved by BFS.&quot;, or the comment posted by OP as reply to MCH's comment), therefore it seemed to be about material covered in typical undergraduate algorithms courses, and thus off-topic for cstheory.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The question had a close vote and another upvoted comment that this is covered in standard textbooks in algorithms when I migrated it to math.SE. ./PostHistory.xml:5391:  <row Id="7813" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1135" RevisionGUID="e7dedd99-616b-4a63-8975-a70ae235f968" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="A question was asked [regarding the payoff from sampling among Bernoulli variables][1], and was tagged with [tag:machine-learning] and [tag:optimization]. Lev provided a [nice and clean answer][2] explaining that this is a special case of a bandit problem.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Bandit problems are quite common in ML, and there are [six questions][3] on the site about them. But there's no tag, and in all cases, the term appears in the question. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;**My question:**&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; Should we tag the question as `bandit`&#xD;&#xA;&gt; because of the answer, or leave it as&#xD;&#xA;&gt; is because the question was not&#xD;&#xA;&gt; directly related to bandits (relying&#xD;&#xA;&gt; on search to help someone find the&#xD;&#xA;&gt; relevant information)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/6412/optimal-payoff-from-sampling-from-a-collection-of-bernoulli-random-variables&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/6412/optimal-payoff-from-sampling-from-a-collection-of-bernoulli-random-variables/6414#6414&#xD;&#xA;  [3]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/search?q=bandit" />
./PostHistory.xml:5392:  <row Id="7814" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1280" RevisionGUID="c995cdc3-ee81-4486-b721-6ed84015f1b3" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="I was trying to add a bounty to Lawrence Cayton's [question on exact near neighbors][1], but I can nowhere see the link to start a bounty. I've looked at other questions and didn't have a problem seeing the link, so I'm wondering if this is a problem with my machine/browser or is a generic problem. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/7844/exact-nearest-neighbor-in-d-dimensional-euclidean-space" />
./PostHistory.xml:5393:  <row Id="7815" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1137" RevisionGUID="6d10719c-7f42-41e5-ad28-11b0638e918e" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="Should simple but important questions about terminology belong to CSTheory.stackexchange.com?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Questions like this one:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/6420/are-languages-for-grammars-programming-languages&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;If not, to which site it may be moved?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;--------&#xD;&#xA;There are no definitions in Wikipedia's article on programming language.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&quot;A programming language is an artificial language&quot; (1) &quot;designed to express computations that can be performed by a machine, particularly a computer.&quot; (2) &quot;Programming languages can be used to create programs that control the behavior of a machine, to express algorithms precisely, or as a mode of human communication.&quot; (3)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Intended design purposes cannot be part of definition. So we must omit (2). Usage patterns also cannot be part of definition. So we omit (3). The rest is (1) which is very badly stated and clearly incomplete.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&quot;A programming language is a notation for writing programs, which are specifications of a computation or algorithm.&quot;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;No definition of program in Wikipedia and one can not define notion referring to other undefined notion.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;-------&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&quot;A computer program (also a software program, or just a program)&quot; (0) &quot;is a sequence&quot; (1) &quot;of instructions&quot;(2) &quot;written to perform a specified task for a computer.&quot; (3)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;(1) Programs are clearly not always sequences. For example constraints or expressions are clearly not constitute sequences, but sets and trees correspondingly. (2) Programs are not have to be instructions. Are lambda expressions instructions? (3) intended purpose is not part of definition. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;So we have no definition of programming language nor a program in Wikipedia." />
./PostHistory.xml:5394:  <row Id="7816" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1293" RevisionGUID="49507c9f-6681-4b83-b2a5-19712f772f04" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="If we asked a question which was seen as on-topic (and maybe even upvoted) and it hung around on the site for a while, but did not generate an answer. Can we migrate the question to another site where it remains in scope? Or should I just cross-post and double-link?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;As a concrete example, I asked a question about crypto-currency on Jun 28:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/q/7145/1037&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;It generated a answer-comment but not quiet an answer, some upvotes, and otherwise has sat idly on cstheory. Since that time, however, a new SE site sprung up: &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;http://crypto.stackexchange.com/&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Where this question would remain in scope. Does it make sense to migrate the question if the OP (in this case me) agrees? Or would that be bad-practice?" />
./PostHistory.xml:5395:  <row Id="7817" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1168" RevisionGUID="ea588ca7-4840-4cf2-9c1a-887116d5b8c3" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="I've managed to get myself into a rollback war with a user on [this post][1]. The original title was&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; Way of obtaining chomsky normalform,&#xD;&#xA;&gt; does it influence performance of CYK&#xD;&#xA;&gt; parser?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;which I changed to&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; Does the particular CNF representation&#xD;&#xA;&gt; of a grammar influence the performance&#xD;&#xA;&gt; of a CYK parser?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;which the OP then changed back to the original version, which I then changed back, which was then changed by the OP back to &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; Way of obtaining Chomsky normal form,&#xD;&#xA;&gt; does it influence performance of CYK&#xD;&#xA;&gt; parser?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;My understanding from the comments is that the OP is concerned with confusing Chomsky Normal form and Conjunctive normal form, which I agree needs to be disambiguated. However, to my eye at least, the OP's phrasing is not proper English. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Of late, I've been doing 'broken-window' work where I clean up capitalizations and add punctuation etc, on the grounds that a cleaned up question is more likely to be answered, and also reflects better on the page and site as a whole. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;My question is: at what point should I stop attempting to fix grammar on questions when the OP seems unwilling to accept my changes ? &#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/7010/way-of-obtaining-chomsky-normal-form-does-it-influence-performance-of-cyk-parser" />
./PostHistory.xml:5396:  <row Id="7818" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1295" RevisionGUID="62cf3dd0-cfb8-478f-b7f7-bfbfb83e6cba" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="It would be nice to have a set of general recommendations and requirements for users asking &quot;[How to model X][1]&quot;, &quot;[Applications of theory][2]&quot;, and &quot;How to do X&quot; questions where X is an informal task (i.e. not stated in a clear mathematically rigorous way). Having such a list of recommendations and requirements would help the OPs of those post in improving the quality of their question and make it easier for others to answer them.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;MathOverflow has a set of general suggestions on its &quot;[How to ask][3]&quot; page, and we also have some other [general suggestions][4] in our [FAQ][5]. If you have any suggestion please post it below as an answer.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;---&#xD;&#xA;Related meta-discussions:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/514/how-to-model-this-questions&#xD;&#xA;* https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/1251/how-to-deal-with-how-to-do-x-questions-where-x-is-a-very-high-level-software&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I have created a [wiki][6] for formal-modeling tag. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/formal-modeling&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/application-of-theory&#xD;&#xA;  [3]: http://mathoverflow.net/howtoask&#xD;&#xA;  [4]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/faq#questions-should-be-based-on-knowledge-sharing-not-on-shirking&#xD;&#xA;  [5]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/faq&#xD;&#xA;  [6]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/tags/formal-modeling/info" />

./PostHistory.xml:5399:  <row Id="7821" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1299" RevisionGUID="6096d059-251b-41cf-b5eb-dd2bed04ca55" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="In the question: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/4784/compendium-of-the-best-approximation-and-hardness-results-for-np-optimization-pro,&#xD;&#xA;it is pointed out that a wiki for computational problems similar to [Complexity Zoo][1] can be beneficial for the researchers. It is a great help for researchers to know the best algorithmic results (lower and/or bound) related to a problem. Apparently, the zoo people started a new wiki for computational problems: [complexity garden][2]. I contacted the editors of complexity garden and they agreed to devote this wiki to algorithmic results of problems in addition to its original complexity related scope.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Now, I would like to announce this opportunity to populate the Garden. I can add an answer to the above question, but I think not many people will see that. **Is there anyway to announce this using cstheory.stackexchange?**&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://qwiki.stanford.edu/index.php/Complexity_Zoo&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: http://qwiki.stanford.edu/index.php/Complexity_Garden" />

./PostHistory.xml:5402:  <row Id="7824" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1225" RevisionGUID="a83db728-0128-45e1-a4c1-8e5403d9b815" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="I think you can ask a serious question on this without even going all the way to community wiki. I did a similar thing here:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/q/4816/1037&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I ended up asking a very specific question (has reverse mathematics been applied to cstheory) and getting very good specific answers that taught me a lot.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;For the computation axioms it might be better to ask specific questions like: what basic (or philosophical) axioms have been proposed for computation? How do these axioms relate to &quot;specific axioms from paper&quot;? What insights have they given us? What are the limitations of &quot;specific axioms from paper&quot;? How could you modify &quot;specific axioms from paper&quot; to allow quantum computing? Stuff like that.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I think simply asking for community members to contribute individual axioms will result in something pretty chaotic. Partially because you usually want to contribute a set of axioms not a single one, anyways. Also because it is not clear what a ranked list of axioms will mean... but I think this was discussed in the comment thread under Kaveh's answer already.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I definitely support making a blog post about axioms and computation." />

./PostHistory.xml:5404:  <row Id="7826" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1363" RevisionGUID="7cb2119b-b086-4be7-bd36-b318ba434df3" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="Consider the following two questions:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; - [Information leaking of simulation based security][1]&#xD;&#xA; - [Why SHA-224 and SHA-256 use different initial values?][2]&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;There's already a scope clash between [crypto.SE][3] and us, and I think these questions might be examples of questions that could be referred there ? ./PostHistory.xml:5405:  <row Id="7827" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1228" RevisionGUID="f2bc0237-858a-4e9c-9129-68ba4388cf41" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="### change log&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;----&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Jul. 27, 2012:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- Added [academia.se] to the list of suggested sites&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;----&#xD;&#xA;Mar. 20, 2012:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- Added [cs.se] to the list of suggested sites&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;----&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Feb. 23, 2012:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Another small update to the FAQ. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Change log:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; * Added [crypto.se] and [scicomp.se] to the list of suggested sites,&#xD;&#xA; * Made the tips for writing a better question a section.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;----&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Nov. 17, 2011:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I have edited the official FAQ a little bit (mainly adding links to some entries of the official FAQ that we refer to in comments). Please comemnt if you don't like the edits or have other suggestions on how to improve the general FAQ:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;----&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;[FAQ](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/faq)&#xD;&#xA;----&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;**Theoretical Computer Science - Stack Exchange** is for theoretical computer scientists and researchers in related fields.  We welcome _research-level_ questions in _theoretical computer science_ (TCS).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Although there is no black-and-white distinction between research-level questions and non-research-level questions, questions are considered to be &quot;research-level&quot; roughly when they can be discussed between two professors or between two graduate students working on Ph.D.'s, but not usually between a professor and a typical undergraduate student. It does not include questions at the level of difficulty of typical undergraduate course/textbook homework/exercise.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;For an explanation of what TCS is, we refer you to the description of ACM Special Interest Group on Algorithms and Computation Theory (SIGACT):&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; &gt; TCS covers a wide variety of topics including algorithms, data structures, computational complexity, parallel and distributed computation, probabilistic computation, quantum computation, automata theory, information theory, cryptography, program semantics and verification, machine learning, computational biology, computational economics, computational geometry, and computational number theory and algebra.  **Work in this field is often distinguished by its emphasis on mathematical technique and rigor.** &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;##My question is not a research-level question in TCS, where can I ask it?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;For questions other than research-level questions in TCS, you may want to consider the following places to ask:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; * General Computer Science — [Computer Science - Stack Exchange](http://cs.stackexchange.com/)&#xD;&#xA; * General Mathematics (including *theoretical* CS) — [Mathematics - Stack Exchange](https://math.stackexchange.com/)&#xD;&#xA; * Research-level Mathematics — [Math Overflow](http://mathoverflow.net/)&#xD;&#xA; * Social and Professional Academic Issues — [Academia - Stack Exchange](http://academia.stackexchange.com/)&#xD;&#xA; * Programming — [Stack Overflow](http://stackoverflow.com/)&#xD;&#xA; * General Artificial Intelligence — [Meta Optimize](http://metaoptimize.com/qa/)&#xD;&#xA; * Statistics and Data Mining — [Cross Validated](http://stats.stackexchange.com/)&#xD;&#xA; * Applied Cryptography and Security — [Crypto - Stack Exchange](http://crypto.stackexchange.com/)&#xD;&#xA; * Computation used in Science and Engineering — [Computational Science - Stack Exchange](http://scicomp.stackexchange.com/)&#xD;&#xA; * Questions about this site — [Theoretical Computer Science - Stack Exchange - Meta][1]&#xD;&#xA; * Other — check the list of sites on [Stack Exchange Network](http://stackexchange.com/sites)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;##Questions should be based on knowledge sharing, not on shirking&#xD;&#xA;You should only post questions you're actually seriously thinking about. Users are expected to do their part and try to answer their question by themselves before posting them on cstheory and asking for help from others. Search to see if your question is already answered somewhere else (e.g. Wikipedia) before asking a question. **Try to make your question interesting for others by providing some background knowledge**. Remember, *questions should be based on knowledge sharing, not on shirking. Shirking goes against the spirit of the site.* &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;##Tips about writing better questions&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* [How to Ask?](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/how-to-ask)&#xD;&#xA;* [How to ask a good question?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/300/how-to-ask-a-good-question)&#xD;&#xA;* [How to write a good MathOverflow question?](http://mathoverflow.net/howtoask)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Please also check our list of [**useful resources**](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/229#229) *before* asking a question.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;##FAQ&#xD;&#xA;Currently we have two separate lists of FAQs.  See also the longer **[Official Theoretical Computer Science FAQ](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science)**.  Some of the most important entries in the other FAQ are:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; * [How do I write **formulas**?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/237#237)&#xD;&#xA; * [What kind of questions are **too basic**?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/235#235)&#xD;&#xA; * [My (wonderful!) **question got closed**!  What do I do now?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/361#361)&#xD;&#xA; * [What is the **policy on crossposting** to/from MathOverflow?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/231#231)&#xD;&#xA; * [Can I ask about this **cool paper** that I just saw **on the arxiv**?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/274/is-it-ok-to-ask-about-the-correctness-of-preprints-on-crank-friendly-topics/281#281)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" />
./PostHistory.xml:5406:  <row Id="7828" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1372" RevisionGUID="4ec8cdb1-0e04-464e-a21a-0e2b51b29ac0" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="This question is on rewriting of the [automata theory question.][1]&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I am at a loss to understand this extensive rewriting of the question to make it look &quot;research&quot; level. In the process a certain innocence and resonance the question had is gone! It was for precisely this reason that it evoked so many good answers.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;As Noam said [yesterday][2], can we take it easy? Can the site allow some latitude in these matters?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;PS: I appreciate the effort and time that goes into rewriting driven the desire to make this a better site.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Update (from suresh): Here's the original question:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; In class we are currently learning about state machines and so-called&#xD;&#xA;&gt; &quot;regular expressions&quot; and languages that are &quot;accepted&quot;.&#xD;&#xA;&gt; &#xD;&#xA;&gt; This is all interesting stuff we are learning, but I was hoping there&#xD;&#xA;&gt; was a really good reason for learning such a concept...&#xD;&#xA;&gt; &#xD;&#xA;&gt; I know that there is always a way for application in topics related to&#xD;&#xA;&gt; CS theory, but with this whole automata concept I can't really&#xD;&#xA;&gt; extrapolate the cruciality of it... any experts here would like to&#xD;&#xA;&gt; offer their perspective?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;and the final edit (for comparison):&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; There is always a way for application in topics related to theoretical&#xD;&#xA;&gt; computer science. But textbooks and undergraduate courses usually&#xD;&#xA;&gt; don't explain the reason that automata theory is an important topic&#xD;&#xA;&gt; and whether it still has applications in practice. Therefore&#xD;&#xA;&gt; undergraduate students might have trouble in understanding the&#xD;&#xA;&gt; importance of automata theory and might think it is not of any&#xD;&#xA;&gt; practical use anymore.&#xD;&#xA;&gt; &#xD;&#xA;&gt; Is automata theory still useful in practice?&#xD;&#xA;&gt; &#xD;&#xA;&gt; Should it be part of undergraduate CS curriculum?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/q/8539/1449&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/q/1369/1449" />
./PostHistory.xml:5407:  <row Id="7829" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1234" RevisionGUID="a03ed6ae-298b-4a05-a33b-73b3d7c79b35" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="Jeff's answer may not be the answer you are looking for but it doesn't mean that it is not an answer, I personally think it is a good answer to the question. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;You are free to choose to accept whichever answer you like most, and you can vote on answers as you please. Other users are also free to post answers and vote as they please. Looking at the votes, it seems that other users think that Jeff's answer is a good one. You cannot restrict the answers to those answers you like.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;If you don't like the answers you have got so far then check this FAQ entry: [What if I don’t get a good answer?](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/faq#bounty)" />
./PostHistory.xml:5408:  <row Id="7831" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1394" RevisionGUID="7bd59a8d-9168-4a3b-b0c4-872fab676553" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="Lots of people come on this site asking (often) similar questions about PhD.&#xD;&#xA;Shouldn't we create some sort of &quot;Master&quot; question which would appear as 'to read before putting PhD in your title' (amongst the suggestions), and which would answer many of the frequently asked questions?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;This wiki could also give the kind of questions that we will not answer on cstheory.se.&#xD;&#xA;Another advantage would be that it would be easier to refer every one to this question when asking about PhD?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;To be more precise, I was thinking of a CW with all the &quot;mainstream&quot; answers, for the recurrent questions such as : &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  - Litterature&#xD;&#xA;[1](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/8632/phd-development-literature-review-tactics), &#xD;&#xA;[2](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/5613/mathematical-background-needed-for-pursuing-a-phd-in-tcs),&#xD;&#xA;[3](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/5312/what-math-courses-should-i-take-to-prepare-for-a-cs-masters-or-phd),&#xD;&#xA;  - topics&#xD;&#xA;[4](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2783/topic-for-phd-in-computer-science),&#xD;&#xA;[5](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1573/what-topics-are-suggested-for-ph-d-research),&#xD;&#xA;[6](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/5048/deciding-between-different-phd-programs), &#xD;&#xA;[7](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/8780/graduate-studies-phd-in-cs-theory-vs-applied-math),&#xD;&#xA;[8](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2783/topic-for-phd-in-computer-science),&#xD;&#xA;  - fundings&#xD;&#xA;[9](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/7409/funding-opportunities-for-non-european-people-going-to-europe-for-a-phd-in-tcs),&#xD;&#xA;  - Universities/Places/people&#xD;&#xA;[10](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/8787/phd-or-master-augmented-reality-uk),&#xD;&#xA;(see also on [meta](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/996/should-we-allow-this-type-of-question-evaluating-a-doctoral-program-institute))&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;So it could be just stuff like this, I am not saying all the questions I quoted could be put in this CW: some really interesting ones cannot be foreseen and it is really a good thing for this site to have them appearing. However for readability reasons, if at least the main ideas were in the same place it might be easier for the people asking the questions?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Then of course we can create a template that refers to this CW when people ask about PhD." />
./PostHistory.xml:5409:  <row Id="7832" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1243" RevisionGUID="9efe2ea2-8ed2-46f7-9693-d794b1afabe9" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="I started typing up a question on transitioning from quantum to classical random walks on the line, with the punchline being along the lines of:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt;Are there models of decoherence for the quantum walk such that we can tune the walk to spread as $\Theta(t^k)$ for any $1/2 \leq k \leq 1$?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The question is tangentially related to cstheory because classical random walks are useful in algorithm design, and quantum random walks have proven useful for making a number of cool algorithms. Thus, it is important to understand the difference between quantum and classical random walks. Sometimes, the easiest way to do this is to consider toy models, such as walks on the line.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Further, I think there are enough quantum folks at cstheory that I might get a very good answer.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;On the other hand, the question is clearly physics-y and would be of little interest to non-quantum cstheory members. The question would be more at home at [Theoretical Physics.SE](http://area51.stackexchange.com/proposals/23848/theoretical-physics?referrer=3Cmub2jRLCYDvVVb-6SmDQ2) but unfortunately the site has not made it to beta, yet. I could try [physics.SE](http://physics.stackexchange.com/) but a look the question list suggests that that site lost its research focus, and this is a research level question. Also, I check cstheory all the time and enjoy the community, so I prefer to ask questions here.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Should I try asking this question and removing it if the community doesn't approve? Or is this question so clearly off-topic that by asking it I would be setting a bad example?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;EDIT:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;After 3 proceed comments, I posted the question:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/7629/transitioning-from-quantum-to-classical-random-walks-on-the-line&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;If you think there is a way I can improve the question or make it clearer/better motivated please suggest it here or in the comments of the question.&#xD;&#xA;" />

./PostHistory.xml:5418:  <row Id="7842" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1274" RevisionGUID="c818d35e-a75b-4d2f-be08-b1a996f15f30" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="[The question](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/7809/all-pairs-shortest-path-in-undirected-and-unweighted-graphs) (which was &quot;banished&quot; to Math.SE) asks if there is a better solution to APSP than running BFS from each node. That is equivalent to asking if there is an algorithm that runs in less than $O(mn + n^2)$ time. It is a major open problem to improve significantly on this running time: Chan got a $\log n$ speedup in SODA'06 (paper title: &quot;All-pairs shortest paths for unweighted undirected graphs in o(mn) time&quot;) but no further progress has been made. In the undirected and unweighted case, one can solve the problem in matrix multiplication time ($n^{2.376}$) with some ingenious algorithms from the mid-90's (one is due to Seidel).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;So this is a perfectly fine question for CSTheory. Why was it closed and migrated?" />
./PostHistory.xml:5419:  <row Id="7843" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1431" RevisionGUID="9c6454f2-cd79-4773-ad7d-21b83cc92f6f" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="I wanted to contribute &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/9116/in-what-manner-and-to-which-degree-would-programming-on-a-hypothetical-ternary-c&quot;&gt;this question&lt;/a&gt; to this discussion - it's definitely borderline at best as &quot;research-level&quot;, and it would be on topic for a general CS non-research-level site (it's not, strictly speaking, math, so I doubt math.SE would welcome it either), but as it is it's a bit orphaned within stackexchange. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;However, putting the boilerplate &quot;Welcome to cstheory...&quot; on such a question and downvoting may not be terribly helpful - I dislike the outcome SO punting something to us, where we kill it. I think I'd specifically like to suggest that we cut SO migrated questions (that can be answered) a little bit of slack, and try to work with the SO moderators (I don't know how...) to make sure that doesn't happen too much.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;As Suresh says, the example in this original post was actually kind of successful (it was on topic and the migration-repost generated more discussion), so this might be a better example of a less-than-desirable migration. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;" />

./PostHistory.xml:5421:  <row Id="7845" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1282" RevisionGUID="f38107ea-b924-454b-b19f-74cf6e50da90" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="See the bullets at the bottom of&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/faq#bounty&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;For the basic set of rules around bounties. ./PostHistory.xml:5422:  <row Id="7846" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1455" RevisionGUID="dda58074-1243-4849-b3a7-e596b394eac9" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="I decided to turn my comment into an answer.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;1. cstheory is NOT a discussion forum.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;2. The main kind of questions for cstheory are questions *in* TCS. soft-questions can be acceptable (and I have expressed my opinion previously that I support including them in the scope), but they are not the main kind of questions for cstheory (e.g. they are acceptable as long as they are infrequent). soft-questions should be held to higher standards than non-subjective questions in TCS.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;3. I don't like when users who haven't contributed to cstheory drop by from time to time and ask subjective and controversial questions. IMO, these users should first contribute to cstheory by asking and answering questions *in* TCS before asking subjective and possibly controversial questions *about* TCS. soft-question about TCS which are not in the scope (e.g. if the answer to the question is so trivial that any researchers or graduate student in TCS would know the answer like [this](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/9226/whats-a-good-news-source-for-computer-science)) then they are not suitable for cstheory.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;4. Finally, there are different types of soft-questions. In particular, when the question is a subjective one, it can be good subjective soft-question or a bad subjective soft-question. Bad subjective soft-questions should get closed directly. (and IMHO there was not a need for locking this question.)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;See [this post](http://blog.stackoverflow.com/2010/09/good-subjective-bad-subjective/) for more on the distinction between good subjective and bad subjective." />
./PostHistory.xml:5423:  <row Id="7847" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1289" RevisionGUID="725d5456-0d6b-4c86-9d25-f75962831a3d" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="I just noticed that the BibTeX entry provided by the &quot;cite&quot; button on questions is not as good as it could be. For example, let's take the [Problems Between P and NPC](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/q/79/) question. This is the BibTeX entry provided by the stack exchange software:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&lt;pre&gt;&#xD;&#xA;\@MISC {79,&#xD;&#xA;    TITLE = {Problems Between P and NPC},&#xD;&#xA;    AUTHOR = {Lev Reyzin (https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/users/123/lev-reyzin)},&#xD;&#xA;    HOWPUBLISHED = {Theoretical Computer Science},&#xD;&#xA;    NOTE = {URL:https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/q/79 (version: 2011-08-09)},&#xD;&#xA;    EPRINT = {https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/q/79},&#xD;&#xA;    URL = {https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/q/79}&#xD;&#xA;}&#xD;&#xA;&lt;/pre&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;This is how it appears in the bibliography:&#xD;&#xA;&gt;[1] Lev Reyzin (https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/users/123/lev reyzin).  Problems between p and npc.  Theoretical Computer Science.  URL:https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/q/79 (version: 2011-08-09).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Can we change the citation text? This citation has several problems. For example, &quot;Theoretical Computer Science&quot; is already the name of a journal, and the phrase doesn't describe this site. It should be more like &quot;Theoretical Computer Science Stack Exchange&quot; or something to that effect. If we can change this, are there any other changes that we should make?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;For example, this is how MathOverflow generates BibTex entries:&#xD;&#xA;&lt;pre&gt;&#xD;&#xA;@MISC {MO23478,    &#xD;&#xA;    TITLE = {Examples of common false beliefs in mathematics.},    &#xD;&#xA;    AUTHOR = {gowers\phantom{x}(mathoverflow.net/users/1459)},    &#xD;&#xA;    HOWPUBLISHED = {MathOverflow},    &#xD;&#xA;    NOTE = {\url{http://mathoverflow.net/questions/23478} (version: 2010-05-04)},    &#xD;&#xA;    EPRINT = {http://mathoverflow.net/questions/23478},    &#xD;&#xA;    URL = {http://mathoverflow.net/questions/23478},    &#xD;&#xA;}&#xD;&#xA;&lt;/pre&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;This gets rendered as&#xD;&#xA;&gt; [1] gowers  (mathoverﬂow.net/users/1459).   Examples of common false beliefs in mathematics.&#xD;&#xA;MathOverﬂow. [http://mathoverflow.net/questions/23478](http://mathoverflow.net/questions/23478) (version: 2010-05-04).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I like MO's citation. It has a shorter link to the user page (no username in URL), the URL gets linked due to the \url command, and the user URL skips the &quot;http://&quot; part." />
./PostHistory.xml:5424:  <row Id="7849" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1296" RevisionGUID="110d5451-c4e2-4a0c-996c-7f8356ae69fa" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="[Peter Shor][1] and [Aryabhata][2] provide separate arguments for why it's impossible (with linear preprocessing) to [solve membership queries on an unordered set in $O(\log n)$ time][3] in the comparison model. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/7841/comparison-based-data-structure-for-finding-items/7896#7896&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/7841/comparison-based-data-structure-for-finding-items/7939#7939&#xD;&#xA;  [3]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/7841/comparison-based-data-structure-for-finding-items" />

./PostHistory.xml:5426:  <row Id="7851" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1302" RevisionGUID="d679eaf5-8f85-4d3e-8b19-21a9e50976bd" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="I was wondering the same thing. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;It was [an edit suggestion by an anonymous user](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/suggested-edits/207), the edit was a major one and I didn't know enough about the topic to know if it is OK so I didn't approve it. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;It seems that when such an edit suggestion is approved it is shown as an edit by community user." />
./PostHistory.xml:5427:  <row Id="7852" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1473" RevisionGUID="22615269-75a9-4f97-9db7-86973d4de88a" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="I think [trouble-with-paper](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/trouble-with-paper) is not a useful tag. I suggest that we remove it (by merging with tag-removed).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;###update:&#xD;&#xA;Tags for non soft questions are mainly used for subject classification and for keywords (there are some exceptions like reference-request). I think that we should keep the number of these (reference-request like) tags as small as possible. And the burden is on the creator of the tag to justify the usefulness of these tags.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The main use of tags is categorizing question to make it easier to search/ignore/... questions. This tag doesn't express much about the content of the question. It seems very unlikely to me that anyone would use the `trouble-with-paper` tag. It almost feels like tagging a question with a `question` tag." />

./PostHistory.xml:5431:  <row Id="7856" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1358" RevisionGUID="cb4f7453-4d01-42a8-90ef-122275fc4577" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="After reading a [post](http://chat.stackexchange.com/transcript/message/2051962#2051962) by user [Gopi](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/users/4873/gopi) in the chat room, I wrote a [query on Data Explorer which lists the number of questions posted in each month and the number of closed questions among them](http://data.stackexchange.com/theoreticalcomputerscience/s/1921/closed-questions-per-month) (although it is not exactly what Gopi asked).  I will not try to interpret the data here, but if you find it interesting or if you have something to say about it, let me know.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;For the last month in the table, the actual number of questions and closed questions should be larger than the numbers shown in the table because the table is as of the time of the last update of the database.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;[Questions with no answers, low score, and low activity for a while are deleted automatically](https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/81887/what-happens-to-unanswered-questions-from-deleted-accounts/82408#82408).  This means that in most cases, closed questions with negative score which are more than 30 days old and closed questions with score 0 which are more than 365 days old will be deleted and not included in the table.  Therefore, the actual number and the actual rate of closed questions for more than one month old will be higher than shown in the table.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;**Warning**.  I am not familiar with SQL, the language in which this query is written.  Therefore, the query may well contain a bug.  In case you find a bug, I am happy to learn about it.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;**Aside**.  The table shows that there is one question posted in 2008.  Unfortunately this is not an evidence for a time machine.  This question was migrated from another site, and it was posted in 2008 in the original site.  Ideally the query should use the month when the question started to appear on cstheory.stackexchange.com, but I currently ignore this issue because this should affect only the migrated questions and there are not many of them." />
./PostHistory.xml:5432:  <row Id="7857" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1488" RevisionGUID="d455a5d1-4044-42f7-be5e-bea4df47a066" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="While checking [computational science meta](https://scicomp.meta.stackexchange.com/) today, I noticed that my perception about the  [proposal][1]/[site][2] might not be true. mbq, the original person behind the proposal is not that much involved anymore and there has been some changes. See for example [this meta question about their scope][3].&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;My perception was that the site is for &quot;scientists doing science by heavy computations&quot;. But it seems that it might not be true anymore that there are questions about algorithms and distributed computing among other things. I am not saying that there is significant overlap right now (I haven't had time to go over the questions on the site) but I am now concerned about it.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;See also my discussion with Geoff (one of pro-term moderators) [here](https://scicomp.meta.stackexchange.com/a/176/207).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I don't think we want to see another SE site covering a significant part of our scope (as crypto.se did and hit the number of crypto questions on cstheory, see [this](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/tags/cr.crypto-security/topusers)).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Here are some question that I think we need to think about:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; Do you think there is a problem about the current scope of computational sciences site? Do we need to be concerned about this?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; What distinguishes questions that are suitable for cstheory from those on computational sciences and vic versa on overlapping topics (like algorithms, distributed computing, ...)? Is there a significant overlap? &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; What should we do if there is a significant overlap between the two sites?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;----&#xD;&#xA;As a side issue, I feel that we might have an even larger problem when the CS proposal launches if its scope is modified later in such a way that it contains cstheory, and I should say that [the current attitude of the SE team about the proposal description][4] is not comforting for me. As I said earlier, I support a math.se like version of CS, but I don't want it to start to significantly overlap with cstheory. I think the effect of crypto.se on our crypto questions is quite clear.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://area51.stackexchange.com/proposals/28815/computational-science&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: http://scicomp.stackexchange.com/&#xD;&#xA;  [3]: https://scicomp.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/2/lets-define-our-scope&#xD;&#xA;  [4]: http://discuss.area51.stackexchange.com/questions/4226/computer-science-the-audience-description-is-now-wrong" />
./PostHistory.xml:5433:  <row Id="7858" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1367" RevisionGUID="8c9af5e5-e274-4e3a-89d4-6e2eced0937d" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="(This is a more detailed version of my comment on the question.)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Closing and deletion are different notions.  (But some closed and even non-closed questions are deleted automatically.  See below.)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* Closed but not deleted questions are listed in your profile.&#xD;&#xA;* Unless you have [reputation points ≥ 10,000](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/privileges/moderator-tools) or you are a moderator, you cannot view deleted questions (including your own questions which have been deleted).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;There is a [feature request on Meta Stack Overflow](https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/2645/show-all-of-my-question-answers-to-me-even-if-they-are-deleted) to allow a user to see his/her own questions which have been deleted, but this request was declined in June 2010.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### Why are some closed (and even non-closed) questions deleted automatically?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;If a question has no answers, low score, and no activity for a long time, it is deleted automatically.  Closed questions tend to have low score and low activity, and therefore I imagine that they are often subject to this automatic deletion mechanism.  See [this post](https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/81887/what-happens-to-unanswered-questions-from-deleted-accounts/82408#82408) for the gory details.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;See [this](https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/65768/do-closed-questions-get-deleted-automatically-after-some-time) for another reason why closed questions may be deleted earlier than the automatic deletion kicks in." />

./PostHistory.xml:5436:  <row Id="7861" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1497" RevisionGUID="b9b9d7aa-3f3d-4a51-8ef8-66edf39a939b" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="I was trying to edit [this question][1] to get the rendering of arrays working. ./PostHistory.xml:5437:  <row Id="7862" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1404" RevisionGUID="9be63e8d-51ff-4587-b2da-5c9366cf9a49" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="Zirui, cstheory is a Q&amp;A site with a scope defined in its FAQ. The scope of cstheory is research-level. Questions that are at the level of difficulty of typical undergraduate students are not part of the scope. There are other Q&amp;A sites which have a more general scope like [Math.SE][1] that would welcome questions from students.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Votes (down and up) are one of the main ways users express their opinion about the quality of a question and how interesting it is. A user may down vote a question if she/he thinks the question is off-topic or has other problems (e.g. unclear, not answerable in its current form, argumentative, not a real question, post to solicit opinion, ...).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;----&#xD;&#xA;If you want to know why [your question](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/8826/is-halting-that-hard-yes) is down voted you can ask for that in place of attacking other users. I will explain my down vote in more detail below:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;It seems to me that you are trying to find a way to get around the undecidability of halting problem. The halting problem (as it is defined in the literature) is undecidable and that is a mathematical theorem. Now one might be interested in decidable variations of halting problem. That is a well studied topic, and one can ask a research level question about that. There are also researchers working on these kind of problems who try to find ways to deal with undecidability in practice (mainly in formal methods community, but also in theoretical computer science). &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;On the other hand your question has no sign that you are familiar with the literature. I can tell that this is something a typical undergraduate student taking their first course in computability would ask. It is nice that a student would think about this kind of problems. But everything has a place and the place of this question is not cstheory. If you ask it on Math.SE you probably will not get any down votes. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;As an analogy, it is completely fine and even encouraged that students ask questions like this in an undergraduate computability class from the instructor. Asking it in a research-level computability workshop will probably be unwelcome.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;If you ask a question about halting problem and show that you are familiar with the literature and understand the basics in the area, and the question is a real question (posting a question to see how others think about your idea about how to solve halting problem is not a real question) and is clearly stated (can be answered without much back-and-forth comments where others try to guess what you want to ask, which can be a sign that the question is not well-thought), then that can be on-topic and I would guess would not receive any down votes.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;ps:&#xD;&#xA;I would suggest that you take a look at the [this section of the FAQ](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/faq#questions-should-be-based-on-knowledge-sharing-not-on-shirking) and also the pages linked there. Following those suggestions would increase the chance that your questions are well perceived by the community.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://math.stackexchange.com/&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/faq" />
./PostHistory.xml:5438:  <row Id="7863" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1507" RevisionGUID="2806b738-9ec0-4134-b602-b056ca26ba6a" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="We have a few questions where it seemed like cs.SE might be their natural home. ./PostHistory.xml:5446:  <row Id="7871" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1490" RevisionGUID="3ae2677d-a59b-4723-ab5e-5eef7d70963b" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="I flagged the second answer in [a question I asked][1] because it is only a reply to a comment I left in the first answer. ./PostHistory.xml:5447:  <row Id="7872" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1554" RevisionGUID="1e1dcd22-248b-443f-afbb-21af1d8a53df" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="I wonder who on earth would be happy to read a series of long, boilerplate comments such as:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; Welcome to cstheory, a Q&amp;A site for _research-level_ questions in _theoretical computer science_ (TCS). Your question does not appear to be a research-level question in TCS. Please see the [FAQ](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/faq) for more information on what is meant by this and suggestions for sites that might welcome your question. Finally, if your question is closed for being out of scope, and you believe you can edit the question to make it a research-level question, please feel free to do so. Closing is not permanent and questions can be reopened, check the [FAQ](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/faq) for more information.&#xD;&#xA;&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; Please add some context/background/motivation for the question if you think the question is a research-level question and in [Theoretical Computer Science](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/)'s scope. You can find tips about writing a better question in our FAQ. For general level questions please consider posting on [Computer Science](http://cs.stackexchange.com/).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I know, these comments partly came from [another thread on meta](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/1381/comment-templates), but this does not change the fact that they are stupidly long.  Please do not use them.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;_Added_: It is fine to argue that in theory, it should be possible to improve the templates to make it concise and to the point.  I have seen this argument many times.  In practice, no one has ever been able to make such an edit, and I think that there is a good reason why it is impossible.  If you have time to argue the theoretical possibility, just edit the templates instead and have it done.&#xD;&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:5448:  <row Id="7873" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1547" RevisionGUID="1f68ee07-d4bf-488e-a2d4-7c567cccd5f9" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="First, make sure that the question is really not suitable.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;If you are sure that it is not suitable, then it is better to do something about it than just leave it as it is.  There are five options: edit, delete, vote to close, flag, and leave a comment.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### Edit a question&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;If you can change the question so that it is suitable, please edit it.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;But please do not edit one question to a completely unrelated question!  It is better to keep different questions separate.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### Delete a question&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;You can delete your own question if you are a registered user of the website and the question has not received an answer.  (For the precise conditions when you can and cannot delete your own post, see “When _can’t_ I delete my own post?” in [this post on Meta Stack Overflow](https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/5221/what-can-cause-a-post-to-be-deleted-and-what-does-that-actually-mean/5222#5222)).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Deleted questions do not appear in lists of questions (including your own profile page), and most non-moderator users cannot read deleted questions.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;For some reason, when you click “delete” link of your question, the system asks “Vote to delete this post?” suggesting that you are merely _voting_ to delete instead of deleting, but this is probably just a glitch in the system; if you click “Yes,” the post is deleted immediately.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### Vote to close a question&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;You can cast a close vote to your own question if your reputation points is 250 or higher.  See [this page](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/privileges/view-close-votes) for an explanation of closure (not in the mathematical sense).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### Flag a question for moderator attention&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;If none of the above helps and you need a help about usage of the website from moderators, please flag your own question for moderator attention.  Please explain what help you need in the flag dialog box.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;[This page](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/privileges/flag-posts) states that you need at least 15 reputation points to flag a post.  I do not know if this applies also to flagging your own post.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### Leave a comment&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;You can always post a comment on your question.  Even when you cannot delete, vote to close, or flag, and you cannot think of a way to edit the question so that it becomes suitable, it is probably better to leave a comment that you are aware that you posted an inappropriate question.  In addition, if you need some help about usage of the website and you cannot flag the post, posting a comment might get some user’s attention.&#xD;&#xA;" />

./PostHistory.xml:5450:  <row Id="7875" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1553" RevisionGUID="ed0f8ad8-ee9d-443e-931d-8bb89bed0a6b" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="We have two relatively popular tags [tag:lg.learning] (53 questions) and [tag:machine-learning] (75 questions). However, I am not sure where the line between the two is drawn. For lg.learning wiki we have:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt;Tag [tag:lg.learning] refers to the research area of [machine learning](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Machine_learning), and [learning theory](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computational_learning_theory) specifically (falling under [arXiv](http://arxiv.org/archive/cs)'s [cs.LG - Learning](http://arxiv.org/list/cs.LG/recent)), as opposed to the general practice of learning.  This tag includes the theory of PAC learning, algorithmic learning theory, and computational aspects of Bayesian inference and graphical models.  Questions about implementation issues and statistical properties of machine learning systems are more likely to be welcomed at the [CrossValidated](http://stats.stackexchange.com/) or [MetaOptimize Q&amp;A](http://metaoptimize.com/qa/) sites.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt;The questions _must_ satisfy the usual scope requirements for cstheory as explained in the [FAQ](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/faq).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;And for [tag:machine-learning] we have the wiki-excerpt:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt;Theoretical questions about Machine learning, especially Computational Learning Theory, including Algorithmic Learning Theory, PAC learning, and Bayesian Inference&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;and the whole wiki:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt;This tag should be used for *theoretical* questions related to Machine Learning (roughly falling under [arXiv](http://arxiv.org/archive/cs)'s [cs.LG - Learning](http://arxiv.org/list/cs.LG/recent)).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt;The question _must_ satisfy the usual scope requirements for cstheory as explained in the [FAQ](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/faq).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt;You may also want to check AI Q&amp;A site [Meta Optimize](http://metaoptimize.com/qa/) which has a more general AI scope.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;To me, it seems that we are using them as synonyms. Is this the case? If so, then which should be the main tag? lg.learning follows our ArXiv tag convention, but machine-learning is more popular and more likely to be searched for." />
./PostHistory.xml:5451:  <row Id="7876" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1570" RevisionGUID="fe8e973c-bef3-451b-bded-5ae38e22729d" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="One issue that we should be careful and is included in the FAQ is that people should ask questions that they really care about. If you intend or are thinking about working on a related problem then the question can be fine and explaining this motivation and the kind of problems that you want to work on would make the question focused. On the other hand, an out of curiosity question is not a real question, neither questions that are intended to be discussions about a topic or solicit opinions about it.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;We have many tips in [the meta post about writing and asking better questions][1] and there are a [few more links][2] to similar advice in the FAQ that you should check if you haven't. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The problem is that some users insist on ignoring these even if they are reminded several times by various people.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/300/how-to-ask-a-good-question&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/faq#tips-about-writing-better-questions" />
./PostHistory.xml:5452:  <row Id="7877" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1596" RevisionGUID="9336d8ea-dbf8-4ff3-8213-037f8dcf2614" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="Some of the comments on [Gil's recent question](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/12558/a-notion-of-monotone-quantum-circuits#question) are flagged as not-constructive.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;They are not literally offensive or rude, they are not irrelevant to the question, but honestly they don't seem to contain anything that anyone who is a little bit familiar with the topics would not know (and surely Gil is more that a little bit familiar with these topics). In other words, anyone could have written a similar comment. They don't add any new information/knowledge.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The reasons for flagging a comment supported by the software are:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* rude or offensive&#xD;&#xA;* not constructive / off-topic&#xD;&#xA;* obsolete&#xD;&#xA;* too chatty&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I am not sure if any of them applies to these comments (maybe &quot;too chatty&quot;?). On the other hand I personally feel that leaving such comments are inappropriate and possibly harmful to the usefulness of the site (as I understand, people don't come here to read general comments that anyone would know or could find out by a simple Google search but to ask question from people who have expertise on those topics).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;On cstheory, we generally don't remove comments as long as they are not really off-topic or clearly rude.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Is leaving general comments that do not add any significant information to the question OK?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Questions that are answerable by simple Googling or looking at the relevant Wikipedia article are considered off-topic on cstheory. Should these criteria also apply to other posts on the site like comments?" />
./PostHistory.xml:5453:  <row Id="7878" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1560" RevisionGUID="128eed81-3c08-4540-8869-9ee85234b46a" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="[The comment][1] you left on the question was for an *unregistered* user. A person doesn't need to create an account to post questions/answers. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Note also that a user **cannot** delete their account by themselves (if they have interacted with the site, have cast votes or have posted questions/answers). To delete a user account you have to involve an SE or a community moderator. Please see [this](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/help/user-deletion) for further information and the process through which a user can ask SE for deletion of their account. &#xD;&#xA;In short, what you have described cannot happen.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I personally haven't seen any request for deletion recently (can't remember when was the last time).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Regarding asking questions anonymously, by default, asking questions or answering questions using pseudo-names or anonymously is completely fine. People have various reasons to remain anonymous or to use pseudo-names. I don't see any reason to be annoyed about this. If you don't like such users don't interact with them. Whether to remain anonymous or to reveal identity is that user choice, not yours nor ours. If there is a problem about a question posted by an anonymous user (e.g. it is a homework questions) then we can discuss that particular case separately. By itself remaining anonymous on the site is completely fine. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Please don't write comments like &quot;And we we would love to know who you are!&quot;. This is not constructive. A user doesn't need to reveal their identity to ask questions. People are welcome to post questions and answer anonymously. Also, IMO, down-voting questions just because they are posted anonymously is a very bad behavior.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/12172/can-addition-be-carried-out-in-less-than-depth-5#comment33412_12172" />
./PostHistory.xml:5454:  <row Id="7881" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1639" RevisionGUID="811f43d9-4a24-4c13-97e5-8c2a50a51b8e" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="I was quite happy to see the question [Pointers for CS applications of logic][1]. Scott Aaronson in his blog sometimes uses the scenario of super-intelligent alien beings having a discussion with us to emphasise the universality of certain notions in mathematics or computer science. This post felt like a very scaled-down but realistic form of that thought experiment. A person from a different, but closely related field comes to us and says, &quot;we do logic, you do logic, and we have all these cool results, but what do you have to show for your logic.&quot;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; It is difficult to tell from the wording how deep the author's knowledge of classical mathematical logic is, but the question does request for answers that appeal to advanced logical concepts. I was absolutely gung-ho about writing an answer because questions that specifically want and advanced-level survey are rare. A couple of hours later, I realised that this was never going to end. I'm glad to see that the question has now been made community wiki. I think my current answer is too long and should be split into different answers. I have three concrete proposals for answers to that question. Please let me know if you agree with these proposals.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;*Proposal 1*. Every answer discusses a specific sub-area of computational logic and consists of three paragraphs. The first paragraph give a high-level overview of the field aimed at researchers in mathematics or TCS. The second paragraph highlights some results in the field and techniques used to prove those results. The third paragraph mentions current directions and open problems.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;*Proposal 2*. We make a &quot;table of contents&quot; answer that lists different sub-areas of computational logic and hyperlinks to the different answers. Anyone can add to this list, and then add a separate answer for the area mentioned.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;*Proposal 3.* If the OP agrees, we modify the original question a bit to make explicit the structure desired for answers. (We could also do this in the ToC answer I suggest in Proposal 2, but people might not read other answers before replying.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I feel such an advanced research summary would be a valuable resource for the future reference, and that obtaining such a survey via our user base would be effective. If it works here, we could also follow a similar protocol/structure for certain other broad reference requests. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;What say ye?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/15061/pointers-for-cs-applications-of-logic" />

./PostHistory.xml:5456:  <row Id="7883" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1592" RevisionGUID="2be1b448-91f7-48cd-b72d-4e236ddb4dcf" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="I've posted my first question:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/12585/to-what-extent-can-an-algorithm-predict-the-time-complexity-an-arbitrary-input-p#12585&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Which admittedly is not a graduate-level question, and thus not covered under the scope of this site. Given that the question was rejected from Stack Overflow for being too advanced, and now rejected from TCS for being _not advanced enough_, what are some guidelines for determining which site to send a question to? It has been suggested that this particular question can be sent to both [SE Programmers][1] and [SE CS][2], so there are four candidate sites.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I ask because the scope of each site FAQ overlaps quite a bit and I feel that, for a question like this, it can fit into several categories. As somebody familiar with the SO board, but not with these sites - it is daunting to figure out where to place my question (and others like it).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://softwareengineering.stackexchange.com/&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: http://cs.stackexchange.com/" />
./PostHistory.xml:5457:  <row Id="7884" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1614" RevisionGUID="b3f51d9d-4d7c-4aae-8d6e-fbedd911b39a" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="I [asked a question][1] which was somewhat popular and after some time got a very nice answer. I accepted the answer and made an edit with a [fairly minor correction][2] to the answer. My edit was rejected, and it's not clear to me why (the message is &quot;changes too much in the original post,&quot; but it simply corrects half of a sentence). While I would welcome specifics about my edit, I don't care too much about the particular fix and I do not want to make a big deal about it.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I'm mostly wondering for the larger picture if there is a good way to avoid this situation recurring. Some possibilities:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; - Longer or more detailed and specific messages for rejected edits. The message I got looks like it was from a drop-down, and so maybe the reason did not fit nicely into a category.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; - Some system for moderators to defer to the opinion of the original author of the content that was edited, because he may be able to judge the edit more easily (being more familiar with what he wrote)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; - Some form of edits that are &quot;unapproved&quot; but optionally visible to users (e.g. a comment shows up below the post with my name that says &quot;this is my revised version of what I think the above should say, but [moderator] believes it might change the author's intent&quot;).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I realize that not many edits are rejected though, so perhaps I'm in the minority here, and focus on this issue would be misplaced. I'm also not sure of the technical feasibility of any of these suggestions, and perhaps that rules some or all of them out.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;**Edit:** In a discussion on the linked post I got some more details about the specifics of why my edit might not be preferred. Based on that it seems more likely that the problem is to do with feedback accompanying a rejected edit rather than the actual decision of whether to accept/reject (and so the first bullet would likely be the most appropriate fix).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Also, as one who hasn't edited or reviewed an edit I do not have a good feel for the bounds on the scope of edits; perhaps all other edits here have just been re-taggings and math-modes, and mine should have been a comment instead. Is this scope discussed somewhere? If not, should it be? Maybe that's the fix.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/14319/natural-clique-to-k-color-reduction&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/review/suggested-edits/2603" />
