./PostHistory.xml:5460:  <row Id="7887" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1616" RevisionGUID="c50a1167-b56b-455c-92f3-a9de428a51ec" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="For every question and answer, share-&gt;cite results in a suggested BibTeX citation.  Now that people are actually [starting to cite the site][1], I think we need to revise the template so it is more useful.  This would also help nudge the diversity of possible ways to cite the site into fewer likely channels.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;First, the existing text &quot;Theoretical Computer Science&quot; is not useful, since the maximum likelihood match for that phrase is the long-established Elsevier journal of that name.  &quot;Theoretical Computer Science Stack Exchange&quot; seems a better phrase.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Second, it seems important to indicate whether the citation is to the question itself, or to a specific answer, in the text itself and not just the URL.  The title that the citation template generates is the title of the question, and I suggest something like &quot;Response to: &quot; as a prefix for answers, or a suffix of the form &quot; (response)&quot;.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Finally, I would like to be able to cite specific comments, and # link to the comment.  However, SE seems to deliberately downplay comments, unlike MO, so I am not holding my breath.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/a/14547" />
./PostHistory.xml:5461:  <row Id="7888" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2646" RevisionGUID="6ddb5439-6594-4d8e-aa1d-6cad0a3853ca" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="Below I am mainly talking about the recent question “[Counting number of increasing subsequences of length k](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/16419/counting-number-of-increasing-subsequences-of-length-k)” by orryowr, but I want answers which are not specific to this question.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Suppose that a user wants to ask a question, and he/she finds out that the question has been already asked and answered.  However, the answers posted there are not satisfactory because they are unclear or they are not answers to the exact question being asked.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Is there a good way to to ask for a clearer or better answer to an old question?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The following are some ways, but they have their own disadvantages.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;One thing he/she can do is to post a question nevertheless, probably stating why the existing answers are not satisfactory.  However, from answerer’s viewpoint, I think that it is better to post a new answer to the _old_ question or edit an answer to the old question rather than posting an answer to the new question, because it is the same question and it is just a better answer.  Therefore, I think that in this situation, the new question should be closed as a duplicate for the old question.  Now from asker’s viewpoint, it is awkward (or possibly even abusive) to post a question knowing that it will be closed as a duplicate of the old question.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Another thing is to write a comment to the old question or its answer.  But if the user is new, he/she cannot post a comment.  In addition, if the user who made that post is no longer active, chances that anyone notices the comment are slim.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Another thing is to edit something in the old question or propose an edit.  If the user has enough rep points, he/she can edit a post.  Add a tag or correct a typo or make some other harmless edit, and the question is bumped on the top page and it receives some attention.  Proposing an edit has one obstacle, but if the proposed edit is accepted, it has the same effect.  But either way, this sounds like an abusive or spam-like activity to me.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Another thing is to bring this up in chat room.  Problems are that it is usually not active, and that if the user is new, he/she cannot post a message in chat.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Another thing is bounty, but this requires some rep points.&#xD;&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:5462:  <row Id="7889" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2678" RevisionGUID="766a5a74-7402-47cf-b055-6903808bf3c2" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="While I was reviewing, I flagged&#xD;&#xA;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/17571/context-free-language as&#xD;&#xA;&lt;br&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&quot;very low quality&quot;, although I was somewhat hesitant about doing so.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Was I correct to flag it as that?&#xD;&#xA;&lt;br&gt;&#xD;&#xA;Is there any other guidance about using that flag?&#xD;&#xA;&lt;br&gt;&#xD;&#xA;(I would imagine some examples of &quot;narrowly qualifies&quot; and &quot;narrowly does not qualify.)" />
./PostHistory.xml:5463:  <row Id="7890" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2651" RevisionGUID="9eb87734-a3a1-42ab-a9f2-2342e5cd55cf" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="I was marking [a question][1] as off-topic and the modal made me choose only between these two options:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; - *belongs to meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com*&#xD;&#xA; - *belongs to stackoverflow.com* &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Is that list automatically generated or we have control over it? ./PostHistory.xml:5464:  <row Id="7891" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2692" RevisionGUID="bce2cfdd-3771-4400-9a18-4a860c2e3bb1" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="##Introduction:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;###September 20, 2013:&#xD;&#xA;Added a link to CS.SE.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;###June 25, 2013:&#xD;&#xA;Adding a link to our FAQ, plus some rewording.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Theoretical Computer Science - Stack Exchange&lt;/strong&gt; &#xD;&#xA;is a question and answer site for&#xD;&#xA;&lt;i&gt;professional researchers in theoretical computer science&lt;/i&gt; and &#xD;&#xA;related fields.&#xD;&#xA; &#xD;&#xA;&gt;It's built and run &lt;em&gt;by users&lt;/em&gt; as a part of the &#xD;&#xA;&lt;a href=&quot;http://stackexchange.com&quot;&gt;Stack Exchange&lt;/a&gt; network of Q&amp;amp;A sites.&#xD;&#xA;We welcome you to join us in asking and answering &#xD;&#xA;&lt;strong&gt;research-level&lt;/strong&gt; questions in &#xD;&#xA;&lt;strong&gt;theoretical&lt;/strong&gt; computer science.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt;For &lt;strong&gt;undergraduate-level questions&lt;/strong&gt;&#xD;&#xA;please visit&#xD;&#xA;&lt;a href=&quot;http://cs.stackexchange.com&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Computer Science&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&#xD;&#xA;which has a broader scope.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt;For more information about the scope&#xD;&#xA;please check out our [FAQ](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/help/on-topic)." />
./PostHistory.xml:5465:  <row Id="7892" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2653" RevisionGUID="a1282a00-d1c6-467f-85a5-92372ce80724" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="This is request for comment from the community regarding the following question:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/q/16500/&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;1. Is the question in its current form suitable for the site?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;2. If it is not, was closing it by a community moderator justified? Or was it  excessive use of moderator powers?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;3. If the question is not suitable in its current form and moderator action was excessive, how should we deal with it?" />
./PostHistory.xml:5466:  <row Id="7893" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2706" RevisionGUID="6d61cedd-999a-4a13-88ad-30ffaf9b2392" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="It's standard practice here to close questions that are too elementary to be considered &quot;research-level&quot;.  But I think people have been too quick to label some questions as &quot;too elementary&quot;, when in fact they describe very real research-level questions.  For example:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* [How are lower bounds for computational complexity proved?](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/q/18372/111)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* [Roots of a polynomial](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/q/18406/111)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;In both cases, there is an undergraduate-level &quot;textbook&quot; answer.  (For the first question: Sorting requires $\Omega(n\log n)$ comparisons.  For the second question: Hilbert's 10th is undecidable.)  But if we look past those easy answers, these are legitimate research-level questions in theoretical computer science.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* Okay, but then how does one prove lower bounds for problems that can't be solved by comparison trees?  Or lower bounds bigger than $\Omega(n\log n)$ for problems solvable in polynomial time?  Or exponential lower bounds for NP-hard problems?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* Okay, but then how does one actually find integer roots of polynomials in practice?  Are there effective algorithms for broad and interesting classes of polynomials?  Are there algorithms with provable approximation guarantees (for interesting classes of polynomials)?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;In both cases, the deeper question is likely not what the original poster intended.  (But StackExchange answers are for the entire community, not just for the original poster.  And why should we shy away from blowing the original poster's mind?)  And even if it were, the posts would require significant editing to bring the deeper question to the fore.  (But editing good questions is generally preferred to closing them.)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;**Should we really close such questions?**  Or am I just being a smartass?" />
./PostHistory.xml:5467:  <row Id="7894" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2722" RevisionGUID="34a75d7a-3cb4-4f4c-be2f-99f6837fdb81" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="I just noticed [this question](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/18912/polar-coding-decoding), asked by a new user, which has two downvotes with no comments. I don't think this question is bad—it could use more explanation, and more demonstration of the OP's having put effort into figuring out the answer. But how can the OP know how to improve the question without getting comments? &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Is there anything we can do so that we stop discouraging people from asking questions on this site by downvoting them indiscriminately? " />
./PostHistory.xml:5468:  <row Id="7895" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2655" RevisionGUID="5b0a0562-5364-4f83-a737-561e1eb26682" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="My view is simply this: moderator powers should be used lightly, and only when the community mechanisms are insufficient to correct a situation. In the case of the above question, here's what my personal (i.e non-moderator) take is:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* the question rambles terribly and doesn't really get to the point&#xD;&#xA;* the poster has a habit of writing questions and answers like this, and frequently gets downvoted/otherwise censured for such postings&#xD;&#xA;* But in this case, another user has suggested a concrete improvement that can be made, and there are a number of upvotes (and faves) for the question. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;So the moderator role here is to help suggest modifications (especially since there appears to be a germ of substance in the question) and encourage the OP to make the changes (which I will note the OP has **not** done). As an individual, the moderator is free to downvote the post in its current form. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;But as a community moderator, I prefer to do nothing rather than do something, and in this case I have to ask what the consequences are of doing nothing. Either the OP will fix the post or not. If not, it's quite likely that other members of the community will downvote the post and/or vote to close it. Or they might attempt to answer the question. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The &quot;worst case scenario&quot; from my point of view might be that an ill-formed question sticks around for a while. But what is the downside of this ? The OP regularly posts ill-formed questions, and they get hammered ([about 2/3 of the questions posted][1] have a net negative score). Clearly the OP is not learning anything from the community view on their question formulation, but I don't see any evidence that these questions are affecting others, or reducing the quality of the site.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Either way, there are sufficiently many options available to the community at large that I (as moderator) don't need to step in. And that's my underlying philosophy. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/users/7884/vzn?tab=questions&amp;sort=votes" />
./PostHistory.xml:5469:  <row Id="7896" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2724" RevisionGUID="d5384f9c-bab1-48a0-a4bc-78c3a10408c1" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="There are several reasons to down-vote a post. We have discussed previously (see [this](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/1264/) and [this](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/1395/)) that we are not going to require or even demand people to explain their votes. When I see a down-vote that I don't understand I politely comment that I don't understand it, but I think demanding an explanation or stating that there is no reason for the down-vote goes too far. It is not an abuse if people are using their votes in a way different from us.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I have argued a number of times that I am against counter-voting, that is voting to null the effect of another user's vote. Everyone has their own opinion. The total reflects the opinion of the community, it is not the job of any particular user to decide what the total should be. Counter-voting encourages other users to do the same and use their votes to null votes in place of express their opinion about the question. Each vote is a manifestation of some user's opinion and if we respect their opinions then we should respect their votes even when we disagree with them.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I think it is more productive if we comment and explain why we think it is a suitable and interesting question in place of just asking others why they have down-voted the post.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;In this particular case, I see several possible reasons for a down-vote. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;1. Formating: It is using an image in place of writing the expression which I think has been one of the reasons people down-vote. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;2. Content: The questions seems to simply ask how to calculate some expression for some particular values. It seems to ask how to apply a method explained in a paper in a particular case in practice. It is too localized and it doesn't seem to be a _research-level_ question in _theoretical_ computer science. It is also unclear what is the trouble the OP is facing in calculating the expression.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;If you ask me I think we are being too open right now (I guess it is partly because people get bored that there are not as many questions as they would like) to questions which should not be here and are more suitable for CS.SE. E.g. [1](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/18703/are-randomized-algorithms-considered-as-complete), [2](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/18628/confused-about-disparity-and-depth-map), [3](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/18886/proof-that-turing-machine-and-lambda-calculus-are-equivalent), [4](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/18575/pigeon-holing-or-bucketing-a-number-based-on-a-set-of-ranges) have been in [the closing review queue][1] for sometime but have not been put _on-hold_. Similarly, it is not clear what [this question](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/18871/bounded-computation-and-incompleteness/18883) is asking and should be put _on-hold_ until clarified but it does not have a single close vote. And [this](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/18903/how-would-the-use-of-ternary-computers-change-complexity-of-algorithms) is clearly not-research level in my opinion.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/tools?tab=close&amp;daterange=last30days" />
./PostHistory.xml:5470:  <row Id="7897" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2660" RevisionGUID="db26c76e-6ba2-4f57-b2dc-236f09983447" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="Here is my opinion and some more general points:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;We interpret &quot;theory&quot; in TCS *broadly*, so in general interdisciplinary questions *can be* on-topic on cstheory. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The main questions one should ask oneself before posting a question on cstheory are:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* **Is there a reason to think that I will receive a *satisfying answer* to my question from theoretical computer scientists?**&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* **Is there a reason to think that answering the question *requires* the expertise of theoretical computer scientists?**&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;If **yes** then cstheory can be a good place to **ask it**.&#xD;&#xA; &#xD;&#xA;If **no** (e.g. an expert in cognitive science is more likely to answer the question in a satisfying manner for OP, or there is no reason to believe answering the question needs the expertise of a theoretical computer scientist) then **probably not**.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;It might be good to think about this and include it in your question as motivation, it can make it interesting for other users.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;You should also formulate your question such that it does not fall into *non-constructive* or *not-a-real-question* categories. When people ask a question they are seeking help from others, they are asking others to spend time to read and think about the question. So we expect people to ask only questions that they *really* care about (if you really care about a question you will spend time and effort on it, and the effort correlates with the quality of the question). We expect people to spend time doing their part before asking others for help, e.g. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* **You have tried to answer your question yourself first (Google, Wikipedia, Complexity Zoo, etc.) before asking it on cstheory,**&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* **You have thought about the question enough to be able to formulate it clearly and in a way that can be answered, you know what you are looking for,**&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* **You have spent time to formulate your question using the language and terminology of theoretical computer scientists and following the norms of their community,**&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* **You have spend time to write your question in a clear and easy to understand format for theoretical computer scientists.**&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;FAQ contains more [tips about writing better questions](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/faq#tips-about-writing-better-questions)." />
./PostHistory.xml:5471:  <row Id="7898" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2673" RevisionGUID="dd80c33e-9444-4d31-9183-1d465817d390" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="Can someone migrate [this question](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/17451/is-there-a-general-way-to-convert-a-critical-section-to-one-or-more-semaphores) to either cs.stackexchange or stackoverflow?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;10 or so hours ago I flagged it as off topic because I wasn't allowed&#xD;&#xA;&lt;br&gt;&#xD;&#xA;to suggest cs.stackexchange as a migration target, but after looking&#xD;&#xA;&lt;br&gt;&#xD;&#xA;at it again, I think stackoverflow would be a better site for it.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;(Also, was &quot;discussion&quot; the right one of the four bold tags for this?)" />
./PostHistory.xml:5472:  <row Id="7899" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2748" RevisionGUID="5ca71bc0-a817-4e0e-87d3-e531d6d0c051" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="There used to be a &quot;too localized&quot; close reason.&#xD;&#xA;What should we do with question which are really unlikely to be of use to any one except the OP?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;E.g. consider the following question:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/q/20227/&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I am hesitant to close it as not research level because it is about understanding a paper.&#xD;&#xA;On the other hand the issue was the OP missing a simple point while reading the paper.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I also don't see how to edit the question to make it a question useful for others.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;What should we do in this and similar cases?" />
./PostHistory.xml:5473:  <row Id="7900" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2675" RevisionGUID="f7623b3a-da54-477e-b1f0-e4694438cc96" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="I don't think that is appropriate. cstheory is a Q&amp;A site. ./PostHistory.xml:5474:  <row Id="7901" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2759" RevisionGUID="daf0ab45-f554-49c9-b13f-a6db1d7a0416" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="I asked a question here. https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/20410/idea-for-proving-that-p-neq-np-implies-one-way-functions-exist&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I would really like to know the answer to it, but it is on hold. ./PostHistory.xml:5475:  <row Id="7902" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2677" RevisionGUID="3904acec-d199-4494-9fc7-5defbc1491e2" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="Currently they are as follows:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I. Introduction:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; &lt;strong&gt;Theoretical Computer Science Stack Exchange&lt;/strong&gt; is a question and answer site for theoretical computer scientists and researchers in related fields. It's built and run &lt;em&gt;by you&lt;/em&gt; as part of the &lt;a href=&quot;http://stackexchange.com&quot;&gt;Stack Exchange&lt;/a&gt; network of Q&amp;amp;A sites. With your help, we're working together to build a library of detailed answers to every question about theoretical computer science.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;II. The sample question displayed:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/4027/coloring-planar-graphs&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;III. Ask about:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; - Specific *research-level* questions in theoretical computer science&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;IV. Don't ask about:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt;&lt;ul&gt;&#xD;&#xA;    &lt;li&gt;Anything not directly related to theoretical computer science&lt;/li&gt;&#xD;&#xA;    &lt;li&gt;Questions that are primarily opinion-based&lt;/li&gt;&#xD;&#xA;    &lt;li&gt;Questions with too many possible answers or that would require an extremely long answer&lt;/li&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:5476:  <row Id="7903" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2760" RevisionGUID="a1834447-eb8f-4106-9e3b-3bad19957ee1" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="In your previous interactions on cstheory&#xD;&#xA;we have seen that you lack the mathematical maturity to understand &#xD;&#xA;what is a valid mathematical argument as I have written several times &#xD;&#xA;(and that is the main reason that &#xD;&#xA;you don't understand the problem with your &quot;arguments&quot; and &#xD;&#xA;keep insisting on them and engaging in extended discussions). &#xD;&#xA;Therefore your questions are off-topic here because you don't have the minimal understanding of the problem being solved, i.e. understand the answers given to you.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;In addition, on cstheory we have [an explicit policy against crank-friendly topics][1]. &#xD;&#xA;The goal of the policy is to be unwelcoming to cranks on this site. &#xD;&#xA;cstheory does not welcome cranks. &#xD;&#xA;It is not a personal issue and &#xD;&#xA;it doesn't mean anything about interactions &#xD;&#xA;we might have outside this site. &#xD;&#xA;But **_on cstheory_ we will not welcome cranks**.  &#xD;&#xA;As a non-expert who has been [insisting to have proven P is not equal to NP][2] for a considerable time despite the fact that no expert has accepted your claim you are considered a crank.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Also you tend to post question to later post (incorrect) answers ( e.g. [1](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/a/9281/), [2](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/a/18007/)),&#xD;&#xA;that is also unwelcome on cstheory.&#xD;&#xA;cstheory should not be used for self-promotion of one's ideas,&#xD;&#xA;if the intention is not to genuinely ask a question then &#xD;&#xA;the question is &quot;not a real question&quot; and&#xD;&#xA;should be closed.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Aside these, questions of the form &#xD;&#xA;&quot;I have this idea, what is wrong with it?&quot; &#xD;&#xA;can be on-topic stated suitably.&#xD;&#xA;However such questions need considerable extra care since &#xD;&#xA;they often result in open-ended extended discussions and &#xD;&#xA;generally open-ended extended discussions are not suitable for &#xD;&#xA;the sites on the Stack Exchange network, these are Q&amp;A sites, not discussion sites.&#xD;&#xA;I and other users have expressed the opinion that &#xD;&#xA;we need a place for discussions, &#xD;&#xA;but cstheory as a Q&amp;A site is not that place.&#xD;&#xA;In fact &#xD;&#xA;_the software for these sites is &#xD;&#xA;intentionally designed to make extended discussions difficult_.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;These are the reasons your question was closed. &#xD;&#xA;Whether some respected expert on the topic has replied to your email does not change them, &#xD;&#xA;so I think your question should remain closed.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;ps: &#xD;&#xA;I don't use &quot;[crank][3]&quot; as a derogatory or disrespectful term, &#xD;&#xA;I use crank to refer to non-experts who &#xD;&#xA;insist on attacking famous open problems and/or their ideas/&quot;solutions&quot; to them, &#xD;&#xA;without any indication that they have the required knowledge and &#xD;&#xA;capability to solve the problem &#xD;&#xA;(or even worse showing signs that &#xD;&#xA;they have problems understanding even basic concepts of the topic).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/q/274/&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: http://arxiv.org/find/cs/1/au:+Feinstein_C/0/1/0/all/0/1&#xD;&#xA;  [3]: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crank_%28person%29" />

./PostHistory.xml:5494:  <row Id="7928" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2790" RevisionGUID="7a9cbda1-7849-4f71-909c-7dc20b103f63" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="I decided to write this because of the comments posted in the &#xD;&#xA;[election chat room](http://chat.stackexchange.com/rooms/12464/theoretical-computer-science-2014-election). &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Actually I agree with part what [Dilworth has written][1]. &#xD;&#xA;As I have told Suresh, Dave, and Shog9&#xD;&#xA;I feel I use moderator powers more often than the community likes and &#xD;&#xA;that is one of the main reasons I have decided to step down. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;But I think I have followed more or less &#xD;&#xA;[what I wrote when I nominated myself for becoming a moderator](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/election/1#post-4481).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I firmly believed and believe that &#xD;&#xA;cstheory is mainly for professional researchers in theoretical computer science. &#xD;&#xA;I don't think I have ever been even slightly impolite towards any of them and &#xD;&#xA;I have not used mod powers in dealing with any of them. &#xD;&#xA;I have tried to follow the policies and the opinion of the community even when &#xD;&#xA;I personally disagreed with it.&#xD;&#xA;So I have been a minimalist moderator towards the target community of the site. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;But I don't think we should be welcoming at all to anyone &#xD;&#xA;who clearly wants to abuse cstheory for purposes that &#xD;&#xA;are likely to hurt the participation of professional researchers. &#xD;&#xA;I have tried not to be rude even towards them &#xD;&#xA;however I don't see any reason why we should be welcoming to cranks. &#xD;&#xA;Rather I think we should not tolerate at all any crank who &#xD;&#xA;clearly wants to abuse cstheory and &#xD;&#xA;keeps annoying others with low quality comments and answers. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;In my opinion we should have been much harsher in dealing with cranks and &#xD;&#xA;that would have saved us &#xD;&#xA;a lot of trouble and trolling by a particular crank &#xD;&#xA;that hasn't shown much improvement in behavior over a long period of time and &#xD;&#xA;despite our efforts.&#xD;&#xA;In fact the abuser seems to interprets &#xD;&#xA;the community's tolerance as support for his behavior and&#xD;&#xA;has started bringing other cranks to the site and&#xD;&#xA;go as far as nominating himself to become a moderator.&#xD;&#xA;I think these clearly show the effect of tolerance on such abusers. &#xD;&#xA;But since the community didn't wanted to deal with the user that way &#xD;&#xA;I left it to other moderators to deal with him as they think is suitable.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Another contentious issue has been question closing. &#xD;&#xA;The moderator closing vote replaces the normal user closing vote. &#xD;&#xA;In other words, &#xD;&#xA;a moderator cannot cast a non-binding close vote. &#xD;&#xA;So as a moderator when I see a question that I think should be closed &#xD;&#xA;I can either close it or do almost nothing and &#xD;&#xA;it is quite difficult for me to do nothing about a question &#xD;&#xA;that I think is off-topic. &#xD;&#xA;If I could cast a non-binding vote I would prefer to do so but&#xD;&#xA;the system doesn't support it.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;These are some of the main reasons &#xD;&#xA;I have decided to step down as a moderator. &#xD;&#xA;I still care about cstheory and &#xD;&#xA;I am going to continue to actively participate on cstheory.&#xD;&#xA;I think it is a very useful resource for connecting researchers &#xD;&#xA;from different fields in theoretical computer science and &#xD;&#xA;helps them with their research though&#xD;&#xA;I think we have a long road till we reach where MO is. &#xD;&#xA;We have many active users that can take on the job of moderation and &#xD;&#xA;closer to what the community would like.&#xD;&#xA;I hope that over the past 3 years I haven't disappointed &#xD;&#xA;the community and those who voted for me &#xD;&#xA;(at least not too much).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://chat.stackexchange.com/transcript/message/13370607#13370607" />
./PostHistory.xml:5495:  <row Id="7929" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2867" RevisionGUID="705f3226-0600-4851-ba0d-bfb76489e022" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="Like most of our other policies initially we copied the policy from MathOverflow. They were using it successfully for sometime. ([meta.MO] might be a better place to ask about it as MO is older and considerably larger than cstheory.)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;We do get spam and low quality answers from time to time but they are generally removed or heavily down-voted. There is also the fact that like other popular CW questions (it is [our policy](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/759/the-new-community-wiki-policy) that big-list questions must be turned into CW) we protect popular big-list questions. This adds a barrier for adding new answers. I think it is a reasonable barrier, in a sense we are saying that these questions are special and potentially problematic so they are required to pass higher standards. To post an answer you have to first show that you are contributing positively in a sense before being able to post your answer to a big-list question. The same applies informally to big-list questions, i.e. they are expected to pass a higher standard of quality otherwise they get several down-votes and/or closed as too broad. (So far those standards are left subjectively to users, I don't think we have discussed or spelled out a guideline on what we expect from big-list questions/answers.)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I should also add that some of these big-list questions are extremely useful. For example, I don't know any online/offline resource that is a better reference than [this big-list question](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/79/problems-between-p-and-npc) for NPI problems." />

./PostHistory.xml:5499:  <row Id="7933" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2872" RevisionGUID="2284f49d-cc7d-46a4-8e04-a9040dba6a20" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="To those who vote to close non-theoretical-computer-science questions: Thank you for tidying up the website, but when you do so, could you please choose the precise reason?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Sometimes new users post questions not in theoretical computer science but in other fields of study such as physics and more applied side of computer science.  Often many close-voters choose the following reason to close such questions:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; Your question does not appear to be a **research-level** question in theoretical computer science. For more information about the scope, please see [help center](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/help/on-topic).  Your question might be suitable for [Computer Science](http://cs.stackexchange.com/) which has a broader scope.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;While it might be technically correct, this reason is very misleading, particularly for those not familiar with theoretical computer science _such as the posters of those questions_, because the bold part strongly suggests that the problem with the question is that it is not at the research level, whereas the real problem is that it is not a question in or about theoretical computer science.  (Moreover, the question might even be a research question in the field which it belongs to.)  If you are curious, [the message quoted above was proposed to be used when a question was not research-level](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/a/2700), so it is an abuse of this reason by all means in my opinion.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;When you choose “off-topic” as the reason, you have an option to enter your custom reason instead of choosing one of the canned responses.  Please use it instead.  Unfortunately, a custom reason works differently from canned responses in that the custom reason is posted as a comment at the time you cast a vote, and I can imagine some circumstances in which you do not want to do this.  But usually this should be fine.&#xD;&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:5500:  <row Id="7934" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2811" RevisionGUID="dfeb5a61-5707-4d5f-88a4-ffa51f54f324" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="Is there a way to see if two accounts are the same? (I found some related questions on meta but not enough information)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Perhaps stackexchange uses some known techniques to calculate the *probability* that two accounts are the same (using cookies, source ip address, HTTP headers, ...)?&#xD;&#xA;(obviously these techniques can be fooled or can lead to wrong results, but in some cases they can be useful)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;For example yesterday I answered an homework-style question https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/21311/proof-for-acyclic-partition-being-np-complete (in the original formulation I thought that it was a completely different problem) and today I see a question by a new user that has a very-very similar formulation: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/21334/np-complete-proof-for-multiple-choice-matching&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I think that the site should be tolerant in similar cases, but it could be useful to avoid spammers and disturbers (especially in other stackexchange sites that have a larger number of users)." />

./PostHistory.xml:5502:  <row Id="7937" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2826" RevisionGUID="1d3e4b76-62d7-46ff-bba6-71fe4038a118" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="As phrased in your question, it is unlikely to be on-topic here. However, that doesn't mean questions about games are off-topic, with the famous counter-example being the one on the [Super Mario Galaxy problem](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/q/6356/1037). Asking a question about 2048 would take some subtlety.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I would recommend asking non-research level questions on [CS.SE](http://cs.stackexchange.com), but I would still suggest making sure first that you clarify all the words you use. The best questions are ones you tried solving yourself.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Finally, keep in mind that the above are my _opinions_ based on a feeling of what the community prefers and a guess at how you would ask a question based on the evidence I have. I could very well be wrong and the community might love your question, I know that a number of cstheory-folks enjoyed playing 2048." />

./PostHistory.xml:5510:  <row Id="7945" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2844" RevisionGUID="72c7aac9-c4d3-43d7-baa5-7c96caee0fa1" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="This is a &quot;manners critique,&quot; and might be annoying to some users; however, I think it's important because I feel that from looking at the site, some users are being targeted for lacking the academic credentials of some of the other users.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;For example, in [this][1] discussion, a user named Craig Feinstein posts a (possibly off-topic) video of a P vs. NP proof.  Another user then calls him a &quot;crank.&quot;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I would like to strongly urge users to stop calling other users &quot;cranks.&quot;  The word crank is nearly always considered derogatory.  If you type &quot;crank meaning&quot; into Google, you will see both of these meanings (among others):&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;1.  an eccentric person, especially one who is obsessed by a particular subject or theory.&#xD;&#xA;2.  a bad-tempered person.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Referring to someone as either &quot;bad-tempered&quot; or &quot;eccentric&quot; is generally considered rude.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I would like to suggest that users who are seeking to make an observation about another user's &#xD;&#xA;interests in mathematics or computer science use the word &quot;enthusiast&quot; instead of &quot;crank.&quot;  For example, if someone called another user a &quot;P vs. NP enthusiast,&quot; this would not be rude or considered bullying.  Telling a user that they are a crank is a form of harassment, and I do not believe that it is appropriate for any of these sites.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;My question is:  Do you agree with my (relatively straightforward) claims above, and that users should stop referring to each other as cranks or other derogatory terms?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Also:  Do you have any other suggestions on improving the atmosphere of cstheory to make it welcoming to all appropriate users, including people who are not professional academics?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1198/what-videos-should-everybody-watch?page=2&amp;tab=votes#tab-top" />

./PostHistory.xml:5517:  <row Id="7953" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2918" RevisionGUID="428c06ca-2485-4755-9994-3a7287573726" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="Recently, I asked [this][1] question on TCS.SE, but it was closed on the pretext that it was not a research-level question. However, I don't understand what makes it &quot;a not research-level question&quot;. It has got 6 upvotes, so at least 6 people find it interesting, and hopefully on-topic, though I know it's not a metric.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I am not asking a &quot;do my homework&quot; question like proving that Max-Cut is NP-complete. I am asking whether there exists a **specific** reduction, i.e. from Vertex Cover to Max-Cut. I suppose if such a reduction exists, then it might give some insights on how some seemingly unrelated problems are related (and also, reductions are almost always fun!).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;So is there anyone else who feels that it's on-topic? Or at least give the specific reason why it was closed, rather than the hand-wavy &quot;not a research-level question&quot;.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/33002/reduction-from-vertex-cover-to-max-cut" />
./PostHistory.xml:5518:  <row Id="7954" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2924" RevisionGUID="2394072a-cd50-4ecf-a725-0ce2b7ecd19d" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="Now that both sites have graduated, let's revisit this request. I proposed [some criteria](https://meta.stackexchange.com/q/261196/1438) last summer (which we've been using internally for a while). My evaluation:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;1. Sanity check: Yes, there are plenty of reasons a question might be asked here that really belongs on the more general CS site.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;2. Gather statistics: In the past 90 days, there have been [6 migrations to and from CS Theory](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/tools/posts/migrated/stats):&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;        cs.stackexchange.com          =&gt; cstheory.stackexchange.com × 4 (25% rejected)&#xD;&#xA;        datascience.stackexchange.com =&gt; cstheory.stackexchange.com × 1&#xD;&#xA;        cstheory.stackexchange.com    =&gt; cs.stackexchange.com × 1&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;   This is underwhelming. It seems that in practice, people are pretty good about posting to CS when they have a non-research-level question. Just one question has been migrated away. It does not seem as if the moderators are being overwhelmed with migration flags. It's also instructive that there are few migrations the other direction. (A 25% rejection rate would be a red flag if it were not just one question.) &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;So I don't see a lot of evidence that this path is needed. Looking at the [close statistics](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/tools/question-close-stats?daterange=last90days) it seems that the custom close reason that directs people to post to CS on their own is the prefered solution. 115 questions have been closed that way over the same time period. Now if the proportion _does_ shift toward migration and if those migrations are successful as a rule, we might have a reason to add this default path." />
./PostHistory.xml:5519:  <row Id="7955" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2934" RevisionGUID="a3819037-0a6f-4cfb-9d76-5778917bca2a" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/ with https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/" Text="The delete button is only for users who haven't done much.&#xD;&#xA;Other users should use the contact form linked at the bottom of that page.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt;If you have voted or posted, please contact the Stack Exchange Team:&#xD;&#xA;&gt;&#xD;&#xA;Visit the [contact form][1] and select 'I need to delete my user profile.' ./PostHistory.xml:5523:  <row Id="7960" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="411" RevisionGUID="b8ae713c-4bef-49a9-84da-a869148612fc" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:33:37.637" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cooking.stackexchange.com/ with https://cooking.stackexchange.com/" Text="This question is partly for fun, but partly serious.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;As a fictional example, suppose that someone asks a question like the following (the motivation part omitted for simplicity):&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; I would like to make pumpkin fries which are crispy on the outside and soft on the inside.  What is an algorithm for that?&#xD;&#xA;&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; Tag: [ds.algorithms]&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;(This question is based on a [real question on Food and Cooking Stack Exchange](https://cooking.stackexchange.com/questions/5036/how-to-make-pumpkin-fries).  By the way, from my personal experience, I strongly discourage you to visit _that_ website when you are hungry.)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;It is outright off-topic on our website, right?  After all, it is a question about cooking, not in the theoretical computer science.  But this question is clearly asking for an algorithm.  Although its goal is not to compute any mathematical objects and it is usually called a recipe, these do not mean that it is not an algorithm.  “It cannot be implemented on computers or Turing machines” does not sound like a good reason that it is not an algorithm, either.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;“Well,” you might say, “even if the question is about algorithms, it is too vague for a question in the theoretical computer science.  How do you define ‘pumpkin fries,’ ‘crispy’ and ‘soft’?  Oh, and you speak of the outside and inside.  Do you mean that pumpkin fries lie in a topological space?”&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;However, if we think this way, it starts to sound as if we should close it as “not a real question” or “subjective and argumentative,” not as off topic.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I am still pretty sure that the question _is_ off topic, but I find it more difficult than I thought to define when a question is about algorithms, especially because I believe that it is correct to say that a cooking recipe is an algorithm.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; **Question**.  What are the criteria to call some question “a question about algorithms,” and are questions asking for cooking recipes “about algorithms” according to your criteria?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;What made me think about this is [the recent question asking how to verify someone’s claim that analog sound is better than digital sound](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1697/does-analog-sound-have-something-that-digital-does-not-closed).  I removed the [ds.algorithms] tag from it and voted to close it as off topic, and it soon got closed.  But I have just realized that the question _was_ asking for an algorithm.  Now I wonder how to justify the claim that this question is off topic.&#xD;&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:5524:  <row Id="7961" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="12" RevisionGUID="caad094f-621e-4d37-8733-2a9fb5dd6334" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:34:28.537" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://tex.stackexchange.com/ with https://tex.stackexchange.com/" Text="I would prefer a site that is aimed at experts, probably at least graduate student or advanced undergraduate, and assuming a reasonable background in theoretical computer science, or a bit of care in phrasing by someone who is not an expert.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Anything below this level seems neither attractive for domain experts to contribute to, nor sufficiently different from Wikipedia or Google Scholar to be valuable.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The [TeX site][1] is great because it focuses on information that is not easy to find in an FAQ.  It is full of the kind of questions one would ask of the local TeX guru, and the answers are typically those that the most knowledgeable gurus would provide.  It is becoming the sort of place where the discussion about a particular question will be the first hit when one asks a related question of a search engine.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;It would be good if this site could be the place where we get to ask our theory neighbours (whether across the hall, or on the other side of the world), about niggling folklore questions, tangents that came up while reading a paper, clarifications about new results, or cool new insights that maybe don't quite work.  I would also like to see a place where such questions are answered with pointers to non-obvious papers, snippets told by colleagues, historical background that isn't published, and insights that may be common in some parts of the community but which are not universally known.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;In other words: I am adept at using a search engine.  But I have no access to the corridor gossip at another institution, and almost certainly haven't noticed how the JACM paper you just read is directly relevant to an arXiv paper that appeared yesterday.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://tex.stackexchange.com/" />
./PostHistory.xml:5525:  <row Id="7962" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="331" RevisionGUID="cbbf3149-34b8-4925-a1c5-642410d1ad35" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:34:28.537" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://tex.stackexchange.com/ with https://tex.stackexchange.com/" Text="This site supports LaTeX markup using MathJax.  In theory this is great, and it certainly helps in expressing oneself.  However, I have been seeing ongoing problems with MathJax.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Specifically, loading fonts often goes off into never-neverland, only to time out with &quot;Can't load Web-Font Math/TeX/Italic&quot; (and the same for ...Regular).  I have cleared the cache and followed the instructions at the MathJax site.  There it is suggested that this particular error might be due to Firefox refusing to load cached objects because of the way they have been configured on the server: [I am referring to this FAQ entry][1], although my interpretation of this entry may be incorrect.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The frustrating thing is that MathML for MO worked really well once I had installed local fonts, while the MathJax experience has been terrible in comparison.  There is a related thread on the TeX site: https://tex.stackexchange.com/questions/2692/comparing-mathjax-and-mathml and a possibly relevant discussion about a bug found (and fixed) with MathJax a few weeks ago at http://sourceforge.net/projects/mathjax/forums/forum/948700/topic/3816654&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Any suggestions?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;_Edit: as mentioned in a comment below, I managed to change the rendering from HTML CSS to MathML, and LaTeX now renders quickly and without weird font timeouts._&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://www.mathjax.org/resources/faqs/#image-fonts" />

./PostHistory.xml:5527:  <row Id="7964" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2761" RevisionGUID="7b690b99-41c8-45ab-b88e-822281233b03" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:37:19.453" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://unix.stackexchange.com/ with https://unix.stackexchange.com/" Text="Some sites have a custom close reason to handle this kind of cases. For example, on [Unix &amp; Linux](https://unix.stackexchange.com/):&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; Questions describing a problem that can't be reproduced and seemingly went away on its own (or went away when a typo was fixed) are off-topic as they are unlikely to help future readers.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I doubt that CSTheory gets enough questions of this type to warrant a custom close reason. If a question is about understanding a point in a research paper, then&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; * either the point is a subtle one that others may miss as well (or the paper omitted a step of the proof), in which case the question is potentially useful to anyone reading the paper and should be answered and remain open;&#xD;&#xA; * or the point is a basic one that the asker happened to miss but where other readers aren't likely to stumble, in which case closing as off-topic with a custom comment plus a comment to explain is fine.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Basically, I agree with what you did, except for one thing: don't use the words “too localized”, which is historical Stack Exchange jargon that most people won't understand. Write something like&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; This question concerns a basic point and is unlikely to be useful to future visitors, [therefore](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/2748/what-to-do-with-too-localized-questions) I am voting to close it.&#xD;&#xA;" />

./PostHistory.xml:5530:  <row Id="7968" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1243" RevisionGUID="98344871-b253-49e7-8c91-b8471558b407" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:39:35.573" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://physics.stackexchange.com/ with https://physics.stackexchange.com/" Text="I started typing up a question on transitioning from quantum to classical random walks on the line, with the punchline being along the lines of:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt;Are there models of decoherence for the quantum walk such that we can tune the walk to spread as $\Theta(t^k)$ for any $1/2 \leq k \leq 1$?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The question is tangentially related to cstheory because classical random walks are useful in algorithm design, and quantum random walks have proven useful for making a number of cool algorithms. Thus, it is important to understand the difference between quantum and classical random walks. Sometimes, the easiest way to do this is to consider toy models, such as walks on the line.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Further, I think there are enough quantum folks at cstheory that I might get a very good answer.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;On the other hand, the question is clearly physics-y and would be of little interest to non-quantum cstheory members. The question would be more at home at [Theoretical Physics.SE](http://area51.stackexchange.com/proposals/23848/theoretical-physics?referrer=3Cmub2jRLCYDvVVb-6SmDQ2) but unfortunately the site has not made it to beta, yet. I could try [physics.SE](https://physics.stackexchange.com/) but a look the question list suggests that that site lost its research focus, and this is a research level question. Also, I check cstheory all the time and enjoy the community, so I prefer to ask questions here.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Should I try asking this question and removing it if the community doesn't approve? Or is this question so clearly off-topic that by asking it I would be setting a bad example?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;EDIT:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;After 3 proceed comments, I posted the question:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/7629/transitioning-from-quantum-to-classical-random-walks-on-the-line&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;If you think there is a way I can improve the question or make it clearer/better motivated please suggest it here or in the comments of the question.&#xD;&#xA;" />

./PostHistory.xml:5533:  <row Id="7971" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2789" RevisionGUID="5ff5397a-0867-4442-ac90-048d42bdaa47" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:39:35.573" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://physics.stackexchange.com/ with https://physics.stackexchange.com/" Text="##***personal*** view on TCS _(.se)_&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;(T)CS is a wondrous, fascinating, beautiful, deep, vibrant field. came to it in preteens, heard about public key cryptography from a relative who clipped out an article from a newspaper on it. dad, a jr high school algebra teacher, brought home one of the 1st PCs, programmed bubble sort for [***fun***,](http://vzn1.wordpress.com/2013/12/02/joy-of-code-2013-natl-cs-edu-week-dec9-16/) explained it to me and said &quot;its slow, it takes $n^2$ time to finish&quot;, and I pondered that concept like a deep zen mystery with beginners mind (before knowing what zen was). &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;in teens, wondered about shannons theorem about hard functions based on counting circuits. _and none of them can be_ ***constructed***. we know they're there, but where are they? what an astonishing deep mystery, almost like a TCS analog of [dark matter](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dark_matter)! and not the only apparent deep parallel between [TCS &amp; physics](https://physics.stackexchange.com/a/89802/33566). and still basically open after more than ½-century. truly this field is full of the Everest of problems. *many or even most in pristine pre-summited state!*&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;in college, learned/experimented/sought [FSM-enlightenment](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/14811/what-is-the-enlightenment-im-supposed-to-attain-after-studying-finite-automata) in an intriguing [research-oriented attack](http://vzn1.wordpress.com/code/collatz-conjecture-experiments/) on one mountain. climbed to a local minimum! also started experimenting with [SAT &amp; factoring](http://cs.stackexchange.com/questions/6588/reducing-the-integer-factorization-problem-to-an-np-complete-problem/6605#6605).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;there are many signs computer science is entering or in the middle of a (very long-range?) [golden age](http://cacm.acm.org/magazines/2013/2/160156-the-explosive-growth-of-postdocs-in-computer-science/fulltext), and thats motivating, energizing, even at times [exciting](http://vzn1.wordpress.com/2014/01/17/dwave-and-the-inception-of-the-qm-computing-dream/). its a field-in-motion. cutting edge and an awesome, buzzing-crackling fusion of abstract theory and real-life application. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;so, a dream job for me would be high-paying TCS research/applications and have come close to that fantasy in real life over the years. but, later, after working 4 yrs in scientific laboratory alongside graduate students and Phds, realized that combination of terms might be verging mostly on an oxymoron; ie it seemed that scientific researchers (not just those in TCS) didnt seem to be (how to put this delicately) reknowned for their salaries.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;am proud to be a contributing part of a rare, unique group that captures some of this energy/momentum/dynamism esp in the way that it [connects with applications](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/19759/core-algorithms-deployed). &#xD;&#xA;([tag:application-of-theory] is my favorite conceptual fusion/paradigm/site tag.) by some very hard work by many dedicated, farsighted, brilliant individuals, cstheory stackexchange is a really superb forum and by far the best venue on the entire cyberspace for that right now, and probably will be for years into the future. it mixes top achievers from academia with the wild open internet (another great/shearing _fusion_).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;TCS is also in the midst and at the forefront of massive/pivotal decade-long shifts and transformations. eg quantum computing, [electronic publishing/open science](http://www.amazon.com/Reinventing-Discovery-The-Networked-Science/dp/0691148902/), [collaborative filtering, collective wisdom, collective intelligence](http://cs.stackexchange.com/questions/4768/references-on-collective-intelligence-with-respect-to-cs-applications) and amazingly the stackexchange site captures various key elements of all that.&#xD;&#xA;am especially interested in &#xD;&#xA;[cyber collaboration](http://vzn1.wordpress.com/volunteer/) possibilities seen in the groundbreaking [polymath](http://polymathprojects.org/) model, which is at heart in its radical/dramatic successes not that different than the [stackexchange system](http://www.simonsfoundation.org/mathematics-and-physical-science/the-global-math-commons/).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;what is [great] TCS? how about simply listing my idiosyncratic personal TCS inspirations/influences/luminary/hero pantheon off the top of my head: [Lipton](http://www.scs.gatech.edu/features/career-solution), [Fortnow](http://www.cc.gatech.edu/features/fortnow), [Jukna](http://www.amazon.com/Boolean-Function-Complexity-Algorithms-Combinatorics/dp/3642245072), [Razborov](http://www.mathunion.org/general/prizes/nevanlinna/prize-winners/o/General/Prizes/Nevanlinna/1990/Razborov/page1.html), [Aaronson](http://www.scottaaronson.com/blog/), [Feynman](http://link.springer.com/article/10.1007%2FBF02650179), [Shor](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shor's_algorithm), Sedgewick, Knuth, [Cook](http://www.claymath.org/sites/default/files/pvsnp.pdf), [Turing](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/11797/alan-turings-contributions-to-computer-science), [Mandelbrot](http://nautil.us/issue/0/the-story-of-nautilus/in-the-mind-of-the-fractal-king), [Hofstadter](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/18968/what-are-the-popular-science-books-that-inspire-tcs), [Wolfram](http://www.wolframscience.com/). etc! (of course not coincidentally several are members of cstheory!)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;oh, and yeah, (sssh, dont tell anyone), then theres my [favorite open problem](http://vzn1.wordpress.com/2012/10/18/math-monster/) of [so many great ones too choose from](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/174/major-unsolved-problems-in-theoretical-computer-science) Ive been interested for ~2½ decades even long before there was a [huge incentive](http://www.claymath.org/millennium-problems/millennium-prize-problems)... _heaven forbid_ not claiming a _proof_ but have a [few new ideas](http://vzn1.wordpress.com/2012/12/08/outline-for-a-np-vsppoly-proof-based-on-monotone-circuits-hypergraphs-and-factoring/)!&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;speaking of zen, at rare times one might even think TCS can even reach [cosmic/transcendant/spiritual](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/189/algorithms-from-the-book) levels! (just had to somehow shamelessly work in the highest-voted question in this essay somehow!)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;hey, if theres still any question about my interest/engagement/affinity for this site, just browse/look at my huge [favorites list](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/users/7884/vzn?tab=favorites) sometime! due to the awesome stackexchange software [built by brilliant software engineers] it can even be searched by keyword eg [cc.complexity theory](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/search?tab=votes&amp;q=infavorites%3a7884%20%5bcc.complexity-theory%5d)" />
./PostHistory.xml:5534:  <row Id="7972" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1424" RevisionGUID="f8b54aec-f1ec-4efc-bb48-58c77617e1fb" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:43:11.827" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://scifi.stackexchange.com/ with https://scifi.stackexchange.com/" Text="This seems like a recipe for fostering quantity above quality. Amongst the 8 sites, CSTheory is the only one where I feel I vaguely belong(ed), so I'll pipe up here, but similar opinions have already been voiced over at [Math](https://math.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/3212/battle-of-the-sites). What I like about CSTheory is the very high level of questions. I would much rather see a push towards quality (for CSTheory, I'm content with maintaining quality as a target) than towards quantity.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Try doing this between [Role Playing Games](http://rpg.stackexchange.com/), [Gaming](https://gaming.stackexchange.com/), [Science Fiction &amp; Fantasy](https://scifi.stackexchange.com/) and a few similar sites, perhaps. And as a user and pro tempore moderator of SF&amp;F, I can't say I'd be thrilled about it (I'd appreciate if it was discussed in chat first). But keep the lowest-common-denominator entertainment off serious sites.&#xD;&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:5535:  <row Id="7973" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="75" RevisionGUID="b924850b-8e06-46a0-b668-0d288e1b9468" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:44:17.023" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://stats.stackexchange.com/ with https://stats.stackexchange.com/" Text="These questions are actually in-scope on the [data analysis site][1].  See [this discussion][2] on scope for that site.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I would argue that the CS Theory site should focus on more theoretical questions, and the given question was applied.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://stats.stackexchange.com/&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: https://stats.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/6/what-should-our-faq-contain/201#201" />
./PostHistory.xml:5536:  <row Id="7974" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1228" RevisionGUID="c012a825-ca75-4236-9402-80c98716506e" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:44:17.023" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://stats.stackexchange.com/ with https://stats.stackexchange.com/" Text="### change log&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;----&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Jul. 27, 2012:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- Added [academia.se] to the list of suggested sites&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;----&#xD;&#xA;Mar. 20, 2012:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- Added [cs.se] to the list of suggested sites&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;----&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Feb. 23, 2012:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Another small update to the FAQ. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Change log:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; * Added [crypto.se] and [scicomp.se] to the list of suggested sites,&#xD;&#xA; * Made the tips for writing a better question a section.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;----&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Nov. 17, 2011:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I have edited the official FAQ a little bit (mainly adding links to some entries of the official FAQ that we refer to in comments). Please comemnt if you don't like the edits or have other suggestions on how to improve the general FAQ:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;----&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;[FAQ](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/faq)&#xD;&#xA;----&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;**Theoretical Computer Science - Stack Exchange** is for theoretical computer scientists and researchers in related fields.  We welcome _research-level_ questions in _theoretical computer science_ (TCS).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Although there is no black-and-white distinction between research-level questions and non-research-level questions, questions are considered to be &quot;research-level&quot; roughly when they can be discussed between two professors or between two graduate students working on Ph.D.'s, but not usually between a professor and a typical undergraduate student. It does not include questions at the level of difficulty of typical undergraduate course/textbook homework/exercise.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;For an explanation of what TCS is, we refer you to the description of ACM Special Interest Group on Algorithms and Computation Theory (SIGACT):&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; &gt; TCS covers a wide variety of topics including algorithms, data structures, computational complexity, parallel and distributed computation, probabilistic computation, quantum computation, automata theory, information theory, cryptography, program semantics and verification, machine learning, computational biology, computational economics, computational geometry, and computational number theory and algebra.  **Work in this field is often distinguished by its emphasis on mathematical technique and rigor.** &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;##My question is not a research-level question in TCS, where can I ask it?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;For questions other than research-level questions in TCS, you may want to consider the following places to ask:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; * General Computer Science — [Computer Science - Stack Exchange](http://cs.stackexchange.com/)&#xD;&#xA; * General Mathematics (including *theoretical* CS) — [Mathematics - Stack Exchange](https://math.stackexchange.com/)&#xD;&#xA; * Research-level Mathematics — [Math Overflow](http://mathoverflow.net/)&#xD;&#xA; * Social and Professional Academic Issues — [Academia - Stack Exchange](http://academia.stackexchange.com/)&#xD;&#xA; * Programming — [Stack Overflow](http://stackoverflow.com/)&#xD;&#xA; * General Artificial Intelligence — [Meta Optimize](http://metaoptimize.com/qa/)&#xD;&#xA; * Statistics and Data Mining — [Cross Validated](https://stats.stackexchange.com/)&#xD;&#xA; * Applied Cryptography and Security — [Crypto - Stack Exchange](http://crypto.stackexchange.com/)&#xD;&#xA; * Computation used in Science and Engineering — [Computational Science - Stack Exchange](http://scicomp.stackexchange.com/)&#xD;&#xA; * Questions about this site — [Theoretical Computer Science - Stack Exchange - Meta][1]&#xD;&#xA; * Other — check the list of sites on [Stack Exchange Network](http://stackexchange.com/sites)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;##Questions should be based on knowledge sharing, not on shirking&#xD;&#xA;You should only post questions you're actually seriously thinking about. Users are expected to do their part and try to answer their question by themselves before posting them on cstheory and asking for help from others. Search to see if your question is already answered somewhere else (e.g. Wikipedia) before asking a question. **Try to make your question interesting for others by providing some background knowledge**. Remember, *questions should be based on knowledge sharing, not on shirking. Shirking goes against the spirit of the site.* &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;##Tips about writing better questions&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* [How to Ask?](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/how-to-ask)&#xD;&#xA;* [How to ask a good question?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/300/how-to-ask-a-good-question)&#xD;&#xA;* [How to write a good MathOverflow question?](http://mathoverflow.net/howtoask)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Please also check our list of [**useful resources**](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/229#229) *before* asking a question.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;##FAQ&#xD;&#xA;Currently we have two separate lists of FAQs.  See also the longer **[Official Theoretical Computer Science FAQ](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science)**.  Some of the most important entries in the other FAQ are:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; * [How do I write **formulas**?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/237#237)&#xD;&#xA; * [What kind of questions are **too basic**?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/235#235)&#xD;&#xA; * [My (wonderful!) **question got closed**!  What do I do now?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/361#361)&#xD;&#xA; * [What is the **policy on crossposting** to/from MathOverflow?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/231#231)&#xD;&#xA; * [Can I ask about this **cool paper** that I just saw **on the arxiv**?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/274/is-it-ok-to-ask-about-the-correctness-of-preprints-on-crank-friendly-topics/281#281)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" />
./PostHistory.xml:5537:  <row Id="7975" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1553" RevisionGUID="540b3f33-e4bb-4052-881c-98272aa750a9" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:44:17.023" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://stats.stackexchange.com/ with https://stats.stackexchange.com/" Text="We have two relatively popular tags [tag:lg.learning] (53 questions) and [tag:machine-learning] (75 questions). However, I am not sure where the line between the two is drawn. For lg.learning wiki we have:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt;Tag [tag:lg.learning] refers to the research area of [machine learning](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Machine_learning), and [learning theory](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computational_learning_theory) specifically (falling under [arXiv](http://arxiv.org/archive/cs)'s [cs.LG - Learning](http://arxiv.org/list/cs.LG/recent)), as opposed to the general practice of learning.  This tag includes the theory of PAC learning, algorithmic learning theory, and computational aspects of Bayesian inference and graphical models.  Questions about implementation issues and statistical properties of machine learning systems are more likely to be welcomed at the [CrossValidated](https://stats.stackexchange.com/) or [MetaOptimize Q&amp;A](http://metaoptimize.com/qa/) sites.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt;The questions _must_ satisfy the usual scope requirements for cstheory as explained in the [FAQ](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/faq).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;And for [tag:machine-learning] we have the wiki-excerpt:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt;Theoretical questions about Machine learning, especially Computational Learning Theory, including Algorithmic Learning Theory, PAC learning, and Bayesian Inference&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;and the whole wiki:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt;This tag should be used for *theoretical* questions related to Machine Learning (roughly falling under [arXiv](http://arxiv.org/archive/cs)'s [cs.LG - Learning](http://arxiv.org/list/cs.LG/recent)).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt;The question _must_ satisfy the usual scope requirements for cstheory as explained in the [FAQ](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/faq).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt;You may also want to check AI Q&amp;A site [Meta Optimize](http://metaoptimize.com/qa/) which has a more general AI scope.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;To me, it seems that we are using them as synonyms. Is this the case? If so, then which should be the main tag? lg.learning follows our ArXiv tag convention, but machine-learning is more popular and more likely to be searched for." />

./PostHistory.xml:5540:  <row Id="7979" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1042" RevisionGUID="7c68f1b0-1167-4ceb-9ad3-956816a82771" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:46:22.537" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://quant.stackexchange.com/ with https://quant.stackexchange.com/" Text="I am a Pro Tem moderator on [Quant Finance SE][1]. We are in a struggle at the moment to get sufficient questions to make it out of beta. One particular issue is that we narrow the question scope to a *professional* level, which for the quant world is (1) very niche and (2) very high-level. This seems to have limited participation dramatically.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The closest analogy I can think of to Quant SE's ideals is TCS SE. How did this site get the traction it currently has? How was it able to maintain participation while requiring PhD-level material?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://quant.stackexchange.com/" />
./PostHistory.xml:5541:  <row Id="7980" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1065" RevisionGUID="a7f08243-92cc-45e1-9f0e-810f12fc439a" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:46:22.537" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://quant.stackexchange.com/ with https://quant.stackexchange.com/" Text="Echoing Suresh, CSTheory is still some way from being successful, as it only attracts a small fraction of the TCS community.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;However, it is important that early users set a high standard, and it might be worth highlighting the especially thoughtful questions and perceptive answers at quant.SE to date.  Perhaps blog posts, an overview article on the Meta site, or an article in a quant publication such as Wilmott magazine could all assist.  Such initiatives have all worked for CSTheory as mentioned by other answers.  The list at https://quant.stackexchange.com/questions?sort=votes seems to be a great starting point, and I have found voting feedback at CSTheory useful in choosing which questions to highlight, for instance when adding entries to Radu Grigore's list at https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/446/broadening-the-scope-of-questions/985#985 and for https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/457/nominations-for-publicity-poster-at-focs&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Listing some of the &quot;greatest hits&quot; allows potential contributors to quickly find content that they are likely to find compelling, and also more firmly establishes the standard that contributors are going to aspire to.&#xD;&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:5542:  <row Id="7981" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1228" RevisionGUID="d2244523-a8ca-45cb-b4c4-262000b9b380" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:48:17.923" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://crypto.stackexchange.com/ with https://crypto.stackexchange.com/" Text="### change log&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;----&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Jul. 27, 2012:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- Added [academia.se] to the list of suggested sites&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;----&#xD;&#xA;Mar. 20, 2012:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- Added [cs.se] to the list of suggested sites&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;----&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Feb. 23, 2012:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Another small update to the FAQ. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Change log:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; * Added [crypto.se] and [scicomp.se] to the list of suggested sites,&#xD;&#xA; * Made the tips for writing a better question a section.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;----&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Nov. 17, 2011:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I have edited the official FAQ a little bit (mainly adding links to some entries of the official FAQ that we refer to in comments). * General Computer Science — [Computer Science - Stack Exchange](http://cs.stackexchange.com/)&#xD;&#xA; * General Mathematics (including *theoretical* CS) — [Mathematics - Stack Exchange](https://math.stackexchange.com/)&#xD;&#xA; * Programming — [Stack Overflow](http://stackoverflow.com/)&#xD;&#xA; * General Artificial Intelligence — [Meta Optimize](http://metaoptimize.com/qa/)&#xD;&#xA; * Statistics and Data Mining — [Cross Validated](https://stats.stackexchange.com/)&#xD;&#xA;
