Remember, *questions should be based on knowledge sharing, not on shirking. Shirking goes against the spirit of the site.* &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;##Tips about writing better questions&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* [How to Ask?](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/how-to-ask)&#xD;&#xA;* [How to ask a good question?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/300/how-to-ask-a-good-question)&#xD;&#xA;* [How to write a good MathOverflow question?](http://mathoverflow.net/howtoask)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Please also check our list of [**useful resources**](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/229#229) *before* asking a question.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;##FAQ&#xD;&#xA;Currently we have two separate lists of FAQs.  See also the longer **[Official Theoretical Computer Science FAQ](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science)**.  Some of the most important entries in the other FAQ are:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; * [How do I write **formulas**?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/237#237)&#xD;&#xA; * [What kind of questions are **too basic**?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/235#235)&#xD;&#xA; * [My (wonderful!) **question got closed**!  What do I do now?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/361#361)&#xD;&#xA; * [What is the **policy on crossposting** to/from MathOverflow?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/231#231)&#xD;&#xA; * [Can I ask about this **cool paper** that I just saw **on the arxiv**?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/274/is-it-ok-to-ask-about-the-correctness-of-preprints-on-crank-friendly-topics/281#281)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" />
./PostHistory.xml:5543:  <row Id="7982" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1293" RevisionGUID="023cded4-21c6-42fd-82fc-3a175672f296" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:48:17.923" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://crypto.stackexchange.com/ with https://crypto.stackexchange.com/" Text="If we asked a question which was seen as on-topic (and maybe even upvoted) and it hung around on the site for a while, but did not generate an answer. Can we migrate the question to another site where it remains in scope? Or should I just cross-post and double-link?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;As a concrete example, I asked a question about crypto-currency on Jun 28:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/q/7145/1037&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;It generated a answer-comment but not quiet an answer, some upvotes, and otherwise has sat idly on cstheory. Since that time, however, a new SE site sprung up: &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;https://crypto.stackexchange.com/&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Where this question would remain in scope. Does it make sense to migrate the question if the OP (in this case me) agrees? Or would that be bad-practice?" />
./PostHistory.xml:5544:  <row Id="7983" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2661" RevisionGUID="4cccc26c-15af-46e5-ae1b-e7bccda12310" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:48:17.923" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://crypto.stackexchange.com/ with https://crypto.stackexchange.com/" Text="##My question is not a research-level question in TCS, where can I ask it?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;For questions other than research-level questions in TCS, you may want to consider the following places to ask:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; * General Computer Science — [Computer Science - Stack Exchange][1]&#xD;&#xA; * General Mathematics (including *theoretical* CS) — [Mathematics - Stack Exchange][2]&#xD;&#xA; * Research-level Mathematics — [Math Overflow][3]&#xD;&#xA; * Social and Professional Academic Issues — [Academia - Stack Exchange][4]&#xD;&#xA; * Programming — [Stack Overflow][5]&#xD;&#xA; * General Artificial Intelligence — [Meta Optimize][6]&#xD;&#xA; * Statistics and Data Mining — [Cross Validated][7]&#xD;&#xA; * Applied Cryptography and Security — [Crypto - Stack Exchange][8]&#xD;&#xA; * Computation used in Science and Engineering — [Computational Science - Stack Exchange][9]&#xD;&#xA; * Questions about this site — [Theoretical Computer Science - Stack Exchange - Meta][10]&#xD;&#xA; * Other — check the list of sites on [Stack Exchange Network][11]&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://cs.stackexchange.com/&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: https://math.stackexchange.com/&#xD;&#xA;  [3]: http://mathoverflow.net/&#xD;&#xA;  [4]: http://academia.stackexchange.com/&#xD;&#xA;  [5]: http://stackoverflow.com/&#xD;&#xA;  [6]: http://metaoptimize.com/qa/&#xD;&#xA;  [7]: https://stats.stackexchange.com/&#xD;&#xA;  [8]: https://crypto.stackexchange.com/&#xD;&#xA;  [9]: http://scicomp.stackexchange.com/&#xD;&#xA;  [10]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/&#xD;&#xA;  [11]: http://stackexchange.com/sites" />

./PostHistory.xml:5547:  <row Id="7986" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1095" RevisionGUID="c8f77565-8d7e-4977-9f9a-f24b7adc9164" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:48:30.257" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cs.stackexchange.com/ with https://cs.stackexchange.com/" Text="For a long time, there was no good answer — it seemed that there was no solution within Stack Exchange. But now the situation is finally resolved.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;## [On the computer science site!](https://cs.stackexchange.com/)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Computer Science accepts all questions about theoretical and applied computer science. (All questions suitable for Stack Exchange, that is.)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Computer Science does not include the technique of programming, even when done as part of a class in a computer science curriculum. There's [Stack Overflow](http://stackoverflow.com/) for that.&#xD;&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:5548:  <row Id="7987" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1228" RevisionGUID="16a3626c-92c4-40d4-a1f2-b9dca8bb7353" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:48:30.257" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cs.stackexchange.com/ with https://cs.stackexchange.com/" Text="### change log&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;----&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Jul. 27, 2012:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- Added [academia.se] to the list of suggested sites&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;----&#xD;&#xA;Mar. 20, 2012:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- Added [cs.se] to the list of suggested sites&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;----&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Feb. 23, 2012:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Another small update to the FAQ. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Change log:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; * Added [crypto.se] and [scicomp.se] to the list of suggested sites,&#xD;&#xA; * Made the tips for writing a better question a section.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;----&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Nov. 17, 2011:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I have edited the official FAQ a little bit (mainly adding links to some entries of the official FAQ that we refer to in comments). Please comemnt if you don't like the edits or have other suggestions on how to improve the general FAQ:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;----&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;[FAQ](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/faq)&#xD;&#xA;----&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;**Theoretical Computer Science - Stack Exchange** is for theoretical computer scientists and researchers in related fields.  We welcome _research-level_ questions in _theoretical computer science_ (TCS).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Although there is no black-and-white distinction between research-level questions and non-research-level questions, questions are considered to be &quot;research-level&quot; roughly when they can be discussed between two professors or between two graduate students working on Ph.D.'s, but not usually between a professor and a typical undergraduate student. It does not include questions at the level of difficulty of typical undergraduate course/textbook homework/exercise.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;For an explanation of what TCS is, we refer you to the description of ACM Special Interest Group on Algorithms and Computation Theory (SIGACT):&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; &gt; TCS covers a wide variety of topics including algorithms, data structures, computational complexity, parallel and distributed computation, probabilistic computation, quantum computation, automata theory, information theory, cryptography, program semantics and verification, machine learning, computational biology, computational economics, computational geometry, and computational number theory and algebra.  **Work in this field is often distinguished by its emphasis on mathematical technique and rigor.** &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;##My question is not a research-level question in TCS, where can I ask it?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;For questions other than research-level questions in TCS, you may want to consider the following places to ask:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; * General Computer Science — [Computer Science - Stack Exchange](https://cs.stackexchange.com/)&#xD;&#xA; * General Mathematics (including *theoretical* CS) — [Mathematics - Stack Exchange](https://math.stackexchange.com/)&#xD;&#xA; * Research-level Mathematics — [Math Overflow](http://mathoverflow.net/)&#xD;&#xA; * Social and Professional Academic Issues — [Academia - Stack Exchange](http://academia.stackexchange.com/)&#xD;&#xA; * Programming — [Stack Overflow](http://stackoverflow.com/)&#xD;&#xA; * General Artificial Intelligence — [Meta Optimize](http://metaoptimize.com/qa/)&#xD;&#xA; * Statistics and Data Mining — [Cross Validated](https://stats.stackexchange.com/)&#xD;&#xA; * Applied Cryptography and Security — [Crypto - Stack Exchange](https://crypto.stackexchange.com/)&#xD;&#xA; * Computation used in Science and Engineering — [Computational Science - Stack Exchange](http://scicomp.stackexchange.com/)&#xD;&#xA; * Questions about this site — [Theoretical Computer Science - Stack Exchange - Meta][1]&#xD;&#xA; * Other — check the list of sites on [Stack Exchange Network](http://stackexchange.com/sites)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;##Questions should be based on knowledge sharing, not on shirking&#xD;&#xA;You should only post questions you're actually seriously thinking about. Users are expected to do their part and try to answer their question by themselves before posting them on cstheory and asking for help from others. Search to see if your question is already answered somewhere else (e.g. Wikipedia) before asking a question. **Try to make your question interesting for others by providing some background knowledge**. Remember, *questions should be based on knowledge sharing, not on shirking. Shirking goes against the spirit of the site.* &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;##Tips about writing better questions&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* [How to Ask?](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/how-to-ask)&#xD;&#xA;* [How to ask a good question?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/300/how-to-ask-a-good-question)&#xD;&#xA;* [How to write a good MathOverflow question?](http://mathoverflow.net/howtoask)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Please also check our list of [**useful resources**](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/229#229) *before* asking a question.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;##FAQ&#xD;&#xA;Currently we have two separate lists of FAQs.  See also the longer **[Official Theoretical Computer Science FAQ](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science)**.  Some of the most important entries in the other FAQ are:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; * [How do I write **formulas**?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/237#237)&#xD;&#xA; * [What kind of questions are **too basic**?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/235#235)&#xD;&#xA; * [My (wonderful!) **question got closed**!  What do I do now?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/361#361)&#xD;&#xA; * [What is the **policy on crossposting** to/from MathOverflow?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/231#231)&#xD;&#xA; * [Can I ask about this **cool paper** that I just saw **on the arxiv**?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/274/is-it-ok-to-ask-about-the-correctness-of-preprints-on-crank-friendly-topics/281#281)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" />
./PostHistory.xml:5549:  <row Id="7988" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1501" RevisionGUID="4131ca1a-0a64-4e05-a95c-37b858ed19e1" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:48:30.257" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cs.stackexchange.com/ with https://cs.stackexchange.com/" Text="Update:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The [Computer Science - Stack Exchange][2] has entered public beta.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;----&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The [Computer Science proposal][1] is almost there and only needs 12 more commitments. You should commit soon if you are interested and want to participate in the private beta.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://area51.stackexchange.com/proposals/35636/computer-science?referrer=pdx8p7tVWqozXN85c5ibxQ2&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: https://cs.stackexchange.com/" />
./PostHistory.xml:5550:  <row Id="7989" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1511" RevisionGUID="1fe22671-37f8-4743-8ceb-9658f8a33e05" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:48:30.257" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cs.stackexchange.com/ with https://cs.stackexchange.com/" Text="The problem with migrating can be seen in this question : &#xD;&#xA;[Is there some other way to describe a formal language other than grammars?](https://cs.stackexchange.com/questions/813/are-there-other-ways-to-describe-formal-languages-other-than-grammars)&#xD;&#xA;The OP did not &quot;migrate&quot; with his question, making a future not answered question, eventhough there are plenty of answers.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I think it would be better to direct the OP toward the cs.SE site, and let him ask his question again than migrating. I am not sure it is optimal for a beta-site to have questions with no accepted answers." />
./PostHistory.xml:5551:  <row Id="7990" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1554" RevisionGUID="809bf443-131c-4e07-82a1-9278672e8cb8" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:48:30.257" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cs.stackexchange.com/ with https://cs.stackexchange.com/" Text="I wonder who on earth would be happy to read a series of long, boilerplate comments such as:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; Welcome to cstheory, a Q&amp;A site for _research-level_ questions in _theoretical computer science_ (TCS). Your question does not appear to be a research-level question in TCS. Please see the [FAQ](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/faq) for more information on what is meant by this and suggestions for sites that might welcome your question. Finally, if your question is closed for being out of scope, and you believe you can edit the question to make it a research-level question, please feel free to do so. Closing is not permanent and questions can be reopened, check the [FAQ](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/faq) for more information.&#xD;&#xA;&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; Please add some context/background/motivation for the question if you think the question is a research-level question and in [Theoretical Computer Science](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/)'s scope. You can find tips about writing a better question in our FAQ. For general level questions please consider posting on [Computer Science](https://cs.stackexchange.com/).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I know, these comments partly came from [another thread on meta](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/1381/comment-templates), but this does not change the fact that they are stupidly long.  Please do not use them.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;_Added_: It is fine to argue that in theory, it should be possible to improve the templates to make it concise and to the point.  I have seen this argument many times.  In practice, no one has ever been able to make such an edit, and I think that there is a good reason why it is impossible.  If you have time to argue the theoretical possibility, just edit the templates instead and have it done.&#xD;&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:5552:  <row Id="7991" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1581" RevisionGUID="32c69634-8424-492c-8482-e7be46092bd4" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:48:30.257" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cs.stackexchange.com/ with https://cs.stackexchange.com/" Text="*Disclaimer: I am a moderator on [Computer Science Stack Exchange](https://cs.stackexchange.com/). While I try to judge this proposal on its own merit, it is likely that the time and energy I have invested in CS.SE influences me.*&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I'm afraid that broadening the scope in this way would destroy the existing community. A Stack Exchange site is defined by two things: the kind of questions it accepts, and the audience it attracts. Even though each question is in principle judged on its intrinsic merits, the long-term effect is to create a community.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;On this site, the community is centered around researchers in theoretical computer science. Participants tend to be researchers in TCS, researchers in other fields, or graduate students aspiring to become researchers. The participants who are welcomed are generally those who came with the expectation of participating in a community dominated by TCS researchers.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I do not see a problem with allowing more applied questions. As long as academics and people who want to fit in with academics dominate the site, that isn't a problem. It may be difficult to bootstrap an applied CS community (it would have been a lot easier to do when the site was young), but if it works, it won't change the tone of the site, and if it fails, the site won't have changed.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;On the other hand, opening the door to more basic questions means opening the door to a broader audience. This should be a carefully controlled process. In particular, I advise you not to try to draw on Stack Overflow as an audience base. A majority of Stack Overflow does not know or care what it means to be a scientist. The kind of people you would attract are those who now post on [Programmers](https://softwareengineering.stackexchange.com/). If you attract those people, be prepared to moderate their content. And to moderate them.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Reacting to specific points in your proposal:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; We now have a natural forum (cs.stackexchange.com) for the more &quot;basic&quot; algorithms questions, and the cstheory &quot;brand&quot; is well established as a 'research-only' venue. So we have an easy process to shunt questions that are obviously undergrad level.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Keep in mind that CS.SE is not exclusively for basic questions. It is for questions at all level, ranging all the way from CS 101 homework to applied research (and even research in theory, but we suggest CSTheory.SE to the rare asker who comes with a theory question that seems to go unanswered because it is too hard).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; excluding questions from people who might be 'research-level' in a sub area but aren't experts in some other domain&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;From what I see (I admit to not following CSTheory.SE very closely), this already happens: as long as there's a feeling that peers are talking with peers, questions tend to be appreciated, left open and answered.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; creating the impression of an unfriendly site (which is a bigger problem in terms of maintaining the audience)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I think the community is doing an adequate job of retaining the audience it likes in and keeping the undesirables in.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;All in all, while the current guidelines may be stricter than this, I think an intelligent application of the existing policies already gives you what you want.&#xD;&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:5553:  <row Id="7992" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1592" RevisionGUID="4277b4ad-be3f-47ce-bf17-cda0cf3bd901" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:48:30.257" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cs.stackexchange.com/ with https://cs.stackexchange.com/" Text="I've posted my first question:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/12585/to-what-extent-can-an-algorithm-predict-the-time-complexity-an-arbitrary-input-p#12585&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Which admittedly is not a graduate-level question, and thus not covered under the scope of this site. Given that the question was rejected from Stack Overflow for being too advanced, and now rejected from TCS for being _not advanced enough_, what are some guidelines for determining which site to send a question to? It has been suggested that this particular question can be sent to both [SE Programmers][1] and [SE CS][2], so there are four candidate sites.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I ask because the scope of each site FAQ overlaps quite a bit and I feel that, for a question like this, it can fit into several categories. As somebody familiar with the SO board, but not with these sites - it is daunting to figure out where to place my question (and others like it).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://softwareengineering.stackexchange.com/&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: https://cs.stackexchange.com/" />
./PostHistory.xml:5554:  <row Id="7993" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2661" RevisionGUID="de200464-7101-4114-ba25-cb470ccd9e7b" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:48:30.257" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cs.stackexchange.com/ with https://cs.stackexchange.com/" Text="##My question is not a research-level question in TCS, where can I ask it?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;For questions other than research-level questions in TCS, you may want to consider the following places to ask:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; * General Computer Science — [Computer Science - Stack Exchange][1]&#xD;&#xA; * General Mathematics (including *theoretical* CS) — [Mathematics - Stack Exchange][2]&#xD;&#xA; * Research-level Mathematics — [Math Overflow][3]&#xD;&#xA; * Social and Professional Academic Issues — [Academia - Stack Exchange][4]&#xD;&#xA; * Programming — [Stack Overflow][5]&#xD;&#xA; * General Artificial Intelligence — [Meta Optimize][6]&#xD;&#xA; * Statistics and Data Mining — [Cross Validated][7]&#xD;&#xA; * Applied Cryptography and Security — [Crypto - Stack Exchange][8]&#xD;&#xA; * Computation used in Science and Engineering — [Computational Science - Stack Exchange][9]&#xD;&#xA; * Questions about this site — [Theoretical Computer Science - Stack Exchange - Meta][10]&#xD;&#xA; * Other — check the list of sites on [Stack Exchange Network][11]&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cs.stackexchange.com/&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: https://math.stackexchange.com/&#xD;&#xA;  [3]: http://mathoverflow.net/&#xD;&#xA;  [4]: http://academia.stackexchange.com/&#xD;&#xA;  [5]: http://stackoverflow.com/&#xD;&#xA;  [6]: http://metaoptimize.com/qa/&#xD;&#xA;  [7]: https://stats.stackexchange.com/&#xD;&#xA;  [8]: https://crypto.stackexchange.com/&#xD;&#xA;  [9]: http://scicomp.stackexchange.com/&#xD;&#xA;  [10]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/&#xD;&#xA;  [11]: http://stackexchange.com/sites" />
./PostHistory.xml:5555:  <row Id="7994" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2698" RevisionGUID="797c75ef-91b0-4bdd-92a9-80c6e605b376" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:48:30.257" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cs.stackexchange.com/ with https://cs.stackexchange.com/" Text="##[Computer Science.SE](https://cs.stackexchange.com/)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;For questions about computer science.  This is a good alternative, for questions that are not at a research level." />
./PostHistory.xml:5556:  <row Id="7995" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2714" RevisionGUID="4b1952fa-c00c-4022-9cd9-f7eb4ac90604" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:48:30.257" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cs.stackexchange.com/ with https://cs.stackexchange.com/" Text="I propose the following guideline: suppose you're teaching a computer science class and a student comes to you with that question. How do you respond?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;In a nutshell, if you just wish the guy would go away, close in situ. If you'd like to help the guy (and the question is about computer science), migrate. In more detail:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; * “What? Is that even English?” → Close (“unclear”).&#xD;&#xA; * “Go read this book.” → Comment, close (too broad).&#xD;&#xA; * “A chimpanzee who'd attended the class would know the answer!” → Close (“unclear”), pray to that the user doesn't come back.&#xD;&#xA; * “What does this have to do with me?” → Close (off-topic).&#xD;&#xA; * “It's a matter of taste.” → Close (opinion-based).&#xD;&#xA; * “That's a direct application of something we covered in class.” → Close (“off-topic, not research-level”), point to a Wikipedia page or to a CS.SE reference thread on the topic (e.g. [How to prove that a language is not regular?](https://cs.stackexchange.com/questions/1031/how-to-prove-that-a-language-is-not-regular)).&#xD;&#xA; * “That's a good question about computer science! You see…” → migrate to CS.SE.&#xD;&#xA; * “Ok, here's a hint to solve this exercise, try it and come back.” → migrate to CS.SE.&#xD;&#xA; * “Gee, a programming question.” → migrate to SO if you think it's a really good question, otherwise close as off-topic.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;If none of the categories applies, use your judgement. There is obviously room for subjectivity. Where does [Omega of a polynomial function](https://cs.stackexchange.com/questions/13578/omega-of-a-polynomial-function) fit? I would close and answer with a comment linking to [Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Big_O_notation#Properties), because it's a really elementary question. Also, technically, it isn't a computer science question, it's a math question that falls short of reaching a CS application. I wouldn't say that migrating it is fundamentally wrong, but it is a bit of a waste of effort.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;If in doubt — if the question is not great but not crap either — you might as well migrate. If the target site doesn't like the question, it can close it." />
./PostHistory.xml:5557:  <row Id="7996" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2729" RevisionGUID="4dffcee6-8aca-4748-9088-6cd39b1a33b1" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:48:30.257" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cs.stackexchange.com/ with https://cs.stackexchange.com/" Text="I posted this [question][1] on cs.stackexchange but didn't get any answers. I was wondering if this is suitable for this site?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cs.stackexchange.com/questions/14328/difficulty-in-understanding-the-quantum-algorithm-for-the-abelian-hidden-subgrou" />
./PostHistory.xml:5558:  <row Id="7997" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2737" RevisionGUID="e8196426-aba5-4f88-b2cb-c87fc8c56f1c" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:48:30.257" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cs.stackexchange.com/ with https://cs.stackexchange.com/" Text="Sometimes (maybe once a month if it's a busy month) we have a tough question in theoretical science on [Computer Science Stack Exchange](https://cs.stackexchange.com/) that nobody can answer.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;After a while we tend to presume that if nobody answered, it's because nobody knows, which makes the question research-level. (It's usually clear which questions went unanswered because nobody knows and which questions went unanswered because nobody bothered.)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;While research-level questions in theoretical computer science are on-topic on CS.SE, it is better if questions get answered. So if a question was asked on CS.SE but would also be suitable for Theoretical Computer Science, usually someone suggests migrating it there.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Assuming that the question is indeed about theoretical computer science, that it has gone unanswered for long enough that we doubt it will be answered on CS.SE, and that the asker is willing, **should we migrate the question to CSTheory.SE?** Should we ask first, and where? ([Chat](http://chat.stackexchange.com/rooms/9446/theory-salon)? but it's pretty much dead.)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Only [moderators of CS.SE](https://cs.stackexchange.com/users?tab=moderators) can initiate the migration; if we do it it would typically be in response to a flag, often a flag from the asker.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Note that if you feel that a question should not have been migrated to CSTheory, you can close it; this will bounce the question back to its original site, but not reopen it there. (This is known as rejecting the migration.) If you find a question migrated from CS.SE and you think that it is not suitable for CSTheory.SE but should have remained open on CS.SE, please vote to close it here, and once it is closed here please flag it for reopening on CS.SE.&#xD;&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:5559:  <row Id="8000" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2789" RevisionGUID="e39bb05a-c790-43db-a429-f7d48ed89215" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:48:30.257" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cs.stackexchange.com/ with https://cs.stackexchange.com/" Text="##***personal*** view on TCS _(.se)_&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;(T)CS is a wondrous, fascinating, beautiful, deep, vibrant field. came to it in preteens, heard about public key cryptography from a relative who clipped out an article from a newspaper on it. dad, a jr high school algebra teacher, brought home one of the 1st PCs, programmed bubble sort for [***fun***,](http://vzn1.wordpress.com/2013/12/02/joy-of-code-2013-natl-cs-edu-week-dec9-16/) explained it to me and said &quot;its slow, it takes $n^2$ time to finish&quot;, and I pondered that concept like a deep zen mystery with beginners mind (before knowing what zen was). &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;in teens, wondered about shannons theorem about hard functions based on counting circuits. _and none of them can be_ ***constructed***. we know they're there, but where are they? what an astonishing deep mystery, almost like a TCS analog of [dark matter](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dark_matter)! and not the only apparent deep parallel between [TCS &amp; physics](https://physics.stackexchange.com/a/89802/33566). and still basically open after more than ½-century. truly this field is full of the Everest of problems. *many or even most in pristine pre-summited state!*&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;in college, learned/experimented/sought [FSM-enlightenment](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/14811/what-is-the-enlightenment-im-supposed-to-attain-after-studying-finite-automata) in an intriguing [research-oriented attack](http://vzn1.wordpress.com/code/collatz-conjecture-experiments/) on one mountain. climbed to a local minimum! also started experimenting with [SAT &amp; factoring](https://cs.stackexchange.com/questions/6588/reducing-the-integer-factorization-problem-to-an-np-complete-problem/6605#6605).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;there are many signs computer science is entering or in the middle of a (very long-range?) [golden age](http://cacm.acm.org/magazines/2013/2/160156-the-explosive-growth-of-postdocs-in-computer-science/fulltext), and thats motivating, energizing, even at times [exciting](http://vzn1.wordpress.com/2014/01/17/dwave-and-the-inception-of-the-qm-computing-dream/). its a field-in-motion. cutting edge and an awesome, buzzing-crackling fusion of abstract theory and real-life application. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;so, a dream job for me would be high-paying TCS research/applications and have come close to that fantasy in real life over the years. but, later, after working 4 yrs in scientific laboratory alongside graduate students and Phds, realized that combination of terms might be verging mostly on an oxymoron; ie it seemed that scientific researchers (not just those in TCS) didnt seem to be (how to put this delicately) reknowned for their salaries.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;am proud to be a contributing part of a rare, unique group that captures some of this energy/momentum/dynamism esp in the way that it [connects with applications](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/19759/core-algorithms-deployed). &#xD;&#xA;([tag:application-of-theory] is my favorite conceptual fusion/paradigm/site tag.) by some very hard work by many dedicated, farsighted, brilliant individuals, cstheory stackexchange is a really superb forum and by far the best venue on the entire cyberspace for that right now, and probably will be for years into the future. it mixes top achievers from academia with the wild open internet (another great/shearing _fusion_).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;TCS is also in the midst and at the forefront of massive/pivotal decade-long shifts and transformations. eg quantum computing, [electronic publishing/open science](http://www.amazon.com/Reinventing-Discovery-The-Networked-Science/dp/0691148902/), [collaborative filtering, collective wisdom, collective intelligence](https://cs.stackexchange.com/questions/4768/references-on-collective-intelligence-with-respect-to-cs-applications) and amazingly the stackexchange site captures various key elements of all that.&#xD;&#xA;am especially interested in &#xD;&#xA;[cyber collaboration](http://vzn1.wordpress.com/volunteer/) possibilities seen in the groundbreaking [polymath](http://polymathprojects.org/) model, which is at heart in its radical/dramatic successes not that different than the [stackexchange system](http://www.simonsfoundation.org/mathematics-and-physical-science/the-global-math-commons/).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;what is [great] TCS? how about simply listing my idiosyncratic personal TCS inspirations/influences/luminary/hero pantheon off the top of my head: [Lipton](http://www.scs.gatech.edu/features/career-solution), [Fortnow](http://www.cc.gatech.edu/features/fortnow), [Jukna](http://www.amazon.com/Boolean-Function-Complexity-Algorithms-Combinatorics/dp/3642245072), [Razborov](http://www.mathunion.org/general/prizes/nevanlinna/prize-winners/o/General/Prizes/Nevanlinna/1990/Razborov/page1.html), [Aaronson](http://www.scottaaronson.com/blog/), [Feynman](http://link.springer.com/article/10.1007%2FBF02650179), [Shor](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shor's_algorithm), Sedgewick, Knuth, [Cook](http://www.claymath.org/sites/default/files/pvsnp.pdf), [Turing](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/11797/alan-turings-contributions-to-computer-science), [Mandelbrot](http://nautil.us/issue/0/the-story-of-nautilus/in-the-mind-of-the-fractal-king), [Hofstadter](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/18968/what-are-the-popular-science-books-that-inspire-tcs), [Wolfram](http://www.wolframscience.com/). etc! (of course not coincidentally several are members of cstheory!)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;oh, and yeah, (sssh, dont tell anyone), then theres my [favorite open problem](http://vzn1.wordpress.com/2012/10/18/math-monster/) of [so many great ones too choose from](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/174/major-unsolved-problems-in-theoretical-computer-science) Ive been interested for ~2½ decades even long before there was a [huge incentive](http://www.claymath.org/millennium-problems/millennium-prize-problems)... _heaven forbid_ not claiming a _proof_ but have a [few new ideas](http://vzn1.wordpress.com/2012/12/08/outline-for-a-np-vsppoly-proof-based-on-monotone-circuits-hypergraphs-and-factoring/)!&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;speaking of zen, at rare times one might even think TCS can even reach [cosmic/transcendant/spiritual](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/189/algorithms-from-the-book) levels! (just had to somehow shamelessly work in the highest-voted question in this essay somehow!)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;hey, if theres still any question about my interest/engagement/affinity for this site, just browse/look at my huge [favorites list](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/users/7884/vzn?tab=favorites) sometime! due to the awesome stackexchange software [built by brilliant software engineers] it can even be searched by keyword eg [cc.complexity theory](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/search?tab=votes&amp;q=infavorites%3a7884%20%5bcc.complexity-theory%5d)" />
./PostHistory.xml:5560:  <row Id="8003" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2819" RevisionGUID="4a035af2-9172-4fce-b574-604e31001f53" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:48:30.257" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cs.stackexchange.com/ with https://cs.stackexchange.com/" Text="For example, this question: https://cs.stackexchange.com/questions/22864/lambda-calculus-difference-between-contexts-and-evaluation-contexts had two very thorough research-level answers, and was migrated to CS.SE. ./PostHistory.xml:5561:  <row Id="8004" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2862" RevisionGUID="645ecc52-4006-4808-ba5c-ad078659b0a4" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:48:30.257" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cs.stackexchange.com/ with https://cs.stackexchange.com/" Text="This is an intriguing idea.  Cool!  It seems like it would be a good experiment.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The tricky bit is to select the criteria for which questions would be shown.  I can see two plausible possibilities:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- Alternative 1: Have a set of tags which are eligible for this, e.g., algorithms, complexity-theory, computability, undecidability, etc.  Any question with vote total of 10+ and with at least one tag in the whitelist would then be eligible to be shown on CSTheory.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; This might whittle down the list of questions to those that are related to theoretical computer science.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; However, it has the problem that many of the questions selected in this way will not be research-level.  There are a lot of questions on CS.SE with 10+ votes that are not research-level questions in theoretical computer science, and they might be unwelcome on CSTheory.  Take a look at the [top questions on CS.SE](https://cs.stackexchange.com/questions?sort=votes) sorted by vote total, or the [top questions on CS.SE with the complexity-theory tag](https://cs.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/complexity-theory?sort=votes&amp;pageSize=50) and you'll see what I mean.  Only a small fraction of the highest-voted questions there would be a good fit for CSTheory; the majority would not be useful to display on CSTheory.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; I looked at the top 50 highest-voted questions on CS.SE with the complexity-theory tag.  All of them have a vote total of 10 or higher.  By my own highly personal assessment, about 10 of them look like they would be good to display on the CSTheory.SE front page.  The others don't look like great candidates (they are elementary, of narrow interest, or were about proving NP-hardness of a specific problem and the question has already been solved).  A 20% hit rate isn't great.  But this is my own personal taste, and others may differ.  I encourage readers to do their own count, see what they get, and post their own evaluation.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- Alternative 2: Allow moderators to select which questions are eligible for display in this way.  This could be indicated, for instance, via a moderator-only tag that's added to the question on CS.SE, which triggers it to be shown on CSTheory -- analogous to the &quot;featured&quot; tag.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; This would require some manual effort from moderators, but allows more control over which questions are displayed, and enables selecting questions which are research-level and which relate to theoretical computer science.  (A minor difficulty with using a special tag is that, if the question already has 5 tags, it may not be possible to add a 6th tag.)&#xD;&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:5562:  <row Id="8005" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2872" RevisionGUID="256d2589-7206-4fe6-8a6b-2cdee482a5c8" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:48:30.257" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cs.stackexchange.com/ with https://cs.stackexchange.com/" Text="To those who vote to close non-theoretical-computer-science questions: Thank you for tidying up the website, but when you do so, could you please choose the precise reason?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Sometimes new users post questions not in theoretical computer science but in other fields of study such as physics and more applied side of computer science.  Often many close-voters choose the following reason to close such questions:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; Your question does not appear to be a **research-level** question in theoretical computer science. For more information about the scope, please see [help center](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/help/on-topic).  Your question might be suitable for [Computer Science](https://cs.stackexchange.com/) which has a broader scope.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;While it might be technically correct, this reason is very misleading, particularly for those not familiar with theoretical computer science _such as the posters of those questions_, because the bold part strongly suggests that the problem with the question is that it is not at the research level, whereas the real problem is that it is not a question in or about theoretical computer science.  (Moreover, the question might even be a research question in the field which it belongs to.)  If you are curious, [the message quoted above was proposed to be used when a question was not research-level](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/a/2700), so it is an abuse of this reason by all means in my opinion.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;When you choose “off-topic” as the reason, you have an option to enter your custom reason instead of choosing one of the canned responses.  Please use it instead.  Unfortunately, a custom reason works differently from canned responses in that the custom reason is posted as a comment at the time you cast a vote, and I can imagine some circumstances in which you do not want to do this.  But usually this should be fine.&#xD;&#xA;" />

./PostHistory.xml:5566:  <row Id="8009" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2960" RevisionGUID="6d1874e8-9e56-4ae8-b79e-ea17d81df76f" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:48:30.257" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://cs.stackexchange.com/ with https://cs.stackexchange.com/" Text="I nominate this question:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;[Filling bins with balls][1]&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The question can be seen as an assignment problem to SAT with only 2 literals for each variable, one negated and the other positive. The question asks what is the minimum subset of clauses that have $k$ or more satisfied literals in an assignment of the formula (not necessarily an assignment that satisfies the formula). &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;[1]: https://cs.stackexchange.com/questions/54990/filling-bins-with-balls" />

./PostHistory.xml:5569:  <row Id="8012" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1228" RevisionGUID="3579e27b-797c-464f-b651-2aa8100811ab" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:49:49.167" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://academia.stackexchange.com/ with https://academia.stackexchange.com/" Text="### change log&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;----&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Jul. 27, 2012:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- Added [academia.se] to the list of suggested sites&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;----&#xD;&#xA;Mar. 20, 2012:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- Added [cs.se] to the list of suggested sites&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;----&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Feb. 23, 2012:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Another small update to the FAQ. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Change log:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; * Added [crypto.se] and [scicomp.se] to the list of suggested sites,&#xD;&#xA; * Made the tips for writing a better question a section.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;----&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Nov. 17, 2011:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I have edited the official FAQ a little bit (mainly adding links to some entries of the official FAQ that we refer to in comments). Please comemnt if you don't like the edits or have other suggestions on how to improve the general FAQ:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;----&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;[FAQ](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/faq)&#xD;&#xA;----&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;**Theoretical Computer Science - Stack Exchange** is for theoretical computer scientists and researchers in related fields.  We welcome _research-level_ questions in _theoretical computer science_ (TCS).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Although there is no black-and-white distinction between research-level questions and non-research-level questions, questions are considered to be &quot;research-level&quot; roughly when they can be discussed between two professors or between two graduate students working on Ph.D.'s, but not usually between a professor and a typical undergraduate student. It does not include questions at the level of difficulty of typical undergraduate course/textbook homework/exercise.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;For an explanation of what TCS is, we refer you to the description of ACM Special Interest Group on Algorithms and Computation Theory (SIGACT):&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; &gt; TCS covers a wide variety of topics including algorithms, data structures, computational complexity, parallel and distributed computation, probabilistic computation, quantum computation, automata theory, information theory, cryptography, program semantics and verification, machine learning, computational biology, computational economics, computational geometry, and computational number theory and algebra.  **Work in this field is often distinguished by its emphasis on mathematical technique and rigor.** &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;##My question is not a research-level question in TCS, where can I ask it?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;For questions other than research-level questions in TCS, you may want to consider the following places to ask:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; * General Computer Science — [Computer Science - Stack Exchange](https://cs.stackexchange.com/)&#xD;&#xA; * General Mathematics (including *theoretical* CS) — [Mathematics - Stack Exchange](https://math.stackexchange.com/)&#xD;&#xA; * Research-level Mathematics — [Math Overflow](http://mathoverflow.net/)&#xD;&#xA; * Social and Professional Academic Issues — [Academia - Stack Exchange](https://academia.stackexchange.com/)&#xD;&#xA; * Programming — [Stack Overflow](http://stackoverflow.com/)&#xD;&#xA; * General Artificial Intelligence — [Meta Optimize](http://metaoptimize.com/qa/)&#xD;&#xA; * Statistics and Data Mining — [Cross Validated](https://stats.stackexchange.com/)&#xD;&#xA; * Applied Cryptography and Security — [Crypto - Stack Exchange](https://crypto.stackexchange.com/)&#xD;&#xA; * Computation used in Science and Engineering — [Computational Science - Stack Exchange](http://scicomp.stackexchange.com/)&#xD;&#xA; * Questions about this site — [Theoretical Computer Science - Stack Exchange - Meta][1]&#xD;&#xA; * Other — check the list of sites on [Stack Exchange Network](http://stackexchange.com/sites)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;##Questions should be based on knowledge sharing, not on shirking&#xD;&#xA;You should only post questions you're actually seriously thinking about. Users are expected to do their part and try to answer their question by themselves before posting them on cstheory and asking for help from others. Search to see if your question is already answered somewhere else (e.g. Wikipedia) before asking a question. **Try to make your question interesting for others by providing some background knowledge**. Remember, *questions should be based on knowledge sharing, not on shirking. Shirking goes against the spirit of the site.* &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;##Tips about writing better questions&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* [How to Ask?](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/how-to-ask)&#xD;&#xA;* [How to ask a good question?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/300/how-to-ask-a-good-question)&#xD;&#xA;* [How to write a good MathOverflow question?](http://mathoverflow.net/howtoask)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Please also check our list of [**useful resources**](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/229#229) *before* asking a question.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;##FAQ&#xD;&#xA;Currently we have two separate lists of FAQs.  See also the longer **[Official Theoretical Computer Science FAQ](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science)**.  Some of the most important entries in the other FAQ are:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; * [How do I write **formulas**?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/237#237)&#xD;&#xA; * [What kind of questions are **too basic**?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/235#235)&#xD;&#xA; * [My (wonderful!) **question got closed**!  What do I do now?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/361#361)&#xD;&#xA; * [What is the **policy on crossposting** to/from MathOverflow?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/231#231)&#xD;&#xA; * [Can I ask about this **cool paper** that I just saw **on the arxiv**?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/274/is-it-ok-to-ask-about-the-correctness-of-preprints-on-crank-friendly-topics/281#281)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" />
./PostHistory.xml:5570:  <row Id="8013" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2661" RevisionGUID="569e2722-c0a4-4ab2-a749-21a287a7a156" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:49:49.167" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://academia.stackexchange.com/ with https://academia.stackexchange.com/" Text="##My question is not a research-level question in TCS, where can I ask it?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;For questions other than research-level questions in TCS, you may want to consider the following places to ask:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; * General Computer Science — [Computer Science - Stack Exchange][1]&#xD;&#xA; * General Mathematics (including *theoretical* CS) — [Mathematics - Stack Exchange][2]&#xD;&#xA; * Research-level Mathematics — [Math Overflow][3]&#xD;&#xA; * Social and Professional Academic Issues — [Academia - Stack Exchange][4]&#xD;&#xA; * Programming — [Stack Overflow][5]&#xD;&#xA; * General Artificial Intelligence — [Meta Optimize][6]&#xD;&#xA; * Statistics and Data Mining — [Cross Validated][7]&#xD;&#xA; * Applied Cryptography and Security — [Crypto - Stack Exchange][8]&#xD;&#xA; * Computation used in Science and Engineering — [Computational Science - Stack Exchange][9]&#xD;&#xA; * Questions about this site — [Theoretical Computer Science - Stack Exchange - Meta][10]&#xD;&#xA; * Other — check the list of sites on [Stack Exchange Network][11]&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cs.stackexchange.com/&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: https://math.stackexchange.com/&#xD;&#xA;  [3]: http://mathoverflow.net/&#xD;&#xA;  [4]: https://academia.stackexchange.com/&#xD;&#xA;  [5]: http://stackoverflow.com/&#xD;&#xA;  [6]: http://metaoptimize.com/qa/&#xD;&#xA;  [7]: https://stats.stackexchange.com/&#xD;&#xA;  [8]: https://crypto.stackexchange.com/&#xD;&#xA;  [9]: http://scicomp.stackexchange.com/&#xD;&#xA;  [10]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/&#xD;&#xA;  [11]: http://stackexchange.com/sites" />
./PostHistory.xml:5571:  <row Id="8015" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2931" RevisionGUID="377b0b11-d968-4c1e-8323-19b60cfd416b" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:49:49.167" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://academia.stackexchange.com/ with https://academia.stackexchange.com/" Text="[![Academia Stack Exchange][1]][2]&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://i.stack.imgur.com/Ln6N5.png&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: https://academia.stackexchange.com/" />
./PostHistory.xml:5572:  <row Id="8016" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1228" RevisionGUID="3aef957e-f908-4332-bdeb-b89fe6a71227" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:53:53.980" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://scicomp.stackexchange.com/ with https://scicomp.stackexchange.com/" Text="### change log&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;----&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Jul. 27, 2012:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- Added [academia.se] to the list of suggested sites&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;----&#xD;&#xA;Mar. 20, 2012:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- Added [cs.se] to the list of suggested sites&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;----&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Feb. 23, 2012:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Another small update to the FAQ. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Change log:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; * Added [crypto.se] and [scicomp.se] to the list of suggested sites,&#xD;&#xA; * Made the tips for writing a better question a section.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;----&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Nov. 17, 2011:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I have edited the official FAQ a little bit (mainly adding links to some entries of the official FAQ that we refer to in comments). Please comemnt if you don't like the edits or have other suggestions on how to improve the general FAQ:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;----&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;[FAQ](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/faq)&#xD;&#xA;----&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;**Theoretical Computer Science - Stack Exchange** is for theoretical computer scientists and researchers in related fields.  We welcome _research-level_ questions in _theoretical computer science_ (TCS).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Although there is no black-and-white distinction between research-level questions and non-research-level questions, questions are considered to be &quot;research-level&quot; roughly when they can be discussed between two professors or between two graduate students working on Ph.D.'s, but not usually between a professor and a typical undergraduate student. It does not include questions at the level of difficulty of typical undergraduate course/textbook homework/exercise.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;For an explanation of what TCS is, we refer you to the description of ACM Special Interest Group on Algorithms and Computation Theory (SIGACT):&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; &gt; TCS covers a wide variety of topics including algorithms, data structures, computational complexity, parallel and distributed computation, probabilistic computation, quantum computation, automata theory, information theory, cryptography, program semantics and verification, machine learning, computational biology, computational economics, computational geometry, and computational number theory and algebra.  **Work in this field is often distinguished by its emphasis on mathematical technique and rigor.** &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;##My question is not a research-level question in TCS, where can I ask it?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;For questions other than research-level questions in TCS, you may want to consider the following places to ask:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; * General Computer Science — [Computer Science - Stack Exchange](https://cs.stackexchange.com/)&#xD;&#xA; * General Mathematics (including *theoretical* CS) — [Mathematics - Stack Exchange](https://math.stackexchange.com/)&#xD;&#xA; * Research-level Mathematics — [Math Overflow](http://mathoverflow.net/)&#xD;&#xA; * Social and Professional Academic Issues — [Academia - Stack Exchange](https://academia.stackexchange.com/)&#xD;&#xA; * Programming — [Stack Overflow](http://stackoverflow.com/)&#xD;&#xA; * General Artificial Intelligence — [Meta Optimize](http://metaoptimize.com/qa/)&#xD;&#xA; * Statistics and Data Mining — [Cross Validated](https://stats.stackexchange.com/)&#xD;&#xA; * Applied Cryptography and Security — [Crypto - Stack Exchange](https://crypto.stackexchange.com/)&#xD;&#xA; * Computation used in Science and Engineering — [Computational Science - Stack Exchange](https://scicomp.stackexchange.com/)&#xD;&#xA; * Questions about this site — [Theoretical Computer Science - Stack Exchange - Meta][1]&#xD;&#xA; * Other — check the list of sites on [Stack Exchange Network](http://stackexchange.com/sites)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;##Questions should be based on knowledge sharing, not on shirking&#xD;&#xA;You should only post questions you're actually seriously thinking about. Users are expected to do their part and try to answer their question by themselves before posting them on cstheory and asking for help from others. Search to see if your question is already answered somewhere else (e.g. Wikipedia) before asking a question. **Try to make your question interesting for others by providing some background knowledge**. Remember, *questions should be based on knowledge sharing, not on shirking. Shirking goes against the spirit of the site.* &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;##Tips about writing better questions&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* [How to Ask?](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/how-to-ask)&#xD;&#xA;* [How to ask a good question?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/300/how-to-ask-a-good-question)&#xD;&#xA;* [How to write a good MathOverflow question?](http://mathoverflow.net/howtoask)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Please also check our list of [**useful resources**](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/229#229) *before* asking a question.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;##FAQ&#xD;&#xA;Currently we have two separate lists of FAQs.  See also the longer **[Official Theoretical Computer Science FAQ](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science)**.  Some of the most important entries in the other FAQ are:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; * [How do I write **formulas**?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/237#237)&#xD;&#xA; * [What kind of questions are **too basic**?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/235#235)&#xD;&#xA; * [My (wonderful!) **question got closed**!  What do I do now?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/361#361)&#xD;&#xA; * [What is the **policy on crossposting** to/from MathOverflow?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/231#231)&#xD;&#xA; * [Can I ask about this **cool paper** that I just saw **on the arxiv**?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/274/is-it-ok-to-ask-about-the-correctness-of-preprints-on-crank-friendly-topics/281#281)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" />
./PostHistory.xml:5573:  <row Id="8017" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1488" RevisionGUID="029955aa-dfba-481f-ac10-7d2dd9088c7f" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:53:53.980" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://scicomp.stackexchange.com/ with https://scicomp.stackexchange.com/" Text="While checking [computational science meta](https://scicomp.meta.stackexchange.com/) today, I noticed that my perception about the  [proposal][1]/[site][2] might not be true. mbq, the original person behind the proposal is not that much involved anymore and there has been some changes. See for example [this meta question about their scope][3].&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;My perception was that the site is for &quot;scientists doing science by heavy computations&quot;. But it seems that it might not be true anymore that there are questions about algorithms and distributed computing among other things. I am not saying that there is significant overlap right now (I haven't had time to go over the questions on the site) but I am now concerned about it.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;See also my discussion with Geoff (one of pro-term moderators) [here](https://scicomp.meta.stackexchange.com/a/176/207).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I don't think we want to see another SE site covering a significant part of our scope (as crypto.se did and hit the number of crypto questions on cstheory, see [this](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/tags/cr.crypto-security/topusers)).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Here are some question that I think we need to think about:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; Do you think there is a problem about the current scope of computational sciences site? Do we need to be concerned about this?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; What distinguishes questions that are suitable for cstheory from those on computational sciences and vic versa on overlapping topics (like algorithms, distributed computing, ...)? Is there a significant overlap? &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; What should we do if there is a significant overlap between the two sites?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;----&#xD;&#xA;As a side issue, I feel that we might have an even larger problem when the CS proposal launches if its scope is modified later in such a way that it contains cstheory, and I should say that [the current attitude of the SE team about the proposal description][4] is not comforting for me. As I said earlier, I support a math.se like version of CS, but I don't want it to start to significantly overlap with cstheory. I think the effect of crypto.se on our crypto questions is quite clear.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://area51.stackexchange.com/proposals/28815/computational-science&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: https://scicomp.stackexchange.com/&#xD;&#xA;  [3]: https://scicomp.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/2/lets-define-our-scope&#xD;&#xA;  [4]: http://discuss.area51.stackexchange.com/questions/4226/computer-science-the-audience-description-is-now-wrong" />

./PostHistory.xml:5579:  <row Id="8023" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="173" RevisionGUID="83d3b7d3-fffb-4998-a9d1-329cbd53b3d3" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:57:54.527" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://mathoverflow.net/ with https://mathoverflow.net/" Text="Over at MathOverflow the community accepts math puzzles, and in fact even has a [couple][1] [tags][2] devoted to them. Of course, puzzles can be illuminating when they require that one makes some creative observation or employ some particularly tricky technique. At the same time, puzzles can be distracting and wholey inappropriate in the landscape of a professional forum.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I think we should decide, before we see our first brain teaser, whether such puzzles are welcome here on CSTheory.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;[1]: https://mathoverflow.net/questions/tagged/recreational&#xD;&#xA;[2]: https://mathoverflow.net/questions/tagged/puzzle" />
./PostHistory.xml:5580:  <row Id="8024" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="175" RevisionGUID="c76546d2-ebd5-4d3f-921b-597e2fa6430d" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:57:54.527" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://mathoverflow.net/ with https://mathoverflow.net/" Text="I think that questions related to &quot;recreational computer science&quot; are welcome. That is, it's perfectly fine if the problem that you are trying to solve doesn't have any applications, and it is fine if it sounds more like something for [FUN](http://www.di.unipi.it/fun07/) than something for FOCS, as long as it is a *good* question. And I think that we have already seen examples of such questions.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Perhaps in future we could also try to have a CW thread like [this](https://mathoverflow.net/questions/29323/math-puzzles-for-dinner), but the consensus seems to be that we have already too many CW questions, so let's wait a bit..." />
./PostHistory.xml:5581:  <row Id="8025" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="198" RevisionGUID="973e9380-d185-4947-a2a9-3bef70bc0799" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:57:54.527" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://mathoverflow.net/ with https://mathoverflow.net/" Text="Many open problems (and some experiments, like hard IMO problems) are handled on the [polymath blog][1].
