JeffE's questions would sit well in a 'CS polymath' blog.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;*Edit*: In other words, I think it's better to start a blog associated with this site, instead of discussing open problems here.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://polymathprojects.org/&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: https://mathoverflow.net/questions/tagged/polymath5" />
./PostHistory.xml:5582:  <row Id="8026" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="231" RevisionGUID="c9a81697-6506-495e-9a0f-d5f2d8f70960" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:57:54.527" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://mathoverflow.net/ with https://mathoverflow.net/" Text="What is the policy on crossposting to/from MathOverflow or other StackExchange sites?&#xD;&#xA;--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Crossposting from [MathOverflow](https://mathoverflow.net/) and other StackExchange sites is perfectly fine, as long as they aren't done in parallel. That is, if you post a question on one site, you should only post to the other site after you have not received a satisfactory answer for some time, and you should provide a link in each post (or in the comments on it) to the other one. As a courtesy, if you post your question here after trying MathOverflow or another StackExchange site, please try to integrate in your question the answers you received on MathOverflow/the other site (even if they did not answer everything).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;---&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Related discussion:&#xD;&#xA;[[1]](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/25/material-to-supplement-the-faq/36#36)&#xD;&#xA;[[2]](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/65/repeat-a-question-from-math-overflow)&#xD;&#xA;[[3]](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/a/2853)" />
./PostHistory.xml:5583:  <row Id="8027" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="300" RevisionGUID="a1515bfa-d306-4428-b9d2-c7b66c7d7117" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:57:54.527" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://mathoverflow.net/ with https://mathoverflow.net/" Text="The moderators spend considerable time on editing badly written questions. A possible way for reducing the number of badly written questions is writing down some guidelines (similar to the MO [guidelines](https://mathoverflow.net/howtoask)) on how to ask/write a good question, and possibly add a link to it on the top of the &quot;ask question&quot; page.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;This thread is for discussing related issues, specially what should be included in our guidelines?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;---&#xD;&#xA;Related: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/q/295/186" />
./PostHistory.xml:5584:  <row Id="8028" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="323" RevisionGUID="805b3763-118d-4d39-9d2b-1508d2eec90a" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:57:54.527" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://mathoverflow.net/ with https://mathoverflow.net/" Text="**Ask a focused question that has a specific goal**&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;MO's FAQ has this beautiful section, which I'll just link to instead of copying:&#xD;&#xA;https://mathoverflow.net/howtoask#specific&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Some of the questions I vote to close fail this test. As the MO FAQ puts it:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; Ask yourself, &quot;If I saw an answer to this question, could I confidently determine whether it tells the asker what she actually wants to know?&quot;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Come to the think of it, the MO FAQ is very well written. Can we copy some of it verbatim?" />
./PostHistory.xml:5585:  <row Id="8029" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="355" RevisionGUID="2a6d4e7e-c2b8-4c70-9fab-a1cfc991e625" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:57:54.527" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://mathoverflow.net/ with https://mathoverflow.net/" Text="This has come up on MO, and they actually have a nifty cite link for questions and answers. A question gets cited like this:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; @MISC {MO39428,    &#xD;&#xA;&gt;     TITLE = {x-th moment method},    &#xD;&#xA;&gt;     AUTHOR = {fkenter (mathoverflow.net/users/8894)},    &#xD;&#xA;&gt;     HOWPUBLISHED = {MathOverflow},    &#xD;&#xA;&gt;     NOTE = {URL: https://mathoverflow.net/questions/39428&#xD;&#xA;&gt; (version: 2010-09-21)},    &#xD;&#xA;&gt;     EPRINT = {https://mathoverflow.net/questions/39428},&#xD;&#xA;&gt; &#xD;&#xA;&gt;     URL = {https://mathoverflow.net/questions/39428},&#xD;&#xA;&gt; }&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;and an answer gets cited like this: &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; @MISC {MO39450,    &#xD;&#xA;&gt;     TITLE = {x-th moment method},    &#xD;&#xA;&gt;     AUTHOR = {Mark Meckes (mathoverflow.net/users/1044)},    &#xD;&#xA;&gt;     HOWPUBLISHED = {MathOverflow},    &#xD;&#xA;&gt;     NOTE = {URL: https://mathoverflow.net/questions/39450&#xD;&#xA;&gt; (version: 2010-09-21)},    &#xD;&#xA;&gt;     EPRINT = {https://mathoverflow.net/questions/39450},&#xD;&#xA;&gt; &#xD;&#xA;&gt;     URL = {https://mathoverflow.net/questions/39450},&#xD;&#xA;&gt; }&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I think that's a reasonable way to do it, so the site gets mentioned. This can be done even if the mention is an acknowledgement: we can say &quot;The authors thank so and So\cite{} for their comments leading to the proof of Lemma 2.1&quot;. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;In other words, whether you choose to cite or acknowledge, the citation mechanism can be used, and I think that's appropriate. The difference between this and a coffee room discussion is that there's no permanent record of the latter to cite, and modulo linkrot, there's one here. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;If you want to acknowledge multiple users, you can use their cstheory user page, or their actual page if it's linked there. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;What we also need is a way to keep track of such references if they appear. It's too soon now, but maybe if anyone sees one they can create a new CW question and start listing examples. " />
./PostHistory.xml:5586:  <row Id="8030" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="356" RevisionGUID="5ada90f7-0d98-4190-8fc3-607ef3dbb5a2" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:57:54.527" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://mathoverflow.net/ with https://mathoverflow.net/" Text="**Update**: I gave up trying to convince other people to use “too localized” instead of “off topic” when closing too elementary questions.  It seems that most people disagree, and I started to feel that it is a waste of time to try to convince people otherwise.  For now, I still hesitate to vote for off topic (or to be listed as one of the people who closed the question as off topic) when I see too elementary a question, so probably I will not vote to close it.  Hopefully there are enough people to close it anyway.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;---&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;When we vote to close a question, we choose the reason from several choices.  It seems that if a question is too elementary, it is often closed for the reason “off topic.”&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I understand that this choice of reason is based on the consensus about the expected level of questions on cstheory.stackexchange.com.  However, if a question is closed for the reason “off topic,” the following explanation is added to the question:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; closed as off topic by [Someone], [Someone], [Someone], [Someone], [Someone] [Date]&#xD;&#xA;&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; Questions on Theoretical Computer Science are expected to generally relate to Theoretical Computer Science, within the scope defined in the [faq](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/faq).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I have trouble even parsing this sentence because of the tentative name of the website, but more importantly this does not mention the expected level of questions on cstheory.stackexchange.com.  It plainly states that the question is not related to the theoretical computer science, which is often false.  This gives the false impression that we take the theoretical computer science very narrowly.  I think that this is problematic.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;(_Added in revision 5_: The link in the explanation quoted above links to the [built-in FAQ](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/faq), not to the [FAQ on Meta](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science).  The built-in FAQ is not clear about the expected level of questions, either, except that the sentence “Theoretical Computer Science - Stack Exchange is for theoretical computer scientists and researchers in related fields” may suggest that research-level questions are expected.  A clearer statement can be reached by the following chain of links: the explanation of “off topic” → [built-in FAQ](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/faq) → [FAQ on Meta](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science) → [What kind of questions are too basic?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/235#235)  But I doubt that users can find this path unless they are already familiar with the website.)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;What should we do?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Here are a few suggestions:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;1. If the consensus is really that cstheory.stackexchange.com is for questions of at least certain level, the explanation of the reason “off topic” should be rewritten to reflect it.  Is this possible?&#xD;&#xA;2. &lt;del&gt;On [MathOverflow](https://mathoverflow.net/), too elementary questions are often closed for the reason “too localized.”  Obviously this is an abuse and [it certainly confuses some users](https://meta.mathoverflow.net/discussion/274/what-does-too-localized-mean-exactly/), but it is possible to interpret it as “This question is so elementary that it is useful only for the asker,” and it is understandable (or at least less prone to misunderstanding).  How about adopting this convention, at least until the explanation of “off topic” is modified to a better description?&lt;/del&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Related:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- See a [related FAQ entry](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/235#235) and the links given there for discussions about what we mean by “too elementary.”&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;_Added in revision 4:_ Whereas the description of the close reason is not shown on the question page on MathOverflow, it is shown on cstheory.stackexchange.com, which may make abusing harder.  Here is the description of the close reason “too localized”:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; This question would only be relevant to a small geographic area, a specific moment in time, or an extraordinarily narrow situation that is not generally applicable to the worldwide audience of the internet.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The point of the suggestion 2 above is that it is at least possible to argue that too elementary questions fall into the third group (and possibly also the second group) of this description.&#xD;&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:5587:  <row Id="8031" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="365" RevisionGUID="a2ea95f9-0b3e-4062-badd-019a63c04729" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:57:54.527" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://mathoverflow.net/ with https://mathoverflow.net/" Text="Just below every MO question appears the following line set off in a box:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; Remember to vote up questions/answers you find interesting or helpful (requires 15 reputation points)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;My question: Should we too have something along these lines, to nudge people into voting up questions/answers that they like? I feel that we should: the reminder helps one remember translate one's appreciation into a vote.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I was prompted to ask this question by the rather low proportion of votes scored by even the [most popular questions][1] here. MO questions seem to score around [twice as many votes][2] for the same amount of popularity (~ views).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions?sort=votes&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: https://mathoverflow.net/questions?sort=votes" />
./PostHistory.xml:5588:  <row Id="8032" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="473" RevisionGUID="756d2af0-0f63-44ac-8e1a-060c0baba1a8" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:57:54.527" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://mathoverflow.net/ with https://mathoverflow.net/" Text="Here are a few elevator pitches which I came up with.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; Drop-in seminar to share problems and answers in theoretical computer science, 24/7.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;(The idea to compare the site to a seminar is borrowed from [MathOverflow](https://mathoverflow.net/faq#pants).  Could use more polishing, as András commented.)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; Virtual coffee break for theoretical computer scientists to ask and answer questions.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;(The coffee-break idea is borrowed from the answers to the question “[How will you cite a discussion on this site in your paper?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/352/how-will-you-cite-a-discussion-on-this-site-in-your-paper)” on Meta.  Coffee was mentioned earlier in a [domain name suggestion](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/1/what-should-our-site-domain-name-be/116#116).)&#xD;&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:5589:  <row Id="8033" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="504" RevisionGUID="cd602546-d003-4744-a3e6-aedd61d1a72f" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:57:54.527" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://mathoverflow.net/ with https://mathoverflow.net/" Text="### Make your title your question&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Try to be as specific as possible about the title of your question. Avoid using general titles that don't specify your question. Don't use the title as a tag.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Read the corresponding MO [guideline][1].&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://mathoverflow.net/howtoask#yourtitle" />
./PostHistory.xml:5590:  <row Id="8034" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="506" RevisionGUID="56c74a13-49a9-43fd-86bb-93820d2e3acf" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:57:54.527" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://mathoverflow.net/ with https://mathoverflow.net/" Text="### Read the MO guidelines &quot;how to ask&quot;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;MathOverflow has a very well written guideline about asking questions, all of the items in their guideline applies to this site also. Please read their [guideline][1].&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://mathoverflow.net/howtoask" />
./PostHistory.xml:5591:  <row Id="8035" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="507" RevisionGUID="e59f6f9a-4f45-4bea-b74b-b2709d0a03e5" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:57:54.527" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://mathoverflow.net/ with https://mathoverflow.net/" Text="### Provide background information&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Try to make your question self-contained. The users of this site are **not** machines and are **not** paid to answer your questions. Be nice to others. Spend some time in explaining the background of your question and the terminology you are using to make it understandable to people not familiar with what you are asking (at least provide a link to a source that would explain the terminology). Make reading your question pleasant to other users of the site.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;You might say, “But anyone working on this field should know what XYZ is.  If someone does not know what it is, he/she cannot answer my question anyway, so explaining it will not help my question get answered.”  That may be correct or incorrect.  It may be incorrect because sometimes people from surprisingly different background can give you useful insight if a question is written in an accessible way.  However, more importantly, do not be selfish.  Let other users learn from your question even if they have absolutely zero probability of being able to answer your question.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Read [the related MO guideline][1].&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://mathoverflow.net/howtoask#motivation" />
./PostHistory.xml:5592:  <row Id="8036" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="588" RevisionGUID="f0153765-af1f-48de-8f34-09b9e4151b1f" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:57:54.527" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://mathoverflow.net/ with https://mathoverflow.net/" Text="I have created [tag-removed] because I saw a similar practice and [tag](https://mathoverflow.net/questions/tagged/tag-removed) on MO. I think the point is not really tagging closed question, the point is *removing all tags from off-topic question* so they do not show up when we search for those tags, and adding [tag-removed] is mainly for stating that the tags are removed from the question and keep all questions tagged with at least one tag." />
./PostHistory.xml:5593:  <row Id="8037" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="665" RevisionGUID="a6609180-8c6f-41dd-bd1c-7b34f04a42f3" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:57:54.527" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://mathoverflow.net/ with https://mathoverflow.net/" Text="Here is a [question][1] cross-posted to MO and answered [there](https://mathoverflow.net/questions/46180/how-to-sample-pairwise-independent-gaussians). The OP has accepted the answer on MO. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Should we ask OP to post an answer with a link to the answer on the other site (alternatively copy the answer from the other site) and accept it so the question does not remain unanswered on cstheory?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;A previous [case](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2611/complexity-of-finding-the-eigendecomposition-of-a-matrix) of the situation where another suer has posted an answer with linking to the answer on MO.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/3034/pairwise-independent-gaussians" />
./PostHistory.xml:5594:  <row Id="8038" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="759" RevisionGUID="eacc3a88-ae50-4bd9-9a3b-fa6e9c56c079" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:57:54.527" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://mathoverflow.net/ with https://mathoverflow.net/" Text="I have been thinking about this for sometime. As you know, SE has changed the Community Wiki policy and now only moderators can make a question a CW. Community Wiki has 2 main effects:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;1. The question becomes owned by community, the original OP does not gain reputation,&#xD;&#xA;2. The required reputation to edit drops to 100,&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;and a side effect:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;3. The answers posted after a questions becomes a Community Wiki become Community Wiki automatically, i.e. the answers are owned by community, (but answers posted before the question becoming CW don't).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;These three effects are not always correlated and there are cases that one wants to have one of these three but not the other two, e.g. the owner does not want to earn reputation but wants the users answering the question to earn reputation for their answers. So it seems to me that SE is mixing too many things in one concept and that is the main reason for many issues we had and have with CW policy.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Robin brought up the idea that we should make the non-CW answers to a CW question CW also. I have a problem with answers becoming CW when the question becomes CW because sometimes the answers deserve to earn reputation, but in the current situation it makes sense, if the answers need to be CW then the previous ones also need to be CW, on the other hand a user might not have answered a question if it was a CW question so I don't know what is the right thing to do here.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I see three clear reasons for making a question a CW (and it would be nice to add other reasons to this list):&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;1. OP doesn't want to earn reputation (for some reason),&#xD;&#xA;2. OP wants to allow others to edit,&#xD;&#xA;3. the question is a ranking list.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;For example I think a question like [this][1] and [this][2] should be CW but the answers should not be and the users answering them should earn reputation for their answers. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Another issue is that the new policy is not clear on what we should do when we think a question or answer needs to be CW, I used to flag some posts for moderator attention but don't do it any more because I now think it is not very nice to suggest someone else question or answer should be CW to the moderators, so I have decided to go with a softer way of adding comments like &quot;I would upvote it if it becomes CW&quot;.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I have an proposal that I think might solve some issues and would like to hear what others think about it:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; In general the question or answer should be made CW only on the request of the owner (with some exceptions, see below), other users that think the post should be CW can leave a non-abusive comment like: &quot;nice answer, I would upvote it if it becomes CW&quot; and up-vote only if/when it becomes CW.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Exceptions:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;1. the OP is a drive-by user and does not reply to the answers or comments after considerable time,&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;2. some clear cases like: a ranking list. These should be explicitly included in the policy,&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;3. other special situations where the moderators have strong reasons for making a question CW.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;What do you think about this proposal (agree, disagree, opinions, improvements and suggestions, ...) and CW in general? &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;**ps:**&#xD;&#xA;Another minor issue about CW is its (lack of) effect on badges, it seems strange that a user does not earn reputation but does earn badges for CW posts, e.g. I should not have earned a badges for [these answers](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/174/major-unsolved-problems-in-theoretical-computer-science/218#218). Right now many of higher level badges are awarded for CW questions/answers, which does not seem a good thing to me.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;---&#xD;&#xA;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/239#239&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/25/material-to-supplement-the-faq&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;---&#xD;&#xA;### MO policy&#xD;&#xA; - https://meta.mathoverflow.net/discussion/6/when-should-questions-be-community-wiki&#xD;&#xA; - https://mathoverflow.net/faq#communitywiki&#xD;&#xA; &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### SE policy&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; - https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/392/should-the-community-wiki-police-be-shut-down&#xD;&#xA; - https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/67581/community-wiki-checkbox-missing-in-action&#xD;&#xA; - https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/67039/what-can-we-do-to-make-community-wiki-better&#xD;&#xA; - https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/11740/what-are-community-wiki-posts&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### Old discussions on cstheory meta:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; - https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/34/community-wiki-etiquette&#xD;&#xA; - https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/62/developing-a-cw-policy&#xD;&#xA; - https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/201/community-wikis&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]:  https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/45/what-are-good-references-to-understanding-the-proof-of-the-pcp-theorem&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2953/advice-on-good-research-practices" />
./PostHistory.xml:5595:  <row Id="8039" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="793" RevisionGUID="1df90399-8ab4-487a-ac8e-451123f77735" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:57:54.527" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://mathoverflow.net/ with https://mathoverflow.net/" Text="## Five-minute edit window&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;When you make a post (a question or an answer) and edit it later, it creates a new revision.  However, if the edit is within five minutes from the original post or the last edit, it does not become a new revision but simply overwrites the last revision.  Usually we do not have to be aware of this, but it becomes relevant if we try to write a sensible edit summary (in the “Edit Summary” textbox on the edit page) because overwriting the revision also overwrites the edit summary.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;For example, suppose that you posted an answer, and made a heavy edit one week later.  You wrote the summary “improved the analysis significantly.”  Just after you hit the “Save Edits” button, you realized several typos in your answer and fixed it with the summary “fixed typos.”  Now the revision history shows an interesting thing: it shows only two revisions, and the newer revision making the significant improvement is shown with the summary “fixed typos.”  :(&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;(This happened to me on MathOverflow.  See the revision 3 of [this revision history](https://mathoverflow.net/revisions/33857/list).)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### Workaround&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;It is easiest to forget about edit summaries, since almost no one will look at the revision history (probably).  However, if you want to make it perfect, you should know what will happen to the edit summary when you edit one post successively.  In particular, you should know whether it will have passed more than five minutes since the last edit or not when you submit the edit, and write the edit summary accordingly.&#xD;&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:5596:  <row Id="8040" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="802" RevisionGUID="5dd61e62-5a64-4a07-bfb6-0b8bd2bc279b" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:57:54.527" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://mathoverflow.net/ with https://mathoverflow.net/" Text="&gt; This policy is now in effect, with 13 votes in favor and 2 against. In addition, three of the amendments suggested in comments passed as well. The new policy on 'topic of research' questions is as follows: &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; **POLICY**: Thesis topic questions are only within site scope if the asker requests feedback about a specific proposed topic. Questions like “What would be a good topic?” will be deemed to be general and unfocused and therefore will be closed. The OP has the option of requesting a reopening of the question if it is modified as per the above policy&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; A special exception can be made for specific programming-style projects on a specific topic, or requests for ideas for implementation, along the lines of [this question][1].&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; When closing a question using this policy as the basis, please link to this discussion. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;From time to time, someone posts a question requesting advice on choosing a research project.  This might be a project for a class, a Master's Thesis, or even the focus of a doctoral dissertation.  We believe the best resources to consult are your course instructor, teaching assistants, and thesis advisor.  They can provide better, more in-depth, advice than brief answers on a web site.  For anyone who would like to ask such questions here anyway, please be aware of the following policy: &#xD;&#xA;&gt; **POLICY**: Thesis topic questions are only within site scope if the asker requests feedback about a specific proposed topic.  General, unfocused questions like, &quot;What would be a good topic?&quot; will be closed as off topic.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;One of the objectives of this site is, &quot;Knowledge sharing, not shirking.&quot;  An essential part of research is to brainstorm project ideas that may or may not be sound, so it is reasonable to use this site to ask for feedback about a project idea you thought up but have not thoroughly investigated. On the other hand, if a project (or thesis) is supposed to be _yours_, it is inappropriate to leave all the conceptual work to others.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;**Update**: Note that there are now suggested modifications to the policy in the answers. Please vote on them as well (the same rule applies for adoption). &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://mathoverflow.net/questions/18440/what-algorithm-in-algebraic-geometry-should-i-work-on-implementing/" />
./PostHistory.xml:5597:  <row Id="8041" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="812" RevisionGUID="d4e8edbe-8842-4166-8f20-00ca64e18862" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:57:54.527" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://mathoverflow.net/ with https://mathoverflow.net/" Text="I think we should distinguish between asking for a research topic and asking for a topic for an undergrad programming project (like in this question: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/3736/ideas-for-a-project-in-mathematica-related-to-theoretical-computer-science ). Of course this site is not the right place for asking for a topic of a PhD dissertation, but I think we should accept questions like &quot;How can I put 10 thousand lines of Java code to a good TCS-related cause?&quot; (or maybe better we could create a big list of ideas for such projects). Moreover, questions like these seem welcome on mathoverflow: https://mathoverflow.net/questions/18440/what-algorithm-in-algebraic-geometry-should-i-work-on-implementing/&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;When I was an undergrad I had to write thousands of lines of code in various languages, quite often with a free topic (and the topic didn't really count towards the grade, the only criterion was a solid amount of working code). It is usually the case that such projects are used just once for 10 minutes by the grader, and then thrown away - so it's like a week of effort wasted (and there are also courses where for example four people write a project together for a year, so the outcome could potentially be really something very useful).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I think it would be a win-win situation if researchers would be able to put on this site (for example in a big-list topic) announcements like: &quot;I need a program searching for a small counterexample for some conjecture&quot; or &quot;I have an idea for an interesting game/simulation spreading the ideas of TCS, but I don't have the time to write it&quot; and so on; the students could then use these ideas for writing their projects, and if successful they would afterwards share the result with the scientific community." />
./PostHistory.xml:5598:  <row Id="8042" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="927" RevisionGUID="f424d657-b112-45ba-af55-a8c0a2888337" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:57:54.527" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://mathoverflow.net/ with https://mathoverflow.net/" Text="To put things forward, I suggest a concrete text.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The current text:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; Theoretical Computer Science - Stack Exchange is for theoretical computer scientists and researchers in related fields.&#xD;&#xA;&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; A rough outline (inclusive, but not exclusive) of topics that are &quot;within scope&quot; for this site is as follows:&#xD;&#xA;&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; &gt; The field of theoretical computer science is interpreted broadly so as to include algorithms, data structures, computational complexity theory, distributed computation, parallel computation, VLSI, machine learning, computational biology, computational geometry, information theory, cryptography, quantum computation, computational number theory and algebra, program semantics and verification, automata theory, and the study of randomness.  **Work in this field is often distinguished by its emphasis on mathematical technique and rigor.**&#xD;&#xA;&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; General FAQs about using the Stack Exchange system are given below.  For specific questions more pertinent to this particular site, please visit the **[Official Theoretical Computer Science FAQ](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science)**.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Although this is not bad as a starting point, there are several shortcomings.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* As is often pointed out, it only mentions what theoretical computer science is and that it does not mention the expected level of questions.&#xD;&#xA;* Related to the first item, a list of alternative sites to ask questions is desirable.  The scope of our website is often better communicated by such a list.&#xD;&#xA;* The quotation is unclear about where it is quoted from.  In fact, it is originally quoted from the self-description of ACM SIGACT but it seems that SIGACT has modified this description after the text was copied, so it is kind of obsolete.  For example, the current list includes computational economics and omits the reference to VLSI, both of which are understandable.&#xD;&#xA;* I cannot see the point of emphasizing only the last sentence in the quotation from SIGACT.&#xD;&#xA;* The distinction between “general FAQs” and “official theoretical computer science FAQ” is confusing at best and makes no sense at worst.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I suggest to revise the above text to the following.  [https://math.stackexchange.com/faq/](https://math.stackexchange.com/faq/) is written very well, and I stole part of the general structure from it.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; **Theoretical Computer Science - Stack Exchange** is for theoretical computer scientists and researchers in related fields.  We welcome _research-level_ questions in _theoretical computer science_ (TCS).&#xD;&#xA;&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; Although there is no black-and-white distinction between research-level questions and non-research-level questions, questions are considered to be “research-level” roughly when they can be discussed between two professors or between two graduate students working on Ph.D.’s, but not usually between a professor and a typical undergraduate student.&#xD;&#xA;&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; For questions other than research-level questions in TCS, you may want to consider the following places to ask:&#xD;&#xA;&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; * Research-level mathematics — [Math Overflow](https://mathoverflow.net/)&#xD;&#xA;&gt; * Programming — [Stack Overflow](http://stackoverflow.com/)&#xD;&#xA;&gt; * General mathematics — [Mathematics - Stack Exchange](https://math.stackexchange.com/); they seem to accept also questions in TCS.&#xD;&#xA;&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; For an explanation of what TCS is, we refer you to the description of ACM Special Interest Group on Algorithms and Computation Theory (SIGACT):&#xD;&#xA;&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; &gt; TCS covers a wide variety of topics including algorithms, data structures, computational complexity, parallel and distributed computation, probabilistic computation, quantum computation, automata theory, information theory, cryptography, program semantics and verification, machine learning, computational biology, computational economics, computational geometry, and computational number theory and algebra.  Work in this field is often distinguished by its emphasis on mathematical technique and rigor. &#xD;&#xA;&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; Currently we have two separate lists of FAQs.  See also **[Official Theoretical Computer Science FAQ](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science)**.  Some of the most important entries in the other FAQ are:&#xD;&#xA;&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; * [What kind of questions are too basic?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/235#235)&#xD;&#xA;&gt; * [How to ask a good question?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/300/how-to-ask-a-good-question)&#xD;&#xA;&gt; * [How do I write formulas?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/237#237)&#xD;&#xA;&gt; * [My (wonderful!) question was closed!  What do I do now?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/361#361)&#xD;&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:5599:  <row Id="8043" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1058" RevisionGUID="578462d8-59fa-41ff-9b0b-a04bb62e6e55" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:57:54.527" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://mathoverflow.net/ with https://mathoverflow.net/" Text="Updated version (March 20, 2011):&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; Use this tag if:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt;- **well-known open problems**: the problem is equivalent to a well-known [open problem](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open_problem) in the literature&#xD;&#xA;- **community open problems**: the question is not answered after considerable time and the community decides that the question is an open problem ([meta][1] can be used for discussions)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt;---&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt;[cstheory][2] is **not** the right place to ask **well-known open problems**. You should post questions you're actually seriously thinking about. If you're thinking about a well-known open problem, provide some background and ask about something specific related to the problem, like &quot;Such and such is a well-known open problem. So-and-so proposed this and that approach. Does anybody know if this aspect of their proposal can be made to work under these circumstances?&quot; If you want to contribute to (or view) a list of open problems, visit the [Open Problem Garden][3].&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt;If it turns out that a problem is equivalent to a well-known open problem, then the [tag:open-problem] tag is added. After that, the question essentially becomes, &quot;What is known about this problem? What are some possible ways to approach this problem? What are some ways that people have tried to attack it before, and with what results?&quot; That way, the cstheory thread for the problem becomes a repository of resources related to the problem. Perhaps the answers could be organized by approach, with an outline of the basic approach, followed by a horizontal rule and a summary of what is promising about the approach and why it doesn't give a complete solution.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt;To join the discussion about how cstheory should deal with open problems, go to [this][4] meta cstheory thread.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;---&#xD;&#xA;The [tag:open-problem]'s [tag wiki][5] is based on [MO][6]'s FAQ on open-problems.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/&#xD;&#xA;  [3]: http://garden.irmacs.sfu.ca/&#xD;&#xA;  [4]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/1058/tag-wiki-open-problem&#xD;&#xA;  [5]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/open-problem  &#xD;&#xA;  [6]: https://mathoverflow.net/faq#openproblems&#xD;&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:5600:  <row Id="8044" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1144" RevisionGUID="b179b574-082e-4575-82bd-c8334b673171" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:57:54.527" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://mathoverflow.net/ with https://mathoverflow.net/" Text="I'm sure everybody is familiar with [mathoverflow][1]. But do you know that they have for each question and answer a &quot;cite&quot; link that opens up a window with a bibtex citation? I'm using them right now and they're great!!&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Can we have something like that? &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://mathoverflow.net/" />
./PostHistory.xml:5601:  <row Id="8045" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1228" RevisionGUID="68f80526-2be6-478e-9783-acf75da05b4e" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:57:54.527" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://mathoverflow.net/ with https://mathoverflow.net/" Text="### change log&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;----&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Jul. 27, 2012:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- Added [academia.se] to the list of suggested sites&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;----&#xD;&#xA;Mar. 20, 2012:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- Added [cs.se] to the list of suggested sites&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;----&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Feb. 23, 2012:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Another small update to the FAQ. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Change log:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; * Added [crypto.se] and [scicomp.se] to the list of suggested sites,&#xD;&#xA; * Made the tips for writing a better question a section.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;----&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Nov. 17, 2011:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I have edited the official FAQ a little bit (mainly adding links to some entries of the official FAQ that we refer to in comments). Please comemnt if you don't like the edits or have other suggestions on how to improve the general FAQ:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;----&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;[FAQ](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/faq)&#xD;&#xA;----&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;**Theoretical Computer Science - Stack Exchange** is for theoretical computer scientists and researchers in related fields.  We welcome _research-level_ questions in _theoretical computer science_ (TCS).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Although there is no black-and-white distinction between research-level questions and non-research-level questions, questions are considered to be &quot;research-level&quot; roughly when they can be discussed between two professors or between two graduate students working on Ph.D.'s, but not usually between a professor and a typical undergraduate student. It does not include questions at the level of difficulty of typical undergraduate course/textbook homework/exercise.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;For an explanation of what TCS is, we refer you to the description of ACM Special Interest Group on Algorithms and Computation Theory (SIGACT):&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; &gt; TCS covers a wide variety of topics including algorithms, data structures, computational complexity, parallel and distributed computation, probabilistic computation, quantum computation, automata theory, information theory, cryptography, program semantics and verification, machine learning, computational biology, computational economics, computational geometry, and computational number theory and algebra.  **Work in this field is often distinguished by its emphasis on mathematical technique and rigor.** &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;##My question is not a research-level question in TCS, where can I ask it?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;For questions other than research-level questions in TCS, you may want to consider the following places to ask:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; * General Computer Science — [Computer Science - Stack Exchange](https://cs.stackexchange.com/)&#xD;&#xA; * General Mathematics (including *theoretical* CS) — [Mathematics - Stack Exchange](https://math.stackexchange.com/)&#xD;&#xA; * Research-level Mathematics — [Math Overflow](https://mathoverflow.net/)&#xD;&#xA; * Social and Professional Academic Issues — [Academia - Stack Exchange](https://academia.stackexchange.com/)&#xD;&#xA; * Programming — [Stack Overflow](http://stackoverflow.com/)&#xD;&#xA; * General Artificial Intelligence — [Meta Optimize](http://metaoptimize.com/qa/)&#xD;&#xA; * Statistics and Data Mining — [Cross Validated](https://stats.stackexchange.com/)&#xD;&#xA; * Applied Cryptography and Security — [Crypto - Stack Exchange](https://crypto.stackexchange.com/)&#xD;&#xA; * Computation used in Science and Engineering — [Computational Science - Stack Exchange](https://scicomp.stackexchange.com/)&#xD;&#xA; * Questions about this site — [Theoretical Computer Science - Stack Exchange - Meta][1]&#xD;&#xA; * Other — check the list of sites on [Stack Exchange Network](http://stackexchange.com/sites)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;##Questions should be based on knowledge sharing, not on shirking&#xD;&#xA;You should only post questions you're actually seriously thinking about. Users are expected to do their part and try to answer their question by themselves before posting them on cstheory and asking for help from others. Search to see if your question is already answered somewhere else (e.g. Wikipedia) before asking a question. **Try to make your question interesting for others by providing some background knowledge**. Remember, *questions should be based on knowledge sharing, not on shirking. Shirking goes against the spirit of the site.* &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;##Tips about writing better questions&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* [How to Ask?](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/how-to-ask)&#xD;&#xA;* [How to ask a good question?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/300/how-to-ask-a-good-question)&#xD;&#xA;* [How to write a good MathOverflow question?](https://mathoverflow.net/howtoask)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Please also check our list of [**useful resources**](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/229#229) *before* asking a question.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;##FAQ&#xD;&#xA;Currently we have two separate lists of FAQs.  See also the longer **[Official Theoretical Computer Science FAQ](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science)**.  Some of the most important entries in the other FAQ are:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; * [How do I write **formulas**?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/237#237)&#xD;&#xA; * [What kind of questions are **too basic**?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/235#235)&#xD;&#xA; * [My (wonderful!) **question got closed**!  What do I do now?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/361#361)&#xD;&#xA; * [What is the **policy on crossposting** to/from MathOverflow?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/231#231)&#xD;&#xA; * [Can I ask about this **cool paper** that I just saw **on the arxiv**?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/274/is-it-ok-to-ask-about-the-correctness-of-preprints-on-crank-friendly-topics/281#281)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" />
./PostHistory.xml:5602:  <row Id="8046" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1289" RevisionGUID="ea9d719e-4897-4586-acc2-e6fc21770f8b" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:57:54.527" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://mathoverflow.net/ with https://mathoverflow.net/" Text="I just noticed that the BibTeX entry provided by the &quot;cite&quot; button on questions is not as good as it could be. For example, let's take the [Problems Between P and NPC](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/q/79/) question. This is the BibTeX entry provided by the stack exchange software:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&lt;pre&gt;&#xD;&#xA;\@MISC {79,&#xD;&#xA;    TITLE = {Problems Between P and NPC},&#xD;&#xA;    AUTHOR = {Lev Reyzin (https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/users/123/lev-reyzin)},&#xD;&#xA;    HOWPUBLISHED = {Theoretical Computer Science},&#xD;&#xA;    NOTE = {URL:https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/q/79 (version: 2011-08-09)},&#xD;&#xA;    EPRINT = {https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/q/79},&#xD;&#xA;    URL = {https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/q/79}&#xD;&#xA;}&#xD;&#xA;&lt;/pre&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;This is how it appears in the bibliography:&#xD;&#xA;&gt;[1] Lev Reyzin (https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/users/123/lev reyzin).  Problems between p and npc.  Theoretical Computer Science.  URL:https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/q/79 (version: 2011-08-09).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Can we change the citation text? This citation has several problems. For example, &quot;Theoretical Computer Science&quot; is already the name of a journal, and the phrase doesn't describe this site. It should be more like &quot;Theoretical Computer Science Stack Exchange&quot; or something to that effect. If we can change this, are there any other changes that we should make?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;For example, this is how MathOverflow generates BibTex entries:&#xD;&#xA;&lt;pre&gt;&#xD;&#xA;@MISC {MO23478,    &#xD;&#xA;    TITLE = {Examples of common false beliefs in mathematics.},    &#xD;&#xA;    AUTHOR = {gowers\phantom{x}(mathoverflow.net/users/1459)},    &#xD;&#xA;    HOWPUBLISHED = {MathOverflow},    &#xD;&#xA;    NOTE = {\url{https://mathoverflow.net/questions/23478} (version: 2010-05-04)},    &#xD;&#xA;    EPRINT = {https://mathoverflow.net/questions/23478},    &#xD;&#xA;    URL = {https://mathoverflow.net/questions/23478},    &#xD;&#xA;}&#xD;&#xA;&lt;/pre&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;This gets rendered as&#xD;&#xA;&gt; [1] gowers  (mathoverﬂow.net/users/1459).   Examples of common false beliefs in mathematics.&#xD;&#xA;MathOverﬂow. [https://mathoverflow.net/questions/23478](https://mathoverflow.net/questions/23478) (version: 2010-05-04).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I like MO's citation. It has a shorter link to the user page (no username in URL), the URL gets linked due to the \url command, and the user URL skips the &quot;http://&quot; part." />
./PostHistory.xml:5603:  <row Id="8047" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1295" RevisionGUID="bae18091-eda3-4232-ad86-239432c510b3" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:57:54.527" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://mathoverflow.net/ with https://mathoverflow.net/" Text="It would be nice to have a set of general recommendations and requirements for users asking &quot;[How to model X][1]&quot;, &quot;[Applications of theory][2]&quot;, and &quot;How to do X&quot; questions where X is an informal task (i.e. not stated in a clear mathematically rigorous way). ./PostHistory.xml:5606:  <row Id="8050" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1580" RevisionGUID="343ce7de-1a07-41c3-9ac4-b3b534c48899" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:57:54.527" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://mathoverflow.net/ with https://mathoverflow.net/" Text="Is there a need for a _How-To Use_ or _Tips &amp; Tricks_ page? One of the things we are thinking about right now is how to transfer all of MathOverflow's add-ons and tweaks to the new platform. We are quite fortunate that many of our little tweaks have already been implemented because sites like this one needed them. Of the leftover features, we have a [Tips and Tricks](https://mathoverflow.net/tips) page and the discreet tips box linking to it from our front page. There doesn't seem to be an equivalent here. (Let me know if I somehow missed it!) I'm wondering if that's because there is no need at all, if it's functionality is already available in another way (there are plenty of tip boxes here and there), or if it would actually be a helpful addition?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;**Just to be clear:** I am asking about the need for such a page here on CSTheory, not about the need on MathOverflow. ./PostHistory.xml:5608:  <row Id="8052" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2691" RevisionGUID="1749d955-200a-437c-8c71-25818b8922ed" CreationDate="2017-04-13T12:57:54.527" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://mathoverflow.net/ with https://mathoverflow.net/" Text="[MathOverflow][1] is now on SE2.0.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Would we like to open the migration path from/to MO?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://mathoverflow.net/" />
./PostHistory.xml:5610:  <row Id="8054" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="951" RevisionGUID="6a2068c0-de87-4225-a94f-909820b67a0f" CreationDate="2017-05-03T08:40:57.363" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://discuss.area51.stackexchange.com/ with https://area51.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="Maybe some voice from outside... IMO there exist a not so well visible but still solid border between Computer Science and something that I call Computational Science.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The first is mostly a part of mathematics dealing with algorithms, data structures, complexities, languages and stuff. This is what mostly happens here.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The second is an interdisciplinary movement of people using computer computations to make science; this group is rather united by common practical problems and methods than a common interest. Those are people that make all kinds of simulations, like computational physicists, computational chemists, computational biologists, computational sociologists, ..., meteorologists, economists, visual/physical effect makers, various kinds of engineers; people processing data, like various data scientists, bioinformaticians, chemoinformaticians, again economists, machine teachers, text miners, image and sound wizards and the rest of data-AI; finally all soft computing, robotics and steering theory debris.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;There is some overlap between the two, mostly in areas of numerics, BLAS and some &quot;golden&quot; algorithms like Smith-Waterman (C-nal Scientists spent thousands of CPU hours in such so they would use any fast working black-box C-ter Scientists would gave them). Outside this C-nal Scientist don't care much about theoretical aspects of their algorithms. Also most C-ter Scientist don't care much about practical aspects of their work -- and that's why I think those two topics won't blend well.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Summing up, I second with integrating C-nal Science on Area, but rather in a new proposal than this site; see my [Area51 discuss question about it](https://area51.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/320/shall-we-unite-computational-science-proposals)." />
./PostHistory.xml:5611:  <row Id="8055" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="970" RevisionGUID="c2c946b9-dc99-47aa-93cb-ebc0883d0c25" CreationDate="2017-05-03T08:40:57.363" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://discuss.area51.stackexchange.com/ with https://area51.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="MathOverflow works very well for mathematicians, in part because it is run by mathematicians, who understand how mathematicians interact. One clever thing they do to make the site useful for the research community is to redirect some questions to the math.SE site. That seems to work very well. (When they have spare time, they do visit math.SE and answer questions.)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The proposal to create a similar place to redirect basic TCS questions was quickly dismissed on area51, because people there [disagree with having two sites on the same topic with different lower bounds][1]. On the other hand, they have nothing against the MathOverflow/math.SE model because they view MathOverflow as being outside SE. (Which, frankly, mixes technical issues --- who runs the site -- with social issues --- who participates in the site.)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;It seems to me that both SE people and TCS researchers might be happy with migrating the TCS researcher community outside the SE network and have it run by TCS researchers. What do you think?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;PS: Just to be clear, I do not feel that we should move, but I think it's an option that is worth discussing.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://area51.meta.stackexchange.com/q/612/13087" />
./PostHistory.xml:5612:  <row Id="8056" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="984" RevisionGUID="f41983d5-fe64-4cce-af7d-6955e5f4da92" CreationDate="2017-05-03T08:40:57.363" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://discuss.area51.stackexchange.com/ with https://area51.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="In the context of new proposals on Area 51, a number of people who are active there and on programming sites have (imho) demonstrated a lack of perspective on the field computer science. For them, it appears, everything not coding is theory and therefore within the scope of cstheory.SE. Needless to say this has hindered both communication and establishing of a general CS site.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Example threads:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; - [Is Computer Science a duplicate of Theoretical Computer Science?][1]&#xD;&#xA; - [Please explain the closing of Computer Science][2]&#xD;&#xA; - [Should research level only sites be allowed?][3]&#xD;&#xA; - [Two level model (MO/Math.SE) vs one level model (SO)][4]&#xD;&#xA; - [What problems does the two-level split solve?][5] &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;How can we make people understand the richness of computer science?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://area51.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/682/is-computer-science-a-duplicate-of-theoretical-computer-science&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: https://area51.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/713/please-explain-the-closing-of-computer-science&#xD;&#xA;  [3]: https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/79351/should-research-level-only-sites-be-allowed&#xD;&#xA;  [4]: https://area51.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/612/two-level-model-mo-math-se-vs-one-level-model-so&#xD;&#xA;  [5]: https://area51.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/630/what-problems-does-the-two-level-split-solve" />
./PostHistory.xml:5613:  <row Id="8057" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1093" RevisionGUID="15654f81-495d-49a1-8d77-25b2c525d963" CreationDate="2017-05-03T08:40:57.363" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://discuss.area51.stackexchange.com/ with https://area51.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="While a person can become a pro in one topic, it is not possible to master all the fields; even if we narrow it to computer science. Interdisciplinary fields make the problem worse. For instance, someone who works in (theoretical, not applied) cryptography must have a good knowledge of the computational complexity.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;What happens when you need to ask a question which, while related to your research topic, happens to be lie within another field? Well, a complicated problem for you might be too basic for researches in the target field.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I like the model of Math.SE / MathOverflow a lot: If I think my question is too basic (which usually is!), I'll ask it on Math.SE. Research-level questions can be asked on the latter.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;This discussion has recently gained momentum on Area51; here are some links:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* [Two level model (MO/Math.SE) vs one level model (SO)](https://area51.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/612/two-level-model-mo-math-se-vs-one-level-model-so)&#xD;&#xA;* [What problems does the two-level split solve](https://area51.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/630/what-problems-does-the-two-level-split-solve)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;And even proposals like **Beginner Theoretical Computer Science** or **Computer Science** were  considered; but they were soon deleted/closed due to lack of support / misunderstanding that they are exact duplicates of other SE sites.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;**Lack of Support:** I believe that such proposals did not advertise themselves well. For instance, if I ever knew that they exist, I'd join them at once. This is the main reason I'm raising the issue here.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;**Exact Duplicates:** Some of the voters (to close) claimed that such proposals are exact duplicates of StackOverflow, while others claim that they are exact duplicates of TCS.SE. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* The former group believed that anything in computer science which is not theoretical is programming related. In my opinion, that is plain wrong. A basic question about Turing machines is a simple counterexample.&#xD;&#xA;* The latter group were unable to distinguish between research-level questions and basic ones.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Some discussions can be found here: [Is Computer Science a duplicate of Theoretical Computer Science](https://area51.meta.stackexchange.com/q/682/22946).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;In an extreme case, Jonik suggested: &quot;Instead of another site, how about modifying the description of the existing site to allow a little less advanced CS theory questions too.&quot; His suggestion was unwelcome, and received some down-votes. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;In another thread, &#xD;&#xA;Joel Spolsky [requested](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/q/947/873) that we (TCS.SE) broaden our view. His suggestion didn't go anywhere either.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; **The bottom line:** I believe that CSTheory must have a non-research-level counterpart. I ask people here to help (re)create one on Area51, and support it adequately.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;PS: There's always an issue of homeworks: Professors don't like their students to *cheat* by asking homework problems in online forums. This can be handled as in Math.SE, or by developing adequate policies at the new site." />
./PostHistory.xml:5614:  <row Id="8058" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1355" RevisionGUID="86a73893-9ceb-4865-9c80-bac3d67f7591" CreationDate="2017-05-03T08:40:57.363" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://discuss.area51.stackexchange.com/ with https://area51.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="Doing a bit of canvassing here, specifically this:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;https://area51.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/3021/is-computer-science-a-duplicate-of-theoretical-computer-science&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Opinions would be greatly appreciated." />
./PostHistory.xml:5615:  <row Id="8059" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1450" RevisionGUID="a5660e5a-a700-4903-bfb3-9b35bbe1fca1" CreationDate="2017-05-03T08:40:57.363" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://discuss.area51.stackexchange.com/ with https://area51.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="It seems that the proposal has gone under several changes. I don't understand the scope anymore. So I posted [a question asking for clarification of its scope][1]. If the scope contains research level questions in TCS then it overlaps with cstheory and its creation will damage cstheory and other existing CS sites. In which case it should be closed because of that.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;To me with current description of the scope of the proposal it seems like an indirect attempt to force two suggestions that cstheory community has rejected previously: 1. extending the scope of cstheory to contain non-research level question 2. extending the scope of cstheory to contain other areas in CS. As long as this is not clarified I am against the proposal since its creation will damage cstheory, more heavily than the creation of crypto.SE did.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://area51.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/3652/scope-of-computer-science-non-programming" />
./PostHistory.xml:5616:  <row Id="8060" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1488" RevisionGUID="5ff50ac9-ae1e-449d-b95d-90e475b6a7ad" CreationDate="2017-05-03T08:40:57.363" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://discuss.area51.stackexchange.com/ with https://area51.meta.stackexchange.com/" Text="While checking [computational science meta](https://scicomp.meta.stackexchange.com/) today, I noticed that my perception about the  [proposal][1]/[site][2] might not be true. mbq, the original person behind the proposal is not that much involved anymore and there has been some changes. See for example [this meta question about their scope][3].&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;My perception was that the site is for &quot;scientists doing science by heavy computations&quot;. But it seems that it might not be true anymore that there are questions about algorithms and distributed computing among other things. I am not saying that there is significant overlap right now (I haven't had time to go over the questions on the site) but I am now concerned about it.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;See also my discussion with Geoff (one of pro-term moderators) [here](https://scicomp.meta.stackexchange.com/a/176/207).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I don't think we want to see another SE site covering a significant part of our scope (as crypto.se did and hit the number of crypto questions on cstheory, see [this](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/tags/cr.crypto-security/topusers)).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Here are some question that I think we need to think about:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; Do you think there is a problem about the current scope of computational sciences site? Do we need to be concerned about this?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; What distinguishes questions that are suitable for cstheory from those on computational sciences and vic versa on overlapping topics (like algorithms, distributed computing, ...)? Is there a significant overlap? &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; What should we do if there is a significant overlap between the two sites?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;----&#xD;&#xA;As a side issue, I feel that we might have an even larger problem when the CS proposal launches if its scope is modified later in such a way that it contains cstheory, and I should say that [the current attitude of the SE team about the proposal description][4] is not comforting for me. As I said earlier, I support a math.se like version of CS, but I don't want it to start to significantly overlap with cstheory. I think the effect of crypto.se on our crypto questions is quite clear.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://area51.stackexchange.com/proposals/28815/computational-science&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: https://scicomp.stackexchange.com/&#xD;&#xA;  [3]: https://scicomp.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/2/lets-define-our-scope&#xD;&#xA;  [4]: https://area51.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/4226/computer-science-the-audience-description-is-now-wrong" />
./PostHistory.xml:5621:  <row Id="8065" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="2970" RevisionGUID="7900acaa-302c-4772-b724-cf3a1842c3cc" CreationDate="2017-05-19T23:39:35.413" UserId="17179" Text="[![ORCID][1]][2]&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://i.stack.imgur.com/6BIAm.png&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: https://orcid.org/" />
./PostHistory.xml:5622:  <row Id="8066" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="2971" RevisionGUID="be6b5228-ba16-4cf6-9071-c263c7c4eefa" CreationDate="2017-05-20T18:05:33.993" UserId="43569" Text="In the help center _[What topics can I ask about here?][1]_, I see a list of SE sites to where certain topics are better suited. ./PostHistory.xml:5627:  <row Id="8071" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="146" RevisionGUID="1c71006e-36ee-463c-a9d0-8e1f47c59b3d" CreationDate="2017-05-23T11:33:34.517" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://stackoverflow.com/ with https://stackoverflow.com/" Text="I asked this question as a vehicle for answering questions about [my statement that &quot;I'm not convinced the site has a future&quot;][1].  I don't think we are yet on course to be a successful Q&amp;A site for a few reasons:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;1. We have no users who I would call names to conjure with.  This matters for any site: e.g., SO has many active users who are highly recognised experts for a large number of topics, and the SX folk think that this is essential to SOs success and will be essential to the sites coming through the SX beta phase. For academic Q&amp;A sites, as opposed to problem-solving sites I think this is even more important.  How important has Terence Tao's endorsement of MO been to that site's success?  The other two beta sites I've participated in, math.SX and tex.SX, had done far better by their 10th day.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;2. We have a lack of high reputation users.  We don't have any 1k+ reputation users at all, so apart from the SX moderators, we have no-one who can edit weak questions, let alone access the moderation tools. It takes five 500+ users to close a question without moderator actions; we have 8.  We have only 23x 250+ users who can retag.  To some extent, this is a fact of life about the early public beta stage, but other sites have done better.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;3. Very little interest has been shown, or effort put into in the things that need to be done on meta to make the site a success.  Shane is our distinguished exception, Suresh has put in some effort, as well.  Besides these two, we have a list of fairly undifferentiated potential moderators: I haven't seen a whole lot of indication as to why one 500+ user would make a better moderator than another.  Work on the FAQ is nonexistent.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;That said, interesting questions have been asked and answered, we've got a pretty clear idea of our scope, and it's early days.  Call me moderately pessimistic, and since I have discovered that I am suddenly what counts for a high-reputation user around here, I'm going to start making an effort.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;**Postscript**&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I don't think we have exactly what I would call &quot;names to conjure with&quot;, but maybe that's too much to expect in TCS, which is much more balkanized that maths, and where the famous names are that much older, and that much less involved in web-based social networking (but, you know, Alan Kay has [an account on SO][2]).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;That said, the comments to this post have shown what a breadth there are of scientists who have made indubitably major contributions to the field, and there has been the beginnings of what I hope will be an influx of users have been excellent contributors to MO.  Lance Fornow, in particular, is a young scientist with a high profile.  I am now officially relaxed about point #1.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/67/who-should-the-moderators-be/122#122&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: https://stackoverflow.com/users/48710/alan-kay" />
./PostHistory.xml:5628:  <row Id="8072" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="191" RevisionGUID="c1b9024f-6bf7-45bb-97a1-043def0910e2" CreationDate="2017-05-23T11:33:34.517" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://stackoverflow.com/ with https://stackoverflow.com/" Text="Yes, within the framework of this Q&amp;A, but it requires a little more judgement of what is interesting than the usual manner of use.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Each dead-end you found started as an avenue worth exploring.  What question characterises that avenue?  &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The risk is that these questions are not very interesting.  There's a close reason &quot;too localized&quot; that may be invoked if a question concerns, among other alternatives, an *extraordinary narrow situation*.  Looking for an interesting generalisation of the subproblem might help.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;If you do craft a nice question, there's a bonus: the motivation for your question is likely to already have interested other posters.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;There was a nice instance of a question on SO, [Circles and triangles problem][1], whose answers were in fact a collaborative investigation; all the subquestions were resolved in the Q&amp;A thread over six days, resulting in a good algorithm that was not there shown to be optimal.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/2588943/circles-and-triangles-problem" />
./PostHistory.xml:5629:  <row Id="8073" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="427" RevisionGUID="a0994391-63fc-44d1-b936-09efc119bbb9" CreationDate="2017-05-23T11:33:34.517" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://stackoverflow.com/ with https://stackoverflow.com/" Text="In his [answer](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/425/questions-about-compilation-errors-in-coq/426#426), supercooldave mentions “the exact nature of the question,” which I think is the very issue.  The problem is: Is the exact nature of these questions “the theory of proof assistants and/or programming languages” or just “programming”?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- If they are about the theory of proof assistants and/or programming languages and using Coq merely for concreteness, they are fine.&#xD;&#xA;- If they are about programming in Coq, they are off topic.  The askers may want to ask them on Stack Overflow, considering there are several [questions on Coq on Stack Overflow](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/coq) and they get some answers, although I do not know whether the answers are correct or not.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Honestly speaking, the more I think about it, the more the questions seem like programming questions.&#xD;&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:5630:  <row Id="8074" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="962" RevisionGUID="8c0175ab-015b-4803-ada4-6d7b0fb2c002" CreationDate="2017-05-23T11:33:34.517" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://stackoverflow.com/ with https://stackoverflow.com/" Text="This is in part a response to Robert Cartaino's comment on Suresh's comment response [here](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/947/is-theoretical-computer-science-too-narrow/961#961).  I wanted to separate it out from the other discussion, though.  I'd like to start by contrasting two questions, one on StackOverflow, and one here.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;First, consider [How do I move the turtle in LOGO](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/1003841/how-do-i-move-the-turtle-in-logo), especially the history of edits and closes.  A simple question with a simple answer, and, instead, it was repeatedly edited and closed by users who decided the question was fake, had nothing to do with programming, etc.  In this case, the asker was someone who wasn't leaving, so he clarified his position and eventually got an answer.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Now consider the question about [disproving the Church-Turing thesis](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/88/what-would-it-mean-to-disprove-church-turing-thesis).  In this case, I answered the question, it received a lot of upvotes, and was accepted by the asker.  However, in the months since that occurred, some of the finest minds in TCS have commented or answered that question, both explaining how wrong I was, and also sharing deep insights about the issue.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;A question I'd like people to consider is: Would you rather have a culture of arrogance, in which anyone with enough rep can decide, &quot;Get real, you couldn't possibly be Donald Knuth, I'm closing your question,&quot; or would you rather have a culture in which leading researchers feel comfortable adding to a question where a fairly high rep user already posted an accepted answer?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The question behind this question is, &quot;Why is there such a difference in the two sites?&quot;  I believe the answer lies in StackOverflow's fallacious belief that crowdsourcing is the best way to arrive at truth.  This may be the case for questions at the level of an Ask-the-Audience game show -- or even most in-the-trenches programming questions -- but when literally only a handful of people know the answer, and there are plenty of ways to deceive yourself that you solved the problem (when you didn't), the method breaks down.  Crowdsourcing does not produce truth; it only produces *an answer that nobody feels like debating any more*.  This lack of debate might arise because everyone is convinced, or because the few people who know the real answer don't see the point of participating.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Suresh has made the point well that a one-size-fits-all perspective about StackExchange sites does not work.  However, I believe this argument does not go far enough.  The quality of questions and answers on StackOverflow would *significantly increase* if that site were broken into smaller pieces.  If quality in answers is the priority, it should be harder than it currently is for C# experts to answer functional programming questions, as one example.  Rather than the academic caution that we have inherited -- not wanting to brashly say things about a field we know little about -- the StackOverflow model encourages people who get lots and lots of upvotes to answer questions in areas where there is little participation, because they'll get even more upvotes, and the people who know better aren't around, or don't want to start confrontation by calling them out.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Right now, on cstheory, if someone created a profile named &quot;Donald Knuth&quot; or &quot;Avi Wigderson&quot; or whoever, and asked a question, I bet everyone would be careful to treat that user like any other, and to treat the question professionally.  The content of the question is what is important, not &quot;making sure we're not being trolled&quot; or whatever.  I believe this attitude comes from our common belief in the importance of truth, as something beyond, &quot;Good enough,&quot; or, &quot;This is what works.&quot;  Moving forward, I think the most important thing to bear in mind is that we want to attract members who share that understanding of the primacy of mathematical truth.  That's what we share with others interested in theory.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;StackExchange, of course, gets revenue as a function of number-of-hits, so I am sure they see the high traffic of StackOverflow as a great thing that should not be messed with by separating out pieces of it.  Ok, fine.  But if they are interested in more crossover among disciplines, they could, for example, institute a tag system that crosses sites.  So, for example, a chemist posting on biostar about the degree sequence of a molecular graph could see questions about degree sequences on cstheory -- and the graph theorist here could see a potential application for the theoretical work!  Personally, I would *love* such a feature.  I'd like to ask Joel Spolsky and Robert Cartaino to work on *that*, instead of asking us to adapt to the StackOverflow site model, which would not serve us well." />
./PostHistory.xml:5631:  <row Id="8075" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="977" RevisionGUID="2a39efec-638c-49b9-9624-472dafd7550f" CreationDate="2017-05-23T11:33:34.517" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://stackoverflow.com/ with https://stackoverflow.com/" Text="I've asked this question at StackOverflow, and someone suggested asking cstheory.SE as well. If it does, should I copy the question, just post a link, or get a moderator to move it?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;https://stackoverflow.com/questions/4898511/problem-bobs-sale" />
./PostHistory.xml:5632:  <row Id="8076" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1080" RevisionGUID="d277748c-2e57-47b4-a43b-acc101531e36" CreationDate="2017-05-23T11:33:34.517" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://stackoverflow.com/ with https://stackoverflow.com/" Text="My questions are about some concepts of programming language. I was wondering if such questions are unacceptable here?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;For example, &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; - One is &quot;[Understand foreign function&#xD;&#xA;   interface (FFI) and language&#xD;&#xA;   binding][1]&quot;&#xD;&#xA; - Another is &quot;[Is there some nice&#xD;&#xA;   description about language&#xD;&#xA;   features][2]&quot;?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;One has been flagged as off-topic on Stack-overflow.
