./PostHistory.xml:5633:  <row Id="8077" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1095" RevisionGUID="aea3a26d-ee9d-4921-ac84-9feb63dfdaa5" CreationDate="2017-05-23T11:33:34.517" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://stackoverflow.com/ with https://stackoverflow.com/" Text="For a long time, there was no good answer — it seemed that there was no solution within Stack Exchange. But now the situation is finally resolved.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;## [On the computer science site!](https://cs.stackexchange.com/)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Computer Science accepts all questions about theoretical and applied computer science. (All questions suitable for Stack Exchange, that is.)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Computer Science does not include the technique of programming, even when done as part of a class in a computer science curriculum. There's [Stack Overflow](https://stackoverflow.com/) for that.&#xD;&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:5634:  <row Id="8078" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1228" RevisionGUID="47ebfdff-2fcb-4046-af3e-976093139c8c" CreationDate="2017-05-23T11:33:34.517" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://stackoverflow.com/ with https://stackoverflow.com/" Text="### change log&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;----&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Jul. 27, 2012:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- Added [academia.se] to the list of suggested sites&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;----&#xD;&#xA;Mar. 20, 2012:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- Added [cs.se] to the list of suggested sites&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;----&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Feb. 23, 2012:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Another small update to the FAQ. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Change log:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; * Added [crypto.se] and [scicomp.se] to the list of suggested sites,&#xD;&#xA; * Made the tips for writing a better question a section.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;----&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Nov. 17, 2011:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I have edited the official FAQ a little bit (mainly adding links to some entries of the official FAQ that we refer to in comments). Please comemnt if you don't like the edits or have other suggestions on how to improve the general FAQ:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;----&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;[FAQ](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/faq)&#xD;&#xA;----&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;**Theoretical Computer Science - Stack Exchange** is for theoretical computer scientists and researchers in related fields.  We welcome _research-level_ questions in _theoretical computer science_ (TCS).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Although there is no black-and-white distinction between research-level questions and non-research-level questions, questions are considered to be &quot;research-level&quot; roughly when they can be discussed between two professors or between two graduate students working on Ph.D.'s, but not usually between a professor and a typical undergraduate student. It does not include questions at the level of difficulty of typical undergraduate course/textbook homework/exercise.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;For an explanation of what TCS is, we refer you to the description of ACM Special Interest Group on Algorithms and Computation Theory (SIGACT):&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; &gt; TCS covers a wide variety of topics including algorithms, data structures, computational complexity, parallel and distributed computation, probabilistic computation, quantum computation, automata theory, information theory, cryptography, program semantics and verification, machine learning, computational biology, computational economics, computational geometry, and computational number theory and algebra.  **Work in this field is often distinguished by its emphasis on mathematical technique and rigor.** &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;##My question is not a research-level question in TCS, where can I ask it?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;For questions other than research-level questions in TCS, you may want to consider the following places to ask:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; * General Computer Science — [Computer Science - Stack Exchange](https://cs.stackexchange.com/)&#xD;&#xA; * General Mathematics (including *theoretical* CS) — [Mathematics - Stack Exchange](https://math.stackexchange.com/)&#xD;&#xA; * Research-level Mathematics — [Math Overflow](https://mathoverflow.net/)&#xD;&#xA; * Social and Professional Academic Issues — [Academia - Stack Exchange](https://academia.stackexchange.com/)&#xD;&#xA; * Programming — [Stack Overflow](https://stackoverflow.com/)&#xD;&#xA; * General Artificial Intelligence — [Meta Optimize](http://metaoptimize.com/qa/)&#xD;&#xA; * Statistics and Data Mining — [Cross Validated](https://stats.stackexchange.com/)&#xD;&#xA; * Applied Cryptography and Security — [Crypto - Stack Exchange](https://crypto.stackexchange.com/)&#xD;&#xA; * Computation used in Science and Engineering — [Computational Science - Stack Exchange](https://scicomp.stackexchange.com/)&#xD;&#xA; * Questions about this site — [Theoretical Computer Science - Stack Exchange - Meta][1]&#xD;&#xA; * Other — check the list of sites on [Stack Exchange Network](http://stackexchange.com/sites)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;##Questions should be based on knowledge sharing, not on shirking&#xD;&#xA;You should only post questions you're actually seriously thinking about. Users are expected to do their part and try to answer their question by themselves before posting them on cstheory and asking for help from others. Search to see if your question is already answered somewhere else (e.g. Wikipedia) before asking a question. **Try to make your question interesting for others by providing some background knowledge**. Remember, *questions should be based on knowledge sharing, not on shirking. Shirking goes against the spirit of the site.* &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;##Tips about writing better questions&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* [How to Ask?](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/how-to-ask)&#xD;&#xA;* [How to ask a good question?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/300/how-to-ask-a-good-question)&#xD;&#xA;* [How to write a good MathOverflow question?](https://mathoverflow.net/howtoask)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Please also check our list of [**useful resources**](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/229#229) *before* asking a question.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;##FAQ&#xD;&#xA;Currently we have two separate lists of FAQs.  See also the longer **[Official Theoretical Computer Science FAQ](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science)**.  Some of the most important entries in the other FAQ are:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; * [How do I write **formulas**?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/237#237)&#xD;&#xA; * [What kind of questions are **too basic**?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/235#235)&#xD;&#xA; * [My (wonderful!) **question got closed**!  What do I do now?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/361#361)&#xD;&#xA; * [What is the **policy on crossposting** to/from MathOverflow?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/231#231)&#xD;&#xA; * [Can I ask about this **cool paper** that I just saw **on the arxiv**?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/274/is-it-ok-to-ask-about-the-correctness-of-preprints-on-crank-friendly-topics/281#281)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/" />
./PostHistory.xml:5635:  <row Id="8079" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2661" RevisionGUID="16746bff-01d9-4775-9e5a-e08aca09b156" CreationDate="2017-05-23T11:33:34.517" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://stackoverflow.com/ with https://stackoverflow.com/" Text="##My question is not a research-level question in TCS, where can I ask it?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;For questions other than research-level questions in TCS, you may want to consider the following places to ask:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; * General Computer Science — [Computer Science - Stack Exchange][1]&#xD;&#xA; * General Mathematics (including *theoretical* CS) — [Mathematics - Stack Exchange][2]&#xD;&#xA; * Research-level Mathematics — [Math Overflow][3]&#xD;&#xA; * Social and Professional Academic Issues — [Academia - Stack Exchange][4]&#xD;&#xA; * Programming — [Stack Overflow][5]&#xD;&#xA; * General Artificial Intelligence — [Meta Optimize][6]&#xD;&#xA; * Statistics and Data Mining — [Cross Validated][7]&#xD;&#xA; * Applied Cryptography and Security — [Crypto - Stack Exchange][8]&#xD;&#xA; * Computation used in Science and Engineering — [Computational Science - Stack Exchange][9]&#xD;&#xA; * Questions about this site — [Theoretical Computer Science - Stack Exchange - Meta][10]&#xD;&#xA; * Other — check the list of sites on [Stack Exchange Network][11]&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cs.stackexchange.com/&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: https://math.stackexchange.com/&#xD;&#xA;  [3]: https://mathoverflow.net/&#xD;&#xA;  [4]: https://academia.stackexchange.com/&#xD;&#xA;  [5]: https://stackoverflow.com/&#xD;&#xA;  [6]: http://metaoptimize.com/qa/&#xD;&#xA;  [7]: https://stats.stackexchange.com/&#xD;&#xA;  [8]: https://crypto.stackexchange.com/&#xD;&#xA;  [9]: https://scicomp.stackexchange.com/&#xD;&#xA;  [10]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/&#xD;&#xA;  [11]: http://stackexchange.com/sites" />
./PostHistory.xml:5636:  <row Id="8081" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="248" RevisionGUID="6c33bb08-df10-4899-91f5-fd62361af82c" CreationDate="2017-05-23T12:40:08.913" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://stackoverflow.com/ with https://stackoverflow.com/" Text="Given the PL Theory parts of my question (but seeing it also being part of practical compiler design) Im thinking it might be a better match here than there?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;https://stackoverflow.com/questions/3616950/formally-constructing-control-flow-graph&#xD;&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:5637:  <row Id="8082" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="341" RevisionGUID="b913c860-02c2-4c2c-a1dd-104e6c8b4544" CreationDate="2017-05-23T12:40:08.913" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://stackoverflow.com/ with https://stackoverflow.com/" Text="I just edited some tag wikis to explain what the tag was for. I did it for tags like pcp and qma where it may not be clear what the acronyms stand for. So for example, for QMA, I explained what it stands for and linked to the Wikipedia page. ([See the tag wiki for QMA.][1])&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I think it would be nice if tag wikis contained enough information to decide what the tag is about. For some tags this is obvious, for other like qma and approximation-hardness, one could just explain that they stand for Quantum Merlin Arthur and Hardness of Approximation respectively, and link to their Wikipedia page, or their page on the complexity zoo, etc.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Is there anything else people feel that tag wikis should contain? For example, StackOverflow's tag wikis are huge. [See the tag wiki for PHP for example][2]. At this stage of the site it seems unnecessary to have such long tag wikis.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;So this is my suggestion:&#xD;&#xA;&gt; A tag wiki should explain what the tag is for (when the tag name doesn't explain it well enough) and perhaps contain a reference (to a website or book) to explain what the concept is. Usually Wikipedia links should suffice for this purpose.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Suggestions? Comments? Also, if your reputation is not high enough, you can request tag wiki edits in this thread, and someone who has enough rep can make the changes.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/tags/qma/info&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: https://stackoverflow.com/tags/php/info" />
./PostHistory.xml:5638:  <row Id="8083" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="927" RevisionGUID="22a53c43-ce88-444e-8b97-09ade5bde6c4" CreationDate="2017-05-23T12:40:08.913" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://stackoverflow.com/ with https://stackoverflow.com/" Text="To put things forward, I suggest a concrete text.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The current text:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; Theoretical Computer Science - Stack Exchange is for theoretical computer scientists and researchers in related fields.&#xD;&#xA;&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; A rough outline (inclusive, but not exclusive) of topics that are &quot;within scope&quot; for this site is as follows:&#xD;&#xA;&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; &gt; The field of theoretical computer science is interpreted broadly so as to include algorithms, data structures, computational complexity theory, distributed computation, parallel computation, VLSI, machine learning, computational biology, computational geometry, information theory, cryptography, quantum computation, computational number theory and algebra, program semantics and verification, automata theory, and the study of randomness.  **Work in this field is often distinguished by its emphasis on mathematical technique and rigor.**&#xD;&#xA;&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; General FAQs about using the Stack Exchange system are given below.  For specific questions more pertinent to this particular site, please visit the **[Official Theoretical Computer Science FAQ](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science)**.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Although this is not bad as a starting point, there are several shortcomings.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* As is often pointed out, it only mentions what theoretical computer science is and that it does not mention the expected level of questions.&#xD;&#xA;* Related to the first item, a list of alternative sites to ask questions is desirable.  The scope of our website is often better communicated by such a list.&#xD;&#xA;* The quotation is unclear about where it is quoted from.  In fact, it is originally quoted from the self-description of ACM SIGACT but it seems that SIGACT has modified this description after the text was copied, so it is kind of obsolete.  For example, the current list includes computational economics and omits the reference to VLSI, both of which are understandable.&#xD;&#xA;* I cannot see the point of emphasizing only the last sentence in the quotation from SIGACT.&#xD;&#xA;* The distinction between “general FAQs” and “official theoretical computer science FAQ” is confusing at best and makes no sense at worst.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I suggest to revise the above text to the following.  [https://math.stackexchange.com/faq/](https://math.stackexchange.com/faq/) is written very well, and I stole part of the general structure from it.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; **Theoretical Computer Science - Stack Exchange** is for theoretical computer scientists and researchers in related fields.  We welcome _research-level_ questions in _theoretical computer science_ (TCS).&#xD;&#xA;&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; Although there is no black-and-white distinction between research-level questions and non-research-level questions, questions are considered to be “research-level” roughly when they can be discussed between two professors or between two graduate students working on Ph.D.’s, but not usually between a professor and a typical undergraduate student.&#xD;&#xA;&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; For questions other than research-level questions in TCS, you may want to consider the following places to ask:&#xD;&#xA;&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; * Research-level mathematics — [Math Overflow](https://mathoverflow.net/)&#xD;&#xA;&gt; * Programming — [Stack Overflow](https://stackoverflow.com/)&#xD;&#xA;&gt; * General mathematics — [Mathematics - Stack Exchange](https://math.stackexchange.com/); they seem to accept also questions in TCS.&#xD;&#xA;&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; For an explanation of what TCS is, we refer you to the description of ACM Special Interest Group on Algorithms and Computation Theory (SIGACT):&#xD;&#xA;&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; &gt; TCS covers a wide variety of topics including algorithms, data structures, computational complexity, parallel and distributed computation, probabilistic computation, quantum computation, automata theory, information theory, cryptography, program semantics and verification, machine learning, computational biology, computational economics, computational geometry, and computational number theory and algebra.  Work in this field is often distinguished by its emphasis on mathematical technique and rigor. &#xD;&#xA;&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; Currently we have two separate lists of FAQs.  See also **[Official Theoretical Computer Science FAQ](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science)**.  Some of the most important entries in the other FAQ are:&#xD;&#xA;&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; * [What kind of questions are too basic?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/235#235)&#xD;&#xA;&gt; * [How to ask a good question?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/300/how-to-ask-a-good-question)&#xD;&#xA;&gt; * [How do I write formulas?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/237#237)&#xD;&#xA;&gt; * [My (wonderful!) question was closed!  What do I do now?](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/361#361)&#xD;&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:5639:  <row Id="8084" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1436" RevisionGUID="2a86427e-77ba-4cf4-bd69-d007d06464c7" CreationDate="2017-05-23T12:40:08.913" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://stackoverflow.com/ with https://stackoverflow.com/" Text="I am in full agreement with you. Please see [this](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/628/a-page-for-most-recent-significatly-modified-questions-not-tag-edits-and-who-h) and [this](https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/69659/a-page-for-questions-sorted-based-on-last-significant-modification-not-tag-edit). We have already asked for this feature, SE didn't agree. (Maybe they will change their opinion if more people complain about it. I would prefer if people use one of them when asking a question and I wouldn't need to do this retagging. I try to restrict my tag edits to the questions on the front page so it has a less annoying effect. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;ps: I don't use RSS/email to get the updates so maybe this is a bigger problem for people using them.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;pps: I think a reasonable solution is to have something similar to [the minor edit checkbox on Wikipedia][1]. ./PostHistory.xml:5640:  <row Id="8085" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1478" RevisionGUID="b11e0b27-c561-41c8-88a4-f6e50a456ac8" CreationDate="2017-05-23T12:40:08.913" UserId="-1" Comment="replaced http://stackoverflow.com/ with https://stackoverflow.com/" Text="Chat can be a place to provide hints, but not answers. Just because a question is not research-level doesn't mean that it doesn't deserve a proper answer. It's just that this particular site is not the proper site for it.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Questions that are too elementary for this site, and mathematical in nature, can be migrated to [Mathematics Stack Exchange](https://math.stackexchange.com/). Questions that are too elementary or too applied for this site, and that are sufficiently close to development, can be migrated to [Stack Overflow](https://stackoverflow.com/), but that's hit-and-miss, as part of the SO the community is keen to close questions that don't contain actual code, even though “software algorithm” questions are explicitly allowed by its [FAQ](https://stackoverflow.com/faq).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;There is, at long last, a [computer science site proposal](http://area51.stackexchange.com/proposals/35636/computer-science-non-programming?referrer=4M74nqLafvszXN85c5ibxQ2) on [Area 51](http://area51.stackexchange.com/), the staging zone for new Stack Exchange sites. Please point out that proposal to askers who might be interested in it.&#xD;&#xA;" />

./PostHistory.xml:5656:  <row Id="8101" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="2978" RevisionGUID="4d9877b8-5e9e-4b02-93f4-ebbe00febe32" CreationDate="2017-09-18T20:23:15.260" UserId="6115" Text="CSTheory is scheduled for an election [next week, September 25th](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/election/3). ./PostHistory.xml:5665:  <row Id="8110" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="2984" RevisionGUID="695d761f-f398-443e-992e-d0712ff0a380" CreationDate="2017-09-25T20:04:55.657" UserId="6115" Text="In connection with the moderator elections, we are holding a Q&amp;A thread for the candidates. For your convenience, I will include all of the questions in quote format with a break in between each, suitable for you to insert your answers. Just [copy the whole thing after the first set of three dashes](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/revisions/695d761f-f398-443e-992e-d0712ff0a380/view-source).Please consider putting your name at the top of your post so that readers will know who you are before they finish reading everything you have written, and also including a link to your answer on your nomination post.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Once all the answers have been compiled, this will serve as a transcript for voters to view the thoughts of their candidates, and will be appropriately linked in the Election page.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Good luck to all of the candidates!&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;**Oh, and when you've completed your answer, please provide a link to it after this blurb here, before that set of three dashes. How would you deal with a user who produced a steady stream of valuable answers, but tends to generate a large number of arguments/flags from comments?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt;2. How would you handle a situation where another mod closed/deleted/etc a question that you feel shouldn't have been?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt;3. Are there any current moderator practices you would like to see changed? Are there any things you would do differently?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt;4. How do you plan to handle flags on comments? Generally speaking, should comments that are obsolete or resolved be deleted, or should they be kept around to preserve the history of the conversation? Should back-and-forth discussion in the comments be deleted, moved to chat, or retained?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt;5. What is your stance on migration from and to [Computer Science Stack Exchange](https://cs.stackexchange.com), respectively?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt;6. Why do you think you would make a good moderator for this site? In your opinion, what do moderators do?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt;7. A diamond will be attached to everything you say and have said in the past, including questions, answers and comments. Everything you will do will be seen under a different light. How do you feel about that?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt;8. In what way do you feel that being a moderator will make you more effective as opposed to simply reaching 10k or 20k rep?" />

./PostHistory.xml:5681:  <row Id="8127" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="2989" RevisionGUID="c0e74627-1836-48ac-9cb6-633034e0dc03" CreationDate="2017-10-02T16:58:34.283" UserId="6115" Text="In about 3 hours, [the nomination phase of the moderator elections](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/election?cb=1) is scheduled to end. However, in order for the election to proceed, it is necessary to have at least one more candidate running than there are slots. This allows for there to be actual voting phases, so that the community can actually show that they support the candidates who are running. Should there not be enough candidates, the nomination phase will instead be extended for another 7 days. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;We need leadership to come from within this community, the election can't move forward unless there's enough folks stepping up to take responsibility. Did you consider nominating but decided not to for some reason? Now would be a great time to reconsider! " />
./PostHistory.xml:5684:  <row Id="8130" PostHistoryTypeId="25" PostId="2989" RevisionGUID="e9b5398d-4a7a-4488-b505-f26cf0384945" CreationDate="2017-10-02T17:20:36.103" Comment="https://twitter.com/StackCSTheory/status/914902949607993344" />
./PostHistory.xml:5685:  <row Id="8131" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="2990" RevisionGUID="6707feee-9c54-445c-a1d7-5f3a02b2a345" CreationDate="2017-10-09T19:44:56.860" UserId="6115" Text="We regret to inform that due to insufficient nominating candidates, we are currently terminating the ongoing election here on Theoretical Computer Science Stack Exchange. Thank you to Bjørn Kjos-Hanssen for having stood up as a candidate in this session. However, as [explained previously](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/2989/2017-moderator-election-we-need-more-candidates), in order for an election to proceed to voting phases it is required that there is at least one more candidate than there are spaces remaining in the election. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;This is important for a variety of reasons. The first is that it allows the election process to proceed in a way that allows candidates to be evaluated before being elected. It also serves to indicate that there are enough people in the community who are willing to handle the responsibilities of overseeing moderation.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;---&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Theoretical Computer Science is not a site that's particularly in danger of low moderation. There's a healthy number of regular users across most reputation brackets who remain active on the site, still handling general moderation tasks.  The flag load itself isn't particularly large, and the current moderation team has expressed that they aren't overwhelmed by it. However, only one of the current moderators is highly active - while this is sufficient for the current flag load, it is healthier for the site to have multiple active moderators, not only to split even the small loads but also to handle situations where one of the moderators may have more pressing matters to attend.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;It could be that now is just not a good time to have hosted an election for this site. The winter holidays are coming up soon, as well, which will mess up with future election timings, so we'll most likely look at some elections coming into the new year. " />
./PostHistory.xml:5688:  <row Id="8134" PostHistoryTypeId="25" PostId="2990" RevisionGUID="7fc1c986-3e82-41d6-9b62-db91a3ef8676" CreationDate="2017-10-09T20:40:31.330" Comment="https://twitter.com/StackCSTheory/status/917489976438345728" />
./PostHistory.xml:5696:  <row Id="8151" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="2993" RevisionGUID="7b164848-3251-40a4-b1f1-93a47fd8d3f0" CreationDate="2018-01-29T05:08:14.643" UserId="6115" Text="It's almost February in 2018, which isn't supposed to be the proper time to cycle these, but for this year it'll be once again, so we'll be refreshing the **Community Promotion Ads** for this year now!&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### What are Community Promotion Ads?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Community Promotion Ads are community-vetted advertisements that will show up on the main site, in the right sidebar. The purpose of this question is the vetting process. Images of the advertisements are provided, and community voting will enable the advertisements to be shown.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### Why do we have Community Promotion Ads?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;This is a method for the community to control what gets promoted to visitors on the site. For example, you might promote the following things:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; - the site's twitter account&#xD;&#xA; - cool events or conferences&#xD;&#xA; - anything else your community would genuinely be interested in&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The goal is for future visitors to find out about *the stuff your community deems important*. This also serves as a way to promote information and resources that are *relevant to your own community's interests*, both for those already in the community and those yet to join. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### Why do we reset the ads every year?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Some services will maintain usefulness over the years, while other things will wane to allow for new faces to show up. Resetting the ads every year helps accommodate this, and allows old ads that have served their purpose to be cycled out for fresher ads for newer things. This helps keep the material in the ads relevant to not just the subject matter of the community, but to the current status of the community. We reset the ads once a year, every December.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The community promotion ads have no restrictions against reposting an ad from a previous cycle. If a particular service or ad is very valuable to the community and will continue to be so, it is a good idea to repost it. It may be helpful to give it a new face in the process, so as to prevent the imagery of the ad from getting stale after a year of exposure.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### How does it work?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The answers you post to this question _must_ conform to the following rules, or they will be ignored. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;1. All answers should be in the exact form of:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;        [![Tagline to show on mouseover][1]][2]&#xD;&#xA;        &#xD;&#xA;           [1]: http://image-url&#xD;&#xA;           [2]: http://clickthrough-url &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;    Please **do not add anything else to the body of the post**. If you want to discuss something, do it in the comments.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;2. The question must always be tagged with the magic [meta-tag:community-ads] tag. In addition to enabling the functionality of the advertisements, this tag also pre-fills the answer form with the above required form.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### Image requirements&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; - The image that you create must be 300 x 250 pixels, or double that if high DPI.&#xD;&#xA; - Must be hosted through our standard image uploader (imgur)&#xD;&#xA; - Must be GIF or PNG&#xD;&#xA; - No animated GIFs&#xD;&#xA; - Absolute limit on file size of 150 KB&#xD;&#xA; - If the background of the image is white or partially white, there must be a 1px border (2px if high DPI) surrounding it.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### Score Threshold&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;There is a **minimum score threshold** an answer must meet (currently **6**) before it will be shown on the main site.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;You can check out the ads that have met the threshold with basic click stats [here][1].&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/ads/display/2993" />

./PostHistory.xml:5716:  <row Id="8176" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="3002" RevisionGUID="ddf5a5e0-260c-4a25-b7cf-0aeda713216d" CreationDate="2018-06-18T20:06:44.320" UserId="6115" Text="After successful evaluation in [our interest check](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/2999/2018-potential-moderator-election-community-interest-check), CSTheory has been scheduled for an election [next week, June 25th](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/election/4). In connection with that, we will be holding a Q&amp;A with the candidates.  This will be an opportunity for members of the community to pose questions to the candidates on the topic of moderation.  Participation is completely voluntary.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Here's how it'll work:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; - Until the nomination phase, (so, until Monday, June 25th at 20:00:00Z UTC, or 4:00 pm EDT on the same day, give or take time to arrive for closure), this question will be open to collect potential questions from the users of the site. Post answers to this question containing any questions you would like to ask the candidates. As a community, you are still free to, for example, hold a live chat session with your candidates to ask further questions, or perhaps clarifications from what is provided in the Q&amp;A.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;If you have any questions or feedback about this process, feel free to post as a comment here.&#xD;&#xA;" />

./PostHistory.xml:5724:  <row Id="8184" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="3007" RevisionGUID="66dcc113-286b-4461-b46b-bbd10f7fbf05" CreationDate="2018-06-25T20:07:36.087" UserId="-1" Text="The 2018 Community Moderator Election is now underway!&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Community moderator elections have three phases:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;1. Nomination phase&#xD;&#xA;2. Primary phase&#xD;&#xA;3. ./PostHistory.xml:5727:  <row Id="8187" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="3008" RevisionGUID="f34621cb-9170-40a8-8b6d-e29f9214d87a" CreationDate="2018-06-25T20:11:57.787" UserId="6115" Text="In connection with the moderator elections, we are holding a Q&amp;A thread for the candidates. Questions collected [from an earlier thread](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/3002/2018-moderator-election-qa-question-collection) have been compiled into this one, which shall now serve as the space for the candidates to provide their answers. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Due to the submission count, we have selected all provided questions as well as our back up questions for a total of 8 questions.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;As a candidate, your job is simple - post an answer to this question, citing each of the questions and then post your answer to each question given in that same answer. For your convenience, I will include all of the questions in quote format with a break in between each, suitable for you to insert your answers. Just [copy the whole thing after the first set of three dashes](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/revisions/f34621cb-9170-40a8-8b6d-e29f9214d87a/view-source).Please consider putting your name at the top of your post so that readers will know who you are before they finish reading everything you have written, and also including a link to your answer on your nomination post.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Once all the answers have been compiled, this will serve as a transcript for voters to view the thoughts of their candidates, and will be appropriately linked in the Election page.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Good luck to all of the candidates!&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;**Oh, and when you've completed your answer, please provide a link to it after this blurb here, before that set of three dashes. Please leave the list of links in the order of submission.**&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;To save scrolling here are links to the submissions from each candidate (in order of submission):&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;---&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt;1. Why do you want to be a moderator for the cstheory stackexchange community?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt;2. When a comment is flagged as 'no longer needed', what criteria will you use to determine whether to keep the comment or to delete it? Do you lean towards keeping all comments as a record of what has transpired? Do you learn towards deleting old comments that are no longer making a major contribution? What approach will you take?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt;3. I have a bit the impression that part of the reason why the &quot;inactivity&quot; of the moderators came to the attention of SE was the question https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/38803/is-norbert-blums-2017-proof-that-p-ne-np-correct which attracted some inappropriate content and corresponding flags. Those flags stayed around for a long time before they were handled. But apart from that episode, I never had the impression that cstheory.se would need more active moderators, the community self-moderation felt sufficient. Should moderators stay inactive as long as the self-moderation of the community works well?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt;4. How would you deal with a user who produced a steady stream of valuable answers, but tends to generate a large number of arguments/flags from comments?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt;5. How would you handle a situation where another mod closed/deleted/etc a question that you feel shouldn't have been?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt;6. In your opinion, what do moderators do?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt;7. A diamond will be attached to everything you say and have said in the past, including questions, answers and comments. Everything you will do will be seen under a different light. How do you feel about that?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt;8. In what way do you feel that being a moderator will make you more effective as opposed to simply reaching 10k or 20k rep?" />

./PostHistory.xml:5732:  <row Id="8192" PostHistoryTypeId="25" PostId="3008" RevisionGUID="46af7e94-433d-41ae-9259-6ecd900fa344" CreationDate="2018-06-25T20:24:55.380" Comment="https://twitter.com/StackCSTheory/status/1011344507940622338" />
./PostHistory.xml:5733:  <row Id="8193" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="3009" RevisionGUID="931a3dae-4103-45ca-a613-7ff3aee3edce" CreationDate="2018-06-25T22:13:56.027" UserId="1993" Text="##Bjørn Kjos-Hanssen&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt;1. Why do you want to be a moderator for the cstheory stackexchange community?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I'd like to gain a deeper understanding of (a) theoretical computer science and (b) the StackExchange system of sites. Also it seems like it should be fairly easy to do a reasonable job. I have [&gt;15K rep on MathOverflow][1] so am pretty familiar with SE sites. I like how SE sites make micro-publishing into a kind of game, and I developed a couple of TCS-related games:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;[![Gamify your Q&amp;A][2]][3]&#xD;&#xA;[![Gamify your Q&amp;A][4]][5]&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I have some [papers][6] on computability theory and theoretical computer science (automata theory) but looking to learn more.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt;2. When a comment is flagged as 'no longer needed', what criteria will you use to determine whether to keep the comment or to delete it? Do you lean towards keeping all comments as a record of what has transpired? Do you learn towards deleting old comments that are no longer making a major contribution? What approach will you take?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;There are some easy cases: if a comment is just pointing out a mistake and that has already been fixed, then the comment is probably no longer needed. Also, if a comment no longer makes sense because related comments have already been deleted, it should make sense to delete. Moreover, if someone goes out of their way and flags a comment like &quot;Thanks!&quot; as no longer needed, I'd tend to go along with that. On the other hand, comments are often substantial and should be kept.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt;3. I have a bit the impression that part of the reason why the &quot;inactivity&quot; of the moderators came to the attention of SE was the question https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/38803/is-norbert-blums-2017-proof-that-p-ne-np-correct which attracted some inappropriate content and corresponding flags. Those flags stayed around for a long time before they were handled. But apart from that episode, I never had the impression that cstheory.se would need more active moderators, the community self-moderation felt sufficient. Should moderators stay inactive as long as the self-moderation of the community works well?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Actually, I hope so, as I have only so much time to spend! :)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;In any case, SE has an official document about this -- [A Theory of Moderation][7].&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt;4. How would you deal with a user who produced a steady stream of valuable answers, but tends to generate a large number of arguments/flags from comments?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The user should receive some friendly hints that they are being problematic. If that doesn't help I would discuss with other moderators and then there is the possibility of a temporary suspension.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt;5. How would you handle a situation where another mod closed/deleted/etc a question that you feel shouldn't have been?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;f it seemed very unreasonable to me I would probably discuss it with the other moderator; if only borderline I'd just let it go.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt;6. In your opinion, what do moderators do?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Deal with flags (by the way I have a [100% helpful flag record on MathOverflow][8]) and some other things discussed in [A Theory of Moderation][7]. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt;7. A diamond will be attached to everything you say and have said in the past, including questions, answers and comments. Everything you will do will be seen under a different light. How do you feel about that?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;That seems okay, what I write here tends to be very neutral and polite, as I am aware that each comment is a nano-publication of sorts.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt;8. In what way do you feel that being a moderator will make you more effective as opposed to simply reaching 10k or 20k rep?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I don't feel that it would &quot;make me more effective&quot; but it could be an interesting way to contribute to the site and stay involved.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://mathoverflow.net/users/4600/bj%C3%B8rn-kjos-hanssen&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: https://i.imgur.com/8lfJTut.png&#xD;&#xA;  [3]: http://math.hawaii.edu/wordpress/bjoern/software/web/complexity-guessing-game/&#xD;&#xA;  [4]: https://i.imgur.com/1YMWwSJ.png&#xD;&#xA;  [5]: http://math.hawaii.edu/wordpress/bjoern/software/web/complexity-option-game/&#xD;&#xA;  [6]: http://math.hawaii.edu/wordpress/bjoern/papers/&#xD;&#xA;  [7]: https://stackoverflow.blog/2009/05/18/a-theory-of-moderation/&#xD;&#xA;  [8]: https://mathoverflow.net/users/flag-summary/4600" />
./PostHistory.xml:5734:  <row Id="8194" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="3010" RevisionGUID="ba85eb92-582f-426d-8e69-dfe918a05b7b" CreationDate="2018-06-26T04:47:33.963" UserId="14207" Text="##Michael Wehar&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt;1. Why do you want to be a moderator for the cstheory stackexchange community?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I want to be a moderator because I care about the community and I believe it's a great honor to take on this role.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I check the cstheory stackexchange platform daily and I suspect that a lot of our members want to continue having the same great experience that they've always had on this platform.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;It will be my duty as moderator to ensure that issues are efficiently resolved and that the community members are satisfied with their experience.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I will gladly connect with and assist any community members who need help.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt;2. When a comment is flagged as 'no longer needed', what criteria will you use to determine whether to keep the comment or to delete it? Do you lean towards keeping all comments as a record of what has transpired? Do you learn towards deleting old comments that are no longer making a major contribution? What approach will you take?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I believe that an author is entitled to choose for themselves whether to keep or delete their comments as long as they are relevant and respectful.  As a result, I will only delete comments in extreme situations.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt;3. I have a bit the impression that part of the reason why the &quot;inactivity&quot; of the moderators came to the attention of SE was the question https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/38803/is-norbert-blums-2017-proof-that-p-ne-np-correct which attracted some inappropriate content and corresponding flags. Those flags stayed around for a long time before they were handled. But apart from that episode, I never had the impression that cstheory.se would need more active moderators, the community self-moderation felt sufficient. Should moderators stay inactive as long as the self-moderation of the community works well?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I feel that moderators should never be inactive.  They should always be active members who contribute to the community and regularly read recent questions.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;That being said, I also feel that moderators should only use their special privileges when it's necessary.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt;4. How would you deal with a user who produced a steady stream of valuable answers, but tends to generate a large number of arguments/flags from comments?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I would first identify whether (1) the comments are inappropriate, (2) the flags are inappropriate, or (3) users are being inappropriate towards each other.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;When something looks clearly inappropriate, I would honestly explain why the comment or flag was inappropriate either directly or via comments.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt;5. How would you handle a situation where another mod closed/deleted/etc a question that you feel shouldn't have been?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Depending on the situation, I would either:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;(1) Leave it closed and trust the other moderator's judgement&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;(2) Reopen it and include a note for why it was reopened&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;(3) Contact the other moderator directly to resolve the issue&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt;6. In your opinion, what do moderators do?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I think that moderators should do the following:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;(1) Flag, Tag, Edit, Review, Resolve Issues&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;(2) When necessary, get involved with community engagement promoting positive behavior on the platform.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt;7. A diamond will be attached to everything you say and have said in the past, including questions, answers and comments. Everything you will do will be seen under a different light. How do you feel about that?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Having the diamond next to my name means that I should act in a way that promotes positive behavior on the platform.  Really, regardless of whether or not I have a diamond next to my name, I should act in a way that promotes positive behavior on the platform.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt;8. In what way do you feel that being a moderator will make you more effective as opposed to simply reaching 10k or 20k rep?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I don't ask the most questions or post the most answers.  But, I read through questions and answers on a daily basis and I regularly comment.  My presence and comments support the mission and goals of our community.  I believe that the moderator position is primarily about supporting the community." />
./PostHistory.xml:5739:  <row Id="8199" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="3012" RevisionGUID="5251022c-c7fe-4bfa-afc3-45f9db4caeb8" CreationDate="2018-07-12T07:08:52.130" UserId="1993" Text="How about some of these:&#xD;&#xA;&gt;[tag:cc.complexity-theory], [tag:ds.algorithms], [tag:np-hardness], [tag:complexity-classes], [tag:fl.formal-languages], [tag:automata-theory]&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Depending on your math background perhaps also [tag:graph-theory], [tag:co.combinatorics].&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;A couple of caveats:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; - As the most popular tag [tag:cc.complexity-theory] gets about 1 question a day,&#xD;&#xA;compared to large sites like Math.StackExchange and Stack Overflow there is less of a need to follow only particular tags.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; - The level of questions may be somewhat high as the site is [for theoretical computer scientists and researchers in related fields][1].&#xD;&#xA; &#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://stackexchange.com/sites#science-traffic" />

./PostHistory.xml:5747:  <row Id="8207" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2947" RevisionGUID="cdd6840c-a227-431b-9784-7320fac9892b" CreationDate="2018-08-22T01:00:02.260" UserId="8237" Comment="updated for 2018" Text="*Update: As of 2018, the downward trend seems to be continuing (see chart at end of post).*&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I have the subjective impression that the rate at which interesting questions and answers are being posted on cstheory.stackexchange.com has decreased substantially over the last year or so. ./PostHistory.xml:5756:  <row Id="8216" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="3015" RevisionGUID="55ca9f96-21aa-4f18-afcf-70a35c9eb096" CreationDate="2018-08-23T12:36:41.600" UserId="8237" Comment="added 52 characters in body" Text="**Update, August 2018:** *The data below was originally gathered in 2016. The trend is the same:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;[![enter image description here][3]][3]&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;4. To correct for votes accumulating over time, here are those plots counting *only votes that occur within seven days of the post*.&#xD;&#xA;(Query is [here](http://data.stackexchange.com/cstheory/query/490815/total-quickly-high-scoring-qa-per-month-for-last-12?upvoteWindow=7).)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;[![enter image description here][4]][4]&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;5. *[EDIT 2018]:* Here's an update of the last chart, this time for 2012--07/2018 divided into 60-day intervals, using an upvote window of 30 days). Above are plots (over time, in 60-day blocks), of (a) number of questions, (b) number of answers, (c) # upvotes / 20, (d) number of questions and answers that received at least five (or at least ten, for (e)) upvotes within 30 days of creation, on cstheory.stackexchange.com.  &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;All trend downward. (The query that generated the data is [here](http://data.stackexchange.com/cstheory/query/889763/activity-over-time?points=46&amp;period=60&amp;upvoteWindow=30#graph).) &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;----------&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;## The same plots on other stackexchange sites, for comparison&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### cs.stackexchange.com&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;[![enter image description here][2]][2]&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### crypto.stackexchange.com&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;[![enter image description here][3]][3]&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### math.stackexchange.com&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;[![enter image description here][4]][4]&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### tex.stackexchange.com&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;[![enter image description here][5]][5]&#xD;&#xA;----------&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://i.stack.imgur.com/f7vVP.png&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: https://i.stack.imgur.com/QFXBV.png&#xD;&#xA;  [3]: https://i.stack.imgur.com/kGCDd.png&#xD;&#xA;  [4]: https://i.stack.imgur.com/hCX8j.png&#xD;&#xA;  [5]: https://i.stack.imgur.com/DZLQ3.png" />

./PostHistory.xml:5778:  <row Id="8238" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="3019" RevisionGUID="de8a6f63-562d-4c43-a474-77a9ebcc78dd" CreationDate="2018-10-01T20:41:12.617" UserId="1993" Text="Sometimes a question gets asked, someone takes the time to respond, but the answer never receives any votes. Sometimes those answers can be quite good, and it would be nice to reward those answers with upvotes.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Would you like to help vote on these answers to older questions? If so, I can suggest a way. Run the following query:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;https://data.stackexchange.com/cstheory/query/889195/search-for-question-with-positive-score-where-all-answers-have-zero-score&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Then click on some of the links in the results (you can sort by question score first if you want), and take a look to see if the answers are good. This looks for questions where the question score is &gt; 0, where there is at least one answer, and where all answers have a score of 0 (which usually means the answer was never voted on; sometimes for good reason, but sometimes because a nice answer was overlooked).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Thanks to [@D.W.][1] for this idea.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cs.meta.stackexchange.com/q/1512/37257" />

./PostHistory.xml:5787:  <row Id="8247" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="3021" RevisionGUID="c75a1197-0d61-49c9-87e6-b40ceac2c04a" CreationDate="2018-10-11T06:49:49.023" UserId="1993" Text="Having such questions might have some value, but also some downsides. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; - It might attract somewhat low-quality answers by people who think they can solve the problem (now that might be a good thing or a bad thing depending what you want the site to be about).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; - StackExchange, and Stack Overflow as the model site in particular, encourages questions that have a good chance of being answered.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;This has been discussed before, for instance at:&#xD;&#xA;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/q/1058/1993" />

./PostHistory.xml:5793:  <row Id="8253" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="3024" RevisionGUID="fd991a03-c8fa-4825-a066-933cef01b3df" CreationDate="2018-10-19T07:01:55.587" UserId="22045" Text="The purpose of this stack exchange, like every other stack exchange, is not to list questions. **It’s to list answers**. Obviously people ask questions that don’t get answered all the time, but an explicit goal is to have as high of a percentage of answered questions as possible.&#xA;&#xA;There are [a number of questions related to P vs NP][1] that have been asked in the past, and many of them have been answered and many more have generated fruitful discussion and partial answers. So, there are productive and on-topic questions that can be asked about the problem. However, “does P equal NP?” with no further context, ideas, or thoughts is not one of them.&#xA;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/p-vs-np" />
./PostHistory.xml:5794:  <row Id="8254" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="3025" RevisionGUID="10f3840a-f233-41fa-b93c-e6cbb78d3662" CreationDate="2018-11-21T19:15:40.293" UserId="16884" Text="As part of implementing the new unified themes across the network, we're gradually rolling out updated site themes for each site. As of today, we have enabled your updated site theme for testing. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;If you can't see it right now, that's by design! This is a very early test implementation of your design and we need your help finding issues with it before we make it live for everyone permanently. So, keep in mind, there will be things that need fixing! We'll address those things as we can.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;If you'd like to review it, here's how:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;## How do I enable it?&#xD;&#xA;[Click here](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/users/preferences) and check the &quot;Beta test new themes&quot; option. This will turn on the new theme for all sites that have one in testing, including this one. *Here's [more info](https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/314542/opt-in-to-beta-testing-new-themes) on how to opt in.* You can uncheck the box to revert to the older theme until the site is live for everyone. **Note, while turning it on is immediate, it will take a few minutes to revert to the old view - *but it will go through!***&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;## What type of feedback do we need?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### On this post: Bugs related to this site's design elements &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Please help us look for issues/bugs related to the theme design and how we have mapped the old theme to the new. This needs to be done within the [limits of the new unified theme](https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/307862/ch-ch-ch-changes-left-nav-responsive-design-themes).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;This could include colors of sections of the design or text, problems with JavaScript add-ons (if applicable), the logo or top banner appearance or other artwork.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;You can also feel free to ask questions about the new layout if you're unsure how to navigate it.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### On Meta Stack Exchange: General concerns about left nav or theming&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;There are some things that are definitely changing everywhere and can't really be adjusted on a per-site basis. A few of them include:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- Top banner is shorter in height, so some artwork has to be adjusted along with some logos.&#xD;&#xA;- Left Navigation is active everywhere (but can be collapsed into a menu by visiting your site preferences - [instructions here][1]).&#xD;&#xA;- Responsive layout is active, which lets the site adjust as browser widths change - no side scrolling (some pages haven't been updated, yet, though). For now, if you prefer the scrolling, you can disable this by clicking the &quot;disable responsiveness&quot; link in the footer.&#xD;&#xA;- Many site elements including tags and voting arrows are standardized across the network.&#xD;&#xA;- Link underlining is active. In an effort to make links more visible, they are now being underlined.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;If you have concerns or issues regarding the left nav or the overall approach we are taking to theming, then [this Meta Stack Exchange post](https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/310908/live-left-nav-new-theming-and-responsiveness) is the right place for feedback. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;As I mentioned earlier, there are some unique design elements like voting arrows and tags that are being standardized in this process. Keeping these custom elements makes our ability to maintain the sites too complex and, while we're very sad to see them go, we're in a difficult position of needing to make the site designs work together so that we can continue to address feature requests and bugs that will make your Q&amp;A experience better. This is addressed in a [Meta Stack Exchange post](https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/314799/why-we-initiated-the-latest-round-of-design-changes-and-the-role-of-meta) if you want more detail.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;## What new themes?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;If you're like, &quot;What the heck are you talking about?&quot;, then you should read the Meta Stack Exchange post entitled [Rollout of new network site themes](https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/312365/rollout-of-new-network-site-themes) (and maybe the posts it links to for the full background). To follow along with the rollout of these new themes, go [here][2].&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;## Thanks so much for your constructive feedback!&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### Oh, Who am I?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;If you don't know me, I'm one of the [Community Managers][3] here at Stack Exchange. I'm here to listen to your input and convey it to our Design team for responses and fixes to bugs. I'll do my best to respond to your concerns and explain whether changes we've made are bugs that can be changed or if they're by design and why.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://meta.stackexchange.com/a/311237/284336&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/314979/rollout-of-responsive-design-site-themes-tracking-post&#xD;&#xA;  [3]: https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/99338/who-are-the-community-team-and-what-do-they-do?s=1%7C141.4591" />

./PostHistory.xml:5819:  <row Id="8279" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="3028" RevisionGUID="2348006e-20d1-465f-a840-f8ea68fcda09" CreationDate="2018-12-07T18:30:36.537" UserId="1993" Text="Questions about what's going on in a small subfield seem okay to me. A couple of potential pitfalls are:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; - Is it something it would make sense to ask your doctoral adviser instead? I think we do want to encourage students to communicate well with their advisers.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; - Is the area narrow enough? For instance,&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; What's new important work in complexity theory&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;might be considered [primarily opinion-based][1], but&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; Are there any recent papers (last five years) on 1-counter automata&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;is more fact-based. In that case, however, there's the question&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; - Is your question easily answerable using a Google search?&#xD;&#xA; &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;So to summarize, a good question of this kind should be fact-based, answerable, but not easily answerable by a Google search or by your doctoral adviser.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/199773/a-question-being-closed-as-primarily-opinion-based" />
./PostHistory.xml:5820:  <row Id="8280" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="3028" RevisionGUID="ad80c3dd-2b0e-4e3b-b1a3-0285151f8393" CreationDate="2018-12-07T19:22:07.893" UserId="1993" Comment="added 152 characters in body" Text="Questions about what's going on in a small subfield seem okay to me.&#xD;&#xA;([More][1] about the [tag:reference-request] tag.)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;A couple of potential pitfalls are:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; - Is it something it would make sense to ask your doctoral adviser instead? I think we do want to encourage students to communicate well with their advisers.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; - Is the area narrow enough? For instance,&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; What's new important work in complexity theory&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;might be considered [primarily opinion-based][2], but&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; Are there any recent papers (last five years) on 1-counter automata&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;is more fact-based. In that case, however, there's the question&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; - Is your question easily answerable using a Google search?&#xD;&#xA; &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;So to summarize, a good question of this kind should be fact-based, answerable, but not easily answerable by a Google search or by your doctoral adviser.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/1630/what-is-the-reference-request-tag&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/199773/a-question-being-closed-as-primarily-opinion-based" />
./PostHistory.xml:5821:  <row Id="8281" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="3028" RevisionGUID="b50df596-d0de-4498-a423-94c336e403b9" CreationDate="2018-12-07T19:48:52.060" UserId="1993" Comment="added 35 characters in body" Text="In principle, questions about what's going on in a small subfield fit into the [tag:reference-request] tag and can be on-topic. ([More][1] about this tag.)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;A couple of potential pitfalls are:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; - Is it something it would make sense to ask your doctoral adviser instead? I think we do want to encourage students to communicate well with their advisers.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; - Is the area narrow enough? For instance,&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; What's new important work in complexity theory&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;might be considered [primarily opinion-based][2], but&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; Are there any recent papers (last five years) on 1-counter automata&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;is more fact-based. In that case, however, there's the question&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; - Is your question easily answerable using a Google search?&#xD;&#xA; &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;So to summarize, a good question of this kind should be fact-based, answerable, but not easily answerable by a Google search or by your doctoral adviser.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/1630/what-is-the-reference-request-tag&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/199773/a-question-being-closed-as-primarily-opinion-based" />
./PostHistory.xml:5823:  <row Id="8295" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="3032" RevisionGUID="fff9145e-6ce1-416a-b01b-4c3fa8bf82c6" CreationDate="2019-01-01T02:50:40.387" UserId="4352" Text="It's New Year's Day in [Stack Exchange land](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zulu_Time)...&#xA;&#xA;A distinguishing characteristic of these sites is how they are moderated:&#xA;   &#xA;&gt; We designed the Stack Exchange network engine to be mostly self-regulating, in that we amortize the overall moderation cost of the system across thousands of teeny-tiny slices of effort contributed by regular, everyday users.  &#xA;&gt; -- [A Theory of Moderation](http://blog.stackoverflow.com/2009/05/a-theory-of-moderation/)&#xA;   &#xA;While there certainly are [Moderators](https://stackoverflow.blog/2018/11/21/our-theory-of-moderation-re-visited/) here, a significant amount of the *moderation* is done by ordinary people, using the privileges &#xA;they've earned by virtue of their contributions to the site. Each of you contributes a little bit of time and effort, and together you accomplish much.&#xA;   &#xA;As we enter a new year, let's pause and reflect, taking a moment to appreciate the work that we do here together. &#xA;To that end, here is how the moderation done here on Theoretical Computer Science breaks down by activity over the past 12 months:&#xA;   &#xA;                     Action                  Moderators Community¹&#xD;&#xA;    ---------------------------------------- ---------- ----------&#xD;&#xA;    Users suspended²                                  1         10&#xD;&#xA;    Users destroyed                                   3          0&#xD;&#xA;    Users contacted                                   3          0&#xD;&#xA;    Tasks reviewed³: Suggested Edit queue             5        240&#xD;&#xA;    Tasks reviewed³: Reopen Vote queue                0         25&#xD;&#xA;    Tasks reviewed³: Low Quality Posts queue          0         95&#xD;&#xA;    Tasks reviewed³: Late Answer queue                0         67&#xD;&#xA;    Tasks reviewed³: First Post queue                 0        783&#xD;&#xA;    Tasks reviewed³: Close Votes queue                1        927&#xD;&#xA;    Questions reopened                                7          0&#xD;&#xA;    Questions protected                               1          1&#xD;&#xA;    Questions migrated                               19          0&#xD;&#xA;    Questions merged                                  1          0&#xD;&#xA;    Questions flagged⁴                                0        344&#xD;&#xA;    Questions closed                                 64        239&#xD;&#xA;    Question flags handled⁴                          86        258&#xD;&#xA;    Posts unlocked                                    1          2&#xD;&#xA;    Posts undeleted                                   2        140&#xD;&#xA;    Posts locked                                      1         23&#xD;&#xA;    Posts deleted⁵                                   40        879&#xD;&#xA;    Posts bumped                                      0        111&#xD;&#xA;    Comments undeleted                                1          0&#xD;&#xA;    Comments flagged                                  0        406&#xD;&#xA;    Comments deleted⁶                               262        927&#xD;&#xA;    Comment flags handled                           169        237&#xD;&#xA;    Answers flagged                                   0         97&#xD;&#xA;    Answer flags handled                             69         28&#xD;&#xA;    All comments on a post moved to chat              3          0&#xA;   &#xA;###Footnotes&#xA;¹ &quot;Community&quot; here refers both to [the membership of Theoretical Computer Science](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/users) *without* [diamonds next to their names](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/users?tab=moderators), and to the automated systems otherwise known as [user #-1](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/users/-1).&#xA;&#xA;² The system will suspend users under three circumstances: when a user is recreated after being previously suspended, when a user is recreated after being destroyed for spam or abuse, and when a network-wide suspension is in effect on an account.&#xA;&#xA;³ This counts every review that was submitted (not skipped) - so the 3 suggested edits reviews needed to approve an edit would count as 3, the goal being to indicate the frequency of moderation actions. This also applies to flags, etc.&#xA;&#xA;⁴ Includes close flags (but *not* close or reopen votes).&#xA;&#xA;⁵ This ignores numerous deletions that happen automatically in response to some other action.&#xA;&#xA;⁶ This includes comments deleted by their own authors (which also account for some number of handled comment flags).   &#xA;   &#xA;&#xA;Wishing you all a happy new year...&#xA;" />
./PostHistory.xml:5826:  <row Id="8299" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="3033" RevisionGUID="bd5de512-3310-4c56-9913-eb6768917cdf" CreationDate="2019-01-23T11:46:50.047" UserId="32595" Text="2019 is here! And with the new year, as usual, comes a new iteration of **Community Promotion Ads**! Let’s refresh these for the coming year :)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### What are Community Promotion Ads?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Community Promotion Ads are community-vetted advertisements that will show up on the main site, in the right sidebar. The purpose of this question is the vetting process. Images of the advertisements are provided, and community voting will enable the advertisements to be shown.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### Why do we have Community Promotion Ads?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;This is a method for the community to control what gets promoted to visitors on the site. For example, you might promote the following things:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; - the site's twitter account&#xD;&#xA; - cool events or conferences&#xD;&#xA; - anything else your community would genuinely be interested in&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The goal is for future visitors to find out about *the stuff your community deems important*. This also serves as a way to promote information and resources that are *relevant to your own community's interests*, both for those already in the community and those yet to join. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### Why do we reset the ads every year?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Some services will maintain usefulness over the years, while other things will wane to allow for new faces to show up. Resetting the ads every year helps accommodate this, and allows old ads that have served their purpose to be cycled out for fresher ads for newer things. This helps keep the material in the ads relevant to not just the subject matter of the community, but to the current status of the community. We reset the ads once a year, every December.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The community promotion ads have no restrictions against reposting an ad from a previous cycle. If a particular service or ad is very valuable to the community and will continue to be so, it is a good idea to repost it. It may be helpful to give it a new face in the process, so as to prevent the imagery of the ad from getting stale after a year of exposure.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### How does it work?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The answers you post to this question _must_ conform to the following rules, or they will be ignored. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;1. All answers should be in the exact form of:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;        [![Tagline to show on mouseover][1]][2]&#xD;&#xA;        &#xD;&#xA;           [1]: http://image-url&#xD;&#xA;           [2]: http://clickthrough-url &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;    Please **do not add anything else to the body of the post**. If you want to discuss something, do it in the comments.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;2. The question must always be tagged with the magic [meta-tag:community-ads] tag. In addition to enabling the functionality of the advertisements, this tag also pre-fills the answer form with the above required form.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### Image requirements&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; - The image that you create must be 300 x 250 pixels, or double that if high DPI.&#xD;&#xA; - Must be hosted through our standard image uploader (imgur)&#xD;&#xA; - Must be GIF or PNG&#xD;&#xA; - No animated GIFs&#xD;&#xA; - Absolute limit on file size of 150 KB&#xD;&#xA; - If the background of the image is white or partially white, there must be a 1px border (2px if high DPI) surrounding it.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;### Score Threshold&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;There is a **minimum score threshold** an answer must meet (currently **6**) before it will be shown on the main site.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;You can check out the ads that have met the threshold with basic click stats [here][1].&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/ads/display/3033" />

./Posts.xml:4:  <row Id="2" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2010-08-16T20:23:47.640" Score="10" ViewCount="219" Body="&lt;p&gt;Over at the TeX SE site, there's been a fair amount of &lt;a href=&quot;https://tex.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/197/so-versus-mo-model-possible-faq-entry&quot;&gt;meta discussion&lt;/a&gt; about whether the site should be closer to the StackOverflow or MathOverflow model for discussions. The linked post has a good summary of the differences, and I'll also link to Andrew Stacey's &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.math.ntnu.no/~stacey/CountingOnMyFingers/MOversusSO.html&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;link off his home page&lt;/a&gt;. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I suspect that we will need to grapple with this question as well: do we want the 'advanced grad student' lower bound that MO effectively maintains, or something lower ? StackOverflow does handle what I'll consider undergraduate-level theoryCS questions. I'll post my own thoughts in an answer below. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="80" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T16:02:33.520" LastActivityDate="2010-08-19T09:57:05.287" Title="The MO vs SO question" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;" AnswerCount="3" CommentCount="0" FavoriteCount="3" />
./Posts.xml:8:  <row Id="6" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2010-08-16T21:34:42.377" Score="14" ViewCount="173" Body="&lt;p&gt;&lt;em&gt;[Below is Scott Morrison's &lt;a href=&quot;https://tex.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/12/vote-early-and-often&quot;&gt;post from tex.se&lt;/a&gt;, reproduced here because it's good advice we need to see early.]&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;hr&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I'm a moderator from MathOverflow, and this &quot;question&quot; is actually unsolicited advice, based on our experience from the initial launch of MathOverflow.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;We should encourage everyone to vote positively as often as possible!&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Every Stack Exchange site will eventually end up with a different &quot;base level&quot; of voting --- that is, the expected number of upvotes for a question of a given level of excellence. (This effect occurs because people see a good question, but already with a certain number of votes, and think &quot;oh, I would have upvoted this, but it already has enough&quot;.)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;It's easy for us to affect this &quot;base level&quot; by encouraging high levels of upvoting now. We're setting the standards, and this really will have an effect.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;(On MathOverflow, we were very active about this early on, specifically encouraging all the initial round of users to vote early and often. You can compare statistics, and see that the average vote total for a MathOverflow question is much higher than on any of the other SE 1.0 sites.)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In case it's not obvious: the rationale for wanting this base level to be high is that it provides better positive feedback to good contributors.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;hr&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;em&gt;— By Scott Morrison&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="115" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T16:02:33.520" LastActivityDate="2010-08-25T22:42:45.140" Title="Vote early and often!" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;voting&gt;&lt;community&gt;" AnswerCount="2" CommentCount="1" />

./Posts.xml:14:  <row Id="12" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="2" CreationDate="2010-08-16T22:22:49.797" Score="10" Body="&lt;p&gt;I would prefer a site that is aimed at experts, probably at least graduate student or advanced undergraduate, and assuming a reasonable background in theoretical computer science, or a bit of care in phrasing by someone who is not an expert.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Anything below this level seems neither attractive for domain experts to contribute to, nor sufficiently different from Wikipedia or Google Scholar to be valuable.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The &lt;a href=&quot;https://tex.stackexchange.com/&quot;&gt;TeX site&lt;/a&gt; is great because it focuses on information that is not easy to find in an FAQ.  It is full of the kind of questions one would ask of the local TeX guru, and the answers are typically those that the most knowledgeable gurus would provide.  It is becoming the sort of place where the discussion about a particular question will be the first hit when one asks a related question of a search engine.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;It would be good if this site could be the place where we get to ask our theory neighbours (whether across the hall, or on the other side of the world), about niggling folklore questions, tangents that came up while reading a paper, clarifications about new results, or cool new insights that maybe don't quite work.  I would also like to see a place where such questions are answered with pointers to non-obvious papers, snippets told by colleagues, historical background that isn't published, and insights that may be common in some parts of the community but which are not universally known.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In other words: I am adept at using a search engine.  But I have no access to the corridor gossip at another institution, and almost certainly haven't noticed how the JACM paper you just read is directly relevant to an arXiv paper that appeared yesterday.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="109" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:34:28.537" LastActivityDate="2010-08-19T02:35:58.207" CommentCount="1" />
./Posts.xml:19:  <row Id="17" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAnswerId="156" CreationDate="2010-08-16T22:51:21.640" Score="8" ViewCount="206" Body="&lt;p&gt;I was waiting to get some examples of questions that might illustrate a lower bound on the kinds of questions we want to field. Here are some examples: &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/56/what-does-the-theorem-of-rice-help-to-prove&quot;&gt;What does the theorem of Rice help to prove?&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/58/minimum-spanning-tree-algorithm&quot;&gt;Minimum spanning tree algorithm.&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/57/what-are-the-advantages-of-a-red-black-tree&quot;&gt;What are the advantages of a red/black tree?&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In each case, the question has an answer that can be found almost immediately on Wikipedia, or enough of an answer can be found that the question should be made much more specific. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Should we vote to close such questions, after supplying a comment stating where to look ?
