./Posts.xml:26:  <row Id="25" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2010-08-17T15:46:32.193" Score="8" ViewCount="739" Body="&lt;p&gt;Since many of the visitors here are new to the Stackexchange environment, it might be useful to collect questions and answers here to add to &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science&quot;&gt;the official site FAQ&lt;/a&gt;. In addition, it would be useful to add questions and answers that help delineate the scope of this site, since we're already getting questions about it. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I'll make this &quot;question&quot; community wiki. Feel free to post answers, or even edit this post to add to the list. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;StackExchange Questions&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;What is a &quot;community wiki&quot;? &lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;What purpose does a community wiki designation serve? &lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;What is the difference between an&#xA;Answer and a Comment, and what&#xA;technical restrictions are there on&#xA;Comments?&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;What happens if you delete something&#xA;you've posted?&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;How does closing and re-opening work? (&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/56/are-list-questions-such-as-about-conferences-on-topic&quot;&gt;see this link&lt;/a&gt; for good practices when voting to close)&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/25/material-to-supplement-the-faq/54#54&quot;&gt;When should you downvote/upvote&lt;/a&gt; ?&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/a/2682/&quot;&gt;An updated cross-posting policy&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Subject-related Questions&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;What kind of questions work best ?&#xA;(i.e what questions won't get closed)&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/25/material-to-supplement-the-faq/36#36&quot;&gt;What is the policy on cross posting&#xA;to/from Mathoverflow&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;How should we tag questions (see &lt;a&#xA;href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/41/arxiv-tags-vs-not&quot;&gt;this&#xA;meta post&lt;/a&gt;)&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Which sources should I check&#xA;before asking a question.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/41/arxiv-tags-vs-not&quot;&gt;What kinds of tags should I use&lt;/a&gt;&#xA;?&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;How do I ask a good question ? (&lt;a href=&quot;http://msmvps.com/blogs/jon_skeet/archive/2010/08/29/writing-the-perfect-question.aspx&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;this post by Jon Skeet&lt;/a&gt; of SO could be adapted for our needs)&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/352/how-will-you-cite-a-discussion-on-this-site-in-your-paper&quot;&gt;How should I cite a post on the site in my paper?&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/a/2662/&quot;&gt;Is my question suitable for cstheory?&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="80" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" LastActivityDate="2014-04-03T23:21:09.897" Title="Material to supplement the FAQ" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;faq&gt;&lt;7-essential&gt;" AnswerCount="13" CommentCount="5" FavoriteCount="3" CommunityOwnedDate="2010-08-17T15:46:32.193" />

./Posts.xml:57:  <row Id="62" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2010-08-22T20:03:26.340" Score="3" ViewCount="138" Body="&lt;p&gt;In the discussion on &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/56/are-list-questions-such-as-about-conferences-on-topic&quot;&gt;this meta question&lt;/a&gt;, I made a comment in passing that I thought there were too many CW questions on the site at present. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;While this may be a transient phenomenon while the site is being seeded, I thought it brought up important issues about whether certain questions should be CW or just closed. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;So my question is:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;What is a clear policy to determine&#xA;  which questions should be deemed CW,&#xA;  which answers should be made CW, and&#xA;  which questions should just be closed&#xA;  ?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;As a reference point for discussion, I'll refer people to &lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.mathoverflow.net/discussion/6/when-should-questions-be-community-wiki&quot;&gt;this meta thread on MO&lt;/a&gt;, where many of the issues we're facing have been discussed. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In keeping with the spirit of that discussion, since I do think that there is a good answer and that people's direct experiences are helpful, I'm &lt;strong&gt;NOT&lt;/strong&gt; making this CW. I also think that the reduction in points for upvotes on questions actually makes me more comfortable about this, since my ability to acquire rep points is limited in comparison to people with good answers. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="80" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-17T10:13:04.397" LastActivityDate="2010-08-22T21:28:19.737" Title="Developing a CW policy." ./Posts.xml:62:  <row Id="67" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2010-08-23T18:24:46.337" Score="9" ViewCount="758" Body="&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Update&lt;/strong&gt;: This post is now closed since the temporary moderators have been selected. Please see &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/222/moderator-pro-tem-announcement&quot;&gt;this announcement&lt;/a&gt; for details. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Important: if you're nominated and accept the nomination, please add the word 'accept' somewhere in the answer, and also mention which timezones you are likely to be able to handle.&lt;/strong&gt; &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Based on &lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/57986/how-to-organize-a-formal-moderator-election-on-a-beta-se-site&quot;&gt;the web-apps template&lt;/a&gt;, we should be choosing candidates to be our site moderators.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Each nomination should be a separate answer. Link the name to the user's profile so we can see their activity.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;The nominee should indicate their acceptance by editing the answer, adding that they accept the nomination. Optionally they can write something about their self. This can be just practical stuff like which hours and how many hours they expect to spend on the site, but also some motivation.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;From the top voted nominees a number of temporary moderators will be appointed, until the site is out of beta and real elections can be held.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Some guidelines:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Must be a currently registered user in good standing&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Must have a reasonably high reputation score to indicate active, consistent participation.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Should exhibit patience and fairness at all times in their questions, answers, and comments.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Should lead by example, showing respect for their fellow community members in everything they write.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;They should want the responsibility. Nominating users isn’t the same as an obligation. It’s purely voluntary!&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;When nominating, please put the name of the nominee as a heading (with a #) and as a link to their real profile. Also add a link to their meta profile. (See the already provided answers). After that, please keep them empty for the nominees to add information themselves.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Besides voting, everybody could off course also point out in the comments why that nominee is a good candidate to be moderator or not.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Read more about &lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/57986/how-to-organize-a-formal-moderator-election-on-a-beta-se-site&quot;&gt;the moderator nomination process here&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="7" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-20T10:29:37.593" LastActivityDate="2010-09-03T16:38:58.990" Title="Who should the moderators be?" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;7-essential&gt;&lt;moderators&gt;" AnswerCount="13" CommentCount="6" FavoriteCount="2" CommunityOwnedDate="2010-08-23T18:29:45.343" />

./Posts.xml:68:  <row Id="73" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAnswerId="81" CreationDate="2010-08-23T20:25:04.690" Score="6" ViewCount="382" Body="&lt;p&gt;This question is prompted by &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/427/what-are-some-real-world-applications-for-genetic-algorithms&quot;&gt;this post on genetic algorithms&lt;/a&gt;, but I think the matter applies more generally as well to other metaheuristic methods like annealing, neural networks and the like. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Are these reasonable topics for discussion on this site ? ./Posts.xml:108:  <row Id="115" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2010-08-25T10:19:40.670" Score="4" ViewCount="374" Body="&lt;p&gt;As a starting point, I was interested in &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/92/is-there-really-a-need-for-theoretical-computer-science-se-site/93#93&quot;&gt;András Salamon's answer&lt;/a&gt; to a question about the need for a &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/92/is-there-really-a-need-for-theoretical-computer-science-se-site/93#93&quot;&gt;TCS Stack Exchange&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Now, as a software engineer, there are a number of topics in theoretical computer science that interest me that fall into the realm of computer science (theoretical or not), but at a much simpler level than it appears many of the questions here discuss:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Automata Theory&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Computability Theory&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Computational Complexity / Analysis of Algorithms&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Cryptography&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Algorithms and Data Structures (probably beyond scope here - my interested is in the applied, not theoretical)&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Artificial Intelligence (probably beyond scope here - my interested is in the applied, not theoretical)&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Computer Vision (probably beyond scope here - my interested is in the applied, not theoretical)&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Image Processing (probably beyond scope here - my interested is in the applied, not theoretical)&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Data Communication (potentially beyond scope, but I can see the theoretical underpinnings being within scope)&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Programming Language Theories (potentially beyond scope, but there are mathematical underpinnings to the design/implementation of programming languages and compilers/interpreters that would probably be within scope)&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Models of Concurrency&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Models of Parallel Computing&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Models of Distributed Computing&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;So, my questions:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;What difficulty of questions are acceptable? My experience in theoretical computer science is limited, but I'm still interested in the theories that underpin what I do.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;What topics are specifically considered a subset of theoretical computer science? I'm looking for someplace where I can ask and get answers to questions in (at least a subset of) the above-listed topics, which are unarguably topics within computer science, but potentially not within theoretical computer science. If this is not the place, can someone point me to a Stack Exchange where these are potentially within scope?&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="403" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" LastActivityDate="2010-08-27T23:01:21.653" Title="What level and types of questions are appropriate for Theoretical Computer Science?" ./Posts.xml:111:  <row Id="118" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2010-08-25T12:12:26.983" Score="17" ViewCount="370" Body="&lt;p&gt;I answered the &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/41/arxiv-tags-vs-not&quot;&gt;Arxiv tags or not&lt;/a&gt; question so:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;The current &lt;code&gt;AA.BB.CCCCC&lt;/code&gt; tags are unwieldy &amp;mdash;a defect in a question tagging scheme, not so bad in an article classification scheme&amp;mdash; and &lt;code&gt;AA&lt;/code&gt; is nearly always &lt;code&gt;cs&lt;/code&gt;.  The exceptions are, AFAICT, misclassifications.  &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;  &#xA;  &lt;p&gt;If we simply dropped the &lt;code&gt;AA.&lt;/code&gt; part off the tag, we would have a system that looks like the MO scheme, and is more pleasant.  We'd also remove the tiresome &lt;code&gt;math.lo.logic&lt;/code&gt; vs. &lt;code&gt;cs.lo.logic&lt;/code&gt; issue.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;  &#xA;  &lt;p&gt;The full Arxiv code can be given in the tag description.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Since the suggestion was well-received, I am promoting it to a retag request.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Two concrete examples: make [cs.cc.complexity-theory] a synonym of [cc.complexity-theory] and [cs.ds.data-structures] a synonym of [ds.data-structures].  There are currently 11 such &quot;cs.&quot; prefixed tags.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;This is tagged [feature-request], so vote up if you think this retagging should be done, down if you think it shouldn't.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="270" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.560" LastActivityDate="2010-11-24T16:57:45.190" Title="Proposal: Remove discipline prefix from the Arxiv-style tags" Tags="&lt;feature-request&gt;&lt;tags&gt;&lt;retag-request&gt;&lt;7-essential&gt;" AnswerCount="3" CommentCount="3" FavoriteCount="2" />
./Posts.xml:113:  <row Id="120" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2010-08-25T13:33:51.220" Score="8" ViewCount="3034" Body="&lt;p&gt;I wanted to raise this question based on &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/73/which-metaheuristic-methods-are-admissible-for-discussion&quot;&gt;the discussion here&lt;/a&gt;. ./Posts.xml:114:  <row Id="121" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2010-08-25T13:41:05.123" Score="4" ViewCount="161" Body="&lt;p&gt;This has been raised several times and we should make a group decision.  Raised before:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/62/developing-a-cw-policy/63#63&quot;&gt;Developing a CW policy.&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/56/are-list-questions-such-as-about-conferences-on-topic/66#66&quot;&gt;Are list questions such as about conferences on-topic?&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/99/places-to-look-for-articles-and-discussions&quot;&gt;Places to look for articles and discussions&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Are questions about the field of TCS on or off topic?  Examples would be lists of books, journals, or conferences.  &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Assuming that they're off-topic, Robert Cartaino has already stated that these questions should not be posted on meta (even though there was some community support for the idea):&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;Because it is off-topic against the&#xA;  purpose of the site. There's already a&#xA;  wide-spread belief that if something&#xA;  is off topic, you just make it&#xA;  community wiki. You don't need to add&#xA;  another layer to that.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;So we need to determine:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Are questions about the field really off-topic?&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;If they are off-topic, does that mean that they can't be asked on meta?&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;These decisions should go into our FAQ.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="7" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" LastActivityDate="2010-08-25T14:54:37.720" Title="Are discussions about the field of TCS off-topic?" ./Posts.xml:115:  <row Id="122" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="67" CreationDate="2010-08-25T13:48:22.783" Score="3" Body="&lt;h1&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/users/270/charles-stewart&quot;&gt;Charles Stewart&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/h1&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/users/270/charles-stewart&quot;&gt;(meta)&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Accept&lt;/strong&gt;. ./Posts.xml:116:  <row Id="123" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="67" CreationDate="2010-08-25T13:54:10.383" Score="5" Body="&lt;h1&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/users/30/aaron-sterling&quot;&gt;Aaron Sterling&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/h1&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/users/30/aaron-sterling&quot;&gt;(meta)&lt;/a&gt;&#xA;&lt;BR&gt;&lt;BR&gt;&#xA;&lt;strong&gt;Accept&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="7" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.537" LastActivityDate="2010-09-02T13:43:27.200" CommentCount="1" CommunityOwnedDate="2010-08-25T13:54:10.383" />
./Posts.xml:124:  <row Id="131" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="41" CreationDate="2010-08-25T20:39:15.593" Score="2" Body="&lt;p&gt;I believe that These arXiv tags should not be used at all.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;My biggest concern is that these tags are not friendly to people who don't know arXiv (I'm one of these people). I have an interest in many computer science topics, but I rarely read computer science publications, have never browsed arVix, and really don't want to learn how to use such a system that I'll never use off of this site.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;However, I routinely read other publications of papers by the IEEE (in fact, I have the most recent issue of IEEE Transactions on Software Engineering next to me right now). Papers in this publication have &quot;index terms&quot; - keywords that describe what the paper is about. I grabbed a copy of the ACM Transactions on Software Engineering and Methodology out of my shelf, and they have three sections: categories and subject descriptions (which contain a code as well as textual descriptions), general terms, and additional key words/phrases. Whenever I've searched for papers in an online database, my matches have always come from the keywords sections or the body of the paper.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Looking at these tags, they are unwieldy. I have no idea what the tag means, and I wouldn't expect that most undergraduate computer scientists and software engineers would either. Given the responses to &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/115&quot;&gt;my previous question here on Meta&lt;/a&gt;, you want to be inclusive of multiple skill levels. If I find it difficult to search and browse through questions based on tags (which are also used in the site search engine), I'll be less likely to use this site.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Instead of following MathOverflow, I believe that this exchange should follow a path closer to that of &lt;a href=&quot;https://math.stackexchange.com/&quot;&gt;Mathematics&lt;/a&gt;. There are &lt;a href=&quot;https://math.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/48/should-mathoverflow-tag-prefixes-be-used&quot;&gt;three&lt;/a&gt; &lt;a href=&quot;https://math.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/186/setting-things-straight-what-style-of-tags-are-we-going-to-be-using-when-we-laun&quot;&gt;relevant&lt;/a&gt; &lt;a href=&quot;https://math.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/59/mathoverflow-tags-others&quot;&gt;discussions&lt;/a&gt; on their Meta that I could find. The Mathematics community appears to be doing quite well in terms of having people of various skill levels (appears to range from undergraduate university-level mathematics on up), their tagging appears to be working quite well, and I honestly find it easier to read and search than MathOverflow.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;But really, if this Stack Exchange follows MathOverflow, I actually see someone else coming along and making another Computer Science exchange geared toward a broader audience, in terms of skill levels. I think that this exchange can avoid this splintering of the community (avoiding another Unix/Linux versus Ubuntu Stack Exchange problem) by catering to as many people of various skill levels and educational backgrounds as possible. Yes, you need a specific focus on certain topics and clearly define what is and is not on-topic, but you want to segregate based on those topics, not by knowledge or experience. By dumping the arVix style tags, you make it easy for everyone to find questions/answers, but also make the site friendlier to less knowledgeable and experienced people such as myself.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;However, that's not to say that arVix isn't useful. I believe Stack Exchanges have the &quot;tag wiki&quot; page that Stack Overflow has. It would be benefitial to identify which tags correspond to arVix topic areas and link to those topic areas in the tag wiki for a given tag.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Also, a technical consideration: The &lt;a href=&quot;http://microformats.org/wiki/rel-tag&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;tags are specified using rel=&quot;tag&quot;&lt;/a&gt; in the source of a page. If you aren't familiar with microformats, search engines actually do pick up on them and they do help people find pages. People who do searches search for things like &quot;data structure&quot; and &quot;data structures&quot;, not &quot;cs.DS.data-structures&quot;. The tags should reflect what people are searching on Google and Bing so that they are brought to questions on Stack Exchanges that are relevant to their searches.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;hr&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I also want to address a few comments and other postings.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Another point that I've read in &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/41/arxiv-tags-vs-not/74#74&quot;&gt;some postings and comments here&lt;/a&gt; is that you want to maintain compatibility with MathOverflow. I think this is a mistake. MathOverflow is a Stack Exchange 1.0 site and, last I heard, had no intention of migrating to Stack Exchange 2.0. However, there are a number of Stack Exchange 2.0 sites that might be of interest to this community in some way that are at various levels of existance - Stack Overflow (people might ask algorithm or data structure implementation questions here), Mathematics (which includes discrete mathematics, graph theory, combinatorics...), Statistical Analysis (which includes machine learning), Not Programming Related, Compiler Design, Software Engineering, Artificial Intelligence, Application Security, Machine Learning, Numerical Modeling and Simulation, Signal Processing, Operating systems Development, Natural Language Processing and Computational Linguistics, and Cryptography (and those are just the first 10 pages of proposals, sorted by progress). These are the communities that need to work together to decide what best belongs where, especially since it appears that there will be a feature to move questions between various Stack Exchange 2.0 sites. Unless things change on MathOverflow, you will never be able to migrate a question from here to MO. However, in the future, it will be possible to migrate questions to the exchanges I mentioned, and so far, none of them are using ArVix tagging.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;As &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/41/arxiv-tags-vs-not/42#42&quot;&gt;first mentioned in a comment here&lt;/a&gt;, some of the ArVix tags are long. Potentially too long to fit in the limit of a tag. The purpose of tags is to help people search and sort through questions. If you start abbreviating ArVix tags, you open up a whole new can of worms with the best way to abbreviate the tags.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="403" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:19:18.947" LastActivityDate="2010-08-25T22:09:30.680" CommentCount="9" />
./Posts.xml:125:  <row Id="132" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="118" CreationDate="2010-08-25T21:58:33.107" Score="3" Body="&lt;p&gt;While at it, we could try to come up with better names for the tags. Here is the current list of tags and their new names. Feel free to edit, but please keep in mind that tags can only have at most 24 characters. Old tags can be left as synonyms.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;strong&gt;cc.complexity-theory&lt;/strong&gt;     &amp;lt;- cs.cc.complexity-theory (&lt;em&gt;Computational Complexity&lt;/em&gt;, cs.cc.complexity-theory in MO)&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;strong&gt;cr.crypto-security&lt;/strong&gt;       &amp;lt;- cs.cr.crypto-security (&lt;em&gt;Cryptography and Security&lt;/em&gt;)&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;strong&gt;cg.comput-geometry&lt;/strong&gt;       &amp;lt;- cs.cg.comp-geom (&lt;em&gt;Computational Geometry&lt;/em&gt;, cs.cg in MO)&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;strong&gt;dc.distributed-comp&lt;/strong&gt;      &amp;lt;- cs.dc.distributed-comp (&lt;em&gt;Distributed Computing&lt;/em&gt;)&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;strong&gt;dc.parallel-comp&lt;/strong&gt;         &amp;lt;- parallelism (&lt;em&gt;Parallel Computing&lt;/em&gt;)&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;strong&gt;ds.data-structures&lt;/strong&gt;       &amp;lt;- cs.ds.data-structures, data-structures (&lt;em&gt;Data Structures&lt;/em&gt;)&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;strong&gt;ds.algorithms&lt;/strong&gt;            &amp;lt;- algorithms (&lt;em&gt;Algorithms&lt;/em&gt;)&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;strong&gt;fl.formal-languages&lt;/strong&gt;      &amp;lt;- cs.fl.formal-languages (&lt;em&gt;Formal Languages and Automata Theory&lt;/em&gt;)&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;strong&gt;gt.game-theory&lt;/strong&gt;           &amp;lt;- cs.gt.game-theory (&lt;em&gt;Computer Science and Game Theory&lt;/em&gt;)&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;strong&gt;lg.machine-learning&lt;/strong&gt;      &amp;lt;- cs.lg.learning (&lt;em&gt;Machine Learning&lt;/em&gt;, cs.lg.learning in MO)&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;strong&gt;lo.logic&lt;/strong&gt;                 &amp;lt;- cs.lo.logic (&lt;em&gt;Logic in Computer Science&lt;/em&gt;, lo.logic in MO is related)&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;strong&gt;ne.neural-evol&lt;/strong&gt;           &amp;lt;- cs.ne.neural-evol (&lt;em&gt;Neural and Evolutionary Computation&lt;/em&gt;)&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;strong&gt;pl.programming-lang&lt;/strong&gt;      &amp;lt;- cs.pl.programming-lang (&lt;em&gt;Programming Languages&lt;/em&gt;)&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Again, &lt;a href=&quot;http://arxiv.org/corr/subjectclasses&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;here&lt;/a&gt; is the list of ArXiv/CORR subject classes.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;And as it seems that &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/41/arxiv-tags-vs-not&quot;&gt;people would like to keep the tags as simple as possible&lt;/a&gt;, I'd suggest that we also change:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;strong&gt;combinatorics&lt;/strong&gt; &amp;lt;- co.combinatorics&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;strong&gt;category-theory&lt;/strong&gt; &amp;lt;- math.ct.category-theory&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The idea would be that each post is tagged with at least one &quot;dotted&quot; ArXiv/CORR tag, and those would be our &quot;top level&quot; tags. Everything else is extra and kept as simple as possible.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="74" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.560" LastActivityDate="2010-09-05T20:08:53.287" CommentCount="8" CommunityOwnedDate="2010-08-25T21:58:33.107" />

./Posts.xml:135:  <row Id="143" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="1" CreationDate="2010-08-26T08:23:05.750" Score="2" Body="&lt;h1&gt;FiniteOracle.com&lt;/h1&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Available, as are *.org, *.net.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;From &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/1/what-should-our-site-domain-name-be/18#18&quot;&gt;gphilip's infinite stable&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="270" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.560" LastActivityDate="2010-08-26T08:23:05.750" CommentCount="0" CommunityOwnedDate="2010-08-26T08:23:05.750" />
./Posts.xml:138:  <row Id="146" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="144" CreationDate="2010-08-26T09:26:42.447" Score="3" Body="&lt;p&gt;I asked this question as a vehicle for answering questions about &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/67/who-should-the-moderators-be/122#122&quot;&gt;my statement that &quot;I'm not convinced the site has a future&quot;&lt;/a&gt;.  I don't think we are yet on course to be a successful Q&amp;amp;A site for a few reasons:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;We have no users who I would call names to conjure with.  This matters for any site: e.g., SO has many active users who are highly recognised experts for a large number of topics, and the SX folk think that this is essential to SOs success and will be essential to the sites coming through the SX beta phase. For academic Q&amp;amp;A sites, as opposed to problem-solving sites I think this is even more important.  How important has Terence Tao's endorsement of MO been to that site's success?  The other two beta sites I've participated in, math.SX and tex.SX, had done far better by their 10th day.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;We have a lack of high reputation users.  We don't have any 1k+ reputation users at all, so apart from the SX moderators, we have no-one who can edit weak questions, let alone access the moderation tools. It takes five 500+ users to close a question without moderator actions; we have 8.  We have only 23x 250+ users who can retag.  To some extent, this is a fact of life about the early public beta stage, but other sites have done better.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Very little interest has been shown, or effort put into in the things that need to be done on meta to make the site a success.  Shane is our distinguished exception, Suresh has put in some effort, as well.  Besides these two, we have a list of fairly undifferentiated potential moderators: I haven't seen a whole lot of indication as to why one 500+ user would make a better moderator than another.  Work on the FAQ is nonexistent.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;That said, interesting questions have been asked and answered, we've got a pretty clear idea of our scope, and it's early days.  Call me moderately pessimistic, and since I have discovered that I am suddenly what counts for a high-reputation user around here, I'm going to start making an effort.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Postscript&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I don't think we have exactly what I would call &quot;names to conjure with&quot;, but maybe that's too much to expect in TCS, which is much more balkanized that maths, and where the famous names are that much older, and that much less involved in web-based social networking (but, you know, Alan Kay has &lt;a href=&quot;https://stackoverflow.com/users/48710/alan-kay&quot;&gt;an account on SO&lt;/a&gt;).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;That said, the comments to this post have shown what a breadth there are of scientists who have made indubitably major contributions to the field, and there has been the beginnings of what I hope will be an influx of users have been excellent contributors to MO.  Lance Fornow, in particular, is a young scientist with a high profile.  I am now officially relaxed about point #1.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="270" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-05-23T11:33:34.517" LastActivityDate="2010-08-30T13:07:49.813" CommentCount="9" />
./Posts.xml:140:  <row Id="148" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="144" CreationDate="2010-08-26T10:19:34.057" Score="3" Body="&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;Do you have general thoughts about the future of the site?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I see a lot of potential here. I'm a software engineer, but I'm dealing with a lot of topics at work that touch on topics here - algorithms and data structures (especially performance), cryptography, stenography, security, as well as concurrent and distributed systems (but these are more from an applied standing rather than the theoretical that is more appropriate here). Even taking a look back at previous jobs, having a Stack Exchange to ask questions and provide answers about computer science topics I've encountered would have been helpful a long time ago.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If anything is going to be a problem, it's going to be scaring away people who aren't experts in the field. Honestly, I'm not that thrilled with the current state of TCS. It's following MathOverflow too closely and is catering to the experts. What makes Stack Overflow (and even Mathematics and Statistical Analysis) so great is that people of various levels of knowledge and experience are using the exact same site. The problem with MathOverflow (and TCS is going down this road) is that it focuses on the experts and the researchers. TCS does have some college students using it, but many are in a program or that deals exclusively with theoretical CS, and these people appear to be doing OK. However, people like me who have a more practical background, but are interested in the theoretical side of things without a formal education, aren't made to feel as welcome (or at least, that's the impression I get).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I think part of the problem is that there is no hands on leadership. This Stack Exchange was proposed by Anand Kulkarni (&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/users/71/anand-kulkarni&quot;&gt;meta profile&lt;/a&gt;, &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/users/71&quot;&gt;site profile&lt;/a&gt;). Yet this user has less than 200 reputation, has only posted 3 things (1 question, 2 answers) on the main site, and has only posted 2 answers on the meta. So right from Day 1, the person who came up with this idea hasn't been involved in the site. Stack Exchange doesn't give you the tools you need to lay the framework for a site until it goes into Private Beta, and by then, it's too late for the person who came up with this idea to propose a framework of how the system works in his/her mind, since other people have already started to use the site.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Given the focus on experts/experienced people and lack of hands on leadership (although some people are emerging as leaders, so this might turn around with the addition of moderators), I wouldn't be surprised if this Stack Exchange doesn't make it. And I think that it would be a shame if it didn't.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;Are you pleased with the quality and interest of the questions and answers you've seen on the main site?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I've asked &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/585/what-is-the-difference-between-a-second-preimage-attack-and-a-collision-attack&quot;&gt;one question&lt;/a&gt;, and I'm quite pleased with the answer I got. The way I worded my question, I didn't expect someone to take the time to write up such a detailed answer. But they did, and I'm better off because of it.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;How well do you think we are doing at resolving issues and conflicts that arise?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I think this is a problem with the Stack Exchange system. The fact that there is no place for meta discussions until the site goes into private beta is a bad thing. So right now, we (and I think several Stack Exchanges have had this problem) have lots of people who read the description of the site, but then got there and were disappointed because the description didn't capture what was really happening. Because of this, everyone comes to Meta after there are already questions and answers posted on the site, time is passing, more questions/answers are being posted, and there's no agreed upon method to do things.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I think it will get better once there are more high reputation users and moderators on the main site, but I do think that this is something that the Stack Exchange team needs to address.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="403" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" LastActivityDate="2010-08-26T10:19:34.057" CommentCount="4" />

./Posts.xml:144:  <row Id="152" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="144" CreationDate="2010-08-26T21:36:19.427" Score="7" Body="&lt;p&gt;For what it's worth: I think that the site is coming along very well, especially at this early stage.  I'm not a part of the community by any stretch of the imagination, but view this as an exciting opportunity to learn about a field for which I have a great interest.  And I think that the site has struck a good balance between being expert friendly, while also allowing some questions that can open up the field to non-experts.  &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;As others have mentioned, the core members of the field would have to comprise of a fairly small number.  Many of the top ranked contributors to the site are clearly experts.  This is a real difference to the other stackexchange sites (putting MO aside for a minute).  While there may be a valid concern about the possibility of too many CW questions (and I am probably one of the top perpetrators), this hasn't been an overwhelming problem: the vast majority of questions have been properly on-topic, and this should only continue to improve as the site develops more of a clear heuristic.  &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;We also have a real opportunity to use this site in a meaningful way.  One trivial example is &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/58/how-to-promote-the-site/137#137&quot;&gt;my idea for promoting the site&lt;/a&gt;.  I would love to see more &quot;meta&quot; thought being given to &lt;em&gt;how we can use the site beyond known Q&amp;amp;A to tackle real open problems&lt;/em&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If anything, it would seem that the primary challenge is getting experts from the different branches of TCS.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="7" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" LastActivityDate="2010-08-26T21:42:19.750" CommentCount="1" />

./Posts.xml:148:  <row Id="156" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="17" CreationDate="2010-08-27T05:50:21.217" Score="2" Body="&lt;p&gt;I would agree that the three questions above are examples of the type of question that should be closed due to being too elementary.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Having said that, I would like to argue that the scope of allowable questions should be kept fairly broad.  As someone who hasn't done graduate coursework in TCS, I find the CW/big-list questions very helpful. (My &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/238/references-for-tcs-proof-techniques&quot;&gt;own question&lt;/a&gt; had 4 votes to close before anyone had a chance to reply, but I think it turned out to be useful to others.)  I know that you don't want the mix of questions to become too elementary and put off the serious researchers.  It would be nice to be able to segregate the more basic questions from the advanced, but given that the theory community is small, there probably aren't enough people to support two separate StackExchange sites.  And hopefully some of the people asking basic questions will eventually be asking (and answering) more advanced stuff.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Here's one little idea that might be workable: ask that anyone posting a question that could be considered undergrad-level material to tag it with something like &quot;intro&quot;.  Then anyone who doesn't want that stuff cluttering up their view could add the intro tag to their ignore filter.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I think over time the mix of questions is going to include more like &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/34/how-hard-is-unshuffling-a-string&quot;&gt;Jeff Erickson's&lt;/a&gt;, and this will become a less sensitive issue.  (By the way, has Bill Gasarch visited here yet?  He's posted some questions in the past on the CC blog that would be great for this site.)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="184" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" LastActivityDate="2010-08-27T05:50:21.217" CommentCount="2" />

3-coloring of a complete graph?&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a graphs with trivial automorphism groups ?&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a functions?&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/522/what-is-the-best-pcp-characterization-of-p&quot;&gt;PCP defining the different notions of efficient computation?&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;IMHO, this is not a nice practice, and I consider this as a possible sign that the author is not really interested in the questions (and maybe haven't spent much time trying to find out the answer by himself/herself). &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Should we discourage this kind of behavior?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;ps: I know that we are still in beta and this might be OK for this stage.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="186" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" LastActivityDate="2010-09-15T15:35:00.613" Title="Is asking a bunch of questions in a short period of time appropriate?" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;" AnswerCount="5" CommentCount="4" FavoriteCount="1" />
./Posts.xml:161:  <row Id="169" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2010-08-27T20:57:51.687" Score="10" ViewCount="193" Body="&lt;p&gt;My motivation for this question is the response to my question &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/682/bounds-on-efx-in-terms-of-fex-other-than-jensens-inequality&quot;&gt;here&lt;/a&gt;, which garnered a vote to close for being too mathy.  Supportive comments and upvoting seemed to have saved that particular question from death, but for future reference, are questions about other fields with applications in CS theory considered OK?  For instance, would CS-oriented questions on these topics be considered on-topic?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;discrete fourier analysis&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;metric geometry&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;geometry of polytopes&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;All of these are definitely pure math, but flip through a recent STOC/FOCS proceedings, and you're likely to see a lot of proofs that use theorems and tools from these fields.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;My personal opinion is that if we want TheoryOverflow to be useful to working researchers, then we have to allow questions about the tools and techniques used in TCS and that means allowing appropriate questions from areas of math with applications in TCS.  Such questions could be asked on MathOverflow, but I do not see a bit of overlap as a problem, and people here are likely to have both interest in such questions as well as the expertise needed to answer them.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="205" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" LastActivityDate="2010-08-28T08:54:30.573" Title="When are areas of pure math that are used in CS considered on-topic?" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;scope&gt;" AnswerCount="1" CommentCount="3" FavoriteCount="2" />

./Posts.xml:164:  <row Id="172" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="169" CreationDate="2010-08-28T08:54:30.573" Score="6" Body="&lt;p&gt;Given the large overlap between math and TCS, my recommendation for questions that might seem out of scope for this site is to do nothing. Either they won't get much attention, or someone will post something, indicating that the question is within scope. Since we don't have a problem with &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/25/material-to-supplement-the-faq/36#36&quot;&gt;cross posting to MO within limits&lt;/a&gt;, that seems the most effective 'let the community decide' strategy. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="80" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" LastActivityDate="2010-08-28T08:54:30.573" CommentCount="1" />
./Posts.xml:165:  <row Id="173" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2010-08-28T19:18:26.127" Score="5" ViewCount="500" Body="&lt;p&gt;Over at MathOverflow the community accepts math puzzles, and in fact even has a &lt;a href=&quot;https://mathoverflow.net/questions/tagged/recreational&quot;&gt;couple&lt;/a&gt; &lt;a href=&quot;https://mathoverflow.net/questions/tagged/puzzle&quot;&gt;tags&lt;/a&gt; devoted to them. Of course, puzzles can be illuminating when they require that one makes some creative observation or employ some particularly tricky technique. At the same time, puzzles can be distracting and wholey inappropriate in the landscape of a professional forum.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I think we should decide, before we see our first brain teaser, whether such puzzles are welcome here on CSTheory.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerDisplayName="Ross Snider" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:57:54.527" LastActivityDate="2010-08-29T03:28:01.600" Title="Are brain teasers and CS puzzles valid questions? ./Posts.xml:167:  <row Id="175" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="173" CreationDate="2010-08-28T21:53:30.207" Score="6" Body="&lt;p&gt;I think that questions related to &quot;recreational computer science&quot; are welcome. ./Posts.xml:179:  <row Id="187" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAnswerId="194" CreationDate="2010-08-29T20:57:30.607" Score="5" ViewCount="208" Body="&lt;p&gt;We will soon have temporary moderators from within the community, and so I wanted to initiate a discussion on policies for suspension/blocks/bans. ./Posts.xml:180:  <row Id="188" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2010-08-30T05:28:32.377" Score="16" ViewCount="252" Body="&lt;p&gt;This question builds on a comment of Shane's in a &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/144/how-are-we-doing/152#152&quot;&gt;previous meta post&lt;/a&gt; on what can be achieved using a theory Q&amp;amp;A site.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I've spent a good deal of time on Jeff Erickson's lovely problem about &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/34/how-hard-is-unshuffling-a-string&quot;&gt;unshuffling a string&lt;/a&gt;, and during the proposal phase, on his question about the complexity of minimum sequences in generalized Rubik's cube.  However, I haven't posted any responses to those questions because I didn't end up with an answer.  &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Most of what I've done is discover dead ends and approaches that don't work.  These might be useful for someone to know so that they don't spend time on the same issue or if they'd like to pick up where I left off.  Unfortunately, the Q&amp;amp;A format doesn't seem naturally suited to this style of inquiry.   A wrong answer isn't an &quot;answer&quot; per se, and a detailed discussion won't fit in a non-nested comment thread.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;The question: how can the CSTheory Q&amp;amp;A&#xA;  format better be used to support these&#xA;  kinds of parallel group investigations&#xA;  into problems?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;One idea is to adopt the convention that &quot;answers&quot; to open questions are to be regarded as a discussion of possible approaches, rather than literal answers or partial answers to the question, then to encourage development of these approaches in the comments.  The downside is that these comments are not nested.  &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Another possibility is to fork new questions concerning particular avenues of inquiry with links back to the parent question, perhaps with a dedicated &quot;subproblem&quot; tag; this might lead to a messy proliferation of subquestions.  &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Has any better format been discovered for collaborative investigation of open problems on other StackExchange sites, in particular, MO?  Are there other features in StackExchange we can activate to support this process?  Or is it better to instead restrict these kinds of investigations to blogs and wikis, as was done in Polymath? &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="71" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" LastActivityDate="2010-08-31T19:30:54.543" Title="How can we collaboratively investigate open problems?" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;" AnswerCount="5" CommentCount="0" FavoriteCount="4" />
./Posts.xml:183:  <row Id="191" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="188" CreationDate="2010-08-30T12:35:41.387" Score="3" Body="&lt;p&gt;Yes, within the framework of this Q&amp;amp;A, but it requires a little more judgement of what is interesting than the usual manner of use.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Each dead-end you found started as an avenue worth exploring.  What question characterises that avenue?  &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The risk is that these questions are not very interesting.  There's a close reason &quot;too localized&quot; that may be invoked if a question concerns, among other alternatives, an &lt;em&gt;extraordinary narrow situation&lt;/em&gt;.  Looking for an interesting generalisation of the subproblem might help.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If you do craft a nice question, there's a bonus: the motivation for your question is likely to already have interested other posters.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;There was a nice instance of a question on SO, &lt;a href=&quot;https://stackoverflow.com/questions/2588943/circles-and-triangles-problem&quot;&gt;Circles and triangles problem&lt;/a&gt;, whose answers were in fact a collaborative investigation; all the subquestions were resolved in the Q&amp;amp;A thread over six days, resulting in a good algorithm that was not there shown to be optimal.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="270" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-05-23T11:33:34.517" LastActivityDate="2010-08-30T12:35:41.387" CommentCount="0" />

./Posts.xml:190:  <row Id="198" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="188" CreationDate="2010-08-31T12:06:45.600" Score="4" Body="&lt;p&gt;Many open problems (and some experiments, like hard IMO problems) are handled on the &lt;a href=&quot;http://polymathprojects.org/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;polymath blog&lt;/a&gt;. ./Posts.xml:196:  <row Id="204" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAnswerId="205" CreationDate="2010-09-01T00:54:21.463" Score="11" ViewCount="315" Body="&lt;p&gt;See &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/813/is-the-lower-bound-proof-in-this-paper-correct&quot;&gt;this question about an origami paper&lt;/a&gt; for example. It's a very specific question about a particular theorem the poster did not follow (or in this case the answer did not match that of the paper).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Personally, I think such questions are great. They provide a nice break from all these CW questions we've been seeing. These questions actually have a correct answer, and are usually technical, and indeed it would be hard for the poster to find the solution anywhere else (other than emailing the authors of said paper).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I just wanted to know if the community finds such questions acceptable. If so, we can include it in the FAQ (if we're going to have a list of example questions in the FAQ).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="206" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" LastActivityDate="2010-09-01T17:48:30.907" Title="Are specific questions about Theorem X in paper Y fine?" ./Posts.xml:201:  <row Id="209" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAnswerId="210" CreationDate="2010-09-01T19:07:13.090" Score="7" ViewCount="4035" Body="&lt;p&gt;c.f &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/843/problem-from-growth-of-function&quot;&gt;this question on O() notation&lt;/a&gt;. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Stackoverflow actually has the 'homework' tag, and is willing to entertain questions of that kind. MO has strong prohibitions in place against it. The first problem here is that it's not entirely obvious that this is a homework question, and that changes my response. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;If it's not a homework question, then I'm willing to nudge the OP along in comments to find the answer themselves&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;if it is, I'd rather not help. &lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;either way, I'm loathe to actually POST an answer, because it's a gratuitous rep honeypot, and it might only encourage more questions along these lines, and I'm not sure I want to encourage questions that are so low-level.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;But I recognize that there are differences of opinion on how welcoming we should be. So what say all ? &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="80" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" LastActivityDate="2010-10-26T16:31:08.373" Title="Homework, or things that look like homework." Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;scope&gt;&lt;homework&gt;" AnswerCount="8" CommentCount="1" FavoriteCount="1" />
./Posts.xml:206:  <row Id="214" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2010-09-02T02:27:56.040" Score="7" ViewCount="399" Body="&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/813/is-the-lower-bound-proof-in-this-paper-correct&quot;&gt;This question&lt;/a&gt; seems to have found an error in a computational geometry paper on CoRR, and David Eppstein in an answer confirmed the error.  I haven't checked it myself, but I wanted to ask if we should set up some policy to contact an author with a pointer to questions of this sort.  This seems to have a lot of potential as an additional service to the community this site could provide (part of &quot;Peer Review 2.0&quot;).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;A concrete suggestion: if a Q&amp;amp;A locates/seems to locate an error in a paper, a moderator should email the corresponding author of the paper with a pointer to the question, and comment in the question that this happened.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="30" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" LastActivityDate="2010-09-04T20:40:25.540" Title="Should there be a protocol to notify authors if we find an error in a paper?" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;" AnswerCount="3" CommentCount="4" />
./Posts.xml:207:  <row Id="215" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAnswerId="219" CreationDate="2010-09-02T07:47:04.940" Score="1" ViewCount="120" Body="&lt;p&gt;What should be done if a question uses copyrighted material?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;E.g. &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/857/which-ac0-problems-are-not-truly-feasible&quot;&gt;this question&lt;/a&gt; seems to use the diagram due to Immermann.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="186" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" LastActivityDate="2010-09-03T17:02:10.660" Title="Copyright issues" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;" AnswerCount="2" CommentCount="0" />
./Posts.xml:210:  <row Id="218" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="209" CreationDate="2010-09-02T09:29:24.983" Score="3" Body="&lt;p&gt;I'm not against homework questions where the qner is upfront about the fact, shares what they understand and don't understand about the solution (both SO guidelines), and where the question is at an appropriate level.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In general, the magic shield against the bad kind of homework question is for answerers to ask themselves &quot;Do I know why the questioner wants to know the answer?&quot;  If not, don't rush to answer, ask why.  For real questions, that typically casts light on how to go about providing an answer.  For abusive questions, it is hard to give good reasons.  I want something along these lines to be in the FAQ, along with what Shane said about the spirit of the site.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In this respect, we could do with being better about questions.  I note that &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/246/extensions-of-beta-theory-of-lambda-calculus&quot;&gt;one of my own questions&lt;/a&gt; is not well-motivated: I should go off and fix it.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="270" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" LastActivityDate="2010-09-02T09:37:51.070" CommentCount="1" />
./Posts.xml:213:  <row Id="221" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="214" CreationDate="2010-09-03T03:40:33.237" Score="2" Body="&lt;p&gt;This is relevant to the &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/204/are-specific-questions-about-theorem-x-in-paper-y-fine&quot;&gt;other thread&lt;/a&gt; too, but I thought I'll just post my comment here. It is a combined answer to the questions asked in both threads.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The other question, which reads &quot;Are specific questions about Theorem X in paper Y fine?&quot; actually covers two types of questions from posters.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Type 1: Questions like &quot;How does one reach eq 3.14 from eq 3.15 in paper X, page Y? I tried the following ... but it didn't work.&quot;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I think most people would agree that these questions are appropriate for this site. The other type of question is the following:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Type 2: &quot;How does the proof of Theorem 3 in [citation] handle the case of disconnected graphs? I don't see how it works for that case.&quot;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;This question might be pointing out a genuine error in a paper. But then again it might just be something the poster did not understand. What I want to say is that it is often hard to tell whether there is a mistake/confusion/non-understanding on your part, or an error in the paper. These correspond to type 1 and 2 questions respectively. If the poster is not able to distinguish between the two types of questions, and if we make it a policy to only allow Type 1 questions and not Type 2, this will be hard for posters.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Would a solution like the following work?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;We allow both type of questions. Questions of type 1 are handled as they usually are by the community. If we realize that it is a question of type 2 (i.e., there are answers which indicate that there is a genuine mistake in the paper), then a moderator emails the author of the paper and informs him of the thread, and offers to have the thread deleted.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Now the author may choose to have the thread deleted, or reply on the thread explaining how the poster has misunderstood and it is not an error, or reply thanking the poster for finding the error, or do nothing, etc. (I am assuming that moderators can delete threads.)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="206" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" LastActivityDate="2010-09-03T03:40:33.237" CommentCount="2" />

That's why we select a few members from each community to act as temporary, provisional Moderators. You can read about the program here: &lt;a href=&quot;http://blog.stackoverflow.com/2010/07/moderator-pro-tempore/&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Moderators Pro Tempore&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I am pleased to announce that these members have stepped up and generously volunteered their time to help us assure that each community’s issues are properly addressed:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;https://i.stack.imgur.com/LFoky.png&quot; alt=&quot;alt text&quot;&gt; &lt;img src=&quot;https://i.stack.imgur.com/yf5FI.png&quot; alt=&quot;alt text&quot;&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;We want to make this site a huge success, and these members are great examples of exactly the type of people we need to make this site succeed. Please welcome them for the hard work and time they contribute.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;Did I overlook anyone?&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Almost certainly. There are members who are actively involved and very deserving of recognition. My failure to account for everyone this early on is in &lt;em&gt;no way&lt;/em&gt; a slight against them. Ideally, Moderators are elected by the community and that's why &lt;strong&gt;you'll have your elections in several weeks.&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Most of all, be respectful and understanding of the Moderators Pro Tem. Members of your community are volunteering their time and learning on the job. It’s a learning experience for everyone. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="237" LastActivityDate="2010-09-03T16:59:53.563" Title="Moderator Pro Tem Announcement" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;moderators&gt;" AnswerCount="2" CommentCount="1" />
./Posts.xml:217:  <row Id="225" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2010-09-03T18:00:40.583" Score="22" ViewCount="4765" Body="&lt;p&gt;This is the official site FAQ for Theoretical Computer Science. This question will contain a list of questions, with each question linking to a &lt;strong&gt;single&lt;/strong&gt; answer. If there is prior discussion on an answer, or you wish to discuss a particular answer, please create a separate meta question and link to it (so that this FAQ remains uncluttered). &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The scope of this site:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/234#234&quot;&gt;Are questions about &lt;em&gt;[this area of computer science]&lt;/em&gt; on-topic here?&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/235#235&quot;&gt;What kind of questions are too basic?&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/238#238&quot;&gt;Specific questions about Theorem X in paper Y?&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/802/policy-questions-about-topic-for-research-project&quot;&gt;I'm looking for ideas for a project. ./Posts.xml:218:  <row Id="228" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="225" CreationDate="2010-09-03T18:43:35.470" Score="3" Body="&lt;h2&gt;What kinds of tags should I use?&lt;/h2&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Each question should have at least one &quot;ArXiv tag&quot;, and any number of additional tags (there is a limitation of at most 5 tags per question and at most 24 characters per tag). Try to re-use &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/tags&quot;&gt;existing tags&lt;/a&gt; whenever possible, but you are also welcome to propose new tags. See &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/tags/synonyms&quot;&gt;this page&lt;/a&gt; for our current list of tag synonyms.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;hr&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;ArXiv tags&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;[FIXME: add answer]&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Related discussion:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/41/arxiv-tags-vs-not)&quot;&gt;arXiv tags vs not?&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/118/proposal-remove-discipline-prefix-from-the-arxiv-style-tags&quot;&gt;Proposal: Remove discipline prefix from the Arxiv-style tags&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;hr&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/tags/soft-question/info&quot;&gt;[soft-question]&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;A soft-question is subjective and argumentative without a precise answer and can be a question &lt;strong&gt;about&lt;/strong&gt; theoretical computer science rather than being a question in it. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Examples:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;How would you teach X to undergrads?&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Why computer scientists do X when Y happens?&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Is theoretical computer science part of pure math?&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;How long will it take to settle P vs NP in your opinion?&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/182/big-picture-vs-soft-question&quot;&gt;More discussion&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;hr&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/tags/big-picture/info&quot;&gt;[big-picture]&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;A big-picture question is higher-level question, and although it can be subjective and argumentative it does not need to be, and is a question &lt;strong&gt;in&lt;/strong&gt; theoretical computer science. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Examples:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;What is the main idea behind Razborov-Rudich natural proofs?&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;What are the obstacles to prove a super-polynomial lower-bound for SAT?&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Where did the idea of Domain theory came from?&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;What are the main objects and constructions used in crypto?&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Is there a program to settle Unique Games Conjecture?&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Is polynomial time Turing computable the right definition for feasible computation?&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;What evidence do we have for Church-Turing thesis?&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/182/big-picture-vs-soft-question&quot;&gt;More discussion&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="74" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" LastActivityDate="2011-02-04T01:42:52.357" CommentCount="0" CommunityOwnedDate="2010-09-03T18:43:35.470" />
./Posts.xml:219:  <row Id="229" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="225" CreationDate="2010-09-03T18:58:15.523" Score="7" Body="&lt;h2&gt;Useful resources&lt;/h2&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Complexity classes:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://qwiki.stanford.edu/wiki/Complexity_Zoo&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;Complexity Zoo&lt;/a&gt;. In questions that are related to complexity classes, it's a good idea to first check the Zoo and see if your question is already answered there – or if it's a well-known open problem. The Zoo also defines the standard naming convention for complexity classes on this site.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Hardness and approximability:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.nada.kth.se/~viggo/wwwcompendium/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;A compendium of NP optimization problems&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Problems related to graph families:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.graphclasses.org/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;Information System on Graph Classes and their Inclusions (ISGCI)&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;hr&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Related discussion: &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/25/material-to-supplement-the-faq/44#44&quot;&gt;[1]&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="74" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" LastActivityDate="2011-04-21T11:39:17.667" CommentCount="2" CommunityOwnedDate="2010-09-03T18:58:15.523" />
./Posts.xml:220:  <row Id="230" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="225" CreationDate="2010-09-03T19:03:29.003" Score="9" Body="&lt;h2&gt;When should I downvote/upvote?&lt;/h2&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;First of all, try to vote &lt;strong&gt;often&lt;/strong&gt;. You have a budget of 30 votes per day, and it is perfectly fine to use up your daily quota.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Here are some guidelines that you can use to decide whether you should upvote, downvote, or not vote at all:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Upvote&lt;/strong&gt; only questions and answers you understand but do so whenever they are of high quality. To evaluate quality for a question think of whether it is interesting, whether it is at the appropriate level, whether it is well formulated. To evaluate quality for an answer think whether it addresses the question and whether you learned something from it. Above all, use your judgement.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Downvote&lt;/strong&gt; a question only if it is clearly not at the appropriate level or it is clearly not well formulated. Downvote an answer only if it is technically wrong, or does not address the question, or is so badly formulated that it is impossible to understand. You should leave a comment explaining why you downvoted whenever you do so, unless that would duplicate an already existing comment.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;You should &lt;strong&gt;ignore a question/answer's current score&lt;/strong&gt; when you decide on &lt;em&gt;your&lt;/em&gt; vote.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;You can't upvote or downvote your own question/answer.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;hr&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Related discussion:&#xA;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/6/vote-early-and-often&quot;&gt;[1]&lt;/a&gt;&#xA;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/25/material-to-supplement-the-faq/54#54&quot;&gt;[2]&lt;/a&gt;&#xA;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/108/ethics-of-upvoting-own-answer&quot;&gt;[3]&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="74" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" LastActivityDate="2010-09-23T03:54:44.740" CommentCount="0" CommunityOwnedDate="2010-09-03T19:03:29.003" />
./Posts.xml:221:  <row Id="231" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="225" CreationDate="2010-09-03T19:11:09.797" Score="5" Body="&lt;h2&gt;What is the policy on crossposting to/from MathOverflow or other StackExchange sites?&lt;/h2&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Crossposting from &lt;a href=&quot;https://mathoverflow.net/&quot;&gt;MathOverflow&lt;/a&gt; and other StackExchange sites is perfectly fine, as long as they aren't done in parallel. That is, if you post a question on one site, you should only post to the other site after you have not received a satisfactory answer for some time, and you should provide a link in each post (or in the comments on it) to the other one. As a courtesy, if you post your question here after trying MathOverflow or another StackExchange site, please try to integrate in your question the answers you received on MathOverflow/the other site (even if they did not answer everything).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;hr&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Related discussion:&#xA;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/25/material-to-supplement-the-faq/36#36&quot;&gt;[1]&lt;/a&gt;&#xA;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/65/repeat-a-question-from-math-overflow&quot;&gt;[2]&lt;/a&gt;&#xA;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/a/2853&quot;&gt;[3]&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="74" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:57:54.527" LastActivityDate="2014-07-05T06:35:40.837" CommentCount="0" CommunityOwnedDate="2010-09-03T19:11:09.797" />
./Posts.xml:222:  <row Id="232" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="225" CreationDate="2010-09-03T19:15:55.080" Score="1" Body="&lt;h2&gt;Can I discuss questions and answers on the site?&lt;/h2&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In addition to questions and answers, cstheory.sx supports, like other Stack Exchange sites, comments on questions and answers.  This supports discussions, and is important to improving posts, challenging possible mistakes, and bringing attention to relevant resources.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Of course, discussions only work if the participants know of the comments.  Besides comments appearing after the question or answer they comment on, the author of the question or answer will see that you have commented, as will anyone who you have notified by @name, where the site tries to figure out who @name might be by looking at the user names of other users who have participated in the thread.  You need at least the first three characters of the user name for the site to figure out that the @nam might be about them.  For more details on comment replies, see “&lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/43019/how-do-comment-replies-work&quot;&gt;How do comment replies work?&lt;/a&gt;” on meta.stackoverflow.com.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="270" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-20T10:29:37.593" LastActivityDate="2010-09-22T23:02:54.463" CommentCount="0" CommunityOwnedDate="2010-09-03T19:15:55.080" />

You can try it here: $\sum_x 2f(v_x)^2$.
