./Posts.xml:224:  <row Id="234" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="225" CreationDate="2010-09-03T19:42:07.137" Score="2" Body="&lt;h2&gt;Are questions about &lt;em&gt;[this area of computer science]&lt;/em&gt; on-topic here?&lt;/h2&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;As &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/faq&quot;&gt;our FAQ&lt;/a&gt; explains, we interpret &quot;Theoretical Computer Science&quot; broadly. Roughly speaking, the subareas of computer science that put &lt;strong&gt;emphasis on mathematical technique and rigor&lt;/strong&gt; are on-topic.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Here are some further clarifications regarding possible borderline cases:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Pure math&lt;/strong&gt;: if the problem has some applications in theoretical computer science, it is welcome here – &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/169/when-are-areas-of-pure-math-that-are-used-in-cs-considered-on-topic&quot;&gt;more discussion&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Artificial intelligence&lt;/strong&gt;: theoretical aspects of artificial intelligence are on-topic; philosophical questions are probably off-topic – &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/114/cstheory-vs-ai-stackexchange-site&quot;&gt;more discussion&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;hr&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Further discussion:&#xA;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/115/what-level-and-types-of-questions-are-appropriate-for-theoretical-computer-scienc&quot;&gt;[1]&lt;/a&gt;&#xA;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/119/our-domain-scope-specifically-defined&quot;&gt;[2]&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="74" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" LastActivityDate="2010-11-12T17:06:04.327" CommentCount="0" CommunityOwnedDate="2010-09-03T19:42:07.137" />
./Posts.xml:225:  <row Id="235" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="225" CreationDate="2010-09-03T19:57:42.990" Score="12" Body="&lt;h2&gt;What kind of questions are too basic?&lt;/h2&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Our aim is to ask and answer &lt;strong&gt;research-level&lt;/strong&gt; questions in theoretical computer science.  &quot;Research-level&quot; means, roughly, questions that might be discussed between two professors, or between graduate students working on Ph.D.'s, but not usually between a professor and the typical undergraduate student. &lt;em&gt;It does not include questions at the level of difficulty of undergraduate homework&lt;/em&gt;. Here are some examples of questions that are off-topic because they are not research-level or because they are too easy:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Questions that can be easily answered by reading a Wikipedia article on the topic.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Questions that can be easily solved by Googling.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Questions that are solved by browsing &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/229#229&quot;&gt;one of these web sites&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Typical homework problems in textbooks.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If you do not think that your question is research-level but you cannot find an answer in above options, you may want to try &lt;a href=&quot;https://math.stackexchange.com/&quot;&gt;https://math.stackexchange.com/&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;hr&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Related discussion:&#xA;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/17/scope-of-questions&quot;&gt;[1]&lt;/a&gt;&#xA;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/115/what-level-and-types-of-questions-are-appropriate-for-theoretical-computer-scienc&quot;&gt;[2]&lt;/a&gt;&#xA;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/209/homework-or-things-that-look-like-homework&quot;&gt;[3]&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="74" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:19:18.947" LastActivityDate="2011-02-02T20:15:48.913" CommentCount="1" CommunityOwnedDate="2010-09-03T19:57:42.990" />
./Posts.xml:226:  <row Id="236" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="225" CreationDate="2010-09-03T20:21:31.257" Score="9" Body="&lt;h2&gt;Do I need to use my real name?&lt;/h2&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;You do not have to, but you are strongly encouraged to use your real name. We hope that this site will become a valuable resource for the research community, and that reputation earned here will translate into reputation outside as well. Using your real name will help make that connection. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;We also hope that research discussions on this site will occasionally lead to actual citations in papers, or even new research ! From that perspective, using your real name will help immensely. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;hr&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Related discussion:&#xA;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/4/on-using-actual-names&quot;&gt;[1]&lt;/a&gt;&#xA;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/187/policy-on-suspending-users&quot;&gt;[2]&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="74" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" LastActivityDate="2010-09-23T18:39:01.657" CommentCount="0" CommunityOwnedDate="2010-09-03T20:21:31.257" />
./Posts.xml:227:  <row Id="237" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="225" CreationDate="2010-09-03T20:27:19.807" Score="14" Body="&lt;h2&gt;How do I write formulas?&lt;/h2&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;This site uses &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.mathjax.org/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;MathJax&lt;/a&gt;. You can simply type (almost) any LaTeX equations between a pair of $-signs, and the system will display it properly typeset. This should work in questions, answers, and comments (with some exceptions).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;hr&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h2&gt;Why don't I see any formulas? Why do I get a &lt;em&gt;[Math Processing Error]&lt;/em&gt;?&lt;/h2&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Try &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.mathjax.org/demos/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;this page&lt;/a&gt; first and see if MathJax works in your system at all. If the demo page works, but formulas on this site don't work, try to &lt;strong&gt;clear your browser's cache&lt;/strong&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;hr&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Related discussion:&#xA;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/3/latex-math-support&quot;&gt;[1]&lt;/a&gt;&#xA;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/195/cant-see-formulas&quot;&gt;[2]&lt;/a&gt;&#xA;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/25/material-to-supplement-the-faq/244#244&quot;&gt;[3]&lt;/a&gt;&#xA;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/258/math-processing-error&quot;&gt;[4]&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="74" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.560" LastActivityDate="2010-12-15T13:47:10.833" CommentCount="1" CommunityOwnedDate="2010-09-03T20:27:19.807" />
./Posts.xml:228:  <row Id="238" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="225" CreationDate="2010-09-03T20:33:33.660" Score="4" Body="&lt;h2&gt;Questions about Theorem X in paper Y?&lt;/h2&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;It is perfectly fine to ask very specific questions like this:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;How does one reach eq 3.14 from eq 3.13 in paper X, page Y? I tried the following ... but it didn't work.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;However, if you suspect that there is a &lt;em&gt;mistake&lt;/em&gt; in a paper, it might be polite to first contact the authors by email before posting a question here.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;hr&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Related discussion:&#xA;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/204/are-specific-questions-about-theorem-x-in-paper-y-fine&quot;&gt;[1]&lt;/a&gt;&#xA;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/214/should-there-be-a-protocol-to-notify-authors-if-we-find-an-error-in-a-paper&quot;&gt;[2]&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="74" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" LastActivityDate="2010-09-07T06:18:12.030" CommentCount="0" CommunityOwnedDate="2010-09-03T20:33:33.660" />
./Posts.xml:229:  <row Id="239" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="225" CreationDate="2010-09-03T20:41:58.067" Score="6" Body="&lt;h2&gt;When to use &quot;community wiki&quot;?&lt;/h2&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The &quot;community wiki&quot; (CW) flag should be reserved for questions where either (i) you do not believe that there exists one (or even a few) good answers, and where &lt;strong&gt;any individual response contributes a small enough piece of the overall answer that no reputation increase is warranted&lt;/strong&gt;, or (ii) you want to encourage other users to edit your answer or question, perhaps if you realise there are gaps in your answers that you would like other users to fill in.  &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;CW is irreversible. When in doubt, do not mark a question CW – this can always be changed later.  A crucial technical point: any answers made to a CW question will themselves be CW.   &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Often, a question that seems like it should be CW can be modified to be more direct and focused, thus avoiding the need for the tag. For example, the seemingly CW question &quot;What are the key papers in topic X&quot; can often be reworded as the more focused &quot;What I should start reading when studying topic X&quot;. The latter has one or a few definite answers and need not be made CW.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If a question or answer is CW, there is something of an invitation to edit it: the reasons for editing are broader for CW posts than non-CW posts.  &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;hr&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Related discussion:&#xA;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/201/community-wikis&quot;&gt;[1]&lt;/a&gt;&#xA;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/34/community-wiki-etiquette&quot;&gt;[2]&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;hr&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h2&gt;When to mark an answer as &quot;community wiki&quot;?&lt;/h2&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Anyone can edit a CW (community wiki) answer and no one earns reputation for it.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;One good use of the CW flag is to aggregate multiple answers into a single one with uniform formatting. Another possible use of the CW flag is to invite others to fill in an incomplete answer. (Perhaps you only have time to sketch the idea, or perhaps you do not know the complete answer but have a strong hunch that your idea points in the right direction.)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;This answer is flagged CW for good reason: There's room for improvement.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="74" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.560" LastActivityDate="2011-02-09T14:20:16.573" CommentCount="2" CommunityOwnedDate="2010-09-03T20:41:58.067" />

This is important to make sure tags reflect the true content of the question, which makes searching and filtering easier. ./Posts.xml:240:  <row Id="251" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="248" CreationDate="2010-09-04T14:16:31.530" Score="2" Body="&lt;p&gt;Svrist,&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;It looks like your question &lt;em&gt;may&lt;/em&gt; fit here, but you want to take some time to formulate it appropriately before posting it. ./Posts.xml:242:  <row Id="253" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2010-09-04T16:57:05.070" Score="1" ViewCount="53" Body="&lt;p&gt;The question &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/942/in-strongly-connected-tournament-t-is-it-np-hard-to-find-a-minimum-number-of-vert&quot;&gt;In Strongly connected tournament T.Is it NP-hard to find a minimum number of vertices(V1) which make T\V1 as non strongly connected tournament.&lt;/a&gt; was retagged twice, from the original &quot;np&quot; to add tags &quot;graph-theory&quot; (which makes sense) and &quot;ds.data-structures&quot; (which doesn't, at least to me).  After checking the FAQ for MO about Community Wiki mode it seems retagging does not count to make a post into a community wiki, so I retagged it yet again.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;My retag removes one of the tags that was added in a previous retag.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;What should the etiquette be for retagging?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I would normally explain my decision to roll back or modify a previous edit.  However, retagging doesn't request an edit comment, so even access to version control tools would not help much here.  It would be nice not to have retag wars, but a meta question for every retag conflict seems too much overhead.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Moreover, if I remember correctly, some MO members were upset when Suresh retagged some old posts, causing them to be bumped onto the front page.  Is this reasonable?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="109" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" LastActivityDate="2010-09-04T16:57:05.070" Title="Retag etiquette?" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;feature-request&gt;" AnswerCount="0" CommentCount="7" />
./Posts.xml:255:  <row Id="268" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAnswerId="270" CreationDate="2010-09-06T17:20:35.553" Score="6" ViewCount="146" Body="&lt;p&gt;I have encountered the following situation several times on cstheory.StackExchange.com, math.StackExchange.com or MathOverflow.net.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;A new user asks a question.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Someone answers, or someone points out that something is unclear in the question.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;The questioner says “Thanks a lot” in a separate answer without accepting the answer, or makes a follow-up post as a new answer to the question without updating the question.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Why didn’t the questioner accept the answer or update the question?  The reason turned out to be that after the questioner posted the question using a cookie-based unregistered account, he/she lost the cookie for some reason.  I guess that he/she can use the &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/users/account-recovery&quot;&gt;recover the access to the account&lt;/a&gt; if he/she had provided an email address, but&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;he/she might not have provided an email address, or&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;he/she may not know that it is possible to recover the lost access to the account.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;(Admittedly I do not know how unregistered accounts and the account recovery functionality work, so I might be completely wrong about its functionality.)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;This made me think that it might be better to encourage people to register especially when &lt;em&gt;asking a question&lt;/em&gt;.  A line in FAQ or the Ask Question page will be fine.  To be perfectly clear, this question is &lt;em&gt;not&lt;/em&gt; about encouraging people to register when &lt;em&gt;posting an answer&lt;/em&gt;, with which the problem is less serious in my opinion.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;On the other hand, it must be a deliberate design that StackExchange allows posting questions and answers without registration.  Therefore, I am not completely sure if it is good to discourage people from asking a question without registering.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;This discussion only tries to address the problem for new users who are unfamiliar with the site but &lt;em&gt;careful enough to read instructions&lt;/em&gt;.  Trying to solve the problem for those who do not read instructions is out of scope of this discussion.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="567" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" LastActivityDate="2010-09-07T03:31:54.820" Title="Should we encourage a new user to register before he/she asks a question?" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;asking-questions&gt;&lt;user-accounts&gt;" AnswerCount="1" CommentCount="3" />
./Posts.xml:261:  <row Id="274" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2010-09-07T21:42:06.230" Score="12" ViewCount="4222" Body="&lt;p&gt;See &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1064/polynomial-time-algorithm-for-graph-isomorphism-testing&quot;&gt;this question&lt;/a&gt; in which someone asked for an update on the status of an arxiv preprint on graph isomorphism. It was downvoted, with a comment &quot;Are this kind of discussions on-topic here? I think there are too many claims of P = NP, P ≠ NP, etc. in ArXiv and elsewhere.&quot;, but my own feeling is that it's useful to have a place to publicly discuss whether it's worthwhile to pay any serious attention to certain controversial preprints.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I guess my question for here is, should this exchange be that place?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Update&lt;/strong&gt; (suresh): Please review and edit the proposed FAQ entry below, so we can add it to the FAQ and resolve this question.  &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="95" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" LastActivityDate="2014-06-19T16:10:44.560" Title="Is it ok to ask about the correctness of preprints on crank-friendly topics?" ./Posts.xml:266:  <row Id="279" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="274" CreationDate="2010-09-08T13:26:00.337" Score="5" Body="&lt;p&gt;I think the same thing happened here: &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/10/is-the-recent-proof-that-p-np-correct&quot;&gt;Is the recent proof that P != NP correct?&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;When a new result appears, many people try to email &quot;giants&quot; in the community, asking them what is their idea on the paper. Many of the researchers are tired of such situations.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I recently witnessed such event due to Deolalikar's paper (See Scott Aaronson's, Dick Lipton's, and others' blogs).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In a &lt;a href=&quot;http://scottaaronson.com/blog/?p=465&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;blog post&lt;/a&gt;, Aaronson considers this forum as &quot;the best thing ever to happen to his inbox,&quot; and offers the motto &quot;Exponentially better than emailing Scott Aaronson&quot; for TCS Stack Exchange.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Among other things, I think TCS SE must become the &quot;de facto&quot; place for discussing new results on theoretical computer science. Conferences and journals have their own review process, but why should this prevent us from discussing them here?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I believe Suresh's point is right: We must not embrace authors here, and we should give them enough right to defend their work. Yet, is it right to do so by not discussing any new result here??&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="873" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" LastActivityDate="2010-09-08T13:26:00.337" CommentCount="0" />
./Posts.xml:267:  <row Id="280" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="209" CreationDate="2010-09-08T15:15:21.317" Score="4" Body="&lt;p&gt;Now we've started having more HW level questions. See&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1083/using-decision-version-of-tsp-to-solve-optimization-version&quot;&gt;Using decision version of TSP to solve optimization version&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1067/is-it-possible-to-have-a-4-coloring-for-a-non-planar-graph&quot;&gt;Is it possible to have a 4-coloring for a non-planar graph ?&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;We need to have a policy for such questions.  &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I think we should stick with MO's policy and close such questions if they are basic. ./Posts.xml:268:  <row Id="281" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="274" CreationDate="2010-09-08T16:31:31.847" Score="13" Body="&lt;h3&gt;A proposed policy for questions on preprints.&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;(in the form of an FAQ.)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;There are good ways to ask about new seemingly exciting results in TCS, and there are bad ways. Below, we give a few examples of each: &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;BAD&lt;/strong&gt;: Have you read this new paper on the arXiv on (seminal problem in complexity)?&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;em&gt;Answer&lt;/em&gt;: Yes, we have. Please do not post this question on this site.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;BAD&lt;/strong&gt;: Is the new claimed proof of (seminal problem in complexity) correct?&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;em&gt;Answer&lt;/em&gt;: If it's at all credible, be assured that people are reading it and trying to determine that. In fact, why not read it yourself ! But don't post this question on this site. &lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;GOOD&lt;/strong&gt;: In this new preprint on the arXiv that claims to solve (seminal problem in TCS), the author refers to quantum range searching on squashed hypercubes. What is that?&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;em&gt;Answer&lt;/em&gt;: We can answer your question here.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;GOOD&lt;/strong&gt;: This new paper claiming a big result is beyond my ken to read. Before I invest the time to learn all this stuff and try to read it, I am curious: have there been any technical rebuttals or discussions of it?&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;em&gt;Answer&lt;/em&gt;: We can answer your question here. &lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;note&lt;/strong&gt;: Such cases are acceptable only if they are really &lt;em&gt;reference-requests&lt;/em&gt; (see &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/a/707&quot;&gt;Josh's answer&lt;/a&gt;). This item cannot be used if the real motivation of the OP is not reading the paper. Using this item to circumvent the general policy will not be permitted.&lt;br&gt;&#xA;Also this item doesn't apply if it is unlikely that there are such references, e.g.  &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;the time is too short for existence of such references,  &lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;reasonable time has passed but the author's claims is not considered credible, &#xA;e.g. the author is not considered an expert in the area and &#xA;the author's claims has not been taken seriously by experts in the area.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Note that if a claim about progress on a famous long standing open problem (like &quot;P vs. NP&quot;) is credible at all, there will be discussions about it online in a short time after its announcement (e.g. on theory blogs like &lt;a href=&quot;http://blog.computationalcomplexity.org/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;Computational Complexity&lt;/a&gt;, &lt;a href=&quot;http://rjlipton.wordpress.com/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;Gödel's Lost Letter and P=NP&lt;/a&gt;, etc.) and if there is not then it is a sign that the claim is not taken seriously by experts.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;hr&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;BAD&lt;/strong&gt;: This new unpublished papers on arXiv proposes a new algorithm and claims it can solve problem X way faster than the best known algorithms. I don't understand the paper and don't want to spend time reading it, can someone verify that the author's claim is correct?&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;em&gt;Answer&lt;/em&gt;: If it's at all credible, be assured that people are reading it and trying to determine that. If you can't check the correctness of the algorithm yourself, you should wait until it is &lt;a href=&quot;http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peer_review&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;peer-reviewed&lt;/a&gt; and &lt;a href=&quot;http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Published_research&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;published&lt;/a&gt;. The peer-review process does not take a very long time, if the paper hasn't been published after several years it is a strong sign that the paper has failed to pass the peer-review process and the author's claim is at least doubtful. Discussing the general correctness of papers which have not passed the peer-review process are off-topic for this site.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Good&lt;/strong&gt;: What is the fastest known algorithm for problem X?&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;em&gt;Answer&lt;/em&gt;: We can answer your question here.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;hr&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;In summary, focus your question on specific technical aspects of the work that you'd like clarification on. You can also try to rephrase your question in a way that avoids mentioning a specific unpublished work but will ask essentially what you want to know.&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Remember: if your question is closed as off-topic, you can still edit your question to address the issues stated for closing it, in which case it can be reopened.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="80" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" LastActivityDate="2014-06-19T16:10:44.560" CommentCount="2" CommunityOwnedDate="2010-09-08T16:31:42.657" />
./Posts.xml:271:  <row Id="284" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="164" CreationDate="2010-09-09T16:36:03.343" Score="3" Body="&lt;p&gt;I think we need to have some policy on this type of thing. Or some way to strongly discourage badly phrased questions. For example, see this thread:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/778/complexity-of-a-variant-of-the-mandelbrot-set-decision-problem&quot;&gt;Complexity of a variant of the Mandelbrot set decision problem?&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If you count all the comments, it took almost 30 comments to get a meaningful question out, and even then it seems like the OP keeps changing the question from iteration to iteration, much to the frustration of people posting answers. I'm not a subject area expert, but the frustration with this user's phrasing in this particular question is evident in that thread.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I've also noticed that this user's questions only start making sense after:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Several rounds of interrogation.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Suresh edits and fixes the question making it comprehensible (thanks for that, Suresh!) &lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Can we remedy this situation somehow?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="206" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" LastActivityDate="2010-09-09T16:36:03.343" CommentCount="7" />
./Posts.xml:274:  <row Id="287" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2010-09-10T09:15:44.430" Score="1" ViewCount="122" Body="&lt;p&gt;While writing this &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1135/whats-the-best-way-to-count-numbers-in-a-set-that-are-below-a-given-threshold&quot;&gt;question about range counting&lt;/a&gt; I was warned by the site that it is likely subjective and will be closed.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Do you think it is subjective?&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;2.1. ./Posts.xml:282:  <row Id="297" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2010-09-13T10:34:02.457" Score="0" ViewCount="201" Body="&lt;p&gt;A problem in answering questions arises when several people try to independently answer a question, and in the middle (or the end) one understands the situation.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The case happened to me, and several other people (See Ryan Williams' comment to Robin Kothari in &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1233/semantic-vs-syntactic-complexity-classes&quot;&gt;this post&lt;/a&gt;).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I suggest adding a &quot;Claim&quot; mechanism, which works as follows:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Upon deciding to answer a question, on clicks some &quot;Claim&quot; button.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;The word &quot;Cliam&quot;, the name of the user who claimed the answer, and several other useful information appears beside the question for some predetermined time (say 20 mins), or until the claimer presses the &quot;Post the answer&quot; button (whichever happens first).&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Everyone else who sees the &quot;claim&quot; notice can decide to wait, or ignorantly answer (based on personal tastes, claimer info, remaining time of the claim, etc.)&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="873" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" LastActivityDate="2010-09-13T23:37:15.597" Title="&quot;Claiming&quot; the Answer" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;" AnswerCount="2" CommentCount="1" ClosedDate="2010-09-14T00:03:52.977" />
./Posts.xml:285:  <row Id="300" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2010-09-13T16:04:45.837" Score="20" ViewCount="1854" Body="&lt;p&gt;The moderators spend considerable time on editing badly written questions. A possible way for reducing the number of badly written questions is writing down some guidelines (similar to the MO &lt;a href=&quot;https://mathoverflow.net/howtoask&quot;&gt;guidelines&lt;/a&gt;) on how to ask/write a good question, and possibly add a link to it on the top of the &quot;ask question&quot; page.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;This thread is for discussing related issues, specially what should be included in our guidelines?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;hr&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Related: &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/q/295/186&quot;&gt;Policy on editing questions ?&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="186" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:57:54.527" LastActivityDate="2015-11-23T05:52:04.290" Title="How to ask a good question" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;faq&gt;&lt;asking-questions&gt;" AnswerCount="15" CommentCount="9" FavoriteCount="9" CommunityOwnedDate="2010-09-14T20:37:57.590" />
./Posts.xml:292:  <row Id="307" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="300" CreationDate="2010-09-14T01:34:20.550" Score="15" Body="&lt;h3&gt;Understand what you really want to ask&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;This may sound odd but, even if you know that you want to ask something, it is sometimes difficult to pin down exactly &lt;em&gt;what you really want to ask&lt;/em&gt;.  It is a good idea to make some effort to identify the exact question you want to ask before actually posting a question.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;For example, many people incorrectly ask “Is there an algorithm which computes X?” when what they really want to know is “Is there a polynomial-time algorithm which computes X?” or even “X can be computed in time O(&lt;i&gt;n&lt;/i&gt;&lt;sup&gt;3&lt;/sup&gt;) in a straightforward way.  Is there a faster algorithm?”&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Knowing the precise question makes it easier to write a clear and easy-to-understand question, which hopefully makes more people interested in your question.  Also, by the time you know the question well enough so that you can state the question clearly, you can sometimes find out the answer by yourself!&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Related guidelines:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Why should you make any effort to ask a question in the first place?  See &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/300/how-to-ask-a-good-question/318#318&quot;&gt;this guideline&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Asking a precise question also allows one to tell what is an answer and what is not.  See &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/300/how-to-ask-a-good-question/323#323&quot;&gt;this guideline&lt;/a&gt; for more on this.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="567" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.560" LastActivityDate="2012-01-13T12:24:06.050" CommentCount="2" CommunityOwnedDate="2010-09-17T11:13:29.927" />
./Posts.xml:294:  <row Id="309" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="308" CreationDate="2010-09-14T03:09:41.663" Score="4" Body="&lt;p&gt;Editing an answer also bumps a question.  See &lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/11596/how-is-the-hot-active-question-algorithm-implemented/11601#11601&quot;&gt;this answer on meta.stackoverflow.com&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="567" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-20T10:29:37.593" LastActivityDate="2010-09-14T03:09:41.663" CommentCount="0" />
./Posts.xml:302:  <row Id="317" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="316" CreationDate="2010-09-15T08:04:10.900" Score="12" Body="&lt;p&gt;I'm not sure how a post-grad is different from an MS or Ph.D student, but I'd say that the questions being discussed here have a lower bound at advanced undergraduate/beginning grad student, and extend all the way up into active researchers at all levels. Many of the &quot;big-list&quot; questions are at the lower end of this range. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;While MO is definitely a strong influence on how we use the site, I think that we are likely to entertain certain kinds of broader questions, especially in the realm of applications. However, from a level point of view, we're probably similar. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I would hope that you wouldn't get scared away ! While the questions might seem out of reach, they do span a wide breadth of topics, on which few of us are experts, and so it's not surprising that many of the topics might appear inaccessible. There might be some crustiness towards ill-posed, unmotivated questions, but clear questions that aren't answerable by Google (&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/300/how-to-ask-a-good-question&quot;&gt;see this thread&lt;/a&gt; on how to ask questions) will (hopefully) get a fair shake, even if they might seem basic.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="80" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" LastActivityDate="2010-09-15T08:04:10.900" CommentCount="2" />
./Posts.xml:303:  <row Id="318" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="300" CreationDate="2010-09-15T14:26:09.377" Score="20" Body="&lt;h3&gt;Only ask what you care about&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;When stated explicitly, this may sound obvious.  Do not ask what &lt;em&gt;someone&lt;/em&gt; cares about, but ask what &lt;em&gt;you&lt;/em&gt; care about.  If &lt;em&gt;you&lt;/em&gt; do not care about a question, either no one really cares or those who care can ask a better question.  Posting a question which you do not care about is a waste of time for everyone who reads the question (and possibly tries to answer it).  Put differently: &lt;strong&gt;Do not ask a question for the sake of asking a question&lt;/strong&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;A corollary of this is: &lt;strong&gt;Try to answer by yourself before posting a question&lt;/strong&gt;.  If you really care about a question, the first thing to do should not be posting the question on a website, but trying to solve it by yourself.  This includes looking up literature, formulating it from different angles, considering small cases, special cases and/or variations, and so on; in short, what you normally do to solve a problem.  If you do not want to think about the question by yourself, ask yourself whether you really care about the question.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;This does not mean that you must not ask a question unless you have proved that you cannot answer it by yourself (which is obviously impossible).  However, make some reasonable effort to try to answer your own question before posting it.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Related guidelines:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Even if you care about the question, the reader may not know it.  Therefore, it is a good idea to include some evidences that you care about it in the question.  Doing so also helps the reader to understand the question better and hopefully results in better answers.  For more on this point, see &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/300/how-to-ask-a-good-question/304#304&quot;&gt;this guideline&lt;/a&gt; and &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/300/how-to-ask-a-good-question/306#306&quot;&gt;this guideline&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="567" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.560" LastActivityDate="2014-10-26T02:59:16.153" CommentCount="9" CommunityOwnedDate="2010-09-15T14:26:09.377" />
./Posts.xml:304:  <row Id="319" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="164" CreationDate="2010-09-15T15:26:01.900" Score="2" Body="&lt;p&gt;My answer to the question “Is asking a bunch of questions in a short period of time appropriate?” is &lt;em&gt;almost&lt;/em&gt; no, because it is &lt;em&gt;almost&lt;/em&gt; impossible to post many well-thought-out questions in a short period of time unless the questioner has kept a stock of well-thought-out questions which are ready for posting.  See &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/300/how-to-ask-a-good-question/318#318&quot;&gt;my answer to another question&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If the questions are well thought-out, I do not mind ten questions from one person in an hour.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="567" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" LastActivityDate="2010-09-15T15:35:00.613" CommentCount="0" />
./Posts.xml:306:  <row Id="321" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAnswerId="322" CreationDate="2010-09-15T15:57:58.983" Score="1" ViewCount="145" Body="&lt;p&gt;In &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1335/a-new-p-vs-np-poll-closed&quot;&gt;this question&lt;/a&gt; I wrote the following comment.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;I voted to close as I don't consider the question objectively answerable. I could imagine a version that would fit with the site, though. A community wiki like: &quot;Please post links to opinions of TCS experts about the P/NP problem.&quot; Maybe. for example, I've heard that Terence Tao considers P/NP to be a 500-year problem, but I've never seen a concrete reference. It seems sorta-kinda in the big-list category to me, and if someone tries to hijack by posting multiple links to a crank, the community will vote those answers down. ./Posts.xml:309:  <row Id="325" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAnswerId="326" CreationDate="2010-09-16T03:07:28.620" Score="0" ViewCount="208" Body="&lt;p&gt;According to the &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/faq&quot;&gt;FAQ of meta&lt;/a&gt;, users with 500 rep can “vote to close, reopen, or migrate any questions.”  Since my rep is below 500, I do not know what exactly means by “migrate” a question. ./Posts.xml:315:  <row Id="331" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAnswerId="336" CreationDate="2010-09-17T13:45:55.910" Score="4" ViewCount="633" Body="&lt;p&gt;This site supports LaTeX markup using MathJax.  In theory this is great, and it certainly helps in expressing oneself.  However, I have been seeing ongoing problems with MathJax.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Specifically, loading fonts often goes off into never-neverland, only to time out with &quot;Can't load Web-Font Math/TeX/Italic&quot; (and the same for ...Regular).  I have cleared the cache and followed the instructions at the MathJax site.  There it is suggested that this particular error might be due to Firefox refusing to load cached objects because of the way they have been configured on the server: &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.mathjax.org/resources/faqs/#image-fonts&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;I am referring to this FAQ entry&lt;/a&gt;, although my interpretation of this entry may be incorrect.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The frustrating thing is that MathML for MO worked really well once I had installed local fonts, while the MathJax experience has been terrible in comparison.  There is a related thread on the TeX site: &lt;a href=&quot;https://tex.stackexchange.com/questions/2692/comparing-mathjax-and-mathml&quot;&gt;https://tex.stackexchange.com/questions/2692/comparing-mathjax-and-mathml&lt;/a&gt; and a possibly relevant discussion about a bug found (and fixed) with MathJax a few weeks ago at &lt;a href=&quot;http://sourceforge.net/projects/mathjax/forums/forum/948700/topic/3816654&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;http://sourceforge.net/projects/mathjax/forums/forum/948700/topic/3816654&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Any suggestions?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;em&gt;Edit: as mentioned in a comment below, I managed to change the rendering from HTML CSS to MathML, and LaTeX now renders quickly and without weird font timeouts.&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="109" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:34:28.537" LastActivityDate="2013-07-08T11:23:50.880" Title="MathJax ongoing problems" Tags="&lt;support&gt;&lt;math&gt;" AnswerCount="1" CommentCount="6" FavoriteCount="1" />

./Posts.xml:325:  <row Id="341" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAnswerId="342" CreationDate="2010-09-19T22:23:15.430" Score="4" ViewCount="129" Body="&lt;p&gt;I just edited some tag wikis to explain what the tag was for. I did it for tags like pcp and qma where it may not be clear what the acronyms stand for. So for example, for QMA, I explained what it stands for and linked to the Wikipedia page. (&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/tags/qma/info&quot;&gt;See the tag wiki for QMA.&lt;/a&gt;)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I think it would be nice if tag wikis contained enough information to decide what the tag is about. For some tags this is obvious, for other like qma and approximation-hardness, one could just explain that they stand for Quantum Merlin Arthur and Hardness of Approximation respectively, and link to their Wikipedia page, or their page on the complexity zoo, etc.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Is there anything else people feel that tag wikis should contain? For example, StackOverflow's tag wikis are huge. &lt;a href=&quot;https://stackoverflow.com/tags/php/info&quot;&gt;See the tag wiki for PHP for example&lt;/a&gt;. At this stage of the site it seems unnecessary to have such long tag wikis.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;So this is my suggestion:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;A tag wiki should explain what the tag is for (when the tag name doesn't explain it well enough) and perhaps contain a reference (to a website or book) to explain what the concept is. Usually Wikipedia links should suffice for this purpose.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Suggestions? Comments? Also, if your reputation is not high enough, you can request tag wiki edits in this thread, and someone who has enough rep can make the changes.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="206" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-05-23T12:40:08.913" LastActivityDate="2010-09-22T13:24:52.417" Title="What should the tag wikis contain?" ./Posts.xml:330:  <row Id="346" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2010-09-20T07:48:19.410" Score="4" ViewCount="139" Body="&lt;p&gt;Now it should be ok to merge &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/distributed-systems&quot;&gt;distributed-systems&lt;/a&gt; -&gt; &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/dc.distributed-comp&quot;&gt;dc.distributed-comp&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;hr&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Edit:&lt;/strong&gt; This has got so far only 1 supporting vote, and according to &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/271/official-interim-procedure-for-doing-retagging&quot;&gt;our policy&lt;/a&gt;, the threshold is 4 votes before the moderators can act. ./Posts.xml:331:  <row Id="347" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAnswerId="348" CreationDate="2010-09-20T16:53:21.793" Score="1" ViewCount="157" Body="&lt;p&gt;When an answer becomes down-voted sufficiently to cause it to have a negative score, is it good practice for the author to remove the answer? ./Posts.xml:335:  <row Id="351" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="271" CreationDate="2010-09-21T00:10:27.363" Score="1" Body="&lt;p&gt;As explained in &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/340/retag-all-cs-xyz-abc-to-xyz-abc/345#345&quot;&gt;Suresh’s post&lt;/a&gt; to another discussion, some tag synonyms are created without their master tags being created.  However, I think that some reconsideration is desirable because creating a tag synonym whose master tag does not exist in the system seems to have caused two problems.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Some tag-related pages are Not Found.  See comments to &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/340/retag-all-cs-xyz-abc-to-xyz-abc/345#345&quot;&gt;Suresh’s post&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Users with rep less than 200 cannot tag his/her own question with either the older tag or the newer tag until some user with rep ≥200 uses the newer tag, even if the older tag is in use.  See a note and comments in a &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1527/confidentiality-of-partial-private-keys-in-certificateless-public-key-crypto&quot;&gt;question&lt;/a&gt; by Zack (but let’s avoid discussing about the issue on the question page).&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Judging from &lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/2779/could-the-tagging-system-be-enhanced-to-support-tag-synonyms&quot;&gt;how the feature of tag synonyms was requested&lt;/a&gt; on meta.stackoverflow.com, it seems to me that a tag synonym is supposed to be created when the master tag is already in use.  Therefore, it is understandable that the system behaves oddly if the master of a tag synonym has not been created.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="567" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" LastActivityDate="2010-09-21T01:26:29.497" CommentCount="4" />
./Posts.xml:339:  <row Id="355" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="352" CreationDate="2010-09-21T17:17:44.093" Score="20" Body="&lt;p&gt;This has come up on MO, and they actually have a nifty cite link for questions and answers. A question gets cited like this:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;@MISC {MO39428,&lt;br&gt;&#xA;      TITLE = {x-th moment method},&lt;br&gt;&#xA;      AUTHOR = {fkenter (mathoverflow.net/users/8894)},&lt;br&gt;&#xA;      HOWPUBLISHED = {MathOverflow},&lt;br&gt;&#xA;      NOTE = {URL: &lt;a href=&quot;https://mathoverflow.net/questions/39428&quot;&gt;https://mathoverflow.net/questions/39428&lt;/a&gt;&#xA;  (version: 2010-09-21)},&lt;br&gt;&#xA;      EPRINT = {&lt;a href=&quot;https://mathoverflow.net/questions/39428&quot;&gt;https://mathoverflow.net/questions/39428&lt;/a&gt;},&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;pre&gt;&lt;code&gt;URL = {https://mathoverflow.net/questions/39428},&#xA;&lt;/code&gt;&lt;/pre&gt;&#xA;  &#xA;  &lt;p&gt;}&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;and an answer gets cited like this: &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;@MISC {MO39450,&lt;br&gt;&#xA;      TITLE = {x-th moment method},&lt;br&gt;&#xA;      AUTHOR = {Mark Meckes (mathoverflow.net/users/1044)},&lt;br&gt;&#xA;      HOWPUBLISHED = {MathOverflow},&lt;br&gt;&#xA;      NOTE = {URL: &lt;a href=&quot;https://mathoverflow.net/questions/39450&quot;&gt;https://mathoverflow.net/questions/39450&lt;/a&gt;&#xA;  (version: 2010-09-21)},&lt;br&gt;&#xA;      EPRINT = {&lt;a href=&quot;https://mathoverflow.net/questions/39450&quot;&gt;https://mathoverflow.net/questions/39450&lt;/a&gt;},&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;pre&gt;&lt;code&gt;URL = {https://mathoverflow.net/questions/39450},&#xA;&lt;/code&gt;&lt;/pre&gt;&#xA;  &#xA;  &lt;p&gt;}&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I think that's a reasonable way to do it, so the site gets mentioned. This can be done even if the mention is an acknowledgement: we can say &quot;The authors thank so and So\cite{} for their comments leading to the proof of Lemma 2.1&quot;. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In other words, whether you choose to cite or acknowledge, the citation mechanism can be used, and I think that's appropriate. The difference between this and a coffee room discussion is that there's no permanent record of the latter to cite, and modulo linkrot, there's one here. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If you want to acknowledge multiple users, you can use their cstheory user page, or their actual page if it's linked there. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;What we also need is a way to keep track of such references if they appear. It's too soon now, but maybe if anyone sees one they can create a new CW question and start listing examples. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="80" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:57:54.527" LastActivityDate="2010-09-21T17:17:44.093" CommentCount="3" />
./Posts.xml:340:  <row Id="356" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2010-09-21T22:18:50.417" Score="3" ViewCount="332" Body="&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Update&lt;/strong&gt;: I gave up trying to convince other people to use “too localized” instead of “off topic” when closing too elementary questions.  It seems that most people disagree, and I started to feel that it is a waste of time to try to convince people otherwise.  For now, I still hesitate to vote for off topic (or to be listed as one of the people who closed the question as off topic) when I see too elementary a question, so probably I will not vote to close it.  Hopefully there are enough people to close it anyway.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;hr&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;When we vote to close a question, we choose the reason from several choices.  It seems that if a question is too elementary, it is often closed for the reason “off topic.”&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I understand that this choice of reason is based on the consensus about the expected level of questions on cstheory.stackexchange.com.  However, if a question is closed for the reason “off topic,” the following explanation is added to the question:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;closed as off topic by [Someone], [Someone], [Someone], [Someone], [Someone] [Date]&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;  &#xA;  &lt;p&gt;Questions on Theoretical Computer Science are expected to generally relate to Theoretical Computer Science, within the scope defined in the &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/faq&quot;&gt;faq&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I have trouble even parsing this sentence because of the tentative name of the website, but more importantly this does not mention the expected level of questions on cstheory.stackexchange.com.  It plainly states that the question is not related to the theoretical computer science, which is often false.  This gives the false impression that we take the theoretical computer science very narrowly.  I think that this is problematic.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;(&lt;em&gt;Added in revision 5&lt;/em&gt;: The link in the explanation quoted above links to the &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/faq&quot;&gt;built-in FAQ&lt;/a&gt;, not to the &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science&quot;&gt;FAQ on Meta&lt;/a&gt;.  The built-in FAQ is not clear about the expected level of questions, either, except that the sentence “Theoretical Computer Science - Stack Exchange is for theoretical computer scientists and researchers in related fields” may suggest that research-level questions are expected.  A clearer statement can be reached by the following chain of links: the explanation of “off topic” → &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/faq&quot;&gt;built-in FAQ&lt;/a&gt; → &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science&quot;&gt;FAQ on Meta&lt;/a&gt; → &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/235#235&quot;&gt;What kind of questions are too basic?&lt;/a&gt;  But I doubt that users can find this path unless they are already familiar with the website.)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;What should we do?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Here are a few suggestions:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;If the consensus is really that cstheory.stackexchange.com is for questions of at least certain level, the explanation of the reason “off topic” should be rewritten to reflect it.  Is this possible?&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;del&gt;On &lt;a href=&quot;https://mathoverflow.net/&quot;&gt;MathOverflow&lt;/a&gt;, too elementary questions are often closed for the reason “too localized.”  Obviously this is an abuse and &lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.mathoverflow.net/discussion/274/what-does-too-localized-mean-exactly/&quot;&gt;it certainly confuses some users&lt;/a&gt;, but it is possible to interpret it as “This question is so elementary that it is useful only for the asker,” and it is understandable (or at least less prone to misunderstanding).  How about adopting this convention, at least until the explanation of “off topic” is modified to a better description?&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Related:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;See a &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/235#235&quot;&gt;related FAQ entry&lt;/a&gt; and the links given there for discussions about what we mean by “too elementary.”&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;em&gt;Added in revision 4:&lt;/em&gt; Whereas the description of the close reason is not shown on the question page on MathOverflow, it is shown on cstheory.stackexchange.com, which may make abusing harder.  Here is the description of the close reason “too localized”:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;This question would only be relevant to a small geographic area, a specific moment in time, or an extraordinarily narrow situation that is not generally applicable to the worldwide audience of the internet.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The point of the suggestion 2 above is that it is at least possible to argue that too elementary questions fall into the third group (and possibly also the second group) of this description.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="567" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:57:54.527" LastActivityDate="2010-11-10T18:20:01.380" Title="The reason to close too elementary questions" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;close-reasons&gt;" AnswerCount="3" CommentCount="13" />
./Posts.xml:342:  <row Id="358" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAnswerId="359" CreationDate="2010-09-22T12:28:19.090" Score="2" ViewCount="329" Body="&lt;p&gt;Currently the question “&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1574/do-you-use-any-article-organizers&quot;&gt;Do you use any article organizers?&lt;/a&gt;” has three votes to close as off topic.  However, in my opinion, this question can be interesting to people working on theoretical computer science and is not off topic, although it is not a question &lt;em&gt;in&lt;/em&gt; TCS.  At least I am interested in what other people in TCS use.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;(As I wrote in a &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/333/protocol-for-accepting-answers-in-cw-and-list-type-questions/337#337&quot;&gt;post to another discussion&lt;/a&gt;, I am a little bit tired of big-list questions, and this question may be one of them, but that is a separate story.)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Also, if you are a theoretical computer scientist looking for good citation organization software, I can imagine a reason for you to want to ask for recommendations of other theoretical computer scientists rather than researchers in other fields; it can be expected that they have similar requirements to you.  In this sense, I can argue that the question is &lt;em&gt;about&lt;/em&gt; TCS, although admittedly the relation is not strong.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Is this question on topic or off topic?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;hr&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;em&gt;Added:&lt;/em&gt; The question has been closed as off topic.  If that is the consensus of people here, I am fine with that, even though it was a little surprising to me because I had an impression that most people were &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions?sort=votes&quot;&gt;happier with non-technical or broad questions than with technical, focused questions&lt;/a&gt;.  Honestly speaking, I personally prefer technical, focused questions than highly-voted soft or broad questions, so I guess that I should feel happy to see that this question has been closed as off topic rather than feeling sad.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="567" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" LastActivityDate="2010-12-03T18:26:40.333" Title="On topic or off topic: Do you use any article organizers?" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;scope&gt;&lt;closing&gt;" AnswerCount="3" CommentCount="1" />
./Posts.xml:344:  <row Id="360" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="341" CreationDate="2010-09-22T13:24:52.417" Score="0" Body="&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;Also, if your reputation is not high enough, you can request tag wiki edits in this thread, and someone who has enough rep can make the changes.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;It might be better to write something along the following to the &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/tags/lg.learning/info&quot;&gt;[lg.learning] tag wiki&lt;/a&gt;:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;The tag [lg.learning] refers to &lt;a href=&quot;http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Machine_learning&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;machine learning&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;to clarify that it does not refer to learning (studying) in general.  Although this should be immediate from the list of questions, I have seen at least &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1574/do-you-use-any-article-organizers&quot;&gt;one question&lt;/a&gt; which was originally tagged as [lg.learning] for no apparent reason and I suspect that the reason is that the asker was confused about what the tag means.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Of course, whether new users (especially those who do not check the list of questions) read the tag wiki or not is another matter, but writing one line will not hurt.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="567" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" LastActivityDate="2010-09-22T13:24:52.417" CommentCount="2" CommunityOwnedDate="2010-09-22T13:24:52.417" />
./Posts.xml:345:  <row Id="361" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="225" CreationDate="2010-09-22T18:13:41.980" Score="6" Body="&lt;h2&gt;My (wonderful!) question was closed! What do I do now?&lt;/h2&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;There are many reasons a particular question might be closed. Don't be discouraged if this happens to you!&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Many such questions have a lot of merit but are closed for reasons that may not have occurred to you. You should consider re-asking your question after reading the comments others leave and adjusting your presentation.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If, after reading through the rest of this FAQ, you have additional concerns about how to effectively formulate your question, post a new question on &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/&quot;&gt;meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com&lt;/a&gt; and link that question to the original source. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;hr&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Related discussion: &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/374/re-ask-vs-edit-reopen&quot;&gt;here&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="108" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.560" LastActivityDate="2010-09-24T07:23:58.973" CommentCount="0" CommunityOwnedDate="2010-09-22T18:13:41.980" />
./Posts.xml:347:  <row Id="363" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="343" CreationDate="2010-09-22T22:42:56.453" Score="4" Body="&lt;p&gt;There is a third tag called [&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/lg.learning&quot;&gt;lg.learning&lt;/a&gt;]. ./Posts.xml:349:  <row Id="365" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAnswerId="366" CreationDate="2010-09-23T02:14:11.670" Score="4" ViewCount="174" Body="&lt;p&gt;Just below every MO question appears the following line set off in a box:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;Remember to vote up questions/answers you find interesting or helpful (requires 15 reputation points)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;My question: Should we too have something along these lines, to nudge people into voting up questions/answers that they like? I feel that we should: the reminder helps one remember translate one's appreciation into a vote.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I was prompted to ask this question by the rather low proportion of votes scored by even the &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions?sort=votes&quot;&gt;most popular questions&lt;/a&gt; here. MO questions seem to score around &lt;a href=&quot;https://mathoverflow.net/questions?sort=votes&quot;&gt;twice as many votes&lt;/a&gt; for the same amount of popularity (~ views).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="148" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:57:54.527" LastActivityDate="2010-09-23T03:45:56.553" Title="Should we add an encouragement to vote à la MO ?" ./Posts.xml:352:  <row Id="368" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2010-09-23T08:26:42.253" Score="3" ViewCount="238" Body="&lt;p&gt;Lance Fortnow asked a question, &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1593/what-is-the-volume-of-information&quot;&gt;What is the Volume of Information?&lt;/a&gt;, which Ross Snider criticised on two grounds:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Off topic: &lt;em&gt;I downvoted because I don't find this question relevant to the site (despite how infinitely interesting it is). It really doesn't meet the qualifications in the FAQ so far as I can tell&lt;/em&gt;, and&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Not advanced as a TCS question: &lt;em&gt;the question (while legitimate and interesting) isn't really a TCS question (and so is not appropriate), and also doesn't meet the qualification here (&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/235#235&quot;&gt;meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/225/…&lt;/a&gt;)&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I'm generally of the opinion that the physical basis of computation is fundamental to computer science &amp;mdash;slogan: computer science is ultimately a physical science, one that involves a lot of formal science&amp;mdash; and is perfectly amenable to formal treatment.  Indeed, quantum computation could hardly be treated rigorously if that were not so.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I'm guessing that Ross' objection is not on those grounds, but rather he finds Lance's question to be the kind of question that has too much physics in it to be good for this site.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Are we worried about this?  Should we resist questions whose TCS to physics quotient gets too low?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;em&gt;Related: &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/17/scope-of-questions&quot;&gt;Scope of questions?&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="270" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" LastActivityDate="2010-09-23T17:53:55.960" Title="Scope: Can questions be too physical for us?" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;scope&gt;" AnswerCount="5" CommentCount="3" />
./Posts.xml:356:  <row Id="372" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="368" CreationDate="2010-09-23T14:35:00.453" Score="2" Body="&lt;p&gt;Honestly, I'm amazed that this question can be viewed as off-topic. It seems to me that cstheory is the perfect place to ask about whether some concept has an existing crisp formulation.  Previous questions in this vein have included asking about &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/668/is-there-a-complexity-theory-analogue-of-rices-theorem-in-computability-theory&quot;&gt;something in the spirit of Rice's theorem in complexity theory&lt;/a&gt; and &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/399/analogs-of-compressed-sensing&quot;&gt;my own question on analogs for compressed sensing&lt;/a&gt;.  Information theory is most definitely a part of theoretical computer science, and asking about whether the concept of volume, borrowed from physics, can be suitably formalized or not in an information theoretic sense is undeniably a valid one.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Moreover, while I'm all for being more strict about soft questions, I feel that being pedantic about the scope of technical questions is going to be a big turn-off to some people.  cstheory is not supposed to be an elite club or something.  It's the virtual equivalent to a coffee break in a conference.  And Fortnow's question would certainly make for interesting conversation there.  Also, the more types of questions we allow, the more people we bring in from different backgrounds, which only helps the cause of growing this site.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="15" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" LastActivityDate="2010-09-23T14:35:00.453" CommentCount="1" />
./Posts.xml:357:  <row Id="373" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="368" CreationDate="2010-09-23T17:53:55.960" Score="3" Body="&lt;p&gt;Because I (inadvertently) initiated this meta discussion I feel I ought to contribute an answer. I also feel the need to defend my position, and what I believe to be true about the relevance of Lance's question in context of this StackExchange.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I agree with Robin under the comments that the question is a good physics question. In fact, Lance's question starts with &quot;From a physics perspective...&quot;. The question is also phrased to include &quot;What is information?&quot; and &quot;What is volume?&quot; (this second question  standing on its own does not qualify in any way as being on-topic).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I am of course aware of the tenable connection between information theory and physics (in fact I mentioned this connection as one of my reasons for pursuing higher studies in TCS in my answer to &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1562/why-go-to-theoretical-computer-science-research&quot;&gt;this question&lt;/a&gt; posted before Lance's question). I hope this dispels to some degree the cargo-cult physics googling caricature of my comment that Charles Stewart presented here; Namely, I am familiar with the topic, but not so familiar that I would hazard to claim any sort of expertise - notice I have never tried to post an authoritative sounding answer to any related question. I hope my comment under Lance's question sounded exactly as handwave-y as it was: it was a motion that was supposed to communicate &quot;you should really talk to physicist because we are by no means the right community to define 'volume' or 'the amount of information in a physical system.'&quot;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;My main thesis would have two parts:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Lance's question, while having connections to TCS, doesn't not constitute a good TCS question. It is not refined enough, it has not been distilled enough, to qualify a good TCS answer. For example, it would be better if the question identified some problem with using bits of precision as a basis of information in a physical system, and asked how this might be resolved. Also that, if we were to admit the question as being relevant to TCS, we should reject it on the grounds that quick reference searches are enough to provide background material and links to better coverage.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;That the question got more upvotes than it deserved because of the name of the author of the question. This question rapidly gathered upvotes, and in fact is currently ranked higher than some very strong TCS questions (for example this one &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1257/properties-of-random-directed-graphs-with-fixed-out-degree&quot;&gt;here&lt;/a&gt;).&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I would like to point out that the answers to the question, from authors I respect and am sure have a great deal of domain knowledge, did &lt;em&gt;not&lt;/em&gt; amount to more than what can be found with a quick Google search.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerDisplayName="Ross Snider" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" LastActivityDate="2010-09-23T17:53:55.960" CommentCount="0" />
./Posts.xml:358:  <row Id="374" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2010-09-23T20:30:28.113" Score="7" ViewCount="100" Body="&lt;p&gt;A fairly typical case:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;A question is not clear enough in the first attempt.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;There is a lot of discussion in the comments. People ask for clarifications, the user answers questions, people suggest modifications to the question, people make guesses regarding what the question is really about, there are answers that are non-answers or answer the wrong question, the question is edited several times...&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;The question gets downvoted and finally closed.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;However, it seems that there is a genuine question that would be on-topic, if it was properly formulated.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Now what should the user do in these cases?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Post a new question (and add a link to the original, closed question).&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Edit the question and ask the moderators to reopen the question (or let people to vote to reopen).&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1588/variable-profit-knapsack-closed&quot;&gt;It seems&lt;/a&gt; that our moderators prefer the approach 2. But to me it isn't obvious that this is the best approach. Once the question gets reopened, it looks messy and off-putting; there may be dozens of confused comments, the edit history is long, and finding out what is still relevant isn't going to be easy.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I would think that the approach 1 would be better. We would get a &quot;clean start&quot;. An empty thread, with no comments and answers. In particular, those who didn't follow the previous discussion in the old thread would be much more likely to try to answer it.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Any other opinions? In particular, what are the benefits of the approach 2?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="74" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" LastActivityDate="2010-09-24T07:22:27.300" Title="Re-ask vs. edit + reopen" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;faq&gt;&lt;vote-to-close&gt;" AnswerCount="1" CommentCount="1" />
./Posts.xml:360:  <row Id="376" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="225" CreationDate="2010-09-24T01:09:50.183" Score="3" Body="&lt;h2&gt;How do I delete my own question/answer?&lt;/h2&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The conditions to delete a post is explained in detail on &lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/5221/what-can-cause-a-post-to-be-deleted-and-what-does-that-actually-mean/5222#5222&quot;&gt;meta.stackoverflow.com&lt;/a&gt;.  If you can delete your post, there is a link labeled “delete” below your post (on the same line as “link” and “flag.”)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If you have not registered, you cannot delete a post.  To delete your post in this case, &lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/42267/how-to-register-my-unregistered-account&quot;&gt;register first&lt;/a&gt; and then try to delete it.  If you still cannot, you may have an unregistered account which is not merged to your registered account.  In this case, ask moderators to merge your unregistered accounts into the registered one.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="567" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-20T10:29:37.593" LastActivityDate="2010-09-24T01:09:50.183" CommentCount="0" CommunityOwnedDate="2010-09-24T01:09:50.183" />
./Posts.xml:361:  <row Id="377" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2010-09-24T06:28:28.840" Score="8" ViewCount="140" Body="&lt;p&gt;This is a follow up to &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/58/how-to-promote-the-site&quot;&gt;Shane's early question&lt;/a&gt; on site promotion. In one respect, things are going fairly well. Our traffic is steadily increasing: from an early number of around 2500 visits/day, we are now at 3200 visits/day. We also have nearly 1500 registered users (part of this is no doubt some reddit love we got for &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1539/whats-new-in-purely-functional-data-structures-since-okasaki&quot;&gt;a post on functional data structures&lt;/a&gt;).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;And yet, I think our numbers overestimate the true penetration of the site within the theoryCS community at large. Here's an experiment I did:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;Estimate the fraction of users with a&#xA;  reputation in the range $(1, 101) \cup&#xA;&amp;gt; [102, \infty)$, and compare this to the fraction of MO users in the range $(1, \infty)$&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The rationale for this is that merely signing up gets you a reputation score of 1, or 101 if you come in via the SE system. So that score doesn't reflect any actual involvement. MO on the other hand is an SE 1.0 site, and so they don't have the 101 bonus. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;While in one respect this is an unfair comparison, because MO has been around a lot longer, it's not entirely unfair because we're only comparing ratios here. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The results: &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;TCS: roughly 20%&lt;br&gt;&#xA;  MO: roughly 40%  &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;  &#xA;  &lt;p&gt;(I did a crude approximation by looking&#xA;  at number of &lt;em&gt;pages&lt;/em&gt; of users, because&#xA;  I have a life :))&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;It seems to me that this might suggest that our relatively large user numbers (relative to this stage in the beta) is an illusion, and so we need to work more at getting people in the community to participate. I know for a fact that many of my colleagues even in the narrow realm of computational geometry aren't here. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I don't have too many concrete ideas apart from some of the suggestions from the last post. But maybe it's a matter of doing more in-community - mentioning the site in talks, citing the site generously when appropriate, and encouraging co-workers and students to post questions (note that I'm not mentioning things like twitter which only touch a small fraction of the &lt;em&gt;theory&lt;/em&gt; community)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="80" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" LastActivityDate="2010-09-29T15:00:44.850" Title="Site Promotion: the next phase" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;7-essential&gt;&lt;site-promotion&gt;" AnswerCount="3" CommentCount="0" FavoriteCount="1" />

./Posts.xml:373:  <row Id="389" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAnswerId="393" CreationDate="2010-09-25T19:11:00.033" Score="5" ViewCount="310" Body="&lt;p&gt;This question came up while discussing &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/352/how-will-you-cite-a-discussion-on-this-site-in-your-paper&quot;&gt;this question&lt;/a&gt;. All the other SE sites I've seen follow this: SuperUser, StackExchange, ServerFault, etc. (Even MathOverflow)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I couldn't find the answer on any of the SE sites, does anyone know what will happen?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="206" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" LastActivityDate="2010-09-27T21:23:22.610" Title="Does our name and domain name have to be the same?"
