./Posts.xml:374:  <row Id="390" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="25" CreationDate="2010-09-25T19:20:26.090" Score="3" Body="&lt;p&gt;I would like to see the following entry in FAQ (in the “Best Practice” section):&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;My answer turned out to be incorrect.  What should I do?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;if there is a consensus about the answer.  Reasonable actions include:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Correct it.  (But sometimes it is better to delete it and repost a correct answer; see the link to Meta Stack Overflow below.)&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Leave it as it is after adding a clear notice that it is incorrect and why.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Delete it.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Such an FAQ entry should cover both the case where a flaw is found by the answerer him/herself and the case where a flaw is pointed out by someone else and the answerer is convinced (because I do not think there is much difference between them).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Related discussions:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/386/policy-on-deleting-incorrect-answers&quot;&gt;Policy on deleting incorrect answers?&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/22630/should-i-remove-a-wrong-answer-peer-pressure&quot;&gt;Should I remove a wrong answer (Peer Pressure)?&lt;/a&gt; on Meta Stack Overflow (but I do not think that everything written there applies to us in the same way)&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;(There is another discussion about &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/50/deleting-your-own-question&quot;&gt;deleting your own &lt;em&gt;question&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/a&gt;, but it is not much related.)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="567" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-20T10:29:37.593" LastActivityDate="2010-09-25T19:20:26.090" CommentCount="2" CommunityOwnedDate="2010-09-25T19:20:26.090" />
./Posts.xml:377:  <row Id="393" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="389" CreationDate="2010-09-26T00:49:24.213" Score="3" Body="&lt;p&gt;&lt;em&gt;Edit: I rewrote this answer significantly in revision 3 to simplify the reasoning, although the conclusion is the same.&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I do not know whether the website name and the domain name of a Stack Exchange website &lt;em&gt;have to&lt;/em&gt; be the same or not.  I agree to Suresh that you should ask on Meta Stack Overflow if you want to know that.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;However, in our case, the website name should be “cstheory.org,” that is, exactly the same as the domain name.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/1/what-should-our-site-domain-name-be&quot;&gt;poll&lt;/a&gt; to decide the site name and the domain name was already closed, and the decision was cstheory.org.  Although most proposals, including the chosen one, only stated a domain name and did not state a website name explicitly, it should be understood that the website name was going to be the same as the domain name up to minor modifications (such as removing the top-level domain or breaking into more than one word).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I prefer “cstheory.org” to “cstheory” or “CS Theory” as the website name for a reason which &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/389/does-our-name-and-domain-name-have-to-be-the-same/391#391&quot;&gt;Jukka already stated&lt;/a&gt;: when pronounced, “C-S-theory” does not identify us.  (In fact, &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/1/what-should-our-site-domain-name-be/100#100&quot;&gt;I stated this during the poll as a comment&lt;/a&gt;, too.)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="567" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" LastActivityDate="2010-09-27T00:18:03.770" CommentCount="0" />
./Posts.xml:380:  <row Id="396" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2010-09-27T05:21:24.227" Score="7" ViewCount="187" Body="&lt;p&gt;Someone recently asked a question about &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1700/what-are-the-essential-papers-that-i-should-read-to-get-started-with-pattern-rec&quot;&gt;references for work in pattern recognition with fuzzy logic&lt;/a&gt;. Leaving aside the issue of topical scope, here's the (harsh) comment I wrote:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;I apologize if this sounds rude, but&#xA;  it's not really our job to help you do&#xA;  a literature search, especially since&#xA;  you haven't provided any evidence of&#xA;  prior efforts in this regard. What&#xA;  you're asking us to help with is the&#xA;  kind of thing you should learn to be&#xA;  doing: navigating an area, finding out&#xA;  what's important (not what's hot!),&#xA;  and so on. If, after doing so, you&#xA;  have a specific question, then that&#xA;  might be more appropriate.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;This might be my own impatience, but I'm beginning to see more questions of the form of &quot;tell me what what's known about area X, or what's the latest in area Y, and so on&quot;, without any evidence that the OP has done some research, and has genuinely hit a brick wall of the form &quot;This specific question appears to be very natural, but I can't find anything on it&quot;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I want to encourage people to ask SPECIFIC questions and not go on fishing trips and expect the community to help out - I'm not a Google replacement. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Am I being too harsh ? &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="80" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" LastActivityDate="2010-09-27T14:25:22.087" Title="Reference requests and the like" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;scope&gt;" AnswerCount="4" CommentCount="0" />
./Posts.xml:382:  <row Id="398" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="396" CreationDate="2010-09-27T10:06:15.070" Score="5" Body="&lt;p&gt;I think that this is an important discussion to decide in which direction our website should go, so thank you for raising this issue.  I do not have an answer, but here is what I thought about this specific question.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;On one hand, I agree with you that the asker was just asking for a broad literature search to get accustomed to a field, and the asker has not shown the evidence that he/she has tried.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;On the other hand, I see some inconsistency when I compare this question to &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/710/quantum-computing-project-ideas&quot;&gt;the question asking for ideas of graduation projects about quantum computing&lt;/a&gt;, which has been perceived positively.  One is about the literature search and the other is about project proposals, but this difference does not seem important (if anything, asking for the literature is &lt;em&gt;more specific&lt;/em&gt;).  Note that the question about quantum computing projects does not show any evidence of prior efforts, either.  Moreover, I feel that the topic “applications of the fuzzy logic to pattern recognition” is more specific than “quantum computing” (I may be biased here; quantum computing is my field of research, and I am not familiar with either the fuzzy logic or pattern recognition).  I have a difficulty justifying the difference of people’s responses.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;em&gt;Added&lt;/em&gt;:  Just to make sure, the question on quantum computing projects I am talking about is &lt;em&gt;not&lt;/em&gt; the same as a &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1715/long-term-project-on-quantum-computing&quot;&gt;more recent question about how to write a research proposal on applications of evolutionary algorithms to quantum computing&lt;/a&gt;.  The latter seems to be of a different nature (therefore I will not talk here about whether it is appropriate or not).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="567" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" LastActivityDate="2010-09-27T14:25:22.087" CommentCount="3" />
./Posts.xml:386:  <row Id="402" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2010-09-27T19:45:27.577" Score="1" ViewCount="178" Body="&lt;p&gt;What should our website look like? ./Posts.xml:387:  <row Id="403" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="225" CreationDate="2010-09-27T23:02:31.717" Score="6" Body="&lt;h2&gt;My answer turned out to be incorrect.  What should I do?&lt;/h2&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;There is no perfect rule telling you what to do in such cases.  Here are some of the options:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Edit it to a correct answer.  In this case, leaving a comment to the answer explaining the edit might be also a good idea.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Leave it as it is after adding a clear notice that it is incorrect and an explanation of why at the beginning of the answer.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Delete it.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The consensus seems to be that leaving only a comment about incorrectness is not sufficient because readers will not notice it until they read the comments.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;An incorrect answer clearly marked as such is often informative because it shows an incorrect approach which other people may think is correct.  Therefore, some people consider that we should not delete an answer just because it is incorrect.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Related discussions: &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/386/policy-on-deleting-incorrect-answers&quot;&gt;[1]&lt;/a&gt; &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/25/material-to-supplement-the-faq/390#390&quot;&gt;[2]&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="567" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" LastActivityDate="2010-09-27T23:02:31.717" CommentCount="0" CommunityOwnedDate="2010-09-27T23:02:31.717" />
./Posts.xml:388:  <row Id="404" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAnswerId="420" CreationDate="2010-09-27T23:37:41.410" Score="9" ViewCount="311" Body="&lt;p&gt;The (domain) name is very important to the success of this site and a strong, witty one can sometimes be that extra hook to grab a new user, while a weak, boring one can put people off, alienate them, or, worse, make others disdainful of the community. That is why we need to put our brains together and take the time to come up with something really striking!&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;However, for reasons that I do not understand, the &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/1/what-should-our-site-domain-name-be&quot;&gt;official race for the site name&lt;/a&gt; was given only four weeks. (If someone can point out where I can find the decision to make September 10th the deadline, please comment.) Then, although there were some small mutterings about a runoff poll (partly due to a number of negative comments against the declared winner), Suresh recently closed the debate by locking the poll. Robin Kothari (and JeffE with a &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/389/does-our-name-and-domain-name-have-to-be-the-same/392#392&quot;&gt;clever new proposal&lt;/a&gt;) reopened the discussion a tiny bit &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/389/does-our-name-and-domain-name-have-to-be-the-same&quot;&gt;here&lt;/a&gt;. Let me formally (propose to) open this again fully.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Full disclosure: I find the current choice extremely unappealing.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;For the &quot;yes&quot; and &quot;no&quot; answers, please &lt;strong&gt;do not downvote&lt;/strong&gt;! (Comments on the question and comments giving reasons for your vote are encouraged though.)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="233" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" LastActivityDate="2010-09-29T21:26:24.217" Title="Should we re-open the debate on the name of the site?" ./Posts.xml:389:  <row Id="405" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="404" CreationDate="2010-09-27T23:40:26.273" Score="10" Body="&lt;h1&gt;Yes, definitely.&lt;/h1&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Edit: I gave my own justification in the question, and I also discussed it &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/389/does-our-name-and-domain-name-have-to-be-the-same/401#401&quot;&gt;elsewhere&lt;/a&gt;, but since Tsuyoshi commented in his answer, I should give a synopsis here too:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;There didn't seem to be an outright&#xA;winner in the original poll.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;More time should have been given to&#xA;the name selection process.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;The naming process should have been&#xA;discussed more openly.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;The site is still new, growing and&#xA;we have no imperative to lock in our&#xA;choice right away.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Least important of all, but still worth mentioning, in my opinion there are &lt;em&gt;several reasons&lt;/em&gt; why the current choice is &lt;em&gt;horrible&lt;/em&gt; and some of these are mentioned in the &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/1/what-should-our-site-domain-name-be/100#100&quot;&gt;respective comments thread&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="233" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" LastActivityDate="2010-09-28T09:09:35.367" CommentCount="4" />
./Posts.xml:390:  <row Id="406" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="404" CreationDate="2010-09-28T00:45:48.717" Score="4" Body="&lt;p&gt;It is painful to say this to you because I think that &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/1/what-should-our-site-domain-name-be/259#259&quot;&gt;your proposal&lt;/a&gt; was the best, but my answer is: no, we shouldn’t.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;First, I do not know if changing the decision is realistic.  I guess that Suresh already told the decision to Stack Overflow, and I do not know if it is possible or desirable to take it back.  (&lt;em&gt;Added&lt;/em&gt;: The domain name CSTheory.org was registered by Stack Overflow on August 26.  &lt;del&gt;While I am sure that they can afford some number of unused domain names, I do not know if it is the right thing to ask them to buy another; it sounds irresponsible to me.&lt;/del&gt;)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Second, I am afraid that canceling the concluded poll sets a bad example.  This poll was done according to a procedure.  If this poll was canceled, polls in the future will not look serious any more.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Third, while a name is important and a good name adds value to the website, I do not think that it is critical for the success of the website.  What is critical is, needless to say, good content and good community.  We should be done with the debate on website name and domain name.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;(More on the third point: Honestly speaking, I think that the name MathOverflow is far from a good name.  It only makes sense to those who know Stack Overflow, and the relation to TeX no longer makes sense because questions about TeX are no longer allowed there (in other words, they chose a name based on an element which was only tangentially related to the topic of the website).  However, as long as the content is good, these negative facts do not matter, at least to me.)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;It must have been surprising to some people that the name “CSTheory.org” was supported by most people.  It was surprising to me at least.  Please accept this surprising fact.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="567" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" LastActivityDate="2010-09-28T15:50:19.207" CommentCount="8" />
./Posts.xml:394:  <row Id="410" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="408" CreationDate="2010-09-28T11:45:24.533" Score="2" Body="&lt;p&gt;I recall reading answers from &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/users/1483/alan-turing&quot;&gt;Alan Turing&lt;/a&gt;. I'm sure he has published in neither STOC nor FOCS, but should nonetheless be given a boost in reputation. But what if it is not the real Alan Turing? Any why should someone's publication record determine their reputation, anyway? And &#xA;why stop at STOC and FOCS? What about POPL? Or TCS? And who decides anyway? &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The reputation systems avoids having to centralise reputation assignment, which avoids the need for subjective judgement. The reputation system is fair, based purely on participation. Finally, the reputation system avoids problems with someone posing as a famous researcher. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="77" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" LastActivityDate="2010-09-28T11:45:24.533" CommentCount="7" />
./Posts.xml:395:  <row Id="411" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2010-09-28T11:48:22.163" Score="1" ViewCount="601" Body="&lt;p&gt;This question is partly for fun, but partly serious.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;As a fictional example, suppose that someone asks a question like the following (the motivation part omitted for simplicity):&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;I would like to make pumpkin fries which are crispy on the outside and soft on the inside.  What is an algorithm for that?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;  &#xA;  &lt;p&gt;Tag: [ds.algorithms]&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;(This question is based on a &lt;a href=&quot;https://cooking.stackexchange.com/questions/5036/how-to-make-pumpkin-fries&quot;&gt;real question on Food and Cooking Stack Exchange&lt;/a&gt;.  By the way, from my personal experience, I strongly discourage you to visit &lt;em&gt;that&lt;/em&gt; website when you are hungry.)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;It is outright off-topic on our website, right?  After all, it is a question about cooking, not in the theoretical computer science.  But this question is clearly asking for an algorithm.  Although its goal is not to compute any mathematical objects and it is usually called a recipe, these do not mean that it is not an algorithm.  “It cannot be implemented on computers or Turing machines” does not sound like a good reason that it is not an algorithm, either.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;“Well,” you might say, “even if the question is about algorithms, it is too vague for a question in the theoretical computer science.  How do you define ‘pumpkin fries,’ ‘crispy’ and ‘soft’?  Oh, and you speak of the outside and inside.  Do you mean that pumpkin fries lie in a topological space?”&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;However, if we think this way, it starts to sound as if we should close it as “not a real question” or “subjective and argumentative,” not as off topic.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I am still pretty sure that the question &lt;em&gt;is&lt;/em&gt; off topic, but I find it more difficult than I thought to define when a question is about algorithms, especially because I believe that it is correct to say that a cooking recipe is an algorithm.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Question&lt;/strong&gt;.  What are the criteria to call some question “a question about algorithms,” and are questions asking for cooking recipes “about algorithms” according to your criteria?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;What made me think about this is &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1697/does-analog-sound-have-something-that-digital-does-not-closed&quot;&gt;the recent question asking how to verify someone’s claim that analog sound is better than digital sound&lt;/a&gt;.  I removed the [ds.algorithms] tag from it and voted to close it as off topic, and it soon got closed.  But I have just realized that the question &lt;em&gt;was&lt;/em&gt; asking for an algorithm.  Now I wonder how to justify the claim that this question is off topic.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="567" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:33:37.637" LastActivityDate="2010-10-08T06:35:32.557" Title="Is asking for a cooking recipe “a question about algorithms”?" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;scope&gt;" AnswerCount="2" CommentCount="2" />
./Posts.xml:397:  <row Id="413" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="408" CreationDate="2010-09-28T12:08:13.537" Score="7" Body="&lt;p&gt;I oppose to your proposal.  Paraphrasing an &lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/752/upvoting-based-on-celebrity-too-many-upvotes-excessive-rep-slurping/757#757&quot;&gt;answer&lt;/a&gt; to a related question on Meta Stack Overflow:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;Your cstheory.stackexchange.com reputation is a measurement of how much the system trusts you.  It is not, nor was it ever intended as, a measurement of how good a theoretical computer scientist you are.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If you are expected to be already familiar with the system, you get automatic 100 reputation points.  If not, you do not.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;em&gt;Added&lt;/em&gt;: Honestly speaking, if some people were frustrated enough by inability to comment or other small things for the first week to quit the website, I guess that they would be frustrated for many other things and would not stay at the website anyway, and giving them 100,000 reputation points would solve little.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="567" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-20T10:29:37.593" LastActivityDate="2010-09-28T14:35:41.740" CommentCount="1" />
./Posts.xml:401:  <row Id="417" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="402" CreationDate="2010-09-28T15:23:08.877" Score="1" Body="&lt;p&gt;The design of the final website is part of the process set by the StackExchange team. Once this site passes the 80 day mark or so of the public beta period, &lt;a href=&quot;http://blog.stackoverflow.com/2010/07/our-designer-in-residence-jin-yang/&quot;&gt;Jin Yang&lt;/a&gt;, the official designer for the Area 51 sites, will post his ideas for a design (including screenshots) and start talking to the community about them.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;You can see some example of prototype designs already published by Jin for a few of the more mature beta sites:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://webapps.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/559/design-ideas-for-web-applications-site-updated-with-screenshots&quot;&gt;Web Applications&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://gaming.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/982/design-ideas-for-gaming-site-updated-with-screenshots-v2&quot;&gt;Gaming&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cooking.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/783/design-ideas-for-cooking-site&quot;&gt;Cooking&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="404" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:43:53.187" LastActivityDate="2010-09-28T15:23:08.877" CommentCount="1" />
./Posts.xml:406:  <row Id="422" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAnswerId="423" CreationDate="2010-09-30T00:12:48.213" Score="2" ViewCount="123" Body="&lt;p&gt;This is another take to &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/268/should-we-encourage-a-new-user-to-register-before-he-she-asks-a-question&quot;&gt;the problem that a new user asks a question without registering and loses the cookie&lt;/a&gt;.  In the discussion I linked to, I wanted to prevent this situation from happening, but I became unsure that it was at all possible to prevent it.  Therefore, I would like to know what should be done when this happens.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;To take a concrete example, I realized that in &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1785/definition-of-a-monotone-machine&quot;&gt;this question&lt;/a&gt;, the asker replied to a comment by posting an &lt;em&gt;answer&lt;/em&gt;, which is a typical symptom of multiple accounts.  I quickly verified that although the asker and the user who replied had the same user name and the same icon, they were different accounts.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;What should I do in a case like this?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Flag it for a moderator attention by myself explaining the situation.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Ask the user to do this.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Ask the user to open a thread on meta.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Something else.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Also, should I ask the user to register?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Note:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;I cannot verify that the two accounts really belong to the same person.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;It seems that only moderators can merge two accounts.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="567" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" LastActivityDate="2010-09-30T07:02:11.800" Title="What should we do if we noticed someone having the multiple-account problem?" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;user-accounts&gt;" AnswerCount="1" CommentCount="0" />
./Posts.xml:408:  <row Id="424" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="225" CreationDate="2010-09-30T10:54:42.217" Score="4" Body="&lt;h2&gt;Why can't I comment on my own question?&lt;/h2&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Ideally, you should always be able to comment on your own question.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If you cannot find a link labeled “add comment” below your own question, you may be using a different account from the one you used to post the question. Note that &lt;em&gt;using the same user name and the same icon does not mean that you are using the same account&lt;/em&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If this happens, ask the moderators to merge the two accounts by flagging the question and state the situation briefly in the flagging comment.  Alternatively, you can open a thread on &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/&quot;&gt;meta&lt;/a&gt; to explain the situation.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;To prevent this from happening in the future, we strongly encourage you to register your account.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Related discussion: &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/422/what-should-we-do-if-we-noticed-someone-having-the-multiple-account-problem&quot;&gt;[1]&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="567" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.560" LastActivityDate="2012-06-12T02:30:34.743" CommentCount="2" CommunityOwnedDate="2010-09-30T10:54:42.217" />
./Posts.xml:409:  <row Id="425" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAnswerId="429" CreationDate="2010-09-30T12:03:32.207" Score="4" ViewCount="241" Body="&lt;p&gt;I would have voted to close the following question as out of scope if it didn't have 3 votes already.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1807/how-to-define-a-function-inductively-on-two-arguments-in-coq&quot;&gt;How to define a function inductively on two arguments in Coq?&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;It is similar to asking how to write a function in a programming language like C++, or getting help about a compilation error. I think it is clearly out of scope for cstheory, as it is not a research level question in theoretical computer science, also it is too narrow.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;ps:&#xA;Almost the same considerations apply to the following question:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/846/eliminating-cofix-in-coq-proof/872&quot;&gt;Eliminating cofix in Coq proof&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="186" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" LastActivityDate="2010-09-30T17:00:16.760" Title="Questions about compilation errors in Coq" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;scope&gt;" AnswerCount="4" CommentCount="6" FavoriteCount="1" />
./Posts.xml:411:  <row Id="427" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="425" CreationDate="2010-09-30T14:21:09.057" Score="1" Body="&lt;p&gt;In his &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/425/questions-about-compilation-errors-in-coq/426#426&quot;&gt;answer&lt;/a&gt;, supercooldave mentions “the exact nature of the question,” which I think is the very issue.  The problem is: Is the exact nature of these questions “the theory of proof assistants and/or programming languages” or just “programming”?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;If they are about the theory of proof assistants and/or programming languages and using Coq merely for concreteness, they are fine.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;If they are about programming in Coq, they are off topic.  The askers may want to ask them on Stack Overflow, considering there are several &lt;a href=&quot;https://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/coq&quot;&gt;questions on Coq on Stack Overflow&lt;/a&gt; and they get some answers, although I do not know whether the answers are correct or not.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Honestly speaking, the more I think about it, the more the questions seem like programming questions.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="567" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-05-23T11:33:34.517" LastActivityDate="2010-09-30T14:32:57.050" CommentCount="1" />

./Posts.xml:418:  <row Id="435" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2010-10-03T07:06:56.173" Score="10" ViewCount="266" Body="&lt;p&gt;It appears that all our handwringing over domain names might be moot. webapps.stackexchange.com was the first SE site to exit beta, and had chosen the domain nothingtoinstall.com (which I thought was clever). 3 days into graduation, and the SE overlords suddenly decided that this was such a horrible name that they are retracting their promise to give out separate domain names, and the new URL forwards back to webapps.stackexchange.com&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;There's a fairly bitter discussion going on in the &lt;a href=&quot;https://webapps.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/624/webapps-stackexchange-com-versus-nothingtoinstall-com&quot;&gt;NTI meta section&lt;/a&gt;, along with a &lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/66443/public-service-announcement-ongoing-offsite-discussion-about-area51-graduates&quot;&gt;parallel discussion on meta.SO&lt;/a&gt;. Bottom line:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;it's unlikely this decision will be changed&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Jeff Atwood claims that a site reaching &quot;&lt;a href=&quot;https://serverfault.com/&quot;&gt;ServerFault&lt;/a&gt;&quot; levels of traffic (38k views/day at least count) will get their own domain, else not&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;He also thinks all names in the SE family are terrible, except the cooking site. &lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;This is extremely inside baseball stuff, so I don't expect anyone to care greatly about it. ./Posts.xml:419:  <row Id="436" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="435" CreationDate="2010-10-03T15:14:26.983" Score="9" Body="&lt;p&gt;Thank you for sharing this information.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I feel disappointed to hear this. ./Posts.xml:421:  <row Id="439" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="25" CreationDate="2010-10-04T14:08:04.013" Score="1" Body="&lt;p&gt;I once posted the following FAQ entry and got two downvotes and no upvotes, so I moved it here to discuss what to do with it.  However, it has been made from &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/214/should-there-be-a-protocol-to-notify-authors-if-we-find-an-error-in-a-paper/254#254&quot;&gt;my post in another discussion&lt;/a&gt;, which has three upvotes and no downvotes at this moment, and I do not know how to interpret this discrepancy. What should I do with this entry?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;hr&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h2&gt;I might have found an error in a paper. Can I discuss it?&lt;/h2&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In general, it is considered wrong to discuss a possible error in a paper on a public forum before giving the author a chance to think about and correct it first. Before posting a question about a possible error, use your imagination to consider what the author may feel about the post.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Related to this, a question or a discussion may reveal an error of a paper in an unexpected way. In that case, it would be better to contact the author to let him/her know about the finding. (If you contacted the author, please leave a line so that other people do not have to worry about the possibility that the author is not notified.) If you are not involved in the discussion but happen to notice a case like this, you can flag the post for a moderator attention.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Related discussions: &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/214/should-there-be-a-protocol-to-notify-authors-if-we-find-an-error-in-a-paper&quot;&gt;[1]&lt;/a&gt; &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/204/are-specific-questions-about-theorem-x-in-paper-y-fine&quot;&gt;[2]&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="567" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.560" LastActivityDate="2010-10-04T14:08:04.013" CommentCount="2" CommunityOwnedDate="2010-10-04T14:08:04.013" />
./Posts.xml:422:  <row Id="440" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2010-10-04T14:40:53.537" Score="8" ViewCount="123" Body="&lt;p&gt;I realise that there have been a number of questions on this topic already (specifically &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/378/how-much-time-before-closing-a-question&quot;&gt;this one&lt;/a&gt;), but I hope that this one will be indulged. Currently there are 35 users with the power to vote to close out of a total of 1640 registered users. I am becoming a little worried that there is a tendency to close questions very quickly if they appear in any way poorly formed. To those of us who have been using the site heavily, asking a question which will be accepted as legitimate (and hence not closed) is relatively easy, but for new users it is not clear that this is the case. I can imagine that it is an extremely discouraging experience to see you question almost immediately closed as off topic. Perhaps with questions from new users we should be more tolerant and use comments to try to shape the question into an acceptable form?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;So, are we being too quick to close?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="204" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" LastActivityDate="2010-10-04T19:28:34.643" Title="Are we being too quick to close questions?" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;" AnswerCount="2" CommentCount="2" FavoriteCount="1" />
./Posts.xml:423:  <row Id="441" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="440" CreationDate="2010-10-04T16:36:24.623" Score="7" Body="&lt;p&gt;I think timing is key. I've seen drive-by questions, where the user posts and disappears. I've also seen users interact with the comments and make changes. I'm all for giving some breathing room, especially since this is not like SO with nearly 2K questions/day. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;My personal suggestion (which I use also because my moderator votes are binding) is to use the 'downvote and comment' mechanism more than the close mechanism, if there's any sense of controversy. There are questions that deserve to be shut down via closing (like &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1911/is-fn-log-n-in-theta-log-n-closed&quot;&gt;this one&lt;/a&gt;), and then there are questions that &lt;strong&gt;might&lt;/strong&gt; be retrievable with more OP work (like &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1881/is-wittens-new-method-of-quantization-useful-for-geometric-complexity-theory-c&quot;&gt;this one&lt;/a&gt;). It costs you almost nothing to downvote, especially if you're a user with enough rep to close. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;But the OP needs to put in some effort as well. If even 24 hours after posting a question and seeing downvotes/comments galore, the OP doesn't either fix the question or repost a new one, then I'm all in favor of moving to close. Or if there's an edit cycle going on and on and on, with no sense of convergence, then again a close might be the best option. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="80" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" LastActivityDate="2010-10-04T16:36:24.623" CommentCount="1" />
./Posts.xml:424:  <row Id="442" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="440" CreationDate="2010-10-04T19:28:34.643" Score="2" Body="&lt;p&gt;I noticed this trend also. I've tried to avoid contributing further too it (and indeed I did contribute to it) by first commenting, then after some time has passed and no change has been made, down-vote or vote to close. After one particular &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1832/complexity-classes-separations-and-inclusions-closed&quot;&gt;unsavoury incident&lt;/a&gt;, I learnt that we need to be a little nicer and more encouraging. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Nowadays I'll even try to answer questions that should be closed (and eventually are closed), if I am able to and the question is not too simple. I can always learn something that way too.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="77" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.537" LastActivityDate="2010-10-04T19:28:34.643" CommentCount="0" />

./Posts.xml:428:  <row Id="446" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2010-10-06T11:57:26.193" Score="21" ViewCount="1753" Body="&lt;p&gt;As a &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/q/1521/873&quot;&gt;Theory B&lt;/a&gt; person, I feel the site really lacks Theory B questions. ./Posts.xml:429:  <row Id="447" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="446" CreationDate="2010-10-06T13:02:26.383" Score="5" Body="&lt;p&gt;This is not an answer but an obvious observation, but I post it anyway in the hope that stating the obvious may shed some light on the situation.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Honestly, I think that the situation is pretty much chicken or the egg.  To begin with, people (not necessarily in Theory B) visit the website because people are already here.  If the pioneering people had failed, we could have ended up with an &lt;a href=&quot;http://blog.stackoverflow.com/2010/07/area-51-asking-the-first-questions/&quot;&gt;empty restaurant&lt;/a&gt; — no one is there, therefore nothing interesting is there, therefore no one wants to visit there.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Thanks to the first participants (especially &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/badges/16/beta&quot;&gt;those who participated while the site was in private beta&lt;/a&gt;), the website as a whole seems to have survived the risk of the empty restaurant syndrome.  However, that does not mean that the risk has gone in each subfield of the theoretical computer science.  I see many strong questions in complexity theory and algorithms, so I guess that the website has survived the risk of the empty restaurant syndrome in these areas.  However, in other areas, I think that the website is still in the middle of the risk.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="567" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" LastActivityDate="2010-10-06T13:02:26.383" CommentCount="1" />
./Posts.xml:431:  <row Id="449" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2010-10-06T20:47:59.050" Score="3" ViewCount="97" Body="&lt;p&gt;We have one post tagged with &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/games&quot;&gt;games&lt;/a&gt;, and 4 tagged with &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/puzzles&quot;&gt;puzzles&lt;/a&gt;. Do we need two separate tags for them ? &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Proposal: RETAG the one games-tagged post (&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1962/is-it-np-hard-to-play-international-draughts-correctly&quot;&gt;on international draughts&lt;/a&gt;) as puzzles.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I'd create a tag synonym for voting, but my AMP will force creation, and I'd rather get the community opinion. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Update&lt;/strong&gt;: Correctly, people have pointed out that games is a generic name that applies to too many settings to be merged with puzzles, and that for this particular example, board-games might be a better tag. ./Posts.xml:439:  <row Id="457" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2010-10-08T22:13:35.393" Score="16" ViewCount="782" Body="&lt;p&gt;Aaron Sterling had the &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/453/site-outreach-promotion-at-focs&quot;&gt;nice suggestion (in comments here)&lt;/a&gt; for site promotion at FOCS: his idea was:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;a poster with a few &quot;best questions&quot;&#xA;  in large print on it: representatives&#xA;  of &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;  &#xA;  &lt;ol&gt;&#xA;  &lt;li&gt;community wiki, &lt;/li&gt;&#xA;  &lt;li&gt;a reference request where a top expert swooped in and resolved the&#xA;  issue, and &lt;/li&gt;&#xA;  &lt;li&gt;an open problem such as an NP-reduction where answerers solved it&#xA;  on the spot&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;  &lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Any nominations ? One per answer, and specify which category: in each case, also pick an answer if none was accepted. If we can get some nominations within a week I can mock up a poster and stick it at the registration desk. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Update:&lt;/strong&gt; Great suggestions all. Any thoughts on the best way to lay these out on a poster ? One idea would be to orient the poster in landscape mode and have three columns, with 1/2 questions/answers in each. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Update 2:&lt;/strong&gt; For logistical reasons, I had to can the poster idea. but I thought I'd use a variant of what Joshua was suggesting, which was to use a single sheet for each question, with the question on the front and the answer on the back. I can generate a number of copies for different questions, and try to slip them into people's registration bags :). &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.cs.utah.edu/~suresh/example.pdf&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;Here's an example&lt;/a&gt; of what I'm thinking. Tell me what you think. AND SOON :)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Update 3:&lt;/strong&gt; New version with only answer hints. Thoughts ? &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Update 4:&lt;/strong&gt; I'm in Las Vegas now, and successfully got a sheet inserted in each registration packet, as well as scattering copies of the sheets on registration desks. I hope this will encourage more people to visit. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="80" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.560" LastActivityDate="2010-10-23T23:56:30.683" Title="Nominations for publicity poster at FOCS ?" ./Posts.xml:440:  <row Id="459" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="457" CreationDate="2010-10-08T22:42:09.503" Score="5" Body="&lt;p&gt;I nominate Tsuyoshi's &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2032/a-decision-problem-which-is-not-known-to-be-in-ph-but-will-be-in-p-if-pnp&quot;&gt;A decision problem which is not known to be in PH but will be in P if P=NP&lt;/a&gt;.  The problem can be stated &lt;strong&gt;very&lt;/strong&gt; concisely, as is needed since you wont have much space on a poster. Moreover, the question looks easy at first sight, but isn't really, making the reader start thinking on this. Whether or not the reader solves the problem, he/she will feel curious to know what the posted answers are and will come here to read the answers.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;This probably falls in category 2, but it wasn't really a ref request.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="206" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.537" LastActivityDate="2010-10-08T22:42:09.503" CommentCount="3" />

./Posts.xml:444:  <row Id="463" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2010-10-09T00:35:07.513" Score="6" ViewCount="765" Body="&lt;p&gt;&lt;em&gt;We closed the &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/1/what-should-our-domain-name-be&quot;&gt;domain naming thread (click for details)&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/em&gt; &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Instead, &lt;strong&gt;let's start with a killer &quot;elevator pitch!&quot;&lt;/strong&gt; Joel will be blogging about the elevator pitch approach to naming, but to get you started: &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h2&gt;The Elevator Pitch&lt;/h2&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;This isn't as easy as it sounds. Imagine the user who will never read your FAQ and you have two seconds to grab their attention. It should be catchy but descriptive. It should be thoroughly clear but painfully concise. &lt;strong&gt;Make every... word... count.&lt;/strong&gt; &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Here are some creative examples: &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://gawker.com/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;Gawker&lt;/a&gt;: Daily Manhattan media news and gossip. Reporting live from the center of the universe. &lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://gizmodo.com/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;Gizmodo&lt;/a&gt;: The gadget guide. So much in love with shiny new toys, it’s unnatural. &lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.autoblog.com/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;Autoblog&lt;/a&gt;: We obsessively cover the auto industry. &lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.dumblittleman.com/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;DumbLittleMan&lt;/a&gt;: So what do we do here? Well, it’s simple. 15 to 20 times per week we provide tips that will save you money, increase your productivity, or simply keep you sane. &lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.needcoffee.com/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;Needcoffee.com&lt;/a&gt;: We are the Internet equivalent of a triple espresso with whipped cream. Mmmm…whipped cream. &lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h2&gt;Use it as a Tagline&lt;/h2&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;A shorter elevator pitch &lt;em&gt;can&lt;/em&gt; be used as a tagline&amp;thinsp;&amp;mdash;&amp;thinsp;something you can display in the header at the top of the page. If it doesn't fit, consider shortening it or creating a separate tagline. Here are some great examples: &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://slashdot.org/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;Slashdot&lt;/a&gt;: News for nerds. Stuff that matters. &lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.lifehacker.com/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;Lifehacker&lt;/a&gt;: Don’t live to geek, geek to live! &lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.thesimpledollar.com/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;The Simple Dollar&lt;/a&gt;: Financial talk for the rest of us. &lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h2&gt;The Motto (don't forget your logo)&lt;/h2&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;A logo begs for it own little, short tagline&amp;thinsp;&amp;mdash;&amp;thinsp;like a motto. Maybe the tagline inspires the logo; Maybe it's the other way around. Mottos make good t-shirt, bumper stickers, and other marketing material. Either way, you'll recognize a good motto when you see it: &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Just do it. &lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Think Different. &lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;The Uncola. &lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Intel inside. &lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Like a rock. &lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;The king of beers. &lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&amp;hellip;and perhaps all this leads to a proper name and domain for your site&amp;hellip; &lt;em&gt;eventually&lt;/em&gt;. So let's start from the basics. &lt;strong&gt;Come up with a killer elevator pitch, tagline, and/or motto!&lt;/strong&gt; &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="237" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" LastActivityDate="2010-10-25T09:37:45.600" Title="Write an Elevator Pitch / Tagline" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;" AnswerCount="14" CommentCount="2" FavoriteCount="2" />

./Posts.xml:459:  <row Id="482" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="21" CreationDate="2010-10-10T19:17:40.237" Score="2" Body="&lt;p&gt;Jeff Atwood of Stack Overflow closed the Area 51 proposal &lt;a href=&quot;http://area51.stackexchange.com/proposals/7848/compiler-design&quot;&gt;Compiler Design&lt;/a&gt; on Oct. 1 on the ground that it was part of Stack Overflow. ./Posts.xml:461:  <row Id="485" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAnswerId="489" CreationDate="2010-10-11T01:41:49.080" Score="6" ViewCount="164" Body="&lt;p&gt;As far as I learned from &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/q/3/873&quot;&gt;this topic&lt;/a&gt;, both CSTheory &amp;amp; MathOverflow use MathJax. In addition, when I checked the version, I noticed that both use v1.0.1.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;However, the math rendering experience is quite different on TCS &amp;amp; MO: while the former takes a (considerable) time to render a formula, the latter works on the fly (especially while entering a question or answer).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Is there a reason behind this?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="873" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" LastActivityDate="2010-10-11T13:15:32.703" Title="Why is our LaTeX math support so different from that of MathOverflow?" ./Posts.xml:463:  <row Id="487" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="457" CreationDate="2010-10-11T04:06:56.243" Score="6" Body="&lt;p&gt;For the converse of category 2 (that is, asked by an expert, answered by a graduate student): Ryan Williams' &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1923/which-interesting-theorems-in-tcs-rely-on-the-axiom-of-choice-or-alternatively&quot;&gt;Which interesting theorems in TCS rely on the Axiom of Choice?&lt;/a&gt;, or maybe just the core question:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;What is the most striking example in TCS that you know where [the axiom of choice is] required?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;With &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1923/which-interesting-theorems-in-tcs-rely-on-the-axiom-of-choice-or-alternatively/1941#1941&quot;&gt;Janne Korhonen's answer&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="129" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" LastActivityDate="2010-10-12T00:56:01.587" CommentCount="1" />
./Posts.xml:465:  <row Id="489" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="485" CreationDate="2010-10-11T13:15:32.703" Score="4" Body="&lt;p&gt;The answer is provided by KennyTM here: &lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/67258#67261&quot;&gt;https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/67258#67261&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="873" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-20T10:29:37.593" LastActivityDate="2010-10-11T13:15:32.703" CommentCount="4" />
./Posts.xml:471:  <row Id="496" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="492" CreationDate="2010-10-11T21:16:50.953" Score="9" Body="&lt;p&gt;As far as I know, there are five ways to render dollar signs in questions and answers.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;code&gt;&amp;#x60;$example$&amp;#x60;&lt;/code&gt; → &lt;code&gt;$example$&lt;/code&gt;.  (use backticks in Markdown)&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;code&gt;$\$$example$\$$&lt;/code&gt; → $\$$example$\$$.  (use LaTeX)&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;code&gt;\$example\$&lt;/code&gt; → \$example\$.  (if you do not mind additional backslashes rendered)&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;code&gt;$example&lt;/code&gt; → $example.  (if you need just one dollar sign)&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;code&gt;＄example＄&lt;/code&gt; → ＄example＄.  (abuse &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.fileformat.info/info/unicode/char/ff04/index.htm&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;Fullwidth Dollar Sign (U+FF04)&lt;/a&gt;)&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;More details:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;As Suresh wrote in a comment, you can use a code span in Markdown (backticks).&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;You can use LaTeX.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;As you did in the question, if you prepend a backslash to a dollar sign, the dollar sign is not considered as a LaTeX math delimiter, but the backslash is also rendered.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;If just one dollar sign is needed, you can write it without any trouble.  What counts as one seems complicated (for example, the example above really contains two dollar signs).&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;You can abuse &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.fileformat.info/info/unicode/char/ff04/index.htm&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;Fullwidth Dollar Sign (U+FF04)&lt;/a&gt;.  But note that most Latin fonts do not contain this letter and that therefore some people may not have a font containing it.  Also, this is an abuse because the character U+FF04 exists only for compatibility with some legacy character sets/encodings.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;See also a &lt;a href=&quot;https://math.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/403/texification-is-too-aggressive-or-how-to-enter-a-dollar-sign&quot;&gt;related question on meta.math.stackexchange.com&lt;/a&gt;, but note that part of the question is obsolete (as stated in an &lt;a href=&quot;https://math.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/403/texification-is-too-aggressive-or-how-to-enter-a-dollar-sign/434#434&quot;&gt;answer&lt;/a&gt;).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="567" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:44:21.953" LastActivityDate="2010-10-12T10:37:19.093" CommentCount="2" />
./Posts.xml:473:  <row Id="499" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="457" CreationDate="2010-10-13T04:42:36.627" Score="5" Body="&lt;p&gt;A category 3 example is David Eppstein's question about &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1346/positive-topological-ordering&quot;&gt;Positive topological ordering&lt;/a&gt;.  This was not only solved (19 days later), but generated a lot of interesting discussion and at least two follow-up questions by other people:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1399/positive-topological-ordering-take-2&quot;&gt;Positive topological ordering, take 2&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1842/positive-topological-ordering-take-3&quot;&gt;Positive topological ordering, take 3&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="109" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.537" LastActivityDate="2010-10-13T04:42:36.627" CommentCount="0" />

./Posts.xml:476:  <row Id="502" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAnswerId="1035" CreationDate="2010-10-13T06:33:31.103" Score="11" ViewCount="374" Body="&lt;p&gt;I am experimenting with some UserScripts to provide additional functionality that the StackExchange sites currently do not support.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In particular, two have proved highly useful:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://math.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/689/latex-rendering-delay&quot;&gt;https://math.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/689/latex-rendering-delay&lt;/a&gt; shows how to reduce the TeX preview delay from the default 5 seconds (!).  Thanks to @Sadeq for the detective work in &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/485&quot;&gt;Why is our LaTeX math support so different from that of MathOverflow?&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://userscripts.org/scripts/show/71948&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;http://userscripts.org/scripts/show/71948&lt;/a&gt; threads comments based on time and &lt;code&gt;@&lt;/code&gt;-tagged names used in the comments&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I would like to hear about UserScripts that others have found useful on CSTheory.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;There are also some generic lists (the functionality of quite a few of these has subsequently been incorporated by the StackExchange sites):&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/5188/what-third-party-tools-exist-to-use-with-stackoverflow&quot;&gt;What third-party tools are there for the trilogy websites?&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://userscripts.org/scripts/search?q=stack+overflow&amp;amp;x=0&amp;amp;y=0&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;http://userscripts.org/scripts/search?q=stack+overflow&amp;amp;x=0&amp;amp;y=0&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.stackoverflow.com/search?q=userscript&quot;&gt;https://meta.stackoverflow.com/search?q=userscript&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="109" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-20T10:29:37.593" LastActivityDate="2014-03-17T05:59:02.753" Title="Useful UserScripts?" ./Posts.xml:478:  <row Id="504" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="300" CreationDate="2010-10-13T10:34:38.193" Score="5" Body="&lt;h3&gt;Make your title your question&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Try to be as specific as possible about the title of your question. Avoid using general titles that don't specify your question. Don't use the title as a tag.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Read the corresponding MO &lt;a href=&quot;https://mathoverflow.net/howtoask#yourtitle&quot;&gt;guideline&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="186" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:57:54.527" LastActivityDate="2010-10-13T10:34:38.193" CommentCount="0" CommunityOwnedDate="2010-10-13T10:34:38.193" />
./Posts.xml:479:  <row Id="506" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="300" CreationDate="2010-10-13T10:58:48.073" Score="4" Body="&lt;h3&gt;Read the MO guidelines &quot;how to ask&quot;&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;MathOverflow has a very well written guideline about asking questions, all of the items in their guideline applies to this site also. Please read their &lt;a href=&quot;https://mathoverflow.net/howtoask&quot;&gt;guideline&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="186" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:57:54.527" LastActivityDate="2010-10-13T10:58:48.073" CommentCount="0" CommunityOwnedDate="2010-10-13T10:58:48.073" />
./Posts.xml:480:  <row Id="507" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="300" CreationDate="2010-10-13T11:06:03.487" Score="10" Body="&lt;h3&gt;Provide background information&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Try to make your question self-contained. The users of this site are &lt;strong&gt;not&lt;/strong&gt; machines and are &lt;strong&gt;not&lt;/strong&gt; paid to answer your questions. Be nice to others. Spend some time in explaining the background of your question and the terminology you are using to make it understandable to people not familiar with what you are asking (at least provide a link to a source that would explain the terminology). Make reading your question pleasant to other users of the site.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;You might say, “But anyone working on this field should know what XYZ is.  If someone does not know what it is, he/she cannot answer my question anyway, so explaining it will not help my question get answered.”  That may be correct or incorrect.  It may be incorrect because sometimes people from surprisingly different background can give you useful insight if a question is written in an accessible way.  However, more importantly, do not be selfish.  Let other users learn from your question even if they have absolutely zero probability of being able to answer your question.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Read &lt;a href=&quot;https://mathoverflow.net/howtoask#motivation&quot;&gt;the related MO guideline&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="186" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:57:54.527" LastActivityDate="2011-02-04T10:34:58.510" CommentCount="1" CommunityOwnedDate="2010-10-13T11:06:03.487" />
./Posts.xml:481:  <row Id="508" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="502" CreationDate="2010-10-13T14:23:52.397" Score="5" Body="&lt;p&gt;Stack Exchange has an experimental feature called &lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/54366/feedback-request-newer-timeline-question-view&quot;&gt;timeline view&lt;/a&gt;.  Currently the timeline page of a question can be reached only by tweaking the URL, but there is a &lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/40617/a-greasemonkey-script-that-adds-timeline-links-to-all-the-questions/40623#40623&quot;&gt;user script by quack quixote&lt;/a&gt; which adds a proper link.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;By default, the user script does not work on any *.stackexchange.com sites.  You have to add the following line to the declaration part:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;pre&gt;&lt;code&gt;// @include http://*.stackexchange.com/*&#xA;&lt;/code&gt;&lt;/pre&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I have been using it for a month and it has never caused a problem as far as I know, which is great.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="567" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-20T10:29:37.593" LastActivityDate="2010-10-13T15:24:58.537" CommentCount="4" />
./Posts.xml:482:  <row Id="509" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2010-10-13T15:10:30.270" Score="2" ViewCount="55" Body="&lt;p&gt;When I saw the question “&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/646/what-is-the-most-efficient-algorithm-to-sample-graphs-with-trivial-automorphism-g&quot;&gt;What is the most efficient algorithm to sample graphs with trivial automorphism groups ?&lt;/a&gt;” by turkistany, it reminded me that I saw a similar question recently, but it was difficult to find which question it was.  It turned out that the “similar” question was “&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2031/generating-graphs-with-trivial-automorphisms&quot;&gt;Generating Graphs with Trivial Automorphisms&lt;/a&gt;” by Sadeq (which was indeed related, but was not similar after all).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Part of the difficulty of finding this question was due to the fact that the former had a tag [&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/automorphism&quot;&gt;automorphism&lt;/a&gt;] while the latter had [&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/graph-isomorphism&quot;&gt;graph-isomorphism&lt;/a&gt;], which rendered tag search useless.  (Of course part of the difficulty is due to my poor searching skill.)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;At this moment, there are five questions with the tag [automorphism], and all of them seem to be about the automorphisms of a graph.  Considering that graph isomorphisms and graph automorphisms are obviously very closely related, it makes some sense to merge these tags, which would have avoided the difficulty I encountered.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;However, converting [automorphism] into a tag synonym of [graph-isomorphism] does not sound right for the future use.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Converting both tags into a tag synonym of a new tag [isomorphism] is another option.  However, [isomorphism] is a little vague, and it can refer to the isomorphisms between languages as in the &lt;a href=&quot;http://blog.computationalcomplexity.org/2003/03/berman-hartmanis-isomorphism.html&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;Berman-Hartmanis isomorphism conjecture&lt;/a&gt; for example.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Leaving these tags as they are is also a valid option.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;What should we do about these tags?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="567" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" LastActivityDate="2010-10-13T15:10:30.270" Title="What should we to with tags [graph-isomorphism] and [automorphism]?" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;tags&gt;&lt;retagging&gt;" AnswerCount="0" CommentCount="6" />
./Posts.xml:483:  <row Id="511" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="457" CreationDate="2010-10-13T17:57:49.193" Score="3" Body="&lt;p&gt;Regarding the layout of such a poster: I actually prefer ad campaigns consisting of several small posters, each in the same style but with different contents. Each time you see a new poster you think how clever it is, rather than just thinking &quot;Oh, there's that same poster again that I've seen 5 times already.&quot;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I don't know if this is feasible or not given the physical layout of FOCS, since there's probably only one registration table and not really other opportunities to put up flyers.  But even if you just have one pile of flyers spread out a little so people can see that there are in fact several distinct ones, that could work.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If so, then I'd suggest one question per page.  The question big and bold, near the top (maybe use landscape layout), and the answer(s) in smaller text--probably necessary because the answer's tend to be longer--maybe with the most exciting/relevant part of the answer also in bold.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Oh, and of course, &quot;cstheory.stackexchange.com&quot; (perhaps plus a &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/463/write-an-elevator-pitch-tagline&quot;&gt;tag line&lt;/a&gt;, which doesn't have to be the same on each page) at the bottom.  Doesn't have to be too large: once you hook 'em with the interesting Q&amp;amp;A, hopefully they'll be interested enough to find out what the flyer is about, regardless of how large or spiffy the URL is.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="129" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" LastActivityDate="2010-10-13T17:57:49.193" CommentCount="2" />
./Posts.xml:485:  <row Id="514" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2010-10-15T20:01:52.390" Score="11" ViewCount="641" Body="&lt;p&gt;There are several questions asking for a good way to model something.  Are they in scope, or should they be closed?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Because a recent example is “&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2200/semantic-distance-between-excerpts-of-text&quot;&gt;Semantic distance between excerpts of text.&lt;/a&gt;” by John Berryman, I will take this as an example, but I would like to discuss a general issue.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Some people argue that this question is really about natural language processing and that without a rigorously defined model, the question is not about theoretical computer science and therefore is off-topic.  I almost agree, but not completely, because it seems like a plausible possibility that questions like this can lead to interesting answers in the theoretical computer science.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I am not sure if I want to see more questions of this kind or not.  On the one hand, it is interesting to see connections of theoretical computer science to various fields of computer science, and encouraging this kind of questions increases the chance of seeing such connections.  On the other hand, if 20% of the questions on the top page are like this and few of them get answers interesting to me (and worse yet, they are bumped by &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/users/-1/community&quot;&gt;community ♦&lt;/a&gt; from time to time), I am sure that I will get sick of those questions.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;em&gt;Added&lt;/em&gt;: Another example of the how-to-model-this questions is “&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2227/finding-islands-of-vertices-in-a-network-of-roads-containing-one-way-streets-clo&quot;&gt;Finding islands of vertices in a network of roads containing one-way streets&lt;/a&gt;” by shindigo.  This question was closed, and I was one of those who voted to close it.  Honestly speaking, I did not realize that this question was in the same “how-to-model-this” category until Suresh pointed out in a comment to the question (silly me).  I hope that comparing these two questions (and possibly other questions in the same category) may shed some light on &lt;em&gt;what we want to aim at&lt;/em&gt; about how-to-model-this questions.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="567" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" LastActivityDate="2010-10-18T02:47:50.217" Title="How-to-model-this questions" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;scope&gt;" AnswerCount="5" CommentCount="0" FavoriteCount="4" />

./Posts.xml:495:  <row Id="524" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="522" CreationDate="2010-10-17T06:01:15.863" Score="6" Body="&lt;p&gt;On the positive side, I think the quality of questions and answers are really high. using the site. (I find it a little bit ironic that mathematicians are faster than cs theorist in adopting new technologies.) Ideally we should have every active theory prof and every tcs graduate student in good universities actively use the site, post questions and answers. We should look more carefully on why this is not the case and address the issues that make people uninterested in using the site. We are also not getting reasonable involvement from researchers in areas outside algorithms, complexity, and computational geometry. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Theory B is very weak on the site, not enough crpto/privacy, combinatorics, and algorithmic game theory and many other very active research areas in &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/119/our-domain-scope-specifically-defined&quot;&gt;our scope&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;more involvement from community (profs, grad students)&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;more questions and answers&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;more active areas&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I think we need a number of active core users who are experts in each area to keep those area active on the site. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Here are some suggestions:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;There are number of reasons that I have heard from people who I have talked with and tried to get interested in using the site. It might help if we collect those reasons and try to address them if possible. &lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Moderators can contact some of the top experts that have used the site, and ask their opinion and for suggestions on making the site more interesting and useful. &lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;List a number of reasons why every theory prof/grad student should use the site: &quot;Why I should check cstheory? Because ...&quot;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Contact a number of researchers in areas that are not active on the site, and tell them that their area is not active on the site and ask them to help us in getting more questions and answers in those areas. &lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;We can also hold special weeks where every user is encouraged to ask a question (even very basic ones from people unfamiliar with those areas, you have attended a talk in some area and you have a very basic question you haven't asked) in a specific area, if we get enough question in those areas, they may generate enough interest to make those areas active. We can also directly invite some of the experts in those areas for the week assigned to each area.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;(Most of these are already suggested by others in other questions.)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="186" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" LastActivityDate="2010-10-17T06:07:44.673" CommentCount="7" CommunityOwnedDate="2010-10-17T06:01:15.863" />

./Posts.xml:511:  <row Id="540" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="120" CreationDate="2010-10-20T17:37:34.797" Score="7" Body="&lt;p&gt;There seems to be quite a bit of interest in answering some applied questions. (I've answered some myself.) After I commented that &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2050/approximation-algorithms-for-maxsat&quot;&gt;Approximation Algorithms for MAXSAT&lt;/a&gt; was off topic, Peter Shor replied:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;In the '80s and '90s, at many universities, theoretical computer science was very unpopular and looked down upon by the rest of computer science because it was viewed as unconnected to practice. Eventually, Google and other successes convinced them that we were worth talking to. Let's please not close off the lines of communication from the other side now, after having worked so long to open them. That would be very bad for the field, not to mention the TCS job market.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Is there a consensus that heuristic algorithms for rigorously defined problems are on-topic, even if we can't prove anything about them? Should we distinguish methods with theoretical partial results (such as branch and bound, which is easily proven correct albeit potentially exponential) from methods with very little theory (such as genetic algorithms)?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="1522" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" LastActivityDate="2010-10-20T17:37:34.797" CommentCount="4" />
./Posts.xml:512:  <row Id="541" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="457" CreationDate="2010-10-21T01:54:33.890" Score="4" Body="&lt;p&gt;I really like the &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2335/multiplicative-version-of-3-sum&quot;&gt;Multiplicative Version of 3SUM&lt;/a&gt; question: given a set of numbers, are there numbers $a$, $b$, $c$ in the set such that $ab=c$? ./Posts.xml:521:  <row Id="550" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2010-10-24T03:20:01.933" Score="2" ViewCount="115" Body="&lt;p&gt;Here are two related questions:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;When should moderators &lt;em&gt;delete&lt;/em&gt; (not close) questions not posted by themselves?&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;When should users with rep points ≥2000 vote to &lt;em&gt;delete&lt;/em&gt; questions not posted by themselves?&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I am asking these questions because the moderation tools (available to users with rep points ≥2000) showed that Suresh deleted the &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2246&quot;&gt;question 2246 on parent&lt;/a&gt; recently.  I would understand it if it were &lt;em&gt;closed&lt;/em&gt;, but I do not think that it should have been deleted.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;My opinion is that questions should be deleted if they contain offensive/inappropriate/illegal material and so on, but questions should not be deleted just because they are poorly asked or off-topic.  Closing is enough for poorly-asked or off-topic questions and, moreover, closed questions &lt;em&gt;serve as bad examples&lt;/em&gt;.  A secondary usage is that if many questions asked by one user are closed, that might tell something about that user to other users.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="567" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" LastActivityDate="2010-10-24T17:29:06.490" Title="When should questions be deleted by others?" ./Posts.xml:523:  <row Id="552" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="522" CreationDate="2010-10-24T16:08:15.450" Score="2" Body="&lt;p&gt;Currently, it doesn't look bad at all. If you have a look at the visits/day number shown on the &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/&quot;&gt;main page&lt;/a&gt;, the number is even better (2,983 vs. 1,326). So one of them seems wrong (or they, confusingly, measure different things). ./Posts.xml:526:  <row Id="555" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAnswerId="557" CreationDate="2010-10-24T20:33:20.680" Score="4" ViewCount="154" Body="&lt;p&gt;&lt;em&gt;For people who have access to deleted questions.&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;A few weeks ago &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/189/algorithms-from-the-book/241#241&quot;&gt;Algorithms from the Book.&lt;/a&gt; was deleted, apparently by the owner.  This was the top ranked answer for the question (Euclidean algorithm), and as of now would still be the top ranked answer.  The user's name is now &quot;deleted&quot; and I assume the account was either accessed by a vandal, or the person decided to remove their contributions to CSTheory.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I think the response is worth preserving, and other responses refer to it.  So I am tempted to copy the text into a new answer, and mention that the answer was originally posted by a person who has removed their profile.  Alternately, the answer could be undeleted.  Is there a consensus on the best way to proceed?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="109" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" LastActivityDate="2010-10-26T08:00:48.400" Title="Undeleting highly voted answers?"
