./Posts.xml:529:  <row Id="558" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="555" CreationDate="2010-10-25T03:45:13.810" Score="2" Body="&lt;p&gt;I wouldn't post this if I didn't think that this is going to create a bad example for future decisions. We are drawing lines about what is appropriate too strictly. We are being too conservative, the default position should be trusting decisions made by other users. If there is a disagreement, if the OP comes back and says I want this removed for some reasons, then we can discuss it, but as long as there is not a conflict, we should be very liberal about what users can do. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;What are we going to do if a user copies a deleted answer and posts it? Are we going to down vote it? Are we going to delete it? What if a number of users undelete a post. The system permits other users to undelete posts, even if it is deleted by the OP. Are we going to punish the users for undeleting it? Are we going to delete it again?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I also don't see any reason legally or ethically for not copying an answer. What is the ethical principle that is being violated? &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;IMHO, copying answers is completely compatible with the philosophy of the site. Let me quote a part of FAQ:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;Other people can edit my stuff?!&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;  &#xA;  &lt;p&gt;Like Wikipedia, this site is collaboratively edited, and all edits are tracked. &lt;strong&gt;If you are not comfortable with the idea of your questions and answers being edited by other trusted users, this may not be the site for you.&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I think this is clear about the philosophy of SE. If you are not happy about copying answers, I respect your view. But if you are saying that it is inappropriate or unethical and/or if you are trying to draw lines too strictly about how other users or moderators should act, and about what is appropriate and what is not, sorry, but I don't agree.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;hr&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;Edit 10/26/2010&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I agree with Tsuyoshi that there is not a need to agree on everything, i.e. I agree with Tsuyoshi to disagree.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;My main point here is on how conservative we should be on what trusted users/moderators can do.&lt;/strong&gt; My view, as I wrote above, is that we should trust decisions made by others and be very liberal, we don't need to discuss every decision made by others, unless there is a conflict/disagreement.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Let me also make it clear that there is a difference between being nice to others and what is ethical. An action can be considered &quot;not being nice to others&quot;, but still don't violate any ethical principles. Being nice is boarder than being ethical (in this context).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Now, let me return to the particular case of this question.&#xA;My sentence about the ethical principle being violated is in the context of our discussion, i.e. the appropriate use of &lt;em&gt;this site&lt;/em&gt;. The argument, if I understood it correctly, is that we should respect the decision made by OP about deleting their post, and I guess this is based on the view that &lt;em&gt;OP own what they have posted&lt;/em&gt;. I am not sure I agree with this. Again if I understood the philosophy of the site correctly, it is very similar to Wikipedia, and it is a collaborative effort. If you have posted something, others can modify, edit, or even copy-and-post it.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Some discussion on why it is not clear to me if a post is owned by OP, specially a CW post:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I. When someone posts an answer/questions, it means that other users are probably going to avoid posting similar content,&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;II. People vote for the answer,&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;III. Other answers may refer to it.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Removing a post can also be considered as not respecting the questioner, other user answering the question, and the votes given to the answer.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Now, if it is CW, i.e. &lt;em&gt;community wiki&lt;/em&gt;, it is more involved. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;IV. CW answers are owned by community, they are edited by other users, and removing a post can cause even more problems in this case. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Assume that we have a CW question about what is the most famous problem in TCS, and someone posts &quot;$P$ vs $NP$&quot;, and of course receive lots of votes, after a few months the OP goes back and removes the answer. Assume that no one notices this. Think how it would look like if someone from outside or a new user reads the question and does not see an &quot;$P$ vs $NP$&quot; answer?! And even if another users posts it again, how many times do other uses have to vote for the same answer? Should we expect them to vote once every time someone removes it and someone else reposts an answer which is essentially the same?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I suggest you read this post: &lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/5221/what-can-cause-a-post-to-be-deleted-and-what-does-that-actually-mean/5222#5222&quot;&gt;What can cause a post to be deleted, and what does that actually mean?&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In particular, this part:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;When can't I delete my own post?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;  &#xA;  &lt;p&gt;You can't delete your answer if it has been accepted.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;  &#xA;  &lt;p&gt;You can't delete your question if it has more than two answers, if an answer has a score &gt;= 2, or it has been closed less than 48 hours ago.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;There are restrictions on when an answer can be removed by OP.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In summery, &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I. it is not clear to me that OP owns what they post, specially CW posts,&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;II. deleting a good highly-voted post by OP (without stating any reasons) can also be considered disrespect towards other users, and may cause problems.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Just to make it clear, I agree that we should be nice to others, and if the OP complains about undeleting their post (and states some reasons for it) I would support the OP, but IMO, the default position should be that &quot;posts can be undeleted by others, even if OP have removed it&quot;, specially if they are good and highly-voted.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="186" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-20T10:29:37.593" LastActivityDate="2010-10-26T08:00:48.400" CommentCount="4" />
./Posts.xml:530:  <row Id="559" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2010-10-25T19:14:57.777" Score="1" ViewCount="136" Body="&lt;p&gt;There are active discussions around both meta and several TCS questions about what questions should be rejected. The two reasons most often stated are (afaik)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;em&gt;too basic&lt;/em&gt; (aka &lt;em&gt;too localized&lt;/em&gt;, whatever that means)&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;em&gt;homework problem&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;There is a multitude of opionions about wether or not these reasons are legitimate or not; I do not want to discuss this here. Let us assume they are (seems reasonable since there is a large faction in favor of them). But then, should we not also close questions like these:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2396/counting-the-number-of-hamiltonian-cycles-in-cubic-hamiltonian-graphs&quot;&gt;Counting the number of Hamiltonian cycles in cubic Hamiltonian graphs?&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2373/complexity-of-simplex-algorithm&quot;&gt;Complexity of simplex algorithm&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;My rationale: These and other questions that are phrased like &quot;What is best ... known?&quot; or &quot;Is there ...?&quot; are &quot;only&quot; a replacement for literature research. They do not pose a motivated, original problem or reflect that work has gone into finding an answer. One could say the one asking has not done his homework.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Of course they are research level questions and therefore inherently more interesting -- and they offer a possibility for experts to show off (in a good way), other than undergrad homework problems.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Nevertheless, I feel that a general rule of thumb for question scope should be found and that the negative approach (finding criteria for closing/rejecting) cannot go anywhere.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;So, let us try to answer the following questions: What makes a question good? What questions should &lt;em&gt;not&lt;/em&gt; be closed?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="1546" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" LastActivityDate="2010-10-25T23:19:40.580" Title="Another go at scope of desirable questions" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;scope&gt;&lt;closing&gt;" AnswerCount="3" CommentCount="7" />
./Posts.xml:536:  <row Id="565" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="209" CreationDate="2010-10-26T11:42:05.553" Score="-6" Body="&lt;p&gt;While undergrad homework is allegedly not within the scope of this site, you can have assignments in graduate courses that are definitely not basic. For example, I am giving a talk in the near future to researchers about something I worked with in my Bachelor's thesis. So it might be hard to draw the line.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;My proposal: Let us create a tag 'homework' if it does not exist already. This way, homework questions that are well posed (ref &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/559/another-go-at-scope-of-desirable-questions/560#560&quot;&gt;this discussion&lt;/a&gt;) can be allowed while people not interested in them can easily filter them out via the form on the main questions page. Something like &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/-homework&quot;&gt;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/-homework&lt;/a&gt; should yield a static page (with corresponding RSS feed) but I did not figure it out exactly. Anyway, this could be implemented easily if we went for it.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Edit:&lt;/strong&gt; In response to the comments, let me elaborate why I want basic TCS questions here, not on MO.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Students looking for help in TCS naturally go to the TCS site, not MO. &lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;I would expect more TCS expertise here than on MO (if not now because of the recent split, then certainly later on)&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;By refusing to answer basic questions -- often in a less than nice way -- we leave a bad impression.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;No pity for people that prefer rejecting questions over using existing tools for filtering. One should be able to expect regular users to use filters rather than newcomers to know the scopes of at least two different communities.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="1546" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" LastActivityDate="2010-10-26T16:31:08.373" CommentCount="10" />
./Posts.xml:537:  <row Id="567" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAnswerId="569" CreationDate="2010-10-26T21:39:52.830" Score="7" ViewCount="267" Body="&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2323/universities-for-quantum-computing-information&quot;&gt;This question&lt;/a&gt; seems to have generated quite a debate in the comments about whether it's appropriate, enough of one that it seems worth discussing in meta.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;There are lots of questions (asking things like which university has a good program, which are the main conferences, what is a good project to pursue) that, at least to me, seem out-of-scope for this site.  However, there are no good other venues (as far as I know) to ask them, and there are clearly people here willing to answer.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;To me, an ideal solution would have this site have 3 areas.  A &quot;main site&quot; a &quot;meta&quot; and a &quot;cafe&quot; that can deal in these other questions.  Only the main site would generate reputation, and the cafe would help fulfill &lt;a href=&quot;http://blog.computationalcomplexity.org/2010/09/theory-social-network.html&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;Lance's vision&lt;/a&gt;.  Unfortunately, I'm guessing the software won't allow for this (right?), so we should figure out a policy of what to do with these questions.  &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I realize this has been discussed in meta before, but I'm still not clear what's in scope -- especially since even the moderators seem to disagree.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="123" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" LastActivityDate="2010-10-27T21:34:08.703" Title="Defining the Scope of This Site (or Theory Cafe?)" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;scope&gt;" AnswerCount="2" CommentCount="8" FavoriteCount="3" />
./Posts.xml:539:  <row Id="570" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2010-10-27T13:40:41.180" Score="5" ViewCount="235" Body="&lt;p&gt;Many users on this site use their real identity.  So, via google or a linked website, it is usually easy to find the contact details of a fellow user.  However, in cases when users wish -- for whatever reason -- to keep their identity secret, what is the protocol for private contact?  (This is not a cryptography question, btw.)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;This is somewhat related to &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/4/on-using-actual-names&quot;&gt;the question on using actual names&lt;/a&gt;.  Adding a private email function has its issues and one of these might be that it removes one less incentive for giving your true identity.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;This question occurred to me while answering &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2328/when-should-you-say-what-you-know/2361#2361&quot;&gt;When should you say what you know?&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="233" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" LastActivityDate="2010-10-27T17:36:12.017" Title="How do I contact another user privately?" Tags="&lt;feature-request&gt;&lt;user-ids&gt;" AnswerCount="2" CommentCount="4" FavoriteCount="1" />
./Posts.xml:551:  <row Id="582" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAnswerId="586" CreationDate="2010-10-28T16:29:43.307" Score="1" ViewCount="104" Body="&lt;p&gt;To whom it may concern:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I had a bounty out on &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2148/intermediate-coding-representation-for-levenshtein-distance&quot;&gt;this question&lt;/a&gt;.  I accepted an answer before the bounty expired and awarded the 50 points.  But then the bounty actually expired and I got a notice that the answer had been auto-selected and only the autoselect-25 points had been awarded.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I'm really darn sure I checked the check-mark as I said.  I'm sure it's possible that I forgot, but due to the low volume of bounties on the site and its newness, I'll trust my memory for now.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="509" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" LastActivityDate="2010-10-28T22:46:37.783" Title="Awarding of bounty failed" Tags="&lt;bug&gt;&lt;status-bydesign&gt;&lt;bounty&gt;" AnswerCount="1" CommentCount="7" />
./Posts.xml:552:  <row Id="583" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2010-10-28T17:12:01.570" Score="19" ViewCount="967" Body="&lt;p&gt;Hi all,&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I chatted with Lance Fortnow at FOCS about the various ideas I brought up in &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/522/beta-period-progress/526#526&quot;&gt;my answer&lt;/a&gt; to &quot;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/522/beta-period-progress&quot;&gt;Beta period progress&lt;/a&gt;&quot;. This &quot;question&quot; is about the first, namely: &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;Write a note in SIGACT News&#xA;  advertising the site.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I was thinking (and maybe this is too pie-in-the-sky) that this post could be written jointly by the community, by editing this very post (I'll put a crude skeleton in place). The article, when published, could be attributed to the website &quot;with contributions from&quot; anyone who helped edit the post (but only real names, please). &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I'd like to make a few requests though:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Use an answer to discuss a particular aspect of the article. I understand that issues will overlap, but it's easier to track answers than have one giant comment thread below this question&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Make sure you use your real name when editing. We can use revision history to determine who changed what. &lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;I think it's also fair to assume that simple edits (syntax, spelling) are not at the contribution level that might merit &quot;with contributions from&quot;, so try to focus on content edits, and we can all chip in to fix minor issues. &lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;If you want to discuss whether we should be doing this at all, a different question might be a better place for that. Frankly, I don't see a downside. &lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Current contributors (please update)&lt;/strong&gt;: Dave Clarke, David Eppstein, Kaveh Ghasemloo, Lev Reyzin, András Salamon, Peter Shor, Aaron Sterling, Suresh Venkatasubramanian.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Further Update:&lt;/strong&gt; I think we should finalize all edits by Friday noon (Mountain time). At that point I'll take the text and links, convert to latex-ized PDF, and send it off to the SIGACT News Editor. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;More updates&lt;/strong&gt;. I'm now locking this post, since it's Friday @ Noon here in Utah. I'll start doing the latexing, and will link to a PDF shortly. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;PDF Update&lt;/strong&gt;: &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.cs.utah.edu/~suresh/cstheory.pdf&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;Here's a link to the PDF&lt;/a&gt;, with the citation format taken from &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/352/how-will-you-cite-a-discussion-on-this-site-in-your-paper&quot;&gt;this meta discussion&lt;/a&gt;. I have emailed this version to &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.cs.montana.edu/mumey/www/Home.html&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;Brendan Mumey&lt;/a&gt; (SIGACT News editor)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;hr&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Questions Answered. In theory.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;pre&gt;&lt;code&gt;cstheory.stackexchange.com&#xA;&lt;/code&gt;&lt;/pre&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;hr&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;Questions Answered.  In Theory.&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Perhaps you're a computer scientist wondering &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1923/which-interesting-theorems-in-tcs-rely-on-the-axiom-of-choice-or-alternatively&quot;&gt;how much the Axiom of Choice matters to the theorems you study and prove&lt;/a&gt;.  Perhaps you're a mathematician who needs &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1263/truly-random-number-generator-turing-computable&quot;&gt;a top expert to explain what &quot;randomness&quot; really means in computability and complexity&lt;/a&gt;.  Perhaps you need &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1284/problems-that-can-be-used-to-show-polynomial-time-hardness-results/&quot;&gt;a list of problems that can be used to show polynomial-time hardness results, to strengthen your toolkit of reductions&lt;/a&gt;.  Or perhaps you think a problem might be open -- but might just as easily be solved -- so &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2708/complexity-of-greatest-common-divisor-gcd/2713&quot;&gt;you'd like to ask&lt;/a&gt; a group of professionals &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2461/interactive-proofs-for-levels-of-the-polynomial-hierarchy&quot;&gt;what they think&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;Visit cstheory.stackexchange.com&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/&quot;&gt;cstheory.stackexchange.com&lt;/a&gt; provides this interaction &quot;at the speed of the internet,&quot; by bringing together researchers from around the world, and across the broad spectrum of theoretical computer science.  Active participants range from advanced undergraduates to well-established scientists. Currently the majority of participants are graduate students and postdoctoral fellows, but the number of senior researchers active within the site is growing quickly.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Even though &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/&quot;&gt;cs.theory.stackexchange.com&lt;/a&gt; is only two months old, it can already boast of 2,000 registered users, 700 answered questions, and -- perhaps most exciting -- &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2328/when-should-you-say-what-you-know/2362#2362&quot;&gt;new research collaborations among computer scientists&lt;/a&gt; who otherwise might never have realized that they were working on related problems.  The atmosphere of the site is a bit like a corridor discussion at a conference: researchers discuss and explain both folklore and the newest results, in a format that can be read at leisure.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Some questions and their answers are highly technical, but the answers from experts are often more than just answers; they contain insights that are not available in papers or textbooks.  For example, a student who requested a &quot;common sense&quot; explanation for how padding arguments related to complexity class separations received &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2434/why-do-complexity-classes-translate-upwards-and-not-downwards/2453#2453&quot;&gt;an intuitive answer from Russell Impagliazzo&lt;/a&gt;; Scott Aaronson summarized the &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2045/are-there-canonical-non-relativizing-techniques/2048#2048&quot;&gt;state-of-the-art in non-relativizing techniques&lt;/a&gt;; Jeff Erickson explained why &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2119/the-reasons-for-bss-real-ram-model-being-prefered-in-computational-geometry/2124#2124&quot;&gt;the real RAM model is preferred in computational geometry&lt;/a&gt;; and a student who asked whether the Nisan-Wigderson pseudorandom number generator relativizes received &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2236/does-nisans-pseudo-random-generator-relativize/2239#2239&quot;&gt;an answer from Noam Nisan&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Questions have also generated new proofs: Peter Shor gave a &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2312/max-cut-with-negative-weight-edges/2318#2318&quot;&gt;reduction from Max-Cut with positive weights to a constant-factor approximation for the version of the problem with negative weights&lt;/a&gt;; Jukka Suomela demonstrated that &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2505/is-the-dominating-set-problem-restricted-to-planar-bipartite-graphs-of-maximum-de/2508#2508&quot;&gt;DOMINATING SET remains NP-complete for planar bipartite graphs of maximum degree 3&lt;/a&gt;; Sariel Har-Peled showed that &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1651/hamiltonicity-of-k-regular-graphs/1656#1656&quot;&gt;Hamiltonicity is NP-complete for k-regular graphs for any fixed k&lt;/a&gt;; and Per Vognsen outlined a &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1772/alternative-proofs-of-schwartzzippel-lemma/1883#1883&quot;&gt;proof for the Schwartz-Zippel Lemma using projective geometry&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In addition to specific technical questions, participants have asked for more general advice from the community, such as &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1893/how-do-i-referee-a-paper&quot;&gt;how to referee papers&lt;/a&gt;, possible &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/979/automata-theory-formal-language-thesis-topic&quot;&gt;Master's thesis topics in automata theory&lt;/a&gt;, pointers to &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1539/whats-new-in-purely-functional-data-structures-since-okasaki&quot;&gt;recent purely functional data structures&lt;/a&gt;, suggestions for an &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2386/inspirational-talk-for-final-year-high-school-pupils/2411#2411&quot;&gt;inspirational talk about theoretical computer science&lt;/a&gt;, and &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2215/how-to-get-a-job&quot;&gt;how to find a job&lt;/a&gt;.  The site is a place for the larger theory community to come together.  The overall scope of the site is &lt;strong&gt;research-level theoretical computer science, broadly defined&lt;/strong&gt;.  &lt;em&gt;Note that homework questions are not allowed on the site&lt;/em&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Everyone with a research interest in theoretical computer science is welcome to create an account.  We encourage participation using real names -- and almost everybody does this -- but it's not required.  Participation costs nothing, and takes as little or as much time as you choose. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;Site Origin and Structure&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Some of the founding members of &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/&quot;&gt;cstheory.stackexchange.com&lt;/a&gt; participated in discussion of a proposed solution to the P/NP problem that spanned multiple blogs, led to the creation of wiki pages, and brought together researchers in disparate fields from around the world.  This effort made it clear that the worldwide theoretical computer science community was ready for -- and needed -- a structured way to ask research-level questions and to consider answers to such questions.  The success of MathOverflow.net (a site devoted to research-level mathematics) encouraged us to adopt the StackExchange software developed by Jeff Atwood and Joel Spolsky. This software provides a user reputation system built on up- and down-voting of contributions to highlight and encourage high quality, and to control spam.  There is also a &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/&quot;&gt;&quot;Meta&quot; area&lt;/a&gt;, for discussions about site scope and direction. Thus far, the system has worked extremely well and we are very pleased with it. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;Who runs the site?&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;You do ! The site is moderated by the community, with users gaining access to more management tools as they gain more reputation within the site. We have an active core of users who diligently monitor the site, help improve the quality of questions and answers, and filter out spam. In fact, this very article is a product of community participation on the site. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;But you don't have to worry about any of that to contribute to the numerous research discussions taking place right now. Please visit -- and participate in! -- &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/&quot;&gt;cstheory.stackexchange.com&lt;/a&gt;, the 24/7/365 gathering-place for theoretical computer scientists from around the world to share information and insights.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="80" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" LastActivityDate="2010-11-05T22:42:21.983" Title="A note in SIGACT news" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;site-promotion&gt;" AnswerCount="7" CommentCount="54" FavoriteCount="4" CommunityOwnedDate="2010-10-28T17:27:28.050" />
./Posts.xml:557:  <row Id="588" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="587" CreationDate="2010-10-29T21:38:17.987" Score="4" Body="&lt;p&gt;I have created [tag-removed] because I saw a similar practice and &lt;a href=&quot;https://mathoverflow.net/questions/tagged/tag-removed&quot;&gt;tag&lt;/a&gt; on MO. I think the point is not really tagging closed question, the point is &lt;em&gt;removing all tags from off-topic question&lt;/em&gt; so they do not show up when we search for those tags, and adding [tag-removed] is mainly for stating that the tags are removed from the question and keep all questions tagged with at least one tag.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="186" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:57:54.527" LastActivityDate="2010-10-29T21:38:17.987" CommentCount="9" />
./Posts.xml:559:  <row Id="590" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2010-10-30T20:52:42.007" Score="0" ViewCount="182" Body="&lt;p&gt;I tried to remove &lt;em&gt;ds.algorithms&lt;/em&gt; from my ignored tags by clicking on the popup &quot;Remove ds.algorithms from Ignored Tags&quot; link on the &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/ds.algorithms&quot;&gt;ds.algorithms page&lt;/a&gt;, and it didn't seem to work. ./Posts.xml:563:  <row Id="594" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="583" CreationDate="2010-10-31T16:24:53.833" Score="2" Body="&lt;p&gt;I really like both the rhythm and the examples of the first paragraph, but think it should be changed a little, I'm just not entirely sure how.  I've tried to be as constructive as I can, given that I don't have a concrete idea on how to change it.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;It currently (Rev 10) reads: &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;Perhaps you're a computer scientist wondering &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1923/which-interesting-theorems-in-tcs-rely-on-the-axiom-of-choice-or-alternatively&quot;&gt;how much the Axiom of Choice matters to the theorems you study and prove&lt;/a&gt;.  Perhaps you're a mathematician who needs &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1263/truly-random-number-generator-turing-computable&quot;&gt;a top expert to explain what &quot;randomness&quot; really means in computability and complexity&lt;/a&gt;.  Perhaps you need &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1284/problems-that-can-be-used-to-show-polynomial-time-hardness-results/&quot;&gt;a list of problems that can be used to show polynomial-time hardness results, to strengthen your toolkit of reductions&lt;/a&gt;.  Or perhaps you think a problem might be open -- but might just as easily be solved -- so &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2379/refereed-games-with-uncorrelated-semi-private-coins&quot;&gt;you'd like to ask a group of professionals what they think&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I have comments on each of the four examples in this opening paragraph:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;(1) I'd guess that most computer scientists have &lt;em&gt;not&lt;/em&gt; wondered how the Axiom of Choice matters to CS; most probably just think that it doesn't. The fact that we got a really interesting answer to the contrary is a success story for the site.  One of the things I enjoy most about the site is that I have learned interesting answers to questions I never would have thought to ask, not because they are not in my area, but because I always assumed the answer was trivial or never had occasion to think about them.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;(2) Are there any non-CS-mathematicians who read SIGACT News?  (Indeed, even the OP for that question is chair of his CS department, in addition to a joint appointment in the Math Dept.) Laurent Beinvenu's answer to that question was &lt;em&gt;great&lt;/em&gt;, but I think we need to rephrase how we're selling it in this opening paragraph. I'm not sure the following is a good way, but I'll just note that his answer is like a short tutorial/primer on ML-randomness (basically all it lacks is the most recent results), something which might appear in a publication like SIGACT News. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Note that the amount of effort to write such a thing for such a publication is much greater than on this site, and would take several months to go through the publication pipeline, if it happened at all.  Here we got a direct line to the source, and we got just the part of the tutorial we wanted, right away.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;(3) A list of problems that can be used to show polynomial-time hardness results seems like a great resource for graduate students and people entering that area of research fresh, but I imagine experts in that area are familiar enough with the literature to have produced much of the entire list on their own. I think it's important that the paragraph clearly recognizes the correct audience for such a question, as is already done in the first two examples.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Again, maybe (but I'm not sure) a good way to think about it is that such a list is like part of a short tutorial that might appear in a publication like SIGACT News, but with a much lower barrier to creation (but still high quality).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;(4) The last example is great.  It's universal: it applies to graduate students &lt;em&gt;and experts&lt;/em&gt;, everyone has had an experience where they wished they could do exactly this.  And on this site, you can. It's a great pre-punch-line for this paragraph (the punchline, of course, being &quot;Visit tcs.se&quot; on the next line).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="129" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" LastActivityDate="2010-10-31T16:24:53.833" CommentCount="2" CommunityOwnedDate="2010-10-31T16:24:53.833" />
./Posts.xml:565:  <row Id="596" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="587" CreationDate="2010-10-31T23:39:27.963" Score="4" Body="&lt;p&gt;Please do not remove tags mechanically just because questions are closed.  If a question is about graph theory and tagged as [graph-theory], there is no need to remove that tag if it is closed for being subjective or for some other reasons.  As &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/587/about-retagging-as-tag-removed/595#595&quot;&gt;András wrote&lt;/a&gt;, closed questions should be reasonably exposed as such to users who are trying to ask similar questions.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If a question is tagged as [graph-theory] but it is not really related to graph theory or any other reasonable topic, I think that it is perfectly fine to remove tags and just tag it as [tag-removed], unless you bump many questions at once for the sake of retagging.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;As Jukka wrote in a comment on the question, if you want to exclude closed questions from search results, add “closed:0” (without the quotation marks) to search terms.  See &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/search&quot;&gt;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/search&lt;/a&gt; for other search options.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="567" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" LastActivityDate="2010-10-31T23:54:36.827" CommentCount="0" />
./Posts.xml:566:  <row Id="597" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2010-11-01T00:31:08.743" Score="11" ViewCount="583" Body="&lt;p&gt;Jukka has &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/587/about-retagging-as-tag-removed&quot;&gt;mentioned&lt;/a&gt; a &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/search&quot;&gt;feature&lt;/a&gt; (a page for more advanced searching) that I was not aware of. Are there other less-known features that you have found useful?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="186" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" LastActivityDate="2011-11-13T00:54:05.007" Title="The less-known features" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;" AnswerCount="13" CommentCount="0" FavoriteCount="5" CommunityOwnedDate="2010-11-04T07:28:25.887" />
./Posts.xml:567:  <row Id="598" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="597" CreationDate="2010-11-01T02:14:06.090" Score="7" Body="&lt;p&gt;Stack Exchange has an experimental feature called timeline view (&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/posts/597/timeline&quot;&gt;example&lt;/a&gt;).  It is useful when you want to know when a post was made, an answer was accepted, and so on (but be careful because it does not always show the complete history).  See &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/502/useful-userscripts/508#508&quot;&gt;my answer&lt;/a&gt; to another question for more details and a link to a user script which makes the timeline view easier to use.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="567" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.560" LastActivityDate="2010-11-01T02:14:06.090" CommentCount="1" CommunityOwnedDate="2010-11-05T15:03:12.430" />
./Posts.xml:573:  <row Id="604" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="601" CreationDate="2010-11-04T13:40:24.813" Score="3" Body="&lt;p&gt;I don't know what the motivations of homework-answerers are, but from my perspective the question closing process must seem bewildering and downright mean to the homework-question-asker (I know, obviously, that this is not how it's intended.) It makes one want to be more helpful than the official closing process.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The message people get when a question gets closed is: &quot;Questions on Theoretical Computer Science are expected to generally relate to Theoretical Computer Science, within the scope defined in the faq.&quot; Not only does that not really explain that the question was closed as homework level, but the FAQ link &lt;b&gt;doesn't go to the right place&lt;/b&gt; - it goes to the Stack Exchangey FAQ &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/faq&quot;&gt;here&lt;/a&gt;, which then has a link to the &quot;Offical FAQ&quot; which then has only an indirect reference to &quot;Typical homework problems in textbooks&quot; being too basic. So that's two or three links to get the first oblique reference to the real reason why a question question was closed. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Is there a way to make Tsuyoshi Ito's comment linked to above or Kaveh's paraphrase actually appear on closed homework questions?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="1024" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" LastActivityDate="2010-11-04T13:40:24.813" CommentCount="2" />
./Posts.xml:576:  <row Id="607" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2010-11-04T20:40:27.483" Score="9" ViewCount="190" Body="&lt;p&gt;In a recent question “&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2606/randomized-algorithm-that-looks-deterministic&quot;&gt;Randomized algorithm that “looks” deterministic?&lt;/a&gt;” by arnab, he posted an &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2606/randomized-algorithm-that-looks-deterministic/2629#2629&quot;&gt;answer&lt;/a&gt; directly communicated by Shafi Goldwasser with the following note:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;Please do not upvote this answer, as it's not mine.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;(This is not the first time I have seen this kind of note on cstheory.stackexchange.com, although I do not remember when and where I saw a similar note before.  I use arnab’s post as an example.)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;It is perfectly fine (and necessary for honesty) to state that the answer is provided by someone else.  But the “please do not upvote this answer” part makes me &lt;em&gt;hmmm&lt;/em&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I guess that he put this note because he considered that he should not earn reputation points by posting an answer provided by someone else.  Although I understand his humbleness, I do not think that it is a good idea to say “do not upvote” for several reasons:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;In my opinion, this answer is good and it should be listed in a higher place on the page than score 0.  In general, a good answer should be listed in an earlier place.  That is how Stack Exchange sites work.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Avoiding upvoting a good answer just because of reputation points seems missing the point, because reputation points are not of primary importance anyway.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;If we have this note as a norm, I am afraid that in the future, &lt;em&gt;not&lt;/em&gt; stating “do not upvote” in an answer provided by someone else may be viewed as inconsiderate.  This seems like a wrong standard to me.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I hope that people will not mind if an asker or someone else earns some rep points by posting a good answer communicated by someone else.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;What is your opinion?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;(As an aside, an answer can be marked as community wiki to avoid reputation gain (or loss).  But note that the primary purpose of marking a post as community wiki is to let other users edit the post, so that is a slight abuse of the system.)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;hr&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Added note about community wiki&lt;/strong&gt;.  As I wrote above, I am aware that a poster can avoid gaining (or losing) reputation points by marking a post as community wiki (CW).  However, this has its own drawback if the poster does not intend to make editing easier.  Moreover, this does not solve the item 3 above; I do not think that we should give a poster a pressure to mark an answer provided by someone else as CW.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="567" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" LastActivityDate="2010-11-05T08:00:49.050" Title="Upvoting an answer provided by someone else" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;reputation&gt;&lt;answers&gt;" AnswerCount="2" CommentCount="5" FavoriteCount="1" />
./Posts.xml:578:  <row Id="609" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="597" CreationDate="2010-11-05T03:32:48.247" Score="5" Body="&lt;p&gt;This is not a less-known feature but a less-known practice.  I hope that this belongs here anyway.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/59445/recent-feature-changes-on-stack-overflow&quot;&gt;Changes of features and policies on Stack Overflow are listed in a thread on Meta Stack Overflow&lt;/a&gt;. ./Posts.xml:582:  <row Id="613" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="612" CreationDate="2010-11-05T11:59:03.280" Score="1" Body="&lt;p&gt;(I do not use a feed reader much, and I may be missing the point.)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I am not sure if the feed for unanswered questions is meaningful.  Since every question is obviously unanswered when it is posted, you will receive every question if your feed reader checks for the update to the feed frequently enough.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If the feed includes only unanswered questions which are at least a few days old, it might be useful, but that is at least something different from the &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/unanswered&quot;&gt;page of unanswered questions&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;That said, there are several (almost duplicate) discussions on Meta Stack Overflow for feeds for unanswered questions:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/13849/rss-for-unansweredtagged-questions&quot;&gt;RSS for unanswered+tagged questions?&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/57300/rss-for-stackoverflows-unanswered-questions-that-matches-my-only-favorite-tags&quot;&gt;RSS for Stackoverflow&amp;#39;s unanswered questions that matches my only favorite tags?&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/41696/why-is-there-no-rss-feed-for-unanswered-tagged-tagname&quot;&gt;Why is there no RSS feed for /unanswered/tagged/tagname?&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/42525/anyway-to-get-a-rss-feed-for-unanswered-questions&quot;&gt;Add an RSS feed for unanswered questions&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In the first link, someone points out a service to convert a usual page to a feed.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="567" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.537" LastActivityDate="2010-11-05T11:59:03.280" CommentCount="4" />
./Posts.xml:587:  <row Id="618" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="65" CreationDate="2010-11-07T13:47:30.787" Score="5" Body="&lt;p&gt;I think that one week is a good time to consider crossposting.  If you do so, please add links &lt;em&gt;in both directions&lt;/em&gt; so that people who read your question at either place will have a chance to know everything posted at the other place.  You can add a comment to the older post if you do not want to bump the question on the top page.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Since the &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/231#231&quot;&gt;FAQ entry about crossposting&lt;/a&gt; links here, I would like to express my opinion about something other than what is asked in this question, namely about crossposting in a short period of time (such as one day).  I feel that it is unfair that some people crosspost a question in more than one place, usually MathOverflow and cstheory.stackexchange.com.  Of course everyone wants to get his/her question answered as quickly as possible, and exposing the question in many places increases the chance.  But they should refrain from doing that, like the rest of us.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Some new users seem to crosspost questions because they do not know where the best place to ask is.  I do not think that it is the right reason for crossposting, either.  For them, I would recommend the following:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Read each of the candidate websites a little so that you can make an educated guess about where the best place for your question is.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Post your question at only one website.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;If you do not get a satisfactory answer in one week or so, crosspost the question on another website if you want to.  Do not forget to link in both directions!&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="567" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" LastActivityDate="2010-11-07T15:41:51.233" CommentCount="4" />
./Posts.xml:591:  <row Id="623" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAnswerId="624" CreationDate="2010-11-07T22:33:44.837" Score="2" ViewCount="168" Body="&lt;p&gt;The comments and links to used when closing an elementary/homework question. ./Posts.xml:593:  <row Id="625" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2010-11-07T23:05:44.593" Score="10" ViewCount="254" Body="&lt;p&gt;As we're now one week away from the end of the 90-day beta period, I thought I'd re-raise the issue of our &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/522/beta-period-progress&quot;&gt;beta period progress&lt;/a&gt;.  So, what news?  &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;(This question really is about news, rather than about how we can bolster our progress, which I think was pretty well covered in the previous question.)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;At least on the &lt;a href=&quot;http://area51.stackexchange.com/proposals/8766/theoretical-computer-science&quot;&gt;proposal site&lt;/a&gt; we are no longer listed as &quot;worrying&quot; in any category, but still only &quot;okay&quot; in terms of questions and visits per day.  Under &quot;avid users&quot; we're still listed as &quot;okay&quot; but we're very close to &quot;excellent.&quot;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Does anyone have any new news from our SE overlords?  Say, for example, what's the likelihood that in a week this site will just disappear?&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Any progress on getting officially sponsored/hosted/some other arrangement by ACM/SIGACT?&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Does the fact that we're in talks with SIGACT (and by &quot;we&quot; here I think I mean Suresh) mean that SE would delay any potential demolition until we finish talking with SIGACT?&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;...?&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="129" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" LastActivityDate="2010-11-08T07:10:51.837" Title="Update on beta period progress? ./Posts.xml:594:  <row Id="626" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="625" CreationDate="2010-11-07T23:25:01.673" Score="6" Body="&lt;p&gt;Judging from the blog posts “&lt;a href=&quot;http://blog.stackoverflow.com/2010/10/when-will-my-site-graduate/&quot;&gt;When will my site graduate?&lt;/a&gt;” by Robert Cartaino and “&lt;a href=&quot;http://blog.stackoverflow.com/2010/09/pruning-season/&quot;&gt;Pruning season&lt;/a&gt;” by Joel Spolsky, it is highly unlikely that the website is shut down in a week.  See also other websites on Area 51 which have been in public beta for more than 90 days.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;At the same time, it is unlikely that we graduate the beta in a week because the strategy seems that the websites in all-green graduate first.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;My guess is that the number “90 days” has little real effect.  We should continue to be a good community, and I guess that we will graduate the beta eventually.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;em&gt;Added&lt;/em&gt;: By the way, “graduating beta” does not only mean that we have our own site design and that we have probably less chance to get shut down.  Actually, from the system point of view, the most relevant effect of graduating beta is that the &lt;a href=&quot;https://math.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/984/promotion-implies-higher-rep-needed-for-privileges-and-nobody-has-such&quot;&gt;thresholds for some privileged actions are raised&lt;/a&gt; from the beta level to the &lt;a href=&quot;https://math.stackexchange.com/privileges&quot;&gt;normal level&lt;/a&gt;.  This means that it is probably not good to go out of beta if we do not have many users with high reputation points.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="567" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:19:18.947" LastActivityDate="2010-11-07T23:35:40.883" CommentCount="8" />

./Posts.xml:596:  <row Id="628" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAnswerId="684" CreationDate="2010-11-08T00:02:19.550" Score="7" ViewCount="193" Body="&lt;p&gt;Editing tags is not adding any information to a question/answers, it is a mainly organizational task. It is not an interesting activity for most users. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;It should be possible to see questions sorted based on the time that last significant activity is performed on them. And in place of stating who has performed last activity on the question, it should say who has performed the last significant activity on them.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The main example of &lt;strong&gt;insignificant/uninteresting activity&lt;/strong&gt; is &lt;em&gt;tag edits&lt;/em&gt;, but small edits to questions/answers (like spelling corrections) might also be considered insignificant and uninteresting.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;hr&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I have posted it on SO meta:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/69659/a-page-for-questions-sorted-based-on-last-significant-modification-not-tag-edits&quot;&gt;A page for questions sorted based on last significant modification (not tag-edits)&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="186" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-20T10:29:37.593" LastActivityDate="2011-04-25T11:43:17.317" Title="A page for most recent significatly modified questions (not tag-edits) and who has performed it" Tags="&lt;feature-request&gt;" AnswerCount="2" CommentCount="2" />
./Posts.xml:597:  <row Id="629" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="597" CreationDate="2010-11-08T00:21:17.833" Score="2" Body="&lt;p&gt;The site's &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/privileges/&quot;&gt;privileges page&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;It show the reputation required for performing various task.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="186" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" LastActivityDate="2010-11-08T00:21:17.833" CommentCount="2" CommunityOwnedDate="2010-11-08T00:21:17.833" />
./Posts.xml:600:  <row Id="632" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="631" CreationDate="2010-11-08T01:32:47.197" Score="10" Body="&lt;h2&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://math.stackexchange.com/&quot;&gt;Math.SE&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/h2&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Non-research level theoretical computer science/math questions, check their &lt;a href=&quot;https://math.stackexchange.com/faq&quot;&gt;FAQ&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="186" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:19:18.947" LastActivityDate="2010-11-08T02:20:05.500" CommentCount="2" CommunityOwnedDate="2010-11-08T01:32:47.197" />
./Posts.xml:604:  <row Id="636" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2010-11-08T22:26:30.927" Score="-3" ViewCount="373" Body="&lt;p&gt;Current policy is to close all questions that &quot;feel like homework&quot; to at least five (high-reputated) people. Those more militant even downvote answers given by others even if those were hints rather than complete solutions. I want to argue for stopping this crusade and allowing all kind of questions that are posed well (&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/559/another-go-at-scope-of-desirable-questions/&quot;&gt;to be defined&lt;/a&gt;) and concern TCS. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;First, rational reasons:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;We cannot for sure distinguish homework from other questions¹&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Getting help/inspiration is not always forbidden, sometimes even encouraged&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;We are not responsible for other people cheating&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Some people are willing to help with low-level question&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Second, opinions:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;By providing help for homework questions we can reach new users&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;We should let people help that want to&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;A well-posed question deserves at least some hints&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Such questions will continue to pop up, always, thanks to Google. We may as well answer them.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The only two reasons I ever read against homework/low-level questions are cheating and scope. Cheating I consider not an issue (see above) and scope should, imho, be defined by active users. If such answer low-level questions, so be it. Those who have some pure utopia in their minds should evaluate wether or not they really speak for most people and/or the greater good. Using RSS it is easy enough to preselect questions based on their titles.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Your thoughts, please.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Ad (1): Let me link to some accepted questions one might consider as homework level:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2430/proving-skip-lists-strongly-weight-balanced-in-expectation&quot;&gt;Proving skip-lists strongly weight-balanced in expectation&lt;/a&gt; (skip lists and more complex analyses were covered in a Master course I took)&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2398/writing-universal-recursive-function&quot;&gt;Writing universal recursive function&lt;/a&gt; (content in the very first Bachelor TCS course)&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2781/is-the-following-problem-np-hard&quot;&gt;Is the following problem NP-Hard?&lt;/a&gt; (although allegedly no homework, simple NP-hardness proofs are Bachelor level)&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2537/is-there-a-non-turing-complete-model-of-computation-whose-halting-problem-is-unde&quot;&gt;Is there a non Turing-complete model of computation whose halting problem is undecidable?&lt;/a&gt; (could very well be asked in basic TCS courses for intuition building)&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="1546" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" LastActivityDate="2010-11-09T02:40:54.370" Title="On the Feasibility of Homework Questions" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;scope&gt;&lt;asking-questions&gt;&lt;homework&gt;" AnswerCount="3" CommentCount="23" FavoriteCount="1" />
./Posts.xml:608:  <row Id="640" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2010-11-09T20:09:43.880" Score="1" ViewCount="185" Body="&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Possible Duplicate:&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br&gt;&#xA;  &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/293/latex-math-and-show-n-more-comments&quot;&gt;Latex math and &amp;ldquo;show N more comments&amp;rdquo;&lt;/a&gt;  &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Math mode works fine -- if slow -- for me until I click on &quot;show more comments&quot;; then, all renderings in this comment thread are again replaced with LaTeX code. Other comment threads on the same question as well as question and answer texts are not affected.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Please confirm this (users) resp fix this (tech admins).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="1546" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" LastActivityDate="2010-11-12T10:46:06.817" Title="Math Mode Breaks When Showing All Comments" Tags="&lt;bug&gt;&lt;status-completed&gt;" AnswerCount="0" CommentCount="1" ClosedDate="2010-11-10T06:02:03.820" />
./Posts.xml:609:  <row Id="641" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2010-11-10T02:42:17.967" Score="7" ViewCount="158" Body="&lt;p&gt;Currently 50 questions are tagged as [&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/np-completeness&quot;&gt;np-completeness&lt;/a&gt;] and 20 questions as [&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/np-hardness&quot;&gt;np-hardness&lt;/a&gt;].  Among them, &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/np-hardness+np-completeness&quot;&gt;7 questions are tagged as both&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I think that the difference of these two tags is too subtle for the distinction to be useful.  Therefore, I propose to merge [np-completeness] to [np-hardness].  Note the direction; I am proposing to make the &lt;em&gt;more popular tag&lt;/em&gt; a synonym for the &lt;em&gt;less popular tag&lt;/em&gt;, which is different from the usual proposal.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I know that NP-completeness and NP-hardness are two different notions.  However, in most cases, questions tagged as [np-completeness] ask whether a certain problem which is trivially in NP is NP-complete or not.  Therefore, the main point is whether the problem is NP-hard or not.  On the other hand, some of the questions tagged as [np-hardness] are about search or optimization problems, which are themselves not in NP (according to the standard definition of NP as a class of decision problems).  But the difference between search/optimization problems and decision problems is a technicality in most cases and should not be important in the classification of questions.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Some questions tagged as [np-hardness] ask about problems which are not known to be in NP.  Therefore, merging in the other direction would make the tag awkward for some questions.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;What do you think?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;hr&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;em&gt;Update&lt;/em&gt;: It has reached +4 with 4 upvotes and 0 downvotes, but there are two negative comments.  What should I do?  Let me clarify my points:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;We should merge [np-completeness] and [np-hardness] into one tag because for most questions, their distinction depends not on the essence of a question but on a particular way a question is stated.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;We should not merge them into [np-completeness] because there are rare cases where the [np-completeness] tag would be awkward.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If merging the two into the [np-hardness] tag is not desired, an alternative suggestion is to merge them into a new tag, for example [np-complete-np-hard].  But this is certainly clumsy.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="567" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" LastActivityDate="2010-11-10T16:27:20.463" Title="Merge [np-completeness] to [np-hardness]?" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;status-completed&gt;&lt;retag-request&gt;" AnswerCount="0" CommentCount="8" />
./Posts.xml:610:  <row Id="642" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAnswerId="643" CreationDate="2010-11-10T22:28:58.010" Score="7" ViewCount="164" Body="&lt;p&gt;If I posted a question, and I got an answer that was very good, then I got another answer that is actually more to the point, shorter, easier, and more intuitive. In that case should I change the accepted answer or it would be frowned at ?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In particular I am talking about this &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2853/are-there-any-proofs-the-undecidability-of-the-halting-problem-that-does-not-depe&quot;&gt;question&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="201" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" LastActivityDate="2010-11-10T22:38:46.390" Title="When is it appropriate to change the accepted answer" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;accepted-answer&gt;" AnswerCount="1" CommentCount="0" />
./Posts.xml:615:  <row Id="647" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="293" CreationDate="2010-11-11T20:22:21.040" Score="2" Body="&lt;p&gt;(Part of this answer had been previously posted as a comment, but I decided to move it to an answer with additional information about user scripts.)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The same issue has been raised also on meta.math.stackexchange.com: &lt;a href=&quot;https://math.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/397/tex-formatting-in-other-comments-in-the-same-post-is-lost-when-the-comment-list-i&quot;&gt;TeX formatting in other comments in the same post is lost when the comment list is updated&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;On that page, &lt;a href=&quot;https://math.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/397/tex-formatting-in-other-comments-in-the-same-post-is-lost-when-the-comment-list-i/650#650&quot;&gt;KennyTM posted a user script as a workaround&lt;/a&gt; (great!).  I posted there a &lt;a href=&quot;https://math.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/397/tex-formatting-in-other-comments-in-the-same-post-is-lost-when-the-comment-list-i/1114#1114&quot;&gt;modified version of it&lt;/a&gt; which should be safer in principle in case *.stackexchange.com be cracked.  To use a user script with Firefox, you need the add-on &lt;a href=&quot;https://addons.mozilla.org/firefox/addon/748/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;Greasemonkey&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="567" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:44:21.953" LastActivityDate="2010-11-11T20:22:21.040" CommentCount="0" />
./Posts.xml:617:  <row Id="649" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAnswerId="650" CreationDate="2010-11-12T17:32:20.623" Score="7" ViewCount="166" Body="&lt;p&gt;I have seen (and I have also used myself) the phrase “research-level questions in theoretical computer science” to describe the scope of cstheory.stackexchange.com.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;However, thinking about it, I believe that the word “research-level” in this context means something like “which arise or can arise in research &lt;em&gt;in TCS&lt;/em&gt;”.  In other words, if a TCS question arises in research in an applied field and it is too easy for TCS research, I do &lt;em&gt;not&lt;/em&gt; think that it is usually called a “research-level question in TCS”.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;This seems too restrictive given that the consensus, though still being developed, seems to be to allow easy questions in TCS as long as they are not something like homework or typical exercises in textbooks and the asker has done reasonable due diligence (see the discussion “&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/636/on-the-feasibility-of-homework-questions&quot;&gt;On the feasibility of homework questions&lt;/a&gt;” started by Raphael and the comments on the question “&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2781/is-the-following-problem-np-hard&quot;&gt;Is the following problem NP-Hard?&lt;/a&gt;”).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Therefore, I want a better description of the scope.  What is your take?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="567" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" LastActivityDate="2010-11-12T18:43:22.820" Title="Better description of the scope than “research-level questions in theoretical computer science”" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;scope&gt;" AnswerCount="1" CommentCount="0" FavoriteCount="2" />

./Posts.xml:621:  <row Id="653" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2010-11-13T19:35:47.917" Score="2" ViewCount="95" Body="&lt;p&gt;I recently opened an account over at &lt;a href=&quot;https://softwareengineering.stackexchange.com/&quot;&gt;https://softwareengineering.stackexchange.com/&lt;/a&gt;. I associated my account there with my account here. I then opened CStheory again, and I got a red banner saying &quot;You've associated your Theoretical Computer Science and Theoretical Computer Science accounts: +100 reputation&quot;. I made a printscreen in case it turns out to be useful.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;This is obviously a bug. I'm almost sure this 100 rep was intended to be awarded to the account I just created. My account on this site gained 100 rep (I went from 358 to 458).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Edit&lt;/strong&gt;: I tried reassociating all my accounts as per Tsuyoshi Ito's answer, which gave the missing 100 rep to my Programming account. I still have 100 too much rep on my CStheory account though.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="988" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-12T07:31:26.050" LastActivityDate="2010-11-13T23:04:57.397" Title="Account association bug" Tags="&lt;bug&gt;&lt;status-completed&gt;&lt;reputation&gt;&lt;user-accounts&gt;" AnswerCount="1" CommentCount="5" />
./Posts.xml:622:  <row Id="654" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="653" CreationDate="2010-11-13T21:33:44.600" Score="1" Body="&lt;p&gt;Reading &lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/57462/is-reputation-100-for-having-at-least-200-on-another-site-retroactive/57463#57463&quot;&gt;this answer&lt;/a&gt; by Jaydles on Meta Stack Overflow suggests that you may be able to recover the lost +100 bonus by &lt;strong&gt;deassociating and reassociating&lt;/strong&gt; your accounts.  Note that &lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/5909/how-do-reputation-bonuses-for-associations-between-accounts-work/5930#5930&quot;&gt;another answer&lt;/a&gt; by Daniel Moura to another question states that you have to start the reassociation on the site where you have ≥200 rep points to get +100 bonus.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The situation in the questions on Meta is certainly different from yours, so be warned that there might be an unexpected consequence.  You may want to bring the issue to Meta Stack Overflow so that more people familiar with the SE systems can give you an advice.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="567" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-20T10:29:37.593" LastActivityDate="2010-11-13T21:33:44.600" CommentCount="2" />
./Posts.xml:623:  <row Id="655" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2010-11-15T10:09:32.977" Score="6" ViewCount="206" Body="&lt;p&gt;This is more a suggestion than a question, though answers and comments are welcome.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In question &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/341/what-should-the-tag-wikis-contain&quot;&gt;What should the tag wikis contain?&lt;/a&gt;, Robin suggests the preferred content for tag wikis. Unfortunately, most tags I checked did not have any wiki.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I added several tag wikis, and felt like suggesting this to other colleagues as well. I believe at least the top-20 tags must have wikis.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="873" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" LastActivityDate="2011-03-25T21:21:22.037" Title="Adding Tag Wikis" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;tag-wiki&gt;" AnswerCount="4" CommentCount="0" FavoriteCount="1" />
./Posts.xml:624:  <row Id="656" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="655" CreationDate="2010-11-15T16:05:20.020" Score="2" Body="&lt;p&gt;There are restrictions on editing tag-wikis. For example, I want to add the following to &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/tag-removed&quot;&gt;&lt;code&gt;[tag-removed]&lt;/code&gt;&lt;/a&gt; but I can't, and I don't think anyone other than moderators can edit it since there are not really answered:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;This tag should only be used when there are no other appropriate tags. If you remove tags from a question and can't find any suitable tag to add, use [tag-removed]. The tag should not be combined with other tags. This tag is not intended to be used for closed question, please don't replace the tags on a closed question if the current tags assigned to the question are appropriate. (Please try to replace tags with [tag-removed] only when the question is already on the front page.) &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;We may also want to add something like this: &#xA;(this is a trick used by moderators on MO to avoid bumping up questions when moderators get rid of tags which shouldn't be tags in the first place, for example meta-tags like: [math], [cs], [general], [advanced], ...)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;[tag-removed] is also used by moderators to silently get rid of a tag which should not exists by merging the tag with [tag-removed]. Please remove [tag-removed] when it is combined with other tags (try to be gentle and avoid removing [tag-removed] aggressively from questions which are not on the front page.)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="186" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" LastActivityDate="2010-11-20T16:08:46.883" CommentCount="1" CommunityOwnedDate="2010-11-15T16:05:20.020" />

tags&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/advice&quot;&gt;&lt;strike&gt;advice&lt;/strike&gt;&lt;/a&gt; (it is a complexity concept and should not be used for requesting advice on something)&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;tags which should not be tags&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="186" LastEditorUserId="-1" ./Posts.xml:626:  <row Id="658" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2010-11-16T19:38:35.697" Score="2" ViewCount="135" Body="&lt;p&gt;In &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2075/bounded-input-bijections-of-infinite-sequences&quot;&gt;this question&lt;/a&gt;, I offered a bounty, but there are only two answers which really qualify as non-answers.  I asked in a comment for the OP to post an answer so I could award him the bounty for asking a cool question, but he hasn't done so.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Would it be kosher for me to post a non-answer myself, award myself the bounty, and then put a bounty on another question?  Would the software even permit that? ./Posts.xml:631:  <row Id="663" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2010-11-17T17:01:56.227" Score="2" ViewCount="181" Body="&lt;p&gt;What does the following message mean?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;closed as off topic by [Someone], [Someone], [Someone], [Someone], [Someone] [Date]&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;  &#xA;  &lt;p&gt;Questions on Theoretical Computer Science are expected to generally relate to Theoretical Computer Science, within the scope defined in the &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/faq&quot;&gt;faq&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="567" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" LastActivityDate="2010-11-17T17:14:10.757" Title="What does “closed as off topic” mean?" Tags="&lt;support&gt;&lt;faq&gt;&lt;closing&gt;&lt;close-reasons&gt;" AnswerCount="1" CommentCount="7" />
./Posts.xml:632:  <row Id="664" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="663" CreationDate="2010-11-17T17:03:19.957" Score="1" Body="&lt;p&gt;When a question is closed, no additional answers may be posted to it.  A user who votes to close a question must select one of the following reasons:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Exact duplicate&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Off topic&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Belongs to meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Subjective and argumentative&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Not a real question&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Too localized&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Since questions on cstheory.stackexchange.com are expected to be research-level questions in theoretical computer science, “off topic” means anything that fails to satisfy this criterion.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Even a question in theoretical computer science will be considered as off topic if, for example, it is too basic to be research-level.  &lt;strong&gt;Forget about the system-generated boilerplate message.&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;A question being closed as off topic means that the question does not belong to cstheory.stackexchange.com.  It does not necessarily mean that the question is bad.  For example, a question about programming (actually writing code) will be probably closed as off topic on cstheory.stackexchange.com even if it is very interesting.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;For general information about closed questions and the meanings of other close reasons on Stack Exchange websites, please refer to &lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/10582/what-is-a-closed-question/10583#10583&quot;&gt;this post&lt;/a&gt; on Meta Stack Exchange.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Related:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/361#361&quot;&gt;My (wonderful!) question was closed! What do I do now?&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/235#235&quot;&gt;What kind of questions are too basic?&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Other discussions/questions posted on meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com about the &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/scope&quot;&gt;scope of cstheory.stackexchange.com&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="567" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-20T10:29:37.593" LastActivityDate="2010-11-17T17:03:19.957" CommentCount="0" CommunityOwnedDate="2010-11-17T17:03:32.937" />
./Posts.xml:633:  <row Id="665" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2010-11-18T02:36:04.230" Score="3" ViewCount="116" Body="&lt;p&gt;Here is a &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/3034/pairwise-independent-gaussians&quot;&gt;question&lt;/a&gt; cross-posted to MO and answered &lt;a href=&quot;https://mathoverflow.net/questions/46180/how-to-sample-pairwise-independent-gaussians&quot;&gt;there&lt;/a&gt;. The OP has accepted the answer on MO. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Should we ask OP to post an answer with a link to the answer on the other site (alternatively copy the answer from the other site) and accept it so the question does not remain unanswered on cstheory?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;A previous &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2611/complexity-of-finding-the-eigendecomposition-of-a-matrix&quot;&gt;case&lt;/a&gt; of the situation where another suer has posted an answer with linking to the answer on MO.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="186" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:57:54.527" LastActivityDate="2010-11-18T12:37:38.413" Title="What to do with cross-posted questions answered on another site?" ./Posts.xml:634:  <row Id="666" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2010-11-18T04:04:32.067" Score="2" ViewCount="159" Body="&lt;p&gt;In the past the &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/advice&quot;&gt;&lt;code&gt;[advice]&lt;/code&gt;&lt;/a&gt; tag has been used for requesting advice (i.e. confused with [advice-request] tag).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Peter &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/655/adding-tag-wikis/657#657&quot;&gt;suggested&lt;/a&gt; replacing [advice] with some other tag. Should we replace [advice] with some other tag and make [advice] a synonym to &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/advice-request&quot;&gt;&lt;code&gt;[advice-request]&lt;/code&gt;&lt;/a&gt;? If the answer is positive, what should be the new tag?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I copy the suggestions here:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;[non-uniform] &lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Multiple tags? advice-Karp-Lipton ... quantum-advice ... advice-(fillinblank)&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Another possible replacement:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;advice-(complexity)&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="186" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" LastActivityDate="2010-11-22T09:57:51.410" Title="Replacing the [advice] tag" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;status-completed&gt;&lt;tags&gt;" AnswerCount="5" CommentCount="11" />
./Posts.xml:636:  <row Id="668" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="666" CreationDate="2010-11-18T05:16:08.553" Score="3" Body="&lt;p&gt;I agree that the tag &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/advice&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;advice&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;advice&lt;/a&gt; should be renamed.  How about [computation-with-advice]?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;em&gt;Added&lt;/em&gt;: Should we have two separate tags for computation with advice and for nonuniform computation, or one tag?
