I do not have an opinion which is better.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="567" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" LastActivityDate="2010-11-20T18:12:32.097" CommentCount="1" />
./Posts.xml:641:  <row Id="673" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2010-11-18T23:15:33.910" Score="5" ViewCount="238" Body="&lt;p&gt;In the light of &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/665/what-to-do-with-cross-posted-questions-answered-on-another-site&quot;&gt;this discussion on crossposted questions&lt;/a&gt;, I'm wondering if we should revisit our crossposting policy. &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/231#231&quot;&gt;The current policy i&lt;/a&gt;s:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;Crossposting from MathOverflow is&#xA;  perfectly fine, as long as they aren't&#xA;  done in parallel. That is, if you post&#xA;  a question on one site, you should&#xA;  only post to the other site after you&#xA;  have not received a satisfactory&#xA;  answer for some time. As a courtesy,&#xA;  if you post your question here after&#xA;  trying MathOverflow, please try to&#xA;  integrate in your question the answers&#xA;  you received on MathOverflow (even if&#xA;  they did not answer everything).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I'm proposing that we delete the statements &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;as long as they aren't&#xA;  done in parallel. That is, if you post&#xA;  a question on one site, you should&#xA;  only post to the other site after you&#xA;  have not received a satisfactory&#xA;  answer for some time.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The rationale is that &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;people are crossposting simultaneously anyway, and it seems tiresome to police users who for the most part have good intentions&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Based on the above discussion, it seems that users don't have problems posting related answers on either site, so the duplication problem isn't that severe&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;It might even be viewed as a success of our site, as well as a natural reflection of the close ties to math, that this happens. &lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Thoughts ? &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Update: Current view (as Peter Shor recommends, in the light of discussion on MO) is: keep the policy as is, but don't come down too hard on cross posting (but definitely encourage people to wait)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="80" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" LastActivityDate="2010-11-23T22:57:28.917" Title="Changing policy on crossposting" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;status-declined&gt;&lt;cross-posting&gt;" AnswerCount="2" CommentCount="4" />
./Posts.xml:646:  <row Id="678" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="597" CreationDate="2010-11-20T18:25:45.930" Score="5" Body="&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/66965/is-there-some-markup-to-post-tags/69482#69482&quot;&gt;Markup for tags&lt;/a&gt;.  They automatically link to the list of tagged questions.  This is sometimes useful on Meta and in tag wikis.  Examples:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;code&gt;[tag:graph-theory]&lt;/code&gt; → &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/graph-theory&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;graph-theory&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;graph-theory&lt;/a&gt; (points to a tag on parent)&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;code&gt;[meta-tag:scope]&lt;/code&gt; → &lt;a href=&quot;/questions/tagged/scope&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;scope&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;scope&lt;/a&gt; (points to a tag on Meta; only available on Meta)&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;code&gt;[tag:this-tag-does-not-exist]&lt;/code&gt; → &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/this-tag-does-not-exist&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;this-tag-does-not-exist&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;this-tag-does-not-exist&lt;/a&gt; (also works for a nonexistent tag)&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="567" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-20T10:29:37.593" LastActivityDate="2011-02-26T22:29:59.820" CommentCount="2" CommunityOwnedDate="2010-11-20T18:25:45.930" />
./Posts.xml:647:  <row Id="679" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAnswerId="683" CreationDate="2010-11-20T20:55:22.613" Score="3" ViewCount="147" Body="&lt;p&gt;The &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/tags&quot;&gt;tags page&lt;/a&gt; says “&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/np-hardness&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;np-hardness&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;np-hardness&lt;/a&gt; × 70,” but the list of questions shows only 64.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="567" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" LastActivityDate="2010-11-23T00:14:26.087" Title="The number of questions tagged as [np-hardness]" Tags="&lt;bug&gt;&lt;status-completed&gt;&lt;tags&gt;" AnswerCount="1" CommentCount="2" />
./Posts.xml:648:  <row Id="680" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAnswerId="682" CreationDate="2010-11-21T18:24:50.740" Score="4" ViewCount="130" Body="&lt;p&gt;How should the tag &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/graph-algorithms&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;graph-algorithms&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;graph-algorithms&lt;/a&gt; be used?  In particular, should it be used together with &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/graph-theory&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;graph-theory&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;graph-theory&lt;/a&gt;, should it be used exclusively of &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/graph-theory&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;graph-theory&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;graph-theory&lt;/a&gt;, or does it depend on questions?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Currently, I fail to see any difference between the questions tagged as &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/graph-algorithms&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;graph-algorithms&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;graph-algorithms&lt;/a&gt; and the &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/ds.algorithms+graph-theory&quot;&gt;questions&lt;/a&gt; tagged both as &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/ds.algorithms&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;ds.algorithms&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;ds.algorithms&lt;/a&gt; and &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/graph-theory&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;graph-theory&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;graph-theory&lt;/a&gt;.  Many questions are actually given all of these three tags.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If there is a guideline how to apply these tags to questions about graph algorithms, it is probably better to explain it in tag wiki.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="567" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" LastActivityDate="2010-11-22T06:39:35.607" Title="How should the tag [graph-algorithms] be used?" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;tags&gt;" AnswerCount="1" CommentCount="2" />
./Posts.xml:649:  <row Id="681" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="655" CreationDate="2010-11-22T00:15:38.973" Score="2" Body="&lt;p&gt;There is nothing wrong with writing tag wikis if someone wants to.  That said, I do not find it “unfortunate” that many tags lack wiki.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;For some tags, it is very desirable to have some explanation.  For example, the meaning of the tag &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/qma&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;qma&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;qma&lt;/a&gt; is unclear to those who are not familiar with the complexity class QMA, but renaming it to something like “quantum-merlin-arthur” makes the meaning of the tag less clear to those who are familiar with the concept, so using the tag wiki (actually its one-line summary which is shown on the question list page) is very appropriate.  Another example is &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/csp&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;csp&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;csp&lt;/a&gt;; renaming it to “constraint-satisfaction-problem” might have been better, but the system does not support this long tag.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Some tags have closely related tags which may be more appropriate for particular questions (such as &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/approximation-algorithms&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;approximation-algorithms&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;approximation-algorithms&lt;/a&gt;, to which &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/approximation-hardness&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;approximation-hardness&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;approximation-hardness&lt;/a&gt; is a possible alternative).  Other tags deserve some explanation of usage (such as &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/big-list&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;big-list&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;big-list&lt;/a&gt; and &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/open-problem&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;open-problem&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;open-problem&lt;/a&gt;).  I do not think that tag wiki is a very effective place to write this kind of explanation, but we do not have many choices anyway, so I think that writing tag wiki is one of the best options available.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Other than these cases, it seems to me that tag wiki is completely optional.  As I said, there is nothing wrong with writing tag wikis if someone wants to, but I do not think that tag wiki is very much needed.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="567" LastEditorUserId="567" LastEditDate="2010-11-22T00:37:43.953" LastActivityDate="2010-11-22T00:37:43.953" CommentCount="0" />
./Posts.xml:650:  <row Id="682" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="680" CreationDate="2010-11-22T06:39:35.607" Score="4" Body="&lt;p&gt;In general, we need the most specific tag relating to the question. So I can easily imagine graph-algorithms being more specific than graph-theory. Also, ds.algorithms is special in that it's an arxiv tag, and we have desired as far as possible to keep at least one arxiv tag for each question. So I'd say the main distinction is between graph-theory and graph.algorithms, and the wiki for graph-theory could say something like&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;If your question pertains specifically&#xA;  to algorithms on graphs, you should&#xA;  use the more specific&#xA;  &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/graph-algorithms&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;graph-algorithms&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;graph-algorithms&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;and the wiki for graph-algorithms could say something like&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;This tag is specifically for&#xA;  algorithms on graphs. For more general&#xA;  graph theory questions, please use&#xA;  &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/graph-theory&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;graph-theory&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;graph-theory&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;ds.algorithms itself should emphasize that it's an arxiv tag, with something like&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;ds.algorithms is a component of the&#xA;  arxiv cs.ds categorization, and should&#xA;  be used on all questions that relate&#xA;  to the design and analysis of&#xA;  algorithms. While the design and&#xA;  analysis of data-structures also&#xA;  includes algorithms, the more specific&#xA;  &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/ds.data-structures&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;ds.data-structures&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;ds.data-structures&lt;/a&gt; should be&#xA;  used for those questions. For&#xA;  algorithms in computational geometry&#xA;  for example (which has its own&#xA;  top-level tag &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/cg.comp-geom&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;cg.comp-geom&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;cg.comp-geom&lt;/a&gt;,&#xA;  algorithmic questions should use both&#xA;  ds.algorithms and cg.comp-geom.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="80" LastActivityDate="2010-11-22T06:39:35.607" CommentCount="1" />
./Posts.xml:653:  <row Id="685" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2010-11-23T18:42:15.553" Score="7" ViewCount="205" Body="&lt;p&gt;We have an informal policy that all questions should have &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/228#228&quot;&gt;at least one top level arxiv tag&lt;/a&gt;. However, &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/quantum-computing&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;quantum-computing&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;quantum-computing&lt;/a&gt; appears with all kinds of other tags, many of which are not arxiv tags. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;My understanding is that the &lt;em&gt;home&lt;/em&gt; for quantum computing on the arxiv is &lt;a href=&quot;http://arxiv.org/archive/quant-ph&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;quant-ph&lt;/a&gt;. If that's the case, should we require all quantum-computing questions to be labelled quant-ph in addition to other specific tags that might be appropriate ? &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="80" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" LastActivityDate="2010-11-27T16:31:48.010" Title="Top-level arxiv tag for quantum computing" Tags="&lt;status-deferred&gt;&lt;tags&gt;" AnswerCount="4" CommentCount="9" />
./Posts.xml:655:  <row Id="687" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="685" CreationDate="2010-11-24T00:34:44.350" Score="3" Body="&lt;p&gt;Since physics arXiv tags don't have two-letter abbreviations, this would confuse everybody who's not familiar with physics on the arXiv. We could add two letters &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/xy.quant-ph&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;xy.quant-ph&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;xy.quant-ph&lt;/a&gt; (with x and y to be determined). ./Posts.xml:658:  <row Id="690" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="455" CreationDate="2010-11-24T13:23:21.653" Score="2" Body="&lt;p&gt;Just some thoughts. &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/ct.category-theory&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;ct.category-theory&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;ct.category-theory&lt;/a&gt; probably shouldn't be a top-level tag, because anybody who is asking a category-theory question on cstheory rather than math overflow should be asking a question related to computer science, and it would help us more to know which area of computer science it's related to, than just whether it involves category theory. Other tags borrowed from the Math arXiv, such as &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/st.statistics&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;st.statistics&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;st.statistics&lt;/a&gt; and &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/co.combinatorics&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;co.combinatorics&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;co.combinatorics&lt;/a&gt; seem fine to me. (Although maybe we should try to decide whether we want to keep the math arXiv tag &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/co.combinatorics&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;co.combinatorics&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;co.combinatorics&lt;/a&gt; or the CS arXiv tag &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/dm.discrete-math&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;dm.discrete-math&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;dm.discrete-math&lt;/a&gt; or both.)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="1677" LastEditorUserId="1677" LastEditDate="2010-11-24T13:30:07.417" LastActivityDate="2010-11-24T13:30:07.417" CommentCount="3" />
./Posts.xml:659:  <row Id="691" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="685" CreationDate="2010-11-24T17:08:10.957" Score="4" Body="&lt;p&gt;I do not see anything wrong with creating a tag about quantum information processing.  However, as I suggested in an &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/455/using-at-least-one-top-level-arxiv-tag/686#686&quot;&gt;answer&lt;/a&gt; to another question, I fail to see why it matters whether some tag has the same name as an arXiv category or not.  For example, the tag &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/cc.complexity-theory&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;cc.complexity-theory&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;cc.complexity-theory&lt;/a&gt; is useful not because it is the same name as arXiv (it is not even the same name as arXiv, actually), but because it groups questions in complexity theory together.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In short, I do not think that “it is called quant-ph in arXiv” is a valid reason to have that tag.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="567" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.560" LastActivityDate="2010-11-24T17:08:10.957" CommentCount="2" />

./Posts.xml:664:  <row Id="696" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="695" CreationDate="2010-11-27T20:19:41.950" Score="1" Body="&lt;p&gt;I just see only one of your questions has been closed and that was for being exact duplicate:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2038/what-techniques-are-used-for-proving-algorithms-optimal-closed&quot;&gt;What techniques are used for proving algorithms optimal?&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;There are different reasons for closing questions and it would be more useful if you gave examples of questions you think should not have been closed. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The interpretation of comments depends on the person, I don't think anyone wants to be rude here, they simply state the reason that they are voting to close the question and this is actually being nice (one can vote to close without stating any reason.) I have not seen any comment even close to &lt;strong&gt;&quot;This is the worst question I've ever seen, I think it should be closed immediately,&quot;&lt;/strong&gt; so I think this is more about how you read them than how they are written.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I think the appropriate time before voting to close a question depends on the reason for closing, e.g. if a question is being closed for being &quot;exact duplicate&quot; I don't see any point in waiting before voting.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I think the discussion would be more constructive if you restrict the discussion to one specific reason for closing.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;And as stated in the FAQ, when a question is closed it does not mean that much. It can be edited and reopened. (I guess the trouble is that most new users don't read the FAQ but the point of FAQ is exactly answering those &lt;em&gt;Frequently Asked Questions&lt;/em&gt; so the answers for those questions are not repeated.)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I haven't checked the numbers but I don't think we are closing question with higher frequency than MO (even though I would have expected otherwise, one reason is: the site is still in beta and most of our users are new to the site and are not familiar with the policies).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="186" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" LastActivityDate="2010-11-28T15:34:45.900" CommentCount="6" />
./Posts.xml:665:  <row Id="697" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2010-11-28T03:43:56.520" Score="11" ViewCount="302" Body="&lt;p&gt;One of the things that regularly prompts me to refresh this stackexchange is the promise of interesting open problems (and not &quot;wide&quot; open problems like major complexity class separations or the complexity of factoring/matrix multiplication/etc).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Encoded in this are three qualities I am looking for. Each are mildly subjective but I hope the general idea is communicated:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Open/important (to somebody).&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Natural/interesting.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Not &quot;wide&quot; open. By &quot;wide&quot; I mean the problem is probably not solvable with current techniques.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;There have been some &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/681/multiplying-n-polynomials-of-degree-1&quot;&gt;seriously&lt;/a&gt; &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/34/how-hard-is-unshuffling-a-string&quot;&gt;cool&lt;/a&gt; open problems posted. There is in fact even a &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/open-problem&quot;&gt;tag&lt;/a&gt; 'open-problem' used to demarcate questions involving open problems. (The two &quot;seriously cool&quot; examples I linked to are both on this list.)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;However, I am worried that the list of questions tagged with 'open-problem' is not complete. For example, &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2461/interactive-proofs-for-levels-of-the-polynomial-hierarchy&quot;&gt;here&lt;/a&gt; is a question that is open, not demarcated with the 'open-problem' tag but that meets the criteria I listed above. This seems to happen with regular frequency: a question is posted, it is resolved soon thereafter that the question has been open in the literature for some time, yet the question is not then given the 'open-problem' tag.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I was wondering if we could compile and keep updated (an ultimately subjective) list of open problems meeting the above criteria which are not given the 'open-problem' tag. A list like this is interesting to me, and I am sure will be interesting to other members. It will be easier to justify the site to newcomers and can help compile some of the most intriguing question for pursuits like the poster for STOC.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerDisplayName="Ross Snider" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" LastActivityDate="2010-11-29T08:21:40.060" Title="What interesting open problems have been asked on this stackexchange?" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;tags&gt;" AnswerCount="3" CommentCount="8" FavoriteCount="5" />
./Posts.xml:668:  <row Id="700" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="697" CreationDate="2010-11-28T18:33:31.360" Score="2" Body="&lt;p&gt;Maybe the best solution is to leave the 18 questions tagged &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/open-problem&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;open-problem&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;open-problem&lt;/a&gt; as they are, but start using the above suggested list as a criterion for new open problems. In addition, if a problem stated as open turns out not to be, or is resolved, we remove the tag. If there's general agreement we can add an FAQ entry to this effect. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="80" LastActivityDate="2010-11-28T18:33:31.360" CommentCount="16" />
./Posts.xml:669:  <row Id="701" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2010-11-29T06:53:25.913" Score="19" ViewCount="557" Body="&lt;p&gt;Hi all. I'm &lt;a href=&quot;http://blog.stackoverflow.com/2010/07/our-designer-in-residence-jin-yang/&quot;&gt;Jin&lt;/a&gt;, and I'll be working on the designs for the Stack Exchange sites as they graduate from the beta phase. Each site will have its own unique theme that will reflect its topic. However, all sites will share quite a bit of common elements so they feel like they're part of the Stack Exchange family.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;For my research on the design, I've been going through the type of questions asked on the site and your design ideas in the &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/33/what-should-our-logo-be&quot;&gt;logo&lt;/a&gt; post.&#xA;&lt;img src=&quot;https://i.stack.imgur.com/GSYbD.png&quot; alt=&quot;alt text&quot;&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I like the Turing Machine and DFA suggestions. I think they represent the concept of TCS very well. For the logo, I normally make its shape to fit within a square dimension; this way it can be easily made into a favicon/apple touch icon.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;For the overall design, I believe a clean look would work well, with a few details that have a hint of &quot;computery stuff.&quot;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Below is the design for the homepage. While it doesn't have all the site elements, it should give you a good idea of the overall look and feel.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;em&gt;(click to see full resolution version)&lt;/em&gt;&#xA;&lt;a href=&quot;https://i.stack.imgur.com/wujRN.png&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;https://i.stack.imgur.com/wujRN.png&quot; alt=&quot;alt text&quot;&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Update:&lt;/strong&gt; Below is the modified version based on your feedback from the original. I changed the logo to the DFA concept Suresh suggested. I've also updated the question title text from Courier to Palatino. I do think it will look good with the math formula text.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://i.stack.imgur.com/QiyWR.png&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;https://i.stack.imgur.com/QiyWR.png&quot; alt=&quot;alt text&quot;&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;As you can see, for the title header I'm using the Turing Machine concept, and &quot;Σ&quot; as the logo. I'm using a faint water mark of a FSM in the background for pure decorative purpose.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The body section is basically the same as the Beta Sketchy theme structure-wise. The focus here is on readability.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Let me know your thoughts. I'm aiming to get the site launched early this week. So early congrats from me!&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;P.S. I need ideas for site's 404/captcha/error page images. ./Posts.xml:673:  <row Id="705" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="701" CreationDate="2010-11-29T10:05:58.600" Score="5" Body="&lt;p&gt;Thanks a lot Jin! I really appreciate the design. I wanted to make one aesthetic suggestion, though: I think the title &quot;THEORETICAL COMPUTER SCIENCE&quot; can be made more appealing by using the Title-Case instead of UPPER-CASE: &quot;Theoretical Computer Science&quot;. A Turing tape does not necessarily hold upper-case symbols, right?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;One more suggestion: In computer science, there's a notion of &lt;strong&gt;oracles&lt;/strong&gt;. Informally, they are functions that &quot;know&quot; the answer to some specified question, and can compute and return it in &lt;strong&gt;one step&lt;/strong&gt;. I think this concept can be used in the design; specifically when an expert (the oracle) answers a question. Specifically, I like the idea with up-voting/down-voting a question/answer. One can imagine the oracle concept replacing the &quot;pen tips&quot; in the TeX design:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;https://i.stack.imgur.com/pcBty.png&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="873" LastActivityDate="2010-11-29T10:05:58.600" CommentCount="9" />
./Posts.xml:674:  <row Id="706" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="701" CreationDate="2010-11-29T14:08:22.607" Score="4" Body="&lt;p&gt;&lt;em&gt;Update&lt;/em&gt;: I like the design revision 2 very much.  Thank you, Jin!&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;hr&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;em&gt;Edit: Below is my comments on revision 1.&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Thank you for the interesting design.  I like this modern look.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Here are a few comments:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;Logo&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;To be honest, I do not think the uppercase sigma is ideal as a logo.  The uppercase sigma is strongly related to discrete mathematics (because the symbol is used for summation), and it is true that theoretical computer science uses discrete mathematics a lot, but theoretical computer science is not the same as discrete mathematics.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;However, without a better alternative, the uppercase sigma is an acceptable compromise.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I like the &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/33/what-should-our-logo-be/314#314&quot;&gt;DFA idea&lt;/a&gt; as is used in Suresh’s publicity materials, but it will not be recognizable in a 16×16-pixel favicon.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;Typewriter font&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I like the use of typewriter font in the website title written on a tape of a Turing machine.  On the other hand, as Suresh said, I am worried about the use of typewriter font in question titles, too, but for a different reason.  Some of the question titles are long, and typewriter font takes too much width.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I do not think that a mix of two fonts is bad by itself.  I am not sure if we want to use the same roman font in both question titles and question bodies just because they can contain MathJax math.  &lt;del&gt;In my (uneducated) opinion, question bodies are probably better in a roman font but question titles can be sans-serif.&lt;/del&gt;  &lt;em&gt;Edit: I removed the last sentence; see my reply to Jin in a comment.&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="567" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" LastActivityDate="2010-11-30T11:49:50.503" CommentCount="4" />
./Posts.xml:675:  <row Id="707" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="274" CreationDate="2010-11-29T17:07:04.550" Score="7" Body="&lt;p&gt;As this issue recently came up again in regards to &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/3360/matrix-multiplication-in-on2-log-n&quot;&gt;this question on matrix multiplication&lt;/a&gt;, I thought I'd throw in my two cents.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;It seems to me entirely reasonable and in line with all the discussion in this thread that the following type of question be allowed:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;This new paper claiming a big result is beyond my ken to read. ./Posts.xml:677:  <row Id="709" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="701" CreationDate="2010-11-30T01:42:53.337" Score="4" Body="&lt;p&gt;For 404/error message, could we try something involve a &lt;strong&gt;nondeterministic search&lt;/strong&gt;: &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;https://i.stack.imgur.com/TGLoZ.jpg&quot; alt=&quot;NTM&quot;&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;In fact the page is founded/the command is succeed. Unfortunately, this is a nondeterministic search/operation and you're in a rejecting branch.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I'm not a native English speaker, so please modify the sentence and/or the concept to make it better.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="1800" LastEditorUserId="1800" LastEditDate="2010-11-30T01:57:23.033" LastActivityDate="2010-11-30T01:57:23.033" CommentCount="2" />
./Posts.xml:678:  <row Id="710" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="701" CreationDate="2010-11-30T03:28:00.620" Score="6" Body="&lt;h2&gt;404 page&lt;/h2&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;For the 404 page, how about a DFA whose final state is a state that doesn't exist. Or maybe a tree (like a search tree), where the node we have reached is non-existent. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;What I mean is something like this:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;https://i.stack.imgur.com/a8ES8.gif&quot; alt=&quot;alt text&quot;&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The idea being that the state marked &quot;??&quot; is where the user is right now, and it's not a valid state somehow.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h2&gt;Up and down arrows&lt;/h2&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;For the up and down arrows for voting, instead of using the usual upward facing triangle and downward facing triangle, we could use a Boolean AND and OR gate. An AND gate is usually depicted as a circle with the wedge ($\wedge$) sign inside it, and an OR gate is usually a circle with a vee ($\vee$) inside. A rough drawing of what I'm suggesting:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;https://i.stack.imgur.com/qKaMk.gif&quot; alt=&quot;alt text&quot;&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The left side shows the arrows by default. The right shows how they would appear after being clicked.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h2&gt;Logo&lt;/h2&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;As pointed out by Tsuyoshi, while $\Sigma$ does appear very frequently in TCS, it's not restricted to TCS alone. However, a small modification of $\Sigma$ is $\Sigma^*$, (Sigma with a star in the exponent). I have only seen this used in TCS (to denote the set of all finite strings over the alphabet $\Sigma$).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h2&gt;$\Sigma^*$&lt;/h2&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h2&gt;Miscellaneous&lt;/h2&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;These are some miscellaneous symbols/images I associate with theoretical computer science. If you need a small image of something related to TCS, you could use one of these.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;$\{0,1\}$&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;$\Sigma^*$&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;$F_2$&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;$3SAT$&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;$O(n \log n)$&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;$P \stackrel{?}{=} NP$&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="206" LastEditorUserId="206" LastEditDate="2010-11-30T04:05:23.407" LastActivityDate="2010-11-30T04:05:23.407" CommentCount="4" />
./Posts.xml:679:  <row Id="711" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="701" CreationDate="2010-11-30T10:24:26.473" Score="3" Body="&lt;p&gt;What about this proposal for the captcha?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;https://i.stack.imgur.com/lFQOt.png&quot; alt=&quot;Are you a human being?&quot;&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Sorry, I couldn't resist... ;-)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="947" LastActivityDate="2010-11-30T10:24:26.473" CommentCount="1" />
./Posts.xml:680:  <row Id="712" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2010-11-30T20:29:54.170" Score="21" ViewCount="473" Body="&lt;p&gt;Hi all,&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The new design just went live, congratulations on the official launch and thank you for your &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/701/design-ideas-for-tcs-site&quot;&gt;design input&lt;/a&gt;!&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If you see any CSS/Styling issues, please start a new question for the bug report, and tag it with &quot;Design&quot; and &quot;Bug.&quot; It will be a lot easier for me to track new questions than reading the comments replied to this thread. As for more subjective styling requests, I tend to let the new design simmer a bit. ./Posts.xml:707:  <row Id="742" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAnswerId="748" CreationDate="2010-12-03T15:01:52.463" Score="2" ViewCount="143" Body="&lt;p&gt;I think questions whose titles are like:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;code&gt;How I can find a recent papers on the subject of Turing machine which exhibit computational power beyond blah blah blah...&lt;/code&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Can we have a policy (or at least some guideline) asking the poster to trim his/her question in a meaningful way?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;PS:&lt;/strong&gt; There's already a policy on the &lt;strong&gt;minimum&lt;/strong&gt; length of the title (15 chars). ./Posts.xml:708:  <row Id="743" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAnswerId="744" CreationDate="2010-12-03T17:19:46.857" Score="2" ViewCount="110" Body="&lt;p&gt;The most recent example of the problem stated in the title is &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/3492/sum-versus-maximum-in-computer-science&quot;&gt;this question&lt;/a&gt;:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;what is more difficult to calculate from the viewpoint of a computer : the &quot;sum&quot; or the &quot;maximum&quot; of a finite set of numbers ?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Here's a reformulation in comments: &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;Can we come up with a model that&#xA;  separates sum and max? For example,&#xA;  could we show that in certain models,&#xA;  computing the sum of  b-bit numbers&#xA;  requires strictly more extra space (in&#xA;  addition to the read-only input tape&#xA;  and write-only output tape) than max?&#xA;  Or is the answer always trivial?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;While not claiming to know the intent of the OP, it seems to me that the original question was fairly basic, but the reformulated question is far more interesting (to me) and is actually a reasonable research level question. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In fact, the reformulated question also &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/3492/sum-versus-maximum-in-computer-science/3497#3497&quot;&gt;has a nice answer&lt;/a&gt;. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;So my question is:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;ul&gt;&#xA;  &lt;li&gt;Would it be appropriate to edit the question to reflect what appears to be&#xA;  the more interesting question&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;  &lt;li&gt;Would it instead be better to encourage the commenter to post a new&#xA;  question ?&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;  &lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="80" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" LastActivityDate="2010-12-03T17:49:47.123" Title="Asking the question that should have been asked" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;asking-questions&gt;" AnswerCount="1" CommentCount="0" />
./Posts.xml:710:  <row Id="745" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="358" CreationDate="2010-12-03T18:26:40.333" Score="0" Body="&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/358/on-topic-or-off-topic-do-you-use-any-article-organizers/359#359&quot;&gt;This answer&lt;/a&gt; is like saying in a CS class, a prof isn't allowed to talk (even briefly) about study habits.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In my opinion closing this type of question out doesn't really benefit the site.  People on the &lt;strong&gt;CLOSE OR DIE&lt;/strong&gt; side want people to talk strictly about CS, but not about how to study CS.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I hadn't heard of Mendelay before, though I'm glad I have now, thanks to one of the answers to that question.  Interestingly, a &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.google.ca/#q=research+paper+organizer&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;Google search for research paper organizer&lt;/a&gt; doesn't reveal Mendelay on the first page of results just yet.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;So, my point is, although this question doesn't fit in &lt;code&gt;/Academia/CS&lt;/code&gt;, it still fits in &lt;code&gt;/Academia&lt;/code&gt;. ./Posts.xml:715:  <row Id="750" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAnswerId="764" CreationDate="2010-12-04T13:09:26.153" Score="3" ViewCount="118" Body="&lt;p&gt;When you open the privileges page and select a privilege with a long name, the percentage of the &lt;em&gt;next&lt;/em&gt; privilege is aligned incorrectly.  This happens for example when you &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/privileges/close-questions&quot;&gt;choose “cast close and reopen votes” privilege&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Always reproducible with Firefox 3.6.12, Internet Explorer 8.0.7600.16385 and Chrome 8.0.552.215 on Windows 7.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;My guess is that the problem itself had been always there, but the font used during the beta was not wide enough to trigger this glitch whereas the font used in the new design is wide enough to trigger it.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;[&lt;em&gt;Added&lt;/em&gt;: Another cause seems to be that the font used to show the percentage is (probably) higher than the vertical space between rows.  Actually, this table is constructed by using floats instead of using a simple &amp;lt;table&amp;gt; element and, if I understand the intent correctly, the very reason for this is to handle the horizontal overflow nicely.  The font being higher than the vertical space destroys this gimmick and produces a worse result when the horizontal overflow occurs.]&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Screenshot of &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/privileges/close-questions&quot;&gt;the page about the “cast close and reopen votes” privilege&lt;/a&gt; with Firefox 3.6.12:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;https://i.stack.imgur.com/AqkVz.png&quot; alt=&quot;screenshot&quot;&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="567" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" LastActivityDate="2014-03-21T15:51:05.927" Title="Alignment glitch on privileges pages" Tags="&lt;bug&gt;&lt;status-completed&gt;&lt;design&gt;" AnswerCount="1" CommentCount="1" FavoriteCount="1" />
./Posts.xml:719:  <row Id="755" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAnswerId="2820" CreationDate="2010-12-05T19:03:10.590" Score="1" ViewCount="59" Body="&lt;p&gt;Part of the text and symbols are covered by the new column.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Example: &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/badges/61/talkative&quot;&gt;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/badges/61/talkative&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="186" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" LastActivityDate="2014-03-21T17:15:40.197" Title="Glitch: part of entries is cut off on badges pages" Tags="&lt;bug&gt;&lt;status-completed&gt;&lt;design&gt;" AnswerCount="1" CommentCount="5" />
./Posts.xml:720:  <row Id="756" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAnswerId="758" CreationDate="2010-12-05T21:16:59.160" Score="1" ViewCount="59" Body="&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/3574/logarithmic-advice-language-in-p&quot;&gt;This question&lt;/a&gt; had this comment:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;Voted to close as off topic (too basic). – Tsuyoshi Ito 43 mins ago&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I therefore assume at least one close vote was cast for this question. As of the moment of writing this, the question is not (yet) closed.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;According to &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/privileges/view-close-votes&quot;&gt;this page&lt;/a&gt;, I should be able to view close votes. They even show a screenshot where this should appear. However, I don't see any such option appearing for me at that question, and I can't remember ever having seen that option appear on any question I've viewed.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Am I doing something wrong here?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="988" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" LastActivityDate="2010-12-05T23:15:52.537" Title="Bug with viewing close votes?" ./Posts.xml:721:  <row Id="757" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="756" CreationDate="2010-12-05T23:12:06.843" Score="5" Body="&lt;p&gt;In brief, the behavior is correct, and the the description of the privilege itself is not well worded. &lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/68512/is-the-explanation-of-view-close-votes-misleading&quot;&gt;This discussion on meta.SO&lt;/a&gt; details the issue.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="80" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-20T10:29:37.593" LastActivityDate="2010-12-05T23:12:06.843" CommentCount="1" />
./Posts.xml:723:  <row Id="759" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2010-12-06T01:26:22.443" Score="7" ViewCount="244" Body="&lt;p&gt;I have been thinking about this for sometime. As you know, SE has changed the Community Wiki policy and now only moderators can make a question a CW. Community Wiki has 2 main effects:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;The question becomes owned by community, the original OP does not gain reputation,&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;The required reputation to edit drops to 100,&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;and a side effect:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol start=&quot;3&quot;&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;The answers posted after a questions becomes a Community Wiki become Community Wiki automatically, i.e. the answers are owned by community, (but answers posted before the question becoming CW don't).&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;These three effects are not always correlated and there are cases that one wants to have one of these three but not the other two, e.g. the owner does not want to earn reputation but wants the users answering the question to earn reputation for their answers. So it seems to me that SE is mixing too many things in one concept and that is the main reason for many issues we had and have with CW policy.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Robin brought up the idea that we should make the non-CW answers to a CW question CW also. I have a problem with answers becoming CW when the question becomes CW because sometimes the answers deserve to earn reputation, but in the current situation it makes sense, if the answers need to be CW then the previous ones also need to be CW, on the other hand a user might not have answered a question if it was a CW question so I don't know what is the right thing to do here.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I see three clear reasons for making a question a CW (and it would be nice to add other reasons to this list):&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;OP doesn't want to earn reputation (for some reason),&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;OP wants to allow others to edit,&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;the question is a ranking list.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;For example I think a question like &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/45/what-are-good-references-to-understanding-the-proof-of-the-pcp-theorem&quot;&gt;this&lt;/a&gt; and &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2953/advice-on-good-research-practices&quot;&gt;this&lt;/a&gt; should be CW but the answers should not be and the users answering them should earn reputation for their answers. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Another issue is that the new policy is not clear on what we should do when we think a question or answer needs to be CW, I used to flag some posts for moderator attention but don't do it any more because I now think it is not very nice to suggest someone else question or answer should be CW to the moderators, so I have decided to go with a softer way of adding comments like &quot;I would upvote it if it becomes CW&quot;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I have an proposal that I think might solve some issues and would like to hear what others think about it:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;In general the question or answer should be made CW only on the request of the owner (with some exceptions, see below), other users that think the post should be CW can leave a non-abusive comment like: &quot;nice answer, I would upvote it if it becomes CW&quot; and up-vote only if/when it becomes CW.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Exceptions:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;the OP is a drive-by user and does not reply to the answers or comments after considerable time,&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;some clear cases like: a ranking list. These should be explicitly included in the policy,&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;other special situations where the moderators have strong reasons for making a question CW.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;What do you think about this proposal (agree, disagree, opinions, improvements and suggestions, ...) and CW in general? &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;ps:&lt;/strong&gt;&#xA;Another minor issue about CW is its (lack of) effect on badges, it seems strange that a user does not earn reputation but does earn badges for CW posts, e.g. I should not have earned a badges for &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/174/major-unsolved-problems-in-theoretical-computer-science/218#218&quot;&gt;these answers&lt;/a&gt;. Right now many of higher level badges are awarded for CW questions/answers, which does not seem a good thing to me.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;hr&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/239#239&quot;&gt;Official FAQ for Theoretical Computer Science&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/25/material-to-supplement-the-faq&quot;&gt;Material to supplement the FAQ&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;hr&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;MO policy&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.mathoverflow.net/discussion/6/when-should-questions-be-community-wiki&quot;&gt;https://meta.mathoverflow.net/discussion/6/when-should-questions-be-community-wiki&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://mathoverflow.net/faq#communitywiki&quot;&gt;https://mathoverflow.net/faq#communitywiki&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;SE policy&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/392/should-the-community-wiki-police-be-shut-down&quot;&gt;Should the community wiki police be shut down?&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/67581/community-wiki-checkbox-missing-in-action&quot;&gt;Community Wiki checkbox missing in action&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/67039/what-can-we-do-to-make-community-wiki-better&quot;&gt;What can we do to make Community Wiki better?&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/11740/what-are-community-wiki-posts&quot;&gt;What are &amp;quot;Community Wiki&amp;quot; posts?&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;Old discussions on cstheory meta:&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/34/community-wiki-etiquette&quot;&gt;Community Wiki Etiquette&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/62/developing-a-cw-policy&quot;&gt;Developing a CW policy.&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/201/community-wikis&quot;&gt;Community Wikis&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="186" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:57:54.527" LastActivityDate="2011-08-20T05:02:03.817" Title="The new Community Wiki policy" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;community-wiki&gt;&lt;policy&gt;" AnswerCount="4" CommentCount="8" FavoriteCount="1" CommunityOwnedDate="2010-12-06T04:10:41.780" />
./Posts.xml:724:  <row Id="760" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="759" CreationDate="2010-12-06T02:03:40.913" Score="2" Body="&lt;p&gt;This may sound radical, but do we ever need CW, especially for questions?  Things will become much easier if we just pretend that questions cannot be made CW, and I suspect that we will not lose much by doing so.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Actually I have never understood when to use community wiki (CW).  As you wrote, making a question CW has several effects, and I cannot see when we want to (1) give up reputation points, (2) make it easy to edit and (3) propagate the same effect to answers at the same time.  For example, I have never understood why big-list questions should be CW.  (I admit that I had flagged several big-list questions for moderator attention to make them CW, following the existing protocol without thinking why.)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;hr&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;em&gt;Added&lt;/em&gt;: As you pointed out in a comment, it is sometimes explained that big-list questions should be CW because votes on answers reflect how good the items mentioned in the answers are rather than how good the answers themselves are.  However, honestly speaking, I doubt that this explanation ultimately makes sense.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Many useful answers (no matter whether the question is a big-list question or not) are simply links to some external items, and in my opinion the answers pointing to good items in a useful way are good.  (One of the examples which I always think of is &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/716/computational-complexity-of-the-3-partition-problem-with-distinct-numbers/758#758&quot;&gt;Serge Gaspers’s answer&lt;/a&gt; to my first question on CS Theory Stack Exchange.  The essential part of the answer is a single reference, and it was extremely useful for me.)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I do not like to talk about reputation points as if they are anything important, but if reputation points are worth talking about, then someone who pointed out a good item in a useful way should gain reputation points in my opinion.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="567" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" LastActivityDate="2010-12-06T02:49:06.337" CommentCount="10" />
./Posts.xml:725:  <row Id="761" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAnswerId="762" CreationDate="2010-12-06T02:17:41.160" Score="3" ViewCount="101" Body="&lt;p&gt;In this &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/3540/what-are-the-recent-tcs-books-whose-drafts-are-available-online/3545#3545&quot;&gt;answer&lt;/a&gt; the question wasn't originally community wiki and it was turned later into one. The answer was posted before it was community wiki and so I got rep for the upvotes. When I noticed I made the answer community wiki so I won't get further rep. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The question is how to reverse the rep. ./Posts.xml:732:  <row Id="769" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAnswerId="771" CreationDate="2010-12-07T02:52:38.660" Score="12" ViewCount="188" Body="&lt;p&gt;This has been bothered my for a while. And a &lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/1170/should-i-be-able-to-cancel-my-up-vote-on-a-comment&quot;&gt;related discussion&lt;/a&gt; is in metaSE, while the post is tagged with [status-declined] and the community seems to disagree with it.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Sometimes by accident I up-voted a wrong comment. Sometimes I misread the comment, and I want to undo my decision. (My fault, of course!) Sometimes I just want to flag the comment instead of upvoting, but after the upvote we &lt;em&gt;can't even&lt;/em&gt; flag the comment!&#xA;That really makes me hesitate to use the functionality of upvoting and flagging. If we can cancel an upvote in a reasonable amount of time (just like the upvotes for questions and answers), it would represents the community's opinion much better.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;Should we have the ability to cancel a comment upvote?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="1800" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-20T10:29:37.593" LastActivityDate="2012-09-02T20:27:07.517" Title="Cancel a comment upvote" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;comments&gt;&lt;up-votes&gt;" AnswerCount="1" CommentCount="0" />
./Posts.xml:733:  <row Id="770" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2010-12-07T03:28:08.363" Score="1" ViewCount="240" Body="&lt;p&gt;The community of TCS SE comes from many nations all over the world, and this increase the diversity of us, which is a pretty good thing.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Some of the members write their names in their own native languages, (e.g. &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/users/1993/bjorn-kjos-hanssen&quot;&gt;Bjørn&lt;/a&gt;, &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/users/88/michael-cadilhac&quot;&gt;Michaël&lt;/a&gt; and &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/users/109/andras-salamon&quot;&gt;András&lt;/a&gt;), and I applaud them for writing names as it should be. In &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/3604/parity-and-circuit-complexity&quot;&gt;this recent post&lt;/a&gt;, @johne linked to a pdf file which is named by Mandarin Chinese, since the file may not belongs to him, so this make sense.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;But should we encourage the use of non-English characters in TCS SE? Since this is a place for sharing ideas and communication, a non-unify language can cause some problems. And while I'm using browsers which can read Unicode, not all the characters can be seem in all the systems. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Furthermore, if someone is writing a post almost entirely in non-English? Say a request for translating the following paragraph for a research purpose:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;令 $U$ 為一大小為 $n$ 的集合, 而 $\mathcal{F}$ 為一非空集合, $\mathcal{F}$ 中每一元素為 $U$ 的子集. 均勻獨立的在 $U$ 上隨機給定 $[2n]$ 內的重量. 則至少有 $1/2$ 的機率會使得 $\mathcal{F}$ 中正好只有一個最小重量的 $U$ 子集.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Is this kind of post allowed in this site?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;Do we encourage the use of non-English characters? If so, what kind of degree do we allowed?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="1800" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.537" LastActivityDate="2010-12-07T23:20:36.137" Title="Non-English characters in TCS StackExchange" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;policy&gt;" AnswerCount="3" CommentCount="6" />
./Posts.xml:734:  <row Id="771" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="769" CreationDate="2010-12-07T05:13:27.250" Score="12" Body="&lt;p&gt;&lt;em&gt;Update&lt;/em&gt;: Since April 2012, we can cancel a comment upvote by clicking the upward arrow again.  We can cancel a comment upvote only for 60 seconds and only if we have not navigated to another page.  &lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/1170/should-i-be-able-to-cancel-my-up-vote-on-a-comment/129032#129032&quot;&gt;Read this for more detail&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;hr&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Yes, we should.  As you wrote very appropriately, there are several reasons why canceling comment upvotes for a limited time window will be useful.  However, note that they declined the request (in August 2009) on Meta Stack Exchange and have not reversed the decision even with more than 70 upvotes.  I would not hold my breath.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="567" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-20T10:29:37.593" LastActivityDate="2012-09-02T20:27:07.517" CommentCount="0" />
./Posts.xml:735:  <row Id="772" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="770" CreationDate="2010-12-07T06:19:22.773" Score="4" Body="&lt;p&gt;There's a &lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.mathoverflow.net/discussion/142/nonenglish-posts/#Item_0&quot;&gt;long and contentious discussion&lt;/a&gt; over at MO on this topic, and I take the position shared by some of the commenters there that we should not create a policy of any kind until there's an actual need for it. The main fear in allowing non-English posts is balkanization, and so far that hasn't been an issue. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I see no reason to &lt;strong&gt;encourage&lt;/strong&gt; posts in another language though, and I'd strongly encourage people to help with translation into English if a post in a different language does show up. We can separate the translation from the original by a rule. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="80" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-17T10:13:04.397" LastActivityDate="2010-12-07T06:19:22.773" CommentCount="1" />
./Posts.xml:736:  <row Id="773" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2010-12-07T06:23:08.463" Score="2" ViewCount="160" Body="&lt;p&gt;I've seen a number of posts where people capture snapshots of parts of a PDF. &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/3517/lower-bounds-for-nondeterministic-multiparty-communication&quot;&gt;This post by Marcos Villagra&lt;/a&gt; is one example. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;How does one do this ? &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Update&lt;/strong&gt;: Marcos has edited his answer to contain actual text instead of a snapshot, so the example linked above is no longer operative. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="80" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" LastActivityDate="2010-12-08T23:59:05.600" Title="Nifty PDF snippets" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;" AnswerCount="3" CommentCount="11" FavoriteCount="0" />

./Posts.xml:753:  <row Id="790" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="789" CreationDate="2010-12-08T23:25:31.483" Score="4" Body="&lt;p&gt;The function of the envelope icon changed a while ago (seemingly at the beginning of November). ./Posts.xml:755:  <row Id="792" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2010-12-09T19:22:08.257" Score="5" ViewCount="138" Body="&lt;p&gt;The Stack Exchange software has many small oddities.  Serious misfeatures should be fixed, but often small oddities are just slightly frustrating and not properly called bugs.  Although all of the oddities should be fixed in the ideal world, it cannot be expected that every small glitch will be fixed.  Sharing them and their workarounds may mitigate the harm caused by those oddities.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Question&lt;/strong&gt;.  What is the small oddity you are aware of, and what is a workaround for it?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The question may not be as clear as I hoped it to be.  See &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/792/small-oddities-in-the-se-software-and-their-workarounds/793#793&quot;&gt;my answer&lt;/a&gt;, which may clarify the question.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="567" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" LastActivityDate="2011-01-31T04:53:39.673" Title="Small oddities in the SE software and their workarounds" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;" AnswerCount="2" CommentCount="0" />
./Posts.xml:756:  <row Id="793" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="792" CreationDate="2010-12-09T19:23:00.597" Score="3" Body="&lt;h2&gt;Five-minute edit window&lt;/h2&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;When you make a post (a question or an answer) and edit it later, it creates a new revision.  However, if the edit is within five minutes from the original post or the last edit, it does not become a new revision but simply overwrites the last revision.  Usually we do not have to be aware of this, but it becomes relevant if we try to write a sensible edit summary (in the “Edit Summary” textbox on the edit page) because overwriting the revision also overwrites the edit summary.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;For example, suppose that you posted an answer, and made a heavy edit one week later.  You wrote the summary “improved the analysis significantly.”  Just after you hit the “Save Edits” button, you realized several typos in your answer and fixed it with the summary “fixed typos.”  Now the revision history shows an interesting thing: it shows only two revisions, and the newer revision making the significant improvement is shown with the summary “fixed typos.”  :(&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;(This happened to me on MathOverflow.  See the revision 3 of &lt;a href=&quot;https://mathoverflow.net/revisions/33857/list&quot;&gt;this revision history&lt;/a&gt;.)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;Workaround&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;It is easiest to forget about edit summaries, since almost no one will look at the revision history (probably).  However, if you want to make it perfect, you should know what will happen to the edit summary when you edit one post successively.  In particular, you should know whether it will have passed more than five minutes since the last edit or not when you submit the edit, and write the edit summary accordingly.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="567" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:57:54.527" LastActivityDate="2010-12-09T19:23:00.597" CommentCount="3" />
./Posts.xml:757:  <row Id="794" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="784" CreationDate="2010-12-10T01:08:26.717" Score="2" Body="&lt;p&gt;David Eppstein shows &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/3690/a-multi-cut-problem/3695#3695&quot;&gt;a variant of max-cut problem is NP-hard&lt;/a&gt;, which is asked by Aaron.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="1800" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" LastActivityDate="2010-12-10T03:27:20.503" CommentCount="6" />
./Posts.xml:759:  <row Id="796" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="784" CreationDate="2010-12-10T04:06:26.473" Score="5" Body="&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2312/max-cut-with-negative-weight-edges/2318#2318&quot;&gt;In this post&lt;/a&gt;, Peter Shor shows that it is impossible to approximate a max-cut on a (possibly-)negative weighted graph within a factor of 2, unless there is also an approximation algorithm with ratio better the currently best algorithm to the max-cut problem on positive weighted graphs.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="1800" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" LastActivityDate="2010-12-10T06:15:31.640" CommentCount="2" />
./Posts.xml:761:  <row Id="798" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2010-12-10T18:53:50.647" Score="6" ViewCount="133" Body="&lt;p&gt;I realized that unfortunately the current illustration on the CAPTCHA page does not make sense.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://sstatic.net/cstheory/img/captcha.png&quot; alt=&quot;illustration on the CAPTCHA page&quot;&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I think that this is supposed to illustrate the &lt;a href=&quot;http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Turing_test&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;Turing test&lt;/a&gt;, but the illustration misses the point because the examiner can see the subject physically in this picture.  The point of the Turing test is that the examiner and the subject are kept in separate rooms so that the examiner has to distinguish a human from a computer by interacting with the subject only through a communication channel that is equally available to both a human and a computer.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I added a separator between the examiner and the two subjects claiming to be human.  This may not be sufficient, but I hope that it is better than the current picture:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;https://i.stack.imgur.com/RDSCX.png&quot; alt=&quot;example of modified illustration&quot;&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="567" LastActivityDate="2010-12-12T16:52:19.367" Title="Illustration on the CAPTCHA page does not make sense" Tags="&lt;feature-request&gt;&lt;design&gt;" AnswerCount="1" CommentCount="4" />

./Posts.xml:764:  <row Id="802" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2010-12-11T18:20:58.520" Score="11" ViewCount="793" Body="&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;This policy is now in effect, with 13 votes in favor and 2 against. In addition, three of the amendments suggested in comments passed as well. The new policy on 'topic of research' questions is as follows: &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;  &#xA;  &lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;POLICY&lt;/strong&gt;: Thesis topic questions are only within site scope if the asker requests feedback about a specific proposed topic. Questions like “What would be a good topic?” will be deemed to be general and unfocused and therefore will be closed. The OP has the option of requesting a reopening of the question if it is modified as per the above policy&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;  &#xA;  &lt;p&gt;A special exception can be made for specific programming-style projects on a specific topic, or requests for ideas for implementation, along the lines of &lt;a href=&quot;https://mathoverflow.net/questions/18440/what-algorithm-in-algebraic-geometry-should-i-work-on-implementing/&quot;&gt;this question&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;  &#xA;  &lt;p&gt;When closing a question using this policy as the basis, please link to this discussion. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;From time to time, someone posts a question requesting advice on choosing a research project.  This might be a project for a class, a Master's Thesis, or even the focus of a doctoral dissertation.  We believe the best resources to consult are your course instructor, teaching assistants, and thesis advisor.  They can provide better, more in-depth, advice than brief answers on a web site.  For anyone who would like to ask such questions here anyway, please be aware of the following policy: &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;POLICY&lt;/strong&gt;: Thesis topic questions are only within site scope if the asker requests feedback about a specific proposed topic.  General, unfocused questions like, &quot;What would be a good topic?&quot; will be closed as off topic.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;One of the objectives of this site is, &quot;Knowledge sharing, not shirking.&quot;  An essential part of research is to brainstorm project ideas that may or may not be sound, so it is reasonable to use this site to ask for feedback about a project idea you thought up but have not thoroughly investigated. On the other hand, if a project (or thesis) is supposed to be &lt;em&gt;yours&lt;/em&gt;, it is inappropriate to leave all the conceptual work to others.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Update&lt;/strong&gt;: Note that there are now suggested modifications to the policy in the answers. Please vote on them as well (the same rule applies for adoption). &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="30" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:57:54.527" LastActivityDate="2010-12-15T04:26:47.127" Title="Policy: Questions about topic for research project" Tags="&lt;status-completed&gt;&lt;faq&gt;&lt;policy&gt;" AnswerCount="4" CommentCount="10" FavoriteCount="1" />
./Posts.xml:765:  <row Id="803" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAnswerId="805" CreationDate="2010-12-11T18:25:28.693" Score="1" ViewCount="64" Body="&lt;p&gt;&lt;em&gt;Edit: I take back this proposal. ./Posts.xml:766:  <row Id="804" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="792" CreationDate="2010-12-11T19:15:32.210" Score="2" Body="&lt;h2&gt;A link with an anchor text in a comment&lt;/h2&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;Update&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;This issue has been fixed.&lt;/strong&gt;  Read more on &lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/52312/comment-links-fail-when-next-to-non-whitespace/77093#77093&quot;&gt;Meta Stack Overflow&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;It seems that this change also affects the comments posted before.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;hr&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;em&gt;Edit: Below is an older description of the issue, which no longer applies.&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;You can put a link in a comment by either writing a complete URL or using the &lt;code&gt;[…](http:…)&lt;/code&gt; syntax, just as in Markdown used for questions and answers.  For example, &lt;code&gt;[TCS Stack Exchange](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/)&lt;/code&gt; results in a link.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;However, be careful when you use the latter syntax in a comment, because not all texts that would produce a link in Markdown also produce a link in comments.  For example, if you enclose the text by a parenthesis like &lt;code&gt;([TCS Stack Exchange](http://cstheory.stackexchange.com/))&lt;/code&gt; in a comment, the server does not recognize the syntax and turn only the URL part into a link.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;Workarounds&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The link syntax &lt;code&gt;[…](http:…)&lt;/code&gt; in comments is unreliable when a non-space character precedes or follows it.  It is better not to use this syntax.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If you insist on using this syntax, an easy way to ensure that the server considers it as a hyperlink is to surround it by spaces.  Some symbols such as a period and a comma seem to be allowed after the text.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="567" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-20T10:29:37.593" LastActivityDate="2011-01-31T04:53:39.673" CommentCount="4" />
./Posts.xml:769:  <row Id="807" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2010-12-11T21:49:52.537" Score="0" ViewCount="147" Body="&lt;p&gt;We had some discussions previously that questions from outside theory are be welcome on this site (to a reasonable extent).
