./Posts.xml:771:  <row Id="809" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="807" CreationDate="2010-12-12T02:25:58.850" Score="1" Body="&lt;p&gt;I do not mind the existence of the tag although I do not see a compelling reason why we &lt;em&gt;need&lt;/em&gt; that tag.  It is not always clear whether a question belongs to “application” or not, and I will not try hard to decide one way or the other.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;As for the name, &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/application-of-theory&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;application-of-theory&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;application-of-theory&lt;/a&gt; (or “application&lt;strong&gt;s&lt;/strong&gt;-of-theory”) seems the best.  &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/application&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;application&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;application&lt;/a&gt; could be misinterpreted as questions about application software.  I do not think that &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/theory-in-practice&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;theory-in-practice&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;theory-in-practice&lt;/a&gt; is easily discoverable.  To address Suresh’s concern that no one will search for &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/application-of-theory&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;application-of-theory&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;application-of-theory&lt;/a&gt;, the input fields which expect tags have autocompletion which completes “appl” to &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/application-of-theory&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;application-of-theory&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;application-of-theory&lt;/a&gt;.  Well, &lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/29277/autocomplete-tags-in-search-box&quot;&gt;except the general search box&lt;/a&gt;. :(&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="567" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-20T10:29:37.593" LastActivityDate="2010-12-12T02:25:58.850" CommentCount="0" />
./Posts.xml:772:  <row Id="810" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="778" CreationDate="2010-12-12T03:04:14.357" Score="2" Body="&lt;p&gt;Here is what Suresh added to the meta discussion “&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/802/policy-questions-about-topic-for-research-project&quot;&gt;Policy: Questions about topic for research project&lt;/a&gt;” started by Aaron Sterling:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;This is a policy question.  The proposed policy in the question (or answers) will be adopted in the case that after 3 days it received at least 5 votes with a majority in favor.  Please upvote or downvote this question based on your opinion of the policy statement as presented (not based on whether the premise of the question is reasonable)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;While I agree on the general principle, I do not agree on the implementation because “at least 5 votes with a majority in favor” is too weak.  In my opinion, most policy changes will not be urgent, and therefore we should adopt a new policy only when it is highly supported.  A proposal with 3 upvotes and 2 downvotes would not be highly supported.  Therefore, I think that we should require at least 5 upvotes in net, that is, (# of upvotes) − (# of downvotes) ≥ 5.  If 5 sounds too large, it is negotiable.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="567" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" LastActivityDate="2010-12-12T03:04:14.357" CommentCount="2" />
./Posts.xml:774:  <row Id="812" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="802" CreationDate="2010-12-12T09:01:48.610" Score="5" Body="&lt;p&gt;I think we should distinguish between asking for a research topic and asking for a topic for an undergrad programming project (like in this question: &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/3736/ideas-for-a-project-in-mathematica-related-to-theoretical-computer-science&quot;&gt;Ideas for a project in Mathematica related to (Theoretical) Computer Science&lt;/a&gt; ). Of course this site is not the right place for asking for a topic of a PhD dissertation, but I think we should accept questions like &quot;How can I put 10 thousand lines of Java code to a good TCS-related cause?&quot; (or maybe better we could create a big list of ideas for such projects). Moreover, questions like these seem welcome on mathoverflow: &lt;a href=&quot;https://mathoverflow.net/questions/18440/what-algorithm-in-algebraic-geometry-should-i-work-on-implementing/&quot;&gt;https://mathoverflow.net/questions/18440/what-algorithm-in-algebraic-geometry-should-i-work-on-implementing/&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;When I was an undergrad I had to write thousands of lines of code in various languages, quite often with a free topic (and the topic didn't really count towards the grade, the only criterion was a solid amount of working code). It is usually the case that such projects are used just once for 10 minutes by the grader, and then thrown away - so it's like a week of effort wasted (and there are also courses where for example four people write a project together for a year, so the outcome could potentially be really something very useful).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I think it would be a win-win situation if researchers would be able to put on this site (for example in a big-list topic) announcements like: &quot;I need a program searching for a small counterexample for some conjecture&quot; or &quot;I have an idea for an interesting game/simulation spreading the ideas of TCS, but I don't have the time to write it&quot; and so on; the students could then use these ideas for writing their projects, and if successful they would afterwards share the result with the scientific community.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="327" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:57:54.527" LastActivityDate="2010-12-12T18:27:36.990" CommentCount="2" />
./Posts.xml:775:  <row Id="813" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="802" CreationDate="2010-12-12T15:56:42.083" Score="6" Body="&lt;p&gt;I cannot understand what is exactly being proposed.  You state:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;POLICY&lt;/strong&gt;: Thesis topic questions are only within site scope if the asker requests feedback about a specific proposed topic.  General, unfocused questions like, &quot;What would be a good topic?&quot; will be closed as off topic.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;but “general, unfocused questions” are closed even without this policy as e.g. “not a real question.”  So, what exactly do you want to achieve by proposing this?  I think that it is better to rephrase the proposed policy to reflect what you really meant.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;hr&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;em&gt;Update&lt;/em&gt;: Based on your comment to this answer, I propose to rephrase the policy as follows:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;POLICY&lt;/strong&gt;: Thesis topic questions are only within site scope if the asker requests feedback about a specific proposed topic.  Questions like “What would be a good topic?” will be deemed to be general and unfocused and therefore will be closed.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Some people have already interpreted the original proposal like this, but I believe that this wording is clearer in what exactly is being proposed.  At the same time, I removed the close reason “as off topic” because I agreed to &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/802/policy-questions-about-topic-for-research-project/811#811&quot;&gt;Kaveh&lt;/a&gt; that “not a real question” may be a better reason to use and that which reason to use is not of primary importance.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="567" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.560" LastActivityDate="2010-12-12T19:31:21.100" CommentCount="14" />

./Posts.xml:778:  <row Id="816" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2010-12-13T02:49:44.870" Score="7" ViewCount="384" Body="&lt;p&gt;We have just had our &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/3756/why-is-it-tn-4-work-for-each-block-of-the-matrix-in-this-divide-and-conquer-tra&quot;&gt;1000th question&lt;/a&gt;; and this is the 12th day we launched; not long, but enough to see how we're doing. I have just observed &lt;a href=&quot;http://stackexchange.com/sites&quot;&gt;a drop in the answer ratio&lt;/a&gt;; at the time &lt;a href=&quot;http://area51.stackexchange.com/proposals/8766/theoretical-computer-science&quot;&gt;we graduated from beta&lt;/a&gt; it was about 2.8, and now it is about 2.5. It is also interesting that in the mean time, our traffic rate is constantly increasing, and the number of &lt;a href=&quot;http://stackexchange.com/leagues/44/month/cstheory/2010-12-01?sort=reputationchange&amp;amp;page=3&quot;&gt;active users&lt;/a&gt; (users with a positive reputation change) in the late month is passed a hundred, a little increase compares to it was in beta.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Maybe the cause of the drop in the answer ratio is the homework problems, but I am not sure. Is this a healthy decrease (since we do not want to push the site too hard), or is it a signal of lacking enough thrust to keep flying our rocket? What do you think?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Another issue is the bounty system. It seems to me that recently, none of the questions with bounties have been answered in the bounty time period. The same problem &lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.mathoverflow.net/discussion/710/the-bounty-time-is-just-too-short/#Item_0&quot;&gt;occurs in MO&lt;/a&gt;, which may due to both sites are theoretical oriented, and since it is related to the system of SE, we do not have too much we can do. Is there any solution to the bounty problem, despite the fact that it serves as a &lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.mathoverflow.net/discussion/246/if-nobody-responds-to-a-bounty-why-do-you-still-lose-the-rep/#Item_0&quot;&gt;mechanism to attract more attention&lt;/a&gt;?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Final thoughts, it seems that most of the traffics comes from a particular region of the world (maybe US), since there is a low traffic gap (for about 8 hours) in the posts. Not a problem but an observation, but I do expect more experts and grad students all over the world to join our community.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Keep going, see how far we can reach :)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="1800" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" LastActivityDate="2010-12-20T03:42:08.247" Title="1000 posts - Is our rocket flying well?" ./Posts.xml:783:  <row Id="822" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAnswerId="824" CreationDate="2010-12-16T12:50:57.937" Score="-6" ViewCount="289" Body="&lt;p&gt;&lt;em&gt;Update&lt;/em&gt;: I withdrew this policy proposal.  It received 5 downvotes and no upvotes.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;hr&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;This is a &lt;strong&gt;policy proposal&lt;/strong&gt;.  The proposed policy in the question or its answers will be adopted in the case that after 3 days it received at least 5 upvotes with a 2/3 majority in favor (*).  Please upvote or downvote this question or its answers based on your opinion of the policy statement as presented, not just based on whether the premise of the question or its answers is reasonable.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;(*) That is, &lt;i&gt;x&lt;/i&gt;≥5 and &lt;i&gt;x&lt;/i&gt;≥2&lt;i&gt;y&lt;/i&gt;, where &lt;i&gt;x&lt;/i&gt; is the number of upvotes and &lt;i&gt;y&lt;/i&gt; is the number of downvotes.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;hr&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I propose the following as a policy:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;POLICY&lt;/strong&gt;.  Questions that describe a proof of some statement or an algorithm for some problem and ask others to do all the work to check its correctness are deemed to be off topic and closed.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The intent is to give a clear ground to close questions like “&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/3706/algorithm-for-longest-path-in-undirected-weighted-graph-closed&quot;&gt;Algorithm for Longest Path in Undirected Weighted Graph&lt;/a&gt;” in the future.  While the question had a specific goal (present a counterexample to the stated algorithm), I find it wrong to ask other people simply to do all the work to check the correctness of proofs or algorithms.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The proposal has something in common with some of the answers to “&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/300/how-to-ask-a-good-question&quot;&gt;How to ask a good question?&lt;/a&gt;,” namely &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/300/how-to-ask-a-good-question/304#304&quot;&gt;this one&lt;/a&gt;, &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/300/how-to-ask-a-good-question/306#306&quot;&gt;this one&lt;/a&gt; and &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/300/how-to-ask-a-good-question/318#318&quot;&gt;this one&lt;/a&gt;, even if they did not already cover the case with which this proposal is concerned.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="567" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.537" LastActivityDate="2010-12-19T17:55:01.577" Title="A policy proposal against questions asking for a correctness check" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;status-declined&gt;&lt;scope&gt;&lt;policy&gt;" AnswerCount="1" CommentCount="15" ClosedDate="2010-12-19T17:50:59.193" />
./Posts.xml:784:  <row Id="823" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAnswerId="927" CreationDate="2010-12-16T15:15:09.927" Score="17" ViewCount="508" Body="&lt;h3&gt;Should we put the phrase &quot;research level&quot; in our general FAQ?&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;While in our &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/235#235&quot;&gt;official FAQ&lt;/a&gt; there is a statement about the scope of our site, that is,&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;Ask and answer research-level questions in theoretical computer science.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;But I just noticed that in the &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/faq&quot;&gt;general FAQ&lt;/a&gt;, which may be noticed by most of the newcomers, does not contain such a clear statement. This may be the cause of existence to some of the out-of-scope questions in the site. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;Should we put the above sentence in our general FAQ, or at least insert the phrase &quot;reseach level&quot; to the first paragraph, which is answering the question about the scope of the site?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="1800" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" LastActivityDate="2012-07-27T21:57:44.470" Title="The modifiable part of our general FAQ" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;faq&gt;&lt;scope&gt;" AnswerCount="4" CommentCount="9" FavoriteCount="1" />
./Posts.xml:785:  <row Id="824" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="822" CreationDate="2010-12-16T15:31:13.367" Score="10" Body="&lt;p&gt;While problems without a clear demonstration that the author had put effort in are less-motivated for me to answer, the judgement of &quot;the evidence that they have took some work&quot; varies from people to people. It is especially hard to tell the difference when the question is from a new user of the site. They may have good question in mind, but failed to express the ideas in a suitable way, as defined by the site's policy.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;For sure we do not want a flood of homework problems and requests for checking the correctness of proofs to some famous open questions, but those have been already discussed and banned in &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/q/601/1800&quot;&gt;these&lt;/a&gt; &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/274/is-it-ok-to-ask-about-the-correctness-of-preprints-on-crank-friendly-topics&quot;&gt;discussions&lt;/a&gt;. And furthermore, we have an alternative choice for questions which do not show their efforts - just ignore them.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In summary, as long as the problems are within scope (that is, &lt;em&gt;research level&lt;/em&gt; questions in &lt;em&gt;theoretical&lt;/em&gt; CS), I see no immediate need to set a policy for restricting the type of the problems people ask, since that may introduce some side-effects.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="1800" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.560" LastActivityDate="2010-12-16T15:31:13.367" CommentCount="2" />
./Posts.xml:787:  <row Id="826" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2010-12-17T06:48:58.493" Score="12" ViewCount="426" Body="&lt;p&gt;This is the first time we've had to deal with this, so I'd like to lay it out there (as well giving the user a chance to respond. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;User &lt;code&gt;johne&lt;/code&gt; has posted three questions on the site, all of which have generated significant controversy and lots of mod requests. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/3604/parity-and-circuit-complexity&quot;&gt;The first one&lt;/a&gt; was about the parity lower bound, and became an unusually long question about the difference between EE and CS regarding the importance of circuits. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/3810/is-there-an-alternative-proof-of-the-tm-halting-problem-other-than-the-standard&quot;&gt;The second&lt;/a&gt; appeared to be a complaint about the use of contradiction/diagonalization in the proof of the halting theorem, and was closed for lack of clarity and concern about whether the concept of a contradiction was itself being called into question. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/3837/alternative-turing-machine-proofs&quot;&gt;The third&lt;/a&gt; question to my mind seemed more genuine, asking if there were any constructive (my rephrasing) proofs of the Halting theoreom, but has since devolved (in comments) into a bit of a mud-slinging war. The one legitimate answer provided appears to have generated very little response from the user. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In addition, the user &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/3836/circuit-complexity-charaterization-for-dlogtime-and-nlogtime/3838#3838&quot;&gt;also answered a question&lt;/a&gt; about DLOGTIME and NLOGTIME with what appeared to be another discussion about differences between the VLSI community vs the TCS community, which I feel is not relevant or helpful.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;This is the first time we've had such an issue come up, and I'd like to discuss how we should proceed. I was loathe to make this about the user (and not just about the questions), but I believe there is a sufficient pattern to warrant a discussion here. In each case, the specific issue can be resolved at the source itself using standard methods (downvoting/closing) so maybe there's nothing to discuss. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="80" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" LastActivityDate="2010-12-21T00:44:11.613" Title="Dealing with user issue" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;users&gt;" AnswerCount="6" CommentCount="4" FavoriteCount="0" />

./Posts.xml:798:  <row Id="838" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="826" CreationDate="2010-12-19T13:40:45.113" Score="3" Body="&lt;p&gt;As I wrote in a comment on &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/826/dealing-with-user-issue/827#827&quot;&gt;V Vinay’s answer&lt;/a&gt;, I hope that the standard methods can handle these issues.  Indeed, the Stack Exchange server has a few ways to “hide” posts with low score, which I think can be used to mitigate the ill effects of poorly written posts, not limited to the ones posted by a particular user.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Questions with score −4 or below are not shown on the top page.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Answers with score −3 or below are shown in gray (&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/837/answers-with-low-score-are-no-longer-shown-in-gray-text&quot;&gt;they were not for a while, but it has been fixed&lt;/a&gt;).&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="567" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" LastActivityDate="2010-12-20T13:26:55.687" CommentCount="0" />
./Posts.xml:800:  <row Id="840" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="816" CreationDate="2010-12-20T03:29:20.423" Score="4" Body="&lt;p&gt;I think we are doing well. I agree that the increase in the number of elementary questions is temporal, and the decrease in the ratio of answers per questions is also effected by smaller number of &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/big-list&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;big-list&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;big-list&lt;/a&gt; and CW questions we get which is not a bad thing by itself, the ratio is just getting closer to the ratio of questions which are not lists/CWs.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I don't know if a lower ratio is a bad thing, this might be a result of the theoretical/mathematical nature of theoretical computer science. I would like to know the current ratio for MO. If we think this is a problem we should try to encourage people to provide more answers to the questions from different perspectives, e.g. by putting an entry in the FAQ explaining it that it is good and in fact &lt;em&gt;encouraged&lt;/em&gt; to post new answers even for questions which have accepted answers (assuming that the new answer is good and adds some new information).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I tried searching for various combinations of words related to the site. We seem to be on the top page in Google for those combinations I have tried (haven't checked Bing). One interesting thing that I noticed is that Suresh's old dated &lt;a href=&quot;http://ai.stanford.edu/~suresh/theory/theory-home.html&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;theory&lt;/a&gt; &lt;a href=&quot;http://robotics.stanford.edu/~suresh/theory/theory-home.html&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;page&lt;/a&gt; is still ranked 2nd on Google when searching for the following words: cs theory. :)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I added a link to the external links section of &lt;a href=&quot;http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Theoretical_computer_science&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;Wikipedia page for Theoretical Computer Science&lt;/a&gt;. ./Posts.xml:810:  <row Id="851" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="845" CreationDate="2010-12-21T19:47:39.447" Score="2" Body="&lt;p&gt;As &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/845/reposted-questions/847#847&quot;&gt;Jukka wrote&lt;/a&gt;, sometimes reposting is a good thing, so I cannot accept the current wording of the proposal.  I would like the policy of the form “If a question is reposted [under some conditions], it should be closed,” but I do not have a concrete proposal for the conditions now.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;On the other hand, it may be better to include answers as well as questions into the scope of the proposed policy.  There was at least one time where someone posted an answer which was eventually downvoted, he/she deleted the answer, and he/she reposted exactly the same answer.  I flagged the reposted answer as a spam with an explanation of the situation as a comment, and the reposted answer was eventually deleted by many spam flags.  I hope that this was an exceptional case, but it might be worth thinking about.  (But after all, that situation was handled without moderator interventions, which may suggest that a new policy does not have to cover the situations like that.)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="567" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.560" LastActivityDate="2010-12-21T19:47:39.447" CommentCount="1" />

./Posts.xml:824:  <row Id="868" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="867" CreationDate="2011-01-08T08:07:57.387" Score="3" Body="&lt;p&gt;It's not possible for questions to have no tags. All questions must have at least one tag.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;There are background processes that cull single-use tags that are more than 6 months old, but even then we retag the question to &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/untagged&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;untagged&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;untagged&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I see -- you want something else, &quot;show me questions without this tag&quot;. Try this blog post.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://blog.stackoverflow.com/2008/10/tags-and-tags-or-tags/&quot;&gt;http://blog.stackoverflow.com/2008/10/tags-and-tags-or-tags/&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;However, bear in mind that &quot;NOT something&quot;, by itself, is disallowed. You must have &quot;something and NOT something else&quot;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="194" LastEditorUserId="194" LastEditDate="2011-01-08T08:13:02.140" LastActivityDate="2011-01-08T08:13:02.140" CommentCount="5" />

./Posts.xml:829:  <row Id="873" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="870" CreationDate="2011-01-10T02:34:18.180" Score="0" Body="&lt;p&gt;I have flagged a few posts for removal using &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/review&quot;&gt;the review page&lt;/a&gt; because IMHO it is better to delete them. They were answers which were not answers (I think from new users). We left comments for the OP that answers are not for asking questions but the OP didn't reply.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In summery, I think there are differences between bad answers and answers which are not answers at all.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;ps: I thought that a deleted post can be undeleted and therefore deletion &lt;em&gt;is&lt;/em&gt; reversible.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;pps: Another misuse of answers is for commenting on other answers by low reputation users, which makes the restriction that new users cannot comment void. There have been many cases that an expert who just started using the system has written very good comments using answers (which I think qualify as good answers), but I think in general we should not allow this to become common for typical new users. So if a new user is using an answer to comment on the question or another answer and the quality of answer is not very good we should notify the user and if the user does not remove the answer by themselves we should remove them.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="186" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" LastActivityDate="2011-01-10T02:42:33.863" CommentCount="3" />
./Posts.xml:831:  <row Id="875" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2011-01-10T10:30:53.453" Score="1" ViewCount="85" Body="&lt;p&gt;I'm proposing a retag as: &lt;code&gt;[queuing-theory]&lt;/code&gt; --&gt; &lt;code&gt;[queueing-theory]&lt;/code&gt;. You can vote for it here:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/tags/queueing-theory/synonyms&quot;&gt;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/tags/queueing-theory/synonyms&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Quoting from &lt;a href=&quot;http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Queueing_theory#Overview&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;Wikipedia&lt;/a&gt;:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;The spelling &quot;queueing&quot; over &quot;queuing&quot; is typically encountered in the academic research field. ./Posts.xml:832:  <row Id="876" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="784" CreationDate="2011-01-12T18:50:31.377" Score="3" Body="&lt;p&gt;Yuval Filmus (with help from Mark Reitblatt) shows algorithms and hardness results for &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/4254/a-special-class-of-regular-languages-circular-languages-is-it-known&quot;&gt;deciding &quot;circular languages&quot;&lt;/a&gt;. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="80" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" LastActivityDate="2011-01-12T18:50:31.377" CommentCount="0" />
./Posts.xml:833:  <row Id="877" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="784" CreationDate="2011-01-14T00:21:22.450" Score="9" Body="&lt;p&gt;By improving a known construction, Hsien-Chih Chang &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/3496/conditions-for-nfa-universality&quot;&gt;gives a family&lt;/a&gt; of $n$-state NFAs $A_n$ for which the shortest word witnessing non-universality has length $2^{(1/5-o(1))n}$, and even to $2^{(1/3-o(1))n}$. This improves upon the previously known bound of $2^{(1/75-o(1))n}$ given in by Ellul et al. (2005).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;References:&#xA;K. Ellul, B. Krawetz, J. Shallit, M. Wang: Regular Expressions: New Results and Open Problems. Journal of Automata, Languages and Combinatorics 10(4): 407-437 (2005)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="2367" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" LastActivityDate="2011-01-14T00:21:22.450" CommentCount="0" />

./Posts.xml:842:  <row Id="886" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAnswerId="891" CreationDate="2011-01-19T05:42:41.407" Score="1" ViewCount="315" Body="&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;This is a policy question. The proposed policy in the question (or answers) will be adopted in the case that after 7 days it receives at least 5 up votes with a 2/3 majority in favor. Please upvote or downvote this question based on your opinion of the policy statement as presented (not based on whether the premise of the question is reasonable).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Please first read: &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/879/should-we-permit-linking-to-illegal-stuff&quot;&gt;Should we permit linking to illegal stuff?&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;If you have a proposal please post it as an answer.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;I will start with a draft just for online copies of copyrighted books which are both unauthorized and illegal (under laws of USA and the state that its laws apply to SE). If you want to include any other thing please post it as a modification to the policy in an answer.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;This is a policy for the site that &lt;em&gt;we adopt&lt;/em&gt; (in the case it is accepted) and does not imply legal obligations of any kind for moderators/community.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Policy Proposal&lt;/strong&gt; (Jan. 19, 2011): Links to unauthorized illegal online copies of copyrighted books are not welcome on this site. Posting such links is considered &lt;em&gt;unethical&lt;/em&gt; and &lt;em&gt;not respectful&lt;/em&gt; to our colleagues; it is not a nice practice. Users are &lt;strong&gt;discouraged&lt;/strong&gt; from posting such links.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;  &#xA;  &lt;p&gt;Questions asking for such links should be closed.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="186" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" LastActivityDate="2011-01-21T00:08:55.257" Title="Site's policy regarding links to unauthorised copies of books" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;policy&gt;" AnswerCount="5" CommentCount="13" />
./Posts.xml:848:  <row Id="892" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAnswerId="893" CreationDate="2011-01-21T14:55:41.367" Score="5" ViewCount="222" Body="&lt;p&gt;In &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/4412/partitioning-a-connected-shape-into-rectangles&quot;&gt;this question&lt;/a&gt;, I received a spot-on one line answer in a comment that referred me to a more extensive answer by someone else to a different question on MathOverflow.  I plan to acknowledge David Eppstein for his answer on MathOverflow, and to cite one or more of the papers he referred to in his answer.  I'm interested, though, in what people think about acknowledging brief comments, especially since the commenter reposted his comment as an answer in an almost under-protest way.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In this specific situation, if the commenter (Peter Shor) were to say, &quot;Yes please acknowledge me,&quot; or, &quot;No, don't,&quot; I would move with that, either way, so I'm not that concerned with the specific. ./Posts.xml:850:  <row Id="894" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2011-01-21T20:33:03.300" Score="3" ViewCount="135" Body="&lt;p&gt;The 2011 Community Moderator Election is now underway!&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Community moderator elections have three phases:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Nomination phase&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Primary phase&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Election phase&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Most elections take between two and three weeks, but this depends how many candidates there are.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Please visit the official election page at&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/election&quot;&gt;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/election&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;for more detail, and to participate!&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If you have general questions about the election process, or questions for moderator candidates, feel free to ask them here on meta -- just make sure your questions are tagged &lt;a href=&quot;/questions/tagged/election&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;election&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;election&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="-1" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" LastActivityDate="2011-01-22T01:50:02.857" Title="2011 Community Moderator Election" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;moderators&gt;&lt;election&gt;" AnswerCount="0" CommentCount="5" CommunityOwnedDate="2011-01-21T20:33:03.300" />
./Posts.xml:851:  <row Id="896" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2011-01-23T07:09:49.590" Score="5" ViewCount="355" Body="&lt;p&gt;First of all, if you have not seen the &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/election&quot;&gt;Moderator Election Page&lt;/a&gt;, please follow the link to see all the nominations and their intros.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://math.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/1254/list-of-questions-for-candidates-in-2010-moderator-election&quot;&gt;In the same spirit as mathSE&lt;/a&gt; in the 2010 election, I think it is a good idea to ask questions about our site and community to the moderator candidates, and by their responses the community can make a better choice in the election phase. (Since comments will &lt;a href=&quot;http://blog.stackoverflow.com/2010/12/stack-exchange-moderator-elections-begin/&quot;&gt;not be allowed&lt;/a&gt; in the primary and election phases.)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Please leave one question per answer, and the candidates can response shortly in the comments. No enforcement if the candidates are unwillingly to answer; and this should not be counted as a negative indication toward the candidates. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;But for preventing that this post works as a &quot;pre-election&quot; to the candidates, please do not vote the comments according to your agreement. ./Posts.xml:863:  <row Id="909" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="907" CreationDate="2011-01-29T05:10:42.337" Score="2" Body="&lt;p&gt;For the benefit of later readers, here is a summary of the facts explained in &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/907/nomination-statement-is-grayed-out-after-re-nomination/908#908&quot;&gt;the answer by a site admin Rebecca Chernoff&lt;/a&gt; and the comments on it:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;A grayed out statement means that the nomination was withdrawn.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;The intent of the admins was not to allow renomination after withdrawal.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;The description of the election did not state this restriction explicitly.  In addition, there was a bug which made renomination seemingly possible.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;In the case of Lev, the admins declared that the withdrawal was a mistake, and added him back to the candidate list.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="567" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.560" LastActivityDate="2011-01-29T19:29:35.700" CommentCount="3" />
./Posts.xml:865:  <row Id="911" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="910" CreationDate="2011-01-29T12:39:40.850" Score="3" Body="&lt;p&gt;It took me some time to figure out how the user interface at &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/election&quot;&gt;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/election&lt;/a&gt; works, so here is what I learned:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;It is not a typical SE user interface where you can change your mind by clicking the vote button again.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;If you are quick, you &lt;em&gt;can&lt;/em&gt; change your votes, and you can remove &lt;em&gt;some&lt;/em&gt; of your votes. For example, if you have chosen A = 1st and B = 2nd, then you can select C = 2nd and your vote on B is removed. And then you can then select C = 1st, and your vote on A is removed, too. This way you can remove all of your votes, &lt;em&gt;except one&lt;/em&gt;! A strange limitation, but that seems to be how it works.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;At some point your votes get frozen. If you try to change your votes, you only get a popup note that says &quot;Your votes are too old to be changed&quot;.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Edit:&lt;/strong&gt; See &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/913/your-votes-are-too-old-to-be-changed&quot;&gt;&amp;quot;Your votes are too old to be changed&amp;quot;&lt;/a&gt; for yet another feature of the system.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="74" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" LastActivityDate="2011-01-30T00:03:23.027" CommentCount="2" />
./Posts.xml:866:  <row Id="912" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAnswerId="915" CreationDate="2011-01-29T13:08:50.053" Score="4" ViewCount="133" Body="&lt;p&gt;On our front page, we have now the following question:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/4625/graph-having-diameter-k-times-the-average-distance-closed&quot;&gt;Graph having diameter k times the average distance [closed]&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If you click on the link, you are redirected to a &quot;Page Not Found&quot; error message at math.stackexchange.com.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Perhaps this is related to a question that was first migrated and then deleted, but the end result is certainly confusing. And it bothers me a bit: a question has been closed, but I cannot read the question or the reason why it was closed.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="74" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" LastActivityDate="2011-02-28T23:21:07.373" Title="Redirect to errors" Tags="&lt;support&gt;&lt;questions&gt;&lt;migration&gt;" AnswerCount="1" CommentCount="2" />
./Posts.xml:868:  <row Id="914" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAnswerId="926" CreationDate="2011-01-29T20:12:52.620" Score="6" ViewCount="83" Body="&lt;p&gt;I am not sure if moderators can change the system message calling for voting, but if possible, please consider changing the current message:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;Cast your final vote in the Theoretical Computer Science 2011 community moderator election!&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;to something along&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;Cast your vote in the Theoretical Computer Science 2011 community moderator election if you have at least 150 reputation points!&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The proposed changes are:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Primary proposal: Add “if you have at least 150 reputation points” because otherwise you are asking people with &amp;lt;150 rep points to do something you disallow, which is not nice.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Secondary proposal: Change “final vote” to simply “vote” because we did not have the primary phase.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Related to the first item, a user of Meta Stack Overflow had proposed something similar in &lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/76506/dont-have-stack-overflow-propose-that-i-vote-in-the-moderator-election-when-i-do&quot;&gt;Don't have Stack Overflow propose that I vote in the moderator election when I don't have the reputation to do so&lt;/a&gt;.  Unlike that post, I am not asking to change the system message depending on the user’s reputation points.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="567" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-20T10:29:37.593" LastActivityDate="2011-02-03T20:03:32.897" Title="Oddities in the election system message" Tags="&lt;support&gt;&lt;status-completed&gt;&lt;election&gt;" AnswerCount="1" CommentCount="1" />
./Posts.xml:873:  <row Id="919" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2011-02-02T11:50:55.910" Score="10" ViewCount="161" Body="&lt;p&gt;Migration is a nice feature but I am starting to get annoyed by the bad migrated questions we are receiving. I haven't counted but my feeling is that the majority of migrated questions to cstheory are problematic. Here is a recent case:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/q/4700/186&quot;&gt;2 partition problem with equal cardinality&lt;/a&gt; &#xA;  is migrated while OP had already posted the same question &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/4644/faster-pseudo-polynomial-time-algorithms-for-partition&quot;&gt;here &lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Moderators on other SE sites don't necessarily understand what is an appropriate question on cstheory and this makes their decisions problematic. An ideal person for making the decision to migrate a question is someone who is an active high reputation user on both sites not just the sending site, but right now this is not the case. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I think that the decision about migrating a question should be made by both sides not just the sending site. We should be able to vet questions before they are migrated to cstheory, for example when a moderator on a sending site migrates a questions it should not become migrated at once but should become a possible migratable question on the receiving site visible only to moderators and high reputation users (say +2K) for a limited time (say one week) and if it receives enough migration votes on the receiving site or if a moderator on the receiving site decides that it is on-topic and suitable for the site then the migration is completed.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Another possibility is to allow high reputation users vote to unmigrate a migrated question back to the original site (with a note to the migrating moderator about it so they will be more careful in their feature migration decisions).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="186" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" LastActivityDate="2011-11-25T15:46:23.017" Title="Migration problems: both sides should be involved in making migration decisions" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;feature-request&gt;&lt;migration&gt;" AnswerCount="4" CommentCount="6" />
./Posts.xml:874:  <row Id="920" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="919" CreationDate="2011-02-02T12:26:33.217" Score="2" Body="&lt;p&gt;Each StackExchange site should have a Migration FAQ. For us, this would be a summary of selected answers in our &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science&quot;&gt;FAQ&lt;/a&gt;, namely those dealing with what is on- and what is off-topic. It should not be longer than half a dozen one-liners.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Before a migration vote can be made, the target site's Migration FAQ pops up with a button to actually vote below it (similar to license crap). This directly educates the migrator under the assumption that he cares (hopefully valid) and prevents a nasty bounce to happen.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="1546" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" LastActivityDate="2011-02-02T12:26:33.217" CommentCount="1" />
./Posts.xml:876:  <row Id="922" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="921" CreationDate="2011-02-02T23:30:31.330" Score="5" Body="&lt;p&gt;I completely agree that there are legitimate reasons to want to undo votes on posts, such as clicking by mistake or changing your mind after some time.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;As I wrote in a comment, &lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/5212/are-there-any-voting-limits/5213#5213&quot;&gt;a vote on a post cannot be canceled except for certain circumstances&lt;/a&gt;.  The official explanation for this restriction, which I cannot find where I saw for now, is “Allowing unlimited undoing would open up the possibility of gaming the system.”  Namely, if you want your answer to be voted up, you could vote down the other answers so that your answer will be shown on the top of the page (because the other answers have now negative score) and lazy users will read only your answer and upvote it.  The downside of this strategy is that you lose 1 rep point every time you cast a downvote, but if you can undo the votes, you can cancel your downvotes after a week or so when no one cares what happens in a question which does not appear on the top page.  Moreover, canceling the downvotes hides the evidence that you have cast many downvotes (the number of upvotes and downvotes you have cast is available on your profile page).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Many (seemingly silly) restrictions on Stack Exchange websites like this originate from the same logic of preventing gaming the system.  I guess that these restrictions came from the real experience by the admins at Stack Overflow Internet Services, Inc., on Stack Overflow and other sites which have longer history than ours.  I appreciate the fact that the admins put their experiences to form the whole Stack Exchange network.  However, I am worried by their general tendency of overreacting to the fear that someone may game the system.  I believe that different communities have different priorities and that earning the rep points is not considered to be as important in cstheory.stackexchange.com as in more popular sites such as Stack Overflow.  I understand that it is sometimes difficult to prevent abusing without ruining the usability for legitimate users, but I hope that they will take the difference like this into account to design the system.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="567" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-20T10:29:37.593" LastActivityDate="2011-02-02T23:30:31.330" CommentCount="2" />
./Posts.xml:880:  <row Id="927" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="823" CreationDate="2011-02-04T07:47:57.343" Score="5" Body="&lt;p&gt;To put things forward, I suggest a concrete text.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The current text:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;Theoretical Computer Science - Stack Exchange is for theoretical computer scientists and researchers in related fields.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;  &#xA;  &lt;p&gt;A rough outline (inclusive, but not exclusive) of topics that are &quot;within scope&quot; for this site is as follows:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;  &#xA;  &lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;    &lt;p&gt;The field of theoretical computer science is interpreted broadly so as to include algorithms, data structures, computational complexity theory, distributed computation, parallel computation, VLSI, machine learning, computational biology, computational geometry, information theory, cryptography, quantum computation, computational number theory and algebra, program semantics and verification, automata theory, and the study of randomness.  &lt;strong&gt;Work in this field is often distinguished by its emphasis on mathematical technique and rigor.&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;  &lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &#xA;  &lt;p&gt;General FAQs about using the Stack Exchange system are given below.  For specific questions more pertinent to this particular site, please visit the &lt;strong&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science&quot;&gt;Official Theoretical Computer Science FAQ&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Although this is not bad as a starting point, there are several shortcomings.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;As is often pointed out, it only mentions what theoretical computer science is and that it does not mention the expected level of questions.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Related to the first item, a list of alternative sites to ask questions is desirable.  The scope of our website is often better communicated by such a list.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;The quotation is unclear about where it is quoted from.  In fact, it is originally quoted from the self-description of ACM SIGACT but it seems that SIGACT has modified this description after the text was copied, so it is kind of obsolete.  For example, the current list includes computational economics and omits the reference to VLSI, both of which are understandable.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;I cannot see the point of emphasizing only the last sentence in the quotation from SIGACT.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;The distinction between “general FAQs” and “official theoretical computer science FAQ” is confusing at best and makes no sense at worst.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I suggest to revise the above text to the following.  &lt;a href=&quot;https://math.stackexchange.com/faq/&quot;&gt;https://math.stackexchange.com/faq/&lt;/a&gt; is written very well, and I stole part of the general structure from it.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Theoretical Computer Science - Stack Exchange&lt;/strong&gt; is for theoretical computer scientists and researchers in related fields.  We welcome &lt;em&gt;research-level&lt;/em&gt; questions in &lt;em&gt;theoretical computer science&lt;/em&gt; (TCS).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;  &#xA;  &lt;p&gt;Although there is no black-and-white distinction between research-level questions and non-research-level questions, questions are considered to be “research-level” roughly when they can be discussed between two professors or between two graduate students working on Ph.D.’s, but not usually between a professor and a typical undergraduate student.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;  &#xA;  &lt;p&gt;For questions other than research-level questions in TCS, you may want to consider the following places to ask:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;  &#xA;  &lt;ul&gt;&#xA;  &lt;li&gt;Research-level mathematics — &lt;a href=&quot;https://mathoverflow.net/&quot;&gt;Math Overflow&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;  &lt;li&gt;Programming — &lt;a href=&quot;https://stackoverflow.com/&quot;&gt;Stack Overflow&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;  &lt;li&gt;General mathematics — &lt;a href=&quot;https://math.stackexchange.com/&quot;&gt;Mathematics - Stack Exchange&lt;/a&gt;; they seem to accept also questions in TCS.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;  &lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;  &#xA;  &lt;p&gt;For an explanation of what TCS is, we refer you to the description of ACM Special Interest Group on Algorithms and Computation Theory (SIGACT):&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;  &#xA;  &lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;    &lt;p&gt;TCS covers a wide variety of topics including algorithms, data structures, computational complexity, parallel and distributed computation, probabilistic computation, quantum computation, automata theory, information theory, cryptography, program semantics and verification, machine learning, computational biology, computational economics, computational geometry, and computational number theory and algebra.  Work in this field is often distinguished by its emphasis on mathematical technique and rigor. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;  &lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &#xA;  &lt;p&gt;Currently we have two separate lists of FAQs.  See also &lt;strong&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science&quot;&gt;Official Theoretical Computer Science FAQ&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;.  Some of the most important entries in the other FAQ are:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;  &#xA;  &lt;ul&gt;&#xA;  &lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/235#235&quot;&gt;What kind of questions are too basic?&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;  &lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/300/how-to-ask-a-good-question&quot;&gt;How to ask a good question?&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;  &lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/237#237&quot;&gt;How do I write formulas?&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;  &lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/361#361&quot;&gt;My (wonderful!) question was closed!  What do I do now?&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;  &lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="567" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-05-23T12:40:08.913" LastActivityDate="2011-02-05T04:06:05.110" CommentCount="27" />
./Posts.xml:882:  <row Id="929" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAnswerId="932" CreationDate="2011-02-05T20:56:41.263" Score="4" ViewCount="298" Body="&lt;p&gt;I found that the binaries of the OpenSTV program for Windows and Mac are available on the &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/election/1&quot;&gt;election&lt;/a&gt; page. ./Posts.xml:896:  <row Id="944" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2011-02-07T16:54:28.830" Score="6" ViewCount="84" Body="&lt;p&gt;Now that &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/823/should-we-put-the-phrase-research-level-in-our-general-faq&quot;&gt;one problem&lt;/a&gt; of the page &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/faq&quot;&gt;cstheory.stackexchange.com/faq&lt;/a&gt; has been resolved, we would like to discuss another: namely, the existence of two lists of FAQs is confusing.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/faq&quot;&gt;cstheory.stackexchange.com/faq&lt;/a&gt; (which I call “FAQ on main” here)&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science&quot;&gt;Official FAQ for Theoretical Computer Science&lt;/a&gt; on the meta site (which I call “FAQ on meta” here)&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;(I am not talking about the &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/faq&quot;&gt;FAQ &lt;em&gt;about&lt;/em&gt; meta&lt;/a&gt;, which serves a different purpose.)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I hope that the new text on the FAQ on main reduces the problem of having two lists by listing some of the most important entries in the FAQ on meta.  Still, I cannot help imagining that both pages are claiming &lt;em&gt;I am the official one!  I am more important than the other list!  Read me first!&lt;/em&gt;, which I do not like.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Note that the moderators cannot edit everything on the FAQ on main, although they can edit certain parts of it.  In a discussion which happened in comments on &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/823/should-we-put-the-phrase-research-level-in-our-general-faq/927#927&quot;&gt;this post&lt;/a&gt;, Suresh (Feb 4 at 16:22) has suggested merging the FAQ on meta to the FAQ on main by putting everything before the section “What kind of questions should I &lt;em&gt;not&lt;/em&gt; ask here?” (if I understand it correctly).  I am not sure if that is the best way.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;em&gt;Update: It turned out that Suresh’s suggestion was something different.  See the comment.&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Other solutions may be:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Include the links of all &lt;em&gt;questions&lt;/em&gt; in the FAQ on meta in the FAQ on main as an itemized list.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Leave the FAQ page on main as is now, and rename the FAQ on meta to something along “Supplemental FAQ for Theoretical Computer Science.”&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;What do you think?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="567" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" LastActivityDate="2011-02-08T20:01:13.123" Title="Existence of two lists of FAQs is confusing" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;" AnswerCount="1" CommentCount="1" FavoriteCount="1" />
./Posts.xml:898:  <row Id="946" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2011-02-09T06:37:48.827" Score="12" ViewCount="679" Body="&lt;p&gt;&lt;em&gt;It seems that overzealous folks at Area 51 closed the proposal without giving it a fair chance.&lt;/em&gt; (Dave Clarke)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;--&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;code&gt;mathoverflow.net&lt;/code&gt; is for mathematicians. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;code&gt;math.stackexchange.com&lt;/code&gt; is for &lt;em&gt;wannabe&lt;/em&gt; and &lt;em&gt;newbie&lt;/em&gt; mathematicians. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;-&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;code&gt;cstheory.stackexchange.com&lt;/code&gt; is for computer scientists. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;code&gt;but-there-is-nothing-AFAIK&lt;/code&gt; for &lt;em&gt;wannabe&lt;/em&gt; and &lt;em&gt;newbie&lt;/em&gt; computer scientists. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Some might say that you can ask your stupid non-research-level questions at math.SE. &#xA;Well, most probably that won't work. For these &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/q/92/612&quot;&gt;reasons&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Such website can help beginners to get to &quot;research level&quot; quickly and then contribute to cstheroy.SE. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;strong&gt;UPDATE:&lt;/strong&gt; Now there is one for &lt;a href=&quot;http://area51.stackexchange.com/proposals/29144/beginner-theoretical-computer-science&quot;&gt;Beginner Theoretical Computer Scientists!&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;NOTES:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;By newbie and wannabe I mean me :D &lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;strike&gt;I have searched area51.SE but there is no such proposal currently.&lt;/strike&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Being a beginner I strongly feel need for beginner cstheory website.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;So, should there be cstheory website for beginners? &#xA;If yes, please suggest a good name for the same. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="612" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" LastActivityDate="2011-02-12T16:08:59.477" Title="A cstheory website for beginners" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;scope&gt;&lt;site-general&gt;&lt;asking-questions&gt;" AnswerCount="3" CommentCount="19" FavoriteCount="1" />
./Posts.xml:903:  <row Id="951" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="947" CreationDate="2011-02-09T18:05:26.973" Score="-4" Body="&lt;p&gt;Maybe some voice from outside... IMO there exist a not so well visible but still solid border between Computer Science and something that I call Computational Science.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The first is mostly a part of mathematics dealing with algorithms, data structures, complexities, languages and stuff. This is what mostly happens here.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The second is an interdisciplinary movement of people using computer computations to make science; this group is rather united by common practical problems and methods than a common interest. Those are people that make all kinds of simulations, like computational physicists, computational chemists, computational biologists, computational sociologists, ..., meteorologists, economists, visual/physical effect makers, various kinds of engineers; people processing data, like various data scientists, bioinformaticians, chemoinformaticians, again economists, machine teachers, text miners, image and sound wizards and the rest of data-AI; finally all soft computing, robotics and steering theory debris.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;There is some overlap between the two, mostly in areas of numerics, BLAS and some &quot;golden&quot; algorithms like Smith-Waterman (C-nal Scientists spent thousands of CPU hours in such so they would use any fast working black-box C-ter Scientists would gave them). Outside this C-nal Scientist don't care much about theoretical aspects of their algorithms. Also most C-ter Scientist don't care much about practical aspects of their work -- and that's why I think those two topics won't blend well.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Summing up, I second with integrating C-nal Science on Area, but rather in a new proposal than this site; see my &lt;a href=&quot;https://area51.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/320/shall-we-unite-computational-science-proposals&quot;&gt;Area51 discuss question about it&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="3737" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-05-03T08:40:57.363" LastActivityDate="2011-02-09T18:05:26.973" CommentCount="6" />
./Posts.xml:914:  <row Id="962" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2011-02-10T17:06:23.427" Score="8" ViewCount="130" Body="&lt;p&gt;This is in part a response to Robert Cartaino's comment on Suresh's comment response &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/947/is-theoretical-computer-science-too-narrow/961#961&quot;&gt;here&lt;/a&gt;.  I wanted to separate it out from the other discussion, though.  I'd like to start by contrasting two questions, one on StackOverflow, and one here.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;First, consider &lt;a href=&quot;https://stackoverflow.com/questions/1003841/how-do-i-move-the-turtle-in-logo&quot;&gt;How do I move the turtle in LOGO&lt;/a&gt;, especially the history of edits and closes.  A simple question with a simple answer, and, instead, it was repeatedly edited and closed by users who decided the question was fake, had nothing to do with programming, etc.  In this case, the asker was someone who wasn't leaving, so he clarified his position and eventually got an answer.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Now consider the question about &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/88/what-would-it-mean-to-disprove-church-turing-thesis&quot;&gt;disproving the Church-Turing thesis&lt;/a&gt;.  In this case, I answered the question, it received a lot of upvotes, and was accepted by the asker.  However, in the months since that occurred, some of the finest minds in TCS have commented or answered that question, both explaining how wrong I was, and also sharing deep insights about the issue.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;A question I'd like people to consider is: Would you rather have a culture of arrogance, in which anyone with enough rep can decide, &quot;Get real, you couldn't possibly be Donald Knuth, I'm closing your question,&quot; or would you rather have a culture in which leading researchers feel comfortable adding to a question where a fairly high rep user already posted an accepted answer?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The question behind this question is, &quot;Why is there such a difference in the two sites?&quot;  I believe the answer lies in StackOverflow's fallacious belief that crowdsourcing is the best way to arrive at truth.  This may be the case for questions at the level of an Ask-the-Audience game show -- or even most in-the-trenches programming questions -- but when literally only a handful of people know the answer, and there are plenty of ways to deceive yourself that you solved the problem (when you didn't), the method breaks down.  Crowdsourcing does not produce truth; it only produces &lt;em&gt;an answer that nobody feels like debating any more&lt;/em&gt;.  This lack of debate might arise because everyone is convinced, or because the few people who know the real answer don't see the point of participating.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Suresh has made the point well that a one-size-fits-all perspective about StackExchange sites does not work.  However, I believe this argument does not go far enough.  The quality of questions and answers on StackOverflow would &lt;em&gt;significantly increase&lt;/em&gt; if that site were broken into smaller pieces.  If quality in answers is the priority, it should be harder than it currently is for C# experts to answer functional programming questions, as one example.  Rather than the academic caution that we have inherited -- not wanting to brashly say things about a field we know little about -- the StackOverflow model encourages people who get lots and lots of upvotes to answer questions in areas where there is little participation, because they'll get even more upvotes, and the people who know better aren't around, or don't want to start confrontation by calling them out.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Right now, on cstheory, if someone created a profile named &quot;Donald Knuth&quot; or &quot;Avi Wigderson&quot; or whoever, and asked a question, I bet everyone would be careful to treat that user like any other, and to treat the question professionally.  The content of the question is what is important, not &quot;making sure we're not being trolled&quot; or whatever.  I believe this attitude comes from our common belief in the importance of truth, as something beyond, &quot;Good enough,&quot; or, &quot;This is what works.&quot;  Moving forward, I think the most important thing to bear in mind is that we want to attract members who share that understanding of the primacy of mathematical truth.  That's what we share with others interested in theory.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;StackExchange, of course, gets revenue as a function of number-of-hits, so I am sure they see the high traffic of StackOverflow as a great thing that should not be messed with by separating out pieces of it.  Ok, fine.  But if they are interested in more crossover among disciplines, they could, for example, institute a tag system that crosses sites.  So, for example, a chemist posting on biostar about the degree sequence of a molecular graph could see questions about degree sequences on cstheory -- and the graph theorist here could see a potential application for the theoretical work!  Personally, I would &lt;em&gt;love&lt;/em&gt; such a feature.  I'd like to ask Joel Spolsky and Robert Cartaino to work on &lt;em&gt;that&lt;/em&gt;, instead of asking us to adapt to the StackOverflow site model, which would not serve us well.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="30" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-05-23T11:33:34.517" LastActivityDate="2011-02-10T17:06:23.427" Title="On the Difference between Crowdsourced Answers and Mathematical Truth" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;" AnswerCount="0" CommentCount="3" FavoriteCount="0" />
./Posts.xml:917:  <row Id="965" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="784" CreationDate="2011-02-10T22:35:04.180" Score="6" Body="&lt;p&gt;Vor &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/4662/is-it-possible-to-find-if-a-sequence-exists-in-polynomial-time-in-the-following-p/4711#4711&quot;&gt;finds a polynomial-time algorithm&lt;/a&gt; for a graph traversal problem raised by Oscar Mederos.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="1677" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" LastActivityDate="2011-02-10T22:35:04.180" CommentCount="0" />
./Posts.xml:918:  <row Id="966" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2011-02-10T23:25:13.010" Score="11" ViewCount="193" Body="&lt;p&gt;We have a number of questions that float up to the top of the queue every month or so. This is the latest one: &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/4236/help-needed-on-method-to-use-for-anomaly-detection&quot;&gt;Help needed on method to use for anomaly detection&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;But some are zombie questions (like the one linked): which means that&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;the question had some issues, and comments were given on how to refine it&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;the question was left open so as to allow time for the OP to fix the question. &lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;the original questioner disappeared or neglected to bother engaging with the commenters&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;the question floated down due to inactivity, and then popped back up thanks to Community. &lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I'd like to propose that we close these questions. I'm NOT proposing that we kill all community-reset questions, but only ones that have the above characteristics. Since closing is reversible, I'm proposing that we treat such questions as if they were just posted and the OP ignored the suggestions, which would normally lead to close votes. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="80" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" LastActivityDate="2011-02-11T21:31:29.377" Title="Zombie question: stake through the heart or not ?" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;closing&gt;" AnswerCount="3" CommentCount="1" FavoriteCount="1" />
./Posts.xml:922:  <row Id="970" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2011-02-11T15:56:48.627" Score="12" ViewCount="336" Body="&lt;p&gt;MathOverflow works very well for mathematicians, in part because it is run by mathematicians, who understand how mathematicians interact. One clever thing they do to make the site useful for the research community is to redirect some questions to the math.SE site. That seems to work very well. (When they have spare time, they do visit math.SE and answer questions.)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The proposal to create a similar place to redirect basic TCS questions was quickly dismissed on area51, because people there &lt;a href=&quot;https://area51.meta.stackexchange.com/q/612/13087&quot;&gt;disagree with having two sites on the same topic with different lower bounds&lt;/a&gt;. On the other hand, they have nothing against the MathOverflow/math.SE model because they view MathOverflow as being outside SE. (Which, frankly, mixes technical issues --- who runs the site -- with social issues --- who participates in the site.)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;It seems to me that both SE people and TCS researchers might be happy with migrating the TCS researcher community outside the SE network and have it run by TCS researchers. What do you think?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;PS: Just to be clear, I do not feel that we should move, but I think it's an option that is worth discussing.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="236" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-05-03T08:40:57.363" LastActivityDate="2012-01-12T17:54:27.530" Title="Why StackExchange?" ./Posts.xml:927:  <row Id="975" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAnswerId="976" CreationDate="2011-02-13T16:42:04.980" Score="10" ViewCount="187" Body="&lt;p&gt;In our discussion of whether the &lt;em&gt;Theoretical&lt;/em&gt; Computer Science is too narrow for this site, I &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/947/is-theoretical-computer-science-too-narrow/964#964&quot;&gt;suggested&lt;/a&gt; a compromise idea that would have different forums like this site, all linked together more so than the average SE sites.  It has been observed that this idea can even tackle the &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/946/a-cstheory-website-for-beginners/974#974&quot;&gt;beginners forum&lt;/a&gt; issue (though I am not sure that would be a good idea).  One major impediment is that the current software does not support such an idea, so the SE people would have to put in considerable effort to make it happen.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The idea went as follows:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;I think it would be great to have a&#xA;  CS stackexchange site that had&#xA;  multiple &quot;forums&quot; (for the different&#xA;  fields of CS) like cstheory. The&#xA;  membership could be shared. The&#xA;  reputation points could transfer&#xA;  across the forums. But each site&#xA;  should have its own homepage which&#xA;  featured only its own questions - tags&#xA;  and filters are not nearly enough.&#xA;  Perhaps the featured bounty questions&#xA;  could be shared across forums, as&#xA;  could questions with very high scores.&#xA;  That way, we could see what exciting&#xA;  things are happening in the other&#xA;  fields and would be tempted to&#xA;  occasionally browse the other forums&#xA;  without their questions clogging the&#xA;  theory ones. This would increase the&#xA;  user base as users from all the forums&#xA;  would occasionally do some browsing&#xA;  and answering each others' questions.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The response seems to have been positive.  I am curious:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Is there support within the community for such a proposal (if done right)?&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&lt;em&gt;Assuming there is community support&lt;/em&gt;, is this something the people running StackExchange are willing to consider implementing.&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Does anyone see a downside? Is there opposition to this idea?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I guess cstheory users can only answer question 1 and the people running SE can only answer question 2.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="123" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" LastActivityDate="2011-02-14T16:03:34.720" Title="Multiple Research Forums (like this One) Linked Together -- a Proposal" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;scope&gt;" AnswerCount="3" CommentCount="5" FavoriteCount="1" />

./Posts.xml:939:  <row Id="987" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="986" CreationDate="2011-02-17T03:59:50.070" Score="0" Body="&lt;p&gt;I took a quick glance over all questions in the list with at least 2 up-votes. ./Posts.xml:945:  <row Id="994" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2011-02-21T04:18:46.903" Score="6" ViewCount="81" Body="&lt;p&gt;So this is probably the first instance what I can only describe as user spam. Unfortunately, non-mods won't be able to see the answers since they've been deleted, but &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/users/3910/mouton&quot;&gt;user mouton&lt;/a&gt;, who joined just today, posted 5 answers in quick succession, none of which made any sense and were immediately flagged by users. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I (somewhat unilaterally) decided to use the SE email mechanism to email the user, in which I explained that their answers were repeatedly being flagged for low quality, and issued a warning that if this activity continued, they would be suspended for two days.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The question I have is: is this a reasonable way of dealing with such cases ? &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Since it will be hard to discuss this out of context, below are examples:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;On &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/857/which-ac0-problems-are-not-truly-feasible&quot;&gt;this question about infeasibility of AC^0 problems&lt;/a&gt;: these answers:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&quot;I guess the Gödel's incompleteness theore mis quite enough to give you a proof on the quid of your question. In addition, I guess that you're not believing in any mathematical demonstration of the &quot;universe&quot;?!&quot;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&quot;(sorry, the arithmetic hierarchy made me thinking about some Bourbaky languages.. :)&quot; &lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;On &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/844&quot;&gt;this question about provable statements about genetic algorithms&lt;/a&gt;:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&quot;my only comment would be that genetic is so complex (it is the same dimension as our society, let's say...big factories) that you can't really put a fixed value on the effect of genetic (it's not the only one which is a factory: search at different scales)so I would suggest you to go more on the geometry philosophy to get an answer to your problem. Maybe also on some orientation and symetry like theory... &quot;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;On &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/5003/&quot;&gt;a question about a graph transformation preserving isomorphism&lt;/a&gt;:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&quot;Isomorphic means that you have a function f such f(G1+G2)=f(G1)+f(G2) and solve some algebraic properties. Please look in wikipedia to look which one, and define your &quot;+&quot; and check if all the properties are correct regarding to your isomorphism&quot;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;On &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/3173/&quot;&gt;a question about proofs that reveal a deeper structure&lt;/a&gt;:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&quot;I met a stat teacher a few days ago. Wanted to ask him some stat question, 'cause I find that math stat is quite abstract. He told me that, yeah, indeed, you should look in some applied statistique to find some concrete example on the stat methodology (test to modelling). If that can help you..It is also for some biological concern.&quot;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;There were also two answers in French, whose quality I can't ascertain. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="80" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" LastActivityDate="2011-02-21T08:08:06.480" Title="Dealing with user spam" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;users&gt;" AnswerCount="1" CommentCount="7" />
./Posts.xml:947:  <row Id="996" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2011-02-21T14:10:30.637" Score="8" ViewCount="182" Body="&lt;p&gt;Should we close this type of question: &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/5048/evaluating-a-doctoral-program-institute-of-cs&quot;&gt;&quot;Evaluating a doctoral programinstitute of CS?&quot;&lt;/a&gt;. On the one hand, it's somewhat similar to the type of career advice questions we do allow. On the other hand, it comes awfully close to &quot;What are the good programs in CS?&quot; which would definitely be closed. ./Posts.xml:952:  <row Id="1001" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAnswerId="1004" CreationDate="2011-02-22T05:26:14.823" Score="3" ViewCount="121" Body="&lt;p&gt;Currently &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/graph-colouring&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;graph-colouring&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;graph-colouring&lt;/a&gt; has a large number of questions, and &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/coloring&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;coloring&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;coloring&lt;/a&gt; has two questions with no significant difference to those of &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/graph-colouring&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;graph-colouring&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;graph-colouring&lt;/a&gt;.
