Which direction should the merge be performed?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="1800" LastActivityDate="2011-02-22T22:19:01.010" Title="Should we merge [coloring] to/from [graph-colouring]?" ./Posts.xml:953:  <row Id="1002" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2011-02-22T05:55:23.047" Score="0" ViewCount="160" Body="&lt;p&gt;This is related to &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/q/455/1800&quot;&gt;the question about top-level tags&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;It seem to me that the tag &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/computability&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;computability&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;computability&lt;/a&gt; acts differently than other tags. While it belongs to the top-level tag &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/lo.logic&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;lo.logic&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;lo.logic&lt;/a&gt; (is it?), a large number of question with &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/computability&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;computability&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;computability&lt;/a&gt; just don't have any top-level tags. I guess some of the poster raises their questions in the field out of &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/lo.logic&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;lo.logic&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;lo.logic&lt;/a&gt;, and it is just hard to think of this top-level tag while posting. And maybe some of them just think that &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/computability&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;computability&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;computability&lt;/a&gt; &lt;em&gt;is&lt;/em&gt; the top-level tag.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;It seems that there are no related categories in Arxiv, so what should we do? Should we leave them there? Should we tag them with &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/lo.logic&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;lo.logic&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;lo.logic&lt;/a&gt;? Or should we make a fake Arxiv tag, like &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/cp.computability&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;cp.computability&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;cp.computability&lt;/a&gt;?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="1800" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" LastActivityDate="2011-02-23T16:35:48.560" Title="[computability] behaves like a top-level tag" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;tags&gt;" AnswerCount="4" CommentCount="0" />
./Posts.xml:954:  <row Id="1003" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="1002" CreationDate="2011-02-22T06:25:37.780" Score="4" Body="&lt;p&gt;Yes, we have treated the [computability] tag as a top level tag, it is like the [quantum-computing] and [physics] tags, and I personally don't see any problem with them. I also don't think they need to have the [lo.logic] tag.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;It might be better to have one corresponding to the AA.BBBB syntax like other top level tags, in which case I should say I don't think [cp.computability] is a good one, [ct.computability] (for computability theory) would be much better, but I think [computability] is also good enough.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/271/official-interim-procedure-for-doing-retagging&quot;&gt;Official interim procedure for doing retagging.&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="186" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" LastActivityDate="2011-02-22T06:33:38.127" CommentCount="4" />
./Posts.xml:957:  <row Id="1006" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="1002" CreationDate="2011-02-22T16:17:15.787" Score="2" Body="&lt;p&gt;I will again advocate against using arXiv style tags.  Coarse tagging is probably useful if the set of tags is designed carefully, and I guess that &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/computability&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;computability&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;computability&lt;/a&gt; is a good tag for that.  We do not have to follow the naming convention in arXiv in tags.  Adding meaningless letters “cp.” to the tag is a terrible way to indicate that it can be used as a coarse category.  Let’s stop using arXiv style tags, and let’s stop creating more arXiv style tags than we unfortunately already have.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="567" LastActivityDate="2011-02-22T16:17:15.787" CommentCount="15" />
./Posts.xml:959:  <row Id="1008" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="1001" CreationDate="2011-02-22T22:19:01.010" Score="2" Body="&lt;p&gt;I agree to Suresh.  &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/graph-colouring&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;graph-colouring&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;graph-colouring&lt;/a&gt; is more informative than &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/coloring&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;coloring&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;coloring&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;One possible argument against merging the two tags into &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/graph-colouring&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;graph-colouring&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;graph-colouring&lt;/a&gt; is that it refers to a narrower notion.  Indeed, I can imagine that some users may feel a mental barrier when trying to tag a question about hypergraph coloring as &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/graph-colouring&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;graph-colouring&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;graph-colouring&lt;/a&gt;.  However, I think that this mental barrier is low enough and that questions about hypergraph coloring (or any notions related to graph coloring) can be tagged as &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/graph-colouring&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;graph-colouring&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;graph-colouring&lt;/a&gt; without much confusion.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;By the way, the difference between American and British spellings should be handled by synonyms.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="567" LastActivityDate="2011-02-22T22:19:01.010" CommentCount="4" />

./Posts.xml:963:  <row Id="1012" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAnswerId="1017" CreationDate="2011-02-23T23:04:47.613" Score="4" ViewCount="118" Body="&lt;p&gt;It is &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/455/using-at-least-one-top-level-arxiv-tag&quot;&gt;recommended&lt;/a&gt; to tag every question with at least one in the (vaguely recognized) set of tags that represent the subject areas of questions.  These tags are sometimes referred to as “top-level tags,” but I would like to change this name if there is a better name.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The word “top-level” implies existence of a hierarchical structure.  Since most tags are not part of any hierarchical structure, the word “top-level” does not make much sense.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Does anyone have an idea what they should be called?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;hr&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;em&gt;Update&lt;/em&gt;: Let’s call them “area tags.”  (Thanks to Kaveh for proposing this name.)  It is a concise name which describes their nature pretty accurately.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="567" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" LastActivityDate="2011-02-25T18:32:47.330" Title="Better name for the so-called “top-level tags”" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;tags&gt;" AnswerCount="1" CommentCount="7" />
./Posts.xml:964:  <row Id="1013" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="1010" CreationDate="2011-02-24T02:34:01.047" Score="-3" Body="&lt;p&gt;Although I am far from being an expert in this, I believe that &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/lg.learning&quot;&gt;lg.learning&lt;/a&gt;  and &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/machine-learning&quot;&gt;machine-learning&lt;/a&gt; refer to the same thing. I do not know of any other kind of learning related to TCS other than machine learning. However, &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/online-learning&quot;&gt;online-learning&lt;/a&gt; is a subtype of machine learning and I believe that it should be a different tag. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="879" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" LastActivityDate="2011-02-24T02:34:01.047" CommentCount="0" />
./Posts.xml:966:  <row Id="1015" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2011-02-24T20:25:13.773" Score="7" ViewCount="244" Body="&lt;p&gt;The question &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/5125/regular-expressions-finding-negation-of-regular-expression&quot;&gt;Regular expressions: Finding “negation” of regular expression?&lt;/a&gt; seems awfully basic to me. ./Posts.xml:970:  <row Id="1019" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2011-02-27T18:15:57.893" Score="3" ViewCount="176" Body="&lt;p&gt;This is a continuation of a discussion which took place in comments on &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/1002/computability-behaves-like-a-top-level-tag/1006#1006&quot;&gt;this post&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;It is &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/455/using-at-least-one-top-level-arxiv-tag&quot;&gt;recommended&lt;/a&gt; to tag every question with at least one &lt;strong&gt;area tag&lt;/strong&gt; (&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/1012/better-name-for-the-so-called-top-level-tags&quot;&gt;formerly called “top-level tag”&lt;/a&gt;).  Currently area tags are named in the following way:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;The area tags which originate from &lt;a href=&quot;http://arxiv.org/corr/subjectclasses&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;CoRR subject areas&lt;/a&gt; are named as &lt;code&gt;xx.description&lt;/code&gt; where &lt;code&gt;xx&lt;/code&gt; is the coresponding CoRR subject area codes and &lt;code&gt;description&lt;/code&gt; is the descriptive name of the area.  Examples are &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/cr.crypto-security&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;cr.crypto-security&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;cr.crypto-security&lt;/a&gt;, &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/cg.comp-geom&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;cg.comp-geom&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;cg.comp-geom&lt;/a&gt;, &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/ds.algorithms&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;ds.algorithms&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;ds.algorithms&lt;/a&gt; and &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/ds.data-structures&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;ds.data-structures&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;ds.data-structures&lt;/a&gt;.  Note that some area tags deviate from the categorization in CoRR.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;The other area tags are labeled like usual tags.  Examples are &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/computability&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;computability&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;computability&lt;/a&gt; and &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/quantum-computing&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;quantum-computing&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;quantum-computing&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;There are two problems with the current area tags.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Names depend on whether they originate from CoRR subject areas or not, which is not an important distinction.  Therefore tags look simply inconsistent.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;There is no advantage of having the corresponding CoRR subject area codes in the tags.  As I understand it, the only purpose of these codes is to indicate that they are area tags.  However, this is incomplete because not every area tag has a two-letter code.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I think that a more consistent naming is better.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If the Stack Exchange server had a functionality of showing area tags in a different color, we would not have to distinguish them by names.  Because it does not have such a functionality, it is better to distinguish area tags by names.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Therefore, I propose the following:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Proposal&lt;/strong&gt;.  Remove the &lt;code&gt;xx.&lt;/code&gt; part from the area tags of the form &lt;code&gt;xx.description&lt;/code&gt; and instead add a fixed prefix to all the area tags.  As the fixed prefix, I suggest to use either &lt;code&gt;a.&lt;/code&gt; (for “area”) or just &lt;code&gt;.&lt;/code&gt;.  [&lt;em&gt;Edit&lt;/em&gt;: I removed the earlier suggestions &lt;code&gt;a:&lt;/code&gt; and &lt;code&gt;:&lt;/code&gt; because it turned out that a colon cannot be used in tags.]&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="567" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" LastActivityDate="2011-03-01T20:40:08.750" Title="Use a consistent prefix to distinguish area tags instead of CoRR subject area codes" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;tags&gt;" AnswerCount="5" CommentCount="26" />
./Posts.xml:972:  <row Id="1021" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2011-02-27T20:59:51.677" Score="4" ViewCount="109" Body="&lt;p&gt;In &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/5180/what-universities-in-the-united-states-or-in-europe-have-a-phd-focus-in-theoretic&quot;&gt;these&lt;/a&gt; &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/5162/are-there-any-known-barriers-to-use-some-approach-for-solving-p-vs-np&quot;&gt;two&lt;/a&gt; questions, there's extensive discussion in comments (in one case in an answer) on the suitability of the question. To me, this seems like a discussion to be had here on meta, and so my question is:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;When such discussions start forming,&#xA;  should we quickly shift the discussion&#xA;  to meta, adding a link and strongly&#xA;  encouraging commenters to move their&#xA;  comments to the corresponding meta&#xA;  thread ?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="80" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" LastActivityDate="2011-02-27T20:59:51.677" Title="Using meta instead of comments for discussion on suitability of a question" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;policy&gt;&lt;comments&gt;" AnswerCount="0" CommentCount="4" />

./Posts.xml:976:  <row Id="1026" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAnswerId="1027" CreationDate="2011-02-28T02:28:23.207" Score="2" ViewCount="280" Body="&lt;p&gt;This is about the following question:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/5162/are-there-any-known-barriers-to-use-some-approach-for-solving-p-vs-np&quot;&gt;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/5162/are-there-any-known-barriers-to-use-some-approach-for-solving-p-vs-np&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="186" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" LastActivityDate="2012-01-12T18:53:00.243" Title="About &quot;Are there any known barriers to use some approach for solving P vs. NP?&quot;" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;closing&gt;&lt;specific-question&gt;" AnswerCount="1" CommentCount="0" FavoriteCount="1" />
./Posts.xml:977:  <row Id="1027" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="1026" CreationDate="2011-02-28T02:35:49.287" Score="6" Body="&lt;p&gt;I think this question should be closed for two different reasons:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I. This is against the policy about not allowing questions about unpublished not-peer-reviewed approaches to open problems and crank-friendly topics. The OP states that this is equivalent to &quot;$\mathbf{P}$ vs. $\mathbf{NP}$&quot;, and therefore it falls under that policy and should be closed as &lt;strong&gt;off-topic&lt;/strong&gt;. The cosmetics like the way of phrasing the question are irrelevant. In fact some users on Math.SE have advised the OP to phrase the question in that way to get around our policy, see &lt;a href=&quot;https://math.stackexchange.com/questions/23850/are-there-any-known-barriers-to-some-approach-for-solving-p-vs-np&quot;&gt;here&lt;/a&gt;:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;If you cross-post this question to CSTheory, it may not be well-received. If you re-phrase your question to something like &quot;Are there known barriers to this approach to P \neq NP?&quot;, this might be better.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;II. The post is also not a real question, refer to the comments by OP under the Math.SE post:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;&quot;I am no researcher and therefore I am only privately interested in this question&quot;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;  &#xA;  &lt;p&gt;&quot;With my above question, I wanted only to share my main idea for attacking this problem. Perhaps some experienced mathematician like you is able to use my idea in some way.&quot;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The OP who states that she/he is not a expert wants to &lt;em&gt;share&lt;/em&gt; his idea about how to solve the open problem with experts, this is clearly &lt;strong&gt;not-a-real-question&lt;/strong&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="186" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:19:18.947" LastActivityDate="2011-02-28T02:49:47.497" CommentCount="16" />
./Posts.xml:978:  <row Id="1028" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2011-02-28T07:56:27.883" Score="6" ViewCount="191" Body="&lt;p&gt;There's a rollback extravaganza happening on &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/5180/what-universities-in-the-united-states-or-in-europe-have-a-phd-focus-in-theoretic&quot;&gt;this question&lt;/a&gt;. There are a number of problems in the question, and foolishly I contributed to this by even answering. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;There are multiple questions within the question, and they are quite different from each other and should have been separated out&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;On the question of universities with a &quot;focus&quot; on theory, there's a clear ambiguity. If the question was asking for places where one could apply directly into a TCS program, then it makes sense (because not many places have this option). That was my intent in answering. However, if the question was asking for places that have a strong theory group (whatever that means) then it's completely out of bounds for our site. &lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;My feeling is that given the massive editing and re-editing happening on the answer (by our mods, no less!), we need to shift all discussion here. My personal preference is that this question be closed, and if the OP wishes to ask a set of very specific questions they may do so. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="80" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" LastActivityDate="2011-02-28T10:57:33.230" Title="Ph.D Schools &quot;focusing&quot; on theory" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;scope&gt;&lt;specific-question&gt;" AnswerCount="0" CommentCount="6" />

./Posts.xml:980:  <row Id="1030" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="502" CreationDate="2011-02-28T17:04:34.990" Score="5" Body="&lt;p&gt;I somehow forgot to post the user script “&lt;a href=&quot;https://stackapps.com/questions/2061/disable-enter-for-submitting-comments&quot;&gt;Disable enter for submitting comments&lt;/a&gt;” by Jeff Atwood of Stack Overflow Internet Services.  As the name says, this user script prevents pressing the Enter key from submitting a comment.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Because I use an &lt;a href=&quot;http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Input_method&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;input method editor&lt;/a&gt; to enter symbols such as quotation marks and mathematical symbols, I find it very difficult to write comments without this user script.  I do not think that this applies to many people, but if you are experiencing the same problem, the user script will save you a lot of time.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="567" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:25:39.260" LastActivityDate="2011-02-28T17:04:34.990" CommentCount="1" />
./Posts.xml:981:  <row Id="1031" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="1019" CreationDate="2011-02-28T20:05:33.720" Score="4" Body="&lt;p&gt;Please keep in mind the following aspects:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;One of the tags appears in the page title (and hence also in Google search results). The logic seems to be the following: take the most common (least specific...) tag and replace each dash with a space. The end result is something like this with the current tags:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;cc.complexity theory - Problems Between P and NPC - Theoretical Computer Science - Stack Exchange&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;The maximum length of a tag is 25 characters. For example, these should be fine (just some hypothetical examples to illustrate the limitations):&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/subject.quantum-computing&quot; ./Posts.xml:990:  <row Id="1041" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="1039" CreationDate="2011-03-05T01:01:31.933" Score="3" Body="&lt;p&gt;This isn't a direct answer to your question but I think this is also useful.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I use an android smartphone and use the app &lt;a href=&quot;https://market.android.com/details?id=org.droidstack&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;Droidstack&lt;/a&gt;. You can use it for every SE site not only TCS.SE. Currently it doesn't support MathJax. So if you want to read the questions with math support you have to open it in your browser (there is a button in this app to do this).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Additionally it checks your reputation score if you want to and notifies any changes. It isn't a full client. You can't post any questions/answers/comments. But if you only wan't to read the questions/answers/comments this is a great app.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Do anybody use some other apps (iphone/ipad or android)?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="2517" LastActivityDate="2011-03-05T01:01:31.933" CommentCount="0" />
./Posts.xml:991:  <row Id="1042" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAnswerId="1043" CreationDate="2011-03-09T22:03:36.907" Score="11" ViewCount="365" Body="&lt;p&gt;I am a Pro Tem moderator on &lt;a href=&quot;https://quant.stackexchange.com/&quot;&gt;Quant Finance SE&lt;/a&gt;. We are in a struggle at the moment to get sufficient questions to make it out of beta. One particular issue is that we narrow the question scope to a &lt;em&gt;professional&lt;/em&gt; level, which for the quant world is (1) very niche and (2) very high-level. This seems to have limited participation dramatically.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The closest analogy I can think of to Quant SE's ideals is TCS SE. How did this site get the traction it currently has? How was it able to maintain participation while requiring PhD-level material?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="2581" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:46:22.537" LastActivityDate="2011-03-17T15:43:04.377" Title="How did TCS SE gain traction?" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;" AnswerCount="5" CommentCount="0" FavoriteCount="1" />
./Posts.xml:992:  <row Id="1043" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="1042" CreationDate="2011-03-09T23:11:57.790" Score="11" Body="&lt;p&gt;My guess is that a lot of it has to do with that computer scientists also form a real-life community.  We read each other's papers, see each other at conferences, try to collaborate.  I think seeing people you know (or at least know of) in real life participate in the site helps new members want to join.  I don't know if the same thing is possible for quants as, from the little of what I know, strategies, etc., are closely guarded company secrets.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;But I'm sure there are other reasons why TCS-SE was successful, including our efforts in promotion, us using real names, and being a genuinely useful tool for researchers.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;EDIT below: &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;To explain some of our publicity efforts. We 1) have promoted TCS-SE at &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/1045/promoting-tcs-se-at-fcrc&quot;&gt;conferences&lt;/a&gt;, 2) &lt;a href=&quot;http://blog.computationalcomplexity.org/2010/09/theory-social-network.html&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;blogged&lt;/a&gt; and tweeted about the site, 3) wrote &lt;a href=&quot;http://portal.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=1907532&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;articles&lt;/a&gt; in professional magazines announcing the site, 4) tried to formally connect with &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.sigact.org/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;SIGACT&lt;/a&gt; (a TCS professional group), 5) told our many peers about it.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Perhaps you can do the equivalent of some of these steps?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="123" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.560" LastActivityDate="2011-03-10T23:44:32.773" CommentCount="6" />
./Posts.xml:994:  <row Id="1045" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2011-03-10T17:06:22.320" Score="13" ViewCount="481" Body="&lt;p&gt;The last time we did an IRL (in real life) promotional event for TCS.SE was at &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/457/nominations-for-publicity-poster-at-focs&quot;&gt;FOCS 2010&lt;/a&gt;. I don't unfortunately have any data on whether that event worked to draw more people in. We also had the SIGACT News article in the latest issue. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.acm.org/fcrc/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;FCRC&lt;/a&gt; is coming up, and STOC/CCC/EC/PLDI/PODC/SPAA will be there. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;What kinds of promotional events might we carry out at FCRC ? In your answer, please clarify also if you plan to attend, and in what capacity you'd be willing to help with execution of your suggestion. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Also, to help with brainstorming, it might be useful to separate out &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;activities that help with spreading word about the site&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;activities that help increase participation from established researchers as well&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;new activities that could become regular occurrences at major conference events.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="80" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" LastActivityDate="2011-09-01T11:05:22.267" Title="Promoting TCS.SE at FCRC" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;site-promotion&gt;" AnswerCount="4" CommentCount="6" FavoriteCount="4" />

./Posts.xml:1004:  <row Id="1056" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAnswerId="1057" CreationDate="2011-03-14T15:27:43.580" Score="5" ViewCount="99" Body="&lt;p&gt;Question: &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/5470/how-do-you-call-a-subsequence-of-consecutive-elements&quot;&gt;How do you call a subsequence of consecutive elements ?&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I guess that many people working in TCS have once wished for concise and unambiguous terms for “contiguous subsequence” and “not necessarily contiguous (but still order-preserving) subsequence,” and therefore the question is reasonably interesting to TCS researchers. ./Posts.xml:1006:  <row Id="1058" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2011-03-15T04:12:48.160" Score="6" ViewCount="85" Body="&lt;p&gt;Updated version (March 20, 2011):&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;Use this tag if:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;  &#xA;  &lt;ul&gt;&#xA;  &lt;li&gt;&lt;strong&gt;well-known open problems&lt;/strong&gt;: the problem is equivalent to a well-known &lt;a href=&quot;http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open_problem&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;open problem&lt;/a&gt; in the literature&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;  &lt;li&gt;&lt;strong&gt;community open problems&lt;/strong&gt;: the question is not answered after considerable time and the community decides that the question is an open problem (&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/&quot;&gt;meta&lt;/a&gt; can be used for discussions)&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;  &lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;  &#xA;  &lt;hr&gt;&#xA;  &#xA;  &lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/&quot;&gt;cstheory&lt;/a&gt; is &lt;strong&gt;not&lt;/strong&gt; the right place to ask &lt;strong&gt;well-known open problems&lt;/strong&gt;. You should post questions you're actually seriously thinking about. If you're thinking about a well-known open problem, provide some background and ask about something specific related to the problem, like &quot;Such and such is a well-known open problem. So-and-so proposed this and that approach. Does anybody know if this aspect of their proposal can be made to work under these circumstances?&quot; If you want to contribute to (or view) a list of open problems, visit the &lt;a href=&quot;http://garden.irmacs.sfu.ca/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;Open Problem Garden&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;  &#xA;  &lt;p&gt;If it turns out that a problem is equivalent to a well-known open problem, then the &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/open-problem&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;open-problem&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;open-problem&lt;/a&gt; tag is added. After that, the question essentially becomes, &quot;What is known about this problem? What are some possible ways to approach this problem? What are some ways that people have tried to attack it before, and with what results?&quot; That way, the cstheory thread for the problem becomes a repository of resources related to the problem. Perhaps the answers could be organized by approach, with an outline of the basic approach, followed by a horizontal rule and a summary of what is promising about the approach and why it doesn't give a complete solution.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;  &#xA;  &lt;p&gt;To join the discussion about how cstheory should deal with open problems, go to &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/1058/tag-wiki-open-problem&quot;&gt;this&lt;/a&gt; meta cstheory thread.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;hr&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/open-problem&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;open-problem&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;open-problem&lt;/a&gt;'s &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/open-problem&quot;&gt;tag wiki&lt;/a&gt; is based on &lt;a href=&quot;https://mathoverflow.net/faq#openproblems&quot;&gt;MO&lt;/a&gt;'s FAQ on open-problems.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="186" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:57:54.527" LastActivityDate="2011-03-20T09:34:57.110" Title="tag wiki: [open-problem]" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;tag-wiki&gt;" AnswerCount="1" CommentCount="4" CommunityOwnedDate="2011-03-20T09:29:47.350" />

./Posts.xml:1012:  <row Id="1065" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="1042" CreationDate="2011-03-16T11:53:57.173" Score="4" Body="&lt;p&gt;Echoing Suresh, CSTheory is still some way from being successful, as it only attracts a small fraction of the TCS community.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;However, it is important that early users set a high standard, and it might be worth highlighting the especially thoughtful questions and perceptive answers at quant.SE to date.  Perhaps blog posts, an overview article on the Meta site, or an article in a quant publication such as Wilmott magazine could all assist.  Such initiatives have all worked for CSTheory as mentioned by other answers.  The list at &lt;a href=&quot;https://quant.stackexchange.com/questions?sort=votes&quot;&gt;https://quant.stackexchange.com/questions?sort=votes&lt;/a&gt; seems to be a great starting point, and I have found voting feedback at CSTheory useful in choosing which questions to highlight, for instance when adding entries to Radu Grigore's list at &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/446/broadening-the-scope-of-questions/985#985&quot;&gt;Broadening the scope of questions&lt;/a&gt; and for &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/457/nominations-for-publicity-poster-at-focs&quot;&gt;Nominations for publicity poster at FOCS ?&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Listing some of the &quot;greatest hits&quot; allows potential contributors to quickly find content that they are likely to find compelling, and also more firmly establishes the standard that contributors are going to aspire to.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="109" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:46:22.537" LastActivityDate="2011-03-16T12:29:38.423" CommentCount="2" />
./Posts.xml:1013:  <row Id="1066" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2011-03-16T15:30:34.220" Score="6" ViewCount="692" Body="&lt;p&gt;Question: &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/5524/algorithm-to-sort-pairs-of-numbers&quot;&gt;Algorithm to sort pairs of numbers&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I believe that this question is at the level of midterm/final exams in an algorithm course and not at the level of research.  Given the positive comment from one of the moderators and the high score (both of which are unbelievable to me), I do not mind if people keep it open, but I will not claim that this website is for research-level questions anymore, and I recommend others to stop doing so, too.  The “research-level questions” restriction has not been enforced consistently anyway, so we should be just honest.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="567" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" LastActivityDate="2011-04-19T11:28:56.767" Title="We should stop claiming that this website is “research-level”" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;scope&gt;&lt;specific-question&gt;" AnswerCount="4" CommentCount="17" />

./Posts.xml:1029:  <row Id="1082" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2011-03-26T23:27:41.280" Score="8" ViewCount="159" Body="&lt;p&gt;As a non-moderator, I can flag questions for a multitude of reasons. One is &quot;It doesn't belong here&quot; and then &quot;off topic&quot;. After that, a list of possibly suited SE sites is shown along with a generic item.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Currently, only meta.cstheory.SE and stackexchange can be chosen. I think at least math.SE should be included, given how many questions we refer (and should move!) there. Other possible targets are tex.SE and stats.SE.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Who manages this list and how can we influence it?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Edit:&lt;/strong&gt; Crossposted on &lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/84902/list-of-target-sites-in-flagging-wizard&quot;&gt;meta.SE&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="1546" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-20T10:29:37.593" LastActivityDate="2011-04-04T23:23:20.053" Title="List of target sites in flagging wizard" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;feature-request&gt;&lt;migration&gt;" AnswerCount="2" CommentCount="0" FavoriteCount="1" />
./Posts.xml:1033:  <row Id="1086" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAnswerId="1087" CreationDate="2011-03-27T21:45:07.877" Score="7" ViewCount="208" Body="&lt;p&gt;I ask moderators to be very careful when migrating questions to Stack Exchange websites.  When in doubt, please close questions as off topic, possibly with a comment suggesting one or a few candidates of websites, and let the asker decide where to ask.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Note that &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/919/migration-problems-both-sides-should-be-involved-in-making-migration-decisions&quot;&gt;we have been frustrated&lt;/a&gt; by the fact that some questions are migrated &lt;em&gt;to&lt;/em&gt; cstheory when they should not be.  We should not do the same thing to other websites.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Here is a recent example: &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/5615/is-there-a-program-app-algorithm-that-can-sort-items-using-manual-choices-and?noredirect=1&quot;&gt;Is there a program / app / algorithm that can sort items using manual choices and deductive logic?&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;This question was recently migrated to Stack Overflow, but I cannot see any programming aspect in the question, and I think that it was wrong to migrate it to Stack Overflow.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In fact, this is a question on query complexity.  Since it is too basic (the Ω(&lt;i&gt;n&lt;/i&gt; log &lt;i&gt;n&lt;/i&gt;) lower bound is well-known and sometimes even covered in undergraduate courses) and the asker had posted the same question on &lt;a href=&quot;https://math.stackexchange.com/questions/28752/is-there-a-program-or-app-that-will-let-you-sort-items-using-manual-choices-and-d&quot;&gt;math&lt;/a&gt; (thanks to Yuval Filmus for the link), I think that it should have been closed as off topic.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="567" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" LastActivityDate="2011-03-28T05:58:09.753" Title="Moderators: Please be very careful when migrating questions to other Stack Exchange websites" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;migration&gt;" AnswerCount="1" CommentCount="6" />
./Posts.xml:1035:  <row Id="1088" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="1082" CreationDate="2011-03-29T22:17:58.003" Score="5" Body="&lt;p&gt;I personally think it is reasonable to include &lt;a href=&quot;https://math.stackexchange.com/&quot;&gt;Math.SE&lt;/a&gt; in the list. We direct users to Math.SE more often than we direct them to SO, therefore it seems as a more natural option (assuming that people on Math.SE don't have objections and we should check that).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I also think it will decrease the amount of moderator intervention in these cases and will help us keep the site research level.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="186" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:19:18.947" LastActivityDate="2011-03-29T22:17:58.003" CommentCount="3" />

./Posts.xml:1038:  <row Id="1093" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAnswerId="1098" CreationDate="2011-04-03T11:30:22.967" Score="22" ViewCount="646" Body="&lt;p&gt;While a person can become a pro in one topic, it is not possible to master all the fields; even if we narrow it to computer science. Interdisciplinary fields make the problem worse. For instance, someone who works in (theoretical, not applied) cryptography must have a good knowledge of the computational complexity.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;What happens when you need to ask a question which, while related to your research topic, happens to be lie within another field? Well, a complicated problem for you might be too basic for researches in the target field.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I like the model of Math.SE / MathOverflow a lot: If I think my question is too basic (which usually is!), I'll ask it on Math.SE. Research-level questions can be asked on the latter.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;This discussion has recently gained momentum on Area51; here are some links:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://area51.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/612/two-level-model-mo-math-se-vs-one-level-model-so&quot;&gt;Two level model (MO/Math.SE) vs one level model (SO)&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://area51.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/630/what-problems-does-the-two-level-split-solve&quot;&gt;What problems does the two-level split solve&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;And even proposals like &lt;strong&gt;Beginner Theoretical Computer Science&lt;/strong&gt; or &lt;strong&gt;Computer Science&lt;/strong&gt; were  considered; but they were soon deleted/closed due to lack of support / misunderstanding that they are exact duplicates of other SE sites.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Lack of Support:&lt;/strong&gt; I believe that such proposals did not advertise themselves well. For instance, if I ever knew that they exist, I'd join them at once. This is the main reason I'm raising the issue here.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Exact Duplicates:&lt;/strong&gt; Some of the voters (to close) claimed that such proposals are exact duplicates of StackOverflow, while others claim that they are exact duplicates of TCS.SE. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;The former group believed that anything in computer science which is not theoretical is programming related. In my opinion, that is plain wrong. A basic question about Turing machines is a simple counterexample.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;The latter group were unable to distinguish between research-level questions and basic ones.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Some discussions can be found here: &lt;a href=&quot;https://area51.meta.stackexchange.com/q/682/22946&quot;&gt;Is Computer Science a duplicate of Theoretical Computer Science&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In an extreme case, Jonik suggested: &quot;Instead of another site, how about modifying the description of the existing site to allow a little less advanced CS theory questions too.&quot; His suggestion was unwelcome, and received some down-votes. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In another thread, &#xA;Joel Spolsky &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/q/947/873&quot;&gt;requested&lt;/a&gt; that we (TCS.SE) broaden our view. His suggestion didn't go anywhere either.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;The bottom line:&lt;/strong&gt; I believe that CSTheory must have a non-research-level counterpart. I ask people here to help (re)create one on Area51, and support it adequately.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;PS: There's always an issue of homeworks: Professors don't like their students to &lt;em&gt;cheat&lt;/em&gt; by asking homework problems in online forums. This can be handled as in Math.SE, or by developing adequate policies at the new site.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="873" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-05-03T08:40:57.363" LastActivityDate="2013-11-20T01:04:23.440" Title="Where to Ask Too Basic Questions?" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;" AnswerCount="4" CommentCount="6" FavoriteCount="7" />
./Posts.xml:1040:  <row Id="1095" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="1093" CreationDate="2011-04-03T14:02:36.363" Score="10" Body="&lt;p&gt;For a long time, there was no good answer — it seemed that there was no solution within Stack Exchange. But now the situation is finally resolved.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h2&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cs.stackexchange.com/&quot;&gt;On the computer science site!&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/h2&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Computer Science accepts all questions about theoretical and applied computer science. (All questions suitable for Stack Exchange, that is.)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Computer Science does not include the technique of programming, even when done as part of a class in a computer science curriculum. There's &lt;a href=&quot;https://stackoverflow.com/&quot;&gt;Stack Overflow&lt;/a&gt; for that.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="634" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-05-23T11:33:34.517" LastActivityDate="2013-11-20T01:04:23.440" CommentCount="7" />

./Posts.xml:1044:  <row Id="1099" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAnswerId="1481" CreationDate="2011-04-07T10:41:57.687" Score="9" ViewCount="234" Body="&lt;p&gt;This question &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/5927/how-fundamental-is-undecidability-closed&quot;&gt;How fundamental is undecidability?&lt;/a&gt; was closed within 25 minutes of being asked.  The OP was rude to a moderator in the comments, and it isn't a great question, so I do think closing it was a fair call.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;However, for me this has highlighted that we seem to be closing questions rather quickly, and certainly before the OP has a chance to change the question in light of comments, for instance to add pointers to literature, or to explain their motivation.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;This may be a reasonable rule, but I don't see it in the FAQ.  Some poor questions in the earlier days of the site went on to be revised (by the OP and by others) to become interesting and useful, generating significant numbers of page views and votes.  There were even instances where for initially uninteresting questions some great answers were provided (e.g. &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/4372/highest-lower-bound-on-np-problems-tsp/4373#4373&quot;&gt;Highest lower bound on NP problems (TSP)&lt;/a&gt;, &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2349/true-bit-complexity-of-matrix-multiplication-is-on4/2350#2350&quot;&gt;True Bit Complexity of matrix multiplication is $O(n^{4})$&lt;/a&gt;, and &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2274/permanents-approximation-and-connection-to-integer-factorization/2276#2276&quot;&gt;Permanents - Approximation and connection to integer factorization&lt;/a&gt; come to mind).  I don't have easy access to the vote histories for pages, but I seem to recall that some fairly anodyne questions even ended up being heavily upvoted after a stellar answer was provided, sort of basking in the reflected glow.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Previous discussions mentioned wanting to keep a clean front page &lt;em&gt;during the beta&lt;/em&gt;, see &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/299/on-closing-and-the-awesome-power-of-moderation&quot;&gt;On closing, and the awesome power of moderation&lt;/a&gt;, &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/378/how-much-time-before-closing-a-question&quot;&gt;How Much Time before Closing a Question?&lt;/a&gt;, and &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/695/why-the-extreme-strictness-on-topic-closing/699#699&quot;&gt;Why the extreme strictness on topic closing?&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I would even hesitate asking a question like &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/2136/rigour-leading-to-insight&quot;&gt;Rigour leading to insight&lt;/a&gt; today.  This question started out quite vague but through feedback turned into a reasonable question, and more importantly led to insightful responses by several people.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Is there an unwritten rule that no-one (not even Ryan) shall ever receive the &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/badges/50/reversal&quot;&gt;reversal&lt;/a&gt; badge?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="109" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" LastActivityDate="2012-02-02T23:26:43.110" Title="Closing questions too quickly, revisited?" ./Posts.xml:1049:  <row Id="1104" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="1103" CreationDate="2011-04-15T05:02:01.290" Score="12" Body="&lt;p&gt;As Kaveh points out, the most bang for the buck is at the FCRC, which combines a large number of ACM conferences, and can also serve as advertisement for creating SE sites in other research domains. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;There are many people here who are probably already going to FCRC and might have papers at STOC/CCC/EC (I'm not one of them unfortunately - I'm going to a different conference at the same time). &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;However, all these conferences are well past their deadlines for paper submission and the program is probably mostly set. ./Posts.xml:1053:  <row Id="1108" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="1105" CreationDate="2011-04-15T20:30:16.237" Score="4" Body="&lt;p&gt;Here is what happened in this case:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The questions is clearly off-topic for the site and was closed by Dave. But two answers were posted before the closing.&#xA;The first one was a one line answer by a new unregistered anonymous user (i.e. didn't have the reputation to comment):&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;To be NP-complete, it must be in NP.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;So I converted it to a comment. But the second answer was similar in essence (by a regular relatively high rep user) and I felt it would be unfair to just convert one of them, so I converted the second one. Then I felt that it would better if I just delete them since they were not adding any information not on the Wikipedia page. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I personally didn't feel good about it after deleting  because we don't have a clear policy on this (and the second answerer knew that the questions is clearly off-topic and that we don't answer them on cstheory), my justification for deletion was previous meta discussions we had where IIRC the conclusion was that we should not answer these questions even in the comments and should just forward the OP to the place where he/she could find the answer (Wikipedia, textbook, ...).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I also felt that deleting them would be in line with closing clearly off-topic questions by moderators (i.e. inside minimal mod intervention). I would have suggested adopting a policy like: &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;answers &lt;em&gt;not containing new information&lt;/em&gt; (in addition to what is on Wikipedia, ...) to &lt;em&gt;clearly&lt;/em&gt; off-topic questions should be deleted, preferably by OP.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;But I think we probably &lt;strong&gt;don't&lt;/strong&gt; need to do this for the following reason:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;hr&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The &lt;a href=&quot;https://math.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/1966/migration-from-cstheory-to-math-se&quot;&gt;feedback&lt;/a&gt; from Math.SE guys on adding Math.SE to the off-topic flagging wizard has been quite positive, so I think it we can simply migrate these questions &lt;em&gt;with their answers&lt;/em&gt; to Math.SE and there is no need to delete the answers by us if the question is migrated to Math.SE.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;ps: I also made a small edit to the general FAQ (Math.SE entry) based on the feedback from Math.SE folks.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="186" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T16:37:16.437" LastActivityDate="2011-04-16T03:27:58.520" CommentCount="3" />
./Posts.xml:1055:  <row Id="1110" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2011-04-17T23:46:15.940" Score="8" ViewCount="437" Body="&lt;p&gt;The consensus seems to be that &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/214/should-there-be-a-protocol-to-notify-authors-if-we-find-an-error-in-a-paper&quot;&gt;if people find errors in papers, they should contact the author directly, not post a question here&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Unfortunately, it seems that we haven't enforced this policy &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1064/polynomial-time-algorithm-for-graph-isomorphism-testing&quot;&gt;in this thread&lt;/a&gt;. ./Posts.xml:1070:  <row Id="1127" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2011-04-28T15:25:07.353" Score="4" ViewCount="248" Body="&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;Update (May 6, 2011): This policy received 8 upvotes and 4 down votes and is now in effect.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;  &#xA;  &lt;p&gt;This is a policy question. The proposed policy in the question (or answers) will be adopted in the case that after 7 days it receives at least 5 up votes with a 2/3 majority in favor. Please upvote or downvote this question based on your opinion of the policy statement as presented (not based on whether the premise of the question is reasonable). &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Some clearly off-topic questions are getting answer before we can close them. When I comment and request the users to remove the answers some of them do not remove their answers and don't reply to my comments (e.g. see &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/6164/binary-how-does-it-work/6165#6165&quot;&gt;this one&lt;/a&gt;). (Also SE has not replied to my email yet regarding adding migration to Math.SE to list of off-topic migration). So I propose the following policy (at least until we find a better solutions):&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Policy Proposal&lt;/strong&gt; (April 28, 2011): Questions which are clearly off-topic should not be answered. When such a question is answered before being closed, the answers will be removed (we will post a comment linking to this policy to the question to explain the removal of the answers).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="186" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" LastActivityDate="2011-05-07T03:57:49.083" Title="Deleting answers to clearly off-topic questions after they get closed" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;status-completed&gt;&lt;policy&gt;" AnswerCount="0" CommentCount="25" FavoriteCount="1" />
./Posts.xml:1077:  <row Id="1135" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2011-05-05T19:24:26.493" Score="3" ViewCount="84" Body="&lt;p&gt;A question was asked &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/6412/optimal-payoff-from-sampling-from-a-collection-of-bernoulli-random-variables&quot;&gt;regarding the payoff from sampling among Bernoulli variables&lt;/a&gt;, and was tagged with &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/machine-learning&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;machine-learning&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;machine-learning&lt;/a&gt; and &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/optimization&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;optimization&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;optimization&lt;/a&gt;. Lev provided a &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/6412/optimal-payoff-from-sampling-from-a-collection-of-bernoulli-random-variables/6414#6414&quot;&gt;nice and clean answer&lt;/a&gt; explaining that this is a special case of a bandit problem.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Bandit problems are quite common in ML, and there are &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/search?q=bandit&quot;&gt;six questions&lt;/a&gt; on the site about them. But there's no tag, and in all cases, the term appears in the question. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;My question:&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;Should we tag the question as &lt;code&gt;bandit&lt;/code&gt;&#xA;  because of the answer, or leave it as&#xA;  is because the question was not&#xA;  directly related to bandits (relying&#xA;  on search to help someone find the&#xA;  relevant information)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="80" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" LastActivityDate="2011-05-05T22:24:44.303" Title="Tagging based on question or answer" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;tags&gt;" AnswerCount="1" CommentCount="0" />
./Posts.xml:1079:  <row Id="1137" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAnswerId="1140" CreationDate="2011-05-06T20:31:29.227" Score="3" ViewCount="158" Body="&lt;p&gt;Should simple but important questions about terminology belong to CSTheory.stackexchange.com?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Questions like this one:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/6420/are-languages-for-grammars-programming-languages&quot;&gt;Are grammars programs?&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If not, to which site it may be moved?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;hr&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;There are no definitions in Wikipedia's article on programming language.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&quot;A programming language is an artificial language&quot; (1) &quot;designed to express computations that can be performed by a machine, particularly a computer.&quot; (2) &quot;Programming languages can be used to create programs that control the behavior of a machine, to express algorithms precisely, or as a mode of human communication.&quot; (3)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Intended design purposes cannot be part of definition. So we must omit (2). Usage patterns also cannot be part of definition. So we omit (3). The rest is (1) which is very badly stated and clearly incomplete.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&quot;A programming language is a notation for writing programs, which are specifications of a computation or algorithm.&quot;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;No definition of program in Wikipedia and one can not define notion referring to other undefined notion.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;hr&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&quot;A computer program (also a software program, or just a program)&quot; (0) &quot;is a sequence&quot; (1) &quot;of instructions&quot;(2) &quot;written to perform a specified task for a computer.&quot; (3)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;(1) Programs are clearly not always sequences. For example constraints or expressions are clearly not constitute sequences, but sets and trees correspondingly. (2) Programs are not have to be instructions. Are lambda expressions instructions? (3) intended purpose is not part of definition. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;So we have no definition of programming language nor a program in Wikipedia.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="491" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" LastActivityDate="2011-05-07T08:05:05.580" Title="Where simple but important questions about terminology may be asked?" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;" AnswerCount="3" CommentCount="2" />

./Posts.xml:1090:  <row Id="1148" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="1146" CreationDate="2011-05-24T06:49:15.113" Score="6" Body="&lt;p&gt;There seems to be more than one question with both the &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/type-theory&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;type-theory&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;type-theory&lt;/a&gt; and &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/programming-lang&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;programming-lang&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;programming-lang&lt;/a&gt; tags.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In any case, type theory is a branch of logic that has seen many applications in programming languages, namely, as type systems. Type theory questions that are not programming language questions often take the form of questions about automated reasoning or proof assistants and their underlying theory. Even though there is a programming language for specifying the input to such proof assistants, PL and type theory people wouldn't consider these to be PL questions.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Also, the fact that a question mentions types, does not necessarily mean it is about type theory, especially if it is a programming languages question. Types are a part of programming languages, but this doesn't mean that every programming languages question about types is a type theory question. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I'll scan through the questions we have thus far and see whether I can draw any additional conclusions.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="77" LastEditorUserId="77" LastEditDate="2011-05-26T06:41:52.913" LastActivityDate="2011-05-26T06:41:52.913" CommentCount="3" />

./Posts.xml:1099:  <row Id="1157" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2011-06-01T04:12:22.443" Score="4" ViewCount="221" Body="&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Possible Duplicate:&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br&gt;&#xA;  &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/1448/community-promotion-ads-1h-2012&quot;&gt;Community Promotion Ads - 1H 2012&lt;/a&gt;  &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;What in the Wide, Wide World of Sports is Going On Here?&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;TL;DR -- put images and links in the answers. If they get voted up enough, they will appear on the main site as community promotion ads.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;But whyyyyyyy?&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;This is a method for the community to control what gets promoted to visitors on the site. For example, you might promote the following things:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;cool site-related open source apps&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;the site's twitter account&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;scripts packs or power tools&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;cool events or conferences&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;anything else your community would genuinely be interested in&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The goal is for future visitors to find out about &lt;em&gt;the stuff your community deems important&lt;/em&gt;. And to click on it for great justice!&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;How does it work?&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The answers you post to this question &lt;em&gt;must&lt;/em&gt; conform to the following rules, or they will be ignored. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;All answers should be in the exact form of:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;pre&gt;&lt;code&gt;[![Tagline to show on mouseover][1]][2]&#xA;&#xA;   [1]: http://image-url&#xA;   [2]: http://clickthrough-url &#xA;&lt;/code&gt;&lt;/pre&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Please &lt;strong&gt;do not add anything else to the body of the post&lt;/strong&gt;. If you want to discuss something, do it in the comments.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;The question must always be tagged with the magic &lt;a href=&quot;/questions/tagged/community-ads&quot; class=&quot;post-tag moderator-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;community-ads&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;community-ads&lt;/a&gt; tag.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;Image requirements&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;The image that you create must be &lt;strong&gt;220 x 250 pixels&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Must be hosted through our standard image uploader (imgur)&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Must be GIF or PNG&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;No animated GIFs&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Absolute limit on file size of 150 KB&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;Score Threshold&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;There is a &lt;strong&gt;minimum score threshold&lt;/strong&gt; an answer must meet (currently 6) before it will be shown on the main site.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;You can check out the ads that have met the threshold with basic click stats &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/ads/display/1157&quot;&gt;here&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="1438" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" LastActivityDate="2011-09-28T22:57:10.267" Title="Community Promotion Ads - 2H 2011" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;site-promotion&gt;&lt;community-ads&gt;" AnswerCount="4" CommentCount="2" FavoriteCount="2" ClosedDate="2011-12-01T22:59:47.597" CommunityOwnedDate="2011-06-01T04:12:44.440" />

./Posts.xml:1131:  <row Id="1193" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="1192" CreationDate="2011-07-14T00:54:40.907" Score="5" Body="&lt;p&gt;Yes, &lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/90324/should-downvotes-on-questions-be-free/90927#90927&quot;&gt;they have changed the system&lt;/a&gt;. Down-voting questions does not effect the reputation of the down voter any more.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;You can also rigger a reputation recalculation &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/reputation&quot;&gt;here&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="186" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.537" LastActivityDate="2011-07-14T08:57:57.140" CommentCount="2" />
./Posts.xml:1134:  <row Id="1196" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2011-07-14T15:50:01.803" Score="12" ViewCount="576" Body="&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;July 21st: The first technical post is now up, &lt;a href=&quot;http://cstheory.blogoverflow.com/2011/07/quantum-query-complexity/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;Quantum query complexity&lt;/a&gt;, by Artem Kaznatcheev.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;  &#xA;  &lt;p&gt;July 16th: The first blog post is now up, &lt;a href=&quot;http://cstheory.blogoverflow.com/2011/07/welcome-to-the-theoretical-computer-science-community-blog/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;here&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;This is not so much a question as an announcement and a request for participation. We now have a cstheory blog at cstheory.blogoverflow.com ! &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;We'll have to feel out the best way to use it to augment the discussions on the site. To start with, we are happy to announce two editors-in-chief of the blog. &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/users/204/joe-fitzsimons&quot;&gt;Joe Fitzsimons&lt;/a&gt; and &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/users/30/aaron-sterling&quot;&gt;Aaron Sterling&lt;/a&gt; have agreed to manage content on the blog, and among their roles will be soliciting posts from YOU to place there.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Which brings me to the second point. As currently envisaged (Joe and Aaron will have more to say on this I'm sure), anyone who's interested can contribute to the blog, and this is how it would work:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;you write a draft on the site&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;An editor reviews it&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;It gets posted. &lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Presumably as time goes on, some contributors might get direct posting rights - we can see how that goes. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;So what should you do now ? Sign up if you're interested in contributing. To do so, post your name and/or a link to your profile, which hopefully has an email address, in an answer below, and one of the admins (Kaveh or myself) will create an account for you. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Once that's done, you can start writing drafts. And I'm sure the editors will nudge people as well. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If you have questions about the format, content styles etc, please create a new meta question and link it here. Let's keep this post primarily for signups. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="80" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" LastActivityDate="2011-08-19T18:05:28.840" Title="CSTheory Blog Announcement and Signup Sheet" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;site-promotion&gt;&lt;blog&gt;" AnswerCount="6" CommentCount="20" FavoriteCount="1" />
./Posts.xml:1139:  <row Id="1201" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2011-07-16T06:04:04.963" Score="2" ViewCount="95" Body="&lt;p&gt;I just noticed some nice user options on MO and I think it would be nice to have them on cstheory also:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Hide questions with ignored tags, (Update: already supported, check the checkbox on perfs page of your profile)&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Show symbols !, ⋅, ∘, ⊡, ⊟, ⊞ for reputations above 0, 15, 100, 2000, 3000, 10000, respectively, (Update: see below)&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Do not show user reputations, (Update: see below)&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Hide vote counts, (Update: see below)&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Apply ignored-tag styles to closed questions.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I particularly like the idea of using symbols in place of numbers for user reputation.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;A similar idea is to use colors in place of numbers for total vote counts and only show exact vote counts if the user clicks on the color. This can reduce the idea that users are sorting the answers but rather are voting based on the sole quality of them and increase voting on answers/questions.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;Update:&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I modified &lt;a href=&quot;https://stackapps.com/questions/2342/hexadecimal-user-rep&quot;&gt;this user script&lt;/a&gt; to get 2, 3, and 4. You can find the scripts on the same page.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="186" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:25:39.260" LastActivityDate="2011-07-18T15:05:31.300" Title="Nice features from MO" Tags="&lt;feature-request&gt;" AnswerCount="3" CommentCount="2" />
./Posts.xml:1143:  <row Id="1205" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2011-07-16T13:18:47.093" Score="4" ViewCount="105" Body="&lt;p&gt;We have already &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/q/1155/1037&quot;&gt;discussed&lt;/a&gt; the general scope of the blog, and there seems to be some ideas as to what it is. Now that we are starting to write posts, I thought it would be nice to figure out the more technical details. Of particular interest: what  &lt;b&gt;length&lt;/b&gt; and &lt;b&gt;level of formality&lt;/b&gt; should we aim for?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Right now I am writing in a style that is pretty close to how I would write an academic paper. For specific claims I reference the literature with proper citations, and for more general further-interest topics I link to Wikipedia or relevant cstheory questions. Is this too formal? Should we cite specific claims in-text or just have a short bibliography section at the end of the post (or neither?). &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;This question is for posts in the 'Expository material on particular sub-areas' genre.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="1037" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" LastActivityDate="2011-07-16T15:20:20.327" Title="Length and level of formality for community blog" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;blog&gt;" AnswerCount="1" CommentCount="0" FavoriteCount="1" />
./Posts.xml:1150:  <row Id="1212" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="784" CreationDate="2011-07-17T19:09:32.050" Score="6" Body="&lt;p&gt;Emanuele Viola &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/5004/are-runtime-bounds-in-p-decidable-answer-no/5006#5006&quot;&gt;proved that runtime bounds in P are undecidable&lt;/a&gt; while answering John Sidles' question. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;(Eventually an earlier proof was found in Juris Hartmanis' monograph &quot;Feasible computations and provable complexity properties&quot; (1978), but it seems users were unaware of the monograph when the question was answered)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="1037" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" LastActivityDate="2011-07-17T19:09:32.050" CommentCount="0" />
./Posts.xml:1157:  <row Id="1222" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2011-07-29T15:38:00.197" Score="1" ViewCount="130" Body="&lt;p&gt;In Scott Aaronson's answer to my &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/7528/extended-church-turing-thesis&quot;&gt;question&lt;/a&gt; about the Extended Church-Turing Thesis, he says&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;I don't see how talking about &quot;proofs&quot; of the CT or ECT adds much light to this discussion. Such &quot;proofs&quot; tend to be exactly as good as the assumptions they rest on---in other words, as what they take words like &quot;computation&quot; or &quot;efficient computation&quot; to mean. So then why not proceed right away to a discussion of the assumptions, and dispense with the word &quot;proof&quot;?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I would like to start a &quot;discussion of the assumptions,&quot; or a question like, &quot;What are the right axioms for the notion of computation and algorithm.&quot;  I would probably seed it with the list of axioms Dershowitz and co-authors use to prove Church-Turing Thesis, or Extended Church-Turing Thesis.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;So my meta-question is this: where would the best venue be for this?  It seems as though it would be a natural candidate for a blog entry, but perhaps it would be better as a community wiki on the main site, so people could vote up and down axioms/intuitions that resonated, or didn't.  Any preferences/suggestions?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;EDIT: thanks everyone for your input. I will ask a question, but probably next week. I don't have time to shepherd a question for the next several days.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="30" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" LastActivityDate="2011-08-02T01:44:10.980" Title="Where is the best place to start a discussion on the right axioms for computation?" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;scope&gt;" AnswerCount="4" CommentCount="1" />
./Posts.xml:1160:  <row Id="1225" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="1222" CreationDate="2011-07-30T07:09:54.760" Score="1" Body="&lt;p&gt;I think you can ask a serious question on this without even going all the way to community wiki. I did a similar thing here:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/q/4816/1037&quot;&gt;Axioms necessary for theoretical computer science&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I ended up asking a very specific question (has reverse mathematics been applied to cstheory) and getting very good specific answers that taught me a lot.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;For the computation axioms it might be better to ask specific questions like: what basic (or philosophical) axioms have been proposed for computation? How do these axioms relate to &quot;specific axioms from paper&quot;? What insights have they given us? What are the limitations of &quot;specific axioms from paper&quot;? How could you modify &quot;specific axioms from paper&quot; to allow quantum computing? Stuff like that.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I think simply asking for community members to contribute individual axioms will result in something pretty chaotic. Partially because you usually want to contribute a set of axioms not a single one, anyways. Also because it is not clear what a ranked list of axioms will mean... but I think this was discussed in the comment thread under Kaveh's answer already.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I definitely support making a blog post about axioms and computation.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="1037" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" LastActivityDate="2011-07-30T07:09:54.760" CommentCount="0" />
