I think that it should.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I expected that the link labeled “blog” at the bottom of the page takes the viewer to the community blog, but it links to &lt;a href=&quot;http://blog.stackexchange.com/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;http://blog.stackexchange.com/&lt;/a&gt; instead.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="567" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" LastActivityDate="2011-08-06T17:19:27.267" Title="Add a link to the community blog" Tags="&lt;feature-request&gt;&lt;status-completed&gt;&lt;blog&gt;&lt;hyperlinks&gt;" AnswerCount="2" CommentCount="5" />
./Posts.xml:1163:  <row Id="1228" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="823" CreationDate="2011-08-02T03:22:09.783" Score="1" Body="&lt;h3&gt;change log&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;hr&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Jul. 27, 2012:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Added [academia.se] to the list of suggested sites&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;hr&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Mar. 20, 2012:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Added [cs.se] to the list of suggested sites&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;hr&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Feb. 23, 2012:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Another small update to the FAQ. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Change log:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Added [crypto.se] and [scicomp.se] to the list of suggested sites,&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Made the tips for writing a better question a section.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;hr&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Nov. 17, 2011:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I have edited the official FAQ a little bit (mainly adding links to some entries of the official FAQ that we refer to in comments). Please comemnt if you don't like the edits or have other suggestions on how to improve the general FAQ:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;hr&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h2&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/faq&quot;&gt;FAQ&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/h2&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Theoretical Computer Science - Stack Exchange&lt;/strong&gt; is for theoretical computer scientists and researchers in related fields.  We welcome &lt;em&gt;research-level&lt;/em&gt; questions in &lt;em&gt;theoretical computer science&lt;/em&gt; (TCS).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Although there is no black-and-white distinction between research-level questions and non-research-level questions, questions are considered to be &quot;research-level&quot; roughly when they can be discussed between two professors or between two graduate students working on Ph.D.'s, but not usually between a professor and a typical undergraduate student. It does not include questions at the level of difficulty of typical undergraduate course/textbook homework/exercise.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;For an explanation of what TCS is, we refer you to the description of ACM Special Interest Group on Algorithms and Computation Theory (SIGACT):&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;TCS covers a wide variety of topics including algorithms, data structures, computational complexity, parallel and distributed computation, probabilistic computation, quantum computation, automata theory, information theory, cryptography, program semantics and verification, machine learning, computational biology, computational economics, computational geometry, and computational number theory and algebra.  &lt;strong&gt;Work in this field is often distinguished by its emphasis on mathematical technique and rigor.&lt;/strong&gt; &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h2&gt;My question is not a research-level question in TCS, where can I ask it?&lt;/h2&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;For questions other than research-level questions in TCS, you may want to consider the following places to ask:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;General Computer Science — &lt;a href=&quot;https://cs.stackexchange.com/&quot;&gt;Computer Science - Stack Exchange&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;General Mathematics (including &lt;em&gt;theoretical&lt;/em&gt; CS) — &lt;a href=&quot;https://math.stackexchange.com/&quot;&gt;Mathematics - Stack Exchange&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Research-level Mathematics — &lt;a href=&quot;https://mathoverflow.net/&quot;&gt;Math Overflow&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Social and Professional Academic Issues — &lt;a href=&quot;https://academia.stackexchange.com/&quot;&gt;Academia - Stack Exchange&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Programming — &lt;a href=&quot;https://stackoverflow.com/&quot;&gt;Stack Overflow&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;General Artificial Intelligence — &lt;a href=&quot;http://metaoptimize.com/qa/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;Meta Optimize&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Statistics and Data Mining — &lt;a href=&quot;https://stats.stackexchange.com/&quot;&gt;Cross Validated&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Applied Cryptography and Security — &lt;a href=&quot;https://crypto.stackexchange.com/&quot;&gt;Crypto - Stack Exchange&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Computation used in Science and Engineering — &lt;a href=&quot;https://scicomp.stackexchange.com/&quot;&gt;Computational Science - Stack Exchange&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Questions about this site — &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/&quot;&gt;Theoretical Computer Science - Stack Exchange - Meta&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Other — check the list of sites on &lt;a href=&quot;http://stackexchange.com/sites&quot;&gt;Stack Exchange Network&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h2&gt;Questions should be based on knowledge sharing, not on shirking&lt;/h2&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;You should only post questions you're actually seriously thinking about. Users are expected to do their part and try to answer their question by themselves before posting them on cstheory and asking for help from others. Search to see if your question is already answered somewhere else (e.g. Wikipedia) before asking a question. &lt;strong&gt;Try to make your question interesting for others by providing some background knowledge&lt;/strong&gt;. Remember, &lt;em&gt;questions should be based on knowledge sharing, not on shirking. Shirking goes against the spirit of the site.&lt;/em&gt; &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h2&gt;Tips about writing better questions&lt;/h2&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/how-to-ask&quot;&gt;How to Ask?&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/300/how-to-ask-a-good-question&quot;&gt;How to ask a good question?&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://mathoverflow.net/howtoask&quot;&gt;How to write a good MathOverflow question?&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Please also check our list of &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/229#229&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;useful resources&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/a&gt; &lt;em&gt;before&lt;/em&gt; asking a question.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h2&gt;FAQ&lt;/h2&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Currently we have two separate lists of FAQs.  See also the longer &lt;strong&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science&quot;&gt;Official Theoretical Computer Science FAQ&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;.  Some of the most important entries in the other FAQ are:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/237#237&quot;&gt;How do I write &lt;strong&gt;formulas&lt;/strong&gt;?&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/235#235&quot;&gt;What kind of questions are &lt;strong&gt;too basic&lt;/strong&gt;?&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/361#361&quot;&gt;My (wonderful!) &lt;strong&gt;question got closed&lt;/strong&gt;!  What do I do now?&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/231#231&quot;&gt;What is the &lt;strong&gt;policy on crossposting&lt;/strong&gt; to/from MathOverflow?&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/274/is-it-ok-to-ask-about-the-correctness-of-preprints-on-crank-friendly-topics/281#281&quot;&gt;Can I ask about this &lt;strong&gt;cool paper&lt;/strong&gt; that I just saw &lt;strong&gt;on the arxiv&lt;/strong&gt;?&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="186" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-05-23T11:33:34.517" LastActivityDate="2012-07-27T04:04:48.453" CommentCount="2" />
./Posts.xml:1167:  <row Id="1234" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="1231" CreationDate="2011-08-02T15:23:09.527" Score="4" Body="&lt;p&gt;Jeff's answer may not be the answer you are looking for but it doesn't mean that it is not an answer, I personally think it is a good answer to the question. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;You are free to choose to accept whichever answer you like most, and you can vote on answers as you please. Other users are also free to post answers and vote as they please. Looking at the votes, it seems that other users think that Jeff's answer is a good one. You cannot restrict the answers to those answers you like.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If you don't like the answers you have got so far then check this FAQ entry: &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/faq#bounty&quot;&gt;What if I don’t get a good answer?&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="186" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" LastActivityDate="2011-08-02T15:29:04.237" CommentCount="0" />

./Posts.xml:1176:  <row Id="1243" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2011-08-04T19:55:38.817" Score="5" ViewCount="110" Body="&lt;p&gt;I started typing up a question on transitioning from quantum to classical random walks on the line, with the punchline being along the lines of:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;Are there models of decoherence for the quantum walk such that we can tune the walk to spread as $\Theta(t^k)$ for any $1/2 \leq k \leq 1$?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The question is tangentially related to cstheory because classical random walks are useful in algorithm design, and quantum random walks have proven useful for making a number of cool algorithms. Thus, it is important to understand the difference between quantum and classical random walks. Sometimes, the easiest way to do this is to consider toy models, such as walks on the line.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Further, I think there are enough quantum folks at cstheory that I might get a very good answer.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;On the other hand, the question is clearly physics-y and would be of little interest to non-quantum cstheory members. The question would be more at home at &lt;a href=&quot;http://area51.stackexchange.com/proposals/23848/theoretical-physics?referrer=3Cmub2jRLCYDvVVb-6SmDQ2&quot;&gt;Theoretical Physics.SE&lt;/a&gt; but unfortunately the site has not made it to beta, yet. I could try &lt;a href=&quot;https://physics.stackexchange.com/&quot;&gt;physics.SE&lt;/a&gt; but a look the question list suggests that that site lost its research focus, and this is a research level question. Also, I check cstheory all the time and enjoy the community, so I prefer to ask questions here.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Should I try asking this question and removing it if the community doesn't approve? Or is this question so clearly off-topic that by asking it I would be setting a bad example?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;EDIT:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;After 3 proceed comments, I posted the question:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/7629/transitioning-from-quantum-to-classical-random-walks-on-the-line&quot;&gt;Transitioning from quantum to classical random walks on the line&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If you think there is a way I can improve the question or make it clearer/better motivated please suggest it here or in the comments of the question.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="1037" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:39:35.573" LastActivityDate="2011-08-05T05:40:59.570" Title="Is a question about decoherence in quantum walks on the line in scope?" ./Posts.xml:1184:  <row Id="1251" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAnswerId="1252" CreationDate="2011-08-10T23:47:45.843" Score="3" ViewCount="134" Body="&lt;p&gt;From time to time we get questions that are of the form:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;How can I do X? &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;or&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;Is X studied?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;(often by a user not familiar with TCS) where X is a very high-level real-world task, so it is not clear what the theoretical question is being asked, what is the exact theoretical model, and how one can answer the post. &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/7694/distributed-peer-to-peer-collaboration-to-create-a-database-possible&quot;&gt;Here&lt;/a&gt; is a recent example asking for how to &quot;distributively maintain a database of all baseball games&quot; which will also deal with &quot;spam&quot; and &quot;fake&quot; data from its users. For analogy, it is like asking &quot;How can I built a rocket that can take a human to Mars? Has this been studied?&quot;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;How should we deal with them?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I am partly asking this meta question so we can refer to it when we get such questions.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="186" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" LastActivityDate="2011-08-23T04:14:17.023" Title="How to deal with &quot;How to do X?&quot; questions where X is a very high-level (software engineering) task" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;scope&gt;" AnswerCount="2" CommentCount="0" FavoriteCount="1" />
./Posts.xml:1186:  <row Id="1253" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="1251" CreationDate="2011-08-12T14:29:36.547" Score="3" Body="&lt;p&gt;“How can I do X?” and “Is X studied?” are very different.  The latter (as it is) is silly as Suresh writes.  However, the former can be interesting.  I think that it is incorrect to close a question just because it is application-oriented.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I think that the discussion about &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/514/how-to-model-this-questions&quot;&gt;How-to-model-this questions&lt;/a&gt; applies.  In particular, as &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/514/how-to-model-this-questions/519#519&quot;&gt;Scott Aaronson writes&lt;/a&gt;, there are better and worse ways to ask a “How can I do X?” question:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;Having said that, there are better and worse ways to pose a modeling question. I think the best ways would make it clear (a) why TCS (as opposed to a different field, like systems or AI) might be well-equipped to answer the question, and (b) what a helpful answer would look like. (In other words: if the only answer to your question you could reasonably expect from a TCS expert is &quot;I dunno,&quot; why are you asking it here? :) )&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="567" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" LastActivityDate="2011-08-12T14:29:36.547" CommentCount="10" />
./Posts.xml:1187:  <row Id="1254" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="1231" CreationDate="2011-08-15T13:23:00.737" Score="4" Body="&lt;p&gt;If you ask a question and see no answers you like, one course of action is to &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/privileges/set-bounties&quot;&gt;put a bounty&lt;/a&gt; on the question.  You can even specify in the comments the type of answer you think would get awarded the bounty.  This would incentivize people to answer the questions your way, as you'd be the one to determine who gets the bounty.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;One note: you need at least 75 reputation to offer a bounty.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="123" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" LastActivityDate="2011-08-15T13:23:00.737" CommentCount="0" />

./Posts.xml:1196:  <row Id="1264" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAnswerId="1272" CreationDate="2011-08-17T03:13:01.370" Score="6" ViewCount="237" Body="&lt;p&gt;I have recently been reflecting on my voting patterns. The discussion on &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/7728/multiplication-of-normal-distributions/7729#7729&quot;&gt;this answer&lt;/a&gt; suggests that different people have different views on downvoting. I thought it would be good to figure out what the community thinks should be rule-of-thumb guidelines on downvoting.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I usually downvoted questions if they are poorly written and show little effort on the part of the asker (and if there was edits made to improve the question, I would cancel my downvote) or if I think they are out-of-scope for cstheory.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;For answers I usually downvote if they don't answer the question or if they are incorrect. However, I sometimes downvote answers to a homework question, especially if its a homework-level answers.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;For answers on community-wiki questions I vote much more aggressively, sometimes downvoting something if I don't agree with or the answer is not insightful (especially for big list questions).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I thought this voting strategy is reasonable, but looking at the stats suggests that I downvoted a lot more than everybody else. In particular I think I have the highest total downvotes (~99) and one of the highest downvote percentages (~10%). How should I adjust my downvoting?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Also, there is some general downvoting differences between our top 20 rep users, and the MO top 20 rep users. In particular, it seems MO is more willing to downvote:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;% down | MO | TCS&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;  &#xA;  &lt;p&gt;0.x% | 4  | 7&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;  &#xA;  &lt;p&gt;1.x% | 1 | 2&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;  &#xA;  &lt;p&gt;2.x% | 2 | 3&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;  &#xA;  &lt;p&gt;3.x% | 2 | 2&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;  &#xA;  &lt;p&gt;4.x% | 4 | 2&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;  &#xA;  &lt;p&gt;&gt; 5% | 7 | 4&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;That might mean a difference in convention or cstheory just has higher quality questions and answers.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;What are the conventions and norms for down-voting on cstheory?&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="1037" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" LastActivityDate="2011-08-18T04:25:01.343" Title="Conventions on downvoting" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;voting&gt;&lt;down-votes&gt;&lt;etiquette&gt;" AnswerCount="2" CommentCount="2" FavoriteCount="1" />
./Posts.xml:1198:  <row Id="1266" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2011-08-17T03:59:08.143" Score="3" ViewCount="78" Body="&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://math.stackexchange.com/questions/57957/designer-looking-for-help-with-an-algorithm-to-calculate-layout-of-rectangles-bas&quot;&gt;This question&lt;/a&gt; was posted on math.stackexchange.com and I've become curious.  I unfortunately posted an answer that I'm disappointed with.  I've got some questions myself, and I'm wondering about the potential for relaying research-level information from this site to another site.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In other words, I'd like to know if it's discouraged for me to ask a question here inspired by a question from another site (while that question hasn't been answered)?  I'd like to research the information using this site and the web and eventually post an answer that's not so research level on the other site, math.stackexchange.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I'm wondering what I should do here - I really feel I've made a mistake already.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="1549" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:19:18.947" LastActivityDate="2011-08-17T12:40:22.893" Title="Are research-related cross posts discouraged?" ./Posts.xml:1203:  <row Id="1271" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAnswerId="1277" CreationDate="2011-08-17T15:26:44.473" Score="3" ViewCount="97" Body="&lt;p&gt;If we write a blog post for the cstheory community blog, may we crosspost the same post to our own blog as well, with both posts pointing to each other?  &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I noticed this issue was discussed in the comments of &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/1155/community-blogging&quot;&gt;this post and its answers&lt;/a&gt;, but I don't think we came to an agreement.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;EDIT: Unless I hear otherwise, I will assume cross-posting is okay.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="123" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" LastActivityDate="2011-08-19T14:32:33.893" Title="Cross-posting Cstheory Blog Posts" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;policy&gt;&lt;blog&gt;" AnswerCount="1" CommentCount="9" />
./Posts.xml:1204:  <row Id="1272" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="1264" CreationDate="2011-08-18T00:28:27.383" Score="7" Body="&lt;p&gt;Here is my two cents:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Down voting a post (answer/question) without commenting is NOT OK, it is against the norm, this is discussed in the last town hall meeting and there seemed to be a consensus among the people attending the meeting. Without a comment the purpose of the down-vote is not clear, it is not a constructive down-vote, and a user answering the question can get confused because he or she might not understand what is wrong with the answer or what behavior is being criticized.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;I don't find down-voting answers just because of answering a question reasonable. If the user answering the question has not done anything unreasonable and the answer is OK it does not deserve a down-vote IMO. &lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;On the other hand, it might be reasonable to down vote an answer when its poster has done something unreasonable or against the norms, e.g. &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/q/601/1037&quot;&gt;answering a question which is clearly homework&lt;/a&gt; (not just off-topic), it can be reasonable in such situation because the user is violating an agreed norm about not answering homework questions (and note that even in these cases the down-vote should be explained in a comment).&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;If an answer is not: a. correct, b. well-written, c. an answer to the question; i.e. it is not a good answer to the question then it is reasonable (and even sometimes encouraged) to down-vote it, (but again, even in these cases the down-vote should be explained in a comment).&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="186" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.560" LastActivityDate="2011-08-18T00:36:39.757" CommentCount="2" />
./Posts.xml:1206:  <row Id="1274" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2011-08-18T06:08:46.357" Score="9" ViewCount="262" Body="&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/7809/all-pairs-shortest-path-in-undirected-and-unweighted-graphs&quot;&gt;The question&lt;/a&gt; (which was &quot;banished&quot; to Math.SE) asks if there is a better solution to APSP than running BFS from each node. That is equivalent to asking if there is an algorithm that runs in less than $O(mn + n^2)$ time. It is a major open problem to improve significantly on this running time: Chan got a $\log n$ speedup in SODA'06 (paper title: &quot;All-pairs shortest paths for unweighted undirected graphs in o(mn) time&quot;) but no further progress has been made. In the undirected and unweighted case, one can solve the problem in matrix multiplication time ($n^{2.376}$) with some ingenious algorithms from the mid-90's (one is due to Seidel).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;So this is a perfectly fine question for CSTheory. Why was it closed and migrated?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="225" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" LastActivityDate="2011-08-20T13:41:48.903" Title="Why was &quot;All pairs shortest path in undirected and unweighted graphs&quot; closed and migrated?" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;specific-question&gt;&lt;migration&gt;" AnswerCount="2" CommentCount="1" FavoriteCount="1" />
./Posts.xml:1207:  <row Id="1275" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="1274" CreationDate="2011-08-18T06:39:05.973" Score="2" Body="&lt;p&gt;I think you are referring to  &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/7809/all-pairs-shortest-path-in-undirected-and-unweighted-graphs&quot;&gt;this&lt;/a&gt; question.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;What you are saying about the problem is interesting, but I am not sure that was the what the OP was asking, i.e. although there is a research-level answer to the question as you have explained above, the way the question was phrased by the OP didn't seem to be asking for a research level question, it seemed that the user was not aware of standard material on finding all sources shortest path (and honestly it still seems so to me, e.g. &quot;I'm aware that the single source shortest path in a undirected and unweighted graph can be easily solved by BFS.&quot;, or the comment posted by OP as reply to MCH's comment), therefore it seemed to be about material covered in typical undergraduate algorithms courses, and thus off-topic for cstheory.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The question had a close vote and another upvoted comment that this is covered in standard textbooks in algorithms when I migrated it to math.SE. It had already one answer posted, since there was disagreement whether we should delete the answers for non-research level question and the preferred solution IIRC was migrating the answer and the question to Math.SE I migrated it to Math.SE in place of simply closing it.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;This is the explanation for why it got migrated to Math.SE. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I would be happy to hear any suggestions on how I can improve my decision making when closing/imigrating questions (it might be better to open a new discussion).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;hr&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Another issue is should we reopen it and erase the migration history or not. I personally lean towards reopening it because I think the research level answer that you have explained should be  made available on the main site although IMO it is not what the OP was asking for. I think we can also edit the question to make it look research level.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="186" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" LastActivityDate="2011-08-18T07:10:25.500" CommentCount="7" />
./Posts.xml:1212:  <row Id="1280" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAnswerId="1281" CreationDate="2011-08-20T05:44:07.430" Score="2" ViewCount="98" Body="&lt;p&gt;I was trying to add a bounty to Lawrence Cayton's &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/7844/exact-nearest-neighbor-in-d-dimensional-euclidean-space&quot;&gt;question on exact near neighbors&lt;/a&gt;, but I can nowhere see the link to start a bounty. ./Posts.xml:1218:  <row Id="1286" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="1285" CreationDate="2011-08-21T07:56:23.473" Score="2" Body="&lt;p&gt;For question which are completely and clearly off-topic and are very unlikely to get reopens or edited in a reasonable way that would make them on-topic on cstheory, (e.g. undergrad homework questions) it is reasonable to migrate. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;A main reason that OP asks such a question on cstheory is that he/she does not know where to ask it and asks the question on the wrong one.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Pro:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;It will keep the question open, (one question is saved)&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;May cause less bitterness than just closing the question (since it is probable that it will get answered on the other site)&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Usually such questions get negative total vote here, and might eventually get deleted.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;?&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Con:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;We might make a mistake as in &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/1274/why-was-all-pairs-shortest-path-in-undirected-and-unweighted-graphs-closed-and&quot;&gt;this case&lt;/a&gt; (but by being more careful we can reduce the possibility of something similar happening).&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;?&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="186" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" LastActivityDate="2011-08-21T07:56:23.473" CommentCount="3" />

./Posts.xml:1221:  <row Id="1289" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2011-08-21T20:47:41.893" Score="14" ViewCount="189" Body="&lt;p&gt;I just noticed that the BibTeX entry provided by the &quot;cite&quot; button on questions is not as good as it could be. For example, let's take the &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/q/79/&quot;&gt;Problems Between P and NPC&lt;/a&gt; question. This is the BibTeX entry provided by the stack exchange software:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;pre&gt;&#xA;\@MISC {79,&#xA;    TITLE = {Problems Between P and NPC},&#xA;    AUTHOR = {Lev Reyzin (https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/users/123/lev-reyzin)},&#xA;    HOWPUBLISHED = {Theoretical Computer Science},&#xA;    NOTE = {URL:https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/q/79 (version: 2011-08-09)},&#xA;    EPRINT = {https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/q/79},&#xA;    URL = {https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/q/79}&#xA;}&#xA;&lt;/pre&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;This is how it appears in the bibliography:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;[1] Lev Reyzin (&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/users/123/lev&quot;&gt;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/users/123/lev&lt;/a&gt; reyzin).  Problems between p and npc.  Theoretical Computer Science.  URL:&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/q/79&quot;&gt;Problems Between P and NPC&lt;/a&gt; (version: 2011-08-09).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Can we change the citation text? This citation has several problems. For example, &quot;Theoretical Computer Science&quot; is already the name of a journal, and the phrase doesn't describe this site. It should be more like &quot;Theoretical Computer Science Stack Exchange&quot; or something to that effect. If we can change this, are there any other changes that we should make?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;For example, this is how MathOverflow generates BibTex entries:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;pre&gt;&#xA;@MISC {MO23478,    &#xA;    TITLE = {Examples of common false beliefs in mathematics.},    &#xA;    AUTHOR = {gowers\phantom{x}(mathoverflow.net/users/1459)},    &#xA;    HOWPUBLISHED = {MathOverflow},    &#xA;    NOTE = {\url{https://mathoverflow.net/questions/23478} (version: 2010-05-04)},    &#xA;    EPRINT = {https://mathoverflow.net/questions/23478},    &#xA;    URL = {https://mathoverflow.net/questions/23478},    &#xA;}&#xA;&lt;/pre&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;This gets rendered as&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;[1] gowers  (mathoverﬂow.net/users/1459).   Examples of common false beliefs in mathematics.&#xA;  MathOverﬂow. &lt;a href=&quot;https://mathoverflow.net/questions/23478&quot;&gt;https://mathoverflow.net/questions/23478&lt;/a&gt; (version: 2010-05-04).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I like MO's citation. It has a shorter link to the user page (no username in URL), the URL gets linked due to the \url command, and the user URL skips the &quot;http://&quot; part.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="206" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:57:54.527" LastActivityDate="2013-08-07T15:14:09.490" Title="BibTeX entry for citations" Tags="&lt;feature-request&gt;&lt;citations&gt;" AnswerCount="2" CommentCount="0" />
./Posts.xml:1225:  <row Id="1293" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2011-08-22T21:01:16.187" Score="3" ViewCount="89" Body="&lt;p&gt;If we asked a question which was seen as on-topic (and maybe even upvoted) and it hung around on the site for a while, but did not generate an answer. Can we migrate the question to another site where it remains in scope? Or should I just cross-post and double-link?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;As a concrete example, I asked a question about crypto-currency on Jun 28:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/q/7145/1037&quot;&gt;Bitcoin and preventing double spending in decentralized digital currencies&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;It generated a answer-comment but not quiet an answer, some upvotes, and otherwise has sat idly on cstheory. Since that time, however, a new SE site sprung up: &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://crypto.stackexchange.com/&quot;&gt;https://crypto.stackexchange.com/&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Where this question would remain in scope. Does it make sense to migrate the question if the OP (in this case me) agrees? ./Posts.xml:1227:  <row Id="1295" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2011-08-23T04:26:57.707" Score="1" ViewCount="50" Body="&lt;p&gt;It would be nice to have a set of general recommendations and requirements for users asking &quot;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/formal-modeling&quot;&gt;How to model X&lt;/a&gt;&quot;, &quot;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/application-of-theory&quot;&gt;Applications of theory&lt;/a&gt;&quot;, and &quot;How to do X&quot; questions where X is an informal task (i.e. not stated in a clear mathematically rigorous way). Having such a list of recommendations and requirements would help the OPs of those post in improving the quality of their question and make it easier for others to answer them.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;MathOverflow has a set of general suggestions on its &quot;&lt;a href=&quot;https://mathoverflow.net/howtoask&quot;&gt;How to ask&lt;/a&gt;&quot; page, and we also have some other &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/faq#questions-should-be-based-on-knowledge-sharing-not-on-shirking&quot;&gt;general suggestions&lt;/a&gt; in our &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/faq&quot;&gt;FAQ&lt;/a&gt;. ./Posts.xml:1231:  <row Id="1299" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2011-08-24T16:38:58.067" Score="4" ViewCount="107" Body="&lt;p&gt;In the question: &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/4784/compendium-of-the-best-approximation-and-hardness-results-for-np-optimization-pro&quot;&gt;Compendium of the Best Approximation and Hardness Results for NP optimization problems&lt;/a&gt;,&#xA;it is pointed out that a wiki for computational problems similar to &lt;a href=&quot;http://qwiki.stanford.edu/index.php/Complexity_Zoo&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;Complexity Zoo&lt;/a&gt; can be beneficial for the researchers. It is a great help for researchers to know the best algorithmic results (lower and/or bound) related to a problem. Apparently, the zoo people started a new wiki for computational problems: &lt;a href=&quot;http://qwiki.stanford.edu/index.php/Complexity_Garden&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;complexity garden&lt;/a&gt;. I contacted the editors of complexity garden and they agreed to devote this wiki to algorithmic results of problems in addition to its original complexity related scope.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Now, I would like to announce this opportunity to populate the Garden. ./Posts.xml:1255:  <row Id="1323" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2011-09-06T13:24:55.540" Score="2" ViewCount="127" Body="&lt;p&gt;Several months back, I asked in math.SE &lt;a href=&quot;https://math.stackexchange.com/questions/36747/dynamic-programming-problem-and-shortest-path-problem&quot;&gt;the following question&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;I wonder if any dynamic programming problem can always be converted to&#xA;  a source-sink shortest path problem in a network with source and sink&#xA;  nodes given? &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The reason I asked is because I always pictured the type of problems that could be solved by DP as source-sink shortest path problems. In other words, the type of problems seemed to always have the interpretation as source-sink shortest path problems, but I was not sure if it was correct.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The only answer I have got so far is&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;The answer is no. The simplest example off the top of my head is the&#xA;  longest substring of ones in a 0,1 string. The typical DP solution&#xA;  would be to use a 1D array and store the length of the longest&#xA;  substring up that includes the i-th character in the i-th coordinate. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;When I further asked:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;why is the example not able to be formulated into a source-sink&#xA;  shortest path problem in a network?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The reply is:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;I don't really see an easy way of doing it as a source-sink SPP. For&#xA;  the DP solution, the answer is obtained by scanning the array for the&#xA;  largest number.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I am now still not sure how DP solves the longest substring of ones in a 0,1 string, and whether this problem can be interpreted as a source-sink shortest path problem. Also I feel the answerer may run out of idea from his reply. Since my question may also be relevant to algorithm theory, I am not sure if I can post my question on this site?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Thanks and regards!&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="1003" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:19:18.947" LastActivityDate="2011-09-06T13:24:55.540" Title="Can I post this question about dynmaic programming?" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;" AnswerCount="0" CommentCount="1" />
./Posts.xml:1256:  <row Id="1324" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="784" CreationDate="2011-09-08T23:50:59.190" Score="3" Body="&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/8123/complexity-of-selective-network-improvement-problem/8137#8137&quot;&gt;Chandra Chekuri shows&lt;/a&gt; that a &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/8123/complexity-of-selective-network-improvement-problem&quot;&gt;generalization of min-cost flow&lt;/a&gt; (where the goal is to choose a low-cost set of edges to &quot;repair&quot; in order to reduce their cost) is NP-hard by reduction from SET COVER. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="80" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" LastActivityDate="2011-09-08T23:50:59.190" CommentCount="0" />
./Posts.xml:1263:  <row Id="1331" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2011-09-12T19:12:33.703" Score="2" ViewCount="83" Body="&lt;p&gt;We have a tag for &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/clustering&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;clustering&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;clustering&lt;/a&gt; and (currently) 16 questions. ./Posts.xml:1266:  <row Id="1334" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="1331" CreationDate="2011-09-14T10:11:16.823" Score="3" Body="&lt;p&gt;I had checked the papers on arXiv about clustering. They use various top level tags depending on the topic (CV, LG, DB, ...). &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;It seems to me that most of the questions tagged clustering fall under LG, but the problem is that we have two tags &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/lg.learning&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;lg.learning&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;lg.learning&lt;/a&gt; and &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/machine-learning&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;machine-learning&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;machine-learning&lt;/a&gt;. It seems that on arXiv the second one is subset of the first, but we are using the first one in a more restricted way.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;ps: having a tag specifying the subject area is useful. It organizes the questions so people can filter them easily, it is useful in the same way that AMS MSC, ACM CCS, and arXiv top level tags for papers are, and it is not arbitrary.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="186" LastEditorUserId="186" LastEditDate="2011-09-14T13:24:51.033" LastActivityDate="2011-09-14T13:24:51.033" CommentCount="8" />
./Posts.xml:1267:  <row Id="1335" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2011-09-15T04:48:02.473" Score="0" ViewCount="86" Body="&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://meta.theoreticalphysics.stackexchange.com/questions/10/no-meta-tags-please&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;Over at the newly minted theoreticalphysics site&lt;/a&gt;, &lt;a href=&quot;http://meta.theoreticalphysics.stackexchange.com/users/10/dori&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;Dori&lt;/a&gt; mentions that as part of a &lt;a href=&quot;http://blog.stackoverflow.com/2010/08/the-death-of-meta-tags/&quot;&gt;year-old effort&lt;/a&gt; to clean &quot;meta&quot; tags, she's going to start removing the &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/reference-request&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;reference-request&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;reference-request&lt;/a&gt; tag. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;While I don't have very strong feelings on the matter, I do find the tag useful to quickly indicate what it is that the questioner actually wants. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;Should we make an argument for keeping the tag ?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="80" LastActivityDate="2011-09-15T06:30:20.173" Title="The end of reference-request ?" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;tags&gt;" AnswerCount="1" CommentCount="4" ClosedDate="2011-09-15T06:43:48.670" />
./Posts.xml:1268:  <row Id="1336" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="1335" CreationDate="2011-09-15T06:30:20.173" Score="2" Body="&lt;p&gt;I don't think the arguments for meta-tags being bad from &lt;a href=&quot;http://blog.stackoverflow.com/2010/08/the-death-of-meta-tags/&quot;&gt;Jeff's post&lt;/a&gt; apply to these tags. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;The reason meta-tags are a problem is that they do not describe the content of the question.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/reference-request&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;reference-request&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;reference-request&lt;/a&gt; does describe the content as well as &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/soft-question&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;soft-question&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;soft-question&lt;/a&gt;. We haven't had any problem with them and there are quite useful. So I don't think there is any reason to remove them. I agree that there has been lots of bad meta-tags (e.g. subjective) but it doesn't mean that all meta-tags are bad.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Jeff continues:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;How can you tell you’re using a meta-tag? It’s easier than you might think.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;  &#xA;  &lt;ol&gt;&#xA;  &lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;If the tag can’t work as the only tag on a question, it’s probably a meta-tag. Every tag you use should be able to work, more or less, as the only tag on a question. Meta-tags, like [beginner], [subjective], and [best-practices], are useless by themselves — they tell you nothing at all about the content of the question.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;  &lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;If the tag commonly means different things to different people, it’s probably a meta-tag.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;  &lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;We have had questions which were tagged just as &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/soft-question&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;soft-question&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;soft-question&lt;/a&gt;. So I think what we call a meta-tag is different from what they call a meta-tag. We use meta-tags mainly for soft questions, i.e. question about TCS not in TCS. In comparison, non-meta-tags on cstheory are used in a similar way to subject classification and keywords for papers.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="186" LastActivityDate="2011-09-15T06:30:20.173" CommentCount="2" />

./Posts.xml:1290:  <row Id="1358" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2011-09-30T19:08:27.623" Score="7" ViewCount="194" Body="&lt;p&gt;After reading a &lt;a href=&quot;http://chat.stackexchange.com/transcript/message/2051962#2051962&quot;&gt;post&lt;/a&gt; by user &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/users/4873/gopi&quot;&gt;Gopi&lt;/a&gt; in the chat room, I wrote a &lt;a href=&quot;http://data.stackexchange.com/theoreticalcomputerscience/s/1921/closed-questions-per-month&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;query on Data Explorer which lists the number of questions posted in each month and the number of closed questions among them&lt;/a&gt; (although it is not exactly what Gopi asked).  I will not try to interpret the data here, but if you find it interesting or if you have something to say about it, let me know.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;For the last month in the table, the actual number of questions and closed questions should be larger than the numbers shown in the table because the table is as of the time of the last update of the database.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/81887/what-happens-to-unanswered-questions-from-deleted-accounts/82408#82408&quot;&gt;Questions with no answers, low score, and low activity for a while are deleted automatically&lt;/a&gt;.  This means that in most cases, closed questions with negative score which are more than 30 days old and closed questions with score 0 which are more than 365 days old will be deleted and not included in the table.  Therefore, the actual number and the actual rate of closed questions for more than one month old will be higher than shown in the table.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Warning&lt;/strong&gt;.  I am not familiar with SQL, the language in which this query is written.  Therefore, the query may well contain a bug.  In case you find a bug, I am happy to learn about it.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Aside&lt;/strong&gt;.  The table shows that there is one question posted in 2008.  Unfortunately this is not an evidence for a time machine.  This question was migrated from another site, and it was posted in 2008 in the original site.  Ideally the query should use the month when the question started to appear on cstheory.stackexchange.com, but I currently ignore this issue because this should affect only the migrated questions and there are not many of them.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="567" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" LastActivityDate="2011-10-04T12:59:31.793" Title="The number of questions and closed questions" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;closing&gt;&lt;data-explorer&gt;" AnswerCount="2" CommentCount="4" FavoriteCount="1" />

./Posts.xml:1299:  <row Id="1367" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="1365" CreationDate="2011-10-03T20:07:46.913" Score="5" Body="&lt;p&gt;(This is a more detailed version of my comment on the question.)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Closing and deletion are different notions.  (But some closed and even non-closed questions are deleted automatically.  See below.)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Closed but not deleted questions are listed in your profile.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Unless you have &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/privileges/moderator-tools&quot;&gt;reputation points ≥ 10,000&lt;/a&gt; or you are a moderator, you cannot view deleted questions (including your own questions which have been deleted).&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;There is a &lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/2645/show-all-of-my-question-answers-to-me-even-if-they-are-deleted&quot;&gt;feature request on Meta Stack Overflow&lt;/a&gt; to allow a user to see his/her own questions which have been deleted, but this request was declined in June 2010.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;Why are some closed (and even non-closed) questions deleted automatically?&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If a question has no answers, low score, and no activity for a long time, it is deleted automatically.  Closed questions tend to have low score and low activity, and therefore I imagine that they are often subject to this automatic deletion mechanism.  See &lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/81887/what-happens-to-unanswered-questions-from-deleted-accounts/82408#82408&quot;&gt;this post&lt;/a&gt; for the gory details.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;See &lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/65768/do-closed-questions-get-deleted-automatically-after-some-time&quot;&gt;this&lt;/a&gt; for another reason why closed questions may be deleted earlier than the automatic deletion kicks in.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="567" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" LastActivityDate="2011-10-04T20:50:33.373" CommentCount="0" />
./Posts.xml:1303:  <row Id="1371" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="1369" CreationDate="2011-10-10T15:18:13.113" Score="7" Body="&lt;p&gt;I think &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/q/8543/30&quot;&gt;this question&lt;/a&gt; on the future of computer science could have been worked with instead of closed.  A version of the question like, &quot;What are the main position papers about the future of computer science?&quot; might be very informative.  There are certainly citations available from CACM and other places, about the mismatch between the current hardware curriculum and the emerging needs of the hardware industry, or the current software engineering curriculum and the emerging needs of the software industry.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Without too much work, that question could have been made useful for the site -- i.e., requesting links and hard content, not just the posting of opinions.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Now, perhaps Noam totally disagrees with me about this particular question, and I am hijacking his thread, but as long as we are here, I thought I would let people know my position.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="30" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.537" LastActivityDate="2011-10-10T15:18:13.113" CommentCount="4" />
./Posts.xml:1304:  <row Id="1372" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2011-10-11T20:36:08.390" Score="5" ViewCount="332" Body="&lt;p&gt;This question is on rewriting of the &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/q/8539/1449&quot;&gt;automata theory question.&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I am at a loss to understand this extensive rewriting of the question to make it look &quot;research&quot; level. In the process a certain innocence and resonance the question had is gone! It was for precisely this reason that it evoked so many good answers.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;As Noam said &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/q/1369/1449&quot;&gt;yesterday&lt;/a&gt;, can we take it easy? Can the site allow some latitude in these matters?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;PS: I appreciate the effort and time that goes into rewriting driven the desire to make this a better site.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Update (from suresh): Here's the original question:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;In class we are currently learning about state machines and so-called&#xA;  &quot;regular expressions&quot; and languages that are &quot;accepted&quot;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;  &#xA;  &lt;p&gt;This is all interesting stuff we are learning, but I was hoping there&#xA;  was a really good reason for learning such a concept...&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;  &#xA;  &lt;p&gt;I know that there is always a way for application in topics related to&#xA;  CS theory, but with this whole automata concept I can't really&#xA;  extrapolate the cruciality of it... any experts here would like to&#xA;  offer their perspective?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;and the final edit (for comparison):&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;There is always a way for application in topics related to theoretical&#xA;  computer science. But textbooks and undergraduate courses usually&#xA;  don't explain the reason that automata theory is an important topic&#xA;  and whether it still has applications in practice. Therefore&#xA;  undergraduate students might have trouble in understanding the&#xA;  importance of automata theory and might think it is not of any&#xA;  practical use anymore.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;  &#xA;  &lt;p&gt;Is automata theory still useful in practice?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;  &#xA;  &lt;p&gt;Should it be part of undergraduate CS curriculum?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="1449" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" LastActivityDate="2011-11-02T19:36:12.897" Title="&quot;Research&quot; Level" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;specific-question&gt;" AnswerCount="5" CommentCount="5" />

./Posts.xml:1312:  <row Id="1380" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="1369" CreationDate="2011-10-18T13:38:56.750" Score="3" Body="&lt;p&gt;Related discussion on MO:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.mathoverflow.net/discussion/1174/redirecting-people-who-did-not-read-the-faq/&quot;&gt;https://meta.mathoverflow.net/discussion/1174/redirecting-people-who-did-not-read-the-faq/&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Concerning Robin's suggestion, there is a list of possible comments on TeX.SE:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://tex.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/430/text-building-blocks&quot;&gt;https://tex.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/430/text-building-blocks&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="186" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-17T10:13:04.397" LastActivityDate="2011-10-18T13:38:56.750" CommentCount="5" />
./Posts.xml:1313:  <row Id="1381" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2011-10-21T20:05:20.697" Score="10" ViewCount="1049" Body="&lt;p&gt;This post is inspired by answers to &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/q/1369&quot;&gt;this question&lt;/a&gt; and a similar list on &lt;a href=&quot;https://tex.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/430&quot;&gt;TEX.SE&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The idea is to make a bunch of templates for commonly-used comments, like comments explaining that a question is out of scope and the question will be closed. Collecting such templates in one place makes it easier for those who don't wish to type out a personalized comment every time they vote to close a question.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Please post templates as answers. This question is CW, so feel free to edit other people's answers to improve the templates.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="206" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" LastActivityDate="2013-07-21T11:56:10.070" Title="Comment templates" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;faq&gt;&lt;policy&gt;&lt;comments&gt;" AnswerCount="8" CommentCount="5" FavoriteCount="6" CommunityOwnedDate="2011-10-21T21:47:07.853" />
./Posts.xml:1314:  <row Id="1382" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="1381" CreationDate="2011-10-23T03:20:34.820" Score="8" Body="&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;New user posts a question which doesn't appear to be in the scope (research-level TCS)&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;code&gt;Welcome to CSTheory, a Q&amp;amp;A site for *research-level* questions in *theoretical computer science* (TCS). ./Posts.xml:1315:  <row Id="1383" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="1372" CreationDate="2011-10-23T21:31:04.340" Score="3" Body="&lt;p&gt;I would like to share my vague feeling: reducing the personal tone from a post can be sometimes good, but it must be difficult to do it right.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;As a general principle, I think that reducing the personal tone from the question is sometimes good.  Too much personal tone can be distracting, and reducing the personal tone can improve the readability of a question (or perhaps also an answer).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In this particular example, the question before the edit sounds a little like a diary rather than a question written as a question from the beginning.  It is fine in a blog, but it is probably suboptimal on a Q&amp;amp;A website.  I guess that this is why Kaveh felt the need for an edit.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;However, in this particular example, I do not think that it was done well.  I do not like the opening after the edit:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;There is always a way for application in topics related to theoretical computer science.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Despite the intent of the edit which Kaveh explained, this does not sound like a professional to me.  Instead, it sounds like some newbie who tries to pretend to be a professional.  Frankly speaking, the question sounded at least honest before the edit, but it sounds pretentious after the edit.  I am sorry, but I do not like how the question is stated after the edit at all.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Also, it should be pointed out that &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/300/how-to-ask-a-good-question/306#306&quot;&gt;we encourage to include a personal motivation in a question&lt;/a&gt;: we want a question which the asker cares out of his/her own interest rather than a question which the asker thinks that someone cares.  In this sense, good questions necessarily contain some personal part.  I do not think that it is right to remove everything personal from a question.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Thinking this way, it seems very difficult to edit a question to reduce the personal tone while maintaining some degree of personality.  If you do it, you should do it right.  I guess that it is a perfectly reasonable choice to give up such a difficult task and just either leave the question open or close it.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="567" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" LastActivityDate="2011-11-02T19:36:12.897" CommentCount="0" />
./Posts.xml:1316:  <row Id="1384" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="1381" CreationDate="2011-10-25T06:18:14.923" Score="8" Body="&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;User crossposts a question on multiple sites.&lt;/strong&gt; &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;code&gt;It appears that you have crossposted this question *simultaneously*. While we don't mind a question being reposted, our [site policy](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/a/231/) only permits a repost after sufficient time has passed and you have not obtained the desired answer elsewhere. I am closing the question since simultaneous crossposting duplicates effort and fractures discussion. Please wait a few days and then if your question is still not answered request a reopening by flagging the question for moderator attention (after summarizing relevant discussions from other sites).&lt;/code&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Which will appear as:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;It appears that you have crossposted this question &lt;em&gt;simultaneously&lt;/em&gt;. ./Posts.xml:1318:  <row Id="1387" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2011-10-26T15:22:08.660" Score="21" ViewCount="989" Body="&lt;p&gt;The mission of Stack Exchange is to make the internet a better place to get expert answers to your questions. The Stack Exchange Fellowship Program aims to support students conducting research in subjects related to our academic Q&amp;amp;A sites in order to (a) increase the quality of information in a particular subject and (b) facilitate the exchange of information between experts in the field. Individual awards range from 250 to 1000 dollars (USD).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Applicants should be advanced undergraduate, graduate students or professionals pursuing research related to one the following Stack Exchange sites:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://english.meta.stackexchange.com/q/2077/13231&quot;&gt;English&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://linguistics.meta.stackexchange.com/q/202/344&quot;&gt;Linguistics&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://physics.meta.stackexchange.com/q/942/5450&quot;&gt;Physics&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://physics.meta.stackexchange.com/q/942/5450&quot;&gt;Statistics&lt;/a&gt;  &lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Theoretical Computer Science&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://meta.theoreticalphysics.stackexchange.com/q/170/533&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;Theoretical Physics&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Applications will be accepted on a rolling basis starting immediately. For more details and to apply, check out the &lt;a href=&quot;http://dl.dropbox.com/u/37818223/SE%20Fellowship%20Application.docx&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;application&lt;/a&gt;!&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;We are also accepting volunteers from the community to help review applications. Volunteers should have some level of expertise in the subject area (professors and those who have or are pursuing advanced degrees are ideal candidates). Reviewers will be given 3 weeks from when they receive materials or may request more time if needed. Following the first wave of submissions, those selected to be Stack Exchange Fellows will be asked to review 3 to 4 new applications. To facilitate the review process, reviewers will rate applications on several scales instead of making judgments on funding. You can find the Reviewer Form &lt;a href=&quot;http://dl.dropbox.com/u/37818223/Reviewer%20Sheet.docx&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;here&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Reviewers and successful candidates are encouraged to customize the &quot;about me&quot; section of the user profile by including information on:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Area of expertise and current occupation &lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Key academic goals/milestones&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Role in the Fellowship program (applicant, reviewer, fellow, both)&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;SE grant project, if applicable &lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If you have any questions regarding the Fellowship Program, or would like more information about applying or becoming a reviewer, please email &lt;em&gt;academics@stackexchange.com&lt;/em&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Edited: Applications accepted on a rolling basis until December 31, 2011. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="6961" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:49:12.240" LastActivityDate="2011-12-23T12:51:55.027" Title="Introducing Stack Exchange Research Support and Fellowship Program" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;" AnswerCount="3" CommentCount="5" FavoriteCount="11" />
./Posts.xml:1320:  <row Id="1389" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="1372" CreationDate="2011-10-27T11:59:51.837" Score="1" Body="&lt;p&gt;This is not a research question but a teaching question, about the reason for the design of the typical CS curriculum. ./Posts.xml:1325:  <row Id="1395" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2011-11-01T19:08:24.100" Score="15" ViewCount="536" Body="&lt;p&gt;I am worried about the attitude of some people who claim that down-voters must always explain the reason for down-voting or who criticize the users who vote down posts without explanations.  (&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/1264/conventions-on-downvoting/1272#1272&quot;&gt;Here is an example of such a criticism&lt;/a&gt;.)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;On the Stack Exchange system, voting is anonymous: users have the right to vote without revealing their identities for whatever reasons they have.  Down-voters who do not wish to reveal their identities cannot explain the reason because there is no way to post a comment anonymously.  This is a legitimate use of the system, and I do not think that users should be criticized just because they down-voted a post without giving an explanation.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Of course, no one should expect that votes without explanation are as convincing as votes with good justification.  Because of this, I think that it is wiser to explain the reason when you vote down a post.  But that is a separate issue.  My point is that as long as we use a system which allows anonymous voting, it is users’ right to vote up or down without giving any justification.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="567" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" LastActivityDate="2012-06-07T20:15:38.637" Title="About some criticisms against down-votes without explanations" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;down-votes&gt;" AnswerCount="5" CommentCount="1" FavoriteCount="3" />
./Posts.xml:1327:  <row Id="1397" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="1394" CreationDate="2011-11-01T22:22:03.483" Score="-3" Body="&lt;p&gt;Please don't. This kind of information shouldn't be on the site at all, and instances that do appear ought to be closed. Using the CW status is merely &lt;a href=&quot;http://blog.stackoverflow.com/2011/08/the-future-of-community-wiki/&quot;&gt;abusive&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Put another way, &quot;The PhD CW question&quot; is to this site as [any question that belongs on Programmers SE] is to Stack Overflow.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;(I admit that I'm a bit annoyed right now. Now that I'm actually a grad student, I came here to look up information about a research-related topic. ./Posts.xml:1329:  <row Id="1399" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="1394" CreationDate="2011-11-02T16:00:46.497" Score="2" Body="&lt;p&gt;I am fine with advice questions from people who are target community of the site, less so with questions which are from others (e.g. undergrad students), there are other recourses on the net that deal with topics quite well, and there seems no reason the TCS researchers  will give a better answer than those resources. I think we should avoid it as much as possible. It does NOT turn a off-topic into a on-topic one.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;(The problem is that people want to express that they &lt;em&gt;like&lt;/em&gt; a post but think the author deserves &lt;em&gt;no reputation&lt;/em&gt; for posting it. CW is being abused for covering this conflict.)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="186" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.537" LastActivityDate="2011-11-02T16:00:46.497" CommentCount="4" />
./Posts.xml:1332:  <row Id="1402" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2011-11-05T12:55:38.813" Score="2" ViewCount="159" Body="&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/users/7104/anonymous-coward&quot;&gt;This user&lt;/a&gt; seems to be the &lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.mathoverflow.net/discussion/1164/recent-questions-in-complexity-theory/&quot;&gt;same one on MO&lt;/a&gt; which has posted several questions on MathOverflow without following them up and the questions are left there.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Now the user has started doing the same thing here, and she/he doesn't reply to the comments to clarify the questions and does not seem to care about them being answered or not.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;How should we deal with this? Or do you think there is a better way to deal with this? &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;(The reason I am asking this is that it seems the user is probably a graduate student in TCS and the questions can end up being interesting if we can make her/him reply to the comments and clarify her/his questions.)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="186" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" LastActivityDate="2011-11-05T12:55:38.813" Title="About user Anonymous Coward" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;specific-question&gt;&lt;specific-user-account&gt;" AnswerCount="0" CommentCount="2" />
./Posts.xml:1334:  <row Id="1404" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="1403" CreationDate="2011-11-07T15:13:15.310" Score="5" Body="&lt;p&gt;Zirui, cstheory is a Q&amp;amp;A site with a scope defined in its FAQ. The scope of cstheory is research-level. Questions that are at the level of difficulty of typical undergraduate students are not part of the scope. There are other Q&amp;amp;A sites which have a more general scope like &lt;a href=&quot;https://math.stackexchange.com/&quot;&gt;Math.SE&lt;/a&gt; that would welcome questions from students.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Votes (down and up) are one of the main ways users express their opinion about the quality of a question and how interesting it is. A user may down vote a question if she/he thinks the question is off-topic or has other problems (e.g. unclear, not answerable in its current form, argumentative, not a real question, post to solicit opinion, ...).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;hr&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If you want to know why &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/8826/is-halting-that-hard-yes&quot;&gt;your question&lt;/a&gt; is down voted you can ask for that in place of attacking other users. I will explain my down vote in more detail below:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;It seems to me that you are trying to find a way to get around the undecidability of halting problem. The halting problem (as it is defined in the literature) is undecidable and that is a mathematical theorem. Now one might be interested in decidable variations of halting problem. That is a well studied topic, and one can ask a research level question about that. There are also researchers working on these kind of problems who try to find ways to deal with undecidability in practice (mainly in formal methods community, but also in theoretical computer science). &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;On the other hand your question has no sign that you are familiar with the literature. I can tell that this is something a typical undergraduate student taking their first course in computability would ask. It is nice that a student would think about this kind of problems. But everything has a place and the place of this question is not cstheory. If you ask it on Math.SE you probably will not get any down votes. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;As an analogy, it is completely fine and even encouraged that students ask questions like this in an undergraduate computability class from the instructor. Asking it in a research-level computability workshop will probably be unwelcome.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If you ask a question about halting problem and show that you are familiar with the literature and understand the basics in the area, and the question is a real question (posting a question to see how others think about your idea about how to solve halting problem is not a real question) and is clearly stated (can be answered without much back-and-forth comments where others try to guess what you want to ask, which can be a sign that the question is not well-thought), then that can be on-topic and I would guess would not receive any down votes.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;ps:&#xA;I would suggest that you take a look at the &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/faq#questions-should-be-based-on-knowledge-sharing-not-on-shirking&quot;&gt;this section of the FAQ&lt;/a&gt; and also the pages linked there. Following those suggestions would increase the chance that your questions are well perceived by the community.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="186" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" LastActivityDate="2011-11-07T15:21:33.820" CommentCount="0" />

./Posts.xml:1351:  <row Id="1422" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2011-11-14T21:54:27.087" Score="-7" ViewCount="384" Body="&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;In response to the community's feedback on this contest, &lt;strong&gt;we've decided&#xA;  to cancel it.&lt;/strong&gt; We never intended to favor quantity over quality, but we&#xA;  can see how this contest missed the mark. We appreciate all the&#xA;  constructive criticism regarding this idea.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;  &#xA;  &lt;p&gt;In case you haven't seen the contest yet and are interested, you can&#xA;  still read the announcement below.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;As more and more research-oriented sites pop up on Stack Exchange, we can’t help but be impressed with the amazing academic resource our users have created. We also can’t help but wonder... which academic community has the most Stack spirit? In an epic question-asking battle, would Math take down Statistics? Could Linguistics edge out English? If only there was a way to find out... &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Oh wait! There is: an epic question-asking battle. Let’s do it! It’s getting close to the holidays after all, so now is a perfect time for us to say thank you by continuing our tradition of giving back. As such, the community that wins this battle will get 1000 USD to donate to a charity of their choice. Winners of each round will also get 100 USD to donate to charity.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Here’s how the battle will work:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Participating sites are English, Math, Statistics, Theoretical Computer Science, Linguistics, Physics, Philosophy, and History.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Each round will last a week, and the contest will be single-elimination bracket-style. &lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;To move on to the next round, the average number of questions each site asks per day during the round must exceed that site’s current average. Whichever site exceeds their average by more questions wins the round. &lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;To determine who would face off in the first round, we seeded the sites according to past activity.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Are you ready for this?! Here it is:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;https://i.stack.imgur.com/DIyMj.png&quot; alt=&quot;enter image description here&quot;&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;A few more notes:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Although this is a contest, a “Battle of the Sites” if you will, it’s all in the spirit of fundraising for charity and having fun. So while we understand (and encourage!) competitiveness, try to keep it friendly. &lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;While we expect this contest to generate a lot of new questions, we&#xA;have full faith in the community’s ability to uphold its standards&#xA;and preference for good questions. If we find that a site is getting&#xA;a lot of bad questions during the contest, it will have to be&#xA;disqualified.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Round one starts now and ends Sunday 11/20 at 11:59 pm UTC. Ready. ./Posts.xml:1356:  <row Id="1427" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="1422" CreationDate="2011-11-15T14:44:28.690" Score="5" Body="&lt;p&gt;There are two things which feel wrong to me in this game.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;One is the wrong metric.  Because of the metric used in the game, the game seems to encourage quantity over quality.  That is not what we want in this community, as Gilles stated.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;More importantly, the other is the very intent of this game, namely, trying to make the users as productive as possible.  Let me quote Asaf Karagila’s comment on &lt;a href=&quot;https://math.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/3212/battle-of-the-sites&quot;&gt;meta.math.stackexchange.com&lt;/a&gt; (emphasis in original):&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;To add on the above, this is exactly why I left DeviantART.  I &lt;strong&gt;hate&lt;/strong&gt; (with true passion) communities that try to prod me into being &quot;more&quot; productive as a member of the community.  Especially communities which I actually feel a part (which as a person I can honestly say that it is a very rare and very transient feeling).  I truly hope that the SE sites do not plan on having these &quot;happy happy joy joy&quot; activities often, I'd imagine I am not the only one feeling negatively about this sort of initiative.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I share this feeling.  I do not want cstheory.stackexchange.com to tell me to be more productive on the website.  I participate in the website to the extent that it is fun to me, not more, and it is annoying to be asked to change it in any way.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Usually I try to ignore such an annoying request.  But when it becomes a burden to ignore the requests like this, that will be the time for me to leave this website.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="567" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T16:37:16.437" LastActivityDate="2011-11-15T14:54:08.263" CommentCount="0" />

./Posts.xml:1365:  <row Id="1436" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="1435" CreationDate="2011-11-29T06:48:47.980" Score="13" Body="&lt;p&gt;I am in full agreement with you. Please see &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/628/a-page-for-most-recent-significatly-modified-questions-not-tag-edits-and-who-h&quot;&gt;this&lt;/a&gt; and &lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/69659/a-page-for-questions-sorted-based-on-last-significant-modification-not-tag-edit&quot;&gt;this&lt;/a&gt;. We have already asked for this feature, SE didn't agree. (Maybe they will change their opinion if more people complain about it. I think at least we should get something like &lt;a href=&quot;https://stackoverflow.com/?tab=interesting&quot;&gt;this&lt;/a&gt;).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I edit questions which don't use one of the top level tags (for classification reason). I would prefer if people use one of them when asking a question and I wouldn't need to do this retagging. I try to restrict my tag edits to the questions on the front page so it has a less annoying effect. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;ps: I don't use RSS/email to get the updates so maybe this is a bigger problem for people using them.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;pps: I think a reasonable solution is to have something similar to &lt;a href=&quot;http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Help:Minor_edit&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;the minor edit checkbox on Wikipedia&lt;/a&gt;. It works on Wikipedia well even with completely anonymous users, surely would not create a problem if the edits are made by high rep users.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="186" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-05-23T12:40:08.913" LastActivityDate="2012-01-02T12:18:22.247" CommentCount="3" />
