./Posts.xml:1375:  <row Id="1447" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="1437" CreationDate="2011-12-01T19:03:04.977" Score="3" Body="&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Introducing CSTheory to students via Algorithmic Contest&lt;/strong&gt; &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In order to make the event more interesting for students, we are&#xA;organizing an Online Algorithmic Contest as part of FSTTCS.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The format of the contest is as follows:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;1.Three problems will be posed on the first day of the conference on &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.algomuse.appspot.com/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;Algo Muse website&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol start=&quot;2&quot;&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;The students can answer them at their leisure and submit in two&#xA;days. The contest is open to anyone, so we are expecting around 100-150 participants. Top performers will get some prizes. &lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;After the contest, we will publish an editorial which will contain&#xA;solutions to the problems along with some additional references. (Brief&#xA;history: We have been conducting some internal contests in IIT Bombay for a while now).&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;How CSTheory can be promoted&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;One problem will be designed such that the editorial will contain links&#xA;to the following CSTheory posts as a natural extension to the solution:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/8569/problems-to-reduce-from-to-prove-an-omegan-log-n-lower-bound&quot;&gt;Problems to reduce from to prove an $\Omega(n\log n)$ lower bound&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1284/problems-that-can-be-used-to-show-polynomial-time-hardness-results/&quot;&gt;Problems that can be used to show polynomial-time hardness results&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;This would be a gentle way of getting students interested about CSTheory&#xA;site.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="547" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.537" LastActivityDate="2011-12-01T19:29:18.427" CommentCount="1" />
./Posts.xml:1376:  <row Id="1448" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2011-12-01T22:59:23.027" Score="5" ViewCount="299" Body="&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Possible Duplicate:&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br&gt;&#xA;  &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/1619/community-promotion-ads-2013&quot;&gt;Community Promotion Ads - 2013&lt;/a&gt;  &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;We're hitting the start of the new year, and that means a new iteration of the Community Promotion Ads!&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;What in the Wide, Wide World of Sports is Going On Here?&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;TL;DR -- put images and links in the answers. If they get voted up enough, they will appear on the main site as community promotion ads.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;But whyyyyyyy?&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;This is a method for the community to control what gets promoted to visitors on the site. For example, you might promote the following things:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;cool site-related open source apps&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;the site's twitter account&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;scripts packs or power tools&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;cool events or conferences&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;anything else your community would genuinely be interested in&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The goal is for future visitors to find out about &lt;em&gt;the stuff your community deems important&lt;/em&gt;. And to click on it for great justice!&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;How does it work?&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The answers you post to this question &lt;em&gt;must&lt;/em&gt; conform to the following rules, or they will be ignored. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;All answers should be in the exact form of:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;pre&gt;&lt;code&gt;[![Tagline to show on mouseover][1]][2]&#xA;&#xA;   [1]: http://image-url&#xA;   [2]: http://clickthrough-url &#xA;&lt;/code&gt;&lt;/pre&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Please &lt;strong&gt;do not add anything else to the body of the post&lt;/strong&gt;. If you want to discuss something, do it in the comments.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;The question must always be tagged with the magic &lt;a href=&quot;/questions/tagged/community-ads&quot; class=&quot;post-tag moderator-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;community-ads&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;community-ads&lt;/a&gt; tag.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;Image requirements&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;The image that you create must be &lt;strong&gt;220 x 250 pixels&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Must be hosted through our standard image uploader (imgur)&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Must be GIF or PNG&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;No animated GIFs&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Absolute limit on file size of 150 KB&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;Score Threshold&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;There is a &lt;strong&gt;minimum score threshold&lt;/strong&gt; an answer must meet (currently 6) before it will be shown on the main site.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;You can check out the ads that have met the threshold with basic click stats &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/ads/display/1448&quot;&gt;here&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="6115" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" LastActivityDate="2012-07-18T20:02:26.050" Title="Community Promotion Ads - 2012" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;community-ads&gt;" AnswerCount="2" CommentCount="2" ClosedDate="2012-12-10T14:52:17.733" CommunityOwnedDate="2011-12-01T22:59:23.027" />

./Posts.xml:1382:  <row Id="1455" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="1453" CreationDate="2011-12-12T21:57:07.317" Score="3" Body="&lt;p&gt;I decided to turn my comment into an answer.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;cstheory is NOT a discussion forum.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;The main kind of questions for cstheory are questions &lt;em&gt;in&lt;/em&gt; TCS. soft-questions can be acceptable (and I have expressed my opinion previously that I support including them in the scope), but they are not the main kind of questions for cstheory (e.g. they are acceptable as long as they are infrequent). soft-questions should be held to higher standards than non-subjective questions in TCS.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;I don't like when users who haven't contributed to cstheory drop by from time to time and ask subjective and controversial questions. IMO, these users should first contribute to cstheory by asking and answering questions &lt;em&gt;in&lt;/em&gt; TCS before asking subjective and possibly controversial questions &lt;em&gt;about&lt;/em&gt; TCS. soft-question about TCS which are not in the scope (e.g. if the answer to the question is so trivial that any researchers or graduate student in TCS would know the answer like &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/9226/whats-a-good-news-source-for-computer-science&quot;&gt;this&lt;/a&gt;) then they are not suitable for cstheory.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Finally, there are different types of soft-questions. In particular, when the question is a subjective one, it can be good subjective soft-question or a bad subjective soft-question. Bad subjective soft-questions should get closed directly. (and IMHO there was not a need for locking this question.)&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;See &lt;a href=&quot;http://blog.stackoverflow.com/2010/09/good-subjective-bad-subjective/&quot;&gt;this post&lt;/a&gt; for more on the distinction between good subjective and bad subjective.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="186" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" LastActivityDate="2011-12-12T22:13:15.140" CommentCount="5" />
./Posts.xml:1388:  <row Id="1462" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2012-01-10T17:08:35.453" Score="6" ViewCount="105" Body="&lt;p&gt;A main source of reasonable closed questions that we have are questions that are just below research-level: maybe they're really advanced undergraduate questions, or intro grad-level questions that are straightforward. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Our policy has been to close these questions (maybe with hints in the comments) and recommend that the user ask them on math.SE if appropriate.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I'm not proposing a change in scope to allow such questions. What I'm proposing is that we suggest that these questions be posted on our chat system. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;This idea is actually due to &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/a/1460/80&quot;&gt;Artem Kaznatcheev in an answer&lt;/a&gt; &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/1459/simple-questions-during-reading-papers&quot;&gt;to this question&lt;/a&gt;. I think it's an interesting suggestion for three reasons:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;It allows us to keep such questions 'in-house' without watering down the quality of questions on the main site. This would encourage people who might not otherwise be able to be on the site to participate, and over time they might be able to &quot;graduate&quot; to questions on the main site. &lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;It allows us to use the chat feature, which has been left unused thus far. Since many of the questions of this nature that people post have quick answers, the chat system enables that quick back-and-forth&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Participation is 'opt-in': since the chat system isn't front and center, there's no danger that people uninterested in answering such questions might be forced to wade through pages and pages to get to the 'research-level' questions.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;One fear that we've had in the past with allowing lower-level questions is that we'd get swamped with such questions and that things like reputation counts and question scores would get biased towards answering such questions. Keeping them in the chat system ensures that questions get answered, but this doesn't happen.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Thoughts ? &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="80" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" LastActivityDate="2012-01-28T17:06:24.907" Title="Moving relevant but possibly-below-level questions to chat ?" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;chat&gt;" AnswerCount="2" CommentCount="4" />

./Posts.xml:1393:  <row Id="1472" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="1471" CreationDate="2012-01-14T21:11:36.550" Score="7" Body="&lt;p&gt;When one of the moderators casts a close/reopen vote, the question is closed/reopened immediately.  Kaveh is one of the moderators.  See &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/about&quot;&gt;this&lt;/a&gt; for the list of moderators.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;You need at least 250 reputation points to cast a close or reopen vote to your own questions.  See &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/privileges/view-close-votes&quot;&gt;this&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;You can edit your own question by clicking the “edit” link below the question.  After editing, you can ask moderators to take a look at the question for reopening by flagging the question and selecting “it needs ♦ moderator attention.”&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="567" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" LastActivityDate="2012-01-14T21:11:36.550" CommentCount="6" />
./Posts.xml:1394:  <row Id="1473" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2012-01-16T20:17:34.573" Score="2" ViewCount="134" Body="&lt;p&gt;I think &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/trouble-with-paper&quot;&gt;trouble-with-paper&lt;/a&gt; is not a useful tag. I suggest that we remove it (by merging with tag-removed).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;update:&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Tags for non soft questions are mainly used for subject classification and for keywords (there are some exceptions like reference-request). I think that we should keep the number of these (reference-request like) tags as small as possible. And the burden is on the creator of the tag to justify the usefulness of these tags.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The main use of tags is categorizing question to make it easier to search/ignore/... questions. This tag doesn't express much about the content of the question. It seems very unlikely to me that anyone would use the &lt;code&gt;trouble-with-paper&lt;/code&gt; tag. It almost feels like tagging a question with a &lt;code&gt;question&lt;/code&gt; tag.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="186" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" LastActivityDate="2012-01-17T00:49:28.763" Title="The trouble-with-paper tag" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;tags&gt;" AnswerCount="1" CommentCount="4" />
./Posts.xml:1396:  <row Id="1475" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="1428" CreationDate="2012-01-22T21:19:22.003" Score="3" Body="&lt;p&gt;Comparing the last 5 posts on &lt;a href=&quot;http://cstheory.blogoverflow.com&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;the blog&lt;/a&gt; to &lt;a href=&quot;http://blogoverflow&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;Blog Overflow's Aggregation&lt;/a&gt;, the list is the same:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;https://i.stack.imgur.com/Tbd3L.png&quot; alt=&quot;blog vs feed&quot;&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Blog Overflow uses &lt;a href=&quot;http://cstheory.blogoverflow.com/feed&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;the blog's rss feed&lt;/a&gt; to list the latest posts, so if they are showing in our own aggregation, the source feed is listing the posts.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Checking this feed against W3C's Feed Validation Service results in &lt;a href=&quot;http://validator.w3.org/feed/check.cgi?url=http%3A%2F%2Fcstheory.blogoverflow.com%2Ffeed&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;a valid result&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Please make sure that &lt;code&gt;http://cstheory.blogoverflow.com/feed&lt;/code&gt; is the url that is being used to aggregate.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Aside from that, I don't have enough information on specific details to investigate this further. ./Posts.xml:1397:  <row Id="1476" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2012-01-26T02:19:05.587" Score="2" ViewCount="48" Body="&lt;p&gt;On &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/9887/tradeoff-bounds-for-halfspace-range-counting/9893#9893&quot;&gt;this question&lt;/a&gt; I posted an answer, which points to a survey paper which could answer his question, but I didn't have the time or expertise to fully answer the question myself. Later, another user posted another, more authoritative answer which more directly addresses the question and also points to the same survey. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I'm wondering, should the two answers be consolidated in any way, or should I edit my answer to point to the second answer? The reason that I ask is that now that the second answer has been posted, mine somewhat redundant. ./Posts.xml:1399:  <row Id="1478" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="1462" CreationDate="2012-01-28T17:06:24.907" Score="1" Body="&lt;p&gt;Chat can be a place to provide hints, but not answers. Just because a question is not research-level doesn't mean that it doesn't deserve a proper answer. It's just that this particular site is not the proper site for it.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Questions that are too elementary for this site, and mathematical in nature, can be migrated to &lt;a href=&quot;https://math.stackexchange.com/&quot;&gt;Mathematics Stack Exchange&lt;/a&gt;. Questions that are too elementary or too applied for this site, and that are sufficiently close to development, can be migrated to &lt;a href=&quot;https://stackoverflow.com/&quot;&gt;Stack Overflow&lt;/a&gt;, but that's hit-and-miss, as part of the SO the community is keen to close questions that don't contain actual code, even though “software algorithm” questions are explicitly allowed by its &lt;a href=&quot;https://stackoverflow.com/faq&quot;&gt;FAQ&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;There is, at long last, a &lt;a href=&quot;http://area51.stackexchange.com/proposals/35636/computer-science-non-programming?referrer=4M74nqLafvszXN85c5ibxQ2&quot;&gt;computer science site proposal&lt;/a&gt; on &lt;a href=&quot;http://area51.stackexchange.com/&quot;&gt;Area 51&lt;/a&gt;, the staging zone for new Stack Exchange sites. Please point out that proposal to askers who might be interested in it.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="634" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-05-23T12:40:08.913" LastActivityDate="2012-01-28T17:06:24.907" CommentCount="7" />
./Posts.xml:1402:  <row Id="1481" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="1099" CreationDate="2012-01-31T20:57:56.570" Score="6" Body="&lt;p&gt;As a relatively new user, I am surprised by how quickly some questions seem to be closed. Because of that, sometimes I've been afraid of asking a question because it might not be &quot;research-ish enough&quot;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In some cases it is absolutely clear that a question is just homework, but I find it annoying that just because the question &lt;em&gt;looks like&lt;/em&gt; homework it is almost immediately downvoted and/or closed, without much insight as to &lt;em&gt;why&lt;/em&gt; it is being downvoted/closed.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;This is particularly true for an area I'm interested in --Automata Theory and Formal Languages--, because many homework questions seem to come from undergrad students taking this course (&lt;em&gt;&quot;Is $L$ context free?&quot;&lt;/em&gt;), and also because it doesn't seem to be a mainstream research area (it was 50 years ago, but not now). However, some questions are interesting enough, but are welcomed at once with the following message:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;Welcome to cstheory, a Q&amp;amp;A site for research-level questions in theoretical computer science (TCS). Your question does not appear to be a research-level question in TCS. (...)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;See, for example, &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/9969/finite-automata-that-accept-binary-strings-divisible-by-n&quot;&gt;this one&lt;/a&gt;. Another example is the question about $a^ib^jc^k$ with $i\neq j\neq k\neq i$, which ended up with a &lt;a href=&quot;http://cstheory.blogoverflow.com/2011/09/it-only-looks-like-a-homework-problem/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;blog post&lt;/a&gt; a year after it was asked.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I'm sure that much (if not all) of what I'm saying now has been said before, but I felt the need to express my opinion, because it looks like not much has changed, unless these practices were really worse ten months ago.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="5396" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.537" LastActivityDate="2012-01-31T20:57:56.570" CommentCount="2" />

./Posts.xml:1406:  <row Id="1485" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="1099" CreationDate="2012-02-02T23:26:43.110" Score="2" Body="&lt;p&gt;@Janoma,&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;The issue of down voting without commenting has been discussed extensively and the current view is that commenting is not required but encouraged.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Closing is not a big deal as is explained in the comment template says. A question can be reopened if it is deemed suitable for the site by 5 high rep members of the community. &lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;It is not easy to see whether a question is research-level or not unless the author of the question explains the motivation and background. It is normal to close a question which looks like non-research-level when there is not any motivation or when it seems that the author does not understand the elementary stuff.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;The question you have linked to is by student working on a problem set. IIRC, the question already had a -1 vote when I posted the comment. And again as the &lt;em&gt;full&lt;/em&gt; comment says:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;Welcome to cstheory, a Q&amp;amp;A site for &lt;em&gt;research-level&lt;/em&gt; questions in &lt;em&gt;theoretical computer science&lt;/em&gt; (TCS). Your question does not appear to be a research-level question in TCS. &lt;strong&gt;Please see the [FAQ] for more information on what is meant by this and suggestions for sites that might welcome your question. Finally, if your question is closed for being out of scope, and you believe you can edit the question to make it a research-level question, please feel free to do so. Closing is not permanent and questions can be reopened, check the [FAQ] for more information.&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The FAQ also contains an item &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/361#361&quot;&gt;My (wonderful!) question got closed! What do I do now?&lt;/a&gt;. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I think we have emphasized it enough that closing is not a big deal. &lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Further more, neither of the questions that you have linked to have got closed in the first place, so I am not sure if they are examples of what you are claiming. &lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;If you think there is nice question hidden inside a question, then you can make suggestions to the OP to improve the question, or ask a new question yourself.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;The opinion at the time was that we are not closing the question too quickly, there is no problem with closing clearly off-topic questions as soon as possible. If later the question is improved to an on-topic question it can be reopened. As you could see from the state of this discussion before your new answer, it was accepted that quickly closing these questions is fine so I am not sure why you expected a change regrading in closing them.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;ps: next time, please start a new discussion by posting a question in place of posting an answer to an old discussion.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="186" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.560" LastActivityDate="2012-02-02T23:26:43.110" CommentCount="7" />

./Posts.xml:1422:  <row Id="1502" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAnswerId="1503" CreationDate="2012-03-07T14:13:46.167" Score="7" ViewCount="109" Body="&lt;p&gt;Sorry if this has already been asked, I could not find an appropriate answer and  I want to make sure that I understand these features.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Question&lt;/strong&gt;: what's the most correct way to use flags and down-votes? &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Or, what makes less harm: an incorrect flag or an incorrect vote down + comment? Should I do nothing if I doubt or should I try to participate?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Explanation&lt;/strong&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I am one of those users without enough reputation to vote for closing but I can try to help the site by voting up good questions (which I try to use &lt;em&gt;much&lt;/em&gt; more often) and flagging or voting down those which I believe not to be suitable. My question is about what to do in theSo, the question is, if you doubt between what to do latter case.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;First, this what the FAQ says about flagging vs answering low-quality posts:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;Most importantly, don't feed the trolls! Replying to abusive, off-topic, or inappropriate content only encourages it – whereas flagging allows removal without providing undue attention. &#xA;  Post related to: &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/1264/conventions-on-downvoting&quot;&gt;conventions on downvoting&lt;/a&gt;.&#xA;  Which suggest that flagging is the best thing to do when you thing a post does not match the standards we expect. However, declined flags get a preventive remark:&#xA;  Flag declined - flags should only be used to make moderators aware of content that requires their intervention.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Which suggests that flagging may flood moderators. Then I thought, maybe it is better that users control content by voting up/down. But whenever you vote down you see a pop-up:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;Please consider adding a comment if you think this post can be improved.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Or in other words, try to make constructive suggestions. But then you can be &quot;feeding trolls&quot;...&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Related posts:&lt;/strong&gt; &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/1264/conventions-on-downvoting&quot;&gt;conventions on downvoting&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="7286" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" LastActivityDate="2012-03-08T10:45:12.970" Title="When should I really flag or vote down?" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;voting&gt;&lt;down-votes&gt;&lt;flagging&gt;" AnswerCount="2" CommentCount="4" />
./Posts.xml:1424:  <row Id="1504" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="1502" CreationDate="2012-03-08T02:51:30.703" Score="5" Body="&lt;p&gt;We had a discussion earlier on downvoting conventions:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/q/1264/1037&quot;&gt;Conventions on downvoting&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In particular, in that post I outline my convention for down-voting and ask if it is too harsh (since I am one of the most frequent down-voters on the site). ./Posts.xml:1440:  <row Id="1521" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2012-05-07T05:06:56.627" Score="2" ViewCount="42" Body="&lt;p&gt;I've written a script that lets you insert dollar symbols automatically(via a keyboard shortcut or button) in the editor window on Stack Exchange sites that support MathJax. You guys also get a special &lt;code&gt;NP&lt;/code&gt; button(&lt;kbd&gt;Alt&lt;/kbd&gt;-&lt;kbd&gt;S&lt;/kbd&gt;, S for sansserif) that encloses the selection in &lt;code&gt;$\mathsf{...}$&lt;/code&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Also, note that &lt;kbd&gt;Alt&lt;/kbd&gt;-&lt;kbd&gt;Z&lt;/kbd&gt; lets you exit math mode--this lets you type math smoothly. For example, you can use &lt;kbd&gt;Alt&lt;/kbd&gt;-&lt;kbd&gt;S&lt;/kbd&gt;, type PSPACE, and  then use &lt;kbd&gt;Alt&lt;/kbd&gt;-&lt;kbd&gt;Z&lt;/kbd&gt; to bring the cursor out of math mode, where you can continue typing. (It's been a big help to me on chem.SE, with the &lt;code&gt;\ce{...}&lt;/code&gt; button--I can type chemical formulae within the flow of the code).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Also, you have &lt;kbd&gt;Alt&lt;/kbd&gt;-&lt;kbd&gt;O&lt;/kbd&gt; for Big O notation, but I doubt you'll use it.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Feel free to check it out!&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://stackapps.com/questions/3373/mathjax-buttons&quot;&gt;Installation instructions and details here&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="9327" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:25:39.260" LastActivityDate="2012-05-07T05:22:28.553" Title="MathJax buttons/hotkeys script" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;math&gt;" AnswerCount="1" CommentCount="3" />

./Posts.xml:1442:  <row Id="1523" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2012-05-10T05:13:02.103" Score="4" ViewCount="79" Body="&lt;p&gt;When going through several migrations the user owning the post may loose the ownership. E.g. if user X has profiles on sites A and C but not B, and one of his posts on A is migrated to B and then to C, X looses the ownership of the post although he has a profile on C.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Here is an example: &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Post: &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/q/11392/&quot;&gt;Master Equations and Operator Sum Form&lt;/a&gt; (see &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/11392/master-equations-and-operator-sum-form/11393#11393&quot;&gt;this answer&lt;/a&gt;)&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;User: &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/users/1519/john-sidles&quot;&gt;John Sidles&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="186" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" LastActivityDate="2012-09-30T01:54:07.210" Title="migration: post ownership lost through multiple migrations" Tags="&lt;bug&gt;&lt;migration&gt;" AnswerCount="1" CommentCount="6" />

./Posts.xml:1448:  <row Id="1530" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2012-06-01T02:54:46.463" Score="5" ViewCount="121" Body="&lt;p&gt;Probably most have heard about this, but just in case someone has missed it, here is &lt;a href=&quot;https://plus.google.com/u/0/103703080789076472131/posts/DDA6tr8SDJ8&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;a short post&lt;/a&gt; and &lt;a href=&quot;http://poynder.blogspot.co.uk/2012/05/open-access-peoples-petition.html&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;a longer post&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The petition itself is &lt;a href=&quot;https://wwws.whitehouse.gov/petitions#!/petition/require-free-access-over-internet-scientific-journal-articles-arising-taxpayer-funded-research/wDX82FLQ&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;here&lt;/a&gt;. You may want to check &lt;a href=&quot;http://access2research.org/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;the Access2Research site&lt;/a&gt; and &lt;a href=&quot;http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Access2Research&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;the Wikipedia article about it&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Edit:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Here is a post on &lt;a href=&quot;http://gowers.wordpress.com/2012/05/24/have-you-signed-the-open-access-petition/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;Tim Gowers' blog&lt;/a&gt; and an article in &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.guardian.co.uk/science/blog/2012/may/22/us-petition-open-access-publishing?fb=optOut&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;The Guardian&lt;/a&gt;. You don't need to be a US citizen to sign the petition and its effects will not be restricted to the US.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;It can be considered politics but it is an issue deeply related to the community. This post was intended to spread the information so others can also have a look at the petition and sign it in case they agree with it. It is not intended for discussion, arguing, nor convincing other about it. Blog posts like Gowers' are more appropriate for discussion.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="186" LastEditorUserId="186" LastEditDate="2012-06-03T18:45:07.777" LastActivityDate="2012-06-03T18:45:07.777" Title="Petition for Open Access to Taxpayer-Funded Research" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;" AnswerCount="0" CommentCount="10" ClosedDate="2012-06-06T23:57:22.357" />
./Posts.xml:1450:  <row Id="1532" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="1395" CreationDate="2012-06-07T20:15:38.637" Score="2" Body="&lt;p&gt;So I got called out on this issue on a comment that I made &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/11666/numbers-of-ways-of-expressing-the-sum-of-a-number-between-a-b&quot;&gt;here&lt;/a&gt;. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The problem that I have with anonymous downvoting is not that it's anonymous. I don't see a reason to add a redundant comment to back up a downvote. ./Posts.xml:1451:  <row Id="1533" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2012-06-12T13:07:54.953" Score="4" ViewCount="43" Body="&lt;p&gt;I propose to rename the tag &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/dynamic&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;dynamic&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;dynamic&lt;/a&gt; (currently 8 questions) to &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/dynamic-algorithms&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;dynamic-algorithms&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;dynamic-algorithms&lt;/a&gt; (currently nonexistent), because the questions with the tag are really about dynamic algorithms, that is, algorithms about certain objects with online updates.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;(There was &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1588/variable-profit-knapsack&quot;&gt;one closed question&lt;/a&gt; where the tag &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/dynamic&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;dynamic&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;dynamic&lt;/a&gt; was used to mean dynamic programming.  I modified this tag manually.)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I cannot use the existing system for creating a tag synonym (which would automatically merge the created tag synonym to the real tag) because the tag &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/dynamic-algorithms&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;dynamic-algorithms&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;dynamic-algorithms&lt;/a&gt; does not exist at this moment.  Therefore, I would like to invoke the &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/271/official-interim-procedure-for-doing-retagging&quot;&gt;official interim procedure for doing retagging&lt;/a&gt; for this purpose.  This means:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;Score +4 or more of this meta post is interpreted as a consensus that the tag &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/dynamic&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;dynamic&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;dynamic&lt;/a&gt; should be renamed to &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/dynamic-algorithms&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;dynamic-algorithms&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;dynamic-algorithms&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I do &lt;strong&gt;not&lt;/strong&gt; think that the old tag &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/dynamic&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;dynamic&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;dynamic&lt;/a&gt; should be a tag synonym after renaming, but I do not have a strong opinion about this.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="567" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.537" LastActivityDate="2012-06-15T01:01:54.377" Title="Proposal: Rename the tag [dynamic] to [dynamic-algorithms]" Tags="&lt;support&gt;&lt;status-completed&gt;&lt;retag-request&gt;" AnswerCount="0" CommentCount="7" />

./Posts.xml:1464:  <row Id="1547" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="1546" CreationDate="2012-07-07T22:33:58.643" Score="4" Body="&lt;p&gt;First, make sure that the question is really not suitable.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If you are sure that it is not suitable, then it is better to do something about it than just leave it as it is.  There are five options: edit, delete, vote to close, flag, and leave a comment.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;Edit a question&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If you can change the question so that it is suitable, please edit it.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;But please do not edit one question to a completely unrelated question!  It is better to keep different questions separate.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;Delete a question&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;You can delete your own question if you are a registered user of the website and the question has not received an answer.  (For the precise conditions when you can and cannot delete your own post, see “When &lt;em&gt;can’t&lt;/em&gt; I delete my own post?” in &lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/5221/what-can-cause-a-post-to-be-deleted-and-what-does-that-actually-mean/5222#5222&quot;&gt;this post on Meta Stack Overflow&lt;/a&gt;).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Deleted questions do not appear in lists of questions (including your own profile page), and most non-moderator users cannot read deleted questions.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;For some reason, when you click “delete” link of your question, the system asks “Vote to delete this post?” suggesting that you are merely &lt;em&gt;voting&lt;/em&gt; to delete instead of deleting, but this is probably just a glitch in the system; if you click “Yes,” the post is deleted immediately.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;Vote to close a question&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;You can cast a close vote to your own question if your reputation points is 250 or higher.  See &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/privileges/view-close-votes&quot;&gt;this page&lt;/a&gt; for an explanation of closure (not in the mathematical sense).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;Flag a question for moderator attention&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If none of the above helps and you need a help about usage of the website from moderators, please flag your own question for moderator attention.  Please explain what help you need in the flag dialog box.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/privileges/flag-posts&quot;&gt;This page&lt;/a&gt; states that you need at least 15 reputation points to flag a post.  I do not know if this applies also to flagging your own post.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;Leave a comment&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;You can always post a comment on your question.  Even when you cannot delete, vote to close, or flag, and you cannot think of a way to edit the question so that it becomes suitable, it is probably better to leave a comment that you are aware that you posted an inappropriate question.  In addition, if you need some help about usage of the website and you cannot flag the post, posting a comment might get some user’s attention.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="567" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" LastActivityDate="2012-07-08T11:51:00.753" CommentCount="1" />

./Posts.xml:1470:  <row Id="1553" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2012-07-19T22:14:49.967" Score="3" ViewCount="102" Body="&lt;p&gt;We have two relatively popular tags &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/lg.learning&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;lg.learning&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;lg.learning&lt;/a&gt; (53 questions) and &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/machine-learning&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;machine-learning&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;machine-learning&lt;/a&gt; (75 questions). However, I am not sure where the line between the two is drawn. For lg.learning wiki we have:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;Tag &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/lg.learning&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;lg.learning&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;lg.learning&lt;/a&gt; refers to the research area of &lt;a href=&quot;http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Machine_learning&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;machine learning&lt;/a&gt;, and &lt;a href=&quot;http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computational_learning_theory&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;learning theory&lt;/a&gt; specifically (falling under &lt;a href=&quot;http://arxiv.org/archive/cs&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;arXiv&lt;/a&gt;'s &lt;a href=&quot;http://arxiv.org/list/cs.LG/recent&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;cs.LG - Learning&lt;/a&gt;), as opposed to the general practice of learning.  This tag includes the theory of PAC learning, algorithmic learning theory, and computational aspects of Bayesian inference and graphical models.  Questions about implementation issues and statistical properties of machine learning systems are more likely to be welcomed at the &lt;a href=&quot;https://stats.stackexchange.com/&quot;&gt;CrossValidated&lt;/a&gt; or &lt;a href=&quot;http://metaoptimize.com/qa/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;MetaOptimize Q&amp;amp;A&lt;/a&gt; sites.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;  &#xA;  &lt;p&gt;The questions &lt;em&gt;must&lt;/em&gt; satisfy the usual scope requirements for cstheory as explained in the &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/faq&quot;&gt;FAQ&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;And for &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/machine-learning&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;machine-learning&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;machine-learning&lt;/a&gt; we have the wiki-excerpt:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;Theoretical questions about Machine learning, especially Computational Learning Theory, including Algorithmic Learning Theory, PAC learning, and Bayesian Inference&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;and the whole wiki:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;This tag should be used for &lt;em&gt;theoretical&lt;/em&gt; questions related to Machine Learning (roughly falling under &lt;a href=&quot;http://arxiv.org/archive/cs&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;arXiv&lt;/a&gt;'s &lt;a href=&quot;http://arxiv.org/list/cs.LG/recent&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;cs.LG - Learning&lt;/a&gt;).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;  &#xA;  &lt;p&gt;The question &lt;em&gt;must&lt;/em&gt; satisfy the usual scope requirements for cstheory as explained in the &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/faq&quot;&gt;FAQ&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;  &#xA;  &lt;p&gt;You may also want to check AI Q&amp;amp;A site &lt;a href=&quot;http://metaoptimize.com/qa/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;Meta Optimize&lt;/a&gt; which has a more general AI scope.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;To me, it seems that we are using them as synonyms. Is this the case? If so, then which should be the main tag? lg.learning follows our ArXiv tag convention, but machine-learning is more popular and more likely to be searched for.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="1037" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:44:17.023" LastActivityDate="2012-07-19T22:14:49.967" Title="What is the difference between the tags lg.learning and machine-learning?" ./Posts.xml:1471:  <row Id="1554" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2012-07-20T12:08:03.590" Score="-3" ViewCount="135" Body="&lt;p&gt;I wonder who on earth would be happy to read a series of long, boilerplate comments such as:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;Welcome to cstheory, a Q&amp;amp;A site for &lt;em&gt;research-level&lt;/em&gt; questions in &lt;em&gt;theoretical computer science&lt;/em&gt; (TCS). Your question does not appear to be a research-level question in TCS. Please see the &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/faq&quot;&gt;FAQ&lt;/a&gt; for more information on what is meant by this and suggestions for sites that might welcome your question. Finally, if your question is closed for being out of scope, and you believe you can edit the question to make it a research-level question, please feel free to do so. Closing is not permanent and questions can be reopened, check the &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/faq&quot;&gt;FAQ&lt;/a&gt; for more information.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;  &#xA;  &lt;p&gt;Please add some context/background/motivation for the question if you think the question is a research-level question and in &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/&quot;&gt;Theoretical Computer Science&lt;/a&gt;'s scope. You can find tips about writing a better question in our FAQ. For general level questions please consider posting on &lt;a href=&quot;https://cs.stackexchange.com/&quot;&gt;Computer Science&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I know, these comments partly came from &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/1381/comment-templates&quot;&gt;another thread on meta&lt;/a&gt;, but this does not change the fact that they are stupidly long.  Please do not use them.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;em&gt;Added&lt;/em&gt;: It is fine to argue that in theory, it should be possible to improve the templates to make it concise and to the point.  I have seen this argument many times.  In practice, no one has ever been able to make such an edit, and I think that there is a good reason why it is impossible.  If you have time to argue the theoretical possibility, just edit the templates instead and have it done.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="567" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:48:30.257" LastActivityDate="2012-07-21T11:32:31.370" Title="Please avoid boilerplate comments" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;comments&gt;" AnswerCount="2" CommentCount="9" />
./Posts.xml:1477:  <row Id="1560" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="1558" CreationDate="2012-07-31T23:49:22.807" Score="8" Body="&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/12172/can-addition-be-carried-out-in-less-than-depth-5#comment33412_12172&quot;&gt;The comment&lt;/a&gt; you left on the question was for an &lt;em&gt;unregistered&lt;/em&gt; user. A person doesn't need to create an account to post questions/answers. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Note also that a user &lt;strong&gt;cannot&lt;/strong&gt; delete their account by themselves (if they have interacted with the site, have cast votes or have posted questions/answers). To delete a user account you have to involve an SE or a community moderator. Please see &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/help/user-deletion&quot;&gt;this&lt;/a&gt; for further information and the process through which a user can ask SE for deletion of their account. &#xA;In short, what you have described cannot happen.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I personally haven't seen any request for deletion recently (can't remember when was the last time).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Regarding asking questions anonymously, by default, asking questions or answering questions using pseudo-names or anonymously is completely fine. People have various reasons to remain anonymous or to use pseudo-names. I don't see any reason to be annoyed about this. If you don't like such users don't interact with them. Whether to remain anonymous or to reveal identity is that user choice, not yours nor ours. If there is a problem about a question posted by an anonymous user (e.g. it is a homework questions) then we can discuss that particular case separately. By itself remaining anonymous on the site is completely fine. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Please don't write comments like &quot;And we we would love to know who you are!&quot;. This is not constructive. A user doesn't need to reveal their identity to ask questions. People are welcome to post questions and answer anonymously. Also, IMO, down-voting questions just because they are posted anonymously is a very bad behavior.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="186" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" LastActivityDate="2012-08-01T00:10:42.343" CommentCount="4" />
./Posts.xml:1478:  <row Id="1561" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2012-08-03T22:25:43.777" Score="5" ViewCount="39" Body="&lt;p&gt;I feel that we should rename &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/matrix-product&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;matrix-product&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;matrix-product&lt;/a&gt; to &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/matrix-multiplication&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;matrix-multiplication&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;matrix-multiplication&lt;/a&gt; since it seems it is the more common terminology.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Any opinions?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="186" LastActivityDate="2012-08-04T05:52:10.013" Title="tags: renaming &quot;matrix-product&quot; to &quot;matrix-multiplication&quot;" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;tags&gt;" AnswerCount="1" CommentCount="0" />

./Posts.xml:1486:  <row Id="1570" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="1563" CreationDate="2012-08-09T00:42:34.507" Score="1" Body="&lt;p&gt;One issue that we should be careful and is included in the FAQ is that people should ask questions that they really care about. If you intend or are thinking about working on a related problem then the question can be fine and explaining this motivation and the kind of problems that you want to work on would make the question focused. On the other hand, an out of curiosity question is not a real question, neither questions that are intended to be discussions about a topic or solicit opinions about it.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;We have many tips in &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/300/how-to-ask-a-good-question&quot;&gt;the meta post about writing and asking better questions&lt;/a&gt; and there are a &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/faq#tips-about-writing-better-questions&quot;&gt;few more links&lt;/a&gt; to similar advice in the FAQ that you should check if you haven't. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The problem is that some users insist on ignoring these even if they are reminded several times by various people.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="186" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" LastActivityDate="2012-08-09T00:49:46.387" CommentCount="16" />
./Posts.xml:1493:  <row Id="1578" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="1534" CreationDate="2012-08-09T19:51:09.067" Score="6" Body="&lt;p&gt;Although there is no built in functionality, there is a greasemonkey script available (thanks to &lt;a href=&quot;https://cogsci.stackexchange.com/users/19/ben-brocka&quot;&gt;Ben Brocka&lt;/a&gt; for pointing it out):&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.stackexchange.com/q/3360&quot;&gt;Ignore Users Script&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;It is not encouraged that we use this script. ./Posts.xml:1495:  <row Id="1580" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2012-08-12T21:37:52.210" Score="5" ViewCount="64" Body="&lt;p&gt;Is there a need for a &lt;em&gt;How-To Use&lt;/em&gt; or &lt;em&gt;Tips &amp;amp; Tricks&lt;/em&gt; page? If so, what would be on it?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;(Tips and tricks include searching, urlencoding, markdown, how to see mathjax input, special question urls, site bugs and features.)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Motivation:&lt;/strong&gt; As you may be aware &lt;a href=&quot;https://mathoverflow.net/&quot;&gt;MathOverflow&lt;/a&gt; will soon be &lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.mathoverflow.net/discussion/1416/mathoverflow-20/&quot;&gt;part of the stackexchange network&lt;/a&gt;! One of the things we are thinking about right now is how to transfer all of MathOverflow's add-ons and tweaks to the new platform. We are quite fortunate that many of our little tweaks have already been implemented because sites like this one needed them. Of the leftover features, we have a &lt;a href=&quot;https://mathoverflow.net/tips&quot;&gt;Tips and Tricks&lt;/a&gt; page and the discreet tips box linking to it from our front page. There doesn't seem to be an equivalent here. (Let me know if I somehow missed it!) I'm wondering if that's because there is no need at all, if it's functionality is already available in another way (there are plenty of tip boxes here and there), or if it would actually be a helpful addition?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Just to be clear:&lt;/strong&gt; I am asking about the need for such a page here on CSTheory, not about the need on MathOverflow. Please stay on topic! (There is &lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.mathoverflow.net/&quot;&gt;another place&lt;/a&gt; to discuss MathOverflow issues.)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="341" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:57:54.527" LastActivityDate="2012-08-13T06:11:36.560" Title="How-To Use/Tips &amp; Tricks" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;feature-request&gt;" AnswerCount="0" CommentCount="13" />
./Posts.xml:1496:  <row Id="1581" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="1572" CreationDate="2012-08-12T23:30:32.150" Score="3" Body="&lt;p&gt;&lt;em&gt;Disclaimer: I am a moderator on &lt;a href=&quot;https://cs.stackexchange.com/&quot;&gt;Computer Science Stack Exchange&lt;/a&gt;. While I try to judge this proposal on its own merit, it is likely that the time and energy I have invested in CS.SE influences me.&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I'm afraid that broadening the scope in this way would destroy the existing community. A Stack Exchange site is defined by two things: the kind of questions it accepts, and the audience it attracts. Even though each question is in principle judged on its intrinsic merits, the long-term effect is to create a community.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;On this site, the community is centered around researchers in theoretical computer science. Participants tend to be researchers in TCS, researchers in other fields, or graduate students aspiring to become researchers. The participants who are welcomed are generally those who came with the expectation of participating in a community dominated by TCS researchers.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I do not see a problem with allowing more applied questions. As long as academics and people who want to fit in with academics dominate the site, that isn't a problem. It may be difficult to bootstrap an applied CS community (it would have been a lot easier to do when the site was young), but if it works, it won't change the tone of the site, and if it fails, the site won't have changed.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;On the other hand, opening the door to more basic questions means opening the door to a broader audience. This should be a carefully controlled process. In particular, I advise you not to try to draw on Stack Overflow as an audience base. A majority of Stack Overflow does not know or care what it means to be a scientist. The kind of people you would attract are those who now post on &lt;a href=&quot;https://softwareengineering.stackexchange.com/&quot;&gt;Programmers&lt;/a&gt;. If you attract those people, be prepared to moderate their content. And to moderate them.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Reacting to specific points in your proposal:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;We now have a natural forum (cs.stackexchange.com) for the more &quot;basic&quot; algorithms questions, and the cstheory &quot;brand&quot; is well established as a 'research-only' venue. So we have an easy process to shunt questions that are obviously undergrad level.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Keep in mind that CS.SE is not exclusively for basic questions. It is for questions at all level, ranging all the way from CS 101 homework to applied research (and even research in theory, but we suggest CSTheory.SE to the rare asker who comes with a theory question that seems to go unanswered because it is too hard).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;excluding questions from people who might be 'research-level' in a sub area but aren't experts in some other domain&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;From what I see (I admit to not following CSTheory.SE very closely), this already happens: as long as there's a feeling that peers are talking with peers, questions tend to be appreciated, left open and answered.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;creating the impression of an unfriendly site (which is a bigger problem in terms of maintaining the audience)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I think the community is doing an adequate job of retaining the audience it likes in and keeping the undesirables in.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;All in all, while the current guidelines may be stricter than this, I think an intelligent application of the existing policies already gives you what you want.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="634" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:48:30.257" LastActivityDate="2012-08-12T23:30:32.150" CommentCount="1" />
./Posts.xml:1501:  <row Id="1586" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2012-08-15T19:46:59.693" Score="0" ViewCount="34" Body="&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Possible Duplicate:&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br&gt;&#xA;  &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/52/reversing-a-vote-to-close&quot;&gt;Reversing a vote to close&lt;/a&gt;  &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I was recently browsing the questions and by accident (I thought I was in a different tab) voted to close a question off-topic:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/q/12319/1037&quot;&gt;Can quantum algorithms with exponential speed-up be rederived using span-programs?&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In no way do I think this question is off-topic (and hopefully 4 others won't also accidentally vote), but I can't find a way to withdraw my close vote. Is there a mechanism in place to do so? I imagine accidental votes like mine don't happen often (since it requires 3 button clicks; and only the completely absent minded people like me would get confused by that), but questions do get edited for the better, potentially nullifying an early close-vote.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;How can I withdraw my close vote?&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="1037" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.537" LastActivityDate="2012-08-15T19:46:59.693" Title="How to withdraw close votes?" ./Posts.xml:1502:  <row Id="1587" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="52" CreationDate="2012-08-15T23:22:09.910" Score="4" Body="&lt;p&gt;(You already know the answer, but let me post it as an answer.)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Unfortunately, we cannot cancel close votes at our own will.  See the &lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/915/can-we-have-the-ability-to-rescind-a-close-vote-before-it-closes&quot;&gt;feature request&lt;/a&gt; on Meta Stack Overflow and the &lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/915/can-we-have-the-ability-to-rescind-a-close-vote-before-it-closes/33949#33949&quot;&gt;answer from Jeff Atwood&lt;/a&gt;, one of the administrators of the Stack Exchange network.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;This may not be actually as bad as it sounds, because close votes expire after some amount of time.  See &lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/97556/close-votes-expire-too-soon-for-low-traffic-tags/97581#97581&quot;&gt;this post&lt;/a&gt; for detail.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="567" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-20T10:29:37.593" LastActivityDate="2012-08-16T14:48:37.177" CommentCount="0" />
./Posts.xml:1503:  <row Id="1588" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAnswerId="1590" CreationDate="2012-08-16T09:08:55.527" Score="2" ViewCount="80" Body="&lt;p&gt;If you come across a question which has been answered correctly, but in a fashion that would require effectively a total rewrite to make it (in your opinion) understandable for the question-asker and who ever comes across the answer later, is it better to edit the answer (even though it's essentially a rewrite), or to post a new answer, with a clear statement of credit?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;As this is meant to be a research level Q &amp;amp; A, I assume that we can expect the reader to do a bit of work, but there's also a point where an answer is opaque thanks to the style of the writer (as opposed to because the question is difficult). The situation may also be complicated by the answer being original research (though only a small chunk of course).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I guess an alternative formulation is whether it's more valued (in the context of the site) to recognise primacy or clarity (on the assumption that reputation will be siphoned one way or the other)? &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;This is kind of similar to &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/338/policy-on-editing-answers&quot;&gt;this question&lt;/a&gt;, but beyond the point where a few suggestions would improve the answer, it really needs a total rewrite.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="9520" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" LastActivityDate="2012-08-18T22:10:44.497" Title="Editing versus rewriting other people's answers" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;reputation&gt;&lt;answers&gt;&lt;editing&gt;" AnswerCount="1" CommentCount="7" />
./Posts.xml:1507:  <row Id="1592" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAnswerId="1594" CreationDate="2012-09-12T18:46:53.173" Score="4" ViewCount="162" Body="&lt;p&gt;I've posted my first question:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/12585/to-what-extent-can-an-algorithm-predict-the-time-complexity-an-arbitrary-input-p#12585&quot;&gt;To what extent can an algorithm predict the time complexity an arbitrary input program?&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Which admittedly is not a graduate-level question, and thus not covered under the scope of this site. It has been suggested that this particular question can be sent to both &lt;a href=&quot;https://softwareengineering.stackexchange.com/&quot;&gt;SE Programmers&lt;/a&gt; and &lt;a href=&quot;https://cs.stackexchange.com/&quot;&gt;SE CS&lt;/a&gt;, so there are four candidate sites.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I ask because the scope of each site FAQ overlaps quite a bit and I feel that, for a question like this, it can fit into several categories. ./Posts.xml:1511:  <row Id="1596" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2012-09-13T01:33:10.883" Score="12" ViewCount="353" Body="&lt;p&gt;Some of the comments on &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/12558/a-notion-of-monotone-quantum-circuits#question&quot;&gt;Gil's recent question&lt;/a&gt; are flagged as not-constructive.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;They are not literally offensive or rude, they are not irrelevant to the question, but honestly they don't seem to contain anything that anyone who is a little bit familiar with the topics would not know (and surely Gil is more that a little bit familiar with these topics). In other words, anyone could have written a similar comment. They don't add any new information/knowledge.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The reasons for flagging a comment supported by the software are:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;rude or offensive&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;not constructive / off-topic&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;obsolete&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;too chatty&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I am not sure if any of them applies to these comments (maybe &quot;too chatty&quot;?). On the other hand I personally feel that leaving such comments are inappropriate and possibly harmful to the usefulness of the site (as I understand, people don't come here to read general comments that anyone would know or could find out by a simple Google search but to ask question from people who have expertise on those topics).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;On cstheory, we generally don't remove comments as long as they are not really off-topic or clearly rude.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Is leaving general comments that do not add any significant information to the question OK?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Questions that are answerable by simple Googling or looking at the relevant Wikipedia article are considered off-topic on cstheory. Should these criteria also apply to other posts on the site like comments?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="186" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" LastActivityDate="2012-09-16T08:30:47.537" Title="What to do about general comments by non-experts which do not add any new information/knowedgle?" ./Posts.xml:1518:  <row Id="1603" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2012-10-20T19:21:29.277" Score="8" ViewCount="266" Body="&lt;p&gt;In order to limit the number of &quot;non research level&quot; questions asked on cstheory (that cause annoying downvotes/see-the-FAQ comments/migration/closing), I think that a good idea would be to add a short but visible subtitle under the &quot;Theoretical Computer Science&quot; to underline the scope of the site, something like:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&quot;CSTheory site is for &lt;strong&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/faq#questions&quot;&gt;research level questions&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/strong&gt; in theoretical computer science, see &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/faq&quot;&gt;FAQ&lt;/a&gt; for more details. ./Posts.xml:1519:  <row Id="1604" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="1603" CreationDate="2012-10-20T20:28:14.560" Score="6" Body="&lt;p&gt;Although I am guilty of using the phrase “research-level questions” again and again, it is not at all clear whether “research-level” really describes the current scope or the desirable scope correctly.  &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/1066/we-should-stop-claiming-that-this-website-is-research-level#comment3475_1115&quot;&gt;I once suggested “research-oriented”&lt;/a&gt; as a more honest description of the current criteria, but this term has not been used often.  There are too many discussions about the appropriate level of questions; see &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/1572/on-modifying-our-scope-a-proposal&quot;&gt;this&lt;/a&gt; for example.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I think that it would be ideal to settle the issue on the scope first and then state this scope clearly in the website.
