./Posts.xml:1523:  <row Id="1608" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="1605" CreationDate="2012-11-08T22:38:57.287" Score="4" Body="&lt;p&gt;As Suresh explained, it means that a user who had voted up your posts had his/her account deleted, and therefore his/her votes were automatically cancelled.  See &lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/126470/what-does-user-was-removed-mean-and-why-did-my-reputation-change-because-of-it/126471#126471&quot;&gt;this post on Meta Stack Overflow&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I think that the message is confusing, and &lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/130122/more-descriptive-user-was-removed-explanation&quot;&gt;some people have the same opinion&lt;/a&gt;.  Moreover, some people think that &lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/125740/dont-throw-away-all-votes-when-a-user-is-deleted&quot;&gt;the system should not cancel votes just because the voter had his/her account deleted&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="567" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-20T10:29:37.593" LastActivityDate="2012-11-08T22:38:57.287" CommentCount="1" />
./Posts.xml:1525:  <row Id="1610" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="1609" CreationDate="2012-11-17T16:15:35.890" Score="0" Body="&lt;p&gt;will take a stab at answering this based on comments &amp;amp; culture here &amp;amp; sketch something out that can be used as a point for further discussion because its a direction/approach Ive been thinking about &amp;amp; looking into &amp;amp; even veering towards myself &amp;amp; its key to this group. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;this question is probably a little too hypothetical. in principle you could build a paper by stringing together some stackexchange answers but it would be unusual. as mod kaveh writes, each question must stand on its own separate merit and also note, few people regularly post questions here or with high frequency esp those with high rep, and there is some possibility that frequent questions are actually informally frowned on via the voting mechanisms &amp;amp; current collective voting tendencies. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;the pattern is more in general that high rep users answer random newcomer questions. also, it is unlikely that you would get solid answers to all the separate (presumably nontrivial) questions.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;basically yes, that is part of the &lt;em&gt;raison d'etre&lt;/em&gt; of the group, to occasionally collaboratively generate scientific research to theoretical computer science in general &amp;amp; complexity theory in particular (complexity theory entries even were once highlighted here in css formatting). however the conventions around this are new &amp;amp; still being established as we speak.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;1st, use the stackexchange search engine highly extensively and also the tag system, both can be very effective. find every relevant post to your paper or subject. figure out the best knowledge that is posted on the group. figure out the border between the known and unknown and what is posted vs not posted. this also requires close familiarity with nearby papers. it helps to bookmark or &quot;favorite&quot; all related posts on here &amp;amp; elsewhere. use the related posts column on the right also. mix this with heavy cross use of google. in some cases you may find an expert on here posting on the subj. you can look at their own answers &amp;amp; look at their papers.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;next, try posting a single carefully crafted question totally centered on your subject and your paper and what you're thinking of establishing. its a delicate mix between the general (background) and the specific (the new result/concept you're aiming for). as if you have a single chance to ask the experts what you'd most want to know but what you also most think they'd be able to answer. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;responses will help you figure out what is known by the crowd but also how relevant it is to this group based on reaction in form of comments, enthusiasm, voting, etc. it has to be at a &quot;just right difficulty&quot; between too easy [not research] and too hard [you wont get replies/answers]. it takes some time to find that balance &amp;amp; its an ongoing challenge. dont assume that if there is a good answer, someone will post it. dont assume that if people post answers, those are the best possible. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;you will prob find if you are very focused that there are two gaps. one is the gap between what you want to establish in your paper and what is established in related literature. the other gap is what you can actually find out by using this group (both by searching it and posting questions). these two gaps are interrelated. you can judge whether you can build on all this with meaningful new results. but those key results will basically have to be generated by you, nobody else, unless you have found &lt;em&gt;offline&lt;/em&gt; collaborators in your own professional circles. you can use other results as a &quot;jumping off&quot; point.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;so finally, leverage everything youve found and write a paper. if the answers on stackexchange are very notable and innovative, you can cite them in your paper using the stackexchange urls/&quot;cite&quot; feature. this is really not much different than citing blogs, which is occasionally done in real scientific papers. however note that this is somewhat problematic because content on here can disappear very easily due to voting, moderators, users [who can delete stuff] etc...&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;probably the best and most successful model of all this invented so far is polymath[3] with a difficult problem and published arxiv paper to its credit but keep in mind this is a project started by a field medalist Gowers and promoted by his friends eg Tao and Kalai who are also very elite/accomplished theorists.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;[1] &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/352/how-will-you-cite-a-discussion-on-this-site-in-your-paper&quot;&gt;How will you cite a discussion on this site in your paper?&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;[2] &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/188/how-can-we-collaboratively-investigate-open-problems?rq=1&quot;&gt;How can we collaboratively investigate open problems?&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;[3] &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.siam.org/news/news.php?id=1731&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;Massively collaborative mathematics/Polymath&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;[4] &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/383/highlights-of-cstheory-stackexchange-com&quot;&gt;Highlights of cstheory.stackexchange.com&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;[5] &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/697/what-interesting-open-problems-have-been-asked-on-this-stackexchange&quot;&gt;What interesting open problems have been asked on this stackexchange?&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;[6] &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/1316/attacking-open-questions&quot;&gt;Attacking Open Questions&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;[7] &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/1257/references-to-cstheory-in-the-literature&quot;&gt;References to cstheory in the literature&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;[8] &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/784/original-proofs-generated-on-the-parent-site&quot;&gt;Original proofs generated on the parent site&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;[9] &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.cs.utah.edu/~suresh/cstheory.pdf&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;Questions answered. in theory.&lt;/a&gt;&#xA;(early tcs.se ad &amp;amp; highlights reel for the beta period by mod Suresh)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;[10] &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/300/how-to-ask-a-good-question&quot;&gt;How to ask a good question&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="7884" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.560" LastActivityDate="2012-11-17T16:37:18.973" CommentCount="0" />
./Posts.xml:1526:  <row Id="1613" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2012-11-24T18:44:27.387" Score="12" ViewCount="77" Body="&lt;p&gt;Is it possible to have the subdomain: tcs.stackexchange.com route to this forum? Currently it is not occupied (refer image) and, personally, I find it more intuitive than cstheory.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;https://i.stack.imgur.com/A7wxl.png&quot; alt=&quot;enter image description here&quot;&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="3862" LastEditorUserId="3862" LastEditDate="2012-11-25T05:29:08.703" LastActivityDate="2012-11-25T05:29:08.703" Title="Adding tcs subdomain as alias" Tags="&lt;feature-request&gt;" AnswerCount="0" CommentCount="0" />
./Posts.xml:1527:  <row Id="1614" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2012-11-26T07:20:31.157" Score="2" ViewCount="84" Body="&lt;p&gt;I &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/14319/natural-clique-to-k-color-reduction&quot;&gt;asked a question&lt;/a&gt; which was somewhat popular and after some time got a very nice answer. I accepted the answer and made an edit with a &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/review/suggested-edits/2603&quot;&gt;fairly minor correction&lt;/a&gt; to the answer. My edit was rejected, and it's not clear to me why (the message is &quot;changes too much in the original post,&quot; but it simply corrects half of a sentence). While I would welcome specifics about my edit, I don't care too much about the particular fix and I do not want to make a big deal about it.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I'm mostly wondering for the larger picture if there is a good way to avoid this situation recurring. Some possibilities:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Longer or more detailed and specific messages for rejected edits. The message I got looks like it was from a drop-down, and so maybe the reason did not fit nicely into a category.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Some system for moderators to defer to the opinion of the original author of the content that was edited, because he may be able to judge the edit more easily (being more familiar with what he wrote)&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Some form of edits that are &quot;unapproved&quot; but optionally visible to users (e.g. a comment shows up below the post with my name that says &quot;this is my revised version of what I think the above should say, but [moderator] believes it might change the author's intent&quot;).&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I realize that not many edits are rejected though, so perhaps I'm in the minority here, and focus on this issue would be misplaced. I'm also not sure of the technical feasibility of any of these suggestions, and perhaps that rules some or all of them out.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Edit:&lt;/strong&gt; In a discussion on the linked post I got some more details about the specifics of why my edit might not be preferred. Based on that it seems more likely that the problem is to do with feedback accompanying a rejected edit rather than the actual decision of whether to accept/reject (and so the first bullet would likely be the most appropriate fix).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Also, as one who hasn't edited or reviewed an edit I do not have a good feel for the bounds on the scope of edits; perhaps all other edits here have just been re-taggings and math-modes, and mine should have been a comment instead. Is this scope discussed somewhere? If not, should it be? Maybe that's the fix.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="12483" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" LastActivityDate="2012-11-26T15:24:36.560" Title="Not sure why my edit was rejected; maybe moderators should be able to defer to the author of the work being edited" Tags="&lt;feature-request&gt;&lt;editing&gt;" AnswerCount="1" CommentCount="0" />
./Posts.xml:1529:  <row Id="1616" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2012-12-02T08:35:21.047" Score="6" ViewCount="39" Body="&lt;p&gt;For every question and answer, share-&gt;cite results in a suggested BibTeX citation.  Now that people are actually &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/a/14547&quot;&gt;starting to cite the site&lt;/a&gt;, I think we need to revise the template so it is more useful.  This would also help nudge the diversity of possible ways to cite the site into fewer likely channels.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;First, the existing text &quot;Theoretical Computer Science&quot; is not useful, since the maximum likelihood match for that phrase is the long-established Elsevier journal of that name.  &quot;Theoretical Computer Science Stack Exchange&quot; seems a better phrase.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Second, it seems important to indicate whether the citation is to the question itself, or to a specific answer, in the text itself and not just the URL.  The title that the citation template generates is the title of the question, and I suggest something like &quot;Response to: &quot; as a prefix for answers, or a suffix of the form &quot; (response)&quot;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Finally, I would like to be able to cite specific comments, and # link to the comment.  However, SE seems to deliberately downplay comments, unlike MO, so I am not holding my breath.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="109" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" LastActivityDate="2012-12-02T10:22:41.990" Title="Changing citation template" Tags="&lt;feature-request&gt;" AnswerCount="1" CommentCount="2" />
./Posts.xml:1531:  <row Id="1618" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2012-12-07T23:29:29.743" Score="7" ViewCount="215" Body="&lt;p&gt;This is more an announcement than a question. ./Posts.xml:1532:  <row Id="1619" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2012-12-10T14:51:54.630" Score="8" ViewCount="250" Body="&lt;p&gt;As it is December 2012, we are now going to reset our Community Promotion Ads for the new year.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;What are Community Promotion Ads?&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Community Promotion Ads are community-vetted advertisements that will show up on the main site, in the right sidebar. The purpose of this question is the vetting process. Images of the advertisements are provided, and community voting will enable the advertisements to be shown.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;Why do we have Community Promotion Ads?&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;This is a method for the community to control what gets promoted to visitors on the site. For example, you might promote the following things:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;cool site-related open source apps&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;the site's twitter account&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;script packs or power tools&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;cool events or conferences&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;anything else your community would genuinely be interested in&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The goal is for future visitors to find out about &lt;em&gt;the stuff your community deems important&lt;/em&gt;. This also serves as a way to promote information and resources that are &lt;em&gt;relevant to your own community's interests&lt;/em&gt;, both for those already in the community and those yet to join. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;Why do we reset the ads every year?&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Some services will maintain usefulness over the years, while other things will wane to allow for new faces to show up. Resetting the ads every year helps accommodate this, and allows old ads that have served their purpose to be cycled out for fresher ads for newer things. This helps keep the material in the ads relevant to not just the subject matter of the community, but to the current status of the community. We reset the ads once a year, every December.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The community promotion ads have no restrictions against reposting an ad from a previous cycle. If a particular service or ad is very valuable to the community and will continue to be so, it is a good idea to repost it. It may be helpful to give it a new face in the process, so as to prevent the imagery of the ad from getting stale after a year of exposure.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;How does it work?&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The answers you post to this question &lt;em&gt;must&lt;/em&gt; conform to the following rules, or they will be ignored. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;All answers should be in the exact form of:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;pre&gt;&lt;code&gt;[![Tagline to show on mouseover][1]][2]&#xA;&#xA;   [1]: http://image-url&#xA;   [2]: http://clickthrough-url &#xA;&lt;/code&gt;&lt;/pre&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Please &lt;strong&gt;do not add anything else to the body of the post&lt;/strong&gt;. If you want to discuss something, do it in the comments.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;The question must always be tagged with the magic &lt;a href=&quot;/questions/tagged/community-ads&quot; class=&quot;post-tag moderator-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;community-ads&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;community-ads&lt;/a&gt; tag. In addition to enabling the functionality of the advertisements, this tag also pre-fills the answer form with the above required form.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;Image requirements&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;The image that you create must be &lt;strong&gt;220 x 250 pixels&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Must be hosted through our standard image uploader (imgur)&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Must be GIF or PNG&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;No animated GIFs&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Absolute limit on file size of 150 KB&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;Score Threshold&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;There is a &lt;strong&gt;minimum score threshold&lt;/strong&gt; an answer must meet (currently &lt;strong&gt;6&lt;/strong&gt;) before it will be shown on the main site.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;You can check out the ads that have met the threshold with basic click stats &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/ads/display/1619&quot;&gt;here&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="6115" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" LastActivityDate="2013-10-05T03:03:38.283" Title="Community Promotion Ads - 2013" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;community-ads&gt;" AnswerCount="5" CommentCount="2" FavoriteCount="2" ClosedDate="2013-12-06T10:21:45.410" CommunityOwnedDate="2012-12-10T14:51:54.630" />
./Posts.xml:1533:  <row Id="1620" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="1619" CreationDate="2012-12-10T14:52:37.953" Score="4" Body="&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://twitter.com/StackCSTheory&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;https://i.stack.imgur.com/av260.png&quot; alt=&quot;Tagline to show on mouseover&quot;&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="6115" LastActivityDate="2012-12-10T14:52:37.953" CommentCount="2" CommunityOwnedDate="2012-12-10T14:52:37.953" />

./Posts.xml:1541:  <row Id="1628" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="1623" CreationDate="2012-12-26T02:20:14.927" Score="3" Body="&lt;p&gt;It seems to be that posting your request on on &lt;a href=&quot;https://plus.google.com/u/0/communities/102658328974323340942&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;CS Theory Google+ community&lt;/a&gt; would be quite appropriate, and you might find reviewers that way.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="123" LastActivityDate="2012-12-26T02:20:14.927" CommentCount="0" />
./Posts.xml:1542:  <row Id="1629" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="1625" CreationDate="2012-12-26T04:21:25.420" Score="15" Body="&lt;p&gt;I did notice it. The question has given a huge spike in the number of visits to csthoery for one day.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I believe the explanation is simple: someone shared &lt;a href=&quot;http://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=4961357&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;a link to the question&lt;/a&gt; on a popular site (&lt;a href=&quot;http://news.ycombinator.com/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;Hacker News&lt;/a&gt; in this case) which caused a huge temporary spike in the number of visitors. It seems that the question is interesting for general CS audience who may not be researchers in TCS. We have had a number of &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/badges/37/famous-question&quot;&gt;famous questions&lt;/a&gt; with relatively huge number of viewers, this one is not that different.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I don't think it is that useful regarding marketing the site to our target community though. However it is a nice example of a question that can be used for outreach to people outside theory. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Note that regular users from other SE sites get enough reputation to vote on the question, so the total number of votes does not necessarily reflect the quality of the question relative to other questions according to regular cstheory users. (This is one of the issues that I think MO negotiated with SE when they decided to migrate to SE2.0 to make sure it won't happen on MO after it migrates to SE2.0).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;This happens also on other SE sites like Math.SE, e.g. &lt;a href=&quot;https://math.stackexchange.com/questions/54506/is-this-batman-equation-for-real&quot;&gt;the batman equation question&lt;/a&gt;. It will happen from time to time, I don't think it is not a big deal as long as it is not causing a problem. If we see that the question starts to cause problem we can make it protected or even lock it (as is common practice on other SE sites).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="186" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.537" LastActivityDate="2012-12-26T04:44:25.090" CommentCount="3" />
./Posts.xml:1552:  <row Id="1639" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2013-01-14T06:43:01.163" Score="3" ViewCount="167" Body="&lt;p&gt;I was quite happy to see the question &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/15061/pointers-for-cs-applications-of-logic&quot;&gt;Pointers for CS applications of logic&lt;/a&gt;. Scott Aaronson in his blog sometimes uses the scenario of super-intelligent alien beings having a discussion with us to emphasise the universality of certain notions in mathematics or computer science. This post felt like a very scaled-down but realistic form of that thought experiment. A person from a different, but closely related field comes to us and says, &quot;we do logic, you do logic, and we have all these cool results, but what do you have to show for your logic.&quot;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;It is difficult to tell from the wording how deep the author's knowledge of classical mathematical logic is, but the question does request for answers that appeal to advanced logical concepts. I was absolutely gung-ho about writing an answer because questions that specifically want and advanced-level survey are rare. A couple of hours later, I realised that this was never going to end. I'm glad to see that the question has now been made community wiki. I think my current answer is too long and should be split into different answers. I have three concrete proposals for answers to that question. Please let me know if you agree with these proposals.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;em&gt;Proposal 1&lt;/em&gt;. Every answer discusses a specific sub-area of computational logic and consists of three paragraphs. The first paragraph give a high-level overview of the field aimed at researchers in mathematics or TCS. The second paragraph highlights some results in the field and techniques used to prove those results. The third paragraph mentions current directions and open problems.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;em&gt;Proposal 2&lt;/em&gt;. We make a &quot;table of contents&quot; answer that lists different sub-areas of computational logic and hyperlinks to the different answers. Anyone can add to this list, and then add a separate answer for the area mentioned.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;em&gt;Proposal 3.&lt;/em&gt; If the OP agrees, we modify the original question a bit to make explicit the structure desired for answers. (We could also do this in the ToC answer I suggest in Proposal 2, but people might not read other answers before replying.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I feel such an advanced research summary would be a valuable resource for the future reference, and that obtaining such a survey via our user base would be effective. If it works here, we could also follow a similar protocol/structure for certain other broad reference requests. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;What say ye?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="4155" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" LastActivityDate="2013-01-14T07:01:27.920" Title="Help answering the &quot;CS applications of logic&quot; question" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;" AnswerCount="0" CommentCount="2" />
./Posts.xml:1553:  <row Id="2639" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="1619" CreationDate="2013-01-16T12:47:51.377" Score="5" Body="&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://academia.stackexchange.com&quot;&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;https://i.stack.imgur.com/QlIlq.png&quot; alt=&quot;Academia Stack Exchange&quot;&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="8030" LastActivityDate="2013-01-16T12:47:51.377" CommentCount="5" CommunityOwnedDate="2013-01-16T12:47:51.377" />
./Posts.xml:1559:  <row Id="2645" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="1619" CreationDate="2013-02-08T00:56:59.637" Score="7" Body="&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://www.writelatex.com&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;https://i.stack.imgur.com/kCClB.png&quot; alt=&quot;writeLaTeX - Real Time Collaborative Mathematical Programming in your Browser&quot;&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="13656" LastActivityDate="2013-02-08T00:56:59.637" CommentCount="4" CommunityOwnedDate="2013-02-08T00:56:59.637" />
./Posts.xml:1560:  <row Id="2646" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2013-02-10T02:15:05.387" Score="5" ViewCount="64" Body="&lt;p&gt;Below I am mainly talking about the recent question “&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/16419/counting-number-of-increasing-subsequences-of-length-k&quot;&gt;Counting number of increasing subsequences of length k&lt;/a&gt;” by orryowr, but I want answers which are not specific to this question.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Suppose that a user wants to ask a question, and he/she finds out that the question has been already asked and answered.  However, the answers posted there are not satisfactory because they are unclear or they are not answers to the exact question being asked.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Is there a good way to to ask for a clearer or better answer to an old question?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The following are some ways, but they have their own disadvantages.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;One thing he/she can do is to post a question nevertheless, probably stating why the existing answers are not satisfactory.  However, from answerer’s viewpoint, I think that it is better to post a new answer to the &lt;em&gt;old&lt;/em&gt; question or edit an answer to the old question rather than posting an answer to the new question, because it is the same question and it is just a better answer.  Therefore, I think that in this situation, the new question should be closed as a duplicate for the old question.  Now from asker’s viewpoint, it is awkward (or possibly even abusive) to post a question knowing that it will be closed as a duplicate of the old question.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Another thing is to write a comment to the old question or its answer.  But if the user is new, he/she cannot post a comment.  In addition, if the user who made that post is no longer active, chances that anyone notices the comment are slim.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Another thing is to edit something in the old question or propose an edit.  If the user has enough rep points, he/she can edit a post.  Add a tag or correct a typo or make some other harmless edit, and the question is bumped on the top page and it receives some attention.  Proposing an edit has one obstacle, but if the proposed edit is accepted, it has the same effect.  But either way, this sounds like an abusive or spam-like activity to me.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Another thing is to bring this up in chat room.  Problems are that it is usually not active, and that if the user is new, he/she cannot post a message in chat.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Another thing is bounty, but this requires some rep points.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="567" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" LastActivityDate="2013-02-11T04:39:43.540" Title="How to ask for a clearer answer to an old question" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;asking-questions&gt;&lt;exact-duplicates&gt;" AnswerCount="1" CommentCount="3" />
./Posts.xml:1563:  <row Id="2650" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="2647" CreationDate="2013-02-12T15:18:57.970" Score="6" Body="&lt;p&gt;Theoretical computer science is the study of the mathematical nature of computation.  See &lt;a href=&quot;http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Theoretical_computer_science&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;Wikipedia&lt;/a&gt; and the references therein.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;As Dave Clarke pointed out in a comment, the scope of cstheory.stackexchange.com is explained in &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/faq&quot;&gt;FAQ&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="567" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" LastActivityDate="2013-02-12T15:18:57.970" CommentCount="0" />
./Posts.xml:1564:  <row Id="2651" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2013-02-12T17:51:40.460" Score="2" ViewCount="28" Body="&lt;p&gt;I was marking &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/q/16432/1542&quot;&gt;a question&lt;/a&gt; as off-topic and the modal made me choose only between these two options:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;em&gt;belongs to meta.cstheory.stackexchange.com&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;em&gt;belongs to stackoverflow.com&lt;/em&gt; &lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Is that list automatically generated or we have control over it? In case we do, it would be helpful to add also &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;em&gt;belongs to cs.stackexchange.com&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;This is something that we would want every time the question is not a research question. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="1542" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" LastActivityDate="2013-02-12T17:51:40.460" Title="Can we control flag settings?" ./Posts.xml:1565:  <row Id="2652" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2013-02-14T09:02:20.367" Score="2" ViewCount="59" Body="&lt;p&gt;When I tried to migrate the following question to CS.SE the question got closed as off-topic, got locked by community, but was not migrated.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/16462/so-is-a-relational-database-just-a-1-dimensional-array&quot;&gt;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/16462/so-is-a-relational-database-just-a-1-dimensional-array&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;It seems that this situation occurred also when Suresh tried to migrate another question.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="186" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" LastActivityDate="2013-02-14T22:10:08.307" Title="migration problem" Tags="&lt;bug&gt;&lt;status-completed&gt;&lt;migration&gt;&lt;moderators&gt;" AnswerCount="0" CommentCount="3" />
./Posts.xml:1566:  <row Id="2653" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAnswerId="2655" CreationDate="2013-02-17T07:24:10.467" Score="5" ViewCount="386" Body="&lt;p&gt;This is request for comment from the community regarding the following question:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/q/16500/&quot;&gt;in SAT resolution proofs, are all DAGs possible?&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Is the question in its current form suitable for the site?&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;If it is not, was closing it by a community moderator justified? Or was it  excessive use of moderator powers?&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;If the question is not suitable in its current form and moderator action was excessive, how should we deal with it?&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="186" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" LastActivityDate="2013-02-18T05:06:46.660" Title="Should the question about structure of resolution proofs be closed?" ./Posts.xml:1568:  <row Id="2655" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="2653" CreationDate="2013-02-17T22:29:44.700" Score="11" Body="&lt;p&gt;My view is simply this: moderator powers should be used lightly, and only when the community mechanisms are insufficient to correct a situation. In the case of the above question, here's what my personal (i.e non-moderator) take is:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;the question rambles terribly and doesn't really get to the point&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;the poster has a habit of writing questions and answers like this, and frequently gets downvoted/otherwise censured for such postings&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;But in this case, another user has suggested a concrete improvement that can be made, and there are a number of upvotes (and faves) for the question. &lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;So the moderator role here is to help suggest modifications (especially since there appears to be a germ of substance in the question) and encourage the OP to make the changes (which I will note the OP has &lt;strong&gt;not&lt;/strong&gt; done). As an individual, the moderator is free to downvote the post in its current form. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;But as a community moderator, I prefer to do nothing rather than do something, and in this case I have to ask what the consequences are of doing nothing. Either the OP will fix the post or not. If not, it's quite likely that other members of the community will downvote the post and/or vote to close it. Or they might attempt to answer the question. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The &quot;worst case scenario&quot; from my point of view might be that an ill-formed question sticks around for a while. But what is the downside of this ? The OP regularly posts ill-formed questions, and they get hammered (&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/users/7884/vzn?tab=questions&amp;amp;sort=votes&quot;&gt;about 2/3 of the questions posted&lt;/a&gt; have a net negative score). Clearly the OP is not learning anything from the community view on their question formulation, but I don't see any evidence that these questions are affecting others, or reducing the quality of the site.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Either way, there are sufficiently many options available to the community at large that I (as moderator) don't need to step in. And that's my underlying philosophy. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="80" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" LastActivityDate="2013-02-17T22:29:44.700" CommentCount="5" />
./Posts.xml:1573:  <row Id="2660" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="2659" CreationDate="2013-03-26T08:26:46.537" Score="5" Body="&lt;p&gt;Here is my opinion and some more general points:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;We interpret &quot;theory&quot; in TCS &lt;em&gt;broadly&lt;/em&gt;, so in general interdisciplinary questions &lt;em&gt;can be&lt;/em&gt; on-topic on cstheory. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The main questions one should ask oneself before posting a question on cstheory are:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Is there a reason to think that I will receive a &lt;em&gt;satisfying answer&lt;/em&gt; to my question from theoretical computer scientists?&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Is there a reason to think that answering the question &lt;em&gt;requires&lt;/em&gt; the expertise of theoretical computer scientists?&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If &lt;strong&gt;yes&lt;/strong&gt; then cstheory can be a good place to &lt;strong&gt;ask it&lt;/strong&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If &lt;strong&gt;no&lt;/strong&gt; (e.g. an expert in cognitive science is more likely to answer the question in a satisfying manner for OP, or there is no reason to believe answering the question needs the expertise of a theoretical computer scientist) then &lt;strong&gt;probably not&lt;/strong&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;It might be good to think about this and include it in your question as motivation, it can make it interesting for other users.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;You should also formulate your question such that it does not fall into &lt;em&gt;non-constructive&lt;/em&gt; or &lt;em&gt;not-a-real-question&lt;/em&gt; categories. When people ask a question they are seeking help from others, they are asking others to spend time to read and think about the question. So we expect people to ask only questions that they &lt;em&gt;really&lt;/em&gt; care about (if you really care about a question you will spend time and effort on it, and the effort correlates with the quality of the question). We expect people to spend time doing their part before asking others for help, e.g. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;You have tried to answer your question yourself first (Google, Wikipedia, Complexity Zoo, etc.) before asking it on cstheory,&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;You have thought about the question enough to be able to formulate it clearly and in a way that can be answered, you know what you are looking for,&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;You have spent time to formulate your question using the language and terminology of theoretical computer scientists and following the norms of their community,&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;You have spend time to write your question in a clear and easy to understand format for theoretical computer scientists.&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;FAQ contains more &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/faq#tips-about-writing-better-questions&quot;&gt;tips about writing better questions&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="186" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" LastActivityDate="2013-03-29T05:03:51.573" CommentCount="1" />
./Posts.xml:1574:  <row Id="2661" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="225" CreationDate="2013-03-31T19:17:11.870" Score="0" Body="&lt;h2&gt;My question is not a research-level question in TCS, where can I ask it?&lt;/h2&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;For questions other than research-level questions in TCS, you may want to consider the following places to ask:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;General Computer Science — &lt;a href=&quot;https://cs.stackexchange.com/&quot;&gt;Computer Science - Stack Exchange&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;General Mathematics (including &lt;em&gt;theoretical&lt;/em&gt; CS) — &lt;a href=&quot;https://math.stackexchange.com/&quot;&gt;Mathematics - Stack Exchange&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Research-level Mathematics — &lt;a href=&quot;https://mathoverflow.net/&quot;&gt;Math Overflow&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Social and Professional Academic Issues — &lt;a href=&quot;https://academia.stackexchange.com/&quot;&gt;Academia - Stack Exchange&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Programming — &lt;a href=&quot;https://stackoverflow.com/&quot;&gt;Stack Overflow&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;General Artificial Intelligence — &lt;a href=&quot;http://metaoptimize.com/qa/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;Meta Optimize&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Statistics and Data Mining — &lt;a href=&quot;https://stats.stackexchange.com/&quot;&gt;Cross Validated&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Applied Cryptography and Security — &lt;a href=&quot;https://crypto.stackexchange.com/&quot;&gt;Crypto - Stack Exchange&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Computation used in Science and Engineering — &lt;a href=&quot;https://scicomp.stackexchange.com/&quot;&gt;Computational Science - Stack Exchange&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Questions about this site — &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/&quot;&gt;Theoretical Computer Science - Stack Exchange - Meta&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Other — check the list of sites on &lt;a href=&quot;http://stackexchange.com/sites&quot;&gt;Stack Exchange Network&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="186" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-05-23T11:33:34.517" LastActivityDate="2013-03-31T19:17:11.870" CommentCount="1" CommunityOwnedDate="2013-03-31T19:17:11.870" />
./Posts.xml:1575:  <row Id="2662" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="25" CreationDate="2013-03-31T19:29:23.317" Score="1" Body="&lt;h2&gt;Is my question suitable for cstheory?&lt;/h2&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Theoretical Computer Science - Stack Exchange&lt;/strong&gt; is a Q&amp;amp;A for &#xA;&lt;em&gt;professional researchers&lt;/em&gt; in &lt;em&gt;theoretical computer science&lt;/em&gt; and related fields. &#xA;We welcome &lt;em&gt;research-level&lt;/em&gt; questions in &lt;em&gt;theoretical computer science&lt;/em&gt; (TCS).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;Reseach-level&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Although there is no black-and-white distinction between &#xA;research-level questions and non-research-level questions, &#xA;questions are considered to be &quot;research-level&quot; roughly when &#xA;they can be discussed between two professors or &#xA;between two graduate students working on Ph.D.'s, &#xA;but not usually between a professor and a typical undergraduate student. &#xA;It does not include questions at the level of difficulty of typical undergraduate course/textbook homework/exercise.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;TCS&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;For an explanation of what TCS is, &#xA;we refer you to the description of ACM Special Interest Group on Algorithms and Computation Theory (SIGACT):&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;TCS covers a wide variety of topics including algorithms, data structures, computational complexity, parallel and distributed computation, probabilistic computation, quantum computation, automata theory, information theory, cryptography, program semantics and verification, machine learning, computational biology, computational economics, computational geometry, and computational number theory and algebra. Work in this field is often distinguished by its emphasis on mathematical technique and rigor.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;Questions should be based on knowledge sharing, not on shirking&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;You should only post questions you're actually seriously thinking about. Users are expected to do their part and try to answer their question by themselves before posting them on cstheory and asking for help from others. Search to see if your question is already answered somewhere else (e.g. Wikipedia) before asking a question. &lt;strong&gt;Try to make your question interesting for others by providing some background knowledge&lt;/strong&gt;. Remember, &lt;em&gt;questions should be based on knowledge sharing, not on shirking. Shirking goes against the spirit of the site.&lt;/em&gt; &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;hr&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;Checking if your question is on-topic&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;You can check if if your question is on-topic cstheory by answering the following questions:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Do you have a good reason to think that &#xA;&lt;strong&gt;your question is likely to receive a &lt;em&gt;satisfying answer&lt;/em&gt; &#xA;from theoretical computer scientists&lt;/strong&gt;?&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Do you have a good reason to think that &#xA;&lt;strong&gt;answering your question &lt;em&gt;requires&lt;/em&gt; &#xA;the expertise of &lt;em&gt;professional researchers&lt;/em&gt; in &lt;em&gt;theoretical&lt;/em&gt; computer science&lt;/strong&gt;?&lt;br&gt;&#xA;$ $&lt;br&gt;&#xA;If your question can be answered &#xA;by the knowledge of undergraduate/introductory textbook/course on the topic &#xA;then it is off-topic for cstheory. &#xA;Your question might be suitable for &#xA;our sister site &lt;a href=&quot;http://cs.stackexchange.com&quot;&gt;Computer Science - StackExchange&lt;/a&gt; &#xA;which has a broader scope.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Do you know the basics of the topic that your question is about&lt;/strong&gt; &#xA;(at least at the level of an undergraduate/introductory textbook/course on the topic)?&lt;br&gt;&#xA;$ $&lt;br&gt;&#xA;If not, please consider learning the basics before posting your question on cstheory. &#xA;Note that if you post a question without knowing the basics &#xA;it is likely that you will make a &lt;em&gt;basic&lt;/em&gt; mistake. &#xA;Therefore you should expect your question to get down-voted and closed, &#xA;possibly without any further explanation.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If &lt;strong&gt;yes&lt;/strong&gt; then cstheory can be a good place to &lt;strong&gt;ask it&lt;/strong&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If &lt;strong&gt;no&lt;/strong&gt; &#xA;(e.g. an expert in some other topic is more likely to &#xA;answer the question in a satisfying manner for you, or &#xA;there is no reason to believe answering the question requires the expertise of &#xA;professional researchers in theoretical computer science) &#xA;then &lt;strong&gt;probably not&lt;/strong&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;It can be good to think about these and include your answers to them in your question. &#xA;It will show us that you have thought about the suitability of your question for cstheory.&#xA;It can also act as motivation for your question, &#xA;which can make it more interesting for us.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;hr&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Spend time to formulate and write your question clearly. &#xA;When you ask a question you are seeking help from us, &#xA;you are asking us to spend time to read and think about the question. &#xA;We expect you to ask &lt;em&gt;only&lt;/em&gt; questions that you &lt;em&gt;really&lt;/em&gt; care about, &#xA;not out of idle curiosity. &#xA;If you care about your question &#xA;you should spend time and effort on it, &#xA;the effort correlates with the quality of the question. &#xA;If you want us to spend our time on your question, &#xA;you should have spent enough time on it.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In summery, we expect you to spend time doing your part &#xA;before asking others for help, e.g. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Try to answer your question yourself first &#xA;(Google, Wikipedia, Complexity Zoo, etc.) &#xA;before asking us,&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Spend enough time thinking about your question to be able to &#xA;formulate it clearly and in a way that can be answered, &#xA;i.e. you should know what you are looking for,&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Spend time on formulating your question &#xA;using the language and terminology of theoretical computer scientists correctly and&#xA;following the norms of their community,&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Spend time to write your question &#xA;in a clear and easy to understand format for theoretical computer scientists.&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;FAQ contains more &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/faq#tips-about-writing-better-questions&quot;&gt;tips about writing better questions&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="186" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.537" LastActivityDate="2013-03-31T19:38:05.793" CommentCount="0" CommunityOwnedDate="2013-03-31T19:29:23.317" />
./Posts.xml:1576:  <row Id="2663" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2013-04-03T06:20:21.980" Score="6" ViewCount="102" Body="&lt;p&gt;This post is for keeping interesting queries about cstheory.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;hr&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Related meta questions:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/q/502/186&quot;&gt;Useful UserScripts?&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="186" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" LastActivityDate="2013-04-11T05:06:07.810" Title="Useful database queries" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;" AnswerCount="6" CommentCount="4" FavoriteCount="2" CommunityOwnedDate="2013-04-03T06:20:21.980" />
./Posts.xml:1577:  <row Id="2664" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="2663" CreationDate="2013-04-03T06:20:21.980" Score="1" Body="&lt;h2&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://data.stackexchange.com/theoreticalcomputerscience/query/4038/find-interesting-unanswered-questions&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;Find interesting unanswered questions&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/h2&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;This query finds unanswered questions and sorts them based an estimated weight on how interesting they seem to be for the user running the query. The estimate uses: question score, asker's reputation, and how well you do on the tags for the question.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I guess this is similar to what they use for the &lt;a href=&quot;https://stackoverflow.com/?tab=interesting&quot;&gt;interesting questions tab&lt;/a&gt; on &lt;a href=&quot;https://stackoverflow.com/&quot;&gt;SO&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="186" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-05-23T12:40:08.913" LastActivityDate="2013-04-03T06:20:21.980" CommentCount="0" CommunityOwnedDate="2013-04-03T06:20:21.980" />

./Posts.xml:1590:  <row Id="2677" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="2676" CreationDate="2013-05-02T05:06:28.113" Score="0" Body="&lt;p&gt;Currently they are as follows:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I. It's built and run &lt;em&gt;by you&lt;/em&gt; as part of the &lt;a href=&quot;http://stackexchange.com&quot;&gt;Stack Exchange&lt;/a&gt; network of Q&amp;amp;A sites. ./Posts.xml:1595:  <row Id="2682" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="25" CreationDate="2013-05-13T11:25:03.047" Score="2" Body="&lt;h2&gt;An updated cross-posting FAQ item?&lt;/h2&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/225/official-faq-for-theoretical-computer-science/231#231&quot;&gt;old one&lt;/a&gt; is restricted to MO. &#xA;Here is a possible update:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;While we don't mind an on-topic question being reposted, &#xA;  our &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/a/231/&quot;&gt;site policy&lt;/a&gt; prohibits simultaneous crossposting as &#xA;  it duplicates effort and fractures discussion. &#xA;  Cross-posting is only permitted if:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;  &#xA;  &lt;ul&gt;&#xA;  &lt;li&gt;it is not simultaneous, and &lt;/li&gt;&#xA;  &lt;li&gt;the OP has waited a reasonable time (a few days) without receiving a satisfying answer before posting it on another site, and&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;  &lt;li&gt;the OP has provided links in both directions between the copies.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;  &lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;  &#xA;  &lt;p&gt;The OP is expected to keep all copies up-to-date, &#xA;  e.g. if one copy is clarified based on the comments, &#xA;  the OP should clarify the other one also. &#xA;  Similarly, &#xA;  if she receives a satisfying answer on the other site, &#xA;  she should post an answer on cstheory linking to the full answer&#xA;  (or do better by posting a complete answer &#xA;  tailored to cstheory based on what she has leaned). &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;  &#xA;  &lt;p&gt;In the case that the cross-posting does not satisfy these conditions &#xA;  moderators close the question as not-constructive and &#xA;  will explain the policy in a comment: &#xA;  the OP should wait a week and &#xA;  if she does not receive a satisfying answer by then &#xA;  she can flag the question for moderator attention and &#xA;  ask for the question to be reopened.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="186" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.560" LastActivityDate="2013-05-13T11:36:24.903" CommentCount="6" CommunityOwnedDate="2013-05-13T11:25:03.047" />

./Posts.xml:1600:  <row Id="2687" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2013-06-13T03:24:33.387" Score="5" ViewCount="247" Body="&lt;p&gt;We have to decide what should be our custom close reasons. We can have 3 custom close reasons.  Each can be up to 400 characters. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The default format of a close reason as follows:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;&lt;code&gt;Questions about X are off-topic because Y.  For more information, see [Z](link to meta post).&lt;/code&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I am adding a few possible reasons below as answers. Please up-vote those which you think we should have. If you don't like the phrasing of a close reason please comment below its answer to make suggestion on how it can be improved. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Fill free to post other possible custom closing reasons. Keep in mind that we can have only 3 custom closing reasons, so should optimize to cover the frequently used clsoing reasons.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;hr&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;SE has changed the closing reasons and mechanism. Each site can have its own costum off-topic closing reasons. See &lt;a href=&quot;http://blog.stackoverflow.com/2013/06/the-war-of-the-closes/&quot;&gt;The War of the Closes&lt;/a&gt; on SE blog.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Reference:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/184154/closing-changes-on-hold-unclear-too-broad-opinion-based-off-topic-reasons&quot;&gt;Closing changes: on hold, unclear, too broad, opinion-based, off-topic reasons, bye-bye to Too Localized&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="186" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-20T10:29:37.593" LastActivityDate="2013-09-24T15:48:22.093" Title="Our custom closing reasons" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;closing&gt;&lt;site-settings&gt;" AnswerCount="8" CommentCount="8" />

./Posts.xml:1604:  <row Id="2692" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="2676" CreationDate="2013-06-25T19:01:29.257" Score="2" Body="&lt;h2&gt;Introduction:&lt;/h2&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;September 20, 2013:&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Added a link to CS.SE.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;June 25, 2013:&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Adding a link to our FAQ, plus some rewording.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Theoretical Computer Science - Stack Exchange&lt;/strong&gt; &#xA;  is a question and answer site for&#xA;  &lt;i&gt;professional researchers in theoretical computer science&lt;/i&gt; and &#xA;  related fields.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;  &#xA;  &lt;p&gt;It's built and run &lt;em&gt;by users&lt;/em&gt; as a part of the &#xA;  &lt;a href=&quot;http://stackexchange.com&quot;&gt;Stack Exchange&lt;/a&gt; network of Q&amp;amp;A sites.&#xA;  We welcome you to join us in asking and answering &#xA;  &lt;strong&gt;research-level&lt;/strong&gt; questions in &#xA;  &lt;strong&gt;theoretical&lt;/strong&gt; computer science.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;  &#xA;  &lt;p&gt;For &lt;strong&gt;undergraduate-level questions&lt;/strong&gt;&#xA;  please visit&#xA;  &lt;a href=&quot;http://cs.stackexchange.com&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Computer Science&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&#xA;  which has a broader scope.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;  &#xA;  &lt;p&gt;For more information about the scope&#xA;  please check out our &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/help/on-topic&quot;&gt;FAQ&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="186" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" LastActivityDate="2013-09-21T06:51:51.097" CommentCount="0" />
./Posts.xml:1609:  <row Id="2697" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2013-07-01T05:14:50.687" Score="9" ViewCount="95" Body="&lt;p&gt;I noticed that we get a fair number of non-research-level questions.  This is not too surprising, since if someone comes here and just looks at the title of the site, they might get the wrong impression.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Suggestion: Add some text to the &quot;Ask a Question&quot; page to clarify this.  For instance, on the sidebar it currently says &quot;Is your question about theoretical computer science?  We prefer questions that can be answered, not just discussed.&quot;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Perhaps this could be revised to &quot;Is your question about theoretical computer science?  We prefer questions that can be answered, not just discussed.  We prefer questions at a research level.&quot; Would this help avoid confusion, or do you think people would just overlook that?  &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;See also: &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/q/1603/5038&quot;&gt;Limiting non research level questions&lt;/a&gt; (which seems like an even better suggestion, but apparently has not been implemented).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="5038" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" LastActivityDate="2013-07-01T05:14:50.687" Title="More prominent indication that this site is for research-level questions?" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;site-general&gt;" AnswerCount="0" CommentCount="5" />
./Posts.xml:1610:  <row Id="2698" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="631" CreationDate="2013-07-01T05:16:52.617" Score="4" Body="&lt;h2&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cs.stackexchange.com/&quot;&gt;Computer Science.SE&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/h2&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;For questions about computer science.  This is a good alternative, for questions that are not at a research level.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="5038" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:48:30.257" LastActivityDate="2013-07-01T05:16:52.617" CommentCount="0" CommunityOwnedDate="2013-07-01T05:16:52.617" />
./Posts.xml:1611:  <row Id="2699" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="2687" CreationDate="2013-07-04T01:29:53.330" Score="5" Body="&lt;h3&gt;Simultaneous crossposting:&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;Our &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/a/231/&quot;&gt;site policy&lt;/a&gt; prohibits &lt;strong&gt;&lt;em&gt;simultaneous&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;  &lt;strong&gt;crossposting&lt;/strong&gt;: it duplicates effort and fractures discussion. Crossposting is permitted after a week has passed without a satisfying answer elsewhere. When crossposting please summarize the relevant discussions from other sites in your question and link between the copies in both directions.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;$ $&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;&lt;code&gt;Our [site policy](https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/a/231/) prohibits ***simultaneous***  **crossposting**: it duplicates effort and fractures discussion. Crossposting is permitted after a week has passed without a satisfying answer elsewhere. When crossposting please summarize the relevant discussions from other sites in your question and link between the copies in both directions.&lt;/code&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="186" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.560" LastActivityDate="2013-07-13T04:34:13.823" CommentCount="0" CommunityOwnedDate="2013-07-04T01:29:53.330" />
./Posts.xml:1613:  <row Id="2701" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="2687" CreationDate="2013-07-04T01:32:54.857" Score="1" Body="&lt;h3&gt;Not &lt;em&gt;theoretical&lt;/em&gt; computer science:&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;Questions does not appear to be a research-level question in &lt;strong&gt;theoretical&lt;/strong&gt; computer science.  For more information, please see &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/help/on-topic&quot;&gt;scope&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="186" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.537" LastActivityDate="2013-07-04T01:32:54.857" CommentCount="0" CommunityOwnedDate="2013-07-04T01:32:54.857" />
./Posts.xml:1614:  <row Id="2702" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="2687" CreationDate="2013-07-04T01:44:31.060" Score="4" Body="&lt;h3&gt;Not enough effort&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Doesn't know the basics definitions/results, hasn't tried to answer the oneself, the answer can be found on Wikipedia/Complexity Zoo/... or by a simple Google search.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;Questions must demonstrate a minimal understanding of the problem being solved. Tell us what you've tried to do, why it didn't work, and how it should work. See also &lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.stackexchange.com/q/&quot;&gt;our question checklist&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="186" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-20T10:29:37.593" LastActivityDate="2013-07-04T01:44:31.060" CommentCount="0" CommunityOwnedDate="2013-07-04T01:44:31.060" />
./Posts.xml:1618:  <row Id="2706" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2013-07-18T15:24:40.587" Score="9" ViewCount="187" Body="&lt;p&gt;It's standard practice here to close questions that are too elementary to be considered &quot;research-level&quot;.  But I think people have been too quick to label some questions as &quot;too elementary&quot;, when in fact they describe very real research-level questions.  For example:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/q/18372/111&quot;&gt;How are lower bounds for computational complexity proved?&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/q/18406/111&quot;&gt;Roots of a polynomial&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In both cases, there is an undergraduate-level &quot;textbook&quot; answer.  (For the first question: Sorting requires $\Omega(n\log n)$ comparisons.  For the second question: Hilbert's 10th is undecidable.)  But if we look past those easy answers, these are legitimate research-level questions in theoretical computer science.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Okay, but then how does one prove lower bounds for problems that can't be solved by comparison trees?  Or lower bounds bigger than $\Omega(n\log n)$ for problems solvable in polynomial time?  Or exponential lower bounds for NP-hard problems?&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Okay, but then how does one actually find integer roots of polynomials in practice?  Are there effective algorithms for broad and interesting classes of polynomials?  Are there algorithms with provable approximation guarantees (for interesting classes of polynomials)?&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In both cases, the deeper question is likely not what the original poster intended.  (But StackExchange answers are for the entire community, not just for the original poster.  And why should we shy away from blowing the original poster's mind?)  And even if it were, the posts would require significant editing to bring the deeper question to the fore.  (But editing good questions is generally preferred to closing them.)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Should we really close such questions?&lt;/strong&gt;  Or am I just being a smartass?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="111" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" LastActivityDate="2013-07-19T05:25:33.713" Title="Assuming good faith for naïve questions" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;" AnswerCount="2" CommentCount="6" FavoriteCount="2" />
./Posts.xml:1621:  <row Id="2709" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="2687" CreationDate="2013-07-25T22:20:46.930" Score="-2" Body="&lt;h2&gt;Default off-topic closing reason&lt;/h2&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;This is used as default, when other reasons are not used.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Right now it reads:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;This question does not appear to be a &lt;strong&gt;research-level&lt;/strong&gt; question in &lt;strong&gt;theoretical&lt;/strong&gt; computer science.  For more information, please see &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/help/on-topic&quot;&gt;scope&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Since it is the default, I think we should edit it to be broader. Something like:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;As posted this question is not suitable for cstheory.  For more information about why it is closed please refer to &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/help/on-topic&quot;&gt;help center&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="186" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.537" LastActivityDate="2013-07-25T22:20:46.930" CommentCount="0" CommunityOwnedDate="2013-07-25T22:20:46.930" />
./Posts.xml:1623:  <row Id="2711" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="2710" CreationDate="2013-08-02T08:42:36.327" Score="4" Body="&lt;p&gt;Try finding the answer to your question yourself by checking&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;General&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.google.com&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;Google&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://scholar.google.com&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;Google Scholar&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://en.wikipedia.org&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;Wikipedia&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;Specific&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://complexityzoo.uwaterloo.ca/Complexity_Zoo&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;Complexity Zoo&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.nada.kth.se/~viggo/wwwcompendium/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;A compendium of NP optimization problems&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.openproblemgarden.org/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;Open Problem Garden&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.graphclasses.org/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;Information System on Graph Classes and their Inclusions&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="186" LastEditorUserId="186" LastEditDate="2013-08-21T19:13:41.693" LastActivityDate="2013-08-21T19:13:41.693" CommentCount="1" />
./Posts.xml:1624:  <row Id="2712" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAnswerId="2714" CreationDate="2013-08-02T21:07:24.483" Score="14" ViewCount="324" Body="&lt;p&gt;I have a request.  It would be nice if the moderators here would avoid migrating low-quality questions to CS.SE.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I noticed recently a few low-quality questions that were migrated to the Computer Science Stack Exchange (CS.SE) site.  I would suggest that we avoid doing that.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;If it's a good question, and on-topic for CS.SE, I definitely encourage you to migrate to CS.SE.  For instance, if it is not research-level but would be a reasonable question, migrating to CS.SE is a great idea.  Go for it!&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;But if it's a bad question -- one that would be a bad question for CS.SE -- please don't migrate it to CS.SE.  If it's a bad question, just close it, don't migrate it.  Please don't make CS.SE a dumping ground for bad questions.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;If it's a good question -- well-researched, on-topic, focused, narrow -- but has some English/grammar problems, don't let that stop you from migrating.  If it's just the English, we can edit it over at CS.SE.  But if it is a fundamentally bad question -- e.g., not well-researched, or a duplicate, or unclear -- I personally don't think it should be migrated over to CS.SE&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;One recent example: &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/q/18536/5038&quot;&gt;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/q/18536/5038&lt;/a&gt;.  In my opinion, that question shouldn't have been migrated to CS.SE.  It is not a good fit for the Computer Science Stack Exchange.  The question does not show evidence of effort.  It asks a question about a topic that is already covered by reference questions at CS.SE, with no evidence that the question-asker was aware of that.  These issues are not something that those of us at CS.SE can fix through simple edits to the question.  Of course, that's just one example.  I don't mean to pick on that one or focus on that one too much.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Kaveh explains that the CS.SE admins specifically requested that &quot;badly written&quot; questions are still OK to migrate to CS.SE.  I didn't realize that!  That explains a lot.  Perhaps that's something we should discuss.  I'm not sure whether &quot;badly written&quot; refers to the English/grammar, or to more fundamental issues (like whether it's a good question, whether it is well-researched, whether it is on-topic and focused and detailed and not a duplicate).  If the former, I agree, English/grammar problems should not be a barrier to migration.  If the latter, well, I guess I might have a slight difference of opinion with the CS.SE admins -- maybe that's something we need to discuss on CS.meta, instead of here.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I certainly don't mean to imply that this is a huge, systemic problem that requires major changes to migration, and I don't mean to imply the moderators here are doing anything wrong (I think the moderators are doing a great job!).  Overall I think the process is generally working well.  I just wanted to suggest a minor refinement that I think might make things work better on CS.SE.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Related:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/q/1086/5038&quot;&gt;Moderators: Please be very careful when migrating questions to other Stack Exchange websites&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/q/1285/5038&quot;&gt;To migrate or not to migrate (just close)&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/q/1507/5038&quot;&gt;Migrating to cs.SE&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cs.meta.stackexchange.com/q/691/755&quot;&gt;Do we want CSTheory.SE to migrate bad questions over here?&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="5038" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.537" LastActivityDate="2013-09-24T05:49:29.113" Title="Please don't migrate bad questions to CS.Stack Exchange" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;migration&gt;&lt;closing&gt;" AnswerCount="3" CommentCount="7" />
./Posts.xml:1626:  <row Id="2714" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="2712" CreationDate="2013-08-05T00:06:19.923" Score="10" Body="&lt;p&gt;I propose the following guideline: suppose you're teaching a computer science class and a student comes to you with that question. How do you respond?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In a nutshell, if you just wish the guy would go away, close in situ. If you'd like to help the guy (and the question is about computer science), migrate. In more detail:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;“What? Is that even English?” → Close (“unclear”).&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;“Go read this book.” → Comment, close (too broad).&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;“A chimpanzee who'd attended the class would know the answer!” → Close (“unclear”), pray to that the user doesn't come back.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;“What does this have to do with me?” → Close (off-topic).&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;“It's a matter of taste.” → Close (opinion-based).&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;“That's a direct application of something we covered in class.” → Close (“off-topic, not research-level”), point to a Wikipedia page or to a CS.SE reference thread on the topic (e.g. &lt;a href=&quot;https://cs.stackexchange.com/questions/1031/how-to-prove-that-a-language-is-not-regular&quot;&gt;How to prove that a language is not regular?&lt;/a&gt;).&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;“That's a good question about computer science! You see…” → migrate to CS.SE.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;“Ok, here's a hint to solve this exercise, try it and come back.” → migrate to CS.SE.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;“Gee, a programming question.” → migrate to SO if you think it's a really good question, otherwise close as off-topic.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If none of the categories applies, use your judgement. There is obviously room for subjectivity. Where does &lt;a href=&quot;https://cs.stackexchange.com/questions/13578/omega-of-a-polynomial-function&quot;&gt;Omega of a polynomial function&lt;/a&gt; fit? I would close and answer with a comment linking to &lt;a href=&quot;http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Big_O_notation#Properties&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;Wikipedia&lt;/a&gt;, because it's a really elementary question. Also, technically, it isn't a computer science question, it's a math question that falls short of reaching a CS application. I wouldn't say that migrating it is fundamentally wrong, but it is a bit of a waste of effort.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If in doubt — if the question is not great but not crap either — you might as well migrate. If the target site doesn't like the question, it can close it.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="634" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:48:30.257" LastActivityDate="2013-08-05T00:11:51.853" CommentCount="5" />
./Posts.xml:1627:  <row Id="2715" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="1619" CreationDate="2013-08-07T12:58:47.617" Score="8" Body="&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://crypto.stackexchange.com/&quot;&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;https://i.stack.imgur.com/rEGd0.png&quot; alt=&quot;Join Crypto Stackexchange&quot;&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="10694" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:48:17.923" LastActivityDate="2013-10-05T03:03:38.283" CommentCount="0" CommunityOwnedDate="2013-08-07T12:58:47.617" />
./Posts.xml:1634:  <row Id="2722" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2013-09-09T20:29:07.690" Score="2" ViewCount="211" Body="&lt;p&gt;I just noticed &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/18912/polar-coding-decoding&quot;&gt;this question&lt;/a&gt;, asked by a new user, which has two downvotes with no comments. I don't think this question is bad—it could use more explanation, and more demonstration of the OP's having put effort into figuring out the answer. But how can the OP know how to improve the question without getting comments? &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Is there anything we can do so that we stop discouraging people from asking questions on this site by downvoting them indiscriminately? &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="1677" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" LastActivityDate="2013-09-29T20:37:10.550" Title="Drive-by downvoting on new user's questions."
