./Posts.xml:1636:  <row Id="2724" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="2722" CreationDate="2013-09-10T18:17:39.800" Score="3" Body="&lt;p&gt;There are several reasons to down-vote a post. We have discussed previously (see &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/1264/&quot;&gt;this&lt;/a&gt; and &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/1395/&quot;&gt;this&lt;/a&gt;) that we are not going to require or even demand people to explain their votes. When I see a down-vote that I don't understand I politely comment that I don't understand it, but I think demanding an explanation or stating that there is no reason for the down-vote goes too far. It is not an abuse if people are using their votes in a way different from us.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I have argued a number of times that I am against counter-voting, that is voting to null the effect of another user's vote. Everyone has their own opinion. The total reflects the opinion of the community, it is not the job of any particular user to decide what the total should be. Counter-voting encourages other users to do the same and use their votes to null votes in place of express their opinion about the question. Each vote is a manifestation of some user's opinion and if we respect their opinions then we should respect their votes even when we disagree with them.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I think it is more productive if we comment and explain why we think it is a suitable and interesting question in place of just asking others why they have down-voted the post.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In this particular case, I see several possible reasons for a down-vote. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Formating: It is using an image in place of writing the expression which I think has been one of the reasons people down-vote. &lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Content: The questions seems to simply ask how to calculate some expression for some particular values. It seems to ask how to apply a method explained in a paper in a particular case in practice. It is too localized and it doesn't seem to be a &lt;em&gt;research-level&lt;/em&gt; question in &lt;em&gt;theoretical&lt;/em&gt; computer science. It is also unclear what is the trouble the OP is facing in calculating the expression.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If you ask me I think we are being too open right now (I guess it is partly because people get bored that there are not as many questions as they would like) to questions which should not be here and are more suitable for CS.SE. E.g. &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/18703/are-randomized-algorithms-considered-as-complete&quot;&gt;1&lt;/a&gt;, &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/18628/confused-about-disparity-and-depth-map&quot;&gt;2&lt;/a&gt;, &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/18886/proof-that-turing-machine-and-lambda-calculus-are-equivalent&quot;&gt;3&lt;/a&gt;, &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/18575/pigeon-holing-or-bucketing-a-number-based-on-a-set-of-ranges&quot;&gt;4&lt;/a&gt; have been in &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/tools?tab=close&amp;amp;daterange=last30days&quot;&gt;the closing review queue&lt;/a&gt; for sometime but have not been put &lt;em&gt;on-hold&lt;/em&gt;. Similarly, it is not clear what &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/18871/bounded-computation-and-incompleteness/18883&quot;&gt;this question&lt;/a&gt; is asking and should be put &lt;em&gt;on-hold&lt;/em&gt; until clarified but it does not have a single close vote. And &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/18903/how-would-the-use-of-ternary-computers-change-complexity-of-algorithms&quot;&gt;this&lt;/a&gt; is clearly not-research level in my opinion.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="186" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" LastActivityDate="2013-09-29T20:37:10.550" CommentCount="8" />
./Posts.xml:1640:  <row Id="2728" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="2726" CreationDate="2013-09-23T17:04:00.917" Score="3" Body="&lt;p&gt;In addition to what Suresh wrote, keep in mind that the audiences are also different. The cstheory community is mainly composed of professional researchers in theoretical computer science. We have more specialists here who might not visit CS.SE. However the expectations from questions are also higher. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;See also&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/300/how-to-ask-a-good-question&quot;&gt;How to write a good question&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/25/material-to-supplement-the-faq/2662#2662&quot;&gt;Is my question suitable for cstheory?&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="186" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" LastActivityDate="2013-09-23T17:04:00.917" CommentCount="0" />
./Posts.xml:1641:  <row Id="2729" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2013-09-24T03:44:12.693" Score="3" ViewCount="72" Body="&lt;p&gt;I posted this &lt;a href=&quot;https://cs.stackexchange.com/questions/14328/difficulty-in-understanding-the-quantum-algorithm-for-the-abelian-hidden-subgrou&quot;&gt;question&lt;/a&gt; on cs.stackexchange but didn't get any answers. ./Posts.xml:1642:  <row Id="2730" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="2712" CreationDate="2013-09-24T05:42:21.390" Score="3" Body="&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;A small note and update about migration&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;As you know only moderators can migrate questions to CS.SE right now and this is unlikely to change until CS.SE graduates. I think Suresh generally does not migrate questions, Dave does sometimes, but most of the migrations to CS.SE was performed by me. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Since the discussions here and on meta.CS.SE I have stopped migrating questions except in very special cases because people do not seem to be happy with them and migration has become too complicated (check if there is a duplicate or reference questions, etc.). In practice questions are either &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/2706/&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;OK here&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/a&gt; or &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/posts/2714/&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;not OK there&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;So &lt;strong&gt;in practice we don't migrate questions to CS.SE anymore&lt;/strong&gt;. Please keep this in mind when commenting or flagging for migration.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="186" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.560" LastActivityDate="2013-09-24T05:49:29.113" CommentCount="6" />
./Posts.xml:1644:  <row Id="2732" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2013-10-01T17:59:30.283" Score="5" ViewCount="76" Body="&lt;p&gt;Here is a recent example. Can we get rid of automatic conversion of questions to CW?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/19222/constant-factor-approximation-of-hypergraph-maxdicut&quot;&gt;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/19222/constant-factor-approximation-of-hypergraph-maxdicut&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="186" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" LastActivityDate="2013-10-02T05:12:33.790" Title="Can we get rid of automatic conversion to CW?" ./Posts.xml:1645:  <row Id="2733" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="2732" CreationDate="2013-10-02T04:45:16.060" Score="7" Body="&lt;p&gt;TL;DR: This is an excellent suggestion -- one that I think there is sadly no chance of being implemented, alas.  The only way to fix this is to rely upon our moderators to un-CW such questions (you'll have to flag it for their attention).  I'd certainly hope our moderators would be glad to do that.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;hr&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In more detail: I agree with you.  I too would like to see automatic conversion to community wiki disabled.  I think it's a lousy feature; it disincentives improvements to questions and answers.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Unfortunately it has been suggested previously on Meta.Stackoverflow many times over the past 4 years, and it looks very unlikely that it will be changed:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.stackexchange.com/q/8654/160917&quot;&gt;SO is too eager to turn my edited answers into Community Wiki&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.stackexchange.com/q/192434/160917&quot;&gt;Community Wiki punishes users for improving their posts&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.stackexchange.com/q/179746/160917&quot;&gt;Should authors be encouraged to maintain their answers?&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.stackexchange.com/q/183918/160917&quot;&gt;What is the reason behind auto convertion to Community Wiki after 5-10 edits?&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.stackexchange.com/q/179901/160917&quot;&gt;Why does repeated editing by same user lead to community wiki?&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.stackexchange.com/q/333/160917&quot;&gt;Is there any point forcing a post to Community Wiki after 6 owner edits?&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.stackexchange.com/q/155621/160917&quot;&gt;Don&amp;#39;t auto community wiki answers to questions made CW through too many edits&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.stackexchange.com/q/181436/160917&quot;&gt;Give some kind of warning before Community Wiki takes effect?&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.stackexchange.com/q/79250/160917&quot;&gt;Add warning if your edit will make the post Community Wiki&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.stackexchange.com/q/157928/160917&quot;&gt;Avoid conversion to CW at 10 edits: allow user option to not have post pushed to top of home page&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Apparently, the rationale given for the existing auto-CW-conversion behavior is that the site designers were worried that people would continually edit their question to bump it to the front page of the site.  I personally don't think the current behavior is the best solution to that problem, but whatever: it's clear that the site developers have a different view, that they have thought about this, they do have reasons for the current behavior, and ultimately, this is unlikely to change (at least, not in the foreseeable future).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;For now, no changes seem likely to come our way.&#xA;Instead, the standard workaround seems to be: if you notice that a question/answer was auto-converted to CW inappropriately, flag it for a moderator (flag as &quot;needs moderator attention&quot;), and ask the moderator to please reverse the community wiki status.  Moderators have that ability.  Apparently, many moderators have stated that they do routinely grant these requests (absent concrete reasons not to), and it is considered legitimate to ask the moderators to do so.  See, e.g.,&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.stackexchange.com/a/179756/160917&quot;&gt;https://meta.stackexchange.com/a/179756/160917&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.stackexchange.com/q/192784/160917&quot;&gt;What criteria are taken into account when deciding to undo Community Wiki status on answers?&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.stackexchange.com/a/192438/160917&quot;&gt;https://meta.stackexchange.com/a/192438/160917&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.stackexchange.com/a/83373/160917&quot;&gt;https://meta.stackexchange.com/a/83373/160917&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.stackexchange.com/a/179825/160917&quot;&gt;https://meta.stackexchange.com/a/179825/160917&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Unfortunately, you'll still lose any rep that was accumulated between when the answer was auto-converted to CW and when the moderator reverts the CW status.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;hr&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;My proposal:&lt;/strong&gt; Our moderators should routinely and gladly grant such flag requests, as long as there has not been any signs of abuse.  We should be grateful to anyone who takes the time to improve their questions or answers, as long as they're not abusing the feature to try to bump their question/answer to the front page.  I don't think our moderators should refuse to grant such flags (e.g., on the basis that they're going to wait for this behavior to be changed -- as it's pretty clear this behavior is not going to be changed any time soon).  That just penalizes people who put extra time and energy into improving their questions/answers.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="5038" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-20T10:29:37.593" LastActivityDate="2013-10-02T05:12:33.790" CommentCount="2" />

./Posts.xml:1649:  <row Id="2737" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2013-11-19T21:43:01.830" Score="7" ViewCount="136" Body="&lt;p&gt;Sometimes (maybe once a month if it's a busy month) we have a tough question in theoretical science on &lt;a href=&quot;https://cs.stackexchange.com/&quot;&gt;Computer Science Stack Exchange&lt;/a&gt; that nobody can answer.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;After a while we tend to presume that if nobody answered, it's because nobody knows, which makes the question research-level. (It's usually clear which questions went unanswered because nobody knows and which questions went unanswered because nobody bothered.)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;While research-level questions in theoretical computer science are on-topic on CS.SE, it is better if questions get answered. So if a question was asked on CS.SE but would also be suitable for Theoretical Computer Science, usually someone suggests migrating it there.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Assuming that the question is indeed about theoretical computer science, that it has gone unanswered for long enough that we doubt it will be answered on CS.SE, and that the asker is willing, &lt;strong&gt;should we migrate the question to CSTheory.SE?&lt;/strong&gt; Should we ask first, and where? (&lt;a href=&quot;http://chat.stackexchange.com/rooms/9446/theory-salon&quot;&gt;Chat&lt;/a&gt;? but it's pretty much dead.)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Only &lt;a href=&quot;https://cs.stackexchange.com/users?tab=moderators&quot;&gt;moderators of CS.SE&lt;/a&gt; can initiate the migration; if we do it it would typically be in response to a flag, often a flag from the asker.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Note that if you feel that a question should not have been migrated to CSTheory, you can close it; this will bounce the question back to its original site, but not reopen it there. (This is known as rejecting the migration.) If you find a question migrated from CS.SE and you think that it is not suitable for CSTheory.SE but should have remained open on CS.SE, please vote to close it here, and once it is closed here please flag it for reopening on CS.SE.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="634" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:48:30.257" LastActivityDate="2014-02-06T17:03:04.923" Title="Protocol for migrations from CS.SE" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;migration&gt;" AnswerCount="1" CommentCount="6" />
./Posts.xml:1650:  <row Id="2738" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2013-11-20T05:39:35.657" Score="5" ViewCount="396" Body="&lt;p&gt;&lt;em&gt;taken from the promo email&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Winter Bash is an annual event that can run on any Stack Exchange site that chooses to participate. Users earn “hats” for their gravatars by completing certain tasks (analogous to badges). Certain actions trigger the user receiving a hat, which their gravatar can “wear”. We track everyone’s progress earning hats in a leaderboard that looks something like this: &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;https://i.stack.imgur.com/BxPic.jpg&quot; alt=&quot;enter image description here&quot;&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Winter Bash 2013 will again be available to all sites that choose to participate. We’re redesigning the landing page and redesigning all the hats to keep things fresh and exciting. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Some Details&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;This event will run from 16 December 2013 to 3 January 2014. Users will be able to see their entire hat collection at &lt;a href=&quot;http://winterbash2013.stackexchange.com&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;http://winterbash2013.stackexchange.com&lt;/a&gt;. That site will also have a landing page, explaining the rules and other details of the event. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Individual users who don’t want to participate, don’t want to see hats, and/or are generally anti-hat will have an “I hate hats” option available. And just like last time, at the end of the event, all hats will go back into storage. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The only visual change to the Stack Exchange sites themselves will be the presence of the hats and the “I hate hats” button in the footer.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;Should we participate in the 2013 Winter Bash ? I've created two&#xA;  comments to vote on. ./Posts.xml:1651:  <row Id="2739" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAnswerId="2742" CreationDate="2013-11-22T19:15:49.290" Score="6" ViewCount="85" Body="&lt;p&gt;It's been &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/19917/graph-isomorphism-polynomial-time-reduction-from-gi-for-disconnected-graphs-to?noredirect=1#comment52499_19917&quot;&gt;pointed out&lt;/a&gt; that the &quot;How to Ask&quot; box that appears when a user is &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/ask&quot;&gt;asking a question&lt;/a&gt; doesn't mention that TCS Stack Exchange is for research-level questions only. ./Posts.xml:1654:  <row Id="2744" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="2738" CreationDate="2013-11-27T21:59:42.960" Score="11" Body="&lt;p&gt;At the time I write this, the leading option in the poll is &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/2738/should-we-participate-in-the-stack-exchange-winter-bash#comment6819_2738&quot;&gt;SHRUG&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If SHRUG wins, then instead of hats, CSTheory should get epaulettes.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;https://i.stack.imgur.com/KC4c0.jpg&quot; alt=&quot;Suresh with badly cut epaulettes&quot;&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="634" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" LastActivityDate="2013-11-27T21:59:42.960" CommentCount="4" />
./Posts.xml:1655:  <row Id="2745" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2013-12-06T10:20:56.017" Score="7" ViewCount="425" Body="&lt;p&gt;It's the time of the year again, namely it is December 2013, and so we shall now refresh our Community Promotion Ads for the new year.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;What are Community Promotion Ads?&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Community Promotion Ads are community-vetted advertisements that will show up on the main site, in the right sidebar. The purpose of this question is the vetting process. Images of the advertisements are provided, and community voting will enable the advertisements to be shown.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;Why do we have Community Promotion Ads?&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;This is a method for the community to control what gets promoted to visitors on the site. For example, you might promote the following things:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;cool site-related open source apps&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;the site's twitter account&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;script packs or power tools&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;cool events or conferences&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;anything else your community would genuinely be interested in&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The goal is for future visitors to find out about &lt;em&gt;the stuff your community deems important&lt;/em&gt;. This also serves as a way to promote information and resources that are &lt;em&gt;relevant to your own community's interests&lt;/em&gt;, both for those already in the community and those yet to join. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;Why do we reset the ads every year?&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Some services will maintain usefulness over the years, while other things will wane to allow for new faces to show up. Resetting the ads every year helps accommodate this, and allows old ads that have served their purpose to be cycled out for fresher ads for newer things. This helps keep the material in the ads relevant to not just the subject matter of the community, but to the current status of the community. We reset the ads once a year, every December.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The community promotion ads have no restrictions against reposting an ad from a previous cycle. If a particular service or ad is very valuable to the community and will continue to be so, it is a good idea to repost it. It may be helpful to give it a new face in the process, so as to prevent the imagery of the ad from getting stale after a year of exposure.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;How does it work?&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The answers you post to this question &lt;em&gt;must&lt;/em&gt; conform to the following rules, or they will be ignored. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;All answers should be in the exact form of:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;pre&gt;&lt;code&gt;[![Tagline to show on mouseover][1]][2]&#xA;&#xA;   [1]: http://image-url&#xA;   [2]: http://clickthrough-url &#xA;&lt;/code&gt;&lt;/pre&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Please &lt;strong&gt;do not add anything else to the body of the post&lt;/strong&gt;. If you want to discuss something, do it in the comments.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;The question must always be tagged with the magic &lt;a href=&quot;/questions/tagged/community-ads&quot; class=&quot;post-tag moderator-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;community-ads&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;community-ads&lt;/a&gt; tag. In addition to enabling the functionality of the advertisements, this tag also pre-fills the answer form with the above required form.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;Image requirements&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;The image that you create must be &lt;strong&gt;220 x 250 pixels&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Must be hosted through our standard image uploader (imgur)&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Must be GIF or PNG&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;No animated GIFs&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Absolute limit on file size of 150 KB&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;Score Threshold&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;There is a &lt;strong&gt;minimum score threshold&lt;/strong&gt; an answer must meet (currently &lt;strong&gt;6&lt;/strong&gt;) before it will be shown on the main site.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;You can check out the ads that have met the threshold with basic click stats &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/ads/display/2745&quot;&gt;here&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="6115" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" LastActivityDate="2014-09-13T06:56:17.573" Title="Community Promotion Ads - 2014" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;community-ads&gt;" AnswerCount="9" CommentCount="0" FavoriteCount="1" ClosedDate="2015-01-01T03:19:56.123" CommunityOwnedDate="2013-12-06T10:20:56.017" />

./Posts.xml:1669:  <row Id="2760" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="2759" CreationDate="2014-01-05T10:00:24.103" Score="6" Body="&lt;p&gt;In your previous interactions on cstheory&#xA;we have seen that you lack the mathematical maturity to understand &#xA;what is a valid mathematical argument as I have written several times &#xA;(and that is the main reason that &#xA;you don't understand the problem with your &quot;arguments&quot; and &#xA;keep insisting on them and engaging in extended discussions). &#xA;Therefore your questions are off-topic here because you don't have the minimal understanding of the problem being solved, i.e. understand the answers given to you.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In addition, on cstheory we have &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/q/274/&quot;&gt;an explicit policy against crank-friendly topics&lt;/a&gt;. &#xA;The goal of the policy is to be unwelcoming to cranks on this site. &#xA;cstheory does not welcome cranks. &#xA;It is not a personal issue and &#xA;it doesn't mean anything about interactions &#xA;we might have outside this site. &#xA;But &lt;strong&gt;&lt;em&gt;on cstheory&lt;/em&gt; we will not welcome cranks&lt;/strong&gt;.&lt;br&gt;&#xA;As a non-expert who has been &lt;a href=&quot;http://arxiv.org/find/cs/1/au:+Feinstein_C/0/1/0/all/0/1&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;insisting to have proven P is not equal to NP&lt;/a&gt; for a considerable time despite the fact that no expert has accepted your claim you are considered a crank.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Also you tend to post question to later post (incorrect) answers ( e.g. &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/a/9281/&quot;&gt;1&lt;/a&gt;, &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/a/18007/&quot;&gt;2&lt;/a&gt;),&#xA;that is also unwelcome on cstheory.&#xA;cstheory should not be used for self-promotion of one's ideas,&#xA;if the intention is not to genuinely ask a question then &#xA;the question is &quot;not a real question&quot; and&#xA;should be closed.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Aside these, questions of the form &#xA;&quot;I have this idea, what is wrong with it?&quot; &#xA;can be on-topic stated suitably.&#xA;However such questions need considerable extra care since &#xA;they often result in open-ended extended discussions and &#xA;generally open-ended extended discussions are not suitable for &#xA;the sites on the Stack Exchange network, these are Q&amp;amp;A sites, not discussion sites.&#xA;I and other users have expressed the opinion that &#xA;we need a place for discussions, &#xA;but cstheory as a Q&amp;amp;A site is not that place.&#xA;In fact &#xA;&lt;em&gt;the software for these sites is &#xA;intentionally designed to make extended discussions difficult&lt;/em&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;These are the reasons your question was closed. &#xA;Whether some respected expert on the topic has replied to your email does not change them, &#xA;so I think your question should remain closed.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;ps: &#xA;I don't use &quot;&lt;a href=&quot;http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crank_%28person%29&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;crank&lt;/a&gt;&quot; as a derogatory or disrespectful term, &#xA;I use crank to refer to non-experts who &#xA;insist on attacking famous open problems and/or their ideas/&quot;solutions&quot; to them, &#xA;without any indication that they have the required knowledge and &#xA;capability to solve the problem &#xA;(or even worse showing signs that &#xA;they have problems understanding even basic concepts of the topic).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="186" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" LastActivityDate="2014-01-05T10:14:23.833" CommentCount="2" />
./Posts.xml:1670:  <row Id="2761" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="2748" CreationDate="2014-01-07T11:11:44.447" Score="4" Body="&lt;p&gt;Some sites have a custom close reason to handle this kind of cases. For example, on &lt;a href=&quot;https://unix.stackexchange.com/&quot;&gt;Unix &amp;amp; Linux&lt;/a&gt;:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;Questions describing a problem that can't be reproduced and seemingly went away on its own (or went away when a typo was fixed) are off-topic as they are unlikely to help future readers.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I doubt that CSTheory gets enough questions of this type to warrant a custom close reason. If a question is about understanding a point in a research paper, then&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;either the point is a subtle one that others may miss as well (or the paper omitted a step of the proof), in which case the question is potentially useful to anyone reading the paper and should be answered and remain open;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;or the point is a basic one that the asker happened to miss but where other readers aren't likely to stumble, in which case closing as off-topic with a custom comment plus a comment to explain is fine.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Basically, I agree with what you did, except for one thing: don't use the words “too localized”, which is historical Stack Exchange jargon that most people won't understand. Write something like&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;This question concerns a basic point and is unlikely to be useful to future visitors, &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/2748/what-to-do-with-too-localized-questions&quot;&gt;therefore&lt;/a&gt; I am voting to close it.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="634" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:37:19.453" LastActivityDate="2014-01-07T11:11:44.447" CommentCount="0" />
./Posts.xml:1671:  <row Id="2762" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2014-01-13T20:44:51.627" Score="4" ViewCount="165" Body="&lt;p&gt;The 2014 Community Moderator Election is now underway!&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Community moderator elections have three phases:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Nomination phase&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Primary phase&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Election phase&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Most elections take between two and three weeks, but this depends on how many candidates there are.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Please visit the official election page at&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/election&quot;&gt;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/election&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;for more detail, and to participate!&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If you have general questions about the election process, or questions for moderator candidates, feel free to ask them here on meta -- just make sure your questions are tagged &lt;a href=&quot;/questions/tagged/election&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;election&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;election&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="-1" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" LastActivityDate="2014-01-28T22:04:33.030" Title="2014 Community Moderator Election" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;status-completed&gt;&lt;election&gt;&lt;moderators&gt;" AnswerCount="1" CommentCount="0" FavoriteCount="1" CommunityOwnedDate="2014-01-13T20:44:51.627" />
./Posts.xml:1672:  <row Id="2763" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2014-01-13T20:54:56.500" Score="5" ViewCount="205" Body="&lt;p&gt;In connection with the moderator elections, we will be holding a Q&amp;amp;A with the candidates.  This will be an opportunity for members of the community to pose questions to the candidates on the topic of moderation.  Participation is completely voluntary.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;The purpose of this thread was to collect questions for the questionnaire. The questionnaire is now live, and you may find it &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/2778/2014-moderator-election-qa-questionnaire&quot;&gt;here&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Here's how it'll work:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;During the nomination phase, (so, until January 20th at 20:00:00Z UTC, or 3:00 pm EST on the same day, give or take time to arrive for closure), this question will be open to collect potential questions from the users of the site. Post answers to this question containing any questions you would like to ask the candidates. Please only post &lt;em&gt;one question per answer&lt;/em&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;We, the Community Team, will be providing a small selection of generic questions. The first two will be guaranteed to be included, the latter ones are if the community doesn't supply enough questions. This will be done in a single post, unlike the prior instruction.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;This is a perfect opportunity to voice questions that are specific to your community and issues that you are running into at current.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;At the end of the phase, the Community Team will select &lt;strong&gt;up to 8 of the top voted questions submitted by the community&lt;/strong&gt; provided in this thread, to use in addition to the aforementioned 2 guaranteed questions. We reserve some editorial control in the selection of the questions and may opt not to select a question that is tangential or irrelevant to moderation or the election. That said, if I have concerns about any questions in this fashion, I will be sure to point this out in comments before the decision making time.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Once questions have been selected, a new question will be opened to host the actual questionnaire for the candidates, containing 10 questions in total.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;This is not the only option that users have for gathering information on candidates. As a community, you are still free to, for example, hold a live chat session with your candidates to ask further questions, or perhaps clarifications from what is provided in the Q&amp;amp;A.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If you have any questions or feedback about this new process, feel free to post as a comment here.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="6115" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" LastActivityDate="2014-01-28T22:04:58.000" Title="2014 Moderator Election Q&amp;A - Question Collection" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;status-completed&gt;&lt;election&gt;" AnswerCount="5" CommentCount="0" FavoriteCount="2" />

./Posts.xml:1682:  <row Id="2773" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="2767" CreationDate="2014-01-19T14:45:04.260" Score="8" Body="&lt;h2&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/users/657/neel-krishnaswami&quot;&gt;Neel Krishnaswami&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/h2&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="186" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" LastActivityDate="2014-01-19T14:45:04.260" CommentCount="3" CommunityOwnedDate="2014-01-19T14:45:04.260" />
./Posts.xml:1683:  <row Id="2774" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="2767" CreationDate="2014-01-19T20:19:01.077" Score="9" Body="&lt;h2&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/users/705/andrej-bauer&quot;&gt;Andrej Bauer&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/h2&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="77" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" LastActivityDate="2014-01-19T20:19:01.077" CommentCount="0" CommunityOwnedDate="2014-01-19T20:19:01.077" />
./Posts.xml:1686:  <row Id="2777" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="2767" CreationDate="2014-01-20T17:04:31.747" Score="2" Body="&lt;h2&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/users/30/aaron-sterling&quot;&gt;Aaron Sterling&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/h2&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="7884" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" LastActivityDate="2014-01-20T17:04:31.747" CommentCount="0" CommunityOwnedDate="2014-01-20T17:04:31.747" />
./Posts.xml:1687:  <row Id="2778" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2014-01-20T20:02:43.587" Score="9" ViewCount="323" Body="&lt;p&gt;In connection with the moderator elections, we are holding a Q&amp;amp;A thread for the candidates. Questions collected &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/2763/2014-moderator-election-qa-question-collection/&quot;&gt;from an earlier thread&lt;/a&gt; have been compiled into this one, which shall now serve as the space for the candidates to provide their answers. Due to the lack of submission count, we have selected all provided questions as well as our back up questions for a total of 10 questions.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;As a candidate, your job is simple - post an answer to this question, citing each of the questions and then post your answer to each question given in that same answer. For your convenience, I will include all of the questions in quote format with a break in between each, suitable for you to insert your answers. Just &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/revisions/3cd73cb5-df21-4957-90f7-e57c60fdea44/view-source&quot;&gt;copy the whole thing after the first set of three dashes&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Once all the answers have been compiled, this will serve as a transcript for voters to view the thoughts of their candidates, and will be appropriately linked in the Election page. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Good luck to all of the candidates!&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;hr&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;What is your personal view of the role of CSTheory: in particular, please post an answer to &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/2752/what-tcs-stackexchange-is-for-and-what-is-your-aim-in-participation&quot;&gt;Gil Kalai's question here&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;  &#xA;  &lt;p&gt;How would you deal with a user who produced a steady stream of valuable answers, but tends to generate a large number of arguments/flags from comments?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;  &#xA;  &lt;p&gt;How would you handle a situation where another mod closed/deleted/etc a question that you feel shouldn't have been?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;  &#xA;  &lt;p&gt;What is your personal view of the role that CSTheory should/will/does play in the greater TCS community?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;  &#xA;  &lt;p&gt;Practically, one of the most important roles of a moderator, is to decide which questions to close, if at all. There are several attitudes toward this problem. Do you think that referring specifically to the user who asks the question and his or her perceived capabilities (e.g., &quot;lack of mathematical maturity&quot;, as expressed by some moderators) is a legitimate reason (or part of a reason) for closing a question? Or should you judge a question only by its own merits?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;  &#xA;  &lt;p&gt;In your opinion, what do moderators do?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;  &#xA;  &lt;p&gt;A diamond will be attached to everything you say and have said in the past, including questions, answers and comments. Everything you will do will be seen under a different light. How do you feel about that?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;  &#xA;  &lt;p&gt;In what way do you feel that being a moderator will make you more effective as opposed to simply reaching 10k or 20k rep?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;  &#xA;  &lt;p&gt;We often get low quality or obsolete or chatty flags. Based on early discussions the moderators normally don't take any action and dismiss them as not requiring moderator intervention. Do you think we should continue this way or change the policy?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;  &#xA;  &lt;p&gt;This is one of my concerns about long term health of the site. Do you consider the primary goal of this Q&amp;amp;A site to be helping researchers in theoretical computer science and related fields to get help with their research?&lt;br/&gt;&#xA;  If you do how should we deal with persistent trouble making users who try to abuse the site for their own wishes? E.g. users who are not researchers in theoretical computer science or any related field and insist on posting questions/answers/comments that are off-topic by the site's policies, e.g. cranks that want to use the site to verify or draw attention to their attempts on famous open problems?&lt;br/&gt;&#xA;  How can we make sure the site will not be overridden by users who are not researchers so cstheory does not suffer the faith of other online open resources for researchers like Usenet groups? (Keep in mind that with the current amount of community participation in closing we are going to have very serious trouble if the number of such users with 3k+ reputation reaches 5).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="6115" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" LastActivityDate="2014-01-28T20:22:55.953" Title="2014 Moderator Election Q&amp;A - Questionnaire" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;election&gt;" AnswerCount="3" CommentCount="9" FavoriteCount="2" />
./Posts.xml:1691:  <row Id="2788" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="2778" CreationDate="2014-01-22T04:10:11.417" Score="9" Body="&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;What is your personal view of the role of CSTheory: in particular, please post an answer to &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/2752/what-tcs-stackexchange-is-for-and-what-is-your-aim-in-participation&quot;&gt;Gil Kalai's question here&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;As a graduate student, I find that in my studies and research I am only exposed to a certain small part of theoretical computer science. This website allows me to keep my finger on the pulse of other subfields and see what sort of questions are interesting others and how they think about certain problems. As such, I think cstheory is primarily a great way to bring the community together.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In the longer term, my hope is to use the &lt;a href=&quot;http://egtheory.wordpress.com/2013/09/15/algorithmic-lens/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;algorithmic lens&lt;/a&gt; as a viewpoint on other sciences and I hope others do so as well. If non-computer scientists start using tools from cstheory then this website (and its placement among other science and math websites in the SE network) could provide a great way for us to engage with them, and share our knowledge while figuring out what problems they want to use our tools to address.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;How would you deal with a user who produced a steady stream of valuable answers, but tends to generate a large number of arguments/flags from comments?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I would address the specific flags through comments, discuss with the other moderators, and if the behavior persists contact the user over chat. If direct communication with the user does not resolve the issue then I would consider a suspension for some amount of time and contact over email (if such means are available).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;How would you handle a situation where another mod closed/deleted/etc a question that you feel shouldn't have been?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I would contact the mod in private. If after a discussion we are still unsure of the decision then I would raise the question in meta for input from the community. However, I doubt this would come up since in my experience so far I have not seen closed questions for which I disagreed with closing.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;What is your personal view of the role that CSTheory should/will/does play in the greater TCS community?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In my answer to the first question, I described my views for this site in cstheory and the larger scientific community. I think we are already moving toward this organically, but it might help to show more clearly why cstheory is a worthwhile part of a researcher's workflow by generating more answers to lists like:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/q/784/1037&quot;&gt;Original proofs generated on the parent site&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;*&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/q/1257/1037&quot;&gt;References to cstheory in the literature&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;Practically, one of the most important roles of a moderator, is to decide which questions to close, if at all. There are several attitudes toward this problem. Do you think that referring specifically to the user who asks the question and his or her perceived capabilities (e.g., &quot;lack of mathematical maturity&quot;, as expressed by some moderators) is a legitimate reason (or part of a reason) for closing a question? Or should you judge a question only by its own merits?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I think it is important to judge questions by their own merit. The only time I would let my knowledge of the users previous activity affect my decision is if I am unsure about the questions. However, in these cases of being unsure, I will never act before the community voices their opinion.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;There is a special case of questions that accidentally capture a deeper issue, and are simple when read at a surface level but significant at a deeper level. In this case, I think it is important to engage with the user through comments to see if this deeper exploration will serve the user, or if they were just looking for the easy answer. This is often a judgement of the users &quot;mathematical maturity&quot;. If they were not looking for a deeper discussion, and the question is fine otherwise, I would consider migration to CS.SE.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;In your opinion, what do moderators do?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Moderators should interfere as little as possible with community self-governance, and act decisively only in clear cut cases where the community guidelines are already set. Moderators should also act as unbiased intermediaries in case of heated discussions and encourage good behavior by example.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;A diamond will be attached to everything you say and have said in the past, including questions, answers and comments. Everything you will do will be seen under a different light. How do you feel about that?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;It will not change how I ask or answer questions. However, I will actively take note to make sure my comments are always unbiased, constructive, and within community norms.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;In what way do you feel that being a moderator will make you more effective as opposed to simply reaching 10k or 20k rep?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The only differences I know is the binding vote and diamond (I guess there are also some drastic actions like suspension, but I will hopefully never have to use those). As someone that spends an unreasonable amount of time on the internet, the binding vote will allow me to act decisively and quickly in clear cut cases. Since &quot;close&quot; now means &quot;on hold&quot;, this will hopefully improve questions. The diamond will allow me to set a good example in my actions on the site.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;We often get low quality or obsolete or chatty flags. Based on early discussions the moderators normally don't take any action and dismiss them as not requiring moderator intervention. Do you think we should continue this way or change the policy?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I would encourage use of our third space (i.e. the chat room) to avoid some of the chatty discussions. However, otherwise I would leave the decision on this policy to more experienced moderators or the community (maybe we should raise a meta discussion on this?).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;This is one of my concerns about long term health of the site. Do you consider the primary goal of this Q&amp;amp;A site to be helping researchers in theoretical computer science and related fields to get help with their research?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;As I mentioned in my first answer, I see helping researchers with their research as only part of the goals of this site. I think it is also a way to communicate with other disciplines, and a way to build community. Further, it is a way for future researchers to keep an idea of what the community is interested in, and learn from reading others questions and answers.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;If you do how should we deal with persistent trouble making users who try to abuse the site for their own wishes? E.g. users who are not researchers in theoretical computer science or any related field and insist on posting questions/answers/comments that are off-topic by the site's policies, e.g. cranks that want to use the site to verify or draw attention to their attempts on famous open problems?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;We already have a &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/q/274/1037&quot;&gt;policy on crank-friendly preprints and topics&lt;/a&gt;, I will enforce this policy. I don't think we have gotten too many problems with cranky users, especially compared to other SE sites. We have a great community that already deals with this well.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;How can we make sure the site will not be overridden by users who are not researchers so cstheory does not suffer the faith of other online open resources for researchers like Usenet groups? (Keep in mind that with the current amount of community participation in closing we are going to have very serious trouble if the number of such users with 3k+ reputation reaches 5).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;We can make sure of this by continuing to ask great research-level questions and providing amazing answers. However, I do agree that the reputation mechanism on the site is broken and it is easy for a persistent user to accumulate reputation. These sort of users are unavoidable, and in most cases they don't cause much trouble. However, if a specific user continually upsets the community then I will proceed as in the &quot;large number of arguments/flags&quot; question: discuss with the user and community and suspend if necessary.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="1037" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" LastActivityDate="2014-01-22T04:10:11.417" CommentCount="1" />
./Posts.xml:1692:  <row Id="2789" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="2752" CreationDate="2014-01-23T03:41:48.227" Score="-7" Body="&lt;h2&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&lt;em&gt;personal&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/strong&gt; view on TCS &lt;em&gt;(.se)&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/h2&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;(T)CS is a wondrous, fascinating, beautiful, deep, vibrant field. came to it in preteens, heard about public key cryptography from a relative who clipped out an article from a newspaper on it. dad, a jr high school algebra teacher, brought home one of the 1st PCs, programmed bubble sort for &lt;a href=&quot;http://vzn1.wordpress.com/2013/12/02/joy-of-code-2013-natl-cs-edu-week-dec9-16/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&lt;em&gt;fun&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;,&lt;/a&gt; explained it to me and said &quot;its slow, it takes $n^2$ time to finish&quot;, and I pondered that concept like a deep zen mystery with beginners mind (before knowing what zen was). &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;in teens, wondered about shannons theorem about hard functions based on counting circuits. &lt;em&gt;and none of them can be&lt;/em&gt; &lt;strong&gt;&lt;em&gt;constructed&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;. we know they're there, but where are they? what an astonishing deep mystery, almost like a TCS analog of &lt;a href=&quot;http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dark_matter&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;dark matter&lt;/a&gt;! and not the only apparent deep parallel between &lt;a href=&quot;https://physics.stackexchange.com/a/89802/33566&quot;&gt;TCS &amp;amp; physics&lt;/a&gt;. and still basically open after more than ½-century. truly this field is full of the Everest of problems. &lt;em&gt;many or even most in pristine pre-summited state!&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;in college, learned/experimented/sought &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/14811/what-is-the-enlightenment-im-supposed-to-attain-after-studying-finite-automata&quot;&gt;FSM-enlightenment&lt;/a&gt; in an intriguing &lt;a href=&quot;http://vzn1.wordpress.com/code/collatz-conjecture-experiments/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;research-oriented attack&lt;/a&gt; on one mountain. climbed to a local minimum! also started experimenting with &lt;a href=&quot;https://cs.stackexchange.com/questions/6588/reducing-the-integer-factorization-problem-to-an-np-complete-problem/6605#6605&quot;&gt;SAT &amp;amp; factoring&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;there are many signs computer science is entering or in the middle of a (very long-range?) &lt;a href=&quot;http://cacm.acm.org/magazines/2013/2/160156-the-explosive-growth-of-postdocs-in-computer-science/fulltext&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;golden age&lt;/a&gt;, and thats motivating, energizing, even at times &lt;a href=&quot;http://vzn1.wordpress.com/2014/01/17/dwave-and-the-inception-of-the-qm-computing-dream/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;exciting&lt;/a&gt;. its a field-in-motion. cutting edge and an awesome, buzzing-crackling fusion of abstract theory and real-life application. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;so, a dream job for me would be high-paying TCS research/applications and have come close to that fantasy in real life over the years. but, later, after working 4 yrs in scientific laboratory alongside graduate students and Phds, realized that combination of terms might be verging mostly on an oxymoron; ie it seemed that scientific researchers (not just those in TCS) didnt seem to be (how to put this delicately) reknowned for their salaries.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;am proud to be a contributing part of a rare, unique group that captures some of this energy/momentum/dynamism esp in the way that it &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/19759/core-algorithms-deployed&quot;&gt;connects with applications&lt;/a&gt;. &#xA;(&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/application-of-theory&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;application-of-theory&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;application-of-theory&lt;/a&gt; is my favorite conceptual fusion/paradigm/site tag.) by some very hard work by many dedicated, farsighted, brilliant individuals, cstheory stackexchange is a really superb forum and by far the best venue on the entire cyberspace for that right now, and probably will be for years into the future. it mixes top achievers from academia with the wild open internet (another great/shearing &lt;em&gt;fusion&lt;/em&gt;).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;TCS is also in the midst and at the forefront of massive/pivotal decade-long shifts and transformations. eg quantum computing, &lt;a href=&quot;http://rads.stackoverflow.com/amzn/click/0691148902&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;electronic publishing/open science&lt;/a&gt;, &lt;a href=&quot;https://cs.stackexchange.com/questions/4768/references-on-collective-intelligence-with-respect-to-cs-applications&quot;&gt;collaborative filtering, collective wisdom, collective intelligence&lt;/a&gt; and amazingly the stackexchange site captures various key elements of all that.&#xA;am especially interested in &#xA;&lt;a href=&quot;http://vzn1.wordpress.com/volunteer/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;cyber collaboration&lt;/a&gt; possibilities seen in the groundbreaking &lt;a href=&quot;http://polymathprojects.org/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;polymath&lt;/a&gt; model, which is at heart in its radical/dramatic successes not that different than the &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.simonsfoundation.org/mathematics-and-physical-science/the-global-math-commons/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;stackexchange system&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;what is [great] TCS? how about simply listing my idiosyncratic personal TCS inspirations/influences/luminary/hero pantheon off the top of my head: &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.scs.gatech.edu/features/career-solution&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;Lipton&lt;/a&gt;, &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.cc.gatech.edu/features/fortnow&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;Fortnow&lt;/a&gt;, &lt;a href=&quot;http://rads.stackoverflow.com/amzn/click/3642245072&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;Jukna&lt;/a&gt;, &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.mathunion.org/general/prizes/nevanlinna/prize-winners/o/General/Prizes/Nevanlinna/1990/Razborov/page1.html&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;Razborov&lt;/a&gt;, &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.scottaaronson.com/blog/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;Aaronson&lt;/a&gt;, &lt;a href=&quot;http://link.springer.com/article/10.1007%2FBF02650179&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;Feynman&lt;/a&gt;, &lt;a href=&quot;http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shor&amp;#39;s_algorithm&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;Shor&lt;/a&gt;, Sedgewick, Knuth, &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.claymath.org/sites/default/files/pvsnp.pdf&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;Cook&lt;/a&gt;, &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/11797/alan-turings-contributions-to-computer-science&quot;&gt;Turing&lt;/a&gt;, &lt;a href=&quot;http://nautil.us/issue/0/the-story-of-nautilus/in-the-mind-of-the-fractal-king&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;Mandelbrot&lt;/a&gt;, &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/18968/what-are-the-popular-science-books-that-inspire-tcs&quot;&gt;Hofstadter&lt;/a&gt;, &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.wolframscience.com/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;Wolfram&lt;/a&gt;. etc! (of course not coincidentally several are members of cstheory!)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;oh, and yeah, (sssh, dont tell anyone), then theres my &lt;a href=&quot;http://vzn1.wordpress.com/2012/10/18/math-monster/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;favorite open problem&lt;/a&gt; of &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/174/major-unsolved-problems-in-theoretical-computer-science&quot;&gt;so many great ones too choose from&lt;/a&gt; Ive been interested for ~2½ decades even long before there was a &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.claymath.org/millennium-problems/millennium-prize-problems&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;huge incentive&lt;/a&gt;... &lt;em&gt;heaven forbid&lt;/em&gt; not claiming a &lt;em&gt;proof&lt;/em&gt; but have a &lt;a href=&quot;http://vzn1.wordpress.com/2012/12/08/outline-for-a-np-vsppoly-proof-based-on-monotone-circuits-hypergraphs-and-factoring/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;few new ideas&lt;/a&gt;!&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;speaking of zen, at rare times one might even think TCS can even reach &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/189/algorithms-from-the-book&quot;&gt;cosmic/transcendant/spiritual&lt;/a&gt; levels! (just had to somehow shamelessly work in the highest-voted question in this essay somehow!)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;hey, if theres still any question about my interest/engagement/affinity for this site, just browse/look at my huge &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/users/7884/vzn?tab=favorites&quot;&gt;favorites list&lt;/a&gt; sometime! due to the awesome stackexchange software [built by brilliant software engineers] it can even be searched by keyword eg &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/search?tab=votes&amp;amp;q=infavorites%3a7884%20%5bcc.complexity-theory%5d&quot;&gt;cc.complexity theory&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="7884" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:48:30.257" LastActivityDate="2014-01-23T04:40:20.670" CommentCount="6" />
./Posts.xml:1693:  <row Id="2790" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2014-01-24T19:02:30.437" Score="26" ViewCount="715" Body="&lt;p&gt;I decided to write this because of the comments posted in the &#xA;&lt;a href=&quot;http://chat.stackexchange.com/rooms/12464/theoretical-computer-science-2014-election&quot;&gt;election chat room&lt;/a&gt;. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Actually I agree with part what &lt;a href=&quot;http://chat.stackexchange.com/transcript/message/13370607#13370607&quot;&gt;Dilworth has written&lt;/a&gt;. &#xA;As I have told Suresh, Dave, and Shog9&#xA;I feel I use moderator powers more often than the community likes and &#xA;that is one of the main reasons I have decided to step down. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;But I think I have followed more or less &#xA;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/election/1#post-4481&quot;&gt;what I wrote when I nominated myself for becoming a moderator&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I firmly believed and believe that &#xA;cstheory is mainly for professional researchers in theoretical computer science. &#xA;I don't think I have ever been even slightly impolite towards any of them and &#xA;I have not used mod powers in dealing with any of them. &#xA;I have tried to follow the policies and the opinion of the community even when &#xA;I personally disagreed with it.&#xA;So I have been a minimalist moderator towards the target community of the site. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;But I don't think we should be welcoming at all to anyone &#xA;who clearly wants to abuse cstheory for purposes that &#xA;are likely to hurt the participation of professional researchers. &#xA;I have tried not to be rude even towards them &#xA;however I don't see any reason why we should be welcoming to cranks. &#xA;Rather I think we should not tolerate at all any crank who &#xA;clearly wants to abuse cstheory and &#xA;keeps annoying others with low quality comments and answers. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In my opinion we should have been much harsher in dealing with cranks and &#xA;that would have saved us &#xA;a lot of trouble and trolling by a particular crank &#xA;that hasn't shown much improvement in behavior over a long period of time and &#xA;despite our efforts.&#xA;In fact the abuser seems to interprets &#xA;the community's tolerance as support for his behavior and&#xA;has started bringing other cranks to the site and&#xA;go as far as nominating himself to become a moderator.&#xA;I think these clearly show the effect of tolerance on such abusers. &#xA;But since the community didn't wanted to deal with the user that way &#xA;I left it to other moderators to deal with him as they think is suitable.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Another contentious issue has been question closing. &#xA;The moderator closing vote replaces the normal user closing vote. &#xA;In other words, &#xA;a moderator cannot cast a non-binding close vote. &#xA;So as a moderator when I see a question that I think should be closed &#xA;I can either close it or do almost nothing and &#xA;it is quite difficult for me to do nothing about a question &#xA;that I think is off-topic. &#xA;If I could cast a non-binding vote I would prefer to do so but&#xA;the system doesn't support it.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;These are some of the main reasons &#xA;I have decided to step down as a moderator. &#xA;I still care about cstheory and &#xA;I am going to continue to actively participate on cstheory.&#xA;I think it is a very useful resource for connecting researchers &#xA;from different fields in theoretical computer science and &#xA;helps them with their research though&#xA;I think we have a long road till we reach where MO is. &#xA;We have many active users that can take on the job of moderation and &#xA;closer to what the community would like.&#xA;I hope that over the past 3 years I haven't disappointed &#xA;the community and those who voted for me &#xA;(at least not too much).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="186" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" LastActivityDate="2014-01-25T19:29:11.537" Title="Why I am stepping down" ./Posts.xml:1713:  <row Id="2813" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2014-03-04T18:23:53.143" Score="7" ViewCount="107" Body="&lt;p&gt;I just noticed the &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/trouble-with-paper&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;trouble-with-paper&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;trouble-with-paper&lt;/a&gt; tag. &#xA;It is a meta tag and I think it not a useful tag for for filtering or searching and &#xA;I think questions should stand alone and contain enough information to make sense independent of papers they may use as context. ./Posts.xml:1718:  <row Id="2818" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="502" CreationDate="2014-03-17T05:59:02.753" Score="2" Body="&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.mathoverflow.net/questions/1485/formatting-citations-to-the-literature-on-mathoverflow&quot;&gt;Citation Helper&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Adds a button for adding citations. ./Posts.xml:1719:  <row Id="2819" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2014-03-20T16:21:25.590" Score="6" ViewCount="201" Body="&lt;p&gt;For example, this question: &lt;a href=&quot;https://cs.stackexchange.com/questions/22864/lambda-calculus-difference-between-contexts-and-evaluation-contexts&quot;&gt;https://cs.stackexchange.com/questions/22864/lambda-calculus-difference-between-contexts-and-evaluation-contexts&lt;/a&gt; had two very thorough research-level answers, and was migrated to CS.SE. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="2185" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:48:30.257" LastActivityDate="2014-06-19T18:30:26.047" Title="Are we migrating too readily?" ./Posts.xml:1721:  <row Id="2821" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="25" CreationDate="2014-03-22T20:15:14.623" Score="0" Body="&lt;h3&gt;Asking questions like &quot;is my/this solution to P vs. NP correct&quot; is off-topic&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;(also applies to other famous open problems similar to P vs. NP)&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;cstheory is not a peer-review site. We don't check, verify, or discuss such solutions. If you think you have a solution send it to a journal or conference that peer-reviews such articles. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Keep in mind that most reputable ones have a policy similar to &lt;a href=&quot;http://jacm.acm.org/instructions/pnp&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;JACM's policy&lt;/a&gt;:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;No author may submit more than one paper to J. ACM, ACM Trans. on Algorithms, or ACM Trans. on Computation Theory  in any 24 month period,  purporting to resolve the P versus NP question or related long-standing questions in complexity theory, except by invitation of the Editor-in-Chief. This applies to resubmissions of previously rejected manuscripts.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;hr&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Related discussions&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/q/274/&quot;&gt;Policy on unverified solutions of famous open problems&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Related discussions on CS.SE:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cs.meta.stackexchange.com/q/109/&quot;&gt;How to deal with questions about crank-heavy topics?&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cs.meta.stackexchange.com/q/647/&quot;&gt;What constitutes an appropriate check-my-proof question?&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cs.meta.stackexchange.com/q/786/&quot;&gt;How to ask P vs NP questions without getting closed?&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Related discussions on MathOverflow:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.mathoverflow.net/q/1263&quot;&gt;Can I ask whether or not a paper that proves P=NP is correct?&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.mathoverflow.net/q/360&quot;&gt;What should be the policy on “open problems” on MO?&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="186" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-17T10:13:04.397" LastActivityDate="2014-03-22T20:15:14.623" CommentCount="0" CommunityOwnedDate="2014-03-22T20:15:14.623" />
./Posts.xml:1724:  <row Id="2824" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="2822" CreationDate="2014-03-25T16:58:12.133" Score="4" Body="&lt;p&gt;As &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/a/2823&quot;&gt;Artem Kaznatcheev notes&lt;/a&gt;, comments on Stack Exchange sites are really designed to be an ephemeral &quot;scratchpad&quot; for improving questions and answers.  They provide very limited markup options, they're not searchable (using the internal SE search; Google and other external search engines do index &lt;em&gt;some&lt;/em&gt; of them), and they're subject to deletion at any time for any or no reason.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The idea is that, once the question has been solved through discussion in the comments, the solution should be written up as an answer (or incorporated into an existing answer), crediting the contributors to the discussion as needed. At that point, the &quot;scratchpad&quot; comments are no longer needed, and may be deleted.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;No, it doesn't always work that way in practice, but that's the way it's designed to work.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;One thing you can do, to try and get a little closer to the ideal, is to occasionally go over your old answers and see if any of them have comments (written by you or someone else) that add value to the answer. If you spot any, edit the answer to incorporate the information directly into it (with appropriate credit, as needed). This ensures that, even if the comments are later deleted, the useful information in them will not be lost. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;You can also go over your old comments (available in your user profile, under &quot;activity&quot; &amp;rarr; &quot;comments&quot;) and see if any of them might be usefully turned into edits or stand-alone answers.  Also, if any questions you've asked have been effectively answered via comments, you can either summarize the conclusions into a self-answer (again, with appropriate credit, of course) or just ask the user who posted the most useful comment(s) to turn them into an answer.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In some cases, once the comments have been turned or edited into answers, you may also want to delete them (if they're yours) or flag them as obsolete (if not) immediately.  However, that's completely optional.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="8729" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.560" LastActivityDate="2014-03-25T16:58:12.133" CommentCount="10" />
./Posts.xml:1726:  <row Id="2826" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="2825" CreationDate="2014-03-30T16:29:22.803" Score="2" Body="&lt;p&gt;As phrased in your question, it is unlikely to be on-topic here. However, that doesn't mean questions about games are off-topic, with the famous counter-example being the one on the &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/q/6356/1037&quot;&gt;Super Mario Galaxy problem&lt;/a&gt;. Asking a question about 2048 would take some subtlety.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I would recommend asking non-research level questions on &lt;a href=&quot;http://cs.stackexchange.com&quot;&gt;CS.SE&lt;/a&gt;, but I would still suggest making sure first that you clarify all the words you use. The best questions are ones you tried solving yourself.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Finally, keep in mind that the above are my &lt;em&gt;opinions&lt;/em&gt; based on a feeling of what the community prefers and a guess at how you would ask a question based on the evidence I have. I could very well be wrong and the community might love your question, I know that a number of cstheory-folks enjoyed playing 2048.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="1037" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" LastActivityDate="2014-03-30T16:29:22.803" CommentCount="3" />

./Posts.xml:1731:  <row Id="2831" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="25" CreationDate="2014-04-03T22:59:38.230" Score="0" Body="&lt;h2&gt;cstheory polices&lt;/h2&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Policies are cstheory's laws &#xA;(in addition to general Stack Exchange policies &#xA;required to be followed by all sites on the Stack Exchange network).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Policies are passed by voting on meta.&#xA;Right now a policy requires 2/3 majority in favor with at least 5 up votes to pass.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Typically we start with a &lt;a href=&quot;/questions/tagged/discussion&quot; class=&quot;post-tag required-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;discussion&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;discussion&lt;/a&gt; question on meta.&#xA;When the discussion has received enough feedback &#xA;we move to the voting phase &#xA;by posting a &lt;a href=&quot;/questions/tagged/policy&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;policy&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;policy&lt;/a&gt; question.&#xA;The policy question must start with&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;This is a policy question. The proposed policy in the question (or answers) will be adopted in the case that after 7 days it receives at least 5 up votes with a 2/3 majority in favor. Please upvote or downvote this question based on your opinion of the policy statement as presented (not based on whether the premise of the question is reasonable).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;A policy post should contain a short summery of the discussion and a link to it. &#xA;It should be followed by the statement of the proposed policy:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;Policy Proposal ([DATE]): [STATEMENT OF THE POLICY]&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The title of the policy question should start with &quot;Policy:&quot;.&#xA;Typically the &lt;a href=&quot;/questions/tagged/featured&quot; class=&quot;post-tag moderator-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;featured&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;featured&lt;/a&gt; tag is added to the question by a moderator.&#xA;During the 7 days following the proposal users can vote for or against the policy.&#xA;After 7 days voting ends and the policy either is passed or is rejected.&#xA;A moderator tags the post accordingly with either &lt;a href=&quot;/questions/tagged/status-completed&quot; class=&quot;post-tag moderator-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;status-completed&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;status-completed&lt;/a&gt; or &lt;a href=&quot;/questions/tagged/status-declined&quot; class=&quot;post-tag moderator-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;status-declined&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;status-declined&lt;/a&gt;, and locks the question and its answers to preserve the votes, and removes the &lt;a href=&quot;/questions/tagged/featured&quot; class=&quot;post-tag moderator-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;featured&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;featured&lt;/a&gt; tag.&#xA;Users who want to propose a change to a policy should start a new discussion.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;During the voting period there can be suggestions for amendments or modifications.&#xA;If an amendment is passed a moderator will modify the policy question to add the passed amendments.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;For an example, please see &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/q/802/&quot;&gt;this policy&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="186" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.560" LastActivityDate="2014-04-03T23:21:09.897" CommentCount="0" CommunityOwnedDate="2014-04-03T22:59:38.230" />

./Posts.xml:1736:  <row Id="2836" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="2835" CreationDate="2014-04-21T14:59:54.217" Score="5" Body="&lt;p&gt;I think there are a few separate issues here, that perhaps should be handled differently depending on the behavior of the individual(s). I'll just focus on one that I've noticed (at least one other that I won't touch on is students, like Ryan's, asking homework problems under pseudonyms).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The surge I've noticed recently is primarily PilarLoof, HeloLobo, and Grid_y_Bill, who I suspect are all the same person (and others have expressed the same opinion), and have been posting questions more suitable for mathoverflow, often without any indication as to why they are relevant to CS, although a few of them seem to be. When asked why they chose cstheory.SE over MO, they gave essentially nonsensical responses. (BTW, I think we definitely &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/q/2691/129&quot;&gt;should open the migration path to mathoverflow&lt;/a&gt;, because of these questions. It would make them much easier to identify and deal with...)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In this case, I think it would be appropriate for the moderators to 1) determine if these pseudonyms are all in fact the same individual, and if so 2) ask for a good reason they keep using pseudonyms to post off-topic questions, and if there is not a good reason then, 3) take some sort of action.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;What sort of action? I could imagine several possibilities, though I don't know which of them are technically feasible with the current SE software:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;a) Ban the user (by which I mean the actual person, not just the username - perhaps by IP address as suggested by Saeed in the comments, or some other mechanism?)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;b) Ban the user (same as above) for a fixed period of time - e.g. 30 or 60 days&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;c) Put the user on &quot;probation&quot; (possibly for a fixed period of time). I imagine this would be something like: any of their questions must be approved by, say, 3 or 4 users with sufficient rep before the question appears on the site. This would be a pre-filtering approach to questions rather than the current post-filtering approach. If the user continued to abuse the site causing high rep users to spend lots of time rejecting off-topic questions, then more drastic action could be taken.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;d) Other suggestions...?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="129" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" LastActivityDate="2014-04-22T16:14:58.453" CommentCount="13" />
