./Posts.xml:1744:  <row Id="2844" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAnswerId="2896" CreationDate="2014-06-09T02:32:15.630" Score="6" ViewCount="847" Body="&lt;p&gt;This is a &quot;manners critique,&quot; and might be annoying to some users; however, I think it's important because I feel that from looking at the site, some users are being targeted for lacking the academic credentials of some of the other users.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;For example, in &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/1198/what-videos-should-everybody-watch?page=2&amp;amp;tab=votes#tab-top&quot;&gt;this&lt;/a&gt; discussion, a user named Craig Feinstein posts a (possibly off-topic) video of a P vs. NP proof.  Another user then calls him a &quot;crank.&quot;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I would like to strongly urge users to stop calling other users &quot;cranks.&quot;  The word crank is nearly always considered derogatory.  If you type &quot;crank meaning&quot; into Google, you will see both of these meanings (among others):&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;an eccentric person, especially one who is obsessed by a particular subject or theory.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;a bad-tempered person.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Referring to someone as either &quot;bad-tempered&quot; or &quot;eccentric&quot; is generally considered rude.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I would like to suggest that users who are seeking to make an observation about another user's &#xA;interests in mathematics or computer science use the word &quot;enthusiast&quot; instead of &quot;crank.&quot;  For example, if someone called another user a &quot;P vs. NP enthusiast,&quot; this would not be rude or considered bullying.  Telling a user that they are a crank is a form of harassment, and I do not believe that it is appropriate for any of these sites.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;My question is:  Do you agree with my (relatively straightforward) claims above, and that users should stop referring to each other as cranks or other derogatory terms?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Also:  Do you have any other suggestions on improving the atmosphere of cstheory to make it welcoming to all appropriate users, including people who are not professional academics?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="1338" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" LastActivityDate="2015-04-30T21:34:04.797" Title="Stop using the word &quot;crank&quot; on CStheory.se" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;" AnswerCount="3" CommentCount="23" FavoriteCount="2" />
./Posts.xml:1745:  <row Id="2845" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="2745" CreationDate="2014-06-11T20:03:59.130" Score="0" Body="&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.physicsoverflow.org&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;https://i.stack.imgur.com/TG2kD.png&quot; alt=&quot;PhysicsOverflow: a graduate-level upward physics site&quot;&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="20481" LastActivityDate="2014-06-11T20:03:59.130" CommentCount="0" CommunityOwnedDate="2014-06-11T20:03:59.130" />
./Posts.xml:1748:  <row Id="2848" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="2840" CreationDate="2014-06-18T13:39:40.767" Score="1" Body="&lt;p&gt;Yes.  This is a known consequence of the design of this feature, and the StackExchange team has indicated that they do not plan to fix it.  The issue is that they cache this number, and the cache gets out of date.  Also, they compute the total number of reviews, rather than the number that you personally can perform, because they don't want to compute it separately for each user, which can also cause the number to be inflated.  Computing the correct number for each user would be too computationally expensive, apparently.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;So, in summary: known defect, no plan to fix it.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;See &lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.stackexchange.com/q/230742/160917&quot;&gt;Notification for reviews shows way too many&lt;/a&gt; and &lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.stackexchange.com/q/230833/160917&quot;&gt;Modulate the review notification&amp;#39;s color to reflect changes, or make it dismissible&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="5038" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-20T10:29:37.593" LastActivityDate="2014-06-18T13:39:40.767" CommentCount="1" />
./Posts.xml:1750:  <row Id="2850" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAnswerId="2853" CreationDate="2014-07-01T04:43:23.387" Score="2" ViewCount="108" Body="&lt;p&gt;If I post a question on CS.SE and don't get an answer, is it OK to post the same question on TCS.SE after waiting a week or so?  In other words, is cross-posting on CS.SE and TCS.SE OK (rather than migrating) if there is a delay of a week between them?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I'm asking to see if I can clarify the policy, because I am confused.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;To be clear: I am not asking about simultaneous cross-posting.  I'm asking about cross-posting after a delay of a week, when the question didn't get an answer on the original site. I'm not talking about migrating a question or deleting the original one and posting it on a new site; I'm talking about cross-posting, where the question is open on both CS.SE and TCS.SE.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Here is what I have been able to find:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;The standard StackExchange policy is: it is not OK to cross-post the same question on multiple sites.  If you post it on one site and after a week or two don't get an answer, you can flag it to ask the moderators to migrate it, but you should not cross-post (not even after a week or two).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Source: &lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.stackexchange.com/q/64068/160917&quot;&gt;Is cross-posting a question on multiple Stack Exchange sites permitted if the question is on-topic for each site?&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Currently, the TCS policy says that it is OK to cross-post on TCS.SE and MathOverflow, if you post on one and don't get an answer even after waiting a week or so (and if you must cross-link the two).  However this doesn't say anything about other SE sites other than MathOverflow, so it's not clear if this applies more broadly.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Source: &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/a/231/5038&quot;&gt;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/a/231/5038&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;There was a proposal to change that policy to allow simultaneous cross-posting on TCS.SE and MO, but that proposal was marked status-declined (it was rejected).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Source: &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/q/673/5038&quot;&gt;Changing policy on crossposting&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Peter Shor points out that one of the close reasons says&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;Our &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/a/231/5038&quot;&gt;site policy&lt;/a&gt; prohibits &lt;strong&gt;&lt;em&gt;simultaneous&lt;/em&gt; crossposting&lt;/strong&gt;: it duplicates effort and fractures discussion. Crossposting is permitted after a week has passed without a satisfying answer elsewhere. When crossposting please summarize the relevant discussions from other sites in your question and link between the copies in both directions. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;This sure sounds like cross-posting after a delay is allowed.  On the other hand, when you click on the link to the &quot;site policy&quot;, the policy described at the link target actually only mentions MathOverflow, not other SE sites.  (I hadn't noticed this previously, because I don't have enough reputation to vote to close.)&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;CS.SE does not seem to have any special policy about this, and I can't find any discussion of this on Meta.CS.SE.  Therefore, I would assume that CS.SE abides by the standard StackExchange policy, by default.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Also, given the standard StackExchange policy and the impact on both sites, I would guess that probably cross-posting on two SE sites should only be allowed if both sites opt into a policy of allowing cross-posting.  CS.SE does not seem to have opted to allow cross-posting on CS.SE+TCS.SE, and since I can't find any clear evidence that TCS.SE has, either.  (It appears that before adopting the current policy regarding cross-posting on TCS.SE+MO, both TCS.SE and MO were consulted; however, I can't find any evidence of any consultation with CS.SE about cross-posting on CS.SE+TCS.SE.)&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;My conclusion: It's not clear to me what is allowed.  The information on the policy does not seem entirely self-consistent, to my eyes.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;So, what &lt;em&gt;is&lt;/em&gt; the current policy?  Is cross-posting on CS.SE and TCS.SE allowed, if you wait a week?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;And if this has not been previously addressed, what &lt;em&gt;should&lt;/em&gt; the policy be?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="5038" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-20T10:29:37.593" LastActivityDate="2014-07-03T05:59:47.490" Title="Is it OK to cross-post on CS.SE and TCS.SE, after a suitable delay?" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;questions&gt;&lt;cross-posting&gt;" AnswerCount="2" CommentCount="2" />
./Posts.xml:1751:  <row Id="2851" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="2850" CreationDate="2014-07-01T04:53:41.067" Score="0" Body="&lt;p&gt;If this has not been addressed before, here is my proposed policy (to allow others to vote on it): We should not allow cross-posting on CS.SE and TCS.SE.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Of course many people might like to get more attention by posting their question on as many places as possible, but that doesn't mean it's good for the community for that to happen.  It has some costs:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;It fragments discussion and answers.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Inevitably the two will diverge.  For instance, there might be a good answer on one but not the other.  Even if they are cross-linked, this makes it harder than necessary for others to discover the answer to the question.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;It makes it harder for others who have the same question to find the question and benefit from the answers we've built up.  Splitting answers across two pages dilutes the &quot;Google juice&quot; of both.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;These problems are explained well at &lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.stackexchange.com/q/64068/160917&quot;&gt;the StackExchange page on this issue&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Migration solves the above problems.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;However, migration has its own costs:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;If you migrate, the question disappears from the old site.  The old URL doesn't stop working -- it redirects to the location on the new site, so Google searches that turn up the old URL will still get you to the right place -- but search on the new site will no longer turn up the old question.  This makes it impossible for people who have the same question to find the old question by searching on the old site.  To find it, they'd have to either search on Google or search on the new site.  So, if the question was squarely within scope on the old site, this makes it harder to find the information.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;This means there are some pros and cons either way.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Weighing the pros and cons, I'd suggest we stick with the default StackExchange policy and prohibit cross-posting on CS.SE and TCS.SE (cross-posting shouldn't be allowed, not even if you wait a week or two for an answer and get nothing).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="5038" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-20T10:29:37.593" LastActivityDate="2014-07-01T16:03:33.137" CommentCount="4" />
./Posts.xml:1754:  <row Id="2854" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="2745" CreationDate="2014-07-20T15:05:37.990" Score="5" Body="&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://scirate.com/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;https://i.stack.imgur.com/LyjNt.png&quot; alt=&quot;SciRate&quot;&gt;&lt;/a&gt;     &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="5582" LastActivityDate="2014-07-20T15:05:37.990" CommentCount="1" CommunityOwnedDate="2014-07-20T15:05:37.990" />
./Posts.xml:1760:  <row Id="2861" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="2745" CreationDate="2014-09-06T22:59:17.113" Score="5" Body="&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://cs.stackexchange.com&quot;&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;https://i.stack.imgur.com/t2h5m.png&quot; alt=&quot;PL and Compilers on CS.SE&quot;&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="15393" LastEditorUserId="186" LastEditDate="2014-09-12T00:38:05.797" LastActivityDate="2014-09-12T00:38:05.797" CommentCount="0" CommunityOwnedDate="2014-09-06T22:59:17.113" />
./Posts.xml:1761:  <row Id="2862" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="2859" CreationDate="2014-09-10T05:05:21.170" Score="1" Body="&lt;p&gt;This is an intriguing idea.  Cool!  It seems like it would be a good experiment.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The tricky bit is to select the criteria for which questions would be shown.  I can see two plausible possibilities:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Alternative 1: Have a set of tags which are eligible for this, e.g., algorithms, complexity-theory, computability, undecidability, etc.  Any question with vote total of 10+ and with at least one tag in the whitelist would then be eligible to be shown on CSTheory.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;This might whittle down the list of questions to those that are related to theoretical computer science.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;However, it has the problem that many of the questions selected in this way will not be research-level.  There are a lot of questions on CS.SE with 10+ votes that are not research-level questions in theoretical computer science, and they might be unwelcome on CSTheory.  Take a look at the &lt;a href=&quot;https://cs.stackexchange.com/questions?sort=votes&quot;&gt;top questions on CS.SE&lt;/a&gt; sorted by vote total, or the &lt;a href=&quot;https://cs.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/complexity-theory?sort=votes&amp;amp;pageSize=50&quot;&gt;top questions on CS.SE with the complexity-theory tag&lt;/a&gt; and you'll see what I mean.  Only a small fraction of the highest-voted questions there would be a good fit for CSTheory; the majority would not be useful to display on CSTheory.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I looked at the top 50 highest-voted questions on CS.SE with the complexity-theory tag.  All of them have a vote total of 10 or higher.  By my own highly personal assessment, about 10 of them look like they would be good to display on the CSTheory.SE front page.  The others don't look like great candidates (they are elementary, of narrow interest, or were about proving NP-hardness of a specific problem and the question has already been solved).  A 20% hit rate isn't great.  But this is my own personal taste, and others may differ.  I encourage readers to do their own count, see what they get, and post their own evaluation.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Alternative 2: Allow moderators to select which questions are eligible for display in this way.  This could be indicated, for instance, via a moderator-only tag that's added to the question on CS.SE, which triggers it to be shown on CSTheory -- analogous to the &quot;featured&quot; tag.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;This would require some manual effort from moderators, but allows more control over which questions are displayed, and enables selecting questions which are research-level and which relate to theoretical computer science.  (A minor difficulty with using a special tag is that, if the question already has 5 tags, it may not be possible to add a 6th tag.)&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="5038" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:48:30.257" LastActivityDate="2014-09-12T00:50:54.580" CommentCount="3" />

./Posts.xml:1766:  <row Id="2867" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="2865" CreationDate="2014-09-18T23:36:14.610" Score="9" Body="&lt;p&gt;Like most of our other policies initially we copied the policy from MathOverflow. They were using it successfully for sometime. ([meta.MO] might be a better place to ask about it as MO is older and considerably larger than cstheory.)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;We do get spam and low quality answers from time to time but they are generally removed or heavily down-voted. There is also the fact that like other popular CW questions (it is &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/759/the-new-community-wiki-policy&quot;&gt;our policy&lt;/a&gt; that big-list questions must be turned into CW) we protect popular big-list questions. This adds a barrier for adding new answers. I think it is a reasonable barrier, in a sense we are saying that these questions are special and potentially problematic so they are required to pass higher standards. To post an answer you have to first show that you are contributing positively in a sense before being able to post your answer to a big-list question. The same applies informally to big-list questions, i.e. they are expected to pass a higher standard of quality otherwise they get several down-votes and/or closed as too broad. (So far those standards are left subjectively to users, I don't think we have discussed or spelled out a guideline on what we expect from big-list questions/answers.)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I should also add that some of these big-list questions are extremely useful. For example, I don't know any online/offline resource that is a better reference than &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/79/problems-between-p-and-npc&quot;&gt;this big-list question&lt;/a&gt; for NPI problems.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="186" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" LastActivityDate="2014-10-25T02:23:59.330" CommentCount="3" />
./Posts.xml:1768:  <row Id="2869" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="856" CreationDate="2014-10-06T22:39:25.463" Score="1" Body="&lt;p&gt;The link colors look different enough, I think.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;However, the &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/856/contrast-visited-unvisited-hyperlinks#comment2417_856&quot;&gt;core premise here&lt;/a&gt; (that we use visited/unvisited styles to indicate new answers on a post) is flawed. We don't.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;With that in mind, I suggest keeping an eye on the questions list (sorted by active, so posts with new edits/answers/etc float to the top) instead of relying on the link color.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="8005" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" LastActivityDate="2014-10-06T22:39:25.463" CommentCount="0" />

./Posts.xml:1770:  <row Id="2871" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="2870" CreationDate="2014-10-25T02:05:41.043" Score="3" Body="&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;There is nothing wrong per se with questions which don't have a single answer. Where have you got that idea? If you mean &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/big-list&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;big-list&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;big-list&lt;/a&gt; questions then yes, we allow them, for more information have a look at &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/2865/on-the-efficacy-of-big-list-questions&quot;&gt;On the efficacy of &amp;quot;Big List&amp;quot; questions&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Yes, as a research oriented site we have allowed things that might be problematic on other sites like SO. If you want a simple guide, we follow MO model than SO model. The reason is simple: we started the site with the goal of making something similar to MO for TCS, the communities are similar, etc. So if it is OK on MO it is probably OK here. Other SE sites don't matter that much for our policy decisions.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;See also &lt;a href=&quot;http://blog.stackoverflow.com/2010/09/good-subjective-bad-subjective/&quot;&gt;Good subjective, bad subjective&lt;/a&gt;. There is nothing wrong with asking &lt;em&gt;good&lt;/em&gt; subjective questions.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="186" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.560" LastActivityDate="2014-10-25T02:05:41.043" CommentCount="1" />
./Posts.xml:1771:  <row Id="2872" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2014-11-10T08:15:48.230" Score="1" ViewCount="103" Body="&lt;p&gt;To those who vote to close non-theoretical-computer-science questions: Thank you for tidying up the website, but when you do so, could you please choose the precise reason?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Sometimes new users post questions not in theoretical computer science but in other fields of study such as physics and more applied side of computer science.  Often many close-voters choose the following reason to close such questions:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;Your question does not appear to be a &lt;strong&gt;research-level&lt;/strong&gt; question in theoretical computer science. For more information about the scope, please see &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/help/on-topic&quot;&gt;help center&lt;/a&gt;.  Your question might be suitable for &lt;a href=&quot;https://cs.stackexchange.com/&quot;&gt;Computer Science&lt;/a&gt; which has a broader scope.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;While it might be technically correct, this reason is very misleading, particularly for those not familiar with theoretical computer science &lt;em&gt;such as the posters of those questions&lt;/em&gt;, because the bold part strongly suggests that the problem with the question is that it is not at the research level, whereas the real problem is that it is not a question in or about theoretical computer science.  (Moreover, the question might even be a research question in the field which it belongs to.)  If you are curious, &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/a/2700&quot;&gt;the message quoted above was proposed to be used when a question was not research-level&lt;/a&gt;, so it is an abuse of this reason by all means in my opinion.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;When you choose “off-topic” as the reason, you have an option to enter your custom reason instead of choosing one of the canned responses.  Please use it instead.  Unfortunately, a custom reason works differently from canned responses in that the custom reason is posted as a comment at the time you cast a vote, and I can imagine some circumstances in which you do not want to do this.  But usually this should be fine.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="567" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:48:30.257" LastActivityDate="2014-11-10T08:15:48.230" Title="The close reason used for non-theoretical-computer-science questions" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;vote-to-close&gt;&lt;close-reasons&gt;&lt;new-users&gt;" AnswerCount="0" CommentCount="6" />

./Posts.xml:1774:  <row Id="2875" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2015-01-01T03:19:35.050" Score="10" ViewCount="273" Body="&lt;p&gt;The dawn of a new year, 2015, now approaches, or has already approached, either way it means that it is now time to reset our Community Promotion Ads!&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;What are Community Promotion Ads?&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Community Promotion Ads are community-vetted advertisements that will show up on the main site, in the right sidebar. The purpose of this question is the vetting process. Images of the advertisements are provided, and community voting will enable the advertisements to be shown.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;Why do we have Community Promotion Ads?&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;This is a method for the community to control what gets promoted to visitors on the site. For example, you might promote the following things:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;cool site-related open source apps&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;the site's twitter account&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;cool events or conferences&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;anything else your community would genuinely be interested in&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The goal is for future visitors to find out about &lt;em&gt;the stuff your community deems important&lt;/em&gt;. This also serves as a way to promote information and resources that are &lt;em&gt;relevant to your own community's interests&lt;/em&gt;, both for those already in the community and those yet to join. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;Why do we reset the ads every year?&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Some services will maintain usefulness over the years, while other things will wane to allow for new faces to show up. Resetting the ads every year helps accommodate this, and allows old ads that have served their purpose to be cycled out for fresher ads for newer things. This helps keep the material in the ads relevant to not just the subject matter of the community, but to the current status of the community. We reset the ads once a year, every December.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The community promotion ads have no restrictions against reposting an ad from a previous cycle. If a particular service or ad is very valuable to the community and will continue to be so, it is a good idea to repost it. It may be helpful to give it a new face in the process, so as to prevent the imagery of the ad from getting stale after a year of exposure.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;How does it work?&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The answers you post to this question &lt;em&gt;must&lt;/em&gt; conform to the following rules, or they will be ignored. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;All answers should be in the exact form of:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;pre&gt;&lt;code&gt;[![Tagline to show on mouseover][1]][2]&#xA;&#xA;   [1]: http://image-url&#xA;   [2]: http://clickthrough-url &#xA;&lt;/code&gt;&lt;/pre&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Please &lt;strong&gt;do not add anything else to the body of the post&lt;/strong&gt;. If you want to discuss something, do it in the comments.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;The question must always be tagged with the magic &lt;a href=&quot;/questions/tagged/community-ads&quot; class=&quot;post-tag moderator-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;community-ads&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;community-ads&lt;/a&gt; tag. In addition to enabling the functionality of the advertisements, this tag also pre-fills the answer form with the above required form.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;Image requirements&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;The image that you create must be &lt;strong&gt;220 x 250 pixels&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Must be hosted through our standard image uploader (imgur)&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Must be GIF or PNG&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;No animated GIFs&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Absolute limit on file size of 150 KB&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;Score Threshold&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;There is a &lt;strong&gt;minimum score threshold&lt;/strong&gt; an answer must meet (currently &lt;strong&gt;6&lt;/strong&gt;) before it will be shown on the main site.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;You can check out the ads that have met the threshold with basic click stats &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/ads/display/2875&quot;&gt;here&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="6115" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.560" LastActivityDate="2015-11-02T11:52:00.670" Title="Community Promotion Ads - 2015" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;community-ads&gt;" AnswerCount="9" CommentCount="1" CommunityOwnedDate="2015-01-01T03:19:35.050" />
./Posts.xml:1775:  <row Id="2876" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="2875" CreationDate="2015-01-01T03:19:35.050" Score="7" Body="&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://twitter.com/StackCSTheory&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;https://i.stack.imgur.com/7wb56.png&quot; alt=&quot;Tagline to show on mouseover&quot;&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="6115" LastActivityDate="2015-01-01T03:19:35.050" CommentCount="1" CommunityOwnedDate="2015-01-01T03:19:35.050" />

./Posts.xml:1777:  <row Id="2878" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="2875" CreationDate="2015-01-01T22:36:06.817" Score="12" Body="&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://cs.stackexchange.com&quot;&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;https://i.stack.imgur.com/t2h5m.png&quot; alt=&quot;Theoretical and Applied Computer Science&quot;&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="634" LastActivityDate="2015-01-01T22:36:06.817" CommentCount="1" CommunityOwnedDate="2015-01-01T22:36:06.817" />
./Posts.xml:1778:  <row Id="2879" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAnswerId="2880" CreationDate="2015-01-06T01:47:35.157" Score="4" ViewCount="137" Body="&lt;p&gt;I post questions on this site which seems to annoy some people. I am sincerely trying my best to post quality research-level questions. For instance, this post, &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/27300/np-complete-problem-with-quasi-polynomial-bound-on-the-number-of-solutions&quot;&gt;NP-complete problem with quasi-polynomial bound on the number of solutions &lt;/a&gt; , has received 15 upvotes and 3 downvotes. ./Posts.xml:1810:  <row Id="2918" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2015-11-11T19:56:36.710" Score="2" ViewCount="107" Body="&lt;p&gt;Recently, I asked &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/33002/reduction-from-vertex-cover-to-max-cut&quot;&gt;this&lt;/a&gt; question on TCS.SE, but it was closed on the pretext that it was not a research-level question. However, I don't understand what makes it &quot;a not research-level question&quot;. It has got 6 upvotes, so at least 6 people find it interesting, and hopefully on-topic, though I know it's not a metric.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I am not asking a &quot;do my homework&quot; question like proving that Max-Cut is NP-complete. I am asking whether there exists a &lt;strong&gt;specific&lt;/strong&gt; reduction, i.e. from Vertex Cover to Max-Cut. I suppose if such a reduction exists, then it might give some insights on how some seemingly unrelated problems are related (and also, reductions are almost always fun!).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;So is there anyone else who feels that it's on-topic? ./Posts.xml:1812:  <row Id="2920" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="2918" CreationDate="2015-11-12T05:22:52.717" Score="4" Body="&lt;p&gt;If you want to understand the scope you can check our &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/help/on-topic&quot;&gt;help/on-topic&lt;/a&gt;.&#xA;It explains what we mean by research-level.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Your question is closed because 5 of users who can vote to close &#xA;voted to close the question as off-topic.&#xA;As Lev wrote questions at the level of &#xA;typical undergraduate textbook exercises are off-topic here.&#xA;The picture in the book is a hint that&#xA;the way to show that Max-Cut is NPC is to reduce Vertex Cover to it.&#xA;The question might be appropriate for &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/&quot;&gt;Computer Science&lt;/a&gt; which has a broader scope&#xA;but read check their help center to make sure you understand their policies.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="186" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.560" LastActivityDate="2015-11-12T05:22:52.717" CommentCount="0" />
./Posts.xml:1816:  <row Id="2924" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="1550" CreationDate="2015-12-23T01:32:29.217" Score="5" Body="&lt;p&gt;Now that both sites have graduated, let's revisit this request. I proposed &lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.stackexchange.com/q/261196/1438&quot;&gt;some criteria&lt;/a&gt; last summer (which we've been using internally for a while). My evaluation:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Sanity check: Yes, there are plenty of reasons a question might be asked here that really belongs on the more general CS site.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Gather statistics: In the past 90 days, there have been &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/tools/posts/migrated/stats&quot;&gt;6 migrations to and from CS Theory&lt;/a&gt;:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;pre&gt;&lt;code&gt;cs.stackexchange.com          =&amp;gt; cstheory.stackexchange.com × 4 (25% rejected)&#xA;datascience.stackexchange.com =&amp;gt; cstheory.stackexchange.com × 1&#xA;cstheory.stackexchange.com    =&amp;gt; cs.stackexchange.com × 1&#xA;&lt;/code&gt;&lt;/pre&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;This is underwhelming. It seems that in practice, people are pretty good about posting to CS when they have a non-research-level question. Just one question has been migrated away. It does not seem as if the moderators are being overwhelmed with migration flags. It's also instructive that there are few migrations the other direction. (A 25% rejection rate would be a red flag if it were not just one question.) &lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;So I don't see a lot of evidence that this path is needed. Looking at the &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/tools/question-close-stats?daterange=last90days&quot;&gt;close statistics&lt;/a&gt; it seems that the custom close reason that directs people to post to CS on their own is the prefered solution. 115 questions have been closed that way over the same time period. Now if the proportion &lt;em&gt;does&lt;/em&gt; shift toward migration and if those migrations are successful as a rule, we might have a reason to add this default path.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="16884" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.610" LastActivityDate="2015-12-23T01:32:29.217" CommentCount="6" />
./Posts.xml:1817:  <row Id="2925" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2016-01-15T03:26:53.213" Score="5" ViewCount="239" Body="&lt;p&gt;It's 2016 now, and we've &lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/272563/were-standardizing-the-sidebar-width-at-300px-on-all-sites&quot;&gt;made some changes to the sidebar size&lt;/a&gt;. As such, we can now restart the Community Promotion Ads for 2016!&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Keep in mind, we have updated some of the guidelines compared to previously - the changes are marked in bold in the Image Requirements section.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;What are Community Promotion Ads?&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Community Promotion Ads are community-vetted advertisements that will show up on the main site, in the right sidebar. The purpose of this question is the vetting process. Images of the advertisements are provided, and community voting will enable the advertisements to be shown.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;Why do we have Community Promotion Ads?&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;This is a method for the community to control what gets promoted to visitors on the site. For example, you might promote the following things:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;cool site-related open source apps&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;the site's twitter account&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;cool events or conferences&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;anything else your community would genuinely be interested in&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The goal is for future visitors to find out about &lt;em&gt;the stuff your community deems important&lt;/em&gt;. This also serves as a way to promote information and resources that are &lt;em&gt;relevant to your own community's interests&lt;/em&gt;, both for those already in the community and those yet to join. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;Why do we reset the ads every year?&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Some services will maintain usefulness over the years, while other things will wane to allow for new faces to show up. Resetting the ads every year helps accommodate this, and allows old ads that have served their purpose to be cycled out for fresher ads for newer things. This helps keep the material in the ads relevant to not just the subject matter of the community, but to the current status of the community. We reset the ads once a year, every December.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The community promotion ads have no restrictions against reposting an ad from a previous cycle. If a particular service or ad is very valuable to the community and will continue to be so, it is a good idea to repost it. It may be helpful to give it a new face in the process, so as to prevent the imagery of the ad from getting stale after a year of exposure.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;How does it work?&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The answers you post to this question &lt;em&gt;must&lt;/em&gt; conform to the following rules, or they will be ignored. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;All answers should be in the exact form of:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;pre&gt;&lt;code&gt;[![Tagline to show on mouseover][1]][2]&#xA;&#xA;   [1]: http://image-url&#xA;   [2]: http://clickthrough-url &#xA;&lt;/code&gt;&lt;/pre&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Please &lt;strong&gt;do not add anything else to the body of the post&lt;/strong&gt;. If you want to discuss something, do it in the comments.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;The question must always be tagged with the magic &lt;a href=&quot;/questions/tagged/community-ads&quot; class=&quot;post-tag moderator-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;community-ads&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;community-ads&lt;/a&gt; tag. In addition to enabling the functionality of the advertisements, this tag also pre-fills the answer form with the above required form.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;Image requirements&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;The image that you create must be &lt;strong&gt;300 x 250 pixels&lt;/strong&gt;, or double that if high DPI.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Must be hosted through our standard image uploader (imgur)&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Must be GIF or PNG&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;No animated GIFs&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Absolute limit on file size of &lt;strong&gt;150 KB&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;strong&gt;If the background of the image is white or partially white, there must be a 1px border (2px if high DPI) surrounding it.&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;Score Threshold&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;There is a &lt;strong&gt;minimum score threshold&lt;/strong&gt; an answer must meet (currently &lt;strong&gt;6&lt;/strong&gt;) before it will be shown on the main site.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;You can check out the ads that have met the threshold with basic click stats &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/ads/display/2925&quot;&gt;here&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="6115" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-20T10:29:37.593" LastActivityDate="2016-02-26T18:43:03.627" Title="Community Promotion Ads - 2016" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;community-ads&gt;" AnswerCount="8" CommentCount="1" />

./Posts.xml:1833:  <row Id="2942" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="2941" CreationDate="2016-04-28T18:48:26.363" Score="5" Body="&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;What is the policy of StackExchange on spam posts?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;They should be flagged as spam, as described in &lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.stackexchange.com/q/58032&quot;&gt;What are the “spam” and “rude or abusive” (offensive) flags, and how do they work?&lt;/a&gt; A post that gets 6 spam flags from ordinary users, or 1 spam flag from a moderator, is deleted, locked, &quot;censored&quot; (hidden even from 10K users, unless they look at revision history), and most importantly, the author is blocked from posting again. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;It's important to keep in mind the Stack Exchange definition of spam: an advertisement/promotion of some sort, as elaborated in the linked post. A &quot;low quality non-research question&quot; is not spam.  &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;How should we deal with users that intentionally post many off-topic posts? &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Close &lt;em&gt;and&lt;/em&gt; downvote their posts. They will be either blocked or at least slowed down by the system: &lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.stackexchange.com/q/243460&quot;&gt;Rolling question rate limits are now network-wide&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerDisplayName="user30448" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-20T10:29:37.593" LastActivityDate="2016-04-28T18:48:26.363" CommentCount="2" />

./Posts.xml:1841:  <row Id="2950" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAnswerId="2951" CreationDate="2016-07-01T18:13:16.643" Score="9" ViewCount="152" Body="&lt;p&gt;When I ask questions of the form &quot;what is the complexity of problem BLAH&quot;, then there is an ambiguity (to me) about whether an accepted answer should simply give the best known bounds according to current literature, or whether I shouldn't accept an answer until the exact complexity has been nailed (which may require an original proof).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In particular I am not sure what to do about answers that say that the problem is open. In a sense, these answers solve my problem, as they tell me that the question is already known to be tricky and is not so likely to be answered in the near future. On the other hand, they do not give the answer that I am interested in, and could be ultimately replaced by a more definitive answer. &lt;strong&gt;Should such answers be accepted?&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Here are some examples:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;In &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/35942/complexity-of-testing-if-a-hypergraph-has-generalized-hypertreewidth-2&quot;&gt;this question&lt;/a&gt;, I asked about the complexity of a problem, and an author of the most relevant  paper on the topic answered that he did not know. This answer is of course very useful, but I do not know whether I should accept it.  &lt;em&gt;(Update: meanwhile, a new answer has been posted, so the description here no longer makes sense)&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;In &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/32505/is-it-still-open-to-determine-the-complexity-of-computing-the-treewidth-of-plana&quot;&gt;that question&lt;/a&gt;, I accepted an answer saying that the problem was still open. I guess this is reasonable as my question was asking &quot;is the problem still open&quot;.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;(Sorry if this isn't the right kind of questions for meta.CS.SE. I'm not familiar with the meta sites.)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="4795" LastEditorUserId="4795" LastEditDate="2016-11-29T13:30:16.590" LastActivityDate="2016-11-29T13:30:16.590" Title="Should I accept an answer stating that the question is an open problem?" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;" AnswerCount="2" CommentCount="0" />
./Posts.xml:1847:  <row Id="2956" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2016-10-17T16:09:33.457" Score="10" ViewCount="214" Body="&lt;p&gt;StackExchange is looking to discontinue &lt;em&gt;all&lt;/em&gt; community blogs, including &lt;a href=&quot;http://cstheory.blogoverflow.com&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;our own&lt;/a&gt;. They are asking what we want to be done with our old posts (for example, migration to 3rd parties). &lt;strong&gt;Does anybody have opinions on this?&lt;/strong&gt; I am interested in the opinion of post authors and the editors, in particular.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Our blog hasn't seen new posts in over 4 years, and is unlikely to see new ones at this rate. However, I know that a &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/a/22226/1037&quot;&gt;number of us&lt;/a&gt; run our own active blogs. So we might be interested in migrating our posts. For example, I have migrated/adapted my two posts on &lt;a href=&quot;https://egtheory.wordpress.com/2013/12/09/quantum-query-complexity/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;quantum query complexity&lt;/a&gt; (&lt;a href=&quot;http://cstheory.blogoverflow.com/2011/07/quantum-query-complexity/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;original&lt;/a&gt;) and the &lt;a href=&quot;https://egtheory.wordpress.com/2013/12/16/negative-adversary-method/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;negative adversary method&lt;/a&gt; (&lt;a href=&quot;http://cstheory.blogoverflow.com/2011/08/lower-bounds-by-negative-adversary-method/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;original&lt;/a&gt;) over to my own blog nearly three years ago. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;As a possible option, the blog I run -- &lt;a href=&quot;https://egtheory.wordpress.com&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;TheEGG&lt;/a&gt; -- is a community project and has over 18 contributors. I would be happy to welcome any of the non-time specific (i.e. not the old conference announcements/dissections) posts over to my blog if their authors don't run their own blogs (or think it fits poorly with their more narrow theme). I would stagger their (re)release over the coming weeks. If they are interested, I might make slight stylistic edit suggestions to the respective authors to make their post(s) fit better with TheEGG's readership. If you are interested in having your post go this route, either respond in the comments here or email me at: lastname (dot) firstname (at) gmail (dot) com.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;As a second, low effort, option: We can simply convert the blog to static pages that would remain on servers that SE manages.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="1037" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:32:31.537" LastActivityDate="2017-10-29T04:13:03.410" Title="What do we want to do about blog being discontinued?" ./Posts.xml:1848:  <row Id="2959" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2016-11-21T23:55:01.770" Score="9" ViewCount="135" Body="&lt;p&gt;Based on &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/q/2949/5038&quot;&gt;earlier feedback&lt;/a&gt;, I'm creating this thread to advertise questions on CS.SE that would be interesting to this community and haven't received an answer.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Guidelines:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Each answer should link directly to a &lt;strong&gt;single question&lt;/strong&gt; on CS.SE that has not been adequately answered and that &lt;strong&gt;would be of interest&lt;/strong&gt; to this community.  In particular, the question should be research-level and related to theoretical computer science.  Also, make sure the question has remained open on CS.SE for a significant period of time with no answer (say, at least two weeks).  Don't re-post a question that's an already well-known open problem or has already been re-posted on CSTheory.SE.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Each answer should include a &lt;strong&gt;short summary&lt;/strong&gt; of the question asked. There's no need to repost the CS.SE question verbatim, but it should be fairly clear what the question is about without following the link.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Feel free to &lt;strong&gt;downvote and vote-to-delete suggestions that aren't &quot;up to snuff&quot;&lt;/strong&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Don't abuse this thread&lt;/strong&gt;.  Abusing this thread is an easy way to ensure it is closed/deleted. This thread will stay open only as long as the CSTheory community feels it serves a useful purpose.  For instance, don't post links to CS.SE questions that are essentially homework exercises, not research level, or not within our scope.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="5038" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.613" LastActivityDate="2019-05-04T16:34:14.450" Title="Interesting unanswered questions on CS.SE" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;other-se-sites&gt;" AnswerCount="2" CommentCount="0" />
./Posts.xml:1849:  <row Id="2960" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="2959" CreationDate="2016-11-26T22:55:00.033" Score="4" Body="&lt;p&gt;I nominate this question:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cs.stackexchange.com/questions/54990/filling-bins-with-balls&quot;&gt;Filling bins with balls&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The question can be seen as an assignment problem to SAT with only 2 literals for each variable, one negated and the other positive. The question asks what is the minimum subset of clauses that have $k$ or more satisfied literals in an assignment of the formula (not necessarily an assignment that satisfies the formula). &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="28688" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-04-13T12:48:30.257" LastActivityDate="2016-11-26T23:34:01.803" CommentCount="0" />
./Posts.xml:1850:  <row Id="2961" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2016-12-12T02:45:28.190" Score="3" ViewCount="58" Body="&lt;p&gt;There are several questions that are officially &quot;unanswered,&quot; but which were effectively answered in the comments. For example, &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/5463/can-one-amplify-p-np-beyond-p-ph&quot;&gt;this one&lt;/a&gt; was answered by Russell Impagliazzo in the comments. It's been a long time (~5 years), and no better answer is forthcoming. It's a little annoying that this question still appears as &quot;Unanswered.&quot; Yet I don't feel comfortable just posting Russell's answer, because then any upvotes it received would go to me instead of Russell. I could of course post a CW answer to avoid getting upvotes myself, but then it precludes Russell from ever posting an answer and getting upvotes. ./Posts.xml:1852:  <row Id="2963" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2017-02-02T14:01:21.693" Score="3" ViewCount="96" Body="&lt;p&gt;It is a bit late into this new year, being that we're already in the second month, but we are now cycling the Community Promotion Ads for 2017!&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;What are Community Promotion Ads?&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Community Promotion Ads are community-vetted advertisements that will show up on the main site, in the right sidebar. The purpose of this question is the vetting process. Images of the advertisements are provided, and community voting will enable the advertisements to be shown.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;Why do we have Community Promotion Ads?&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;This is a method for the community to control what gets promoted to visitors on the site. For example, you might promote the following things:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;the site's twitter account&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;cool events or conferences&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;anything else your community would genuinely be interested in&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The goal is for future visitors to find out about &lt;em&gt;the stuff your community deems important&lt;/em&gt;. This also serves as a way to promote information and resources that are &lt;em&gt;relevant to your own community's interests&lt;/em&gt;, both for those already in the community and those yet to join. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;Why do we reset the ads every year?&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Some services will maintain usefulness over the years, while other things will wane to allow for new faces to show up. Resetting the ads every year helps accommodate this, and allows old ads that have served their purpose to be cycled out for fresher ads for newer things. This helps keep the material in the ads relevant to not just the subject matter of the community, but to the current status of the community. We reset the ads once a year, every December.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The community promotion ads have no restrictions against reposting an ad from a previous cycle. If a particular service or ad is very valuable to the community and will continue to be so, it is a good idea to repost it. It may be helpful to give it a new face in the process, so as to prevent the imagery of the ad from getting stale after a year of exposure.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;How does it work?&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The answers you post to this question &lt;em&gt;must&lt;/em&gt; conform to the following rules, or they will be ignored. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;All answers should be in the exact form of:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;pre&gt;&lt;code&gt;[![Tagline to show on mouseover][1]][2]&#xA;&#xA;   [1]: http://image-url&#xA;   [2]: http://clickthrough-url &#xA;&lt;/code&gt;&lt;/pre&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Please &lt;strong&gt;do not add anything else to the body of the post&lt;/strong&gt;. If you want to discuss something, do it in the comments.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;The question must always be tagged with the magic &lt;a href=&quot;/questions/tagged/community-ads&quot; class=&quot;post-tag moderator-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;community-ads&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;community-ads&lt;/a&gt; tag. In addition to enabling the functionality of the advertisements, this tag also pre-fills the answer form with the above required form.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;Image requirements&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;The image that you create must be 300 x 250 pixels, or double that if high DPI.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Must be hosted through our standard image uploader (imgur)&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Must be GIF or PNG&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;No animated GIFs&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Absolute limit on file size of 150 KB&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;If the background of the image is white or partially white, there must be a 1px border (2px if high DPI) surrounding it.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;Score Threshold&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;There is a &lt;strong&gt;minimum score threshold&lt;/strong&gt; an answer must meet (currently &lt;strong&gt;6&lt;/strong&gt;) before it will be shown on the main site.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;You can check out the ads that have met the threshold with basic click stats &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/ads/display/2963&quot;&gt;here&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="6115" LastEditorUserId="-1" LastEditDate="2017-03-16T15:45:13.560" LastActivityDate="2017-06-17T17:34:28.757" Title="Community Promotion Ads - 2017" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;community-ads&gt;" AnswerCount="4" CommentCount="0" />

As a community, you are still free to, for example, hold a live chat session with your candidates to ask further questions, or perhaps clarifications from what is provided in the Q&amp;amp;A.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If you have any questions or feedback about this process, feel free to post as a comment here.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="6115" LastEditorUserId="6115" LastEditDate="2017-09-25T20:06:08.293" LastActivityDate="2017-09-25T20:06:08.293" Title="2017 Moderator Election Q&amp;A - Question Collection" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;election&gt;" AnswerCount="5" CommentCount="0" />
./Posts.xml:1872:  <row Id="2984" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2017-09-25T20:04:55.657" Score="8" ViewCount="167" Body="&lt;p&gt;In connection with the moderator elections, we are holding a Q&amp;amp;A thread for the candidates. For your convenience, I will include all of the questions in quote format with a break in between each, suitable for you to insert your answers. Just &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/revisions/695d761f-f398-443e-992e-d0712ff0a380/view-source&quot;&gt;copy the whole thing after the first set of three dashes&lt;/a&gt;.Please consider putting your name at the top of your post so that readers will know who you are before they finish reading everything you have written, and also including a link to your answer on your nomination post.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Once all the answers have been compiled, this will serve as a transcript for voters to view the thoughts of their candidates, and will be appropriately linked in the Election page.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Good luck to all of the candidates!&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Oh, and when you've completed your answer, please provide a link to it after this blurb here, before that set of three dashes. Please leave the list of links in the order of submission.&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;To save scrolling here are links to the submissions from each candidate (in order of submission):&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;hr&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;ol&gt;&#xA;  &lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;How would you deal with a user who produced a steady stream of valuable answers, but tends to generate a large number of arguments/flags from comments?&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;  &lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;How would you handle a situation where another mod closed/deleted/etc a question that you feel shouldn't have been?&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;  &lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Are there any current moderator practices you would like to see changed? Are there any things you would do differently?&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;  &lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;How do you plan to handle flags on comments? Generally speaking, should comments that are obsolete or resolved be deleted, or should they be kept around to preserve the history of the conversation? Should back-and-forth discussion in the comments be deleted, moved to chat, or retained?&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;  &lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;What is your stance on migration from and to &lt;a href=&quot;https://cs.stackexchange.com&quot;&gt;Computer Science Stack Exchange&lt;/a&gt;, respectively?&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;  &lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Why do you think you would make a good moderator for this site? In your opinion, what do moderators do?&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;  &lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;A diamond will be attached to everything you say and have said in the past, including questions, answers and comments. Everything you will do will be seen under a different light. How do you feel about that?&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;  &lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;In what way do you feel that being a moderator will make you more effective as opposed to simply reaching 10k or 20k rep?&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;  &lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="6115" LastEditorUserId="4352" LastEditDate="2017-10-09T20:48:56.663" LastActivityDate="2017-10-09T20:48:56.663" Title="2017 Moderator Election Q&amp;A - Questionnaire" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;election&gt;" AnswerCount="0" CommentCount="2" FavoriteCount="1" />
./Posts.xml:1873:  <row Id="2985" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2017-09-25T20:12:12.653" Score="6" ViewCount="122" Body="&lt;p&gt;The 2017 Community Moderator Election is now underway!&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Community moderator elections have three phases:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Nomination phase&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Primary phase&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Election phase&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Most elections take between two and three weeks, but this depends on how many candidates there are.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Please visit the official election page at&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/election&quot;&gt;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/election&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;for more detail, and to participate!&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If you have general questions about the election process, or questions for moderator candidates, feel free to ask them here on meta -- just make sure your questions are tagged &lt;a href=&quot;/questions/tagged/election&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;election&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;election&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="-1" LastActivityDate="2017-09-25T20:12:12.653" Title="2017 Community Moderator Election" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;moderators&gt;&lt;election&gt;" AnswerCount="0" CommentCount="3" CommunityOwnedDate="2017-09-25T20:12:12.653" />
./Posts.xml:1874:  <row Id="2986" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAnswerId="2987" CreationDate="2017-09-27T12:57:18.413" Score="1" ViewCount="42" Body="&lt;p&gt;The election page is suppposed to send us here to Meta, but the link is bad:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;pre&gt;&lt;code&gt;https://cstheory.meta.com/tags/election&#xA;&lt;/code&gt;&lt;/pre&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://i.stack.imgur.com/3F0xo.png&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;https://i.stack.imgur.com/3F0xo.png&quot; alt=&quot;enter image description here&quot;&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="1546" LastEditorUserId="8005" LastEditDate="2017-09-27T18:03:28.717" LastActivityDate="2017-09-27T18:03:40.013" Title="Election page sends us to nirvana instead of meta" Tags="&lt;bug&gt;&lt;status-completed&gt;&lt;election&gt;" AnswerCount="1" CommentCount="0" />
./Posts.xml:1876:  <row Id="2989" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2017-10-02T16:58:34.283" Score="8" ViewCount="267" Body="&lt;p&gt;In about 3 hours, &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/election?cb=1&quot;&gt;the nomination phase of the moderator elections&lt;/a&gt; is scheduled to end. However, in order for the election to proceed, it is necessary to have at least one more candidate running than there are slots. This allows for there to be actual voting phases, so that the community can actually show that they support the candidates who are running. Should there not be enough candidates, the nomination phase will instead be extended for another 7 days. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;We need leadership to come from within this community, the election can't move forward unless there's enough folks stepping up to take responsibility. Did you consider nominating but decided not to for some reason? Now would be a great time to reconsider! &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="6115" LastEditorUserId="4352" LastEditDate="2017-10-09T20:48:51.567" LastActivityDate="2017-10-09T20:48:51.567" Title="2017 Moderator Election - We need more candidates!" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;election&gt;" AnswerCount="0" CommentCount="14" />
./Posts.xml:1877:  <row Id="2990" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2017-10-09T19:44:56.860" Score="13" ViewCount="264" Body="&lt;p&gt;We regret to inform that due to insufficient nominating candidates, we are currently terminating the ongoing election here on Theoretical Computer Science Stack Exchange. Thank you to Bjørn Kjos-Hanssen for having stood up as a candidate in this session. However, as &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/2989/2017-moderator-election-we-need-more-candidates&quot;&gt;explained previously&lt;/a&gt;, in order for an election to proceed to voting phases it is required that there is at least one more candidate than there are spaces remaining in the election. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;This is important for a variety of reasons. The first is that it allows the election process to proceed in a way that allows candidates to be evaluated before being elected. It also serves to indicate that there are enough people in the community who are willing to handle the responsibilities of overseeing moderation.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;hr&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Theoretical Computer Science is not a site that's particularly in danger of low moderation. There's a healthy number of regular users across most reputation brackets who remain active on the site, still handling general moderation tasks.  The flag load itself isn't particularly large, and the current moderation team has expressed that they aren't overwhelmed by it. However, only one of the current moderators is highly active - while this is sufficient for the current flag load, it is healthier for the site to have multiple active moderators, not only to split even the small loads but also to handle situations where one of the moderators may have more pressing matters to attend.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;It could be that now is just not a good time to have hosted an election for this site. The winter holidays are coming up soon, as well, which will mess up with future election timings, so we'll most likely look at some elections coming into the new year. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="6115" LastActivityDate="2017-10-09T19:44:56.860" Title="2017 Moderator Election has been cancelled" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;election&gt;" AnswerCount="0" CommentCount="2" />
./Posts.xml:1879:  <row Id="2993" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2018-01-29T05:08:14.643" Score="6" ViewCount="48" Body="&lt;p&gt;It's almost February in 2018, which isn't supposed to be the proper time to cycle these, but for this year it'll be once again, so we'll be refreshing the &lt;strong&gt;Community Promotion Ads&lt;/strong&gt; for this year now!&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;What are Community Promotion Ads?&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Community Promotion Ads are community-vetted advertisements that will show up on the main site, in the right sidebar. The purpose of this question is the vetting process. Images of the advertisements are provided, and community voting will enable the advertisements to be shown.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;Why do we have Community Promotion Ads?&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;This is a method for the community to control what gets promoted to visitors on the site. For example, you might promote the following things:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;the site's twitter account&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;cool events or conferences&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;anything else your community would genuinely be interested in&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The goal is for future visitors to find out about &lt;em&gt;the stuff your community deems important&lt;/em&gt;. This also serves as a way to promote information and resources that are &lt;em&gt;relevant to your own community's interests&lt;/em&gt;, both for those already in the community and those yet to join. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;Why do we reset the ads every year?&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Some services will maintain usefulness over the years, while other things will wane to allow for new faces to show up. Resetting the ads every year helps accommodate this, and allows old ads that have served their purpose to be cycled out for fresher ads for newer things. This helps keep the material in the ads relevant to not just the subject matter of the community, but to the current status of the community. We reset the ads once a year, every December.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The community promotion ads have no restrictions against reposting an ad from a previous cycle. If a particular service or ad is very valuable to the community and will continue to be so, it is a good idea to repost it. It may be helpful to give it a new face in the process, so as to prevent the imagery of the ad from getting stale after a year of exposure.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;How does it work?&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The answers you post to this question &lt;em&gt;must&lt;/em&gt; conform to the following rules, or they will be ignored. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;All answers should be in the exact form of:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;pre&gt;&lt;code&gt;[![Tagline to show on mouseover][1]][2]&#xA;&#xA;   [1]: http://image-url&#xA;   [2]: http://clickthrough-url &#xA;&lt;/code&gt;&lt;/pre&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Please &lt;strong&gt;do not add anything else to the body of the post&lt;/strong&gt;. If you want to discuss something, do it in the comments.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;The question must always be tagged with the magic &lt;a href=&quot;/questions/tagged/community-ads&quot; class=&quot;post-tag moderator-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;community-ads&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;community-ads&lt;/a&gt; tag. In addition to enabling the functionality of the advertisements, this tag also pre-fills the answer form with the above required form.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;Image requirements&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;The image that you create must be 300 x 250 pixels, or double that if high DPI.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Must be hosted through our standard image uploader (imgur)&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Must be GIF or PNG&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;No animated GIFs&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Absolute limit on file size of 150 KB&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;If the background of the image is white or partially white, there must be a 1px border (2px if high DPI) surrounding it.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;Score Threshold&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;There is a &lt;strong&gt;minimum score threshold&lt;/strong&gt; an answer must meet (currently &lt;strong&gt;6&lt;/strong&gt;) before it will be shown on the main site.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;You can check out the ads that have met the threshold with basic click stats &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/ads/display/2993&quot;&gt;here&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="6115" LastActivityDate="2018-01-30T19:26:27.193" Title="Community Promotion Ads - 2018" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;community-ads&gt;" AnswerCount="2" CommentCount="0" FavoriteCount="1" ClosedDate="2019-02-07T13:27:21.267" />

./Posts.xml:1883:  <row Id="2998" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="2997" CreationDate="2018-03-22T15:47:12.400" Score="2" Body="&lt;p&gt;1) A person with no affiliation to Stack Exchange who published a large number of e-books compiled from Stack Exchange questions and answers. ./Posts.xml:1884:  <row Id="2999" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2018-06-05T16:00:25.233" Score="9" ViewCount="200" Body="&lt;p&gt;Since the last election, the Community Team's noticed that the bulk of the flag handling's been mostly done by a single moderator. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;We have systems in place to remove inactive moderators, but since we always have a minimum of three moderators on the team that removal would be accompanied by an election to have replacements made. As you're probably aware, &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/q/2990/32595&quot;&gt;this community's last election failed due to lack of candidates&lt;/a&gt;. ./Posts.xml:1887:  <row Id="3002" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2018-06-18T20:06:44.320" Score="6" ViewCount="123" Body="&lt;p&gt;After successful evaluation in &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/2999/2018-potential-moderator-election-community-interest-check&quot;&gt;our interest check&lt;/a&gt;, CSTheory has been scheduled for an election &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/election/4&quot;&gt;next week, June 25th&lt;/a&gt;. In connection with that, we will be holding a Q&amp;amp;A with the candidates.  This will be an opportunity for members of the community to pose questions to the candidates on the topic of moderation.  Participation is completely voluntary.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;The purpose of this thread was to collect questions for the questionnaire. The questionnaire is now live, and you may find it &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/3008/2018-moderator-election-qa-questionnaire&quot;&gt;here&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Here's how it'll work:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Until the nomination phase, (so, until Monday, June 25th at 20:00:00Z UTC, or 4:00 pm EDT on the same day, give or take time to arrive for closure), this question will be open to collect potential questions from the users of the site. Post answers to this question containing any questions you would like to ask the candidates. Please only post &lt;em&gt;one question per answer&lt;/em&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;We, the Community Team, will be providing a small selection of generic questions. The first two will be guaranteed to be included, the latter ones are if the community doesn't supply enough questions. This will be done in a single post, unlike the prior instruction.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;If your question contains a link, please use the syntax of &lt;code&gt;[text](link)&lt;/code&gt;, as that will make it easier for transcribing for the finished questionnaire.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;This is a perfect opportunity to voice questions that are specific to your community and issues that you are running into at currently.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;At the start of the nomination phase, the Community Team will select &lt;strong&gt;up to 8 of the top voted questions submitted by the community&lt;/strong&gt; provided in this thread, to use in addition to the aforementioned 2 guaranteed questions. &lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Once questions have been selected, a new question will be opened to host the actual questionnaire for the candidates, typically containing 10 questions in total.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;This is not the only option that users have for gathering information on candidates. As a community, you are still free to, for example, hold a live chat session with your candidates to ask further questions, or perhaps clarifications from what is provided in the Q&amp;amp;A.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If you have any questions or feedback about this process, feel free to post as a comment here.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="6115" LastEditorUserId="6115" LastEditDate="2018-06-25T20:12:31.633" LastActivityDate="2018-06-25T20:12:31.633" Title="2018 Moderator Election Q&amp;A - Question Collection" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;election&gt;" AnswerCount="4" CommentCount="0" FavoriteCount="1" />
