./Posts.xml:1892:  <row Id="3007" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2018-06-25T20:07:36.087" Score="5" ViewCount="112" Body="&lt;p&gt;The 2018 Community Moderator Election is now underway!&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Community moderator elections have three phases:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Nomination phase&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Primary phase&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Election phase&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Most elections take between two and three weeks, but this depends on how many candidates there are.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Please visit the official election page at&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/election&quot;&gt;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/election&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;for more detail, and to participate!&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If you have general questions about the election process, or questions for moderator candidates, feel free to ask them here on meta -- just make sure your questions are tagged &lt;a href=&quot;/questions/tagged/election&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;election&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;election&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="-1" LastActivityDate="2018-06-25T20:07:36.087" Title="2018 Community Moderator Election" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;moderators&gt;&lt;election&gt;" AnswerCount="0" CommentCount="0" FavoriteCount="1" CommunityOwnedDate="2018-06-25T20:07:36.087" />
./Posts.xml:1893:  <row Id="3008" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2018-06-25T20:11:57.787" Score="5" ViewCount="125" Body="&lt;p&gt;In connection with the moderator elections, we are holding a Q&amp;amp;A thread for the candidates. Questions collected &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/3002/2018-moderator-election-qa-question-collection&quot;&gt;from an earlier thread&lt;/a&gt; have been compiled into this one, which shall now serve as the space for the candidates to provide their answers. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Due to the submission count, we have selected all provided questions as well as our back up questions for a total of 8 questions.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;As a candidate, your job is simple - post an answer to this question, citing each of the questions and then post your answer to each question given in that same answer. For your convenience, I will include all of the questions in quote format with a break in between each, suitable for you to insert your answers. Just &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/revisions/f34621cb-9170-40a8-8b6d-e29f9214d87a/view-source&quot;&gt;copy the whole thing after the first set of three dashes&lt;/a&gt;.Please consider putting your name at the top of your post so that readers will know who you are before they finish reading everything you have written, and also including a link to your answer on your nomination post.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Once all the answers have been compiled, this will serve as a transcript for voters to view the thoughts of their candidates, and will be appropriately linked in the Election page.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Good luck to all of the candidates!&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Oh, and when you've completed your answer, please provide a link to it after this blurb here, before that set of three dashes. Please leave the list of links in the order of submission.&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;To save scrolling here are links to the submissions from each candidate (in order of submission):&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;hr&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;ol&gt;&#xA;  &lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Why do you want to be a moderator for the cstheory stackexchange community?&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;  &lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;When a comment is flagged as 'no longer needed', what criteria will you use to determine whether to keep the comment or to delete it? Do you lean towards keeping all comments as a record of what has transpired? Do you learn towards deleting old comments that are no longer making a major contribution? What approach will you take?&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;  &lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;I have a bit the impression that part of the reason why the &quot;inactivity&quot; of the moderators came to the attention of SE was the question &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/38803/is-norbert-blums-2017-proof-that-p-ne-np-correct&quot;&gt;Is Norbert Blum&amp;#39;s 2017 proof that $P \ne NP$ correct?&lt;/a&gt; which attracted some inappropriate content and corresponding flags. Those flags stayed around for a long time before they were handled. But apart from that episode, I never had the impression that cstheory.se would need more active moderators, the community self-moderation felt sufficient. Should moderators stay inactive as long as the self-moderation of the community works well?&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;  &lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;How would you deal with a user who produced a steady stream of valuable answers, but tends to generate a large number of arguments/flags from comments?&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;  &lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;How would you handle a situation where another mod closed/deleted/etc a question that you feel shouldn't have been?&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;  &lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;In your opinion, what do moderators do?&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;  &lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;A diamond will be attached to everything you say and have said in the past, including questions, answers and comments. Everything you will do will be seen under a different light. How do you feel about that?&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;  &lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;In what way do you feel that being a moderator will make you more effective as opposed to simply reaching 10k or 20k rep?&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;  &lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="6115" LastEditorUserId="4352" LastEditDate="2018-07-12T14:28:27.103" LastActivityDate="2018-07-12T14:28:27.103" Title="2018 Moderator Election Q&amp;A - Questionnaire" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;election&gt;" AnswerCount="2" CommentCount="3" FavoriteCount="1" />
./Posts.xml:1894:  <row Id="3009" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="3008" CreationDate="2018-06-25T22:13:56.027" Score="1" Body="&lt;h2&gt;Bjørn Kjos-Hanssen&lt;/h2&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;ol&gt;&#xA;  &lt;li&gt;Why do you want to be a moderator for the cstheory stackexchange community?&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;  &lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I'd like to gain a deeper understanding of (a) theoretical computer science and (b) the StackExchange system of sites. Also it seems like it should be fairly easy to do a reasonable job. I have &lt;a href=&quot;https://mathoverflow.net/users/4600/bj%C3%B8rn-kjos-hanssen&quot;&gt;&gt;15K rep on MathOverflow&lt;/a&gt; so am pretty familiar with SE sites. I like how SE sites make micro-publishing into a kind of game, and I developed a couple of TCS-related games:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://math.hawaii.edu/wordpress/bjoern/software/web/complexity-guessing-game/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;https://i.imgur.com/8lfJTut.png&quot; alt=&quot;Gamify your Q&amp;amp;A&quot;&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&#xA;&lt;a href=&quot;http://math.hawaii.edu/wordpress/bjoern/software/web/complexity-option-game/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;https://i.imgur.com/1YMWwSJ.png&quot; alt=&quot;Gamify your Q&amp;amp;A&quot;&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I have some &lt;a href=&quot;http://math.hawaii.edu/wordpress/bjoern/papers/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;papers&lt;/a&gt; on computability theory and theoretical computer science (automata theory) but looking to learn more.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;ol start=&quot;2&quot;&gt;&#xA;  &lt;li&gt;When a comment is flagged as 'no longer needed', what criteria will you use to determine whether to keep the comment or to delete it? Do you lean towards keeping all comments as a record of what has transpired? Do you learn towards deleting old comments that are no longer making a major contribution? What approach will you take?&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;  &lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;There are some easy cases: if a comment is just pointing out a mistake and that has already been fixed, then the comment is probably no longer needed. Also, if a comment no longer makes sense because related comments have already been deleted, it should make sense to delete. Moreover, if someone goes out of their way and flags a comment like &quot;Thanks!&quot; as no longer needed, I'd tend to go along with that. On the other hand, comments are often substantial and should be kept.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;ol start=&quot;3&quot;&gt;&#xA;  &lt;li&gt;I have a bit the impression that part of the reason why the &quot;inactivity&quot; of the moderators came to the attention of SE was the question &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/38803/is-norbert-blums-2017-proof-that-p-ne-np-correct&quot;&gt;Is Norbert Blum&amp;#39;s 2017 proof that $P \ne NP$ correct?&lt;/a&gt; which attracted some inappropriate content and corresponding flags. Those flags stayed around for a long time before they were handled. But apart from that episode, I never had the impression that cstheory.se would need more active moderators, the community self-moderation felt sufficient. Should moderators stay inactive as long as the self-moderation of the community works well?&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;  &lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Actually, I hope so, as I have only so much time to spend! :)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In any case, SE has an official document about this -- &lt;a href=&quot;https://stackoverflow.blog/2009/05/18/a-theory-of-moderation/&quot;&gt;A Theory of Moderation&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;ol start=&quot;4&quot;&gt;&#xA;  &lt;li&gt;How would you deal with a user who produced a steady stream of valuable answers, but tends to generate a large number of arguments/flags from comments?&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;  &lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The user should receive some friendly hints that they are being problematic. If that doesn't help I would discuss with other moderators and then there is the possibility of a temporary suspension.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;ol start=&quot;5&quot;&gt;&#xA;  &lt;li&gt;How would you handle a situation where another mod closed/deleted/etc a question that you feel shouldn't have been?&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;  &lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;f it seemed very unreasonable to me I would probably discuss it with the other moderator; if only borderline I'd just let it go.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;ol start=&quot;6&quot;&gt;&#xA;  &lt;li&gt;In your opinion, what do moderators do?&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;  &lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Deal with flags (by the way I have a &lt;a href=&quot;https://mathoverflow.net/users/flag-summary/4600&quot;&gt;100% helpful flag record on MathOverflow&lt;/a&gt;) and some other things discussed in &lt;a href=&quot;https://stackoverflow.blog/2009/05/18/a-theory-of-moderation/&quot;&gt;A Theory of Moderation&lt;/a&gt;. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;ol start=&quot;7&quot;&gt;&#xA;  &lt;li&gt;A diamond will be attached to everything you say and have said in the past, including questions, answers and comments. Everything you will do will be seen under a different light. How do you feel about that?&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;  &lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;That seems okay, what I write here tends to be very neutral and polite, as I am aware that each comment is a nano-publication of sorts.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;ol start=&quot;8&quot;&gt;&#xA;  &lt;li&gt;In what way do you feel that being a moderator will make you more effective as opposed to simply reaching 10k or 20k rep?&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;  &lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I don't feel that it would &quot;make me more effective&quot; but it could be an interesting way to contribute to the site and stay involved.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="1993" LastActivityDate="2018-06-25T22:13:56.027" CommentCount="3" />
./Posts.xml:1895:  <row Id="3010" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="3008" CreationDate="2018-06-26T04:47:33.963" Score="4" Body="&lt;h2&gt;Michael Wehar&lt;/h2&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;ol&gt;&#xA;  &lt;li&gt;Why do you want to be a moderator for the cstheory stackexchange community?&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;  &lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I want to be a moderator because I care about the community and I believe it's a great honor to take on this role.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I check the cstheory stackexchange platform daily and I suspect that a lot of our members want to continue having the same great experience that they've always had on this platform.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;It will be my duty as moderator to ensure that issues are efficiently resolved and that the community members are satisfied with their experience.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I will gladly connect with and assist any community members who need help.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;ol start=&quot;2&quot;&gt;&#xA;  &lt;li&gt;When a comment is flagged as 'no longer needed', what criteria will you use to determine whether to keep the comment or to delete it? Do you lean towards keeping all comments as a record of what has transpired? Do you learn towards deleting old comments that are no longer making a major contribution? What approach will you take?&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;  &lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I believe that an author is entitled to choose for themselves whether to keep or delete their comments as long as they are relevant and respectful.  As a result, I will only delete comments in extreme situations.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;ol start=&quot;3&quot;&gt;&#xA;  &lt;li&gt;I have a bit the impression that part of the reason why the &quot;inactivity&quot; of the moderators came to the attention of SE was the question &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/38803/is-norbert-blums-2017-proof-that-p-ne-np-correct&quot;&gt;Is Norbert Blum&amp;#39;s 2017 proof that $P \ne NP$ correct?&lt;/a&gt; which attracted some inappropriate content and corresponding flags. Those flags stayed around for a long time before they were handled. But apart from that episode, I never had the impression that cstheory.se would need more active moderators, the community self-moderation felt sufficient. Should moderators stay inactive as long as the self-moderation of the community works well?&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;  &lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I feel that moderators should never be inactive.  They should always be active members who contribute to the community and regularly read recent questions.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;That being said, I also feel that moderators should only use their special privileges when it's necessary.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;ol start=&quot;4&quot;&gt;&#xA;  &lt;li&gt;How would you deal with a user who produced a steady stream of valuable answers, but tends to generate a large number of arguments/flags from comments?&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;  &lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I would first identify whether (1) the comments are inappropriate, (2) the flags are inappropriate, or (3) users are being inappropriate towards each other.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;When something looks clearly inappropriate, I would honestly explain why the comment or flag was inappropriate either directly or via comments.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;ol start=&quot;5&quot;&gt;&#xA;  &lt;li&gt;How would you handle a situation where another mod closed/deleted/etc a question that you feel shouldn't have been?&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;  &lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Depending on the situation, I would either:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;(1) Leave it closed and trust the other moderator's judgement&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;(2) Reopen it and include a note for why it was reopened&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;(3) Contact the other moderator directly to resolve the issue&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;ol start=&quot;6&quot;&gt;&#xA;  &lt;li&gt;In your opinion, what do moderators do?&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;  &lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I think that moderators should do the following:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;(1) Flag, Tag, Edit, Review, Resolve Issues&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;(2) When necessary, get involved with community engagement promoting positive behavior on the platform.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;ol start=&quot;7&quot;&gt;&#xA;  &lt;li&gt;A diamond will be attached to everything you say and have said in the past, including questions, answers and comments. Everything you will do will be seen under a different light. How do you feel about that?&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;  &lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Having the diamond next to my name means that I should act in a way that promotes positive behavior on the platform.  Really, regardless of whether or not I have a diamond next to my name, I should act in a way that promotes positive behavior on the platform.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;ol start=&quot;8&quot;&gt;&#xA;  &lt;li&gt;In what way do you feel that being a moderator will make you more effective as opposed to simply reaching 10k or 20k rep?&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;  &lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I don't ask the most questions or post the most answers.  But, I read through questions and answers on a daily basis and I regularly comment.  My presence and comments support the mission and goals of our community.  I believe that the moderator position is primarily about supporting the community.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="14207" LastActivityDate="2018-06-26T04:47:33.963" CommentCount="0" />
./Posts.xml:1897:  <row Id="3012" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="3011" CreationDate="2018-07-12T07:08:52.130" Score="2" Body="&lt;p&gt;How about some of these:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/cc.complexity-theory&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;cc.complexity-theory&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;cc.complexity-theory&lt;/a&gt;, &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/ds.algorithms&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;automata-theory&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;automata-theory&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Depending on your math background perhaps also &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/graph-theory&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;graph-theory&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;graph-theory&lt;/a&gt;, &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/co.combinatorics&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;cc.complexity-theory&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;cc.complexity-theory&lt;/a&gt; gets about 1 question a day,&#xA;compared to large sites like Math.StackExchange and Stack Overflow there is less of a need to follow only particular tags.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;The level of questions may be somewhat high as the site is &lt;a href=&quot;https://stackexchange.com/sites#science-traffic&quot;&gt;for theoretical computer scientists and researchers in related fields&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="1993" LastActivityDate="2018-07-12T07:08:52.130" CommentCount="1" />

./Posts.xml:1899:  <row Id="3014" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAnswerId="3017" CreationDate="2018-08-23T06:01:08.307" Score="5" ViewCount="69" Body="&lt;p&gt;MathOverflow and &lt;a href=&quot;https://math.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/22008/lets-get-mathoverflows-citation-helper-here-too&quot;&gt;Math.SE&lt;/a&gt; have a &lt;a href=&quot;http://meta.mathoverflow.net/questions/2583/new-feature-citation-helper&quot;&gt;citation helper&lt;/a&gt; that adds a new button to the post editor to allow references to journal articles (and conference papers?) to be added to posts quicker and easier.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://i.stack.imgur.com/IsI92.png&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;https://i.stack.imgur.com/IsI92.png&quot; alt=&quot;enter image description here&quot;&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Of course we need this, too.  Who agrees with me?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="1993" LastEditorUserId="237" LastEditDate="2018-10-05T14:56:59.670" LastActivityDate="2018-10-05T14:56:59.670" Title="Let's get MathOverflow's “Citation Helper” here, as well!" ./Posts.xml:1900:  <row Id="3015" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="2947" CreationDate="2018-08-23T12:06:32.053" Score="7" Body="&lt;h2&gt;Both &lt;em&gt;interesting&lt;/em&gt; and &lt;em&gt;overall&lt;/em&gt; activity on cstheory are decreasing!&lt;/h2&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Let's measure &quot;interesting&quot; activity by the rate of posts that receive significant upvotes.  By this measure, Figure 1 below suggests that both interesting activity and overall activity are trending downward:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://i.stack.imgur.com/f7vVP.png&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;https://i.stack.imgur.com/f7vVP.png&quot; alt=&quot;enter image description here&quot;&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;Figure 1. Above are plots (over time, in 60-day blocks), of (a) number of questions, (b) number of answers, (c) # upvotes / 20, (d) number of questions and answers that received at least five (or at least ten, for (e)) upvotes within 30 days of creation, on cstheory.stackexchange.com.  &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;All trend downward. (The query that generated the data is &lt;a href=&quot;http://data.stackexchange.com/cstheory/query/889763/activity-over-time?points=46&amp;amp;period=60&amp;amp;upvoteWindow=30#graph&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;here&lt;/a&gt;.) &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;hr&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h2&gt;The same plots on other stackexchange sites, for comparison&lt;/h2&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;cs.stackexchange.com&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://i.stack.imgur.com/QFXBV.png&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;https://i.stack.imgur.com/QFXBV.png&quot; alt=&quot;enter image description here&quot;&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;crypto.stackexchange.com&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://i.stack.imgur.com/kGCDd.png&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;https://i.stack.imgur.com/kGCDd.png&quot; alt=&quot;enter image description here&quot;&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;math.stackexchange.com&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://i.stack.imgur.com/hCX8j.png&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;https://i.stack.imgur.com/hCX8j.png&quot; alt=&quot;enter image description here&quot;&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;tex.stackexchange.com&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h2&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://i.stack.imgur.com/DZLQ3.png&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;https://i.stack.imgur.com/DZLQ3.png&quot; alt=&quot;enter image description here&quot;&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/h2&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="8237" LastEditorUserId="8237" LastEditDate="2018-08-23T21:28:02.507" LastActivityDate="2018-08-23T21:28:02.507" CommentCount="0" CommunityOwnedDate="2018-08-23T12:06:32.053" />
./Posts.xml:1901:  <row Id="3016" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2018-08-29T08:22:22.687" Score="9" ViewCount="50" Body="&lt;p&gt;The colour scheme for buttons on the main site seems to have changed recently:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://i.stack.imgur.com/AY53t.png&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;https://i.stack.imgur.com/AY53t.png&quot; alt=&quot;enter image description here&quot;&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;It makes them nearly unreadable, and they have a disabled look.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="6959" LastEditorUserId="6959" LastEditDate="2018-08-29T08:40:55.187" LastActivityDate="2018-08-29T08:40:55.187" Title="Broken button design" Tags="&lt;bug&gt;&lt;design&gt;" AnswerCount="0" CommentCount="1" />
./Posts.xml:1903:  <row Id="3018" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="3014" CreationDate="2018-09-24T17:32:06.310" Score="2" Body="&lt;p&gt;Some posts where this would be helpful:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;First some of my own answers; in some cases I used the citation helper on MathOverflow and pasted it into CSTheory, but that's a bit inconvenient.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/a/41555/1993&quot;&gt;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/a/41555/1993&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/a/41479/1993&quot;&gt;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/a/41479/1993&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/a/41425/1993&quot;&gt;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/a/41425/1993&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/a/40111/1993&quot;&gt;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/a/40111/1993&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/a/39947/1993&quot;&gt;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/a/39947/1993&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Next, the highest voted questions on CSTheory are often asking for references or sources for results:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/a/1550/1993&quot;&gt;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/a/1550/1993&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/q/1168/1993&quot;&gt;What papers should everyone read?&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/q/3253/1993&quot;&gt;What Books Should Everyone Read?&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/a/18866/1993&quot;&gt;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/a/18866/1993&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="1993" LastActivityDate="2018-09-24T17:32:06.310" CommentCount="0" />
./Posts.xml:1904:  <row Id="3019" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2018-10-01T20:41:12.617" Score="5" ViewCount="26" Body="&lt;p&gt;Sometimes a question gets asked, someone takes the time to respond, but the answer never receives any votes. Sometimes those answers can be quite good, and it would be nice to reward those answers with upvotes.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Would you like to help vote on these answers to older questions? If so, I can suggest a way. Run the following query:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://data.stackexchange.com/cstheory/query/889195/search-for-question-with-positive-score-where-all-answers-have-zero-score&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;https://data.stackexchange.com/cstheory/query/889195/search-for-question-with-positive-score-where-all-answers-have-zero-score&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Then click on some of the links in the results (you can sort by question score first if you want), and take a look to see if the answers are good. This looks for questions where the question score is &gt; 0, where there is at least one answer, and where all answers have a score of 0 (which usually means the answer was never voted on; sometimes for good reason, but sometimes because a nice answer was overlooked).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Thanks to &lt;a href=&quot;https://cs.meta.stackexchange.com/q/1512/37257&quot;&gt;@D.W.&lt;/a&gt; for this idea.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="1993" LastActivityDate="2018-10-01T20:41:12.617" Title="Help vote on answers to good questions" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;voting&gt;&lt;answers&gt;&lt;data-explorer&gt;" AnswerCount="0" CommentCount="0" />
./Posts.xml:1906:  <row Id="3021" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="3020" CreationDate="2018-10-11T06:49:49.023" Score="4" Body="&lt;p&gt;Having such questions might have some value, but also some downsides. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;It might attract somewhat low-quality answers by people who think they can solve the problem (now that might be a good thing or a bad thing depending what you want the site to be about).&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;StackExchange, and Stack Overflow as the model site in particular, encourages questions that have a good chance of being answered.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;This has been discussed before, for instance at:&#xA;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/q/1058/1993&quot;&gt;tag wiki: [open-problem]&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="1993" LastActivityDate="2018-10-11T06:49:49.023" CommentCount="0" />

./Posts.xml:1909:  <row Id="3024" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="3020" CreationDate="2018-10-19T07:01:55.587" Score="4" Body="&lt;p&gt;The purpose of this stack exchange, like every other stack exchange, is not to list questions. &lt;strong&gt;It’s to list answers&lt;/strong&gt;. Obviously people ask questions that don’t get answered all the time, but an explicit goal is to have as high of a percentage of answered questions as possible.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;There are &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/p-vs-np&quot;&gt;a number of questions related to P vs NP&lt;/a&gt; that have been asked in the past, and many of them have been answered and many more have generated fruitful discussion and partial answers. So, there are productive and on-topic questions that can be asked about the problem. However, “does P equal NP?” with no further context, ideas, or thoughts is not one of them.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="22045" LastActivityDate="2018-10-19T07:01:55.587" CommentCount="0" />
./Posts.xml:1910:  <row Id="3025" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2018-11-21T19:15:40.293" Score="6" ViewCount="113" Body="&lt;p&gt;As part of implementing the new unified themes across the network, we're gradually rolling out updated site themes for each site. As of today, we have enabled your updated site theme for testing. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If you can't see it right now, that's by design! This is a very early test implementation of your design and we need your help finding issues with it before we make it live for everyone permanently. So, keep in mind, there will be things that need fixing! We'll address those things as we can.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If you'd like to review it, here's how:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h2&gt;How do I enable it?&lt;/h2&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/users/preferences&quot;&gt;Click here&lt;/a&gt; and check the &quot;Beta test new themes&quot; option. This will turn on the new theme for all sites that have one in testing, including this one. &lt;em&gt;Here's &lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/314542/opt-in-to-beta-testing-new-themes&quot;&gt;more info&lt;/a&gt; on how to opt in.&lt;/em&gt; You can uncheck the box to revert to the older theme until the site is live for everyone. &lt;strong&gt;Note, while turning it on is immediate, it will take a few minutes to revert to the old view - &lt;em&gt;but it will go through!&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h2&gt;What type of feedback do we need?&lt;/h2&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;On this post: Bugs related to this site's design elements&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Please help us look for issues/bugs related to the theme design and how we have mapped the old theme to the new. This needs to be done within the &lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/307862/ch-ch-ch-changes-left-nav-responsive-design-themes&quot;&gt;limits of the new unified theme&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;This could include colors of sections of the design or text, problems with JavaScript add-ons (if applicable), the logo or top banner appearance or other artwork.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;You can also feel free to ask questions about the new layout if you're unsure how to navigate it.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;On Meta Stack Exchange: General concerns about left nav or theming&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;There are some things that are definitely changing everywhere and can't really be adjusted on a per-site basis. A few of them include:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Top banner is shorter in height, so some artwork has to be adjusted along with some logos.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Left Navigation is active everywhere (but can be collapsed into a menu by visiting your site preferences - &lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.stackexchange.com/a/311237/284336&quot;&gt;instructions here&lt;/a&gt;).&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Responsive layout is active, which lets the site adjust as browser widths change - no side scrolling (some pages haven't been updated, yet, though). For now, if you prefer the scrolling, you can disable this by clicking the &quot;disable responsiveness&quot; link in the footer.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Many site elements including tags and voting arrows are standardized across the network.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Link underlining is active. In an effort to make links more visible, they are now being underlined.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If you have concerns or issues regarding the left nav or the overall approach we are taking to theming, then &lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/310908/live-left-nav-new-theming-and-responsiveness&quot;&gt;this Meta Stack Exchange post&lt;/a&gt; is the right place for feedback. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;As I mentioned earlier, there are some unique design elements like voting arrows and tags that are being standardized in this process. Keeping these custom elements makes our ability to maintain the sites too complex and, while we're very sad to see them go, we're in a difficult position of needing to make the site designs work together so that we can continue to address feature requests and bugs that will make your Q&amp;amp;A experience better. This is addressed in a &lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/314799/why-we-initiated-the-latest-round-of-design-changes-and-the-role-of-meta&quot;&gt;Meta Stack Exchange post&lt;/a&gt; if you want more detail.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h2&gt;What new themes?&lt;/h2&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If you're like, &quot;What the heck are you talking about?&quot;, then you should read the Meta Stack Exchange post entitled &lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/312365/rollout-of-new-network-site-themes&quot;&gt;Rollout of new network site themes&lt;/a&gt; (and maybe the posts it links to for the full background). To follow along with the rollout of these new themes, go &lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/314979/rollout-of-responsive-design-site-themes-tracking-post&quot;&gt;here&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h2&gt;Thanks so much for your constructive feedback!&lt;/h2&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;Oh, Who am I?&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If you don't know me, I'm one of the &lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/99338/who-are-the-community-team-and-what-do-they-do?s=1%7C141.4591&quot;&gt;Community Managers&lt;/a&gt; here at Stack Exchange. I'm here to listen to your input and convey it to our Design team for responses and fixes to bugs. I'll do my best to respond to your concerns and explain whether changes we've made are bugs that can be changed or if they're by design and why.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="16884" LastActivityDate="2018-11-21T19:15:40.293" Title="Theoretical Computer Science updated site theme is ready for testing!" ./Posts.xml:1913:  <row Id="3028" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="3027" CreationDate="2018-12-07T18:30:36.537" Score="3" Body="&lt;p&gt;In principle, questions about what's going on in a small subfield fit into the &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/reference-request&quot; class=&quot;post-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;reference-request&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;reference-request&lt;/a&gt; tag and can be on-topic. (&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/1630/what-is-the-reference-request-tag&quot;&gt;More&lt;/a&gt; about this tag.)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;A couple of potential pitfalls are:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Is it something it would make sense to ask your doctoral adviser instead? I think we do want to encourage students to communicate well with their advisers.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Is the area narrow enough? For instance,&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;What's new important work in complexity theory&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;might be considered &lt;a href=&quot;https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/199773/a-question-being-closed-as-primarily-opinion-based&quot;&gt;primarily opinion-based&lt;/a&gt;, but&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;Are there any recent papers (last five years) on 1-counter automata&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;is more fact-based. In that case, however, there's the question&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Is your question easily answerable using a Google search?&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;So to summarize, a good question of this kind should be fact-based, answerable, but not easily answerable by a Google search or by your doctoral adviser.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="1993" LastEditorUserId="1993" LastEditDate="2018-12-07T19:48:52.060" LastActivityDate="2018-12-07T19:48:52.060" CommentCount="0" />
./Posts.xml:1914:  <row Id="3032" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2019-01-01T02:50:40.387" Score="3" ViewCount="29" Body="&lt;p&gt;It's New Year's Day in &lt;a href=&quot;https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zulu_Time&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;Stack Exchange land&lt;/a&gt;...&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;A distinguishing characteristic of these sites is how they are moderated:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;We designed the Stack Exchange network engine to be mostly self-regulating, in that we amortize the overall moderation cost of the system across thousands of teeny-tiny slices of effort contributed by regular, everyday users.&lt;br&gt;&#xA;  -- &lt;a href=&quot;http://blog.stackoverflow.com/2009/05/a-theory-of-moderation/&quot;&gt;A Theory of Moderation&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;While there certainly are &lt;a href=&quot;https://stackoverflow.blog/2018/11/21/our-theory-of-moderation-re-visited/&quot;&gt;Moderators&lt;/a&gt; here, a significant amount of the &lt;em&gt;moderation&lt;/em&gt; is done by ordinary people, using the privileges &#xA;they've earned by virtue of their contributions to the site. Each of you contributes a little bit of time and effort, and together you accomplish much.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;As we enter a new year, let's pause and reflect, taking a moment to appreciate the work that we do here together. &#xA;To that end, here is how the moderation done here on Theoretical Computer Science breaks down by activity over the past 12 months:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;pre&gt;&lt;code&gt;                 Action                  Moderators Community¹&#xA;---------------------------------------- ---------- ----------&#xA;Users suspended²                                  1         10&#xA;Users destroyed                                   3          0&#xA;Users contacted                                   3          0&#xA;Tasks reviewed³: Suggested Edit queue             5        240&#xA;Tasks reviewed³: Reopen Vote queue                0         25&#xA;Tasks reviewed³: Low Quality Posts queue          0         95&#xA;Tasks reviewed³: Late Answer queue                0         67&#xA;Tasks reviewed³: First Post queue                 0        783&#xA;Tasks reviewed³: Close Votes queue                1        927&#xA;Questions reopened                                7          0&#xA;Questions protected                               1          1&#xA;Questions migrated                               19          0&#xA;Questions merged                                  1          0&#xA;Questions flagged⁴                                0        344&#xA;Questions closed                                 64        239&#xA;Question flags handled⁴                          86        258&#xA;Posts unlocked                                    1          2&#xA;Posts undeleted                                   2        140&#xA;Posts locked                                      1         23&#xA;Posts deleted⁵                                   40        879&#xA;Posts bumped                                      0        111&#xA;Comments undeleted                                1          0&#xA;Comments flagged                                  0        406&#xA;Comments deleted⁶                               262        927&#xA;Comment flags handled                           169        237&#xA;Answers flagged                                   0         97&#xA;Answer flags handled                             69         28&#xA;All comments on a post moved to chat              3          0&#xA;&lt;/code&gt;&lt;/pre&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;Footnotes&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;¹ &quot;Community&quot; here refers both to &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/users&quot;&gt;the membership of Theoretical Computer Science&lt;/a&gt; &lt;em&gt;without&lt;/em&gt; &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/users?tab=moderators&quot;&gt;diamonds next to their names&lt;/a&gt;, and to the automated systems otherwise known as &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/users/-1&quot;&gt;user #-1&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;² The system will suspend users under three circumstances: when a user is recreated after being previously suspended, when a user is recreated after being destroyed for spam or abuse, and when a network-wide suspension is in effect on an account.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;³ This counts every review that was submitted (not skipped) - so the 3 suggested edits reviews needed to approve an edit would count as 3, the goal being to indicate the frequency of moderation actions. This also applies to flags, etc.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;⁴ Includes close flags (but &lt;em&gt;not&lt;/em&gt; close or reopen votes).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;⁵ This ignores numerous deletions that happen automatically in response to some other action.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;⁶ This includes comments deleted by their own authors (which also account for some number of handled comment flags).   &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Wishing you all a happy new year...&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="4352" LastActivityDate="2019-01-01T02:50:40.387" Title="2018: a year in moderation" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;moderation&gt;&lt;statistics&gt;" AnswerCount="0" CommentCount="2" />
./Posts.xml:1915:  <row Id="3033" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2019-01-23T11:46:50.047" Score="1" ViewCount="38" Body="&lt;p&gt;2019 is here! And with the new year, as usual, comes a new iteration of &lt;strong&gt;Community Promotion Ads&lt;/strong&gt;! Let’s refresh these for the coming year :)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;What are Community Promotion Ads?&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Community Promotion Ads are community-vetted advertisements that will show up on the main site, in the right sidebar. The purpose of this question is the vetting process. Images of the advertisements are provided, and community voting will enable the advertisements to be shown.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;Why do we have Community Promotion Ads?&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;This is a method for the community to control what gets promoted to visitors on the site. For example, you might promote the following things:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;the site's twitter account&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;cool events or conferences&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;anything else your community would genuinely be interested in&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The goal is for future visitors to find out about &lt;em&gt;the stuff your community deems important&lt;/em&gt;. This also serves as a way to promote information and resources that are &lt;em&gt;relevant to your own community's interests&lt;/em&gt;, both for those already in the community and those yet to join. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;Why do we reset the ads every year?&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Some services will maintain usefulness over the years, while other things will wane to allow for new faces to show up. Resetting the ads every year helps accommodate this, and allows old ads that have served their purpose to be cycled out for fresher ads for newer things. This helps keep the material in the ads relevant to not just the subject matter of the community, but to the current status of the community. We reset the ads once a year, every December.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The community promotion ads have no restrictions against reposting an ad from a previous cycle. If a particular service or ad is very valuable to the community and will continue to be so, it is a good idea to repost it. It may be helpful to give it a new face in the process, so as to prevent the imagery of the ad from getting stale after a year of exposure.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;How does it work?&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The answers you post to this question &lt;em&gt;must&lt;/em&gt; conform to the following rules, or they will be ignored. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;All answers should be in the exact form of:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;pre&gt;&lt;code&gt;[![Tagline to show on mouseover][1]][2]&#xA;&#xA;   [1]: http://image-url&#xA;   [2]: http://clickthrough-url &#xA;&lt;/code&gt;&lt;/pre&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Please &lt;strong&gt;do not add anything else to the body of the post&lt;/strong&gt;. If you want to discuss something, do it in the comments.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;The question must always be tagged with the magic &lt;a href=&quot;/questions/tagged/community-ads&quot; class=&quot;post-tag moderator-tag&quot; title=&quot;show questions tagged &amp;#39;community-ads&amp;#39;&quot; rel=&quot;tag&quot;&gt;community-ads&lt;/a&gt; tag. In addition to enabling the functionality of the advertisements, this tag also pre-fills the answer form with the above required form.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;Image requirements&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;The image that you create must be 300 x 250 pixels, or double that if high DPI.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Must be hosted through our standard image uploader (imgur)&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Must be GIF or PNG&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;No animated GIFs&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Absolute limit on file size of 150 KB&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;If the background of the image is white or partially white, there must be a 1px border (2px if high DPI) surrounding it.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;Score Threshold&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;There is a &lt;strong&gt;minimum score threshold&lt;/strong&gt; an answer must meet (currently &lt;strong&gt;6&lt;/strong&gt;) before it will be shown on the main site.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;You can check out the ads that have met the threshold with basic click stats &lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.meta.stackexchange.com/ads/display/3033&quot;&gt;here&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="32595" LastActivityDate="2019-07-12T00:02:35.337" Title="Community Promotion Ads — 2019" Tags="&lt;discussion&gt;&lt;community-ads&gt;" AnswerCount="1" CommentCount="0" />
./Posts.xml:1916:  <row Id="3034" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="3033" CreationDate="2019-01-23T11:47:13.630" Score="0" Body="&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://twitter.com/StackCSTheory&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;https://i.stack.imgur.com/23gVn.png&quot; alt=&quot;Tagline to show on mouseover&quot;&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" OwnerUserId="32595" LastActivityDate="2019-01-23T11:47:13.630" CommentCount="1" />

./Posts.xml:1922:  <row Id="3043" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2019-06-10T11:42:39.497" Score="1" ViewCount="29" Body="&lt;p&gt;I wrote a comment on this question and after a while it has been removed.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/questions/44005/on-planar-4-regular-graphs&quot;&gt;On planar $4$ regular graphs&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;There is a 1% chance of accidental deletion of that comment  by me. ./Users.xml:1407:  <row Id="6398" Reputation="123" CreationDate="2011-09-01T08:16:53.000" DisplayName="steffen" LastAccessDate="2011-09-01T08:43:16.363" WebsiteUrl="https://twitter.com/MLWiDA" AboutMe="&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Welcome, wanderer !&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I work as a &quot;Data Scientist&quot; (do not really like that job title). Here is my list of recommended readings (is not complete and never will be).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Book recommendations for starters&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;em&gt;Introduction to Machine Learning&lt;/em&gt; by Ethem Alpaydin: To learn the theory.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;em&gt;Python Data Science Handbook&lt;/em&gt; by Jake VanderPlas: To get your hands dirty with Data Science in practice (or as in my case, to make a smooth switch from R to Python)&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;em&gt;Head First Data Analysis&lt;/em&gt; by Michael Milton: The first book I have seen which grasps what I'd like to call the &quot;Data Scientist's mindset&quot;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;em&gt;Cartoon Guide to Statistics&lt;/em&gt; by Larry Gonick and Woollcott Smith: You need some statistics knowledge when working with data, so why don't you start the journey with something funny and lightweight ?&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;General book recommendations&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;em&gt;Thinking, Fast and Slow&lt;/em&gt; by Daniel Kahneman: A lifetime of research how people think and make decisions. &lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;em&gt;The Most Human Human&lt;/em&gt; by Brian Christian: An explorative journey how to be perceived as human as possible during a Turing test.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Sidenotes&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;If you do not know the gender of the contributor, consider to use &lt;a href=&quot;https://english.stackexchange.com/questions/48/is-there-a-correct-gender-neutral-singular-pronoun-his-vs-her-vs-their&quot;&gt;singular they&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;The avatar displays a &quot;Bizzaromant&quot;, a drawing by Felix Mertikat. It's so big!&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;I'm on Linux. Space is cheap – your time is not. = &lt;a href=&quot;https://oeis.org/A191898&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;https://oeis.org/A191898&lt;/a&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;math-container&quot;&gt;$(n,k)$&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;math-container&quot;&gt;$$\boxed{\Lambda(n)=\lim\limits_{s \rightarrow 1} \zeta(s)\sum\limits_{d|n} \frac{\mu(d)}{d^{(s-1)}}}$$&lt;/span&gt;&#xA;&lt;span class=&quot;math-container&quot;&gt;$$\sum\limits_{k=1}^{\infty}\sum\limits_{n=1}^{\infty} \frac{T(n,k)}{n^c \cdot k^s} = \sum\limits_{n=1}^{\infty} \frac{\lim\limits_{z \rightarrow s} \zeta(z)\sum\limits_{d|n} \frac{\mu(d)}{d^{(z-1)}}}{n^c} = \frac{\zeta(s) \cdot \zeta(c)}{\zeta(c + s - 1)}$$&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;math-container&quot;&gt;$$1/a^{b+i c}=1/a^b (\cos (c \log (1/a))+i \sin (c \log (1/a)))$$&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;pre&gt;&lt;code&gt;1/a^(b + I*c) = 1/a^b*(Cos[c*Log[1/a]] + I*Sin[c*Log[1/a]])&#xA;&lt;/code&gt;&lt;/pre&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;14,134725141734693790457251983562... = ?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://oeis.org/A058303&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow noreferrer&quot;&gt;https://oeis.org/A058303&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;pre&gt;&lt;code&gt;s = ZetaZero[1];&#xA;Limit[Zeta[s*c]/Zeta[c + s - 1], c -&amp;gt; 1]&#xA;Limit[Zeta[s*c]/Zeta[c + s*c - 1], c -&amp;gt; 1]&#xA;Limit[(Zeta[s]*Zeta[c]/Zeta[c + s - 1] - Zeta[c]), c -&amp;gt; 1]&#xA;&#xA;N[Table[2*Pi*Exp[1]*Exp[ProductLog[(n - 11/8)/Exp[1]]], {n, 1, 12}]]&#xA;&#xA;Plot[RiemannSiegelTheta[t]/Pi + &#xA;  Im[Log[Zeta[1/2 + I*t]] + I*Pi]/Pi, {t, 0, 60}, ImageSize -&amp;gt; Large]&#xA;&#xA;Table[Limit[&#xA;  Zeta[s] Total[1/Divisors[n]^(s - 1)*MoebiusMu[Divisors[n]]], &#xA;  s -&amp;gt; 1], {n, 1, 32}]&#xA;&lt;/code&gt;&lt;/pre&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://oeis.org/A177885&quot;   I], {n, 1, 12}]&#xA;&#xA;Plot[Im[LogGamma[1/4 + I*t/2]/Pi - I*t/(2*Pi)*Log[Pi] + &#xA;   Log[Zeta[1/2 + I*t]]/Pi + I], {t, 0, 60}, ImageSize -&amp;gt; Large]&#xA;&lt;/code&gt;&lt;/pre&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;From this answer:&#xA;&lt;a href=&quot;http://math.stackexchange.com/a/442686/8530&quot;&gt;http://math.stackexchange.com/a/442686/8530&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;by Raymond Manzoni.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;=IF(OR(ROW()=1; COLUMN()=1);0; IF(ROW()&gt;=COLUMN();EXP(-(1-11/8/(COLUMN()-1))/EXP(1)*SUM(INDIRECT(ADDRESS(ROW()-COLUMN()+1; COLUMN(); 4)&amp;amp;&quot;:&quot;&amp;amp;ADDRESS(ROW()-1; COLUMN(); 4); 4)));0))&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;divided with: /2/PI()/EXP(1) gives reciprocal.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;von Mangoldt function matrix:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;=IF(OR(ROW()=1, COLUMN()=1), 1, IF(ROW()&gt;=COLUMN(),-SUM(INDIRECT(ADDRESS(ROW()-COLUMN()+1,COLUMN(), 4)&amp;amp;&quot;:&quot;&amp;amp;ADDRESS(ROW()-1, COLUMN(), 4), 4)),-SUM(INDIRECT(ADDRESS(COLUMN()-ROW()+1,ROW(), 4)&amp;amp;&quot;:&quot;&amp;amp;ADDRESS(COLUMN()-1, ROW(), 4), 4))))&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://pastebin.com/u/MatsGranvik&quot; 4)&amp;amp;&quot;:&quot;&amp;amp;ADDRESS(ROW()-1; COLUMN()-1; 4); 4))-SUM(INDIRECT(ADDRESS(ROW()-COLUMN()+1;COLUMN(); 4)&amp;amp;&quot;:&quot;&amp;amp;ADDRESS(ROW()-1; COLUMN(); 4); 4));0))&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;pre&gt;&lt;code&gt;Clear[nn];&#xA;&#xA;nn = 12&#xA;&#xA;f[n_, s_] = ((s + 1)^(n - 1) + s - 1)/s;&#xA;&#xA;TableForm[&#xA; ./Users.xml:3048:  <row Id="42413" Reputation="101" CreationDate="2016-09-05T15:46:29.000" DisplayName="John Doe" LastAccessDate="2016-09-15T13:23:20.797" AboutMe="&lt;p&gt;I'd just like to interject for a moment. What you're referring to as calculus, is in fact, real analysis, or as I've recently taken to calling it, &lt;span class=&quot;math-container&quot;&gt;$\left( \mathbf R,\, +,\, \times,\, \leqslant,\, \left| \cdot \right|,\, \tau \,=\, \left\{ A \,\subset\, \mathbf R \mid \forall x\,\in\, A,\, \exists \varepsilon \,&amp;gt;\, 0,\, \left] x \,-\, \varepsilon,\, x \,+\, \varepsilon\right[ \,\subset\, A \right\},\, \bigcap_{\begin{array}{c} A \,\sigma \text{-algebra of}\, \mathbf R \\ \tau \,\subset\, A \end{array}} A,\, \ell \right)$&lt;/span&gt;-analysis. Calculus is not a branch of mathematics unto itself, but rather another application of a fully functioning analysis made useful by topology, measure theory and vital &lt;span class=&quot;math-container&quot;&gt;$\mathbf R$&lt;/span&gt;-related properties comprising a full number field as defined by pure mathematics.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Many mathematics students and professors use applications of real analysis every day, without realizing it. Through a peculiar turn of events, the application of real analysis which is widely used today is often called &quot;Calculus&quot;, and many of its users are not aware that it is merely a part of real analysis, developed by the Nicolas Bourbaki group.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;There really is a calculus, and these people are using it, but it is just a part of the field they use. Calculus is the computation process: the set of rules and formulae that allow the mathematical mind to derive numerical formulae from other numerical formulae. The computation process is an essential part of a branch of mathematics, but useless by itself; it can only function in the context of a complete number field. Calculus is normally used in combination with the real number field, its topology and its measured space: the whole system is basically real numbers with analytical methods and properties added, or real analysis. All the so-called calculus problems are really problems of real analysis.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;" Views="0" UpVotes="0" DownVotes="0" ProfileImageUrl="https://i.stack.imgur.com/aCQyz.png?s=128&amp;g=1" AccountId="8489214" />
